webTitle: Straw's brother guilty of sex assault

fields.headline: Straw's brother guilty of sex assault
fields.trailText: The brother of the home secretary, Jack Straw, was yesterday found guilty of indecently assaulting a teenage girl in her own home. William Straw, 47, was fined £750 plus £275 costs and was ordered to remain on the sex offenders' register for five years.
fields.body:
The brother of the home secretary, Jack Straw, was yesterday found guilty of indecently assaulting a teenage girl in her own home. William Straw, 47, was fined £750 plus £275 costs and was ordered to remain on the sex offenders' register for five years.

Straw, an administrator for the Open University, was accused of assaulting the girl, who cannot be named for legal reasons, in Bramcote, Nottingham, on April 19.

He denied the offence when he appeared before Nottingham magistrates later that month but was convicted by district judge Peter Nuttall at yesterday's resumed hearing.

The court was told that he had met the girl while out shopping and had invited her to his home to see his new dog.

The girl declined but Straw later rang her home, repeated the offer, rode to the house on his bike and invited himself in.

The girl said Straw, who is married but separated and has two children, touched part of her stomach exposed below her crop top and then asked if he could see her bedroom.

"I started to get more worried but he was a family friend, so I said yes," she added.

She said she and Straw went to the bedroom where he sat on the bed. He stroked it and commented on its softness.

As they left the room to go back downstairs, Straw put his hands on her hips. "He started rubbing my hips and staring at my breasts. I told him he was scaring me and he seemed to snap out of a trance."

Straw apologised, went back downstairs and left a short time later, the court heard.

Straw told the court he agreed with most of the girl's evidence but denied touching her. He said he had been on his own, was feeling low and was reaching out to a friendly face.

"On the stairs I stopped and turned and put my hands out to her. I'm not quite sure why I did it and when she said she was scared that's when I realised it was a mistake for me, a 47-year-old man, to be alone with her in her home."

fields.headline: Sisters detained for killing pensioner
fields.trailText: Two teenage sisters were yesterday sentenced for brutally killing a pensioner neighbour who befriended them and gave them birthday cards.
fields.body:
Two teenage sisters were yesterday sentenced for brutally killing a pensioner neighbour who befriended them and gave them birthday cards.

At the Old Bailey, Kellie Lyons, 17, was ordered to serve 10 years in youth detention for manslaughter of Rose Mackenzie, 87, and eight years concurrently for robbery. Jean Lyons, 19, was ordered to serve eight years for manslaughter and six years concurrently for robbery.

Judge Michael Coombe said he had rejected the sisters' claims of remorse, adding: "This was as mean and despicable an offence as can be imagined." The killing was so serious the sisters should be kept on licence for 11 years after release.

Mrs Mackenzie died in hospital in February, a week after being attacked at her flat in the same block the sisters lived, on an estate in Manor House, north London. Masking their faces with balaclavas, the two broke in, hit and kicked the pensioner and stole £800 from a hiding place in the bathroom. When arrested, the sisters, then 17 and 18, blamed each other for the death.

Their defence counsel told the court they would end up in prison, because there was no young offender institution which offered isolation for females. Both women had been subject to threats.

The judge countered: "However much these two girls suffer from their isolation and the hostility of other prisoners who regard this particular crime as outstanding in its hor ror, nothing compares with the suffering inflicted on Rose Mackenzie and her family. I am not impressed by submissions of remorse ... I feel their sorrow was more for their predicament than for Rose or her relatives.

"What makes this crime even graver is that Rose Mackenzie had been a kind lady who befriended these two. She had lent the family money from time to time, there were birthday cards and sweets for what she took to be friendly, young children."

The judge added he believed the jurors had acquitted the sisters of charges of murder because they suspected that one was guilty of murder, but did not know which one.

Outside court, Mrs Mackenzie's great-nephew, Jeff Bennett, said: "Rose enjoyed life even though she was 87 _ I am glad she died without knowing who robbed her. She would have suffered even more if she had known it was the girls she thought were her friends."

Ann Curnow QC, prosecuting, had told the court the pair left the widow with multiple rib fractures and went off to boast to friends of what they had done. On arrest the "inseparable" sisters tried to blame each other, although Jean did admit robbery.

They had lived on the estate for two years with their mother and stepfather, and after average results at school were training to sell perfumes door to door. They had not been in trouble with police before.

webTitle: One third of those arrested in Scotland used heroin

fields.headline: One third of those arrested in Scotland used heroin
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: The level of heroin abuse among people arrested in Scotland is almost double the rate for New York and five times greater than in Los Angeles, according to a study.
fields.body:
The level of heroin abuse among people arrested in Scotland is almost double the rate for New York and five times greater than in Los Angeles, according to a study.

A team at Glasgow University found that 31% of people arrested in two regions of Scotland tested positive for heroin, compared with 18% for New York and 6.5% for Los Angeles. The figure for England was 29%.

The research was commissioned by the Scottish executive to assess the links between drugs and crime, and will be extended across Scotland. It was based on a monitoring programme which has been running in the US for more than a decade.

The researchers took urine samples from more than 400 people arrested for a variety of offences in Strathclyde and Fife last year and compared the results with those for England and 35 regions of the US.

In all, 71% of those arrested in Scotland tested positive for illegal drugs and 31% for heroin. More women than men were found to have heroin in their system; 51% to 26%. Methadone and cannabis use was also more widespread in Scotland, with 12% testing positive for methadone, compared with 8% in England; and 52% testing positive for cannabis, compared with 49% in England.

Neil McKeganey of the university's centre for drug misuse research, who carried out the study, said they had been taken aback by the level of drug use among people arrested for a range of crimes.

"We were surprised that nearly three quarters of people arrested had used illegal drugs and nearly one third had used heroin," he said. "That's much greater than we would have expected. It was a big range of people who were arrested. It was not an addict population."

Prof McKeganey said the findings showed a clear link between drugs and crime in Scotland and highlighted what must be done to address the problem.

"I think the strongest message that comes through is that we need to get treatment services as close to the point of arrest as possible. Hardly any of those who took part had had help with their drug problem while in the police station."

Angus MacKay, the deputy justice minister, said the Scottish executive was keen to extend the programme across Scotland.

"We commissioned this study to give us better information on the links between drugs and crime," he said. "These figures highlight how strong that link is. By extending drug testing across Scotland we will get far better intelligence in drug and crime patterns to help us to target resources," he said.

Drug-related crime is estimated to cost the Scottish economy around £1bn a year.

fields.headline: IOC damned for drugs failure
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Sydney Olympics
fields.trailText: With the Sydney games just a week away, the International Olympic Committee was yesterday condemned for failing to combat the use of performance-enhancing drugs which a report says are more widespread than ever.
fields.byline: Julian Borger  in Washington and  Duncan Mackay  on the Gold Coast
fields.body:
With the Sydney games just a week away, the International Olympic Committee was yesterday condemned for failing to combat the use of performance-enhancing drugs which a report says are more widespread than ever.

In the study, Winning at Any Cost: Doping in Olympic Sports, the IOC is portrayed as a major part of the problem rather than part of the solution.

The 107-page report, commissioned by the US drug czar's policy office and financed by the White House, said the Olympic governing body faced an inherent conflict of interest in its need to attract sponsorship and the consequent desire to avoid the sort of bad publicity created by unmasking cheats.

"Persistent patterns of irregularities in enforcement raises serious doubts about the commitment of the sports' governing bodies to protect the interest of honest athletes, the virtues of the sport and the health and safety of the competitors," the report said.

It added: "For sports governing bodies, tacit approval of performance-enhancing drugs places their credibility in jeopardy."

According to athletes and trainers interviewed by the US national commission on sports and substance abuse, drug use has become almost the norm in some sports, while scientists said attempts to develop new tests "were stymied by... a seeming lack of will at the highest levels of the IOC".

The critical assessment con flicted sharply with IOC claims that it is getting to grips with the problem. It had trumpeted the approval last week of a new test for the drug EPO, which increases the blood's oxygen-carrying capacity. The test contributed this week to the removal of 27 athletes from the Chinese Olympic team.

An IOC spokesman, Franklin Servan-Schreiber, said: "I'm not saying we've won the war on drugs, but we're close to winning the war on EPO and we've put a fear in people who are cheating."

Critics remain unconvinced. Charles Yesalis, the author of a book on performance-enhancing drugs, has dismissed the EPO test as a public relations move. "These games are going to be as drug-laden as the rest."

Even if the new EPO test proves effective in catching or deterring users, there is still no method for detecting two other widely abused prohibited drugs, human growth hormone [HGH] and insulin growth factor [IGF-1].

The level of drug penetration in certain disciplines suggested by the report have surprised few involved in the Olympics. Mark Spitz, winner of a record seven Olympic swimming gold medals in 1972, accused the authorities of "pulling the wool over everybody's eyes".

"There is tremendous pressure from the television networks and also from the nations that know their athletes wouldn't pass those tests," Spitz said.

"They want the television to have athletic competitions with the world record holders there for the finals. It's all about ratings and commercial selling of time and about money. There is a tremendous conflict of interest in what they should do and what they are doing."

"I can't believe they've done nothing," said Daley Thompson, Britain's 1980 and 1984 Olympic decathlon champion. "With all the money pouring into sport you would have thought the one thing they would have done was to stamp out drugs."

The US drug czar, General Barry McCaffrey, said the report demonstrated the need for an independent international body to police the use of drugs. The report noted that the world anti-doping agency created by the IOC last year was under IOC control and only had the power to make recommendations.

The report suggests the creation of an agency which does not have to answer to the IOC, coupled with an international research effort of up to $100m over five years to devise new, more comprehensive tests.

It also suggested the introduction of athletic "passports" which would record each athlete's history of doping tests. There would also be standardised lists of banned substances and a uniform tariff of penalties associated with them.

"When the games begin in Sydney, millions of children will be watching," Gen McCaffrey said. "They'll copy the moves of the basketball players and the strokes of the swimmers. Unless we continue to rid the games of doping and drugs, these children will take the same drugs as they see their stars cheating with."

fields.headline: French-style fuel protest hits Britain
fields.trailText: French-style direct action over rising petrol prices spread across the UK yesterday.
fields.byline: Peter Hetherington  and  Jon Henley in Paris
fields.body:
French-style direct action over rising petrol prices spread across the UK yesterday.

Police moved to avoid traffic chaos on the A1 at Gateshead, Tyne and Wear, last night by warning protesting truck drivers and farmers they faced arrest if they carried out a threat to park lorries and tractors on the busytrunk road. Nevertheless, a slow procession of 100 vehicles, which police said was a mile long, led to huge tailbacks.

Blockading farmers cut off distribution for several hours from the Shell refinery at Ellesmere Port, Cheshire. Fuel supplies to parts of north-west England, Yorkshire and the borders were badly disrupted.

In France, lorry owners belonging to the country's leading road haulage federa tion, the FNTR, refused to follow their leaders' call yesterday afternoon to end their blockade, which has closed 14,000 of 17,000 petrol stations and caused severe disruption throughout the country.

British protesters said they had resorted to direct action out of desperation. Craig Eley, who runs a haulage business in Gateshead, and organised the A1 demonstration, said: "The response has been fantastic. Car drivers were honking their horns in support."

Andrew Spence, regional organiser of Farmers for Action, the group which has been co-ordinating protests around the country, said his members had turned out to lend their weight to the hauliers' call for cuts in fuel taxes. "This is an act of desperation by both the farmers and the truck drivers."

webTitle: Hole in Antarctic ozone now three times size of US

fields.headline: Hole in Antarctic ozone now three times size of US
fields.trailText: The hole in the ozone layer over Antarctica is bigger than ever, US scientists announced yesterday. Nasa has measured the area of thinning ozone as covering an area three times the size of the US.
fields.body:
The hole in the ozone layer over Antarctica is bigger than ever, US scientists announced yesterday. Nasa has measured the area of thinning ozone as covering an area three times the size of the US.

Ozone in the stratosphere forms a natural shield to filter harmful ultraviolet light. But for more than 15 years there has been alarm at dramatic thinning over Antarctica and more recently the Arctic.

A worldwide agreement reached more than 10 years ago banned the long-lived chemicals responsible for ozone destruction. But because of their longevity they are expected to go on damaging the ozone layer for decades. The polar regions are particularly at risk because the chemical reaction which destroys ozone is helped by their weather conditions.

The holes appear each spring - in March in the north and September in the south. Nasa reports that the hole over Antarctica had reached a record size of about 11m square miles by September 3.

Scientists say the hole has stopped growing this year in area but the levels of ozone within are continuing to fall. The lowest readings are usually at the end of September or early October.

Lower levels of ozone are linked to increases in skin cancer and cataracts. There is also fear that ultraviolet radiation could harm plants and microbes. Ozone is an unstable form of oxygen actually created by ultraviolet light. It breaks down and forms again but the presence of chlorine-based CFC chemicals from, among other things, old-style aerosols is interfering with the process.

"These observations reinforce concerns about the frailty of earth's ozone layer. Although production of ozone-destroying gases has been curtailed under international agreements, concentrations of the gases in the stratosphere are only now reaching their peak. Due to their long persistence in the atmosphere, it will be many decades before the ozone hole is no longer an annual occurrence," said Michael Kurylo, manager of the upper atmosphere research programme at Nasa.

Most atmospheric ozone is found between six miles and 18 miles above the earth's surface.

Scientists continuing to investigate this enormous hole are somewhat surprised by its size. "Variations in the size of the ozone hole and of ozone depletion accompanying it from one year to the next are not unexpected," said Jack Kaye at Nasa. "At this point we can only wait to see how the ozone hole will evolve in the coming few months."

Although Nasa satellites began searching for signs of ozone destruction 20 years ago, the hole was discovered by British scientists taking balloon measurements in the Antarctic in 1985.

Brian Gardiner, one of the three British discoverers of the ozone hole, said yesterday: "It is the start of the springtime depletion. We are watching it and the bottom line is it is not getting any better."

webTitle: Britons hurt as coach overturns on US tour

fields.headline: Britons hurt as coach overturns on US tour
fields.standfirst: Elderly passenger needs arms amputated after accident
fields.trailText: Nine British holidaymakers were seriously injured yesterday after a tour bus turned over and skidded on its side for 60 metres along a Nevada highway. They included a 72-year-old woman who had to have her arms amputated.
fields.byline: Jeevan Vasagar  and  Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles
fields.body:
Nine British holidaymakers were seriously injured yesterday after a tour bus turned over and skidded on its side for 60 metres along a Nevada highway. They included a 72-year-old woman who had to have her arms amputated.

The 39 tourists on the coach were on the tenth day of a 15-day tour of the western US. They were on their way to the Mammoth Lakes resort in California when their bus drifted off the two-lane Highway 6/95.

Reports suggest the driver over-corrected the swerve by turning sharply left. The bus rolled over and slid for 60m on its side.

Troy Lineley of Nevada highway patrol said: "The vehicle drifted off the right-hand roadway edge. The driver attempted to correct and in doing so the bus ended up on its side. It came to rest across both lanes on its left side."

All 41 on board, including the British tour director and the American driver, suffered injuries. One of the passengers, a 46-year-old man from Derby, may also lose an arm.

Both he and the woman who had her arms amputated were yesterday in a serious condition in the intensive care unit of the University of Nevada medical centre in Las Vegas. Seven others were being treated at the unit for "road rash" and serious abrasions. They included a 69-year-old man and his wife, 57, from Ammanford, near Swansea, south Wales, and a 56-year-old man from Bolton.

Kate Griswold, a spokeswoman for Washoe medical centre, in Reno, where 17 of the injured were taken, said: "A lot of the injuries are serious abrasions because the bus apparently rolled and skidded. They may have been hanging out of the bus at some point after the first impact."

Other casualties were taken by bus to Nye County regional medical centre with injuries ranging from broken bones to scratches.

One shocked rescuer said: "It was one of the worst things I've ever seen. There were so many patients lying injured that for a time we were overwhelmed."

The crash scene was so remote - five hours by road from either Las Vegas or Reno - that National Guard helicopters and private planes were used to ferry the most critically injured to hospital.

The crash inquiry was yesterday focusing on "driver inattention" as the probable cause after investigators ruled out alcohol or drugs. The weather was clear and there was no wind. It was not clear whether the coach's speed had been excessive. The road was flat, open and straight. A highway patrol spokesman said there were no obvious mechanical defects.

webTitle: Sierra Leone peace force accused of sabotage

fields.headline: Sierra Leone peace force accused of sabotage
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone force accused of sabotage

Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The United Nations force commander in Sierra Leone has accused Nigerian political and military officials at the top of the UN mission in Freetown of "working hard to sabotage the peace process", and the Nigerian army command of looting diamonds in league with the now imprisoned rebel leader, Foday Sankoh.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal  in Freetown  Chris McGreal in Freetown
fields.body:
The United Nations force commander in Sierra Leone has accused Nigerian political and military officials at the top of the UN mission in Freetown of "working hard to sabotage the peace process", and the Nigerian army command of looting diamonds in league with the now imprisoned rebel leader, Foday Sankoh.

In a devastating four-page confidential report obtained by the Guardian, Major-General Vijay Jetley paints a picture of a conspiracy to force him out as the UN commander in Sierra Leone.

The public airing of bitter differences within the UN operation in Freetown comes at a particularly sensitive time as world leaders pledge to overhaul peacekeeping in Africa after a decade of humiliating failures in Angola, Somalia, Rwanda and Sierra Leone. With 7,000 more UN troops destined for Freetown, Gen Jetley's report will force the Security Council to confront issues beyond the numbers of peacekeepers and their mandate, and to consider whether the whole operation is a further threat to stability in west Africa.

The memorandum, called Report on the crisis in Sierra Leone, was written during the upheaval in May that prompted British intervention to prevent the rebel Revolutionary United Front from seizing power. Gen Jetley never officially submitted the document to the UN but it has been widely circulated among members of the Security Council and other major players in Sierra Leone. Its damning criticism of the Nigerians, and its exposure of the deep divisions that have all but paralysed the UN mission, has added pressure for a major shakeup of a discredited peacekeeping force that Britain is counting on to play a leading role in the defeat of the RUF.

Gen Jetley singles out three Nigerians for particular criticism: Kofi Annan's special representative in Freetown, under-secretary-general Oluyemi Adeniji; the former head of Ecomog, the west African intervention force in Sierra Leone which worked with the UN for six months, Major General Gabriel Kpamber; and the deputy force commander, Brigadier-General Mohammed Garba, who is Gen Jetley's immediate subordinate. The report lays bare the personal animosity between Gen Jetley and the men he accuses, but it goes further by detailing a series of actions that he says amount to collusion with the rebels to wreck last year's peace accords because Nigeria wants a free hand to run Sierra Leone and its army wants to control the diamond trade. At the heart of the accusations lie charges that the Nigerians compromised Gen Jetley's efforts to free 500 of his peacekeepers taken hostage by the RUF in May.

"The mission directive given to me and which I tried to follow implicitly, directly conflicted with the interests of not only the warring factions but also of the major players in the diamond racket like Liberia and Nigeria.

"As an Indian, and having no hidden agenda to promote, I became a victim of the machinations of these countries. By placing their stooges in the right places they have not only tried to scuttle the peace process but also try and denigrate me and the country I represent, to promote their own personal ambitions and personal interests.

"It is my opinion that the Ecomog force commander along with the SRSG [Mr Adeniji] and DFC [Gen Garba] have worked hard to sabotage the peace process and show Indians in general and me in particular in a poor light... Keeping the Nigerian interests was paramount even if it meant scuttling the peace process and this also implied that Unamsil [the UN force] was expendable.

"To this end the SRSG and DFC cultivated the RUF leadership especially Foday Sankoh behind my back."

But the report came as no surprise to western and senior UN officials who say that there is ample evidence that the Nigerian army remains heavily implicated in the illegal diamond trade, that its senior officers worked closely with the RUF despite having also fought it, and that the Nigerians believe that, as the largest troop contingent in the UN mission, they should have overall command.

Gen Jetley argues that senior Nigerian army officers - particularly Gen Kpamber and Brigadier-General Maxwell Khobe, who died earlier this year - did not want to withdraw from Sierra Leone because they were making huge amounts of money from illegal diamond mining and payments from the RUF.

"It is well known that public opinion in Nigeria was against the continued deployment of Nigerian troops as part of Ecomog in Sierra Leone, however the Nigerian army was interested in staying in Sierra Leone due to the benefits they were getting from the illegal mining. Gen Khobe was known as the 'Ten Million man', it is alleged that he received up to $10m to permit the activities of RUF. The Ecomog force commander Gen Kpamber was also involved in the illegal diamond mining in connivance with RUF leader Foday Sankoh," Gen Jetley wrote.

In January, Gen Kpamber astonished a meeting of regional heads of state on the peace process by praising Mr Sankoh as the "saviour of the nation". The two men were often seen in each other's company travelling to diamond towns from which the UN was barred. Sierra Leoneans referred to Gen Kpamber as "Sankoh's ADC".

Gen Jetley lists a series of actions by the Nigerian army which he concludes amounted to colluding in the abductions. He notes that while Kenyans, Zambians and Indians were taken captive, the rebels let the Nigerians go.

But the alleged relationship between Mr Sankoh and senior Nigerian officers and officials would explain why the rebel leader was trying to get to the Nigerian High Commission when he was captured. Gen Jetley blames low morale for the mass surrender of his troops.

webTitle: What the European papers say about the price of oil

fields.headline: What the European papers say
fields.trailText: Corriere della Sera, Italy
fields.body:
Corriere della Sera, Italy

"The situation risks spinning out of control throughout Europe if something is not done to reverse the trend. Now even Italy's taxi drivers are threatening blockades. The signs are not encouraging."

Die Welt, Germany

"The price of petrol climbs and climbs. So. Can anyone help? The producers' cartel is holding together, not least as a way of taking revenge for all the ridicule heaped on it in recent years when the west was swimming in oil and oil prices wallowed. Even though we have no influence over oil prices, we are getting rid of nuclear power. Why?"

Libération, France

"In a country we like to proclaim as law-abiding, it is devastating to see how a small fraction of the population can impose on the rest a state of affairs which amounts to occupying public property illegally, with complete impudence and with complete impunity, in order to pursue its own private interests. Of course, the liberty to demonstrate should be defended on principle. But everyone has heard and seen the barricades mounted by road hauliers, farmers and other diesel users. These are not employees, they are desperate employers - and that is different."

Le Monde, France

"It is not the first time that France has been threatened with paralysis through the actions of the road hauliers. It is, however, the first time that the 'boss's boss', the president of the employers' federation, has denounced their tactics. Ernest-Antoine de Seilliere asks the government to 'oppose these methods, which are not worthy of a democracy'. This was serious and responsible. How can one have confidence in employers - social partners - who behave in the way the road transporters are currently behaving?"

El Mundo, Spain

"In this (oil) crisis, as in every other, ranging from Kosovo to the plummeting euro, the European Unions inefficiency disappoints its citizens. Europe has shown it has no real representative...On a number of critical issues involving international diplomacy and law and order, Europe gives the impression that it is firmly situated in the 'doesnt know/doesnt answer' category."

Le Soir, Belgium

"The question is not how much petrol costs today but why the Belgian government and others let prices fall between 1985 and 1999 instead of pursuing the only sensible policy after the first oil crisis which is to set prices in a way which will cut the use of a finite resource."

"The government's fault is therefore not that it taxes too much today but that it didn't levy more taxes yesterday."

"It's important that the government and EU governments remember what they declared 25 years ago after the first oil crisis: We must conserve our energy reserves."

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.standfirst: ICI
fields.trailText: Management at chemicals maker ICI face a grim reality: possible relegation from the FTSE 100.
fields.body:
Management at chemicals maker ICI face a grim reality: possible relegation from the FTSE 100.

A few years ago the prospect of such a company losing its top flight status would have been unthinkable. ICI was a business champion regarded as a key barometer of the economy. Its fall from grace has been swift and brutal. Within a year it has plummeted from the top 40 of the leading index to the bottom 10.

Last night the share price closed down 16p to 438p. ICI's cause was not helped this week by warnings from DuPont, the top US chemical business, that earnings this year will fall below Wall Street expectations.

The actual businesses under ICI's wing are strong. The company reported strong interim results and the specialty side has performed well. But a high level of debt is undermining this performance and only rapid action will be able to haul ICI back up the rankings.

If not, then the FTSE 100 quarterly re-evaluations in December and March could see the once proud name unceremoniously dumped.

Problems centre around overpaying for acquisitions, difficulties getting rid of cyclical assets in tough market conditions and a stubborn refusal to cut the dividend, which has left it saddled with debts of £2.9bn.

The £5bn purchase of Unilever's speciality chemicals business three years ago was a bold move, but its disposal programme ran into trouble when the federal trade commission blocked the sale of its Tioxide business to DuPont.

Success has been achieved in off-loading some of the bulk chemicals side over the past two years, but more deals are needed to turn the situation around. Analysts say the dividend needs to be cut as quickly as possible because cash is "just bleeding from the business".

The City is losing its patience. Action is required soon before ICI slips off the radar screens.

fields.headline: Spirits raised
fields.trailText: Diageo, the drinks conglomerate whose brands include Smirnoff and Guinness, saw its share price rise yesterday after analysts raised their earnings predictions.
fields.body:
Diageo, the drinks conglomerate whose brands include Smirnoff and Guinness, saw its share price rise yesterday after analysts raised their earnings predictions.

Shares went up 5p to close at 589.5p as the American investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter raised its earnings forecast on the group by 4% to 41.5p for 2001.

Deutsche Bank reiterated its buy recommendation and the 12-month share price target remained steady at 700p.

Analysts said that the results reported yesterday were in line with expectations and the performance from the spirits business was particularly strong.

Underlying top line growth was 8% and annual profits increased by 2.7%.

Sector analysts reported there was more confidence in the company being able to deliver top line growth and to achieve expansion of margins.

fields.headline: A mercenary for democracy
fields.standfirst: Mark Malloch Brown, administrator, UN Development Programme
fields.trailText: When the protesters start converging on the World Bank and International Monetary Fund meetings in Prague next week, Mark Malloch Brown will no doubt allow himself a sigh of relief.
fields.body:
When the protesters start converging on the World Bank and International Monetary Fund meetings in Prague next week, Mark Malloch Brown will no doubt allow himself a sigh of relief.

Until just over a year ago, his job as the public face of the bank would have put him directly in the firing line for what are expected to be the biggest rallies against globalisation since the protests which shook the World Trade Organisation talks in Seattle last December.

Trying to justify the bank to people who believe babies are murdered in developing countries and environments destroyed in the organisation's name is no easy task, even for a man with as impressive a track record in the black arts of political spin doctoring as is Malloch Brown.

Instead, he has swapped his post as head of external relations at the bank for the top job at the United Nations Development Programme, an organisation that most development campaigners regard as one of the good guys of the development aid world, although even its best friends would admit it has not always been the most effective outfit.

He is clearly relishing his new role. "It's so much more fun to run one's own development agency rather than apologising for the running of somebody else's," he says. Among his dreams are putting Africa online, reshaping his organisation as the main source of advice to developing countries and mediating in the debate which has split the development community over whether economic growth or redistribution of resources from rich to poor is more important in tackling global poverty.

'Wing and a prayer'

Malloch Brown admits the contrast between the bank and the UNDP was "a bit daunting" at first. The UNDP runs on a shoestring compared to resources available to the bank and the fund. Its core budget this year was $700m - less than what the bank spends on administration - although with the extra resources it mobilises the overall total rises to about $2.5bn. The bank's lending programme, by contrast, totals $7bn.

"It's all got there by a wing and a prayer," says Malloch Brown. In fact, the budget has been declining over the past decade from a peak in 1992 of $1.2bn. The UNDP has been a victim of the aid fatigue which hit the main donors after the collapse of the Iron Curtain removed the political justifications for many countries' lending programmes.

But it has also been a victim of its own reputation for inefficiency and waste. Britain is one of the leading donors which has refused until recently to increase its allocation for the UNDP until it sees evidence that the money is being well spent.

A British national with a long track record in the international system - he worked for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in the early 1980s - Malloch Brown came to the UNDP at the request of the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, to shake up the place and be part of Annan's reforming agenda which was showcased at this week's millennium summit.

But Malloch Brown was received initially with suspicion. Some poor countries believed he had been chosen to smuggle a bank perspective into an institution which has always been seen as an ally of the developing world. While the World Bank and IMF are under the thumb of the donor countries - the Group of Seven leading industrialised economies controls nearly half of the votes on the fund's management board - the UNDP has always been much closer to the recipients of aid.

Malloch Brown freely admits he preaches the bank's line about the need to accompany aid with political and economic reform and he deliberately set out turn the UNDP's focus to the importance of good governance. It was a message not universally popular with aid recipients unaccustomed to receiving lectures on reform from their friends at the UNDP.

"In the first six months I had a bit of rough ride because I said governance ought to be our priority. There was a lot of initial caution, the developing country representatives in New York said 'oh my God, he's another part of this secret political version of the Washington consensus'."

For some developing country governments the strings which come attached to aid programmes these days, requiring them to consult with their electorates, are seen as a new form of political structural adjustment.

But the initial concern has dissipated, according to Malloch Brown, as poor countries have come to realise that they need to change. They would still rather hear the message from the UNDP, however, than endure the more heavy handed approach of the bank or the fund.

Malloch Brown's belief in the importance of democratic reforms comes from his time at the UNHCR during the late 1970s, which convinced him that the root of all problems in developing countries was a lack of democracy.

"If you have a competitive political system in which to resolve differences, you won't have refugee flows," he says.

It was also the spur behind the next stage of his varied career, his work as a political consultant for various developing country governments in the late 1980s and early 1990s.

He describes himself then as a "mercenary for democracy", and he and his colleagues chalked up some impressive victories, including Corrie Aquino's election campaign in the Philippines in 1986 and the no vote in the Chilean referendum of 1988 which eventually ended General Pinochet's rule.

The wave of fledgling democratic governments which came to power in the 1980s were ripe for advice from Malloch Brown's consultancy with its sophisticated polling techniques and understanding of political systems. He learnt a lot, as well, along the way.

"A lot of these nice phrases about local ownership in the development community I learnt at the political coalface."

'In the wrong business'

Malloch Brown sees his role at the UNDP as the culmination of his previous experience. The organisation clearly needs a PR overhaul to restore donors' confidence, but at the same time he has to go gently to avoid alienating the trust of the developing countries, which is its biggest asset.

The old-style UNDP ran thousands of small development projects and had a reputation for being bureaucratic and inefficient. Malloch Brown thinks the project-based approach is a waste of time when its resources are dwarfed by other aid agencies.

"UNDP was in the wrong business, we didn't offer any value added," he says. "In a tight market for official development assistance we were going nowhere."

The plan now is to reposition the UNDP as an advisory and advocacy agency. That is not, he hastens to add, because advice is cheap, although that is an advantage, but because "if you look at the environment in which we are operating, advice is a scarce commodity".

In fact, turning the UNDP into an advisory body will bring it once again into competition with the bank, which is also championing the governance agenda. His old boss, James Wolfensohn, has been trying to reposition his institution as the "listening bank".

But in a head-to-head battle over who should be the prime source of advice to the developing world the UNDP has many advantages.

While the bank is handicapped by the perception that it is in the pocket of the G7, the UNDP can capitalise on trust. "I'm stunned by the freedom I have to raise issues with governments," says Malloch Brown.

The backlash against globalisation which started in Seattle last December has also benefited the UNDP. "The Seattle aftershocks which have driven the developing countries back to us made them more cautious and anxious to find an alternative path."

Malloch Brown is no advocate of stopping the processes of economic integration, however.

"Globalisation is inevitable: the question is on what terms," he says. "We have to make sure that poor people are included in the process."

Until just over a year ago, his job as the public face of the bank would have put him directly in the firing line for what are expected to be the biggest rallies against globalisation since the protests which shook the World Trade Organisation talks in Seattle last December. Trying to justify the bank to people who believe babies are murdered in developing countries and environments destroyed in the organisation's name is no easy task, even for a man with as impressive a track record in the black arts of political spin doctoring as is Malloch Brown. Instead, he has swapped his post as head of external relations at the bank for the top job at the United Nations Development Programme, an organisation that most development campaigners regard as one of the good guys of the development aid world, although even its best friends would admit it has not always been the most effective outfit. He is clearly relishing his new role. "It's so much more fun to run one's own development agency rather than apologising for the running of somebody else's," he says. Among his dreams are putting Africa online, reshaping his organisation as the main source of advice to developing countries and mediating in the debate which has split the development community over whether economic growth or redistribution of resources from rich to poor is more important in tackling global poverty. 'Wing and a prayer' Malloch Brown admits the contrast between the bank and the UNDP was "a bit daunting" at first. The UNDP runs on a shoestring compared to resources available to the bank and the fund. Its core budget this year was $700m - less than what the bank spends on administration - although with the extra resources it mobilises the overall total rises to about $2.5bn. The bank's lending programme, by contrast, totals $7bn. "It's all got there by a wing and a prayer," says Malloch Brown. In fact, the budget has been declining over the past decade from a peak in 1992 of $1.2bn. The UNDP has been a victim of the aid fatigue which hit the main donors after the collapse of the Iron Curtain removed the political justifications for many countries' lending programmes. But it has also been a victim of its own reputation for inefficiency and waste. Britain is one of the leading donors which has refused until recently to increase its allocation for the UNDP until it sees evidence that the money is being well spent. A British national with a long track record in the international system - he worked for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in the early 1980s - Malloch Brown came to the UNDP at the request of the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, to shake up the place and be part of Annan's reforming agenda which was showcased at this week's millennium summit. But Malloch Brown was received initially with suspicion. Some poor countries believed he had been chosen to smuggle a bank perspective into an institution which has always been seen as an ally of the developing world. While the World Bank and IMF are under the thumb of the donor countries - the Group of Seven leading industrialised economies controls nearly half of the votes on the fund's management board - the UNDP has always been much closer to the recipients of aid. Malloch Brown freely admits he preaches the bank's line about the need to accompany aid with political and economic reform and he deliberately set out turn the UNDP's focus to the importance of good governance. It was a message not universally popular with aid recipients unaccustomed to receiving lectures on reform from their friends at the UNDP. "In the first six months I had a bit of rough ride because I said governance ought to be our priority. There was a lot of initial caution, the developing country representatives in New York said 'oh my God, he's another part of this secret political version of the Washington consensus'." For some developing country governments the strings which come attached to aid programmes these days, requiring them to consult with their electorates, are seen as a new form of political structural adjustment. But the initial concern has dissipated, according to Malloch Brown, as poor countries have come to realise that they need to change. They would still rather hear the message from the UNDP, however, than endure the more heavy handed approach of the bank or the fund. Malloch Brown's belief in the importance of democratic reforms comes from his time at the UNHCR during the late 1970s, which convinced him that the root of all problems in developing countries was a lack of democracy. "If you have a competitive political system in which to resolve differences, you won't have refugee flows," he says. It was also the spur behind the next stage of his varied career, his work as a political consultant for various developing country governments in the late 1980s and early 1990s. He describes himself then as a "mercenary for democracy", and he and his colleagues chalked up some impressive victories, including Corrie Aquino's election campaign in the Philippines in 1986 and the no vote in the Chilean referendum of 1988 which eventually ended General Pinochet's rule. The wave of fledgling democratic governments which came to power in the 1980s were ripe for advice from Malloch Brown's consultancy with its sophisticated polling techniques and understanding of political systems. He learnt a lot, as well, along the way. "A lot of these nice phrases about local ownership in the development community I learnt at the political coalface." 'In the wrong business' Malloch Brown sees his role at the UNDP as the culmination of his previous experience. The organisation clearly needs a PR overhaul to restore donors' confidence, but at the same time he has to go gently to avoid alienating the trust of the developing countries, which is its biggest asset. The old-style UNDP ran thousands of small development projects and had a reputation for being bureaucratic and inefficient. Malloch Brown thinks the project-based approach is a waste of time when its resources are dwarfed by other aid agencies. "UNDP was in the wrong business, we didn't offer any value added," he says. "In a tight market for official development assistance we were going nowhere." The plan now is to reposition the UNDP as an advisory and advocacy agency. That is not, he hastens to add, because advice is cheap, although that is an advantage, but because "if you look at the environment in which we are operating, advice is a scarce commodity". In fact, turning the UNDP into an advisory body will bring it once again into competition with the bank, which is also championing the governance agenda. His old boss, James Wolfensohn, has been trying to reposition his institution as the "listening bank". But in a head-to-head battle over who should be the prime source of advice to the developing world the UNDP has many advantages. While the bank is handicapped by the perception that it is in the pocket of the G7, the UNDP can capitalise on trust. "I'm stunned by the freedom I have to raise issues with governments," says Malloch Brown. The backlash against globalisation which started in Seattle last December has also benefited the UNDP. "The Seattle aftershocks which have driven the developing countries back to us made them more cautious and anxious to find an alternative path." Malloch Brown is no advocate of stopping the processes of economic integration, however. "Globalisation is inevitable: the question is on what terms," he says. "We have to make sure that poor people are included in the process."

webTitle: Market forces: Back to square one

fields.headline: Back to square one
fields.trailText: Grand Old Duke of York syndrome. It marched to the top of the hill and then it came straight back down again.
fields.body:
Grand Old Duke of York syndrome. It marched to the top of the hill and then it came straight back down again.

After reaching a closing high for the year on Monday, the FTSE 100 is back to almost where it was before last week's explosion in technology, media and telecom shares.

The reason was the strong oil price. The fear sweeping City trading rooms yesterday was that the soaring price of black gold will push interest rates up across the globe and cause a much sharper than expected economic slowdown.

Dealers were not holding out much hope that Sunday's meeting of Opec in Vienna will solve the problem. Nevertheless, investors were still booking profits in Shell, down 6.5p to 609.5p, and BP, off 9p at 652.5p, just in case.

That said, a slew of poor corporate news, including several profit downgrades and a FTSE 250 company, Independent Energy Holdings, being placed in receivership, did not help lighten the mood.

At the close the blue chip index was down 88.5 points at 6,600.7 points, taking its losses for the week to 195 points.

Granada Compass was in the firing line after a briefing with analysts turned into a public relations disaster. Its shares fell 66p to 711p in heavy volume of 57.3m after analysts took the red pen to forecasts for the recently formed hotels and catering group.

The downgrades, which were in the £30m-£40m region, came after a briefing by the company on Thursday at which it appears to have guided profit forecasts lower.

The reasons for the downgrades were mundane: an adjustment of Granada's accountancy practices to bring them into line with Compass's (in particular the signing of bonus and marketing agreements paid by suppliers to Granada restaurants which will now be recognised in the profit and loss account over the life of the agreement and not in one year); and a sluggish performance from its motorway services division.

But, with most shareholders still to be convinced by the logic of the deal that brought Granada and Compass together, the way the process was handled did little to help sentiment.

Instead of the company disclosing details of the briefing to the market, most investors found out about the downgrade from a newspaper report.

Controls and automation group Invensys failed to claw back any of Thursday's 93.25p loss, despite whispers of a possible takeover. The shares closed down a further 11.75p at 156p.

That move also hurt GKN, off 4.98p to 820p, with dealers reasoning that if Invensys has warned on profits then GKN could be next.

Holders of Kingfisher shares are starting to ask themselves what it going on at the retail conglomerate. On Thursday its shares dropped 12.5p to 478.5p after news that its director of investor relations had quit. Normally such news does not move stock prices but, when it comes six days before interim figures, tongues start to wag. This was the case yesterday. The shares closed off 32p at 446.5p.

About the only bright spot in the market was the mining sector, which was lifted by a sparkling set of figures from Anglo American , up 117p to £44.17. On the back of that news Rio Tinto improved 34p to £11.94, while Billiton rose 6.25p to 301p.

Business services group Hays was always among the best performers, ending 3.5p better at 430p after US investment bank CSFB initiated coverage of the stock with a "buy" recommendation and 479p share price target.

Lower down the order, intellectual rights group BTG firmed 142.5p to £15.75 on the back of deal with Siemens.

A little engineering company called Brunel Holdings rose 0.75p to 3p after it was revealed that John Hemming, who was involved with the Towers bid for Rover, has taken an 8.66% stake.

webTitle: A name that slips off the tongue

fields.headline: A name that slips off the tongue
fields.standfirst: British Gas
fields.trailText: When British Gas demerged in 1997, the executives of the supply and pipeline businesses each fought to keep the brand name. The eventual compromise no doubt made sense to the executives, lawyers and merchant bankers at the time, but it has caused confusion to everyone else.
fields.body:
When British Gas demerged in 1997, the executives of the supply and pipeline businesses each fought to keep the brand name. The eventual compromise no doubt made sense to the executives, lawyers and merchant bankers at the time, but it has caused confusion to everyone else.

The supply business was given a new name, Centrica, but was allowed to trade as British Gas in Britain where the name was well known. When competitors came knocking on the door offering cheaper gas, many customers preferred to stay with British Gas. Surely, people thought, these newcomers must be cutting corners to offer such low prices. Better stay with good old safe British Gas, they thought.

The pipeline business was called BG, so that customers would recognise the initials. It was allowed to use the name British Gas outside Britain. At home it could use the name British Gas International for activities outside the country.

But confusion reigns: when a gas leak develops who does one call? Centrica or BG? The company which sold you the gas or the company which looks after the pipeline? The answer is you call British Gas, alias BG, the company which uses the British Gas name outside the UK. Its telephone number is on the gas bill sent to you by Centrica.

The logic runs as follows: the pipeline that supplies the gas is owned by Transco, a BG subsidiary. But people prefer to call British Gas in an emergency because the gas is, well, in Britain.

Just to add to the confusion you can buy British Gas electricity and, as announced on Monday, British Gas telephone services will soon become available.

So who does the gas service or repair man work for? He may be a qualified independent gas engineer. But if he turns up in a van sporting the British Gas logo, he works for Centrica, who have at least had the decency to market their credit card under a completely different name - Goldfish.

On Thursday BG added a new twist by saying it planned to change its own name to Lattice when it demerges its British Gas International subsidiary shortly.

This bewildering situation arose because Centrica and BG executives recognised the value of the British Gas brand name. People trust British Gas to handle gas without causing explosions. And overseas British Gas enjoys a reputation worth exploiting.

As a brand, British Gas is relatively new. British Gas Corporation was created in 1973 when the industry was restructured. It was a state-owned monopoly which controlled the old regional gas boards. The gas industry had been nationalised in 1948. Prior to that it had been fragmented and, in some cases, badly run.

William Murdoch, a Scottish engineer working for Boulton & Watt, first used gas in 1792 to light his house in Redruth, Cornwall. People had already been trying to use gas produced by heating coal for lighting. But it was Mr Murdoch and Samuel Clegg, a colleague at the Birmingham-based Boulton & Watt, who went on to commercialise the process.

Early gas-powered lighting systems were set up by Mr Murdoch and Mr Clegg in the Yorkshire and Lancashire mills in 1805. Mr Murdoch, who supplied gas plants to individual businesses, opposed a forward-looking plan proposed by Fredrick Winsor for a national gas company which would manufacture gas and pipe it to where it was needed.

The first gas company, the Gas Light and Coke Company, began operations in 1812, and was quickly followed by other similar limited liability companies. Some early gas companies started making gas from whale oil, but quickly switched to the cheaper raw material, coal. Competition was intense often within the same area. Local authorities started to get in on the act. The first was Manchester Corporation which bought the gas plant owned by the local police station. Gas, at the time, was used for street lamps and commerical lighting, and not for domestic consumption.

But gas for domestic heating and cooking became widespread after the invention of the aerated gas burner, credited to Robert Wilhelm Bunsen, and the invention of the gas mantle by Carl Auer von Welsbach.

The industry began to consolidate in the late 1800s, with local authorities and big gas groups emerging as major players. Gas companies, in a refrain to be heard again in the late1900s, were accused of making excess profits. Between the world wars, many gas enterprises went bust or were taken over by big holding companies.

Bomb damage to the industry's infrastructure during the second world war was the first step towards nationalisation. Although a government-commissioned report on the industry's future did not propose nationalisation it formed the basis of the 1948 Gas Act which brought the industry, made up of more than 1,000 gas businesses, into state ownership. They were run by 12 area gas boards.

The industry was to change radically with the arrival of natural gas, first imported and then brought direct from the North Sea in the 1960s. The creation of the British Gas Corporation during the 1973 restructuring of the industry opened the way to its later privatisation in 1986.

British Gas was the one of the Thatcher government's biggest privatisations aimed at the public as well as City institutions. But some of the goodwill built up during the shares sell-off was lost during British Gas's subsequent clashes with the industry regulator.

The fax

Bright lights The first town to be lit by gas was Preston, Lancashire, in 1816

Top favourite Despite the introduction of competition, British Gas still supplies 14.5m of the country's 20m gas users

Brand strength British Gas has used its brand name to build up a business supplying electricity to 3m customers

Natural path The conversion of 13m homes and factories, and 34m individual appliances from town gas to natural gas began in 1967 and took 10 years.

All but one After 1997, when BG was split, it retained all its exploration and production interests except the North and South Morecambe field, which went to Centrica.

webTitle: Home truths:  The government's plans for leasehold reform

fields.headline: Will reform give owners a new lease of life?
fields.standfirst: The government's plans had a mixed response, so Elizabeth Langton puts them to the test
fields.trailText: The government's plans had a mixed response, so Elizabeth Langton puts them to the test
fields.body:
Property experts gave a mixed response to the recent publication of the government's plans for leasehold reform in England and Wales. While ministers presented the draft bill as the answer to leaseholders' prayers, critics said the proposals stopped short of freeing flat owners from the clutches of greedy freeholders.

Closer inspection of the documents reveals that how much owners of leasehold flats and houses benefit from the changes depends upon their particular situation. To test the likely impact of the changes on individuals, Jobs & Money asked property expert Paul Brecknell at solicitors Withers to outline how much of a difference the draft proposals would make when implemented to three hypothetical leaseholders wrestling with common problems.

1 The residents of a Victorian building containing two flats have an absentee landlord. He refuses to properly maintain the outside of the building. Every now and again they are sent bills for work that hasn't been carried out. They are tired of chasing him up with fruitless phone calls.

What could they do now?

Assuming that the landlord has responsibility for repair of the exterior as is generally the case, the leaseholders could apply to the county court requesting that it appoint a manager under the Landlord and Tenant Act 1987.

If the court is satisfied that there has been default on the part of the landlord, it will appoint a suitable managing agent to collect the service charges and carry out the landlord's obligations.

The alternative would be to buy the freehold if both leaseholders agreed to do so and could afford it. This will also involve an application to the county court with the same documentation that would normally apply to a compulsory purchase by the leaseholders of the freehold.

The court will have to be satisfied that at least one leaseholder has lived in his or her flat for the past 12 months or for three years out of the past 10 years. The price payable will be independently established by a valuer and the money paid into court for the landlord.

Of course, if the leaseholders can track down the landlord, they can suggest he appoint a managing agent to manage because he can recover the costs from the leaseholders and it won't cost him anything. Failing his agreeing to that, they can take him to court and force him to carry out his obligations.

What could they do if the reforms are implemented?

The most obvious solution to the leaseholders' problems would be to take advantage of the new right to manage. This is a right for the leaseholders themselves to manage, rather than someone appointed by the court. The application procedure is similar to that which is applied to the compulsory purchase of the freehold.

By taking over the management of the building the leaseholders will be able to administer their own service charges, although the landlord will still have a say in the management of the building by virtue of having voting rights in the management company. The government's proposals in relation to the number of votes the landlord would get in this situation have not yet been fully formulated.

However, in this case it seems likely that the leaseholders would have effective control of the management company even in the unlikely event that the absentee landlord popped up and voted.

2 Two leasehold flats are above a leasehold shop. Once again, the freeholder is absent and refuses to maintain the building. The leaseholders do bits and pieces, but the shop leaseholder refuses to contribute because he doesn't live there.

What could they do now?

The shop owner's lease will generally contain some service charge provisions but these apply only to costs incurred by the landlord. The leaseholders cannot there fore recover any part of the monies they have spent. The most obvious solution here would again be to apply for the appointment of a manager under the 1987 Act to carry out the landlord's function.

What could they do if the reforms are implemented?

Again, the most obvious solution would be to exercise the right to manage. This should allow the leaseholders to take control but a note of caution should once more be sounded in relation to the voting rights in the management company.

The leaseholders would only be able to buy the freehold if the shop premises do not represent more than 25% of the overall internal floor area of the building. However, even if the compulsory purchase of the freehold is possible, it is unlikely that the leaseholders would want to buy the landlord's interest in the shop and end up as the owners of the freehold reversion to that shop.

It may, therefore, be preferable to rely on the 1987 Act right and seek the appointment of a manager under current law.

3 Leaseholders in a block of 30 flats receive frequent demands from their freeholder for maintenance payments. Work has been done but it is sub-standard. The flat owners have got together to write letters demanding to see the accounts but to no avail. They are withholding payments and the freeholder has threatened them with court action.

What could they do now?

The landlord will only be able to require payment if he has complied with the consultation procedures laid down by the Landlord and Tenant Act 1985.

Moreover under the 1985 Act, service charges can only be recovered to the extent that they relate to works of a reasonable standard. The leaseholders could therefore refer the dispute to the Leasehold Valuation Tribunal.

As mentioned, under the current law the landlord cannot seek to forfeit the lease (bring it to an end) without first taking the dispute to the tribunal for resolution, but the landlord could make a claim for the sums owed in the county court.

There is no award of costs in the tribunal but split between a majority of the leaseholders, this would probably be the most economic remedy.

If the landlord were to take the matter to the county court and obtain a judgment to recover any charges at all then the leaseholders could be required to pay some or all of the landlord's costs.

The leaseholders should not withhold payment of all service charges if some are properly due. If they have a good idea of the value of the defective works, they could withhold that element of the charges. This should protect them from an adverse costs order.

Although the leaseholders are demanding to see the accounts, they are only currently entitled to a costs summary certified by an accountant. That would only appear once the year's service charge accounts have been finalised. That could be anything up to 18 months after the costs have occurred. The certification is limited and should not be confused with an audit.

The leaseholders do have the right to inspect and copy the accounts, invoices, etc. that support the costs summary and the landlord must comply with a request to inspect within one month. If the landlord won't oblige, it will be necessary to threaten an application to the court for an order - naturally to include a claim for costs.

What could they do if the reforms are implemented?

The landlord could be required to get an accountant to explain what certification actually involves. One of the leaseholders may have the right to inspect at any time within 21 days of a request to do so.

There may also be a right to withhold payments up to a certain level when a landlord has failed to provide the information required to by law.

The court will have to be satisfied that at least one leaseholder has lived in his or her flat for the past 12 months or for three years out of the past 10 years. The price payable will be independently established by a valuer and the money paid into court for the landlord. Of course, if the leaseholders can track down the landlord, they can suggest he appoint a managing agent to manage because he can recover the costs from the leaseholders and it won't cost him anything. Failing his agreeing to that, they can take him to court and force him to carry out his obligations. What could they do if the reforms are implemented? The most obvious solution to the leaseholders' problems would be to take advantage of the new right to manage. This is a right for the leaseholders themselves to manage, rather than someone appointed by the court. The application procedure is similar to that which is applied to the compulsory purchase of the freehold. By taking over the management of the building the leaseholders will be able to administer their own service charges, although the landlord will still have a say in the management of the building by virtue of having voting rights in the management company. The government's proposals in relation to the number of votes the landlord would get in this situation have not yet been fully formulated. However, in this case it seems likely that the leaseholders would have effective control of the management company even in the unlikely event that the absentee landlord popped up and voted. 2 Two leasehold flats are above a leasehold shop. Once again, the freeholder is absent and refuses to maintain the building. The leaseholders do bits and pieces, but the shop leaseholder refuses to contribute because he doesn't live there. What could they do now? The shop owner's lease will generally contain some service charge provisions but these apply only to costs incurred by the landlord. The leaseholders cannot there fore recover any part of the monies they have spent. The most obvious solution here would again be to apply for the appointment of a manager under the 1987 Act to carry out the landlord's function. What could they do if the reforms are implemented? Again, the most obvious solution would be to exercise the right to manage. This should allow the leaseholders to take control but a note of caution should once more be sounded in relation to the voting rights in the management company. The leaseholders would only be able to buy the freehold if the shop premises do not represent more than 25% of the overall internal floor area of the building. However, even if the compulsory purchase of the freehold is possible, it is unlikely that the leaseholders would want to buy the landlord's interest in the shop and end up as the owners of the freehold reversion to that shop. It may, therefore, be preferable to rely on the 1987 Act right and seek the appointment of a manager under current law. 3 Leaseholders in a block of 30 flats receive frequent demands from their freeholder for maintenance payments. Work has been done but it is sub-standard. The flat owners have got together to write letters demanding to see the accounts but to no avail. They are withholding payments and the freeholder has threatened them with court action. What could they do now? The landlord will only be able to require payment if he has complied with the consultation procedures laid down by the Landlord and Tenant Act 1985. Moreover under the 1985 Act, service charges can only be recovered to the extent that they relate to works of a reasonable standard. The leaseholders could therefore refer the dispute to the Leasehold Valuation Tribunal. As mentioned, under the current law the landlord cannot seek to forfeit the lease (bring it to an end) without first taking the dispute to the tribunal for resolution, but the landlord could make a claim for the sums owed in the county court. There is no award of costs in the tribunal but split between a majority of the leaseholders, this would probably be the most economic remedy. If the landlord were to take the matter to the county court and obtain a judgment to recover any charges at all then the leaseholders could be required to pay some or all of the landlord's costs. The leaseholders should not withhold payment of all service charges if some are properly due. If they have a good idea of the value of the defective works, they could withhold that element of the charges. This should protect them from an adverse costs order. Although the leaseholders are demanding to see the accounts, they are only currently entitled to a costs summary certified by an accountant. That would only appear once the year's service charge accounts have been finalised. That could be anything up to 18 months after the costs have occurred. The certification is limited and should not be confused with an audit. The leaseholders do have the right to inspect and copy the accounts, invoices, etc. that support the costs summary and the landlord must comply with a request to inspect within one month. If the landlord won't oblige, it will be necessary to threaten an application to the court for an order - naturally to include a claim for costs. What could they do if the reforms are implemented? The landlord could be required to get an accountant to explain what certification actually involves. One of the leaseholders may have the right to inspect at any time within 21 days of a request to do so. There may also be a right to withhold payments up to a certain level when a landlord has failed to provide the information required to by law. webTitle: End snub to Austria, say three wise men

fields.headline: End snub to Austria, say three wise men
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Austrian far right in power
fields.trailText: France was facing a political dilemma last night after the three "wise men" appointed by the European Union recommended that the diplomatic quarantine of Austria - long backed by Paris - should end.
fields.body:
France was facing a political dilemma last night after the three "wise men" appointed by the European Union recommended that the diplomatic quarantine of Austria - long backed by Paris - should end.

Austria's respect for human rights is "no less than in other EU member states", their report concludes.

President Jacques Chirac was studying the report, which is said to give Vienna's conservative-led government a clean bill of health despite the continuing participation of the anti-foreigner, far-right Freedom party.

According to a leaked version of the 119-point document, published on a Spanish media website, the "wise men" believe that it would be "counter-productive" to continue the sanctions adopted against Austria by all its of its EU partners after the chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel, formed his coalition in February.

"The measures have already generated nationalist sentiments in Austria, above all because they have sometimes been wrongly interpreted as sanctions against the Austrian people," the report adds.

The "wise men" strongly criticise the Freedom party itself, even though Jörg Haider, infamous for his sympathetic remarks about the Nazi period, has officially resigned as its leader. They say that the party's election campaign created an atmosphere where openly xenophobic demonstrations were a normal event. But in general, violence against foreigners has been less frequent in Austria than in other EU countries, they add.

France is the current holder of the EU's rotating presidency and, with Belgium, was a prime mover behind the decision to impose sanctions, so backing down now could be difficult for Mr Chirac. Most other EU members, including Britain, are keen for the measures to end, as is the commission president, Romano Prodi, who is expected to meet Mr Chirac in Paris today.

The "wise men" - the former Finnish president Martti Ahtisaari, the former Spanish foreign minister Marcelino Oreja and an international lawyer, Jochen Frowein of Germany - were commissioned to produce their report in June after months of impasse that came to bitterly divide the EU.

Specifically, the panel's job was to determine if the Austrian government respects "common European values" of democracy and human rights.

The freeze on bilateral relations, boycotts of school trips, cultural exchanges and military exercises, has had little impact on business and tourism in Austria. But officials in Brussels fear that it could delay vital preparations to admit new member states from eastern Europe.

The issue is complicated by the fact that Austria plans to hold a referendum on the sanctions next month, which is likely to produce a strong anti-EU vote.

The action against Austria has also alienated voters in Denmark and become an important factor in this month's knife-edge referendum on whether to adopt the euro in place of the krone.

fields.headline: How to get a  deposit back
fields.trailText: Landlords almost invariably charge a substantial deposit when they let property. This is, of course, done with the ostensible purpose of protecting them from loss caused by damage the tenants might cause or unpaid rent..
fields.body:
Landlords almost invariably charge a substantial deposit when they let property. This is, of course, done with the ostensible purpose of protecting them from loss caused by damage the tenants might cause or unpaid rent..

Some landlords, though, seem to regard this sum as a loan from tenants for their own benefit or even as an outright payment they are automatically entitled to keep.

Some hang on to deposits to cover spurious items of damage. In one case a landlord tried to keep a £200 deposit because of a broken toilet seat, which actually cost £16 to replace.

Others ignore tenants' requests for their money back altogether. This happened to Donna Eagle and Martin Sanchez when they left their flat in Leeds. The landlord failed to turn up on their last day, as agreed, to give them their £500 back, although they had left the property looking immaculate. When they rang him he put the phone down on them and their letters went unanswered.

Only after Donna, with the help of a legal executive friend, issued county court proceedings did they get their money back.

They sought interest on the sum from the day it was paid to the landlord and he did not dispute that they were entitled to that. However, a surprisingly large number of even apparently respectable landlords do not feel obliged to pay tenants the interest that accrues on a deposit.

Legally, though, unless there is a clear agreement to the contrary, that interest belongs to the tenant, as the deposit has never strictly speaking belonged to the landlord.

When a letting agency is used there may be more chance of the deposit being treated fairly. Tenants should ask the agency to confirm they are holding the deposit as "stakeholders" rather than as landlord's agents. The distinction may be too subtle for some agencies to understand but is important.

Stakeholders owe a duty to both landlord and tenant to deal with the matter fairly. If it is held as landlord's agents the agency is only accountable to the landlord for what they do with the money.

One way tenants can avoid the need for court proceedings to recover their own money is by not paying the final month's rent but asking the landlord to treat the deposit as representing that amount.

Landlords may not like this approach, and even some college accommodation agencies, although supposedly on the tenants' side, seem to discourage it.

However, if the tenants ask the landlord to inspect the property and promise to pay for any legitimate damages claim, honest landlords will not lose out. Theoretically, the tenant may breach the contract by doing this, but not in a way that actually leaves them liable to any action by the landlord.

For most tenants, though, the question of how to approach the deposit will depend upon their relationship with the landlord. One who has been easily contactable, has carried out repairs diligently and agreed to pay over the interest on the deposit, is much less likely to see that deposit as an opportunity to rip off tenants, than one who has let them down.

Good landlords may deserve the courtesy of being allowed to repay the deposit in their own time, but there is no reason why that should be extended to those who have already failed to honour their own legal obligations.

Richard Colbey is a barrister
