webTitle: Jobs: Sandra Deeble conducts a tour to becoming a holiday guide

fields.headline: An urge to keep on trekking
fields.standfirst: Ever thought of turning that adventure holiday into a full-time living? Sandra Deeble conducts a tour to becoming a guide
fields.trailText: Ever thought of turning that adventure holiday into a full-time living? Sandra Deeble conducts a tour to becoming a guide
fields.body:
Returning to the office after a summer holiday can have a back-to-school feel. You're still carrying around those Bonusprint envelopes on the off-chance that you'll find a new victim to inspire with your tales of trekking in Tanzania or chilling in Cornwall.

Thoughts may turn to a job which involves more travel, yet "working in travel" conjures up images of Michelle Collins in Sunburn: condemned to the challenges of pacifying punters who never stop whingeing about the cicadas keeping them awake at night.

Real travel is much more National Geographic: a trusty Nikon, battered Rohan boots, swimming with turtles - doing the world in your own inimitable style. But is it possible to combine real travel with work?

"The adventure travel companies are always looking for good people," says Lyn Hughes, editor of Wanderlust magazine. "It's not a well-paid profession, but it's a fun profession. You've got to be able to drink and have a sense of humour." And if that's beginning to sound a bit Club Med, Lyn is quick to point out: "Whether it's Thomson or Abercrombie and Kent, you've got to be able to give people a good time.

Indeed, in the blurb sent out by Thomson Holidays to would-be reps, applicants are warned: "Making sure all our customers have a great holiday is no holiday."

Yet surely working for a more upmarket operation would offer myriad opportunities for creative globetrotting?

"If you're a Thomson rep, you're going to be advising people on which karaoke bar to go to; with an adventure company, you might be running out of petrol when you're 80 miles from the next town. But you'll always get people whingeing about their rooms," Ms Hughes says bleakly.

It all seems to fall short on glamour. What is more, it's rather like the teacher who climbs the rungs of the educational ladder and ends up spending less time in the classroom; in travel, once you start to work your way up, you're likely to find yourself spending less time on the Silk Route and more on the Central Line.

Having spent time "in the field", as it were, many people become much more office-based. Isn't it difficult to toe the line? "I'm quite happy to be here for a while because it's a very dynamic environment. And I like it because I'm dealing with people I know in Latin America from my days as a tour leader," explains Liz Tremlett, who works in sales and operations at Journey Latin America. She keeps her hand in by doing the odd escorted trip, the next one being the Hummingbird: a taster of Brazil, Paraguay, Bolivia and Peru in 22 days.

With a degree in Latin American studies, working for Journey Latin America is almost a vocation, Ms Tremlett feels.

"Once you get the language you can make massive inroads into understanding the culture. I just like the way things work. It's relaxed, I like the way that people deal with you: they're much more affectionate, it's much warmer." This warmth even extends to the working environment back in London, she says.

"It's a company where a lot of people share your passion for Latin America so there are quite a few office romances. And in the field, says Lyn Hughes, there's even more scope for romantic encounters: "You get all that: 'Let's put up that tent together.' 'Let's light that fire together'."

Someone whose tent-erecting experience led her to her husband is Linda Hearn. After meeting at Canvas Holidays they set up Inntravel in 1984. Short breaks, walking, cycling and painting holidays are particularly attractive to the empty nesters, explains Linda, who believes that the opportunity now for tour operators is: "To give added value and added service: the things that customers can't organise on their own. That's the challenge."

Indeed, a recent survey carried out by Wanderlust magazine reveals that only 11% of readers use a high street travel agent, with 39% booking flights and accommodation direct through the internet while the rest are using specialist tour operators.

But is there life after even the most up-market repping?

"We feel we've now got a structure where people have got a little bit of a career path. If you get to be a product manager then you do get to travel a lot," says Linda Hearn. "But one thing about working in the travel industry is that you end up doing a lot of travelling and not a lot of staying put. For years our kids thought that a holiday was going around checking hotel bedrooms, but then they realised that some of their friends went to a beach in Spain for two weeks and didn't look at anybody else's bedrooms".

Checking bedrooms, bars and restaurants is also part of the job description for Neal Bedford, travel writer for Lonely Planet. In an environment where the publishing manager Katharine Leck gets 10 to 15 approaches from aspiring Lonely Planet writers each week, Neal got his foot in the door via the post-room route.

"I walked into the offices in September 98 and said: 'I'll do anything.' They said: 'If you want to pack some books, we've got a job for you'.

"Originally I wanted to get into cartography. I thought that writing was an untouchable job. But after eight months I did a sample chapter on Docklands. They liked it in the office and that's how I got into it."

Mr Bedford can spend up to three weeks travelling and then three weeks writing. Since he started in March, he's been to Extremadura in Spain and the next stop is Vienna - he's busy now until Christmas. But all the Lonely Planet writers are employed on a freelance basis.

"We pay a fee and on top of that we pay a daily expenses rate is how it works," according to Katharine Leck.

"And you're given a huge style manual and you have to learn that pretty much off by heart," explains Mr Bedford. "Lonely Planet likes you to put a bit of yourself into the book."

Travel writing, and putting a bit of yourself in the book, has always been up there on the dream job list and you can even learn how it's done. At the Arvon Foundation, where tutors include the likes of William Dalrymple, the travel writing courses are immensely popular and are consistently over-subscribed.

"I suppose there's a lot more freedom in this industry," says Mr Bedford, who is actually a trained accountant. "Although I wouldn't say that this is a particularly secure job. You do it because you've got a passion for travelling."

Yet anyone else dreaming of doing a shimmy from accountancy into travel would do well to heed the warning of Lyn Hughes: "An awful lot of people go on wonderful trips and come back and say they want to do something in travel. But you've got to like people, not just places."

Simon Heyes works at Last Frontiers, a company which specialises in tailor-made holidays in South America.

"I'm very happy where I am at the moment. There are four of us and we all do pretty much the same job: we all run the business right the way through and we do a hell of a lot of travelling.

"Since I started working in travel the market has expanded massively. There's an awful lot more affluence around: people with disposable income who want to get a little bit off the beaten track and who don't mind spending £7,000-£8,000 for two people.

"Where the travelling comes in is zipping off as much as we can to see new places. It's all about finding new haciendas and estancias and the only way you can do that is to actually go there. We know about 95% of everything we sell, which I think is pretty unusual.

"Friends think my job sounds absolutely amazing but I've probably become quite blase about it. It's a lifestyle I've got quite used to, although if it ever did stop it would probably be quite a shock."

Sandra Winnick is volunteer programme manager at Earthwatch, an international charity which promotes sustainable conservation by supporting scientific field research and education. Members of the public can work as volunteers alongside field scientists and prices range from £65 for two days to £2,800 for six weeks.

"I used to work for STA Travel but I decided around two years ago that I wanted to move into the charitable sector. Earthwatch wanted someone who was concerned about the actual mission but who also had commercial experience and an understanding of the travel industry.

"I suppose that my job is travel with a difference. We send people all over the world; it's very much like booking a special type of holiday.

"I joined the Spanish dolphins project in July. Two scientists near Almeria have been trying to gather enough data to supply the Ministry of Environment with sufficient information to set up marine protected areas.

"You're on a boat - a refurbished Norwegian fishing vessel - and there's a roster, so you have a go at every activity from putting up the sails to going up to the crow's nest to watch for dolphins. It's quite an unusual way of spending your holiday time but more and more people are looking for something different.

"Over the past few years, people who started with package tours moved on to the tailor-made idea and now some people are saying: 'I've had enough of that, I want to try something different'. With Earthwatch, sometimes you're going into rainforests not normally open to tourists, so it really offers a very different experience."

Earthwatch wanted someone who was concerned about the actual mission but who also had commercial experience and an understanding of the travel industry. "I suppose that my job is travel with a difference. We send people all over the world; it's very much like booking a special type of holiday. "I joined the Spanish dolphins project in July. Two scientists near Almeria have been trying to gather enough data to supply the Ministry of Environment with sufficient information to set up marine protected areas. "You're on a boat - a refurbished Norwegian fishing vessel - and there's a roster, so you have a go at every activity from putting up the sails to going up to the crow's nest to watch for dolphins. It's quite an unusual way of spending your holiday time but more and more people are looking for something different. "Over the past few years, people who started with package tours moved on to the tailor-made idea and now some people are saying: 'I've had enough of that, I want to try something different'. With Earthwatch, sometimes you're going into rainforests not normally open to tourists, so it really offers a very different experience."

webTitle: Notebook: Rank's film fadeout may be too rapid

fields.headline: Smith is taking too much of a gamble
fields.standfirst: Film fadeout may be too rapid
fields.trailText: Despite his striking similarity to Michael Caine, Rank's chief executive, Mike Smith, has displayed precious little sentimentality for the company's cinematic heritage.
fields.body:
Despite his striking similarity to Michael Caine, Rank's chief executive, Mike Smith, has displayed precious little sentimentality for the company's cinematic heritage.

The printer's son from Plaistow has ripped the guts out of a much loved British institution with astonishing speed - since last April he has raised £760m by selling businesses and spent just £25m on acquisitions.

The businesses on the block represent a roll-call of the country's heritage; they include the Pinewood film studio, Butlins holiday camps and Odeon cinemas.

These are hardly the actions of a management team with ambition, although Mr Smith can legitimately point out that he walked into an impossible situation. When he arrived, Rank's debts were close to £1.5bn and profits were in steep decline.

There was some dead wood in the Rank portfolio - the Tom Cobleigh pub chain, for example, was too small to be a viable growth business. Odeon cinemas were swallowing cash and the Deluxe video duplication operation, which Rank still owns, has a limited future as video tapes are replaced by DVDs.

However, Mr Smith's apparent desire to concentrate on gaming seems somewhat arbitrary. Bingo is hardly a dynamic long-term prospect and casinos are a notoriously accident-prone businesses, quite apart from the vagaries of regulatory changes.

Cynics suggest Mr Smith is simply sticking to what he knows best: he used to run the gambling group Ladbrokes. He is right to be ruthless where necessary but he is in danger of taking the word "focus" a tad too literally.

After shock

The London market is suffering a serious attack of the fundamentals. "Top-down" analysts across the Square Mile are having panicky discussions with their "bottom-up" colleagues about how these things called earnings (which were apparently used as a crude measure of value until the end of the last century) might be affected by a squeeze in the price of a raw material called crude oil.

In fact, what we are witnessing is a display of non-globalisation with an accompanying reminder that markets can be very imperfect. The oil price "shock" has happened so suddenly it has taken 18 months. The price per barrel has sat above $30 for much of this year. Truckers in the US have been up in arms, blockading freeways, harassing politicians and the like, since Christmas.

Yet a good portion of the financial elite, sitting in the international centre of London, had not allowed anything so much as a grease spot to spoil their rosy prognoses for corporate profitability.

A reminder that the productivity improvements associated with technological innovation, which have fired the mighty US economy over the past few years, have not rubbed out all rules of economics is welcome.

At the same time, as Opec meets in Vienna this weekend, there is no reason for investors to panic. A good few profit warnings may be in the pipeline. The City's number-crunchers will be fettling their figures. But there is no evidence yet to suggest this is the "event" to blow away an equity bull market that is now close to its tenth anniversary.

Optional extras

Manchester United got into a typical on/off-the-pitch pickle yesterday, with manager Sir Alex Ferguson musing aloud to a fanzine about how he might lock in his most precious talent with share options, leaving the football club's City advisers to rush around all afternoon trying to quash the story.

For a publicly listed company, regardless of its particular business, there are procedures for things like doling out equity kickers. And Manchester United's hard-headed chairman, Roland Smith, knows that because his firm is in the particular (some may say peculiar) business of football it has to be whiter than white when it comes to stock market protocol.

However, setting such technicalities aside (and ignoring the inevitable montage photos of Roy Keane with a fat furry paunch, whiskers and tail), there is something quite inevitable about Mr Ferguson's suggestion.

The demise of rampant dot.commery may have dashed many dreams of overnight riches from share option packages. Yet the shift in the distribution of awards from enterprise, associated with the new economy and born in Silicon Valley, is still happening.

Providers of capital, such as venture capitalists, have clawed back some ground over recent months. Their resource has become more scarce. But key employees, the real producers, are demanding a greater and more transparent share of the rewards. In this matter, football is just like any other creative business.

fields.headline: 'Fat controller' boosts health club muscle
fields.trailText: Railways millionaire Sandy Anderson yesterday added significant muscle to his efforts to reinvent himself as a health and fitness boss by paying £15m for a North-east based health clubs group.
fields.body:
Railways millionaire Sandy Anderson yesterday added significant muscle to his efforts to reinvent himself as a health and fitness boss by paying £15m for a North-east based health clubs group.

Mr Anderson's Mazaran Leisure is paying £15.25m for Springhealth Fitness, operator of seven clubs in cities including Newcastle, Sunderland and Hartlepool. The cash, shares and loan notes deal will double Mazaran's size and complement its six largely southern-based health clubs. Shares in Mazaran climbed p to 30p.

Mr Anderson made £33m from the sale of the Porterbrook train-leasing firm to Stagecoach, a coup that saw him dubbed "the fat controller".

He has since backed several ventures including London wine theme park Vinopolis and AIM-listed pubs group Honeycombe Leisure where he holds majority stakes. Springhealth's 71-year-old owner, Stan Henry, will emerge as the biggest shareholder in the enlarged Mazaran with a stake of around 30%. Mr Anderson's stake will be diluted to 25.8%. However, Mr Anderson remains chairman and plans further deals: "There is going to be consolidation in the industry and we expect to be at the front of it."

In the six months to February 29 Mazaran made a pre-tax loss of £686,000, against £620,000 the previous time.

fields.headline: BA seeks pact with Northwest
fields.standfirst: Board considers ditching American to ease merger
fields.trailText: British Airways is to push for a transatlantic partnership with Northwest Airlines of the US as part of its £3.1bn merger with Dutch rival KLM, in a move likely to shake up the global web of airline alliances.
fields.body:
British Airways is to push for a transatlantic partnership with Northwest Airlines of the US as part of its £3.1bn merger with Dutch rival KLM, in a move likely to shake up the global web of airline alliances.

BA's decision to press for a Northwest alliance effectively jettisons its efforts to seek a closer tie-up with American Airlines, Northwest's US rival.

The BA recommendation is due to be put to the board early next week by senior company executives, the Guardian has learned, in an effort to clear away one of the main barriers to a full merger with KLM. The move will leave a question mark over the Oneworld alliance led by American which includes BA.

A deal with KLM could still be called off at any time as financial details of the merger have still not been agreed months after talks began.

However, Rod Eddington, BA chief executive, is understood to have decided that the company's best chance of winning regulatory approval in the US for further landing slots would come from trying to take over KLM's established partnership with Northwest.

Next week's board meeting comes a fortnight before the next round of talks in London on the open skies agreement between the US and British governments.

Trade negotiators believe that BA will have to offer concessions on its landing slots at Heathrow, Britain's busiest airport, to gain regulatory approval for KLM's pact to be carried over. US regulators have voiced concern about any attempt by BA to gain a stronger foothold in the US market "by the back door".

KLM gained immunity from competition investigations into its alliance with Northwest some time ago.

BA's previous attempts to negotiate a closer relationship with American, which would effectively mean more flights between Britain and the US, had been stalled by US demands that more Heathrow slots were opened up.

As well as deciding that regulators may be more inclined to agree a Northwest alliance, senior executives at BA are understood to have decided that the cost of trying to extricate the company from KLM's arrangement with Northwest would be too onerous.

Someone with knowledge of the talks said yesterday: "Northwest did a brilliant deal with KLM and they will do the same with BA."

BA refused to comment on the details of the talks with KLM yesterday. A spokesman said: "KLM has agreements with Northwest which are an important part of their business and as part of our discussions with them we are looking at how this might fit in."

He warned that "while progress is continuing, we don't have an agreement in place".

BA's decision to plump for Northwest adds a further twist to a transatlantic merry-go-round of partnerships complicated by a fresh round of takeover talks this summer.

In recent weeks, industry analysts have speculated that American, the second largest airline in the US, may be looking to join other global alliances such as the Qualiflyer group led by Swissair.

fields.headline: Lost boys
fields.standfirst:
It is one rule for the offspring of prime ministers, quite another for a son of Belfast

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: On Wednesday, Jean McBride, whose son, Peter, was murdered by Scots Guards James Fisher and Mark Wright in 1992, went to Downing Street to hand in a letter about the continued employment by the British army of the two murderers. She had already submitted a letter in April, but Downing Street recently admitted that it has been lost. Y'know what it's like with kids around. I expect one of them used the back of it to do a drawing, or threw up on it.
fields.body:
On Wednesday, Jean McBride, whose son, Peter, was murdered by Scots Guards James Fisher and Mark Wright in 1992, went to Downing Street to hand in a letter about the continued employment by the British army of the two murderers. She had already submitted a letter in April, but Downing Street recently admitted that it has been lost. Y'know what it's like with kids around. I expect one of them used the back of it to do a drawing, or threw up on it.

In any event, Jean was taking no chances. Her new letter was enlarged to three feet by four and laminated. Let us hope that it does not get used as a changing mat. I invade the privacy of the Blair children in this way because yesterday morning I was listening to Lord Wakeham of the Press Complaints Commission, whose annual report is just out, speaking on the Today programme about the high quality of the British press and its rare lapses. Much of the interview involved his efforts to protect the prime minister's baby from press intrusion.

Given that this is one lord who does not owe his ennoblement to Tony Blair, I was slightly puzzled about why Wakeham is so eager to do his bidding. One would have thought that politicians, who habitually lunge into their constituents' prams with photographers in tow, would occupy the low moral ground on this question.

And I would think that, given the lies Jean McBride has read about the murder of her son, and Wakeham's concern about articles that are "inaccurate or intrude on private grief", the PCC would be a body with better things to do. But let's be honest, Leo Blair is the son of the prime minister, and Peter McBride was just some paddy who got shot.

This week involved a number of anniversaries for Mrs McBride. On September 2 1998, Mo Mowlam released Wright and Fisher from jail. This had nothing to do with the Good Friday agreement. As far as anyone knows, the only loyalist organisation to which they belong is the Scots Guards, and it is not on ceasefire. Their release came two days before the anniversary of their crime.

On Wednesday, it was exactly one year since the high court in Belfast ordered the British army to reconsider its breach of Queen's Regulations in retaining soldiers who had received a custodial sentence, in this case a sentence for murder. Jean came to London to attempt to find out why the army board is taking so long to reconsider its decision. Perhaps the file has been lost.

Press interest in her visit was scanty but she did give a quick radio interview on BBC Northern Ireland. In the interests of balance, of course, the Scottish MP, Tam Dalyell, was then interviewed to stick up for the soldiers, as though somehow the fact that Jean once had a son and he is now dead is merely her opinion.

She is of course used to the popularity of her son's killers in the media. Ludovic Kennedy has used the Daily Mail to say that Peter was a known IRA sympathiser. Kennedy had much to say about the republican sympathies in the New Lodge area, including a magnificent interpretation of working-class Belfast life: "Residents often kept their doors open to provide escape routes for the IRA." In fact, the RUC knew Peter well as a petty thief and have consistently said that he was neither a paramilitary nor a sympathiser. But Kennedy is a grand old man of the media, above such trifles, though not above printing the McBrides' address in full, which proved of assistance to the many people who wished to send them sectarian hate mail.

One would have thought that bringing death threats down on people verges on intrusiveness. And given the PCC's urgent wish to help "prominent people" you would think a person whose home has been identified in a national newspaper would count.

Jean might have gone to the PCC were it not for its earlier rejection of a complaint when the Mail and the Standard repeated the lie that Wright and Fisher believed Peter was carrying a bomb. Every court that has looked at the case concluded the killers were lying, for the simple reason that Peter had just been thoroughly searched by their patrol. He was carrying a T-shirt. Indeed, if they had seriously believed that Peter had a bomb, you might think they would have warned other soldiers and RUC officers who approached the youth as he lay dying in an alley.

Last year, the McBrides saw the Daily Mail run a two-page spread with extracts from a book by the mercenary Colonel Tim Spicer, who was Wright and Fisher's commanding officer. Spicer repeated the old lie among a welter of other inventions - some completely new. Jean was moved to try the PCC again. The commission found the book to be mere "comment" and absolved the Mail from responsibility.

Still, terrible about that christening photo of Leo Blair though, wasn't it?

comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Court threat to Axa over payout that 'short-changes' policyholders

fields.headline: Court threat to Axa over payout that 'short-changes' policyholders
fields.trailText: The Consumers' Association yesterday threatened to mount a legal challenge against insurance group Axa's plans for dividing up £1.7bn in surplus cash after claiming the company was short-changing its 660,000 policyholders.
fields.body:
The Consumers' Association yesterday threatened to mount a legal challenge against insurance group Axa's plans for dividing up £1.7bn in surplus cash after claiming the company was short-changing its 660,000 policyholders.

The CA said the insurer was offering policyholders a "shoddy deal" and added that it was willing to contest Axa's proposals in court on their behalf. The company replied that what it was offering was fair.

During the last fortnight Axa policyholders have received windfall packs detailing how much they will gain from the distribution of its "orphan assets" - money which has been built up over the years from surpluses and unclaimed bonuses. It is proposing to give policyholders a cash payment averaging £400 plus a further bonus which will be added to the value of policies. The plans need to be approved by customers and ratified by the High Court at a hearing in November.

However the CA said it had closely examined the deal and concluded that policyholders would only be getting a total of £525m, or 31%, of the orphan assets, with the company's shareholders receiving arguably more than their entitlement.

Recommendations from the Treasury have previously stated that policyholders are generally entitled to at least 90% of these funds, and that shareholders should receive no more than 10%, the CA said.

Shareholders would receive at least £319m, or 19%, directly, and will benefit indirectly from the fact that Axa wants to put aside £836m, almost half of the total cash, to cover possible tax and other liabilities, it added. Careful tax planning should considerably reduce Axa's tax liabilities, so in reality a significant proportion of this money could end up going to shareholders, according to the consumer body.

"Axa has carved up this money so that shareholders come out on top," said Ashley Holmes, head of legal affairs at the CA. "Anyone who is not happy with this deal should contact Consumers' Association. If policyholders want us to help them, we will contest this deal on their behalf." The CA said it had sought advice from leading actuaries including KPMG.

A spokesman for Axa said: "We maintain this is a fair deal for policyholders." He added that the financial services authority and an independent actuary supported the proposals.

The company would be discussing the matter with the CA at a meeting on Monday and it was "perfectly happy" that the views of the policyholders were going to be represented at the High Court hearing, he said.

webTitle: Loss of Rank Leisure group may scrap famous name

fields.headline: Loss of Rank Leisure group may scrap famous name
fields.trailText: Rank's chief executive, Mike Smith, wants to bring down the curtain on the leisure group's famous name as his break-up of the company takes it further from its cinematic roots.
fields.body:
Rank's chief executive, Mike Smith, wants to bring down the curtain on the leisure group's famous name as his break-up of the company takes it further from its cinematic roots.

Since Mr Smith's appointment early last year, Rank has sold Pinewood film studio, the Odeon cinemas and its share in a Universal Studios theme park in Florida. He confirmed yesterday that the clear-out is likely to continue, with several buyers interested in the group's holiday arm.

"At some stage we will have to consider whether Rank is an appropriate name. When Rank was in films it was obviously very relevant but since then we've moved off in other directions and you wonder whether the Rank name has any goodwill left in it."

fields.headline: Wetherspoon considers second pub brand
fields.trailText: JD Wetherspoon is considering rolling out a second pub brand, according to chairman Tim Martin, who yesterday announced a 37.5% surge in annual pre-tax profits to £36m.
fields.body:
JD Wetherspoon is considering rolling out a second pub brand, according to chairman Tim Martin, who yesterday announced a 37.5% surge in annual pre-tax profits to £36m.

Mr Martin said the company would test the progress of ten Lloyds Number One outlets, bought in June from Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries.

He said: "If they get up to the average sales of Wetherspoon pubs, we will have to look at the possibility of using them as a second brand."

Lloyds Number One outlets have a more "modern, minimalist" interior than Wetherspoon's other pubs. Furthermore, they play music - offering an "eclectic mix of non-chart contemporary music", unlike the rest of the group's pubs.

Wetherspoon originally intended to convert the ten pubs to its own brand, but Mr Martin said he had been impressed by the quality of their fittings and by a recent rise in takings.

Wetherspoon opened 101 pubs last year, taking the total to 428. It recently took its format of large bars, cheap beer and no-smoking areas to the Republic of Ireland for the first time, despite being unable to stock Guinness there due to a dispute over prices.

Like-for-like sales rose 16.9% in the first six months but growth slowed to 7.6% in the second half. Mr Martin said sales increases were returning to a more realistic level, after two outstanding years. The shares rose 8.5p to 367.5p.

webTitle: Jodie and Mary: the point where the law, ethics, religion and humanity are baffled

fields.headline: Jodie and Mary: the point where the law, ethics, religion and humanity are baffled
fields.standfirst: Appeal case on conjoined twins tackles conflicting principles
fields.trailText: A doctor arrives at the scene of an accident to discover two injured men. He immediately sees that one is so badly hurt that he is bound to die but the second could be saved. But the first man is lying on top of the second and moving him would inevitably hasten his death.
fields.body:
A doctor arrives at the scene of an accident to discover two injured men. He immediately sees that one is so badly hurt that he is bound to die but the second could be saved. But the first man is lying on top of the second and moving him would inevitably hasten his death.

What should the doctor do? Would it be right for him to move the first man even though this would accelerate his death in order to save the life of the second? Does he have the right to choose to save one life though his actions would harm a second?

This is the sort of dilemma - taking in complex legal, moral and ethical issues - which the lawyers embroiled in the case of conjoined twins Jodie and Mary have been confronting as they frame arguments for and against the separation operation which would save one of the girls but kill the other.

At one level, the case is a heartbreaking human story. It is impossible to imagine the torment of the girls' parents whose Roman Catholic beliefs mean that they cannot give permission for a procedure which would bring about the death of Mary, only kept alive by the oxygenated blood she receives from her sister. On another level, the case has raised a series of profound questions which are troubling some of Britain's sharpest legal minds and most serious moral and religious thinkers.

Ultimately, the case could have implications about the way the courts and society at large look at fundamental life and death issues.

This weekend a team of eminent lawyers will be attempting, at the behest of the attorney general, to pin down one of the central legal problems of the case - whether the separation will constitute a criminal offence.

If, when the appeal recommences on Wednesday, a definitive argument concludes that the operation could be judged as murder or manslaughter, then the job of the three judges becomes infinitely more straightforward.

The courts cannot authorise a step which would "actively terminate a life" - even to relieve misery and even if the patient or a parent consents. Life can never be terminated by a positive action, such as an injection, but only by the withdrawal of treatment or food.

In the original high court ruling which gave doctors the go-ahead to carry out the separation, Mr Justice Johnson based his judgement on the assertion that Mary's death would be caused by the interruption or withdrawal of the blood supply. This could be compared to the withholding of nourishment, as in the case of Hillsborough football disaster survivor Tony Bland, who spent almost four years in a persistent vegetative state before a ruling that doctors would not be acting unlawfully if they stopped feeding him by tube.

From the start of the appeal, the issue of lawfulness has been central. Lord Justice Brooke, a former chairman of the law commission, described the criminal law aspects of the case as "astonishingly difficult". In one of the most dramatic moments of the case, he brandished a photograph of the girls and asked how a separation could be carried out without a criminal assault on Mary.

The judges also raised the possibility that a crime might be committed if an operation took place because it would lead to Mary's death - or if it did not because this would lead to Jodie's death. If the twins remained conjoined, doctors believe both will die within six months.

Entwined in this legal argument is the most difficult moral issue. Can it ever be right for a doctor to save one life at the expense of another?

Ethicists believe the problem can be approached in two ways. A utilitarian approach is that it is better to save one life even at the cost of another. The absolutist approach - as put forward by the parents and largely backed by Catholic thinkers - is that it can never be right to sacrifice a life.

The Archbishop of Westminster Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, said: "There is a fundamental moral principle at stake - no one may commit a wrong action that good may come of it. The parents in this case have made it clear that they love both their children equally and cannot consent to one of them being killed to help the other. I believe this moral instinct is right. It would set a very dangerous precedent to enshrine in English case law that it was ever right to kill a person that good may come of it."

In 1993 doctors at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia faced a similar quandary over whether to separate conjoined twins Amy and Angela Lakeberg. Doctors said the twins would die within weeks if they were not separated but also knew the operation would result in Amy's death. The parents agreed to the operation and Angela survived for 10 months.

The case sparked a national debate. Alice Dreger, an historian of anatomy at the Michi gan State University, was one of those who forcefully put forward the argument that if the twins had been born separate and the health of both was failing, nobody would have suggested that one sickly twin should be killed and her organs taken for the sake of the other.

David Thomasma, professor of medical ethics at Chicago's Loyola University Medical Centre, also studied the moral implications of the Lakeberg case. He said: "I remember during the debate how quickly people who wanted to intervene could move into the idea that one twin was like a parasite or an appendage - language that makes one morally able to divide them."

In former times, conjoined twins were often used at funfair freak shows. Even today the way they should be regarded remains unclear. During the appeal, Lord Justice Ward put the problem in stark terms when he asked if Jodie and Mary were individuals or the "more horrifying concept" of one person with two heads.

At another point his comments echoed the idea of the weaker of the twins being a parasite when he said: "She's hooked into her sister, draining her sister's life blood from her and will eventually kill her."

If they could be treated as a single entity, it might have made the decision easier: an operation to separate Mary from Jodie could have been compared to a procedure to remove a diseased limb threatening a whole body.

At first glance the law concerning the parents seems more straightforward. While "great weight" has to be attached to their wishes, the court has a duty to ignore them in the best interests of the child.

But Richard Nicholson, editor of the Bulletin of Medical Ethics, suggested that the judges in this instance simply could not make the decision. "In a situation like this when there isn't an obvious right answer, do we not need to put the onus for the decision back on to those for whom it will mean the most, those who are going to have to live with the consequences of the decision? Surely we have to give great power and credence to the parents?"

A complicating factor here is the extraordinary circumstances which have resulted in the case being heard before a British court. The parents come from a remote, unidentified European community with different customs and values to Britain's. They are here because their government has an agreement with Britain that a certain number of people can be treated within the NHS.

Presumably their case would be treated differently if they came before the courts in their own country. But legal experts believe that any efforts by the parents to leave - not that there has been a suggestion that they have tried to - could result in the twins being made wards of court. In effect they are trapped.

And so to the inevitable question of religion. In another dramatic courtroom moment, Lord Justice Ward suggested that it could not be "God's will" that Mary survive because she had not been born with the capacity for independent life. The parents' position remains that it is not "God's will" that people terminate life.

Much of modern British criminal law - which will be the subject of microscopic examination this weekend by those who will be representing the attorney general on Wednesday - is based on 19th-century case law made by judges basing their conclusions on Judaeo-Christian principles.

The thorny question of whether Mary was a "viable" being has also been addressed. If she had not been connected to Jodie she would have died because she lacked a functioning heart or lungs.

The judges queried whether Mary had in fact been "born alive" given the fact that she depended on her twin for her very life breath.

Pro life campaigners are appalled at the notion that Mary might not be considered to have been born alive, pointing out that a decision which would lead to her death could be the thin end of a terrifying wedge. Could a ruling which called into question Mary's very right to be thought of as a human being have implications for severely disabled people?

Helen Watt, research fellow at the Linacre Centre for Healthcare Ethics, said: "Medicine is all about supporting ill people. There are disabled people all over the country who without medical help would die. Are they all non-persons?"

But is Mary's life worthwhile? Technological advances, of course, mean that increasingly patients can be kept alive even when in many eyes death would be preferable.

Former master of the rolls Lord Donaldson ruled that a "balancing exercise" was needed. There was a "strong presumption" in a course of action which would prolong life but said it was not "irrebuttable". Account had to be taken of the pain, suffering and quality of life which a child would experience if life was prolonged.

Counsel on behalf of Mary insisted that the sanctity of life - again a phrase with religious resonances - meant that there was a powerful argument for her to be kept alive in the absence of the lack of proof that she was in pain.

The ethicists point out in a secular society whose people do not believe in a life after death, the fact of physical existence becomes ever more important and the efforts of doctors are concentrated ever more on keeping life going no matter what.

When those decisions are opposed by parents who do have a strong faith - and have to be ratified in a court whose laws are based on religious principles - there is bound to be a clash.

Battle to discard 'circus act' description of babies
Raekha Prasad

In Italy they are gemelli siamesi ; the French call them frères siamois or soeurs siamoises ; and in Spanish they are hermanos siameses or hermanas siamesas . Even the Thais - who no longer refer to their country as Siam - use the term to describe twins whose bodies are joined.

Although it is being used to describe the case of Mary and Jodie, a spokesman for Great Ormond Street children's hospital, said: "'Siamese twins' is not used by anyone in the hospital. We consider it inaccurate and patronising, unless the twins are actually from Thailand. We have had a small battle since the beginning of this story to correct the term."

It comes from Chang and Eng Bunker, born joined at the chest in Thailand in 1811. They became a US circus act.

Harvey Marcovitch, a consultant paediatrician and editor of the journal of the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, said the term had not been used in medical circles for at least 20 years; the profession used it only when talking to lay people. Conjoined was used instead.

In the 1960s the term spastic was not considered pejorative. It became cerebral palsy and is now neuron-impaired. Until the second world war, it was acceptable to call people with learning disabilities morons and idiots. By the 1970s the preferred term was educationally subnormal. By the 1980s it had changed to learning disabilities, and now one term used is special needs.

webTitle: Up to 20 slain in West Timor rampage

fields.headline: Up to 20 slain in West Timor rampage
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Eleven residents of a small village in Indonesian West Timor were murdered on Thursday by a rampaging mob, the Indonesian military confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
Eleven residents of a small village in Indonesian West Timor were murdered on Thursday by a rampaging mob, the Indonesian military confirmed yesterday.

Unnamed UN sources in the East Timorese capital, Dili, said the death toll was 20 but they refused to give details and the reports could not be confirmed.

It is thought that the perpetrators were pro-Jakarta militiamen linked to the group that killed three UN workers in the nearby town of Atambua the previous day.

As militiamen continued house-to-house searches and set up roadblocks across West Timor in a bid to find anyone linked to international humanitarian organisations, the UN completed its airlift of approximately 300 foreign and local employees of international organisations that have been working in West Timor.

Major-General Kiki Syahnakri, Indonesia's regional commander covering West Timor, told UN officials that the massacre occurred in the village of Bese Kama, a few miles from the border with East Timor. He claimed that it happened during a clash between local people and some of the tens of thousands of East Timorese refugees living in the area.

"Kiki said the locals were driven from their homes in the chaos," said Jake Morland, a spokesman for the United Nations high commissioner for refugees West Timor operation, who is now in Bali.

"Indonesian soldiers guarding the border with East Timor left their posts and went to the village to restore order. It was as they were doing that that they discovered the bodies." Neither the victims' identities nor ages were released.

While the Indonesian Army is blaming the East Timorese refugees, the UN believes it is the militia living among the refugees who are responsible for the current violence.

Bese Kama is an area where the UNHCR has been unable to operate since July because of threats and violence against its staff. After its office in the nearest town, Betum, was stoned seven weeks ago the staff were pulled out and have not been back since.

A police intelligence sergeant in Atambua said yesterday: "The militia are in complete control in many areas around Betum. We are waiting for more reinforcements before we can even attempt to restore law and order."

There are more than 2,500 Indonesian police and soldiers currently in West Timor but they appear to be having little impact on the militia.

"The militia are moving around West Timor with impunity," Mr Morland said. "They are going from house to house searching for anyone who has had links to us or our partner organisations."

The problem is exacerbated by the fact that the militia are not a homogeneous force, but disparate rumps of various paramilitary groups that existed in East Timor before the independence referendum just over a year ago. Their ranks have been swelled by thousands of new recruits.

Indonesian officials admit the situation is deteriorating, but the government in Jakarta appears to have little sense of crisis. Senior security minister Bambang Yudhoyono merely said yesterday that it was doing all it could "to find a comprehensive solution and total settlement regarding the refugees and the militias and interaction between them".

In a stinging editorial yesterday, the influential Jakarta Post said: "The government has wasted too much time pussyfooting with the military, who seem determined to prevent their senior generals from facing trial [over the destruction in East Timor last year].

"Surely the government must now realise that the shame and disgrace which the Atambua killings have brought on the entire nation is simply too high a price to pay to shield the dozens of murderous generals... and militia leaders."

A police intelligence sergeant in Atambua said yesterday: "The militia are in complete control in many areas around Betum. We are waiting for more reinforcements before we can even attempt to restore law and order." There are more than 2,500 Indonesian police and soldiers currently in West Timor but they appear to be having little impact on the militia. "The militia are moving around West Timor with impunity," Mr Morland said. "They are going from house to house searching for anyone who has had links to us or our partner organisations." The problem is exacerbated by the fact that the militia are not a homogeneous force, but disparate rumps of various paramilitary groups that existed in East Timor before the independence referendum just over a year ago. Their ranks have been swelled by thousands of new recruits. Indonesian officials admit the situation is deteriorating, but the government in Jakarta appears to have little sense of crisis. Senior security minister Bambang Yudhoyono merely said yesterday that it was doing all it could "to find a comprehensive solution and total settlement regarding the refugees and the militias and interaction between them". In a stinging editorial yesterday, the influential Jakarta Post said: "The government has wasted too much time pussyfooting with the military, who seem determined to prevent their senior generals from facing trial [over the destruction in East Timor last year]. "Surely the government must now realise that the shame and disgrace which the Atambua killings have brought on the entire nation is simply too high a price to pay to shield the dozens of murderous generals... and militia leaders."

fields.headline: Last ferry
fields.standfirst: Strike blocks Europe's longest river
fields.trailText: Disgruntled Romanian shippers blockaded a stretch of the river Danube yesterday, demonstrating their frustration at heavy losses in trade due to Nato's air strike against Serbia last year which has paralysed the waterway.
fields.body:
Disgruntled Romanian shippers blockaded a stretch of the river Danube yesterday, demonstrating their frustration at heavy losses in trade due to Nato's air strike against Serbia last year which has paralysed the waterway.

The Romanian shippers' union placed barges and tugboats across the river at Clarasi, 60 miles south-east of Bucharest, as protesters called for the swift reopening of a navigable channel.

Nato bombing destroyed three bridges over the Danube at Novi Sad.

The shippers' main complaint is that the Yugoslav authorities have failed to unblock navigation at Novi Sad, thus violating international law. They say they have lost more than £100m in trade since June last year and have received little or no compensation for the blocking of their cheapest transport link to western Europe.

The EU has assigned €22m (£13.4m) to pay for clearing up the Danube. Experts say that shipping on the full length of Europe's longest river, which connects 10 countries, will not resume before next year.

fields.headline: Policeman cleared of indecency charges
fields.trailText: A senior policeman alleged to have been "unable to control his sexual behaviour" was cleared yesterday of sexually assaulting two women.
fields.body:
A senior policeman alleged to have been "unable to control his sexual behaviour" was cleared yesterday of sexually assaulting two women.

Ian Beckett, deputy chief constable of Surrey police, had denied charges of indecently assaulting the two civilian workers at the force's headquarters in Guildford in December 1998.

After the jury at Southwark crown court returned the not guilty verdicts, it was revealed that Mr Beckett had tried to kill himself last March by taking an overdose of pills.

The prosecution had accused Mr Beckett, 54, of subjecting the women, who cannot be named, to "humiliating and degrading" ordeals.

One told the jury of first being hugged in his locked and darkened office and on a later occasion being forced to endure him touching her private parts after he asked her to wear red underwear for him as a "Christmas treat".

The other woman said Mr Beckett, a father of two from Chertsey, Surrey, put his hand up her skirt to touch the top of her thigh in an initial attack, before kissing her and fondling one of her breasts in a follow-up assault. Later, she alleged he repeatedly asked her to let him make love to her.

But the jury took just over five-hours to clear him of four counts of indecency. In his defence, Mr Beckett had claimed he was the victim of "lies and fantasy".

As the not guilty verdicts were returned, Mr Beckett, who has been suspended on full pay since January last year, smiled. Gaynor, his wife of 33 years who was in the court throughout the trial, burst into tears and hugged him.

Sallie Bennett-Jenkins, prosecuting, told the jury that Mr Beckett regarded himself as the "top dog" as he "abused his position to carry out sexual assaults of increasing gravity".

She claimed the "first rate" officer had "taken advantage of his position to intimidate and humiliate the two women and subject them to quite appalling behaviour".

The jury was told that Mr Beckett was "unable to control his sexual behaviour".

After his acquittal, Mr Beckett's solicitor, Peter Williams, read a statement on his behalf: "I and my family are relieved the right verdict was reached in a case which has caused us enormous trauma.

"I now ask that we might return to the privacy and dignity of my family life. And of course I'm looking forward to returning to Surrey police as its committed deputy chief constable."

The court heard that when interviewed by City of London officers about the women's claims, Mr Beckett said they could be connected to the fact that he had disciplined two of their friends after an incident with a pornographic email.

Mr Beckett also branded one of his accusers - known only as Mrs X - as a "very, very unhappy" woman who was both incompetent and a liar.

The Surrey police authority will meet on Monday to discuss whether Mr Beckett, who is still suspended from duty, will keep his job.

Its chairman, Alan Peirce, said: "Other disciplinary matters, not the subject of the criminal trial, may have been committed."

Referring to the possible disciplinary hearing against Mr Beckett, Denis O'Connor, chief constable of Surrey, said: "I am aware of three other issues raised by other individuals ... the matters involved are matters to some degree similar."

Regarding the two women who gave evidence during the trial, he said: "Both women do work for Surrey police and we have supported them throughout and will continue to do so."

webTitle: Bruce Gyngell, TV-am saviour, dies aged 71

fields.headline: Bruce Gyngell, TV-am saviour, dies aged 71
fields.standfirst: Obituary
fields.trailText: Bruce Gyngell, the Australian television executive credited with saving TV-am from financial ruin, has died aged 71 from lung cancer.
fields.body:
Bruce Gyngell, the Australian television executive credited with saving TV-am from financial ruin, has died aged 71 from lung cancer.

Sir David Frost, who worked with him at the breakfast television broadcaster, led industry tributes to the man whose declared aim was to "make TV-am eternal summer, so lost, lonely people could turn on and feel warm and bright".

Mr Gyngell's success in beating a technicians' strike won him the admiration of Margaret Thatcher. But he lost the franchise to GMTV in the auction system that she introduced. He later used an awards ceremony to read out a letter of apology from her which said: "Dear Bruce, when I see how some of the other licences have been awarded I am mystified you did not receive yours, and heartbroken."

He was fond of pink: he wore pink shirts and had a pink office into which he brought a trampoline as a cure for stress. He launched the TV career of Ulrika Jonsson, his secretary, by making her the TV-am weather girl.

Sir David said: "Working for him people achieved more than they ever thought themselves capable of."

Greg Dyke, the BBC's director general and a former colleague, said: "Bruce was one of the more colourful characters in our business. He was widely liked. The industry will be a duller place without him."

Mr Gyngell began his television career in Australia, and became managing director of ATV under Lord Grade in the early 1970s. After the loss of the TV-am franchise, he went back to Australia as executive chairman of the Nine network, returning in 1995 as managing director of Yorkshire-Tyne Tees, where he stayed until it was taken over by rival Granada in 1997.

webTitle: Russia's military might to shrink by one-third

fields.headline: Russia's military might to shrink by one-third
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Russia's vast armed forces will be reduced by almost a third by 2003, the defence minister confirmed yesterday, signalling the start of a radical cost-cutting strategy designed to restore order to the ailing military.
fields.body:
Russia's vast armed forces will be reduced by almost a third by 2003, the defence minister confirmed yesterday, signalling the start of a radical cost-cutting strategy designed to restore order to the ailing military.

Igor Sergeyev confirmed that the current 1.2m-strong military would be cut by about 350,000. The biggest reductions will come from the ground troops divisions, which are to lose some 180,000 men. The navy is set to lose 50,000, and the air force about 40,000. The remainder of the cuts will affect border guards and interior ministry troops.

President Vladimir Putin held closed meetings on the reform of the military on the eve of the Kursk submarine disaster when the plans for the drastic reduction in manpower were drawn up.

The decision reflects widespread acceptance that the country can no longer afford to run such a massive army. Russia's defence budget still stands at around £3.2bn - just a fraction of the American defence spending of almost £200bn.

This severe funding shortage has left many troops poorly paid, badly fed and ill equipped - problems which have been spotlighted by Russia's long drawn out battle to combat rebel fighters in the separatist region of Chechnya.

The urgent need for change was highlighted once more in the wake of the Kursk tragedy, with the difficulties in mounting an effective rescue and salvage operation. In his first comments after the disaster, Mr Putin promised to speed up military reform. "The army should be compact, up to date and well paid," he said.

As speculation over the cause of the Kursk disaster continued, Russian officials denied newspaper reports yesterday that a missile fired by a Russian warship sank the nuclear submarine during an exercise.

Navy spokesman Igor Dygalo said: "This kind of accident could not take place during exercises because surface ships and submarines operate within strictly defined training zones."

fields.headline: Rest in peace
fields.trailText: I lived at the women's peace camp at Greenham for over 17 years (Greenham women call it a day after 19 years, September 6) and I am saddened that roadworks are now damaging this historic site.
fields.body:
 I lived at the women's peace camp at Greenham for over 17 years (Greenham women call it a day after 19 years, September 6) and I am saddened that roadworks are now damaging this historic site. It is a shame the Greenham Common Trust has taken so much land, building two roads and roundabouts. It is important the commemorative site is established, particularly as Helen Thomas was killed there. But the area of land available is now much reduced. Local people were not consulted about the cutting down of trees and road building: it is ruining the land that was my home.

Katrina Howse
Newbury

fields.headline: No bouquets for Binky
fields.trailText: In response to Elaine Showalter's article on the New York Times wedding section (A fine romance, August 26), I say "whoa". Has she not read my Last Chance Guide To Getting Married?
fields.body:
 In response to Elaine Showalter's article on the New York Times wedding section (A fine romance, August 26), I say "whoa". Has she not read my Last Chance Guide To Getting Married? In that I specifically suggest that no one ever reads the Times wedding announcements if they have any hope of maintaining a sense of self-esteem and pride.

Beyond the fact that it is utterly tasteless to make one's vows of devotion so public, it is equally vulgar for the newspaper to rub into the face of the hoi polloi just how lucky this tiny percentage of the population really is. The entire wedding section is divisive and cannot help but engender bitterness, rage and envy in the poor unmarried and unconnected souls forced to read it.

First one notices the children of privilege going to their very Ivy schools, and emerging with resumés and careers almost as well-manicured as their teeth. Their squeakiness shines on the page. Then they are foist upon each other and begin the first plunder of their young lives together - for the nest. They secure the best real estate in the city through nepotism: the landlord, as often as not, is their father. From then on, it's simply a matter of consumption and self-indulgence. As for the poor, who's poor? Not Binky, Muffie or Skip.

But these young romantics are not to blame. Nor are their proud parents. It's the Times which is culpable. For years it has promoted this fantasy of happy youth entering into that most sacred institution.

Elaine Showalter may find some comfort in modern brides keeping their maiden name, but it's only a surface difference. If the revolution actually wakes up and remembers to come, the society page will be the first to burn.

Nancy Cohen
New York
lambstar@hotmail.com

webTitle: Russia caught in Japan spy case

fields.headline: Russia caught in Japan spy case
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Japan was shaken by its biggest spy scandal in 20 years and Moscow exposed to public embarrassment when police seized a senior Japanese officer yesterday on suspicion of leaking confidential documents to a Russian military attache suspected of working for his country's secret service.
fields.body:
Japan was shaken by its biggest spy scandal in 20 years and Moscow exposed to public embarrassment when police seized a senior Japanese officer yesterday on suspicion of leaking confidential documents to a Russian military attache suspected of working for his country's secret service.

The unexpected flashback to the cold war prompted an angry exchange of accusations between Tokyo and Moscow, just three days after the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, ended his first official visit to Tokyo by rejecting Japanese claims to four disputed islands.

With that in mind, Japan's choice of this moment to swoop on the naval officer and a Russian diplomatic contact may not be entirely coincidental. Their relationship had been monitored for some time, according to the authorities.

Police said that they caught Shigehiro Hagisaki, 38, who worked as a researcher at the national institute for defence studies and held the rank of lieutenant-commander, as he was passing secret papers to a Russian military attache in a restaurant in Tokyo.

According to the state-owned television channel NHK, the attache, Victor Bogatenkov, 44, is a member of the GRU, the intelligence service which replaced the KGB after the disintegration of the Soviet Union. Mr Bogatenkov has claimed diplomatic immunity from questioning and arrest.

Detectives are reported to have watched the two men exchange envelopes at about 10 meetings in the past year at Chinese restaurants and at bars. Mr Hagisaki is said by the authorities to have admitted supplying information in return for money.

The extent of the leak remains unclear. Mr Hagisaki worked in the documents division of Japan's navy, known as the maritime self-defence forces because the country's post-war constitution restricts it from formally having offensive military capabilities.

He is believed to have had access to sensitive information about his country's submarine forces and about security cooperation with other states.

Embarrassingly for the government, police allege that in searches of the suspect's house and office they found files on the US navy. Washington is Tokyo's main ally.

"This incident invites mis trust about Japan's defence arrangments both at home and overseas," said Hidenao Nakagawa, the government's main spokesman.

The defence minister, Toshio Torashima, said the accused officer's actions were "unforgiveable" and said a complaint would be lodged with Russia once the details of the case were clarified.

But in Moscow a government spokesman took a pugnacious tone, calling the arrest unfriendly and provocative. "Japan, unfortunately, has forces that want to turn the clock backwards because they are unhappy at the radical improvement in bilateral relations," said an official quoted by the news agency Itar-Tass.

Tokyo and Moscow have yet to sign a peace treaty more than 55 years after the end of the second world war because of a sovereignty dispute over the Kurile islands to the north of Japan that were seized by Soviet troops in 1945.

Three years ago, when relations were warming, the two countries's leaders pledged to work towards settling this problem by the end of 2000.

Earlier this week, however, Mr Putin turned down a compromise by the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, who suggested Moscow could cede administrative control in return for agreed sovereignty. This rejection killed off any chance of agreement by the end-of-year deadline.

The two leaders parted with public smiles and promises to cooperate more on regional security, but the lack of progress was a huge disappointment for many in Japan.

webTitle: Letters: ICC may bring lbw devices into play

fields.headline: Straight bat
fields.trailText: If the lbw ruling is taken out of the hands of umpires, all Test matches will be completed within two days (ICC may bring lbw devices into play, September 8).
fields.body:
 If the lbw ruling is taken out of the hands of umpires, all Test matches will be completed within two days (ICC may bring lbw devices into play, September 8). It may prevent wrong decisions, as in the case of Brain Lara, but the overall effect will be an increase in the number of batsmen being given out.

Derek Facey
York

The answer to Mr Porteous (Letters, September 8) is that a run out is a matter of fact; whether the ball would have continued to hit the wicket is a matter of opinion with which technology is unable to assist.

Dr John Knape
London

I can put Mr Walker's mind at rest (Letters, September 8). From the taste I had of it as it rained down, the England players' "champagne" was only fit for spraying around.

Paul Steeples
London

fields.headline: Wesker has a grumpfest
fields.trailText: What is there about British journalists that they feel driven to trivialise (John Sutherland, G2, September 2)? He needs to earn a living, I understand that, but how refreshing it would be if Sutherland begun: "I have before me five books by people who have been in positions of great power, authority, esteem or celebrity, but I am going to trivialise what they've written because my readers would not read me otherwise."
fields.body:
 What is there about British journalists that they feel driven to trivialise (John Sutherland, G2, September 2)? He needs to earn a living, I understand that, but how refreshing it would be if Sutherland begun: "I have before me five books by people who have been in positions of great power, authority, esteem or celebrity, but I am going to trivialise what they've written because my readers would not read me otherwise."

You can't really win with the Sutherlands of this world. Angry young man, mid-life crisis, cultural Jeremiah between the dangerous years of 61 and 66 - there is always a lazy (ageist) epithet available to ho-ho away the serious implications of what actually is being argued. "We're in the middle of a grumpfest." (Oh, the wit of the man.)

I've not read the books by Tusa, Drummond, Walden & Wogan - all of which sound urgent and interesting, despite the silly disparagements (I know I shouldn't be writing this, but please don't hurt me when it's my turn next). I have, however, read Michael Kustow's book culture@risk, which far from being a Jeremiah is a vivid report from the front line, a crackling collage of accounts and critiques, profiles and testimony of some of the leading theatre-makers in the world, written by a generous spirit who opens himself to the talents of others - rare in these sour isles. 80% of the book is taken up with enthusiasms; why does Sutherland chose to dwell on the other 20% which seriously and persuasively argues how such talent is under threat?

Arnold Wesker
Hay on Wye,
Hereford

He needs to earn a living, I understand that, but how refreshing it would be if Sutherland begun: "I have before me five books by people who have been in positions of great power, authority, esteem or celebrity, but I am going to trivialise what they've written because my readers would not read me otherwise." You can't really win with the Sutherlands of this world. Angry young man, mid-life crisis, cultural Jeremiah between the dangerous years of 61 and 66 - there is always a lazy (ageist) epithet available to ho-ho away the serious implications of what actually is being argued. "We're in the middle of a grumpfest." (Oh, the wit of the man.) I've not read the books by Tusa, Drummond, Walden & Wogan - all of which sound urgent and interesting, despite the silly disparagements (I know I shouldn't be writing this, but please don't hurt me when it's my turn next). I have, however, read Michael Kustow's book culture@risk, which far from being a Jeremiah is a vivid report from the front line, a crackling collage of accounts and critiques, profiles and testimony of some of the leading theatre-makers in the world, written by a generous spirit who opens himself to the talents of others - rare in these sour isles. 80% of the book is taken up with enthusiasms; why does Sutherland chose to dwell on the other 20% which seriously and persuasively argues how such talent is under threat? Arnold Wesker Hay on Wye, Hereford

fields.headline: GM shots
fields.trailText: Now that the world may soon be rid of hepatitis B, courtesy of the Salvation Army, Charles Arnzten and GM tomatoes, may we now look forward to some apology from those who have sought so assiduously and successfully to convince the credulous that GM is the work of the Devil?
fields.body:
 Now that the world may soon be rid of hepatitis B, courtesy of the Salvation Army, Charles Arnzten and GM tomatoes (Vaccine in GM fruit, September 8), may we now look forward to some apology from those who have sought so assiduously and successfully to convince the credulous that GM is the work of the Devil?

Prof David Alan Walker
University of Sheffield

The ability to produce hepatitis B vaccine in a transgenic organism should be applauded, but we must be aware of the potential for cynical exploitation of this development for promotion of GM crops. Although the science involved is the same, there is a large "morality gap" between GM crops and transgenic plants used in medicine.

Dr Martin Schwarz
Manchester Children's hospital

fields.headline: Opec fuels new dissent
fields.trailText: When the price of crude oil was $8 a barrel, some oil-producing countries were facing economic ruin. Did the west then point out that oil was too cheap (Clinton wins oil pledge, September 8)?
fields.body:
 When the price of crude oil was $8 a barrel, some oil-producing countries were facing economic ruin. Did the west then point out that oil was too cheap (Clinton wins oil pledge, September 8)? If the cost of petrol is too high - even though it is almost equivalent to that of bottled water - it is the public, brought up in a car culture, that bears the consequences and short-sighted governments that in the past two decades have undermined public transport, while making money from car usage, who are to blame. Many years ago, the Swiss voted in a referendum to increase the price of petrol. Their educated decision was based on environmental consciousness and access to good, cheap public transport. We have a long way to go.

Alexander Marks
Cambridge
am10040@hermes.cam.ac.uk

 From driving frequently in Scandinavia, where fuel prices are higher but speed limits are lower - and are generally adhered to - we find that we pay less per mile simply because we use less petrol. Also, while road safety is a complex issue, involving population types and densities, speed is known to be an important factor. Surely these are powerful reasons to retain and enhance incentives to use less fuel, if necessary through taxation; or do we all fall in behind greed and speed yet again?

Dr Roger Bayston
Nottingham

 The fuel price crisis should cause us to question some fundamental economic assumptions. The global economy is founded on the principle that the more trade, the better. But our forthcoming report, Bringing the Food Economy Home, reveals that in 1998, the last year for which figures are available, the UK exported 263,000 tonnes of milk and cream, while importing 203,000 tonnes. At a time when CO<->2 emissions are threatening the earth's climate and causing asthma rates to soar, such absurdly wasteful transportation is simply unpardonable.

Rather than allowing our taxpayers' money to subsidise ever-larger road networks, thereby tilting the playing field in favour of giant transnational manufacturers and their middlemen, we should be looking to shorten the distance between producers and consumers: supporting the smaller and more accountable enterprises on which the health of communities, both here and around the world, ultimately depends.

John Page
International Society for Ecology and Culture

 Dump the Pump, headed by a BMW-driving businessman from Essex, was all about middle-class drivers wanting to pay less tax (Will that old black magic ruin Brown's best laid plans? September 8). The current protests are about farmers, truck and taxi drivers pointing out that spiralling fuel prices are threatening their livelihoods. Perhaps a real difference between Britain and France is that here the tradition of mass-organised action in the fight for a fairer society has gone out of fashion. Who knows, maybe it's just about to become fashionable again?

Jonathan Butler
Glasgow
butler@dm.unibo.it

During the miners strike, pickets were arrested and charged with obstruction on an almost daily basis. Why is it that farmers and lorry drivers who block major highways never seem to be charged with anything?

Brian Moss
Tamworth,
Staffs

If farming is, as we are frequently told, a seven days a week, 52 weeks a year job, how do farmers find the time to blockade Stanlow oil refinery?

T Hall
Manchester

A solution to the oil crisis: lift the sanctions on Iraq.

Alan Clayden
Nottingham

fields.headline: Clue to pig fever culprit
fields.trailText: Someone discarding salami or uncooked pork into outdoor pig paddocks is suspected of causing Britain's worst livestock crisis since BSE.
fields.body:
Someone discarding salami or uncooked pork into outdoor pig paddocks is suspected of causing Britain's worst livestock crisis since BSE.

Government vets believe a traveller from Asia or Europe, or someone who bought an illegal import, may have tossed contaminated meat from a footpath near the breeding unit in Norfolk where the out break probably started. Alternatively, a bird may have scavenged the meat and carried it to the farm. The infection probably took hold in June although it was not formally identified until last month.

There was no evidence of infection from pigs, vehicles or people on other farms. On eight farms with swine fever, the stock has been slaughtered; hundreds of others are under movement restrictions.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Zermatt
fields.trailText: We got up the 2,500ft of the Trift gorge in an hour and a half, to come out in soft, silky, mist that wrapped itself around the tall, pink-painted walls of the Trift hut. Hot drinks and apple tart were welcome adjuncts on this summer day that looked and felt more like late autumn.
fields.body:
We got up the 2,500ft of the Trift gorge in an hour and a half, to come out in soft, silky, mist that wrapped itself around the tall, pink-painted walls of the Trift hut. Hot drinks and apple tart were welcome adjuncts on this summer day that looked and felt more like late autumn.

As we climbed later up the flower-decked slopes towards the glorious alp called Hohbalmen, we searched for signs of the Rothorn hut, perched on rocks at 10,420ft between the Rothorn glacier and the Trift glacier, but the flowing curtain of cloud made a sighting impossible. This path over the great, grassy shoulder of Hohbalmen gives grand vistas in clear conditions, from the sharp crests of the Dom-Taschhorn group to the north face of the Matterhorn and, eventually, to the crenellations of the Dent d'Herens east ridge. There seemed little chance of us seeing much of this, though, as we passed close by the fluffy flock of sheep that haunt this alp each summer. But as we watched them clanking their collar bells through the golden hawkbit the dark curtains began to part: a sunbeam picked out the steep forest below Sunnegga across the valley.

The climb continues - to more than 8,800ft by the time it curves round to traverse the southern flanks of the Unter Gabelhorn. Here short-leaved gentian and moss-like saxifrage bordered the narrow path and, further along, the gorgeous masterwort and alpine aster decked our way. Suddenly we stood, bathed in sunlight, and high in the heavens saw the summit roof of the Matterhorn! For a couple of weeks the mountain had been subject to repeated snowfalls and no parties had reached the top; now we saw the upper 500ft above the lowering cloud curtain. It had a midwinter look. The cloud shifted further to reveal part of the north face, darkly shaded and sheathed in ice.

As we began the descending traverse clouds gathered again and the Matterhorn was lost to view for the rest of that day. We came down to the moraine and continued along the path to Zmutt, where the farm machinery was covered with plastic sheets. There'd be no more haymaking for days.
