webTitle: Letters: The south central rail franchise

fields.headline: Connex puts its case
fields.trailText: The need for urgent and massive investment in new trains and infrastructure to improve capacity, journey opportunities and quality of service for increasing numbers of customers remains the driving force in our negotiations with the shadow Strategic Rail Authority for the replacement South Central franchise
fields.body:
 The need for urgent and massive investment in new trains and infrastructure to improve capacity, journey opportunities and quality of service for increasing numbers of customers remains the driving force in our negotiations with the shadow Strategic Rail Authority for the replacement South Central franchise (Prescott may signal a rail franchise go-slow, September 5).

The sSRA's statistics for April to June show that performance within the majority of south-east train operating companies has declined. We can certainly do better in terms of cleanliness and information, especially in times of disruption, and our staff are working hard on that. But when it comes to performance, let's be honest: we will not meet expectations of reliability and punctuality without massive investment.

In meeting a 25% increase in passenger demand with ageing trains and an infrastructure dating from Victorian times, Connex's performance has, not surprisingly, suffered. If vital investment is delayed, further decline is inevitable. We have already demonstrated our commitment, in ordering 240 new Class 375 air-conditioned coaches to improve reliability and capacity on Sussex coast routes in advance of the franchise decision. Also, we are negotiating with Railtrack and the sSRA for an early start to electrification of the Oxted-to-Uckfield and Ashford International-to- Hastings routes to bring customers the benefits of new and faster trains.

Olivier Brousse
Managing director, Connex

 Having just experienced Holland's double-deck trains (clean, spacious and very smooth), I have little doubt London and the south-west would benefit greatly if the Dutch succeed in winning the franchise. Perhaps they should be encouraged to bid for more.

Antony Gordon
Nottingham

fields.headline: Rotting petfood 'sold for human consumption'
fields.trailText: Hundreds of tonnes of pet food were deliberately sold to restaurants, takeaways and food shops in a sophisticated scam involving three sets of middlemen, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Hundreds of tonnes of pet food were deliberately sold to restaurants, takeaways and food shops in a sophisticated scam involving three sets of middlemen, a court heard yesterday.

Lorryloads of poultry condemned as unfit for human consumption were palmed off as quality meat to butchers and supermarkets, a jury at Hull crown court was told.

Profits of millions of pounds were made by a gang, which tried out the system in a smaller con nicknamed the "Preston Sausage Fraud", Ben Nolan QC said. The "sophisticated network" hoodwinked suppliers until a mother defrosted rank, long-outdated sausages to cook for a children's party.

"The risk to public health from food poisoning organisms has been unquantifiable," said Mr Nolan, who accused seven wholesale traders of creating a serious threat to food safety for more than three years. He said: "The defendants devised and operated a system for selling meat as wholesome and edible when in truth it was condemned".

Mr Nolan said of the party sausages case: "Because the sausage was frozen and the sell-by date read only December 25 with no year, it was assumed that this was a long-dated product."

Fortunately, when an Essex woman bought several packets for her children's party "her sense of smell told her they were off".

The seven, who all deny conspiracy to defraud by selling unfit poultry meat, are Clive Bold and his son Andrew, of Oldcotes near Worksop, Nottinghamshire; Darren Bibby , also of Oldcotes; Timothy Powell of Hove, East Sussex; Peter and Louise Tantram of Ingham, Lincolnshire, and Kevin Wilson of Cleethorpes, Humberside.

The court heard that pet food was a strictly regulated byproduct of the meat industry, supplied from portions condemned as unfit for humans and distributed and packaged separately. The Bolds and Bibby, said Mr Nolan, had bought "huge quantities of condemned birds" for their petfood company Wells By-products which were then passed on to the Tantrams, who cleaned up the meat at another pet food company, Cliff Top Pet Foods.

From there the chain led to a man called John McGinty, who is not on trial, and on - with petfood wrappings now replaced by ordinary food packaging - to food brokers Wilson and Powell. Mr Nolan said: "Wilson and Powell knew full well the true origin of the product and were defrauding innocent purchasers, be they wholesalers, dealers and - further down the line - retailers and consumers."

Wilson and Powell are also charged in connection with the sausage fraud, which led to 7,910 packets of frozen beef and cocktail sausages being offered for sale up to a year-and-a-half after their sell-by date. The court heard the method involved in the 1996 scam was "a microcosm of the poultry fraud in that the same systems and facilities were used".

The Bolds and the Tantrams are also charged with deceiving the petfood supplier Pedigree by supplying them with cheap turkey when the company had asked for fillets from the human food market to help the launch of a new premium catfood.

Mr Nolan said: "The price differential between petfood and edible turkey is considerable - Pedigree paid £192,000 for turkey which they could have bought for £34,000."

The trial continues.

fields.headline: Japan's credit rating is downgraded
fields.trailText: A leading international credit agency has cut Japan's debt rating for the second time in two years.
fields.body:
A leading international credit agency has cut Japan's debt rating for the second time in two years.

Moody's Investors Service, which assesses the abilities of countries and corporations to repay loans, said the change was necessary because "policy shortcomings and structural problems" had given Japan the highest level of debt among industrial economies.

The agency demoted the sovereign domestic debt rating of the world's second largest economy to Aa2, two notches from the top rank. This is the lowest level among the group of seven rich nations, apart from Italy.

The Japanese government owes more than ¥640 trillion (£4 trillion), 130% of the country's annual output, after a 10-year spending spree designed to keep the economy from sliding into reverse.

Interest payments alone will reach ¥18.4 trillion (£117bn) next year, but the ruling Liberal Democratic Party plans to keep spending until the economy has returned to steady growth, which is not expected until 2002.

Finance minister Kiichi Miyazawa dismissed the Moody's downgrade as "nonsense".

The government insists that Japan has sufficient assets to cover its borrowings easily.

fields.headline: Safety issues threaten LU privatisation
fields.trailText: The Government's £12bn plan to turn the London Underground into a private-public partnership by March 2001 could be undermined by its failure to clear considerable safety problems.
fields.body:
The Government's £12bn plan to turn the London Underground into a private-public partnership by March 2001 could be undermined by its failure to clear considerable safety problems.

The Health and Safety Executive announced last night that it was planning an audit of the LU in December to ensure that safety conditions were being met. It could not accept any plans for change unless it was "completely happy" with the safety case.

The transfer to the private sector, which still leaves the state exercising overall control, would have to be abandoned if safety was at stake.

The HSE said that it was still looking for improvements in the new safety regime. It said it had learnt lessons from the Paddington crash last October, caused partly by the re-alignment of the track outside the station in the lead up to privatisation.

LU has already been singled out by the HSE for its approach to safety. Railway inspectors have criticised senior LU managers for a diffident attitude to the issue.

The public's perception of the underground - one of the biggest in the world - is that it is detoriating. There have been several high profile incidents in the past few weeks, culminating in a serious case earlier this week when some 2,000 people were trapped on the Central line for two hours without fresh air.

The HSE said last night that it was "extremely concerned", particularly as LU was committed to getting passengers out within 30 minutes following an incident.

LU later said that the target was self-imposed, following the King's Cross fire in 1989. The HSE also criticised LU for waiting for an hour before calling the fire brigade. In reponse LU said it had in fact waited only 37 minutes. Even then it had delayed the call because it felt it could cope with the incident itself.

Critics of the HSE say that it is only taking a tough stance against LU because of the Paddington crash. It is expected that the HSE will be criticised for not taking tough action with Railtrack and the train operating companies for signals passed at danger. It has already admitted that its inspection procedures could be improved.

The HSE also said that new rolling stock on the underground was breaking down, and was unreliable. LU replied that the system was performing satisfactorily.

The transfer to the private sector, which still leaves the state exercising overall control, would have to be abandoned if safety was at stake. fields.headline: Independent Energy shut off
fields.trailText: Independent Energy, a trail-blazer in the liberalised market, called in receivers yesterday, prompting fears of a spate of insolvencies among the country's smaller suppliers.
fields.body:
Independent Energy, a trail-blazer in the liberalised market, called in receivers yesterday, prompting fears of a spate of insolvencies among the country's smaller suppliers.

The company, based in Solihull, Birmingham, and founded in 1996, had won plaudits for the way it attacked the freed-up gas and electricity market, winning 242,000 customers and seeing its shares climb to a high of £37.50 in March after raising £99m in New York to fund future growth - a stock market star.

But, with its shares down 10p at 700p early yesterday, the company asked for them to be suspended and called in KPMG as administrative receivers, saying that it had been unable to persuade its bankers to stump up fresh working capital.

Ofgem, the energy regulator, reassured Independent's 242,000 domestic and commercial electricity customers and 63,000 gas customers they would not be disconnected, and said it was in talks with KPMG about potential buyers.

The receivers said they had already received several expressions of interest, but Centrica, which trades as British Gas, had said only 24 hours earlier it had no interest because of Independent's billing problems.

John Sulley, the company's chief executive, said in early summer that billing problems for 160,000 customers - caused by delayed meter readings by previous suppliers - had left it with a £119m hole in its finances.

These problems prompted Ofgem to instruct Independent in May to stop marketing its products and taking on new customers. But the regulator said this had not caused the company's fall.

Independent earlier this year said pre-tax profits for the last six months of 1999 had soared from £707,000 to £12.1m but by July it disclosed its financing problems and said it was in takeover talks.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Go-Ahead bids for franchises
fields.body:
Go-Ahead bids for franchises

Transport group Go-Ahead is considering five more bids for train franchises while its reputation is under heavy scrutiny after the Paddington rail crash.

As its interim results were published yesterday, it said it was interested in high density franchises which will come up for negotiation over the next few years. Pre-tax profits before one-off costs rose 8% to £44.8m. A final 9.2p dividend has resulted in 13p for the year, a 13%increase.

It has rejected a £262m takeover bid by the French state-controlled holding company CDC. Go-Ahead's share stands at 702p.

Money pours in at Leeds United

Leeds United last night revealed it was enjoying its most successful financial start to a season. Its owner Leeds Sporting, expects to reap £10m from money-spinning draws against Barcelona and AC Milan in the Champions League. It also predicts £22m will be generated over the next three years as a result of eight sponsorship deals.

IMF offers fast track help

Aid agencies yesterday welcomed a pledge by the International Monetary Fund to fast-track 20 countries through the west's debt relief programme by the end of the year.

At a meeting with the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and representatives from the main churches, Horst Kohler, IMF's new head, outlined proposals to tackle the logjams in the heavily indebted poor countries programme which has so far failed to live up to expectations.

At present many countries are paying more in debt service to western creditors than they do on health and education.

Condon joins security firm

Former Metropolitan police commissioner Sir Paul Condon has joined the board of security firm Securicor as a non-executive director.

"Paul's wealth of police experience at the most senior level will be invaluable to us in maintaining our relationships with law enforcement agencies, both in Britain and overseas," said Securicor's chairman, Sir Neil Macfarlane.

Hitachi may cut TV jobs

Electrical giant Hitachi refused to comment on reports that around 350 of the 530 employees at its television factory in Hirwaun, south Wales, may loose their jobs. The company said its colour televisions had "struggled to achieve profitability" in recent years, and budgeted losses for the current year were in excess of £4m.

It added that there was "no prospect of recovery" since prices for television sets had been slashed by up to 20% in recent years.

webTitle: Leader: East Timor One year on

fields.headline: Storm over
fields.standfirst:
Timor One year on, instability and violence grow

Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: The uncharacteristic fury expressed by Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, over this week's killing of three aid workers in West Timor was fully justified. Thanks to the New York summit of world leaders, Mr Annan was able to inform Indonesia's President Abdurrahman Wahid of his disgust in person.
fields.body:
The uncharacteristic fury expressed by Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, over this week's killing of three aid workers in West Timor was fully justified. Thanks to the New York summit of world leaders, Mr Annan was able to inform Indonesia's President Abdurrahman Wahid of his disgust in person. The security situation in the Indonesian-run province, where thousands of pro-Jakarta militiamen still roam unchecked a year after neighbouring East Timor's independence referendum provoked an orgy of killing, was totally unacceptable, Mr Annan said. His criticism was echoed by both Bill Clinton and Tony Blair, and by Sadako Ogata, the UNHCR chief, whose agency has logged over 100 attacks on its personnel in West Timor in the past 12 months. The evacuation of remaining UN staff now exposes 120,000 refugees to great hardship amid reports yesterday of new militia murders.

But for all the understandable anger, such protests are unlikely to have much practical impact. In truth, Mr Wahid exercises little or no direct control over events in West Timor or, for that matter, in several other troubled regions of his fragmented country. His decision to send in troop reinforcements may only make matters worse, given that elements within the army are intimately linked to the Timor militias - just as they are deeply implicated in continuing anti-separatist and ethnic and religious violence in places as far apart as Aceh, Sulawesi, Ambon and Papua. Mr Wahid's sacking of the deeply suspect armed forces chief, General Wiranto, has not enabled him to rein in a military that grew accustomed to autonomy of action (and money-making opportunities) during ex-president Suharto's dictatorship.

Demands by human rights groups that commanders, soldiers and militiamen responsible for the East Timor atrocities be called to account have so far brought forth an official list of a mere 19 suspects who may or may not face prosecution. Gen Wiranto is not among them. External pressure for an independent, international war crimes tribunal has been rebuffed. The Jakarta parliament, where Mr Wahid's grip is also tenuous, has meanwhile passed a constitutional amendment allowing the granting of retrospective amnesties for rights abuses. Mr Suharto, on trial for corruption and pleading Pinochet-like incapacity, has for his part already been assured of a presidential pardon should he be found guilty.

Since winning office last October, Mr Wahid has struggled to make his mark, hindered in part by the detached attitude of his deputy, Megawati Sukarnoputri, whom many Indonesians felt was unfairly denied the presidency, but also by his own policy vagueness, indecision, and penchant for foreign travel. An ambitious cabinet reshuffle last month seems to have failed to reboot his administration; indeed, it led to a run on the rupiah. Although the IMF this week readied the latest $400m tranche of a $5bn bail-out, Indonesia's economic position remains dangerously fraught. When this is taken alongside Mr Wahid's evident political weakness and the chaotic security situation, it is little wonder that there is renewed speculation in Jakarta about a fresh government crisis, plots and coups, and regional concern that Indonesia as a unified democracy is drifting towards disintegration.

All of which instability and uncertainty is bad news indeed for the fledgling, penniless nation of East Timor, at present under UN administration but due to take charge of its own affairs by the end of next year. The trauma of its birth may be very far from over.

fields.headline: Jolted Bush plays the underdog
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The embattled Republican presidential candidate George W Bush has been forced to respond to a chorus of party criticism and a run of bad poll results by re-energising his campaign style and giving his slogans a face-lift in the contest with the Democrat Al Gore.
fields.body:
The embattled Republican presidential candidate George W Bush has been forced to respond to a chorus of party criticism and a run of bad poll results by re-energising his campaign style and giving his slogans a face-lift in the contest with the Democrat Al Gore.

Mr Bush has decided to increase the tempo of what has sometimes seemed an unduly leisurely schedule. Instead he now intends to be seen getting in among the voters more, cutting down on set-piece speeches in favour of more glad-handing, and campaigning on a new theme of "Real Plans for Real People."

"I've got to get out and talk to people, and I'm going to do a lot of it," Mr Bush said in Pennsylvania yesterday. "I'm going to tell you what I think, and let the political chips fall where they may."

Mr Bush has decided to redefine himself as the underdog in the race with Mr Gore, who has drawn level and even moved ahead of him for the first time in some recent opinion polls. The move echoes a change of direction in Mr Bush's campaign for the Republican nomination earlier this year after John McCain defeated him in the New Hampshire primary.

Mr Bush has also signalled that he wants to extricate himself from the cul-de-sac he got himself into over the planned series of debates with Mr Gore later in the autumn. In a U-turn from the position he adopted as recently as Monday, Mr Bush has reopened negotiations with Mr Gore on the debate schedule.

Criticism of the Bush campaign from within the party has focused on a range of perceived failings, including the strategy towards the debates. Other issues include the use of negative advertising, the failure to make the case for Mr Bush's $1.3 trillion (£900bn) tax cut plan, the lacklustre performance of Mr Bush's running-mate Dick Cheney, and the tight control exercised by Mr Bush's Texas-based team in Austin.

But with the polls showing that Mr Bush's lead of a few weeks ago has now evaporated, the Republican challenger is eager to shore up his support by claiming that he is facing the fight of his political life.

"This is going to be a tight race," Mr Bush said. "I guess my supporters wanted it to be a runaway. The vice-president is running a strong race, but so am I. I am under no illusions and neither should our supporters be. I am the underdog - I sure am."

Mr Bush tried to laugh off several days of increasingly vocal criticisms of his campaign from within his own party. "That's Washington," he told reporters in Michigan. "That's the place where you find people getting ready to jump out of the foxholes before the first shell is fired."

Asked why he has decided to change tack by going more informal, Mr Bush responded: "Well, it's a better picture."

What is officially described as a campaign "retooling" comes as three new polls showed Mr Gore either tied with Mr Bush or ahead of him. A Zogby poll has Mr Gore leading by 46% to Mr Bush's 40%, while the first of a series of Gallup three-day tracking polls has Mr Gore up by 47% to 44%. A Washington Post poll shows the two men level on 47% each.

The latest poll in one of the key states in the election also shows Mr Gore taking the lead in Missouri by 45% to 41%.

Mr Bush's slide in the polls in the past two weeks has provoked a mood of near panic among some of his supporters. "There's no doubt about it. There's real worry about the general state of things," said the conservative campaigner William Bennett, a former education secretary. "There's nervousness that was not there before."

"The biggest mistake we can make is to try to be all things to all people," the Missouri congressman John Kasich said.

"I'm at a loss to explain the rather significant change in the polling numbers," Tom Ridge, governor of Pennsylvania, said.

fields.headline: Mitsubishi loses face and president
fields.trailText: Mitsubishi Motors was forced yesterday to suffer fresh indignities to atone for its 20-year cover-up of vehicle defects with the resignation of its president and the ceding of boardroom influence at a bargain price to foreign partner, DaimlerChrysler.
fields.body:
Mitsubishi Motors was forced yesterday to suffer fresh indignities to atone for its 20-year cover-up of vehicle defects with the resignation of its president and the ceding of boardroom influence at a bargain price to foreign partner, DaimlerChrysler.

Adding to a day of woe for Japan's fourth biggest car manufacturer, the government filed criminal charges against the company for failing to report customer complaints in a systematic deception that the transport ministry described as "extremely evil".

In an emotional press conference, Mitsubishi president Katsuhiko Kawasoe said he would resign to take responsibility for the scandal, which has forced the company to recall a million cars across the world.

"I offer my deepest apologies for the great trouble that we have caused our customers with this problem," said a red-eyed Mr Kawasoe who was heralded as "Mr Clean" when he took the post amid a pay-off scandal three years ago.

Although he will be replaced by another Mitsubishi executive, vice-president Takashi Sonobe, the biggest change announced yesterday was the allocation of a boardroom seat for DaimlerChrysler.

The world's fifth biggest car maker is in the process of taking a 34% stake in Mitsubishi, but the scandal has allowed it to do so on far more favourable terms. DaimlerChrysler said it has negotiated a 10% discount in the price of the shares it is buying, which will now go for $1.9bn (£1.3bn) rather than the initially agreed $2.1bn. It has the option to buy the company outright in three years.

This may not be necessary. The new boardroom seat is expected to be allocated to Rolf Eckrodt, head of Daimler's Adtranz rail division, who is tipped to take the post of chief operating officer.

Investors hope that he will emulate the performance of another foreign executive at a Japanese car maker, Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of Nissan, who was has pushed ahead rapidly with restructuring sinces Renault took a one-third stake.

Mitsubishi has a debt burden of ¥1.5 trillion (£9.5bn). Before the company can be turned around financially, it has to restore its reputation -an effort that has already cost more than ¥75bn in global recalls.

fields.headline: Oil triggers downhill slide
fields.standfirst: No intervention, just soothing words from Versailles as forex dealers dump euro and the pound
fields.trailText: A wave of selling swept across London's financial markets yesterday as mounting concern over the impact of high oil prices on corporate profits sent share prices reeling.
fields.body:
A wave of selling swept across London's financial markets yesterday as mounting concern over the impact of high oil prices on corporate profits sent share prices reeling.

There were also reports of chaotic scenes in the foreign exchange markets as dealers dumped both sterling and the euro. As the markets awaited a keynote statement on the health of the euro from European finance ministers meeting in Versailles, the pound fell to its lowest level against the dollar for seven years.

The FTSE 100 fell 88.5 points to 6,600.7 as analysts in the Square Mile, digesting a run of profit warnings from the likes of Du Pont and Invensys over recent days, began to weigh up the chances of a sharp economic slowdown.

In Versailles, statements of support for the euro failed to stop the beleaguered currency sliding back towards the all-time low of 86.30 cents seen on Thursday.

In a statement after the meeting, ministers stopped short of calling for intervention on the foreign exchanges but reiterated their support for a strong euro: "The current level of the euro does not reflect the strong economic fundamentals of the euro area."

There was agreement to follow the situation closely, with the statement adding: "A strong euro is in the interest of the euro area."

But currency analysts pointed out that the currency has lost more than quarter of its value against the dollar since its introduction 20 months ago.

With a cocktail of worries building up over currency mis-matches and soaring raw material prices, recent predictions that the US and British economies were on track for a so-called soft landing are being hastily revised.

"It is very straightforward," said Ian Harnett, head of European equity strategy at investment bank UBS Warburg. "Investors are worried that the rise in oil prices will lead to higher interest rates, and higher input costs will hit corporate margins.

"Look at the sectors that have taken a hit today: either they are ones that are damaged by higher input prices or highly rated stocks damaged by higher bonds yields."

However, Philip Wolstencroft, co-head of pan-European equity strategy at Merrill Lynch, argued that the potential impact of the rise in the oil price was being overstated.

"The oil price is a symptom of strong growth rather than a precursor of recession. It might slow growth but there's not much evidence that we are going in that direction at this juncture. I would be sceptical of this new-found belief that we are about to fall off the cliff. The economy is going to be fairly robust."

Oil was also on the Ecofin agenda in Versailles, where ministers backed US demands that Opec agreehigher quotas when the 11 nation oil producers' cartel meets this weekend in Vienna. But the markets remain sceptical about the chances of any short-term relief even if Opec agrees a sharp increase in output.

"They can do very little about a shortage of tankers to bring oil to the west," said Richard Crehan, a strategist at Morgan Stanley. The tightly managed structure of oil refining meant there was little spare capacity to ease bottlenecks.

As the markets awaited a keynote statement on the health of the euro from European finance ministers meeting in Versailles, the pound fell to its lowest level against the dollar for seven years. The FTSE 100 fell 88.5 points to 6,600.7 as analysts in the Square Mile, digesting a run of profit warnings from the likes of Du Pont and Invensys over recent days, began to weigh up the chances of a sharp economic slowdown. In Versailles, statements of support for the euro failed to stop the beleaguered currency sliding back towards the all-time low of 86.30 cents seen on Thursday. In a statement after the meeting, ministers stopped short of calling for intervention on the foreign exchanges but reiterated their support for a strong euro: "The current level of the euro does not reflect the strong economic fundamentals of the euro area." There was agreement to follow the situation closely, with the statement adding: "A strong euro is in the interest of the euro area." But currency analysts pointed out that the currency has lost more than quarter of its value against the dollar since its introduction 20 months ago. With a cocktail of worries building up over currency mis-matches and soaring raw material prices, recent predictions that the US and British economies were on track for a so-called soft landing are being hastily revised. "It is very straightforward," said Ian Harnett, head of European equity strategy at investment bank UBS Warburg. "Investors are worried that the rise in oil prices will lead to higher interest rates, and higher input costs will hit corporate margins. "Look at the sectors that have taken a hit today: either they are ones that are damaged by higher input prices or highly rated stocks damaged by higher bonds yields." However, Philip Wolstencroft, co-head of pan-European equity strategy at Merrill Lynch, argued that the potential impact of the rise in the oil price was being overstated. "The oil price is a symptom of strong growth rather than a precursor of recession. It might slow growth but there's not much evidence that we are going in that direction at this juncture. I would be sceptical of this new-found belief that we are about to fall off the cliff. The economy is going to be fairly robust." Oil was also on the Ecofin agenda in Versailles, where ministers backed US demands that Opec agreehigher quotas when the 11 nation oil producers' cartel meets this weekend in Vienna. But the markets remain sceptical about the chances of any short-term relief even if Opec agrees a sharp increase in output. "They can do very little about a shortage of tankers to bring oil to the west," said Richard Crehan, a strategist at Morgan Stanley. The tightly managed structure of oil refining meant there was little spare capacity to ease bottlenecks.

webTitle: GM apple a day may protect teeth

fields.headline: GM apple a day may protect teeth
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: A daily, genetically modified apple could one day put dentists out of a job. Scientists in Kent are planning to convert apples and strawberries into antibacterial treatments that would protect against tooth decay.
fields.body:
A daily, genetically modified apple could one day put dentists out of a job. Scientists in Kent are planning to convert apples and strawberries into antibacterial treatments that would protect against tooth decay.

Teeth decay occurs because a bacterium called Streptococcus mutans sticks to the tooth surface in a plaque, and begins eating away at the enamel. David James of Horticulture Research International at East Malling told the British Association science festival yesterday that he and colleagues were working with scientists at Guy's hospital on a new peptide - a form of protein - that did not kill the germs, but prevented them from sticking to the plaque.

If a gene that made the protein were engineered into fruit, it could be one of the "magic bullets" in the form of fruit and vegetables in tomorrow's armoury of health care.

"The problem they have is, how do you deliver this to the consumer?" Professor James said. "Obviously you could make it as a pharmaceutical product.

"But our idea in the longer term is to have a means of delivery that involves a raw product. It can't be a processed product because the protein would be destroyed.

There were other reasons for genetically modifying orchards. English apple varieties were under threat from imports, and 30% of Kent's orchards had disappeared in the past five years. East Malling scientists hoped to extend the commercial storage life of apples and pears.

Growers used chemicals to "dwarf" orchard trees to make fruit easier to pick but gene engineers could do the job better. Technology could also produce strawberries that could resist botrytis, a fungus that threatens each year's crop. The first target for a GM British fruit could be the Bramley cooking apple: its pollen is sterile, so there would be no danger of cross pollination.

Dr Rosemary Collier of HRI told the conference she had been looking at ways of protecting vegetables from aphid attack.

The currant-lettuce aphid wintered on currant bushes and in summer was attracted by scent to land on lettuces. She and a colleague were planning to release volatile chemicals that would make the summer lettuces smell like currants - and put the little predator off the scent.

webTitle: Leader: Tories plans to win election

fields.headline: Marginal Tories
fields.standfirst:
Hague brigade fights shy of the E-word

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Such Labour supporters as have recently been feeling queasy about the party's prospects of holding on to power at the next election will have been heartened by the publication in the Daily Telegraph this week of a list of the candidates the Conservatives have chosen to fight in their 170 most winnable seats - that is to say, the seats they would have to win to get back to government.
fields.body:
Such Labour supporters as have recently been feeling queasy about the party's prospects of holding on to power at the next election will have been heartened by the publication in the Daily Telegraph this week of a list of the candidates the Conservatives have chosen to fight in their 170 most winnable seats - that is to say, the seats they would have to win to get back to government. Even remembering the scale of the Tory defeat in May 1997 it seems astonishing now that, for instance, Edinburgh Pentlands, which was lost by Sir Malcolm Rifkind, ranks 85th on the list; that once emblematically Conservative Hove is 65th, and the party's last seat in Sheffield - Hallam - comes 135th.

Labour is rightly concerned that its local parties are still failing to pick enough ethnic minority candidates or women. Only one of the seats they now hold, Gloucester, has chosen a new ethnic minority candidate. But troubling though that is, it puts them way ahead of the Conservatives. Only one remotely capturable constituency will field a Conservative candidate from an ethnic minority - Northampton South, which has picked Shailesh Vara. Only five among the most winnable 50, and 12 among the most winnable 100, have plumped for a woman.

There is, however, another stricken minority here. Just as in Nathaniel Hawthorne's novel The Scarlet Letter Hester Prynne is forced to wear on her bosom the letter A, signifying "adulteress", so 11 names in the Daily Telegraph list were marked with a letter E, which in today's Conservative party implies something even worse: a Europhile. It is even more indicative of the present state of that party that since the list appeared, four of those to whom the mark of shame was attached have objected to being called Europhile. They want their Es erased.

It is possible that some of these 170 are closet Europhiles, pretending to be sceptics in much the same way that, when the left was in charge of the Labour party, some right-wingers masqueraded as unilateralists or members of the Tribune group to keep local parties happy. But even allowing for that, this list leaves little room for doubt that when Ted Heath and Michael Heseltine castigate William Hague for his Eurosceptical line and suggest that it does not reflect the broad view of the party, they do so on a basis of hope rather than one of experience.

webTitle: Man Utd stars in line for share options to boost their wages

fields.headline: Man Utd stars in line for share options to boost their wages
fields.trailText: Manchester United footballers such as David Beckham and Roy Keane could be awarded share options in the club worth around £10m each as part of a possible plan to stop them being poached by the club's big spending foreign rivals.
fields.body:
Manchester United footballers such as David Beckham and Roy Keane could be awarded share options in the club worth around £10m each as part of a possible plan to stop them being poached by the club's big spending foreign rivals.

The prospect of multi-million pound share bonuses - more usually associated with city investment bankers and dot.com entrepreneurs - was raised yesterday after the United manager, Sir Alex Ferguson, was quoted in a fanzine as saying that the plan was being considered to combat spiralling player wages and transfer fees.

A spokesman for the club later insisted there were no share option plans in place, but a number of advisers to United said it was "an excellent idea".

The world's richest football club has at times found it difficult to compete in the transfer market because the strict rules that come with its status on the London stock exchange prevent it splashing out huge sums on players.

Spanish rivals Real Madrid recently spent a world record £43m on Portuguese striker Luis Figo but then warned that its lavish spending on players had landed it with debts of £170m.

"I've found myself frustrated when it comes to the transfer market. That is one reason there are plans to introduce a share-option scheme for players," Sir Alex was quoted as telling United Shareholder magazine.

He has regularly complained that United's rigid salary structure and transfer budget prevent him competing with leading Spanish and Italian clubs for top players.

The share option scheme could be used as a useful bargaining chip when negotiating transfers and salary packages, leading football analysts said. Players would be rewarded in line with the performance of the United share price, which tends to rise in line with success on the field.

"It makes an awful lot of sense," said William Davies, a football analyst at stockbrokers Capel-Cure Sharp.

"The United share price has a good future, certainly for the next few years. Of course the share price could go down, but I regard United as the most attractive football club in the world.

"This would be a relatively cheap way of retaining and attracting players."

Rising wages is one of the biggest problems facing United's accountants. Keane, the club captain, was recently given a pay rise taking him to £52,000 a week.

Company regulations would allow United to offer its players share options worth up to four times their salaries, meaning Keane could land a £10m-plus shares package.

However, there is no guarantee that he would see the full value of his shares. Share options are not usually redeemable for two or three years. Within that time the shares could be worth far more or far less.

Four months ago United became the first football club to be valued in excess of £1bn, after city analysts said that ManUtd.com, the club's website, was worth far more than originally thought.

Since then the shares have fallen back, partly due to the possible overhaul of football transfers by Fifa, the game's governing body.

Analysts fear that the likes of Beckham, who is valued at around £40m, could leave the club for nothing after the Fifa overhaul, meaning that United's assets would not be nearly as valuable as currently thought.

"When the club buys a player, it will have to shell out a considerable sum in wages and won't get anything back in return," said Julian Easthope, an analyst with UBS Warburg.

"Manchester United is up against European clubs who have big benefactors behind them and are willing to take losses to pay high salaries."

webTitle: Decision day for Arafat on statehood card

fields.headline: Decision day for Arafat on statehood card
fields.standfirst:
Palestinian leader expected to shy away despite months of threatening to declare independence

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: In exile and in war, Yasser Arafat has personified his people's aspirations through four turbulent decades and today, with the Palestinians closer to regaining statehood than at any time since 1948, he will take another historic decision: to invite the wrath of Israel and the US by declaring independence next week, or to wait.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Ramallah, West Bank
fields.body:
In exile and in war, Yasser Arafat has personified his people's aspirations through four turbulent decades and today, with the Palestinians closer to regaining statehood than at any time since 1948, he will take another historic decision: to invite the wrath of Israel and the US by declaring independence next week, or to wait.

Mr Arafat's appearance before the Palestine Liberation Organisation's central council in Gaza city this weekend follows another difficult choice, his refusal during talks with President Clinton on the sidelines of the UN millennium summit in New York this week, to yield on the Palestinians' claim to Jerusalem.

But after giving the council's 127 members his version of what transpired at New York, Mr Arafat is expected to urge a postponement of any unilateral declaration of a state until November 15 at the earliest.

This latest delay - Mr Arafat held off such a declaration in May last year - is in part intended to blunt condemnation of the Palestinian leader as the villain of the peace process for his refusal to give Israel sovereignty of Islamic and Christian holy places in those parts of Jerusalem it has occupied since 1967.

"He will sell it to the world, to Europe and America, to show his flexibility," said an Arafat adviser, Mamdoh Nofal. "It is not so important for Mr Arafat to declare on this date, if there is no real change in his position as leader, or in the condition of his people. He has many of the elements of a state. We have 36,000 military men with weapons. We have flags, radio, television, ministries, and a legislative council."

But there are reasons other than his image for Mr Arafat not to declare statehood. One of them is that he does not have the land for a viable state - his forces have exclusive control of only 40% of the West Bank and Gaza - or the finances.

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, has threatened to retaliate against any unilateral declaration by annexing territory and imposing a blockade on an economy that is wholly dependent on Israel.

Another restraint is the lack of support for statehood now, as the Palestinian leader discovered during a fortnight of flying around world capitals after his peace talks with Mr Barak ended inconclusively at Camp David in July despite much direct involvement by President Bill Clinton.

The US and most European countries are among those opposing a unilaterial declaration at present. "Mr Arafat knows that he struck hard at Mr Clinton and Mr Barak when he refused their plans and he knows they are so angry and they are waiting around the corner to ambush him and take revenge. So he will not give them such a chance to strike by declaring a state," Mr Nodal said.

And yet Mr Arafat cannot hold off indefinitely without appearing ridiculous to his own people. Many delegates to the PLO's central council - including members of his own Fatah faction - want him to declare a state next week, no matter what the consequences, because they have no trust in a process which has seen Israel consistently break promises to hand over territory, or release political prisoners.

Negotiations on a final settlement were scheduled to end by May 4 last year: "This interim period has already been extended almost 20 months," said Daoud Talhami, a Palestine National Council member. "We are afraid that any further postponement will make self-rule into a permanent situation" with Israel not taking negotiations seriously, he said.

The weekend meeting in Gaza has the veneer of democracy, but few think the council will do more than rubber-stamp a decision that is Mr Arafat's alone. In six years of self-rule in the West Bank and Gaza, the Palestinian leader has taken a personal interest in the most minute details of administration, holding back the maturation of institutions and the judiciary.

He will be guided this weekend by that same belief that he knows what is best for Palestinians, and by his concern for his own legacy - manifested at home by a ruthless suppression of Palestinian television and print media. At 71, Mr Arafat is determined not to go down in history as the man who betrayed the Muslim claim to Jerusalem, though he would dearly love to die as the first president of independent Palestine.

That was shown again on Thursday during an interview with CNN. "You have to remember, you are speaking to Yasser Arafat," he said when asked if he would compromise on the Haram al-Sharif, the Jerusalem site that has the third holiest shrine of Islam.

"I will continue to liberate all the Islamic and Muslim holy places," an agitated Mr Arafat said. "I can't betray my people. I can't betray the Arabs. I can't betray the Christians. I can't betray the Muslims."

He has also told the Israelis that he fears assassination should he give up the Islamic holy places in Jerusalem. Held sacred by Muslims, the 36 acres of the Haram al-Sharif is also revered by Jews as the site of their temple, destroyed in 70 AD, with the Western (or Wailing) Wall as its one surviving relic.

Palestinians argue that the Israelis and Americans have been unfair to describe Mr Arafat as inflexible, and lacking the courage for bold decisions. They say that he has regularly displayed such mettle as a leader - not least by entering into the peace process seven years ago.

The question of whether to abandon heartfelt claims in Jerusalem, said Bassam Abu Sharif, a long-time adviser, "is not a difficult decision but an impossible one for Arafat".

webTitle: UN gets warning shot on peacekeeping

fields.headline: UN gets warning shot on peacekeeping
fields.standfirst:
Huge corruption in Sierra Leone shows the need for rapid reform

Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The UN's battered reputation as a peacekeeper suffered another blow yesterday after disclosures of massive corruption on the part of the Nigerian element of the UN force in Sierra Leone.
fields.body:
The UN's battered reputation as a peacekeeper suffered another blow yesterday after disclosures of massive corruption on the part of the Nigerian element of the UN force in Sierra Leone.

An internal UN report about the Nigerian force brutally exposes the gap between the peacekeeping ideals expressed by world leaders at the millennium summit in New York this week and the reality on the ground in the conflict zones.

The focus of the summit, which ended yesterday, was on making peacekeeping forces more efficient and more tightly-controlled, primarily in Africa, following the disaster in Rwanda that led to genocide and the debacle in Sierra Leone that saw 500 UN soldiers being taken hostage.

The UN report on the Nigerian force in Sierra Leone reinforces the need for haste in pushing through the reforms.

It raises questions about the effectiveness of multinational forces and whether soldiers from round the world can work together for a common aim. The report was written by the Indian commander, Major General Vijay Kumar Jetley, who complained repeatedly about how he and his troops were denigrated by the Nigerians. There has been strife too between the Nigerians and British troops.

The alternative to a multinational force from continents round the world is a regional force. But the Nigerian performance in Sierra Leone also calls that into question.

The British defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, and the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, supported the idea of regional peacekeeping forces, especially for conflicts such as the one in Sierra Leone. But the fear now is that if the Nigerians behaved so badly as part of a multinational force, they would be even worse if they were the main force operating in the west African country.

Sierra Leone is the biggest UN peacekeeping operation at present, with troops from around the world, and with moves to increase their number from 13,000 to 20,000. Nigeria, with 6,000 troops in the force, would like to have overall control and increase its contingent.

The report is an embarrassment to the Nigerian president, Olusegun Obasanjo, who wants to establish his country as the regional power. Mr Obasanjo, who was at the UN summit yesterday, has gone a long way towards improving Nigeria's image after years of dictatorship. But his efforts are being undone by his army. According to the UN report, the Nigerian army has obstructed peace moves in Sierra Leone because its officers and men are getting rich through illegally trading in diamonds.

The report supports a stream of complaints in the Sierra Leone capital, Freetown, about the Nigerian force. Reports from diverse sources claimed that the Nigerian army was heavily involved in diamonds, false passports, drug-smuggling and other illegal activities. Nigeria is one of the biggest drug centres in Africa and the allegation was that Sierra Leone provided a useful transition point for the shipment of drugs from Nigeria to Europe.

A by-product of this was that the Nigerian army supplied drugs to the Revolutionary United Front rebels, whose ill-disciplined troops have heavy drug habits that go part of the way to explaining the ferocity of their attacks on civilians.

Many of the claims could not be substantiated because they came from the RUF. But others were more credible, such as a pilot working out of Freetown's Lunghi airport who claimed to have knowledge of heavy drug trafficking.

At the heart of it all are Sierra Leone's diamonds. In return for drugs, the Nigerians allegedly receive from the rebels rough diamonds, which are easily sold in Antwerp and Tel Aviv.

The story of the UN is about a chasm between the high ideals at headquarters and the chaos and corruption on the ground.

Gen Jetley complained that the Nigerians put national interest before the good of the UN force. That may be true. But there are many cases of multinational forces co-existing: grumbling, as soldiers do, but getting on with the job, in the Balkans, the Middle East and elsewhere.

The issue in Sierra Leone may be partly one of personality, with Gen Jetley using the report to settle scores with the Nigerians.

The report has to be seen in the context of internal politicking within the UN force in Freetown. The Nigerians resent the fact that they were not given command of the force. The Indians, British and other members of the force would like to see the Nigerians go home, or at the very least ensure that no more arrive.

fields.headline: Wakeham to clarify PM's privacy
fields.standfirst: Special report: Blairs' baby
fields.trailText: The press complaints commission is to clarify its rules on media intrusion following the row over newspaper pictures of Tony Blair's three-month-old son.
fields.body:
The press complaints commission is to clarify its rules on media intrusion following the row over newspaper pictures of Tony Blair's three-month-old son.

Lord Wakeham, the commission's chairman, said yesterday that new guidelines would be published after the prime minister raised concerns over coverage of the christening of his son, Leo.

The guidelines would clarify how the current code should apply to children of prominent figures, such as the prime minister and members of the royal family. There is already a largely successful agreement between the press and St James's Palace over coverage of Prince William, in which regular photo opportunities are given in return for privacy at other times.

Mr Blair, however, has had a difficult relationship with the media over coverage of his family. He had told the press that Leo's christening was private, but some newspapers printed pictures of the Blairs arriving at church with their son. Mr Blair did not make a formal complaint, but asked the commission for guidance.

Lord Wakeham said there was a need to clarify the rules, although the current code would not change.

He said the press code of practice should strike a balance between the public interest and unwarranted intrusion. "What we are looking for are practical, working ways forward, so that it is reasonable on both sides - the public get to know what they should know, newspapers get their stories, but at the same time, privacy is not intruded on the principles concerned in such a way to make their lives intolerable."

fields.headline: Forbidden love
fields.standfirst: Bill and Fidel whisper sweet nothings
fields.trailText: Their eyes met across a crowded room. For years, there had been only a silent, uncertain yearning, spiced with fear. Now they were closer to each other than ever before.
fields.body:
Their eyes met across a crowded room. For years, there had been only a silent, uncertain yearning, spiced with fear. Now they were closer to each other than ever before. The noisy party, the chatter and laughter all around, meant nothing to them. They greeted old friends like Tony, Gerhard and Jacques, Ricardo and Carlos, automatically, hardly taking in what they were saying. Their minds were fixed on one thing, and only one thing. They knew it was forbidden. They knew it could lead to tears and heartache. But something deep inside urged them forward. Slowly, tantalisingly, they edged nearer and nearer. At the very last moment, an over-ebullient Venezuelan almost forced them apart. But then, suddenly, thrillingly, they were together, face to face, gazing into each other's eyes. The moment both had dreamed of for so long had finally come true ...

It is not known exactly what Fidel Castro and Bill Clinton said to each other when they shook hands at Kofi Annan's UN luncheon this week, the first ever personal contact between a US president and the Cuban leader since the 1959 revolution. The White House was at pains to stress that, in keeping with Clinton administration policy on Cuba for the past seven years, nothing substantive was discussed. Yet who knows? Perhaps the conversation went something like this:

Fidel: "Hola, Bill! Que pasa, hombre?"

Bill: "Howdy, Fidel. What's new, bro?"

Fidel: "Not a bad party, this."

Bill: "You mean the Democrats?"

Fidel: "I'm a communist myself."

Bill: "Sure. I heard that."

Fidel: "Y'know, you should come to Havana some day, Bill. It's one helluva wild city! We could show you a good time, know what I mean, amigo?"

Bill: "Hell, no, Fidel. You know I don't give a damn 'bout those Cuban-Americans and all that Bay of Pigs and embargo stuff. But I just can't."

Fidel: "Why not?"

Bill: "Hillary'd never let me, man."

webTitle: Vigilante victim has jail term cut

fields.headline: Vigilante victim has jail term cut
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: A man found guilty of indecently assaulting young girls in a St John Ambulance group run by his wife has been given a reduced jail sentence because a vigilante attack destroyed his home.
fields.body:
A man found guilty of indecently assaulting young girls in a St John Ambulance group run by his wife has been given a reduced jail sentence because a vigilante attack destroyed his home.

Cardiff crown court heard that Roger Gardener's family home in Fleur-de-Lis, Caerphilly, was burned down in August after he was released on bail pending sentence. The family were not in the house at the time.

Gardener and his wife, Margaret, a nurse, were forced out of the village and have been living in a caravan with their daughter, 31, who has learning difficulties.

Jailing him for 15 months yesterday, Judge William Gaskell told Gardener, 56, an unemployed lorry driver: "You will be worried about your daughter because she has lost her home. The unlawful behaviour inflicted on you has the consequence that the sentence is reduced."

Gardener was convicted of indecently assaulting two girls aged 12 and 13 from a first aid class run by his wife at home. Mrs Gardener was out at the time.

The court heard that the girls reported the assaults after Gardener had touched and stroked them and tried to put his hand down their trousers. When he was alone with one of the girls he told her never to tell anybody what had happened, saying that it was her fault.

Judge Gaskell told Gardener he had abused the responsibility he had towards the children. He ordered him to register as a sex offender for 10 years.

Mrs Gardener condemned the outcome as a miscarriage of justice. She said the children had lied and an appeal was planned. "Children have it too easy nowadays," she said. "I'm going to talk to Esther Rantzen and see if she can set up an abuse line for adults."

fields.headline: Bruce Gyngell
fields.standfirst: Maverick television chief who invented the breakfast television sofa and remained Australia's golden media boy for half a century
fields.trailText: Maverick television chief who invented the breakfast television sofa and remained Australia's golden media boy for half a century
fields.body:
Bruce Gyngell, the Australian inventor of British breakfast television, who has died aged 71, was one of the most colourful, idiosyncratic and domineering of media pioneers. He was far removed from the grey-haired executives who have tended to control ITV television behind the scenes. Gyngell stood out even in an industry where media tycoons from Lord (Lew) Grade to Rupert Murdoch called the shots. His staff nicknamed him the "pink panther" because of his love for the colour he saw as life-enhancing: he wore pastel pink shirts, and had his office painted pink, with yellow sofas.

His 50-year career was packed with dramatic twists, spanning the start of television in Australia - his was the first face to appear on screens - and the introduction of sofa-style television to Britain. Gyngell is best known in the UK for his high-profile completion of the rescue of TV-am, a year after its disastrous launch in 1983.

The first commercial breakfast franchise had teetered on the verge of collapse, losing £500,000 a month, when in 1984 he was persuaded by his Australian colleague, the businessman Kerry Packer (who had taken a rescue stake) to sort it out. By 1986 it was ready for flotation on the stock exchange, and briefly flowered into the most profitable of television networks. This was achieved by ruthlessly targeting programme costs - and dumping the 1984 Olympics coverage. He made the station a place "of eternal summer so that the lost, lonely people could turn on and feel warm and bright" - it may have been naff, but it was effective.

He singlehandedly invented friendly sofa-style television and chatty presentation - although it was far from easy. The TV-am sofas were actually benches, to encourage guests to sit up, but upholstered to disguise the fact. Viewers felt they joined a surrogate family, with Anne Diamond playing the fresh-faced but smart girl from next door. The company, run from Camden Lock, North London, was moulded around Gyngell and his often faddish likes and dislikes.

Some thought him barmy, predatory, or worse. Employees had to fit in. But he encouraged newcomers into television: his former secretary, Ulrika Jonsson, was made the weather girl, to inject some cheer into forecasts. Gyngell broke the rules, and liked to pose as being outside the wasteful British television establishment, while always remem bering to court the powerful. One of his early fallings-out was with a talented rising executive, Greg Dyke, who had already set TV-am on the road to recovery with Roland Rat before Gyngell's arrival.

Gyngell, an outspoken believer in market forces, but with charm bordering on charisma, became Margaret Thatcher's favourite broadcasting executive when she was prime minister. When she complained about ITV being the "last bastion of restrictive practices", he endured a bruising technicians' strike from 1987-88 - more than 200 were sacked - but suffered a heart attack due to stress.

He wanted change in ITV to cut out waste, a redrawing of the regional network, a Channel 5 to provide more competition. But by 1988, he was already speaking out against a blind auction of franchises, recognising the destruction it would wreak. By a cruel twist, the highest-bidder auction that Thatcher introduced in the flawed 1990 Broadcasting Act ensured that TV-am's £14.3m bid was completely overshadowed by a rival offer from the GMTV consortium of £34.6m when the awards were announced in October 1991. TV-am, the company he had shaped and nurtured, was effectively destroyed.

But Gyngell had a final surprise up his sleeve. A day after the news broke, he was hosting the first (and last) TV-am journalism awards. There, he dramatically, almost as an afterthought, produced a handwritten letter from Thatcher. He read it out to the astonished audience. "When I see how some of the licences have been awarded, I am mystified that you did not receive yours and heartbroken. You of all people have done so much for the whole of television . . . I am only too painfully aware that I was responsible for the legislation," she wrote.

It was a sensation. The audience gasped, then applauded. Thatcher was saying sorry.

In true Gyngell style, he refused to be broken. He proceeded to hold the company together until December 31 1992, through sheer force of personality. The final morning's broadcast ended, at 9.30 am, with the station belting out You're Simply the Best as a photograph of everyone who had ever worked for the station was flashed on to the screen. It was a moment of high emotion, and great sadness.

Gyngell then hosted a champagne-fuelled farewell party with the sole founder-survivor, Sir David Frost, by his side. Yet, true to promise, the severance terms were very generous, and many of his multi-skilled, hard-working staff were snapped up by GMTV and the rest of ITV. Five years later, he had the bitter satisfaction of being proved right as the licence payments were slashed.

Gyngell always remained Australia's golden media boy. He was born in Melbourne, and inherited some pretty extraordinary genes. His great grandfather was the pyrotechnician for the wedding of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert, while his grandfather, who settled in Australia, introduced cider-making to the continent. His father ran a flying circus before becoming an engineer with Mobil, and his mother was of Irish extraction.

He attended the private Sydney Grammar School and briefly studied medicine at the city's medical school. But he took time out to work as a disc jockey for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, joined the university air squadron and was desolate when the Korean war ended before he had a chance of action. He stayed at ABC until he was 22, when Sir Frank Packer, the newspaper tycoon took a shine to him and offered him a job with Consolidated Press. Packer then won one of the first two licences for commercial television. Gyngell fixed himself up with a two-year traineeship in New York.

At NBC and Columbia University, he fell in love with television, and returned to Australia: on September 16 1956, he opened Packer's network with the words: "Good evening and welcome to television."

In a 10-year stint, he made Channel 9 the most successful network. He got married for the first time, to Ann Barr, and had three children. But, in a pattern that was to repeat itself, he walked out of his job in a row over money and autonomy. He was wooed by the rival Channel 7, with more money and a Bentley - Gyngell loved the good things of life, and was always immaculately dressed.

Then he switched to Lew (later Lord) Grade's ATV in Britain, and backed such 1960s classics as The Golden Shot, Randall & Hopkirk (Deceased) and New Faces. Once again he took off when Grade refused to make him chairman. Back home in Australia, he was offered the chairmanship of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, started an ethnic aboriginal channel, and by the early 1980s had become absorbed with eastern ideas - Zen Buddhism, meditation and the Insight philosophy.

For much of his latter life he followed a macrobiotic diet - even when entertaining at the Savoy. He believed in the power of positive thinking. And he was always very superstitious. At the time of the franchise renewal, staff wore company watches and key fobs, and were supposed to rub them to channel positive forces.

This eccentric streak became ever more pronounced as the success of TV-am allowed him to dictate what went on. The call from Kerry Packer to sort out TV-am, which he had described as a "load of old crap", had made him the UK's highest paid television executive, at £193,000 a year.

In 1986, he married again, this time Kathy Rowan, a TV-am producer, and started a second family, with two sons, Adam (now at Eton) and Jamie. After the licence was handed to GMTV, he toyed with alternatives, but soon returned to Australia, to lick his wounds, and run Channel 9 for two years. He also helped to launch the first World Summit on Children's Television, now a regular biennial fixture.

But this familar maverick did not stay away from Britain for long. He bounced back in 1995, as chief executive of a bruised Yorkshire Television (in an odd double act with its chairman, Ward Thomas), later absorbed by Granada.

F or a man whose private language and jokes could be salty in the extreme, he then pulled another surprise, by turning into a moral guardian. Gyngell was appalled first by tacky late night ITV schedules, and then by a prime-time series, Hollywood Lovers, which had segments on the "mile-high club" and plastic surgery for genitalia. He refused to show these programmes in the Yorkshire region, and ran Whicker's World Turns Again repeats instead.

Two years later, as ITV companies converged, he went into semi-retirement, with homes in Chelsea and Dorset, but with positions at Channel 9 and its holding company, PBC Holdings. It was only in April 2000, as news of his illness spread, that the man who had made such an impact on British television was honoured with a fellowship for lifetime achievement by the Royal Television Society. Many thought it shocking that he had been overlooked for so long.

He is survived by his wife and five children: his son David and daughters Bryony and Sky from his first marriage, and his two sons from his second.

Packer then won one of the first two licences for commercial television. Gyngell fixed himself up with a two-year traineeship in New York. At NBC and Columbia University, he fell in love with television, and returned to Australia: on September 16 1956, he opened Packer's network with the words: "Good evening and welcome to television." In a 10-year stint, he made Channel 9 the most successful network. He got married for the first time, to Ann Barr, and had three children. But, in a pattern that was to repeat itself, he walked out of his job in a row over money and autonomy. He was wooed by the rival Channel 7, with more money and a Bentley - Gyngell loved the good things of life, and was always immaculately dressed. Then he switched to Lew (later Lord) Grade's ATV in Britain, and backed such 1960s classics as The Golden Shot, Randall & Hopkirk (Deceased) and New Faces. Once again he took off when Grade refused to make him chairman. Back home in Australia, he was offered the chairmanship of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, started an ethnic aboriginal channel, and by the early 1980s had become absorbed with eastern ideas - Zen Buddhism, meditation and the Insight philosophy. For much of his latter life he followed a macrobiotic diet - even when entertaining at the Savoy. He believed in the power of positive thinking. And he was always very superstitious. At the time of the franchise renewal, staff wore company watches and key fobs, and were supposed to rub them to channel positive forces. This eccentric streak became ever more pronounced as the success of TV-am allowed him to dictate what went on. The call from Kerry Packer to sort out TV-am, which he had described as a "load of old crap", had made him the UK's highest paid television executive, at £193,000 a year. In 1986, he married again, this time Kathy Rowan, a TV-am producer, and started a second family, with two sons, Adam (now at Eton) and Jamie. After the licence was handed to GMTV, he toyed with alternatives, but soon returned to Australia, to lick his wounds, and run Channel 9 for two years. He also helped to launch the first World Summit on Children's Television, now a regular biennial fixture. But this familar maverick did not stay away from Britain for long. He bounced back in 1995, as chief executive of a bruised Yorkshire Television (in an odd double act with its chairman, Ward Thomas), later absorbed by Granada. F or a man whose private language and jokes could be salty in the extreme, he then pulled another surprise, by turning into a moral guardian. Gyngell was appalled first by tacky late night ITV schedules, and then by a prime-time series, Hollywood Lovers, which had segments on the "mile-high club" and plastic surgery for genitalia. He refused to show these programmes in the Yorkshire region, and ran Whicker's World Turns Again repeats instead. Two years later, as ITV companies converged, he went into semi-retirement, with homes in Chelsea and Dorset, but with positions at Channel 9 and its holding company, PBC Holdings. It was only in April 2000, as news of his illness spread, that the man who had made such an impact on British television was honoured with a fellowship for lifetime achievement by the Royal Television Society. Many thought it shocking that he had been overlooked for so long. He is survived by his wife and five children: his son David and daughters Bryony and Sky from his first marriage, and his two sons from his second.  Bruce Gyngell, broadcasting executive, born July 8 1929; died September 7 2000

webTitle: Romeo and Juliet seduces culture-starved Iranian audiences

fields.headline: Romeo and Juliet seduces culture-starved Iranian audiences
fields.trailText: Juliet wears a fake braid and a veil over her real hair. A male idol of the Iranian cinema appears as Romeo on the dimly-lit stage, as women in the audience gasp.
fields.body:
Juliet wears a fake braid and a veil over her real hair. A male idol of the Iranian cinema appears as Romeo on the dimly-lit stage, as women in the audience gasp.

When some 900 Iranians pack Tehran's Vahdat hall each evening, they come searching for what the director, Ali Rafi'i, calls "their real need for love".

That few of the audience have ever read the script in its original turns the Elizabethan classic into virgin territory.

Mr Rafi'i, a Sorbonne-educated dramatist who was banned for several years from directing plays in Iran, hopes that by breaking the unspoken taboo of glorifying a western icon, art will fill a void in Iran. For 21 years, Iranians have been isolated from the outside world and deprived of classical music, dance and the arts.

"Theatre is not supposed to change the world, but it shows the world can change," he says.

He is doing his part to alter theatrical norms. When a male actor was arrested before the performance one night, he asked a woman to play his part. "Shakespeare had men playing women, we have women playing men," he jokes.

Romeo and Juliet was moral enough to pass the censors, and Mr Rafi'i believes that the compromises he had to make in the staging have allowed him to remain true to the theme and most of the script.

"I never found that I was censoring myself," he says.

"Shakespeare is moral and ethical. We live a life that is filled with metaphors and there is no need for love to be conveyed through touch or embrace. In the play, you never see them in bed making love. They might hold hands, but it is nothing erotic."

An estimated 55,000 Iranians will see the play over 60 performances at a time when conservatives in the judicial establishment are imposing a severe cultural and political crackdown in a fightback against the liberal policies of the culture minister, Ataollah Mohajerani. Progressive newspapers have been shut and writers have been jailed.

Under Mr Mohajerani's leadership, films banned for years have been shown. Art and music once considered un-Islamic has come out of the woodwork and secularist writers have even received prizes.

Most of the play's cast are under 30; actors who want to break the barrier between east and west, Mr Rafi'i says.

"There are young people now who have a different attitude about western culture. They embrace and appreciate it, and don't think about it the way the older generation did."

Juliet, played by Satareh, says the experience is enlightening: "I'm seduced by Shakespeare. I'm in love with it."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report about possible moves to assist with lbw decisions, page 36, yesterday, we discussed a decision against Brian Lara, saying "... the ball had pitched marginally wide of his leg stump, which if he was trying to play the ball meant he should have been given not out". In fact, when the ball pitches outside the leg stump a batsman cannot be given out lbw whether he was attempting to play the ball or not. It is when the ball strikes the batsman outside the line of the off stump, that he can be out lbw, only if he was not playing a shot.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Space station parts launched
fields.body:
Space station parts launched

The space shuttle Atlantis roared off its Florida launch pad yesterday with an international crew on a supply and assembly run to the orbiting international space station. The space station is being prepared for its first long-stay crew expected to arrive in November. Reuters, Cape Canaveral

New Corsica cafe killing

Exactly a month after the murder of nationalist figure Jean-Michel Rossi, four gunmen shot dead a close colleague in front of the cafe where Rossi was killed.

Police said that four gunmen opened fire on Dominique Giuntini, a friend of Rossi, who was an official of the nationalist organisation Cuncolta Independista. AP, Bastia

Too smart for the police

A man who was rejected from the police force after he scored too well in an intelligence test has lost his appeal. The 2nd US circuit court of appeals agreed that New London, Connecticut did not discriminate against Robert Jordan whose test showed an IQ equivalent of 125. The average score for US police officers is 104. AP, New London

fields.headline: Photosensitive drug helps clear arteries
fields.trailText: A drug that works only where a bright light is shone on the body is set to dramatically improve treatment of the biggest killer illness in developed countries, arterial disease.
fields.body:
A drug that works only where a bright light is shone on the body is set to dramatically improve treatment of the biggest killer illness in developed countries, arterial disease.

Use of drugs triggered by light, known as photodynamic therapy (PDT), has been successful in treating head, neck, skin and mouth cancers.

Doctors now claim remarkable results for trials of PDT in balloon angioplasty, endured by thousands of Britons each year to clear blocked arteries.

In angioplasty, a tiny balloon is slid along the artery and inflated to open a blockage, but in a third of cases the artery gets blocked again - with an increased risk of heart failure or limb amputation, and the expensive operation having to be repeated. PDT, where the drug is ingested and triggered by directing a suitcase-sized laser at the area to be treated, seems to sharply reduce the artery clogging again.

Stephen Brown, a professor at the National Medical Laser Centre in London, told the British Association yesterday that seven patients in the world had received combined PDT and angioplasty, all in Britain. "They failed angioplasties the first time, and all were well six months after the new treatment. It's a very new concept, and if it works, it'll revolutionise arterial procedures. The dream is it could be applied to the heart itself."

fields.headline: Blind people's hallucinations 'could explain ghosts'
fields.trailText: Strange ghost-like apparitions and near-death experiences could be caused by a form of "blind vision" often suffered by people who lose their sight, an expert claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Strange ghost-like apparitions and near-death experiences could be caused by a form of "blind vision" often suffered by people who lose their sight, an expert claimed yesterday.

Dominic Ffytche of the Institute of Psychiatry in London told the British Association that 60% of patients suffering from common forms of vision loss had reported hallucinations involving faces.

"You would think it would be of a familiar face, perhaps a relative or someone famous. But they are not. They are often described as being grotesque," he said. "About 40% of people with eye disease hallucinate figures in costumes. These could be Edwardian costumes, knights in shining armour, military uniforms, Napoleonic uniforms, first world war uniforms."

His volunteers hallucinated while he and colleagues observed them using brain scan equipment to pinpoint the activity in the brain that coin cided with the reported hallucination, and which was therefore in some way responsible.

"You get the same phenomena in patients who have had both eyes removed," Dr Ffytche said. "So it is not likely to be abnormal signals coming from the eye. It is a release phenomenon. When there is no information coming in, the brain is idle, cells are firing away and producing these very stereotyped categories of information."

The ability of the brain to conjure up strange and uninvited images could also explain the experience of ghosts. "I am sure that in some way they are related to this," he said.
