webTitle: Arthur myth gives clue to disaster of sixth century

fields.headline: Arthur myth gives clue to disaster of sixth century
fields.standfirst: British Association Tree rings depict comet bombardment
fields.trailText: Scientists are on the trail of a terrible moment in history, recorded only in the annual growth rings of trees around the world.
fields.body:
Scientists are on the trail of a terrible moment in history, recorded only in the annual growth rings of trees around the world.

Chronologies from oaks and other trees from Ireland to Poland, from Finland to Siberia, from North America and even southern South America, all point to the same moment in AD540, when some worldwide event affected growth.

It could, according to Mike Baillie, a palaeoecologist from Queen's University in Belfast, be evidence of a cosmic catastrophe that plunged Europe into the real dark ages. And it could be a key to the world painted in the legends of King Arthur and the Round Table.

Prof Baillie told the British Association's science festival that the tree rings were an accurate record of conditions from the past. The coincidence of low growth in annual rings from around AD540 were evidence of darkened skies and chilly summers, of successive failed harvests and widespread famine. In a succession of upheavals, up to a third of the people of Europe perished.

Even in recent times, he said, failed harvests and epidemics had coincided with stunted tree growth. But stunted growth in three continents in the same year was highly unusual.

"Just how unusual it is can be conveyed by the fact that these chronologies quantify the 540 event as the worst or the second worst or one of the four worst events in the last 1,500 years," he said.

He argued that the story told by the oaks - both living and those extracted from bogs and old buildings - could be evidence of the earth's bombardment by a swarm of comet fragments. There was little evidence in written history, except for a 13th century reference to a comet in Gaul "so vast that the whole sky seemed on fire" in either 540 or 541.

But he said other kinds of story might provide another clue: the dates for the death of the mythical King Arthur were variously 537, 539 and 542, and the legend was centred on the story of a wasteland, an ailing king and failed fertility.

"I've even gone to extreme of looking at some mythology, which is normally taboo for scientists," he said. "The bottom line is, in my view we had some sort of interaction with a comet, a cometary bombardment, not a full-blown comet because we wouldn't be here if we had that, but probably bits of a comet."

Three British astronomers had in 1990 calculated that the earth had been at risk of cometary bombardment between AD400 and AD600.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Driver held over migrants
fields.body:
Driver held over migrants

A London driver was being questioned last night after 37 illegal immigrants, including 12 children, were found in his van on a ferry heading for Dover. The migrants, believed to be from Turkey and Afghanistan, claimed political asylum when they reached Dover.

Rare animals rescued

A hundred rare animals have been seized by police and RSPCA officers from a house in Sanderstead, Surrey, as part of an operation against traders in endangered species. A man is now facing prosecution.

Boys accused of murder bid

Three boys aged 14-16 were were appearing before Stockport magistrates today charged with the attempted murder of Edith Chapman, 87, at her home. Miss Chapman is recovering.

Worms treat sewage

Yorkshire Water is using 120,000 earthworms to consume sludge at its sewage treatment works near Denby Dale, West Yorkshire, as a natural, chemical-free way to kill bacteria.

Pavlova ashes to be sent home

The ashes of Russian ballerina Anna Pavlova are to be returned to her homeland for the 70th anniversary of her death. They have been displayed at Golders Green crematorium in north London since her death in 1931.

Hospital inquiry

The Royal Free hospital in Hampstead, west London, has launched an inquiry after the body of an emergency patient lay undiscovered in a lavatory for more than 12 hours.

webTitle: American race hate leader loses £4m suit

fields.headline: American race hate leader loses £4m suit
fields.trailText: A US jury awarded $6.3m (£4.4m) yesterday to a woman and her son who were attacked by guards outside the Idaho headquarters of the white supremacist group Aryan Nations two years ago.
fields.body:
A US jury awarded $6.3m (£4.4m) yesterday to a woman and her son who were attacked by guards outside the Idaho headquarters of the white supremacist group Aryan Nations two years ago.

The Aryan Nations' leader Richard Butler, the group and its corporate entity were found to be negligent in the selection, training and supervision of the security guards who chased, shot at and assaulted Victoria and Jason Keenan after they stopped to search for a dropped wallet near the Aryan Nations' compound.

The Keenans' lawyer, Morris Dees, said he did not intend to allow the defendants to dispose of their assets. "We intend to enforce this verdict... to take every single asset from the Aryan Nations."

Edgar Steele, representing Butler and the Aryan Nations, said he would press for a new trial or, failing that, an appeal. Butler holds that whites are the true children of God, that Jews are the offspring of Satan and that blacks and other ethnic groups are inferior. AP

fields.headline: Families see Omagh dead photos
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Photographs of the Omagh dead and a tape recording capturing the bomb blast which killed them were presented yesterday at the inquest into the atrocity.
fields.body:
Photographs of the Omagh dead and a tape recording capturing the bomb blast which killed them were presented yesterday at the inquest into the atrocity.

Police pictures showing those declared dead at the scene of the explosion in Co Tyrone two years ago illustrated the scale of the carnage.

A total of 29 people, including a woman seven months' pregnant with twins, died on August 15 1998 in an attack claimed by dissident republican terrorists, the Real IRA.

The photographs showed the bodies where they were initially placed by police, arranged in rows under sheets just off Market Street, where the car bomb went off.

Relatives of those murdered were warned about the content and most left the court, sitting in Omagh leisure centre, to either avoid seeing the images or to watch them in the family room, set aside by the coroner, John Leckey.

The relatives also relived the countdown to the explosion through a recording of police radio messages as they searched for the bomb and tried to move people to safety. The tape carried conversations illustrating where the 25 officers on the ground were, what they were told to do, the situation as they reported it and their priorities.

Stanley McCombe, whose wife Ann died, defended the action taken by the RUC: "I listened to all the tape and to me they did do their utmost under the circumstances."

The coroner rejected an application that Francis Mackey, chairman of the 32 County Sovereignty Movement, linked to the Real IRA, should be added to the list of witnesses.

The inquest was adjourned until Monday.

webTitle: Profile: David James the Dome's crisis manager.

fields.headline: Driving force of the dome doctor
fields.standfirst:
David James prefers to be called a crisis manager. But some see him as a company undertaker

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: David James prefers to be called a crisis manager. But some see him as a company undertaker
fields.body:
On the day "company doctor" David James turned up to inspect his new patient, the assistant at the dome box office offered him an OAP discount. "I thought I looked about 18," James joked. "I work out in the gym every morning at 5.15 for an hour and a quarter. I'm in pretty good shape."

Like the 90 dying businesses he claims to have saved, there is not much fat on James. Nor - if you listen to those at the sharp end of those rescues - much room for sentiment either.

Though he claims to have saved 25,000 jobs, occasionally, as in the case of Dan-Air, the patient has not survived his radical surgery.

"We saw him as an undertaker rather than a doctor," said one union negotiator who dealt with him there. "He's bloody good but he's not a miracle worker. He is interested only in figures. Emotion, sentiment, compassion - I saw none."

James, 62, dislikes the "company doctor" tag , with its overtones of the ruthless surgeon, and prefers to be called a crisis manager. As for Dan-Air, he claims he saved some jobs and helped make Gatwick more than a "bucket and spade airport".

Unflappable

There is, however, a telling story about a photograph he keeps on his desk of the diving support vessel British Argyll, which almost sank one of his toughest cases, North Sea Assets.

"That ship was the last built at Smith's yard on Teesside," said James. "Any tear-jerking stories you ever hear about the poor workers of Sunderland do not take account of the dreadful manner in which that ship was built. It was supposed to be state of the art but turned out to be defective in every respect. It was supposed to be built for £12.4m but cost £42m."

What you must remember, one of his closest colleagues said, is that when "David comes in, more often than not, those involved haven't admitted the truth of the situation to themselves. What he does is blow away the bullshit.

"He is a pretty unflappable guy. David has stared down the barrel of a gun and held his nerve." Quite literally.

In 1986, James - who had been hired to rebuild the engineering group now called TransTec - flew to Tripoli to free a dozen staff working for one of its subsidiaries on a project for the Libyan navy. They had been taken hostage by revolutionary guards. But James was himself held for six days - while the Americans bombed the base, calling it a "legitimate terrorist target" - before negotiating the return of all the men.

It was through another gun - Saddam Hussein's supergun, and his key role in exposing it - that a decade ago James first made the transition from the business pages to the front pages. The affair also cemented his close links with the security services. As the Scott report into arms sent to Iraq makes clear, James did much of the legwork for MI6.

Assassinated

He first noticing the gun's three huge steel tubes, "the thinnest of which had a thumping great muzzle, like something from a strip cartoon siege gun", during a tour of Walter Somers' factory at Halesowen in the West Midlands.

A week after he passed his suspicions on to an MI6 contact called Mr Q, Gerald Bull, the supergun's Canadian designer, was assassinated in Brussels.

James later used his banking contacts to track down the rest of the weapon, which was supposed to fire anthrax shells into Israel, before it left Teesport docks. Part of this cloak-and-dagger operation involved him getting 900 documents from Walter Somers' offices which were photographed secretly through the night with MI6 equipment set up in a room at a Halesowen hotel.

With such a gripping CV, it is hardly surprising that he has been courted by more than one publisher for the story of his life.

He is not immune to vanity, and admits to have "a fairly large City fan club". The only son of a working class cook - born within a mile of the dome - he seems to have had a point to prove. "When I left school at 18 I did not go to Oxford because we could not afford the £1,500 it would have taken to keep me there for three years. Now I can earn that sort of money between breakfast and lunch."

Despite this unabashed self-confidence, there is something in his mix of candour, unshakable competence and quick dry wit which makes people instinctively warm to him.

Firefighter

When he was sent in to sort out Eagle Trust, the empire built by the convicted fraudster John Ferriday, Devon farmer Malcolm Simons complained he had pocketed £2.8m fees over six years. Sir John Harvey-Jones would have been cheaper, he said.

James replied that after deducting the cost of his office, secretary, car, driver, pension and other overheads he was left with "just" £1.5m. "I think you'll find he (Harvey-Jones) is even more expensive than you think I am."

He is certainly a safer pair of hands than his namesake, the equally expensive Aston Villa goalkeeper, nicknamed Calamity James. This David James has his own sobriquet, too - the City's Red Adair, after the Texan who tackles oil well fires.

Stories of his stamina and 80-hour weeks have passed into legend in the Square Mile.

He once worked non-stop for 48 hours at Dan-Air, and later in the space of a few days crisscrossed the globe between London, Hong Kong, Singapore, Bangkok, and back before booking himself into hospital for the night for surgery. He was at his desk the next morning, and rounded off his day with a three-mile run in Hyde Park. James is not a big one for holidays. "I have had the odd weekend in Venice but I have never had a proper holiday abroad. In business I have travelled so much that the last thing I want to do when I'm relaxing is to go a long distance."

That said, he has been known to fly to Sydney to see the whole of a Test match, and allocates himself three sacrosanct weeks a year off to pit his fabled powers of risk analysis against the bookies at Ascot, Goodwood and Cheltenham race courses.

Marriage though, never got a look in. "I never intended to be a bachelor," he said. "When I could have married I felt I was too poor, and when I had enough, I was too busy. Now I am too old."

So what drives this human dynamo to such Stakhanovite excesses in late middle age is something of a mystery.

He lives relatively modestly for a multi-millionaire, between a home in central London and one in Hove close to the cricket ground. Glyndebourne, the home of his other great passion, opera, is only down the road. (He turned around the English Symphony Orchestra just for fun after a major problem with funds). Even his offices in Victoria are "a bit of a broom cupboard". It is the sheer kick of salvaging the seemingly unsalvageable that appears to turn him on.

Asked why he agreed to take on the dome, when he is already chairman of the Robinson Group and a member of Lloyd's regulatory board, James fired back: "Like Everest, it's there. You've got to climb it."

Nor is he being paid, of course. A knighthood being worth so much more, presumably, and a peerage priceless.

webTitle: NatWest in row over tapas bar

fields.headline: NatWest in row over tapas bar
fields.trailText: NatWest has been accused of hypocrisy after a village bank was closed and turned into a bar, even though the company criticises rivals for doing the same thing.
fields.body:
NatWest has been accused of hypocrisy after a village bank was closed and turned into a bar, even though the company criticises rivals for doing the same thing.

The company's advertising campaign, showing a pensioner upset when her bank became a trendy wine bar, aimed to convince customers it would not copy rivals.

The NatWest branch in East Wittering, West Sussex, closed last year. The next nearest branch was in Chichester, seven miles away.

Villagers have now been told the stone building will become a tapas bar called El Banco.

NatWest says there is no embarrassment. A spokesman said: "The branch was sold before the takeover [by Royal Bank of Scotland] but our policies have changed since then.

"Our advertising campaign refers to how we are looking for alternatives to our previous programme of closures."

He admitted 10 branches have been closed in three years, leaving 62 in Sussex.

One of the El Banco owners, Nick Cheshire, said: "It's a boost for the area and will create 10 jobs."

fields.headline: Ancient palace found in jungle
fields.standfirst: Expedition stumbles on 'most incredible Mayan find for a century'
fields.trailText: A Mayan palace that has been discovered in a remote Guatemalan jungle is being hailed as a major archaeologicalfind that could mean the rewriting of Mayan history.
fields.body:
A Mayan palace that has been discovered in a remote Guatemalan jungle is being hailed as a major archaeologicalfind that could mean the rewriting of Mayan history.

The size and condition of the palace are said to rival that of the temple in Tikal, in the north of the country, regarded as one of the great ancient sites of the world. The archaeologists who unearthed the palace literally stumbled into it.

The discovery was made by archaeologists led by Dr Arthur Demarest of Vanderbilt University in Nashville and Dr Tomas Barrientos of the Universidad del Valle in Guatemala.

The expedition, which was sponsored by the Guatemalan Institute of Anthropology and History, the National Geographic Society and Vanderbilt University, unearthed previously hidden buildings and artefacts at Cancuen, north-east of Guatemala City, and near the Pasion River.

It is believed that the discovery will lead to a new understanding of political life in Mayan civilisation which was at its height between AD300 and 900, the so-called classic period.

Mayan civilisation was divided into several rival city states, mainly in Guatemala but also in Mexico, Belize and Honduras.

Classic Mayan civilisation collapsed around AD900 for no generally agreed reason and all the cities were abandoned. It is hoped that the latest discovery may throw some light on this period.

"No-one has found anything like this since the turn of the last century," Dr Demarest told the New York Times. "What is most incredible about this site is that most of the palace is buried virtually intact."

The king who completed the construction of the palace at Cancuen was Tah ak Chaan who ruled the area for around 50 years from 740 onwards.

What differentiates the site from the better-known ones in Guatemala is that there is no sign of the spectacular pyramids which have been seen as the hallmark of the Mayan sites.

This is one of the reasons that it has remained undiscovered for so long.

There was also initially no indication that the city state there had engaged in warfare which is highly unusual for the period.

A lot of jade has already been found at the site. One 16kg (35lb) piece had been discovered which had been used for creating ornaments. The walls are constructed of solid limestone. Surprisingly there is little indication of religious practices which are normally a feature of such sites.

Dr Demarest decided to visit the area last year after more than 10 years of archaeological research in Guatemala. He was following up a finding by members of his team which referred to a princess from Cancuen.

"To the untrained eye, the palace looks just like a great jungle-covered hill," said Dr Demarest.

It was while walking in the area that he fell into a gap and realised that he had stumbled across what turned out to be a three-storey palace built around 11 courtyards and encompassing 170 rooms.

The city appears to have had a large commercial centre with many artisans employed producing ornaments for trading. The stonework is said to be of a very high standard and there have been finds of pyrite, or fool's gold, which was used for making mirrors.

It is estimated that it will take around 10 years to excavate the site fully. Although the area is no longer in the throes of a civil war, which ended in 1996, it is in a fairly inaccessible region of Guatemala.

The full excavations are unlikely to start until next February at the end of the rainy season.

The discovery will be welcomed by the Guatemalan government who have suffered from the departure of tourists in recent months following a fatal attack on a group of Japanese visitors in the village of Todos Santos.

Tikal has been a chief reason for tourists to visit the area and the discovery of such a major site is likely to bring in a new wave of tourists to help the country's embattled economy.

webTitle: Fishing net 'pinger' device could cut porpoise deaths

fields.headline: Fishing net 'pinger' device could cut porpoise deaths
fields.trailText: Fishermen may soon have to fit porpoise scarers to their boats to help end the destruction of thousands of marine mammals entangled in their gear.
fields.body:
Fishermen may soon have to fit porpoise scarers to their boats to help end the destruction of thousands of marine mammals entangled in their gear.

Trials of battery operated underwater "pingers" attached to long nets which are set on the seabed to catch cod and hake have proved so successful at scaring shy harbour porpoises away that the EU is to discuss making them compulsory.

Some boats might need as many as 160 of the devices, each the size of a soft drinks can and costing about £30, to deter the porpoises from feeding in the area when their nets are down.

Porpoises cannot return to the surface to breathe - which they need to do about every four minutes - if they become entangled.

Pingers are already used along the US coasts and tests suggest they would work on this side of the Atlantic. Fishermen from Newlyn, Cornwall, and three Irish ports volunteered for EU-funded trials of pingers led by the sea mammal research unit at St Andrews University, Fife.

Research in the Celtic sea in the early 1990s suggested that 2,200 harbour porpoises, or about 6% of the population, were accidentally killed in fishing nets. The pingers emit sounds every four seconds. These can be heard by humans but also have ultrasonic harmonics.

Andrew Wheeler, of the Cornish Fish Producers' Association, said: "No one wants to catch porpoises. They have no commercial benefit. It is nothing but aggravation. If we can avoid catching them, we will look at it, as long as it is not too much of a cost."

Elliot Morley, the fisheries minister, said the UK had stressed the importance of the trial results with the EU.

"The issue of porpoise by-catch is an international problem and we have to tackle it on an EU basis."

webTitle: The dome. It'll all be over by Christmas. Or shortly after

fields.headline: The dome. It'll all be over by Christmas. Or shortly after
fields.trailText: The point about the Millennium Dome is, of course, that its future has become a battle of wills between the press and the government. War was declared at the New Year's Eve security imbroglio at Stratford tube station, and since then each side has been determined to win at any cost, whether to truth or to the public purse. This is why journalists, including those who have never bothered to go, will never give the dome the slightest credit for anything, and why the government will go on paying to keep it open no matter what happens. This time at least hostilities will be over by Christmas, or just after, and, like the first world war, will end with both sides exhausted and nothing very much changed.
fields.body:
The point about the Millennium Dome is, of course, that its future has become a battle of wills between the press and the government. War was declared at the New Year's Eve security imbroglio at Stratford tube station, and since then each side has been determined to win at any cost, whether to truth or to the public purse. This is why journalists, including those who have never bothered to go, will never give the dome the slightest credit for anything, and why the government will go on paying to keep it open no matter what happens. This time at least hostilities will be over by Christmas, or just after, and, like the first world war, will end with both sides exhausted and nothing very much changed.

But however you slice it, it is a public-relations disaster for the government. Having been abroad at the time, I was glad to hear repeated Peter Mandelson's extraordinarily unpleasant interview on Today about Julia Langdon's biography of Mo Mowlam. Julia is a relation by marriage, so I'm biased, but I think most people would marvel at the way the prime minister's master manipulator, the man with his finger permanently resting on the public pulse, is so ignorant of the general opinion that he thinks that his whining, self-justifying tone, like chocolate-covered bile, will make anyone trust a single judgment he makes.

 Sacha Distel is in trouble at home for suggesting that English is a better language for singing than French. I suspect he's wrong. French is, in itself, a very musical language, even when used by hard-swearing truck drivers, which is why the actual tunes of French songs tend to be so lacklustre. In fact, it's my theory that all French pop songs have the same melody. Take Françoise Hardy's huge hit, Tous les Garçons et les Filles, in which, with hypnotic boredom, the first 12 syllables are all sung on the same note.

 The Bolsheviks at Ekatarinburg knew what to do when you had a house full of unpopular and dysfunctional people; you took them to the cellar and shot the lot. Sadly this won't happen to the cast of Big Brother. (Why, if it's supposed to be gripping the nation, do the best audience figures show that only 10% of us are watching it?) The most depressing news-paper picture of the week showed two ousted occupants of the house, Nichola and Caroline, lying on the floor of some ghastly function, having collided with Vanessa Feltz. Depressing because it's obvious that the British press, desperate for something to fill empty acres of newsprint, has decided that these people are stars, to be courted, feted and reported, and not just that most lethal type of nonentity, the extrovert bore. We will know that the end has been reached when one of them turns up as a member of the Booker prize panel.

 We did a lot of riding on holiday, and decided that the children should wear helmets. Not surprisingly, this evoked a mixture of rage and shame. Our 14-year-old daughter even refused to be photographed with the thing off her head, on the grounds that wearing it had messed up her hair. The result was that I had to act like a paparazzo with my own family, sneaking snapshots when they weren't looking. All very silly, I thought, until I returned to England to learn that a TV company is making a film about the late Kenneth Williams, and wants to use a clip from an interview I did with him on BBC2 almost 20 years ago. I was flattered at first, but then the horror hit me: the long, lank, greasy hair, the appalling glasses and, I suspect, an unforgivable tie! Nobody who watches this will hear a word Williams says. Instead they will be gazing in terrified awe at my hideous, post-1970s appearance, and my poor children will be jeered in school.

 George W Bush is supposedly in hot water after calling a New York Times reporter "a major-league asshole", though I can't imagine it will do him any harm with the voters, especially as the Times has become a very self-consciously elite national paper. And at least what he said was perfectly coherent. There are now many websites devoted to Bushisms, offering hours of agreeable browsing and proving that linguistic incompetence may be genetically transferred. The best quotes appear on all the sites, and include - from last month alone - "we cannot let terrorists and rogue nations hold this nation hostile, or hold our allies hostile" and "this campaign not only hears the voices of the entrepreneurs and the farmers and the entrepreneurs, we hear the voices of those struggling to get ahead".

Other golden goodies include "there's not going to be enough people in the system to take advantage of people like me" (in a discussion of pensions). Or this penetrating analysis of his campaigning style: "Actually, I - this may sound a little west Texan to you, but I like it. When I'm talking about - when I'm talking about myself, and when he's talking about myself, all of us are talking about me." To his rival, John McCain, he said: "I think we agree, the past is over." Then there is his plan for economic recovery: "We ought to make the pie higher." Many of the best are too long to reprint, but have a tremendous rococo charm, as he rambles up and down through the byways of his mind, sometimes getting stuck in the bracken of his inchoate emotions, sometimes being knocked over by a passing thought or aperçu. There's no reason why this should hurt his chances; two of the last three American presidents suffered from just the same affliction.

 Many thanks to all of you who wrote and emailed to say where I could find a copy of William Hope Hodgson's classic horror stories, Carnacki the Ghost-Finder. Though, admittedly, two people only offered the Japanese translation. I now have two copies in English, and have no intention of waiting till I get flu before I read it.
fields.bodyText: The point about the Millennium Dome is, of course, that its future has become a battle of wills between the press and the government. War was declared at the New Year's Eve security imbroglio at Stratford tube station, and since then each side has been determined to win at any cost, whether to truth or to the public purse. This is why journalists, including those who have never bothered to go, will never give the dome the slightest credit for anything, and why the government will go on paying to keep it open no matter what happens. This time at least hostilities will be over by Christmas, or just after, and, like the first world war, will end with both sides exhausted and nothing very much changed. But however you slice it, it is a public-relations disaster for the government. Having been abroad at the time, I was glad to hear repeated Peter Mandelson's extraordinarily unpleasant interview on Today about Julia Langdon's biography of Mo Mowlam. Julia is a relation by marriage, so I'm biased, but I think most people would marvel at the way the prime minister's master manipulator, the man with his finger permanently resting on the public pulse, is so ignorant of the general opinion that he thinks that his whining, self-justifying tone, like chocolate-covered bile, will make anyone trust a single judgment he makes.  Sacha Distel is in trouble at home for suggesting that English is a better language for singing than French. I suspect he's wrong. French is, in itself, a very musical language, even when used by hard-swearing truck drivers, which is why the actual tunes of French songs tend to be so lacklustre. In fact, it's my theory that all French pop songs have the same melody. Take Françoise Hardy's huge hit, Tous les Garçons et les Filles, in which, with hypnotic boredom, the first 12 syllables are all sung on the same note.  The Bolsheviks at Ekatarinburg knew what to do when you had a house full of unpopular and dysfunctional people; you took them to the cellar and shot the lot. Sadly this won't happen to the cast of Big Brother. (Why, if it's supposed to be gripping the nation, do the best audience figures show that only 10% of us are watching it?) The most depressing news-paper picture of the week showed two ousted occupants of the house, Nichola and Caroline, lying on the floor of some ghastly function, having collided with Vanessa Feltz. Depressing because it's obvious that the British press, desperate for something to fill empty acres of newsprint, has decided that these people are stars, to be courted, feted and reported, and not just that most lethal type of nonentity, the extrovert bore. We will know that the end has been reached when one of them turns up as a member of the Booker prize panel.  We did a lot of riding on holiday, and decided that the children should wear helmets. Not surprisingly, this evoked a mixture of rage and shame. Our 14-year-old daughter even refused to be photographed with the thing off her head, on the grounds that wearing it had messed up her hair. The result was that I had to act like a paparazzo with my own family, sneaking snapshots when they weren't looking. All very silly, I thought, until I returned to England to learn that a TV company is making a film about the late Kenneth Williams, and wants to use a clip from an interview I did with him on BBC2 almost 20 years ago. I was flattered at first, but then the horror hit me: the long, lank, greasy hair, the appalling glasses and, I suspect, an unforgivable tie! Nobody who watches this will hear a word Williams says. Instead they will be gazing in terrified awe at my hideous, post-1970s appearance, and my poor children will be jeered in school.  George W Bush is supposedly in hot water after calling a New York Times reporter "a major-league asshole", though I can't imagine it will do him any harm with the voters, especially as the Times has become a very self-consciously elite national paper. And at least what he said was perfectly coherent. There are now many websites devoted to Bushisms, offering hours of agreeable browsing and proving that linguistic incompetence may be genetically transferred. The best quotes appear on all the sites, and include - from last month alone - "we cannot let terrorists and rogue nations hold this nation hostile, or hold our allies hostile" and "this campaign not only hears the voices of the entrepreneurs and the farmers and the entrepreneurs, we hear the voices of those struggling to get ahead". Other golden goodies include "there's not going to be enough people in the system to take advantage of people like me" (in a discussion of pensions). Or this penetrating analysis of his campaigning style: "Actually, I - this may sound a little west Texan to you, but I like it. When I'm talking about - when I'm talking about myself, and when he's talking about myself, all of us are talking about me." To his rival, John McCain, he said: "I think we agree, the past is over." Then there is his plan for economic recovery: "We ought to make the pie higher." Many of the best are too long to reprint, but have a tremendous rococo charm, as he rambles up and down through the byways of his mind, sometimes getting stuck in the bracken of his inchoate emotions, sometimes being knocked over by a passing thought or aperçu. fields.headline: The death of music
fields.trailText: The most contentious issue has proved to be the demise of Alkan. Several readers claim that the object that fell fatally on his head was not, as I stated, a wardrobe, but a bookcase.
fields.body:
Michael Heseltine, the autobiographer, member of parliament and author of the proposition that the best way to bring regeneration to a blighted peninsula is to build a Millennium Dome on it, came up with a wonderful put-down when his leader (a Mr Hague) had the temerity to suggest that this dome be put out of its misery. Hague, he suggested, "may not have been apprised of the facts". What a great way of saying: "This teenage nincompoop has shot off his mouth without having the slightest notion what he is talking about," without uttering one word of insult. This chap will go far.

Which brings me neatly on to a subject that has stirred Smallweed readers into a frenzy: the deaths of musicians. The most contentious issue has proved to be the demise of Alkan. Several readers claim that the object that fell fatally on his head was not, as I stated, a wardrobe, but a bookcase. He was reaching up to the shelf on which he kept the Talmud, which was found in his hand when his body was discovered. But according to Grove, even this is not true: my favourite Exonian savant, of whom more in a moment, asserts that these claims were demolished by the Musical Times in 1976, not because a bound copy of that fine publication fell on them, but because a scholar disproved it.

Basil Howitt writes from Manchester to dispute my findings on Strauss. The one who fell off the platform, he says, was not Eduard, but his brother Josef. Eduard's weakness (he bases this passage on a book on the Strausses by Peter Kemp) was not for falling off platforms but for setting fire to things. According to Kemp, on October 22 1907 Eduard arrived at the premises of a furnace manufacturer in Vienna's Mariahilf district "with a vehicle laden with 'several hundred kilos of waste paper'.

Realising that the 'waste paper' was, in fact, the music archives of the Strauss family, the factory owner attempted in vain to dissuade Strauss from such folly. Seating himself in an armchair in front of the two large kilns, Eduard looked on as workmen scattered the sheets of music into the flames." They finished five hours later. Strauss, it is said, disposed of two more cartloads of music "at a factory in the Porzellangasse". I do hope no one tells me this tale is untrue.

Here is another musical death involving transport. According to Geoffrey Wheatcroft, Gustav Kobbé, compiler of the Complete Opera book, was an amateur yachtsman. One day in 1918 he was sailing at Great South Bay on Long Island Sound when a seaplane landed and sank his boat. Here is another that doesn't: according to Grove, the Bohemian composer Francis Kotzwara, otherwise Frantisek Koczwara, died in mysterious circumstances in a house of ill fame in Vine Street in the St Martin's sector of London in 1791. A footnote explains - they put these things in footnotes to discourage children from reading them - that Susanna Hill stood trial at the Old Bailey on September 16 that year for hanging him. There was no dispute that Hill had placed a cord around the composer's neck, but this seems to have been for reasons which I too shall have to put in a footnote. At any rate, he did not survive, and I'm not sure his set of six songs, listed in Grove, did any better.

Whatever you make of such incidents, there is no doubt at all that the lives as well as the deaths of many great composers are inextricably linked with transport. My favourite Exonian savant lists, among others, De-bus-sy, Bus-oni, Antonio Cab-ezon, Elliot Car-ter, and even Vaughan Williams (usually known as VW). All, as he says, are connected with t-Ravel. Those whose names lack such connotations put them into their work: Bizet's Car-men, for instance, Holst's Plane-ts, or Wag(o)ner's Ring Cycle. Handel, he adds, spent most of his life composing Handel bars. Many other composers, he further claims, must have travelled by bus, since one often reads of them being murdered by conductors. There is more on this issue, including a clarification of Zemlinksy's relationship to Schoenberg, but that is enough for this week.

Smallweed has been apostrophised - I choose the word with care - by the Sutton, Cheam and Worcester Park Conservative Association. In their trenchant publication, Impact for Cheam, two local councillors complain of "another woeful performance by Suttons Liberal Democrat council", which is unable, they claim, to "tend Suttons street scene". "Tony Blairs Labour government", they go on to contend, "has made Britains petrol the most expensive in the World". Even worse, "despite the councils area development committee voting against it", plans continue to be pursued for an ill-considered scheme for development in Wilbury Avenue. "Cheams special character," the councillors warn, "must be saved from further erosion." One of the author's, I see, is the partys spokesman on education on S'utton council. I am sure William Hague would act to defend the partys reputation for literacy, were he only to be apprised of the fact's.

Some dates for your diary: September 16: 209th anniversary of the trial of Susanna Hill.

October 22: 93rd anniversary of the alleged encounter of Eduard Strauss with the furnace manufacturer.

January 2001: 25th anniversary of the appearance of the piece in the Musical Times on the death of Alkan.

September 2001: third anniversary of Peter Mandelson's pledge: "I intend the dome to be a symbol of all that is best in Britain. And it will be. Promise.

 1: An extraordinary story of sexual abnormality.

webTitle: Play dough: Collectors will pay serious money for yesterday's classic discs

fields.headline: Record prices on the table in the vinyl countdown
fields.standfirst: Avid to relive the heady days of their youth, collectors will pay serious money for yesterday's classic discs, says Stewart Dalby
fields.trailText: Avid to relive the heady days of their youth, collectors will pay serious money for yesterday's classic discs, says Stewart Dalby
fields.body:
Some years back, on a visit to Liverpool, I visited the Beatles quarter, the cluster of shops around the site of The Cavern, the now defunct cellar club where the famous band first played.

I nearly bought a copy of The White Album, the double LP issued in the mid-60s at the very height of their fame. The price was £40, which I thought was bit steep, even though the White Album had the distinction, rare at the time, of being numbered, and this was an early number.

Now, of course, I wish I had bought it. In a newly opened Beatles shop in London I saw a similar copy recently for £200. The Beatles are very much an industry in themselves . Liverpool has centred its tourist industry on them: the average tourist spend in the Beatles quarter is almost double what it is on Albert Dock, the expensively refurbished riverside complex of museums, shops and bars.

In auctions, any memorabilia, correspondence or guitars always top the price list often fetching tens of thousands of pounds. But there is a large market not just for the Beatles but for most vinyl records, as witnessed by the large number of record fairs, shops, websites and magazines. Vinyl came in at the beginning of the 60s and coincided with the explosion of popular music in the UK after Bill Haley, Elvis Presley et al had started rock'n'roll in the US.

It is primarily popular music. There are people who collect the old 78-rpm classical records, made of the composite shellac or breakable Bakelite. But Alexander Crum-Ewing at Bonham's, who sells vinyl records at pop and rock memorabilia sales, says: "Generally speaking, we are not interested in the old classical shellac 78 prm recordings. They were breakable and by the time they reached us here they were too scratchy. That is not to say others are not interested.

"A rare recording by Sir Thomas Beecham, say, which has not been reproduced in any other form, would probably be valuable, but here we are interested in the pop and rock market, which is huge."

Joel McIver at Record Collector magazine, which has a circulation of around 50,000, says: "The market is worth millions a year; there are fairs all the time. Who is it that collects them? Is it greying 60s persons like myself, drowning in nostalgia and trying to relive their youth when it was good to be alive?

He laughs as he says: "We do market research on our readership and yes, the bulk of them are people who were young in the 60s and 70s. But there are also younger people who collect more recent bands. There are collectors who have to have every recording made by a particular, favourite band. There are others who need to have every version of a particular song. These really are people who would mortgage their houses for a particular record. Collectors are collectors: you know what they are like."

Record Collector magazine publishes a table of the top 500 collectible artists. The top 10 are usually unchanging year-on-year. The last chart, published in April, had the Beatles at number one, the Rolling Stones at number two, Queen number three and Elvis Presley number four, all exactly the same as last year.

Those jostling for the other six positions include Bob Dylan, Led Zeppelin, Pink Floyd and Jimi Hendrix.

As a rule of thumb Joel McIver reckons that most vinyls by well-known artists would fetch four-figure sums, depending on their condition There is a parallel here with modern first editions of books. They have to be in good condition, and in their dust jackets, to fetch top prices.

Similarly, an LP has to be in mint condition, as if it has never, or hardly ever, been played. The jacket must appear to be untouched. Joel McIver says: "Even an Oasis record from the height of their fame in, say, 1996, could fetch over £1,000."

But a distinction should be made between the well-known artists and rare collectibles. The best- known bands and artists sold records in millions. Moreover, when CDs came along many people disposed of their vinyl, so the fairs became awash with famous names. Not all records by top bands sell.

On the other hand, one-hit wonders or original acetates or demo discs can fetch high prices, partly because they have not been reproduced as CDs.

Martin O'Gorman, who also works at Record Collector magazine, cites records by some of the "progressive" rock bands of the 70s - Dark, worth £1,800 from 1972, Friends, worth £1,500 from 1974, and Dodo Resurrection, £2,000, from 1972.

He says: "They are Pink Floyd-like, long-winded, twiddly, muso things, with one song taking up the whole side of an album."

Another rarity is the 1977 rendition of God Save the Queen, with No Feeling on the B-side, by the Sex Pistols. Shortly after signing the deal with record company A&M the Sex Pistols parted company and the records were ordered to be destroyed. Some survived and can now fetch £1,500.

Inevitably, the UK's most expensive record comes from the Beatles, or at least from the pre-Beatles outfit, the Quarry Men. This was a 10-inch acetate of Buddy Holly's That'll Be the Day/In Spite of All the Danger. Paul McCartney made a few copies of this for his friends. He is also known to have a copy. Martin O'Gorman says: "It would be worth at least £100,000 if he sold it."

fields.headline: Shades of doubt
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... why common errors are no less wrong
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... why common errors are no less wrong
fields.body:
No part of the paper escapes the scrutiny of readers, but some parts are scrutinised more than others. Among these are the leader columns where, recently, we wrote, "Youngsters are undoubtably inspired by the Ginolas and Zolas flaunting their rare skills..."

This brought the following email from a reader in Perugia: "Admittably," he wrote, "I have been absent from Britain for over 20 years, but I still find the neologism 'undoubtably' somewhat objectionable." In fact, although "admittably" may be a neologism, a new word, used here ironically of course, "undoubtably" undoubtedly is not. It is the opposite, an archaism that seems to have enjoyed a sparse and fairly brief currency during the 15th and early 16th centuries before falling into desuetude (a word that you do not hear very often), if not quite into obsolescence. The Oxford English Dictionary notes it as "? Obs".

"Undoubtably" had, according to the OED, exactly the same meaning as "undoubtedly" - the word which has proved to be much more durable and the one which the leader writer undoubtedly intended to use - "without doubt, indubitably". The use of "undoubtably" today is, paradoxically, an error but not an inaccuracy.

It would be nice to think that its use was conscious and that we were deliberately led into a surprising encounter with it in the flat linguistic terrain of contemporary daily journalism. I am afraid not. It is a common and unwitting substitute, particularly perhaps in speech, for the word that enjoys the approved status.

It is difficult to say whether it is, or is about to become, one of those errors so commonly used that it ceases to be regarded as an error and instead gains first our tolerance and then our acceptance as a legitimate part of the language. I think not - not, at any rate, in the foreseeable future. It does not appear in Collins Millennium edition, which has an ear for changes, an absence that may reassure the expatriate (not ex-patriot, as we have been known to say) in Perugia. Nevertheless, its history is seductive and even though it is always these days used in ignorance, and we should disapprove of it, I am not actually affronted by it.

Readers point out other things, often far more irritating, which appear to fall into the same category of ignorant use bringing pressure to bear for change through persistence and proliferation. The confusion of singular and plural is an example and we are guilty of this in many ways.

One of them was illustrated by a headline not long ago in which we said, "President Putin needs time and money to steer his country's transition to a market economy. And neither are in very great supply." We should have said, "And neither is in very great supply" - neither one nor the other is...

On this point Collins is clear, offering the following guidance on usage after its definition of neither: "A verb following a compound subject that uses neither... (nor) should be in the singular if both subjects are in the singular: neither Jack nor John has done the work."

The New Fowler's Modern English usage is good on this, pointing out exceptions and complications, for instance when both subjects are not singular: "Neither eyes nor nose (does its, do their) work" - a complication arising from the use of eyes, plural, with nose, singular.

The current edition of Fowler retains the following admirable advice from the 1926 edition: "The wise man, in writing, evades these problems by rejecting the alternatives - any of which may set up friction between him and his reader - and putting the thing in some other shape_" (The wise man today would avoid a sentence as resoundingly masculine as that - something guaranteed to set up friction.)

The use of "none", over which we often stumble, is much more straightforward and should always be followed by a singular form of verb: but then none of us is perfect.

Readers like to feel that we are at least aspiring to meticulous accuracy ("meticulous inaccuracy" was Proust's satirical comment on the writings of the Goncourt brothers) in our use of the language. A doctor wrote recently to comment on the following statement by another doctor in G2: "I have delivered babies to single mothers." This was not an unusual error, he said, "but it should really have been 'I have delivered single mothers' or 'I have delivered single mothers of their babies.' " He added, "It is a nice point, I know, but it is storks, rather than doctors, that deliver babies." He is right, of course.

Sometimes our informality (a word which Fowler sees as code for "illiterate", "vulgar" or "sloppy") goes too far. We recently noticed a motorist who was "sat in a queue" and a person who "promised to work for free". A little loose, perhaps, even by our standards.

 The Proust remark is quoted in Marcel Proust: A Biography by Jean-Yves Tadi, tr Euan Cameron (Viking).

Among these are the leader columns where, recently, we wrote, "Youngsters are undoubtably inspired by the Ginolas and Zolas flaunting their rare skills..." This brought the following email from a reader in Perugia: "Admittably," he wrote, "I have been absent from Britain for over 20 years, but I still find the neologism 'undoubtably' somewhat objectionable." In fact, although "admittably" may be a neologism, a new word, used here ironically of course, "undoubtably" undoubtedly is not. It is the opposite, an archaism that seems to have enjoyed a sparse and fairly brief currency during the 15th and early 16th centuries before falling into desuetude (a word that you do not hear very often), if not quite into obsolescence. The Oxford English Dictionary notes it as "? Obs". "Undoubtably" had, according to the OED, exactly the same meaning as "undoubtedly" - the word which has proved to be much more durable and the one which the leader writer undoubtedly intended to use - "without doubt, indubitably". The use of "undoubtably" today is, paradoxically, an error but not an inaccuracy. It would be nice to think that its use was conscious and that we were deliberately led into a surprising encounter with it in the flat linguistic terrain of contemporary daily journalism. I am afraid not. It is a common and unwitting substitute, particularly perhaps in speech, for the word that enjoys the approved status. It is difficult to say whether it is, or is about to become, one of those errors so commonly used that it ceases to be regarded as an error and instead gains first our tolerance and then our acceptance as a legitimate part of the language. I think not - not, at any rate, in the foreseeable future. It does not appear in Collins Millennium edition, which has an ear for changes, an absence that may reassure the expatriate (not ex-patriot, as we have been known to say) in Perugia. Nevertheless, its history is seductive and even though it is always these days used in ignorance, and we should disapprove of it, I am not actually affronted by it. Readers point out other things, often far more irritating, which appear to fall into the same category of ignorant use bringing pressure to bear for change through persistence and proliferation. The confusion of singular and plural is an example and we are guilty of this in many ways. One of them was illustrated by a headline not long ago in which we said, "President Putin needs time and money to steer his country's transition to a market economy. And neither are in very great supply." We should have said, "And neither is in very great supply" - neither one nor the other is... On this point Collins is clear, offering the following guidance on usage after its definition of neither: "A verb following a compound subject that uses neither... (nor) should be in the singular if both subjects are in the singular: neither Jack nor John has done the work." The New Fowler's Modern English usage is good on this, pointing out exceptions and complications, for instance when both subjects are not singular: "Neither eyes nor nose (does its, do their) work" - a complication arising from the use of eyes, plural, with nose, singular. The current edition of Fowler retains the following admirable advice from the 1926 edition: "The wise man, in writing, evades these problems by rejecting the alternatives - any of which may set up friction between him and his reader - and putting the thing in some other shape_" (The wise man today would avoid a sentence as resoundingly masculine as that - something guaranteed to set up friction.) The use of "none", over which we often stumble, is much more straightforward and should always be followed by a singular form of verb: but then none of us is perfect. Readers like to feel that we are at least aspiring to meticulous accuracy ("meticulous inaccuracy" was Proust's satirical comment on the writings of the Goncourt brothers) in our use of the language. A doctor wrote recently to comment on the following statement by another doctor in G2: "I have delivered babies to single mothers." This was not an unusual error, he said, "but it should really have been 'I have delivered single mothers' or 'I have delivered single mothers of their babies.' " He added, "It is a nice point, I know, but it is storks, rather than doctors, that deliver babies." He is right, of course. Sometimes our informality (a word which Fowler sees as code for "illiterate", "vulgar" or "sloppy") goes too far. We recently noticed a motorist who was "sat in a queue" and a person who "promised to work for free". A little loose, perhaps, even by our standards.  The Proust remark is quoted in Marcel Proust: A Biography by Jean-Yves Tadi, tr Euan Cameron (Viking). fields.headline: The last word on   Frankness
fields.standfirst: If lies kill love, what does frankness do? -  Abel Hermant
fields.trailText: If lies kill love, what does frankness do? - Abel Hermant
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam is popular with the public because of her frankness and informality, but they are characteristics which doubtless explain any unpopularity she suffers among political colleagues, and which might have contributed to her decision, announced this week, to leave politics. Both she and presidential candidate George W Bush, who in an unguarded moment called a journalist an "asshole" thinking that nearby microphones were switched off, are finding that frankness is an expensive commodity in public life. The same is true in private life, except when it is judiciously employed and tempered by kindness; for frankness can do greater harm to others than to oneself.

To speak frankly is to reveal what one really thinks, to tell the truth exactly as one sees it, and to do so whatever the consequences. When people are not frank they are being careful, or dishonest, or tactful - and often enough all three. Many find that dishonesty and tact are far more useful for getting on in life than frankness, a regrettable truth as regards dishonesty, but not always so as regards tact; for tact is an expression of concern for others' needs and sensitivities, and is an important instrument in helping people negotiate the unpredictable complexities of relationships.

The only kind of person who can always be frank is the saint who has no tincture of spite or small-mindedness in his character. He says what he thinks, and even when it is uncomplimentary to his interlocutors they sense that there is no malice in him and take no offence.

But there are few such people in the world, and since the rest of us cannot guarantee the purity of our motives in speaking bluntly to others, politeness acquires a great value. In every social transaction most of us are, consciously or otherwise, at work assessing how much frankness the circumstances can bear.

Occasions differ - someone in a hurt or vulnerable state might need a few kind indirections to survive his crisis; an assembly of dinner guests might be offended by inappropriately chosen or presented facts, or bored by too large a quantum of them - so in both cases tact is in order. It is an intelligent virtue; everyone can be frank, even (perhaps best of all) the simple and careless; but not everyone can finely adjust how and what he says to ameliorate human intercourse, through which more good is likely to come than otherwise.

Frankness is often a weapon deployed to wound or take revenge. We might sometimes tell people home truths because we are concerned for their welfare, but more often because we are inspired by hurt, jealousy or anger. "All cruel people describe themselves as paragons of frankness," Tennessee Williams observed. And the point about "home truths" is that they - and with them, frankness in general - do not invariably reflect the truth properly so called. Often it is only what one thinks or claims is the truth - even less: one's own unvarnished opinion - which is offered by one's bluntness. Thus it has much more to do with belief than fact, and the former, as a more subjective commodity, is always more likely to be tendentious.

Rabindranath Tagore's remark that "to be outspoken is easy when you do not wait to speak the complete truth" is an astute one, for it adds an important consideration: that you will succeed in properly serving both the truth and your fellow man only if you tell the whole truth, and that requires much more thought and preparation than mere plain speaking usually premises.

There is one arena where frankness is almost invariably a good thing: in the evolution of friendship. The point at which friends can drop their reserve and reveal themselves to each other is the point at which their relationship advances to a higher level. "One frankness invites a reciprocal frankness, and draws forth discoveries, like wine and love," wrote Montaigne. Such are franknesses of the heart, which give another access to one's self, and oneself access to another's self: and without such mutualities life would frankly be worth little.

fields.headline: How it works:   Anti-missile defence
fields.standfirst: An occasional series
fields.trailText: How it works
fields.body:
America's preoccupation with other countries' long-range weapons is behind the design of a new anti-missile system, which congress is likely to approve for deployment later this year. In principle, it is temptingly simple. Hostile missiles blast off, fly round the earth, then come down again on target. All you have to do is intercept them after they have gone up, but before they come down.

In practice, it will be incredibly difficult. Earlier efforts to develop particle beams came to nothing, so the current schemes call for ground-launched missiles to catch the missiles. They will have to be more accurate than missiles have ever been before. The Pentagon reckons this can be done. Incoming missiles are likely to be moving at upwards of five kilometres per second. But the interceptors need carry no warhead. They can be smaller, lighter and easier to manoeuvre.

They would detect the incomers using a complex combination of sensors, based on existing technology. Ground-based radar and satellites with heat sensors would show up enemy missile launches. They would give a good enough prediction of their path to launch interceptors in the right direction. Then heat and light sensors would be used to control small rockets on the final stage of the defending missile and send it into high-speed collision. The enemy weapon would be disintegrated high above the atmosphere.

So far, so reassuring. But also much too optimistic, critics argue. The reason is that there will not just be the warhead hurtling through space. If the hostile party knows there are interceptors, they will modify their own missiles. Mounting a defence against intercontinental ballistic missiles assumes an enemy capable of building them and loading them with nuclear bombs. So it seems reasonable to infer that whoever it is, they can deploy counter-measures which would be technically simpler than making an ICBM in the first place.

And since an anti-missile system really has to be 100% effective, the advantage lies with the attacker. Up above the atmosphere, heavy and light objects follow the same trajectories. So it would be easy to make decoys which cluster round the nuclear warhead and confound the interceptor. A nuclear warhead is heavy and warm, but it would not be too hard to disguise it, cool its outer surface, or even make all the decoys resemble a warhead. The putative nuclear attacker also has the option of building low-flying, sea-launched missiles, or even smuggling the odd warhead to its target overland.

Unlikely, perhaps, but then nuclear deterrence has always traded on pretty unlikely scenarios. The anti-missile defence programme assumes an American president rejecting nuclear blackmail from a newly armed opponent secure in the knowledge that US cities are under a defensive umbrella. A little thought suggests that he or she can never be sure that the umbrella will not be leaky, or that the enemy strike will not come in underneath it.

fields.headline: Ruff-ruff justice
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
Not unsurprisingly, Police Dog Academy (BBC1) was a little mongrel of a programme. It pandered to our basest TV instincts, crossing the cutesy elements of Animal Hospital (endearing puppies) with that staple of the post-docusoap documentary, the progress (or not) of a band of wannabes - in this case, police dog handlers.

With Sandi Toksvig narrating, this was never going to be anything other than warm and fuzzy. It was so upbeat, in fact, that it came over as a recruitment video for the Metropolitan Police. Maybe the government should have thought of that angle before making those Could You? advertisements. "Join us - you can cuddle dogs."

PC Peter liked cuddling dogs but Luke was an old Alsatian and would soon be retired (whether that meant retired in the Mafia sense, they didn't say). Hence PC Peter needed a new partner to help look for stolen videos in bushes. So it was up to PC Steve to produce a new police dog. Not himself, obviously, but with the help of Kerry, who was with puppies. Soon she was without puppies and they were scampering about and getting tested for scaredy cat-ness. We can expect many more weeks of man-dog bonding.

Much more fun than Police Dog Academy would have been a cross between Mersey Blues and When Pets Attack! With Leo in Brookside (Channel 4) hoping to join the boys in blue, we may not have to wait for that kind of carnage down Manor Park way. If he succeeds, he will soon have to arrest his dad since, whatever the crime on the close, Mick is in the frame. Mick has always got off but he is suffering now, what with Susannah's satin nightie pressing against him every night. Is he unfairly accused of crimes because he is black? No, it's because he is annoying and he deserves to suffer.

While Mick and Susannah were preparing to make sweet love (greasing the bedposts, preparing the guacamole), Sinbad was weeping at the state of his life. "What's wrong with me, Rach?" he asked Rachel, who should have been preparing an extensive list in her head. "Do I invite trouble or what?" Rachel discouraged such thoughts but Sinbad was unmoved. "I must do. Whenever anyone comes near me, it goes haywire." Or they get squashed.

The question of Jackie Corkhill's legs must also be raised. Whenever we see her these days, it is behind the counter in the garage or behind the Corkhills' breakfast bar. Have her legs been stolen by the porcelain dolly on the occasional table? Is she on wheels? We should be told.

Is Antoine de Caunes secretly in the pay of William Hague? Eurotrash (Channel 4), with its naked politicians and atrocious Europop, could be part of a plan to scare us off the single European currency and links to our continental cousins. If it is, it's working.

fields.headline: An A-Z of me
fields.standfirst: Charlotte Higgins  can't help loving Clive Rowe, an unlikely diva in a green anorak
fields.trailText: Charlotte Higgins can't help loving Clive Rowe, an unlikely diva in a green anorak
fields.body:
A diva, according to the Collins English Dictionary, is a highly distinguished female singer, or a prima donna. Clive Rowe, who performs as part of the Divas at the Donmar cabaret series at London's Donmar Warehouse, is neither. A classically- trained actor, Rowe, 36, caused a stir when, in 1992, he was cast as a black Enoch Snow in Nicholas Hytner's Carousel. Since then he has appeared in numerous hit "quality" musicals, such as Sam Mendes's Company at the Donmar (1995) and Richard Eyre's National Theatre production of Guys and Dolls (1996). His credentials as a showman are impeccable. But diva? The nearest that Rowe has ever got to false eyelashes and flashing rhinestones is starring as Widow Twankey at the Nottingham Playhouse.

When he appears on stage, all toothy, sheepish smile and wide, surprised eyes, his manner is self-effacing. His act, he says, will be an "A-Z of me". He puts a green anorak on over his T-shirt and takes us back to his first appearance in cabaret - as a kid back in 1978, in his local church hall. The song was Moon River, and he started it seven times before getting it right. Even now, that old anxiety seems to linger.

But the man has charm. You can't help loving him, particularly when he tells us that his early dramatic inspirations were more Bugsy Malone and Dracula Spectacular than Chekhov and Brecht. As we travel through his life in music, from listening to his mum's favourite LPs to his first sung audition, his voice warms up and his intonation improves. His spoken links are funny and well-delivered. It is a bit like Desert Island Discs, except Rowe gets to be himself, Sue Lawley and all the records. The only trouble with this narrative structure is that at the end of the first half, with 11 songs down, Rowe is still describing his life as a student at the Guildhall School of Music and Drama. The pace is looking a little slack.

Fortunately, the second half abandons straight autobiography and, after a quartet of introspec-tive love songs disconcertingly delivered with eyes shut, and a bit of hilarious audience participation in Lulu's Shout, he gives the ecstatic crowd what they've been waiting for: My Boy Bill from Carousel and, as an encore, Sit Down You're Rockin' the Boat from Guys and Dolls. Carry on like that and maybe he could end up a diva after all.

 Ends tonight. Box office: 020-7369 1732.

fields.headline: Watching clay dry
fields.standfirst: There's a marvellous art show at the Barbican. Such a pity about the dance that goes with it, says  Judith Mackrell
fields.trailText: There's a marvellous art show at the Barbican. Such a pity about the dance that goes with it, says Judith Mackrell
fields.body:
Time is one of those subjects that provoke artists to acts of profound hubris - or mayhem. Proust and Powell devoted their lives to constructing huge fictional maps of the psychology of time. John Cage invented a score of silence (4' 33") that aimed to freeze-frame empty seconds. And Andy Goldsworthy has created a monumental sculptural conceit called London Wall, a vast expanse of local clay packed against the curved gallery wall at the Barbican Centre.

The idea is that during the course of Goldsworthy's exhibition (itself entitled Time), viewers can watch the clay drying out and cracking into its own elegant crazy-paving design, but even on a single visit the wall is impressive. Its scale is exhilarating, and close up its unwilled composition of agapanthine shapes and mottled coloration is rather beautiful. But for anyone who is curious to see a rapid précis of this process - the deepening of cracks into fissures and the bleaching of the clay from mud brown to white, Goldsworthy's experiment can also be seen as part of a work currently showing in the Barbican theatre, Régine Chopinot's La Danse du Temps.

Chopinot and Goldsworthy are natural collaborators, since both are introspective artists with big ideas about nature, and both are distressingly capable of veering from imaginative grandeur into New Age preciousness. La Danse du Temps contains these extremes in frustratingly equal measure.

The work starts out with hypnotic promise, as 16 dancers from the Ballet Atlantique (aged from 20 to 70) cross the stage in a drift of movement so slow and fluid they seem less like people than a landscape eroded by wind or tide. We don't register a deliberate composition of rhythms or steps so much as movement eddying and looping through the dancers' bodies. And in the work's overall structure there is a similar sense of ideas passing like weather fronts. At times the dancers breast the stage like waves in flood, at times they seem whirled by a battening gale, at times they stand in space as quiet and concentrated as a night sky.

This organic approach to form is echoed in Ton-That Tiet's music, which evolves in washes of sound from chants to strings and percussion, as well as in Goldsworthy's backdrop, which is essentially a speeded-up film of a clay wall drying. What starts out as a plain expanse gradually fractures during the work's 70 minutes into a mosaic of crevices, revealing at its centre the pattern of a serpentine river course in darker clay.

At its best this work suggests that Chopinot has looked at the world profoundly. Her construction of shape and texture within the mass of the dancers' bodies sometimes possesses the mysterious draw of the natural world. Her nuances of pace and rhythm are subtle enough to make us feel time as a sensuous force. At its leaden worst, however, the choreography's slow pace and drifting structure do invite the inevitable crack about watching paint dry, as we sit and will Goldsworthy's wall to complete its cycle.

Basically, Chopinot's material would suit a work of only half its length, and between her moments of inspired meditation she resorts to wadding of earnest, feeble choreography, conceived in the dreariest, touchy-feely school of new European dance. La Danse du Temps is one of those events that would be transformed by a good editor.

As it is, sitting through its most repetitious longueurs the minutes feel like hours. Time becomes not a subject of contemplation, but an instrument of mild, well-intentioned torture.

 La Danse du Temps is at the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), tonight.

Its scale is exhilarating, and close up its unwilled composition of agapanthine shapes and mottled coloration is rather beautiful. But for anyone who is curious to see a rapid précis of this process - the deepening of cracks into fissures and the bleaching of the clay from mud brown to white, Goldsworthy's experiment can also be seen as part of a work currently showing in the Barbican theatre, Régine Chopinot's La Danse du Temps. Chopinot and Goldsworthy are natural collaborators, since both are introspective artists with big ideas about nature, and both are distressingly capable of veering from imaginative grandeur into New Age preciousness. La Danse du Temps contains these extremes in frustratingly equal measure. The work starts out with hypnotic promise, as 16 dancers from the Ballet Atlantique (aged from 20 to 70) cross the stage in a drift of movement so slow and fluid they seem less like people than a landscape eroded by wind or tide. We don't register a deliberate composition of rhythms or steps so much as movement eddying and looping through the dancers' bodies. And in the work's overall structure there is a similar sense of ideas passing like weather fronts. At times the dancers breast the stage like waves in flood, at times they seem whirled by a battening gale, at times they stand in space as quiet and concentrated as a night sky. This organic approach to form is echoed in Ton-That Tiet's music, which evolves in washes of sound from chants to strings and percussion, as well as in Goldsworthy's backdrop, which is essentially a speeded-up film of a clay wall drying. What starts out as a plain expanse gradually fractures during the work's 70 minutes into a mosaic of crevices, revealing at its centre the pattern of a serpentine river course in darker clay. At its best this work suggests that Chopinot has looked at the world profoundly. Her construction of shape and texture within the mass of the dancers' bodies sometimes possesses the mysterious draw of the natural world. Her nuances of pace and rhythm are subtle enough to make us feel time as a sensuous force. At its leaden worst, however, the choreography's slow pace and drifting structure do invite the inevitable crack about watching paint dry, as we sit and will Goldsworthy's wall to complete its cycle. Basically, Chopinot's material would suit a work of only half its length, and between her moments of inspired meditation she resorts to wadding of earnest, feeble choreography, conceived in the dreariest, touchy-feely school of new European dance. La Danse du Temps is one of those events that would be transformed by a good editor. As it is, sitting through its most repetitious longueurs the minutes feel like hours. Time becomes not a subject of contemplation, but an instrument of mild, well-intentioned torture.  La Danse du Temps is at the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), tonight.

fields.headline: Hatful of hollow
fields.standfirst: Ringo's son was on drums, the Gallaghers were in the crowd - but there was something missing at the front of the stage.  Paul Lester  on the Healers, Johnny Marr's new band
fields.trailText: Ringo's son was on drums, the Gallaghers were in the crowd - but there was something missing at the front of the stage. Paul Lester on the Healers, Johnny Marr's new band
fields.body:
Thirteen years after the Smiths broke up, Johnny Marr still fascinates: the 500-capacity Scala in London is crammed with punters, not to mention celebrities. Noel Gallagher is here (I thought Meg was the one who kept wanting to go out?), as is his brother Liam - together with current main squeeze Nicole Appleton. Bernard Butler of Suede you'd expect to see, but even legendary 1970s scene-maker Rodney Bingenheimer has come to check out the Healers, Marr's first band proper in more than a decade.

Against the sort of budget psychedelic backdrop usually seen in end-of-term school plays, the six musicians assume their positions. Despite counting in their ranks a son of a Beatle (Zak Starkey on drums) and a former member of retro-rockers Kula Shaker (Alonza Bevan on bass), it is Marr in the role of group leader that people have come to see.

He looks cool enough, despite being one month away from his 37th birthday, even if you suspect he probably made a better moody sidekick than a charismatic frontman. As to whether or not he can sing, you'd hardly know, because whatever comes out of his mouth is immediately swallowed up by the music (that the PA is so loud it's distorting doesn't help). The promotional CD doing the rounds, featuring a track called Last Ride, reveals a functional rock voice with, oddly enough, a tone reminiscent of Status Quo's Francis Rossi.

The first two numbers, Bangin' On and the aforementioned Last Ride, are impressive. In fact, if the Oasis songwriter wasn't such a close friend of his, you could almost imagine Marr thinking "Suck on this, Noel" as he unleashes wave after wave of pulverising sound. Because this sort of heavy psychedelic blues-metal (à la Led Zeppelin or the second Stone Roses album) is roughly what Standing on the Shoulder of Giants might have sounded like had Gallagher and Co managed to sustain the impact of that album's opening instrumental, Fuckin' in the Bushes. A contradiction in terms, perhaps, but this is stoner rock with energy.

Unfortunately, the rest of the gig presents mostly variations on that theme. Here It Comes and Caught Up are as pedestrian as their titles. During Down on the Corner, the Healers appear to be doing little more than jamming - filling up the periods when Marr is away from the mike with indelicate musical passages. Even fans of instrumental proficiency would decry the lack of finesse, the pointless reiteration, the bongo solos.

In a recent interview, Marr declared his intention that the Healers should be some holy union of T Rex, the Stooges, Santana and the Wailers, which is to suggest all manner of rhythmical delights and sonic tricks. He even intimated that keyboardist Lee Spencer (former collaborator of William Orbit) would bring a sense of electronic mischief to bear on the Healers' sound.

He doesn't - at least not tonight. Indeed, there is little acknowledgement of musical developments of the past 10 or 20 years. Ironically, Marr arguably did his best work since the Smiths with Electronic, his dance-pop venture with Bernard Sumner of New Order. No doubt he sees all his session-playing with the Pretenders, Roxy Music, The The and Kirsty MacColl as leading up to this. We always knew he had it in him: the desire to rock out, the musical equivalent of dumbing down.

Only the looped drum beat underpinning Voodoo in You changes the pace. The glam-metal stomp of Iggy and the Stooges' I Need Somebody provides a pleasant enough blow to the skull, but that song was so bound up in Iggy's mythos that tonight it is stripped of its meaning. Marr is no Iggy, no Dylan, no Lou Reed, no Neil Young. He will never transcend his era or face the fierce white light/white heat of critical significance again. He's just jamming.
