fields.headline: Relax? Don't do it.
fields.standfirst: The word 'pampering' means: 'Have a wash and stop being such a neurotic cow.' It is sex for the sex-less and rest for the rest-less
fields.trailText: The word 'pampering' means: 'Have a wash and stop being such a neurotic cow.' It is sex for the sex-less and rest for the rest-less
fields.body:
How well I remember the 70s - that rehearsal for Armageddon with a soundtrack by Sailor. The three-day week, the power cuts and my little family sitting around in the candlelight all through the winter of discontent; me gloating, because I couldn't do my homework, my father self-righteous about supporting his fellow trades unionists, and my mum bringing the party down with the occasional cry of, "I don't care about no revolution, Bill. It's dead depressing, sitting 'ere in the bleedin' dark!"

In those days, candles were something you kept in the cupboard under the sink in case of emergencies. And, just as my dear late mum would have goggled at you in disbelief if you'd told her then that she'd go on to spend a good part of her old age struggling to and from the Co-Op on treacherous black ice carrying bottles of bloody water for her jumped-up daughter, she would have been similarly unbelieving that, one day, women would voluntarily spend £20 of their hard-earned money on one poxing scented candle that they would then proceed to burn regardless of the availability of electricity, rather than begrudge parting with 99p for a box of six plain white.

If there was a power cut tonight, in fact, half the professional young childless households in the nation's urban centres probably wouldn't notice, because a lot of them will be listening to their personal mini-disc players by the light of a dozen flickering wicks. It's a strange idea, and not a little sad - all those twenty- and thirtysomething girls slipping out of aromatherapy baths called things like Sensual and Pamper only to sit about in the dappled dark like spare pricks at a seance, while lonely men download cyberporn in their own soft cells.

I'll tell you who's really happy about it, though: the UnShopkeepers. This country, I am sure, will in the future be condemned by some snooty Frenchmen as being a nation of UnShopkeepers. Yes, the butcher and the baker may both be facing rising rates and a future in some godforsaken call centre as their particular skills get priced out by the big boys, but the candlestickmaker is fast becoming king of the heap, central as his goods are to the UnShop.

You know an UnShop when you see it. Just like vampires are the undead, an UnShop gives every impression of being just like any other until you get up close. Then, rather than a pair of fangs and no reflection, you see the tell-tale signs: a mass of candles of every hue and pong, numerous candleholders, strange-shaped, apparently useless little pots that are, in fact, holders for small candles, which, in turn, heat aromatherapy oils and, most vital of all, arrangements of small, coloured pebbles in transparent plastic cubes half-filled with water and which cost the best part of a tenner. Most of these gadgets are made in the developing world, and you can't help but imagine the look on the workers' faces - perplexed, contemptuous, but surely never envious - as they earn their meagre wages making these monumentally useless distractions for adults who have more money than sense. I'm not pointing the finger here. Just the other day, I found myself in a shop called Inspirations, trying to decide between a plastic triangle filled with small, coloured beads and a plastic rectangle filled with small, coloured beads (I couldn't decide, so I bought both).

What the growth of the UnShop feeds off, of course, is the modern mania for relaxation. In the past, relaxation came naturally: a man or woman went to work, did their daily drudgery, peeled off their pantyhose and then got well and truly slaughtered. But barely anyone uses the gorgeous phrase "a little R&R" any more, carrying as it does connotations of slobbing out, drinking up and getting down. It just sounds too dirty . The new buzzwords are "chilling out", "de-stressing" and, worst of all, the repellent "pampering".

For all you trainspotters who like counting how many times I've cracked my Guy Ritchie joke (you know, the one about how he got his scar by falling off his pony and landing on his silver spoon), I'm sure you'll recognise my definitive take on the use of the word "pampering" in modern retail, too. It means: "Have a wash and stop being such a neurotic cow." Pampering is sex for the sex-less and rest for the rest-less. I bet you could prove with pie charts that the more scented candles a woman buys, the less orgasms/job security she has. Because what all the paraphernalia of the relaxation culture seeks to mimic, of course, is the feeling of security - a feeling that is pretty hard to come by in this non-contract, downsizing world, except in that crucial 10 minutes after really good sex.

You have to hand it to capitalism, it's devilishly clever. If, as Lenin said, they could sell us the rope to hang them with, they've also sold us the drugs to tranquillise ourselves with while they proceed to screw more work with less security out of us. Look at aromatherapy: while pretending to be "on the side" of the consumer, it is actually all about medicating the consumer into a state of accepting passivity. If, as homeopaths claim, we should "listen to our bodies", shouldn't we also take positive action to change our situations when we feel anxiety, fear or anger? Yet aromatherapy tells us merely to sniff at something until those feelings go away!

Tragically, even good causes have harnessed this new culture of passivity. WellBeing, which carries out research on health issues affecting women and children, has just launched, with Dove soap, a Dare To Indulge campaign, which, as no less a mezzobrow icon as Lorraine Kelly puts it, is all about "encouraging women to take a little bit of time out for themselves, all for a good cause. Why not get your husband, friends or family to sponsor you in the indulgence of your choice... anything from having an aromatherapy massage to half-an-hour in a bubble bath... whatever makes you unwind, relax and de-stress".

Surely, in the face of endless under-investment by government into research that might stop thousands of people dying needlessly each year, shouldn't we be demanding that they do something useful with our taxes, rather than throwing millions at the Dome? Instead, we're advised to jump in the bath and not come out until our poor, ground-down husbands and friends part with even more money. Cleanliness is not only next to Godliness these days, but also to goodness in all its forms. I can't help thinking that we'll wake up soon, with all the water cold, the bubbles flat and the scum, as ever, rising to the top. Because, so long as we believe that satisfaction can come from personal cleanliness rather than political change, we'll always be whistling in the dark - no matter how many candles we light.

fields.headline: The problems of success
fields.standfirst: We don't have to live at such a frantic pace. There's nothing to stop us sitting in a rocking chair browsing the 160 channels on digital television
fields.trailText: We don't have to live at such a frantic pace. There's nothing to stop us sitting in a rocking chair browsing the 160 channels on digital television
fields.body:
Whatever else we may think about ourselves, we are all convinced of one thing - that we are the most stressed-out generation in the history of mankind. It is odd that we should think this. In Britain, at least, we have never been more prosperous, never more comfortable and never better served by technology. Tasks that were once arduous or irksome to perform are now carried out swiftly and efficiently by machines. In every walk of life, things are easier than they used to be.

Take journalism, for example. Research that used to require hours of telephoning and time-consuming visits to libraries can now be conducted far more quickly and effectively over the internet, and without the frustration involved in having to deal in person with annoying or obstructive people. In the old days, I would have had to dictate this article over the telephone to a copytaker. This was an exhausting experience and often a demoralising one, for there were copytakers who specialised in deflating one's ego with remarks such as, "Was that supposed to be a joke?" Now I will just send it by email to Weekend without fallible human intervention, and with luck it will get there in immaculate condition in only a few seconds.

So why do we believe ourselves to be under such extraordinary stress? Most people would say it is because of the acceleration of life. In the past, we could take our time about things. Now, we are always in a rush. That is the theory, but I am not sure that it holds water. Just because things can be and are done much more quickly than in the past doesn't mean that we all have to live our lives at a frantic pace. There is nothing to stop us sitting in a rocking chair browsing through the 160 channels on digital television, stirring ourselves only to order food for home delivery over the internet from one of the supermarket chains. New technology actually helps us to be lazy slobs, if we so desire.

It is true that computers have not made us calmer. We have come to expect miracles from them, and we feel just as frustrated when they are being slow or unresponsive as a peasant does with a recalcitrant mule. But now the stressful early days when we were getting to know each other are behind us, I find that, on balance, my computer contributes very positively to my general contentment and peace of mind.

If, as is possible, we really are under greater stress than previous generations, I do not blame this on computers or any other forms of new technology, but on the presence of too much choice and too much marketing in the modern world. We have never before been subjected to so much competitive advertising and promotion on so many different media. We are being presented with vastly more options regarding things to buy or do than we can either afford or find time for, and this can cause us great anxiety. Most human beings are both greedy and competitive, and wish to enjoy all of the best that life has to offer - or, at any rate, as much of it as their neighbours enjoy.

But they can't change their cars or their computers or their televisions every day; they can't take dozens of foreign holidays each year; they can't devote themselves to physical fitness while cooking and eating as the TV food pundits would like them to; they can't embrace every religion and every form of medicine in the world at the same time; they can't follow every sport, every form of culture, and every kind of activity that is urged upon them. But many of them would dearly like to, which drives them mad, since their lives are too short and there are not enough hours in the day.

One should not have too much sympathy with people in this condition. They are suffering from what Sir Edward Heath once famously called, during a bad patch in his premiership, "the problems of success". Earlier generations, and still many people in Britain today, suffer from far worse problems than that. In Piers Brendon's excellent new book about the 30s, The Dark Valley, you can read that in 1923 an average of five coal miners were killed in Britain every working day, and 32 were injured every hour. Between 1922 and 1924 (inclusive), 3,603 miners were killed and 597,198 were injured - a far higher casualty rate than in 30 years of the troubles in Northern Ireland. It is true that even the abused coal miners drew some comfort from their lack of alternative ways of earning a living, mainly in a sense of community and solidarity with their fellow sufferers. But what wouldn't they have given to swap their hardship for a little bit of 21st-century stress?

But what wouldn't they have given to swap their hardship for a little bit of 21st-century stress?

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: This warm stranger
fields.standfirst: 'Fred nuzzles in close. His arms are around my waist, his nose in my neck'
fields.trailText: 'Fred nuzzles in close. His arms are around my waist, his nose in my neck'
fields.body:
Panicale is an Umbrian hill town, though in my head it is pronounced by Eddie Waring, the much-missed rugby league commentator. Wonder if Eddie ever brought his wide vowels to Italy. Would enjoy Renaissance tour conducted by Geoffrey Boycott and David Lloyd. "Fra Angelico, he's got nice soft hands, but when it cooms to t' chiaroscuro, Leonardo beats 'im 'ands down, wouldn't yer say, David?"

"Aye, Geoffrey, t' sfumato technique, 'e's got that technique, it tewk 'ours o' practice, but now 'e can paint t'sunset so it lewks just like a bruise."

"Aye, David, I 'ad a bruise like that once, courtesy of Michael Holding."

Restless cricket commentary in head - rather like television play by Jack Rosenthal - betrays my agitation. I am approaching Panicale with handsome middle-aged bisexual Fred, in whose country house I am staying with our associated teenagers. The young folk have been set down miles away on the shores of Lake Trasimeno to smoke, sulk, and perhaps even swim. Suddenly I am alone with Fred.

No need to rush. Can't rush anyway. Too hot. Rugby League impossible - even walking needs to be gentle. Panicale sits proudly on a hilltop, its severe brown city walls drawn up around it like skirts. No suburbs, just a plunge of olives down to the plain. Fred parks under a tree, and I get out into a wave of heat and the sound of late-afternoon cicadas. As we stroll up the gentle incline into the town, Fred takes my arm. Not sure how to interpret this, as everyone else is arm-in-arm - men, women, children. Even Geoffrey Boycott and David Lloyd are arm-in-arm in my head. Strolling. Why do we never stroll in England?

"So, what do you think of it?" asks Fred, as we reach a small square in which small children are playing round a fountain. "On certain days, the fountains run with wine."

I turn to him and see, for an instant, Michelangelo's David's dad. Is he looking deep into my eyes because he likes it, or is it because he's a gay sadist? ("Ah think she might tek spin a bit later, David, ah think t' surface is brekkin oop.")

Echoes of children's voices wash around the brown walls. It is like being inside a gigantic biscuit. Confess I am enchanted. He looks as if he's wondering whether it's Panicale or him. Wonder if he's as uncertain as I am. Heart is beating rather faster than is advisable in middle-aged woman on hot Italian hillside.

Ascend with great slowness into deserted higher square, in which sudden atmosphere of ghosts standing three-deep all around us is so palpable, I shiver.

"Are you cold?" Fred puts his arm around me. Admit I can sense spectral presences. We look up and see For Sale signs beside blind and shuttered windows.

"Maybe you should buy a haunted flat here," smiles Fred. "I'd love you as a neighbour." ("Now, he's flighted that delivery, has Fred," remarks Geoffrey. "He's beat 'er all ends up, she's all over the place.")

He'd love me as a neighbour? What sort of chat-up line is that? "Your eyes... are so neighbourly! Oh God! I'm dying to borrow a cup of sugar and make beautiful noise all night!"

At the top of the town is another square, with a castle, and a warm wall against which we lean to look out at Umbria. Blue hills and a purple plain, across which lights are beginning to twinkle. Fred nuzzles in close. His arms are round my waist, his nose in my neck. Tendrils of my hair wave in his cinnamon-scented breath. I AM BEING EMBRACED. Unambiguously.

"What would you be doing if you were at home?" he whispers.

"A thousand stupid things."

"Well, let's do nothing for the next few hours."

Have to conclude that he is cuddling me because I remind him of his mother. Never mind. That'll do.

Eventually we eat truffles, and fish from the lake, and then spend a long time on the ramparts, kissing like teenagers. I have stopped worrying about our teenagers. For the first time in years, I am not worrying about anybody. The cricketers in my head fall silent at last, and there is only this warm stranger. The plain below is dark and vast like a sea, and I can only suppose we are ships that pass in the night.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall
fields.trailText: Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall
fields.body:
Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall, 36, grew up in London and Gloucestershire. He studied psychology and philosophy at St Peter's College, Oxford, and wrote a food column for the university magazine. He worked briefly at London's River Cafe, then became a journalist and TV presenter. He is best known for his series, A Cook On the Wildside.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Catching a fish on my own and then cooking it for friends.

What is your greatest fear?
Going mad.

Which living person do you most admire?
Pete Townshend, because he wrote the songs on Who's Next while drinking two bottles of brandy a day.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
Losing my temper with inanimate objects.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Lack of passion.

What vehicles do you own?
A push-bike with barbecue attachment.

What is your favourite smell?
The seashore, when I haven't been there for months.

What is your favourite book?
Sentimentally, Shore Fishing, by Trevor Houseby. Intellectually, Moby Dick.

What objects do you always carry with you?
A small, black Swiss army penknife, with corkscrew.

What makes you depressed?
February.

How did you vote in the last election?
Labour.

How will you vote in the next election?
Probably Labour, but with considerably less enthusiasm at this rate.

Do you believe in capital punishment?
Absolutely not.

Do you believe in monogamy?
It's desirable, but very difficult.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
Not for a while.

What is your greatest regret?
Persistently refusing the offer of music lessons when I was a child.

What would your motto be?
There's plenty more fish in the sea.

How would you like to die?
Being pulled into the river Findhorn by a monster salmon.

How would you like to be remembered?
As a great lover, writer, fisherman, host and cook - but I'd settle for the last two.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Not to take it too seriously.

fields.headline: How to retire
fields.trailText: Taking retirement used to be the last thing you did before you died. Now, it's the first thing you do when you want to get a life.
fields.body:
Taking retirement used to be the last thing you did before you died. Now, it's the first thing you do when you want to get a life.

Taking early retirement gives you time finally to do all the really big things that you never had time to do before - such as the crossword. Sadly, doing a crossword and having a mug of hot chocolate in retirement never feels quite as satisfying as they did when you were working, because you know that there's nothing to stop you doing crosswords and drinking hot chocolate all day. Perhaps this is why so many retired people start cutting up newspapers.

For retired people without a specific hobby, this is the biggest home industry - snipping 'interesting' bits from the papers and sending them to people who may have missed them. People who have been retired for more than a year can find that, at the end of a working day, they will have made cuttings from 95% of the newspaper and despatched them all over the world.

With nothing to do, it is possible to get tired of retirement quite quickly. For some people, this happens on the first Monday after their last Friday at work, so they take up a hobby, such as wood whittling, to pass the time. Three years later, they find that they're the largest exporter of lumber products in the European Union.

One clear symptom of early retirement is when women feel the need to wear tracksuits. They do this because they're comfortable, and in them you can move effortlessly from garden to gym to hairdresser. They're also under the mistaken impression that this is what young people wear. Men who have spent their lives in suits suddenly have to choose casual clothing. Once they see how naff they look in patterned trousers and pastel V-necks, many are forced to take up golf.

Even when you retire early, there is a creeping realisation that the next major life event for you will be death. This may explain why people suddenly feel the need to research their family trees. This is not necessarily a good idea, as obsessively neat people can sometimes die early from the compulsion to fill themselves in on the bottom rung.

There is often a nasty and unexpected surprise in early retirement. Just when you thought it was safe to do exactly what you want, you get grandchildren. Naturally, your children assume that, because you've retired, there's nothing you'd rather do than change nappies again. This is often when retirees decide that what they really want to do is to sell their home and live on a yacht.

fields.headline: The colour of calm
fields.standfirst: Make your home a comfort zone with carefully chosen colours. The peace you dream of need only be a lick of paint away, finds Charlotte Abrahams
fields.trailText: Make your home a comfort zone with carefully chosen colours. The peace you dream of need only be a lick of paint away, finds Charlotte Abrahams.
fields.body:
You've seen them in the magazines, those homes - sorry living spaces - that exude a Zen-like calm. You've imagined what it must be like to wake in a bed of pure white linen with wafts of translucent silk moving at the window in the morning breeze. You've imagined what it must be like returning from a stressful day at the office to a room so peaceful you can forego the stiff gin and simply sit and breathe. You've imagined all this, but it is so far from the reality of your home - cluttered with the accessories, noise and bustle of modern life - that you have dismissed it as you would a dream.

Not so fast. Okay, you have to use your home as an office, a kid's play centre, a storage depot and a motel, so a collection of sculpted aromatherapy candles in the centre of the sitting room is an impractical idea, but peace and harmony can still be yours. Honest.

How to achieve this blissful state? It depends who you talk to, but the consensus among the house doctors is that it all comes down to colour and storage systems. You could have guessed storage would come up - sensible, unarguably good for us but dull, dull, dull, the world of interiors' equivalent of fibre and regular exercise. But colour, now that's exciting.

We all associate colour with mood - red is the colour of sexuality and excitement, while blue is cool and reflective - but there are many who take this further, who claim that colour has the power to improve (and presumably damage) our sense of well-being.

Colour therapy is not new. The ancient Egyptians had coloured rooms in their temples for treating and healing, but it is now re-emerging as a popular alternative practice and there are people, such as interior designer Catherine Cumming, who are starting to apply the principles of colour therapy to interior decoration.

In her book, The Colour Healing Home (published next month by Mitchell Beazley, priced £16.99), Cumming argues that it is possible to lift the "energy" around us and enhance our spirits simply through a bit of well-considered decoration. "Colour therapists," she says, "heal people by shining a coloured light on to them. Coloured pigment is less powerful, but once you start opening to it, the effect is astounding."

Such therapy works on the premise that each colour has its own energy and that we absorb this through our light-sensitive cells. The aim is to create a balance and a free-flow of this energy. Obviously, no two people respond to colour in the same way, so this is a highly subjective practice, but there are some general rules. The most calming colours are the cool ones - blues, greens and violets - so the theory is that if we are aiming for peace and tranquillity we should eschew those fabulous hot red walls (far too energising for a stressed-out soul) and stick to the more gentle side of the spectrum.

"Violet," explains Cumming, "is a tranquil colour that promotes inspiration and contemplation. Green is a balancing colour, neither hot nor cold, and is particularly effective in the city, where there are few green fields, but blue is the most calming of all. Being in a blue environment makes you breathe out and really slows you down. It is a perfect colour for bedrooms and promotes good, cosy dreams."

So if we want to create that Zen-like haven, should we paint our house in blocks of blue, green and violet? No. "Too much of a single colour," explains Cumming, "can in fact have a negative effect. Too much deep blue, for example, can slow us down so much that it makes us melancholy [so that's where the term 'the blues' comes from], so all colours must be balanced by their complementary colour." This means that a violet room must contain some intellectually stimulating yellow, while a blue room needs a splash (just a splash mind, too much will lead to confusion rather than calm) of orange, the colour of joy and physical activity.

Of course, for some people, the suggestion that a blue sitting room, nicely balanced by the odd orange scatter cushion, can make you feel more relaxed is just a lot of alternative mumbo-jumbo. Forget energy flows, they say, a room feels good because it looks good, whether it's painted a peaceful lilac, a stark, clinical white, or a deep red with lots of geometric patterns (another no-no, according to the colour therapists, who believe that patterns should be gentle and related to nature if they are going to aid relaxation).

Tricia Guild, founder of the interiors company Designers Guild, is a great believer in the power of pigment, but she is no colour therapist. Her approach is more personal. As she writes in the introduction to her book White Hot: Cool Colours For Modern Living (published by Quadrille, priced £25), "my response to colour has always been intensely personal and emotional. Colour theory and scientific explanations are not my ways of searching - I prefer intuitive responses."

So, although she agrees with Cumming that a retreat-like home should be primarily decorated in colours from the cool end of the spectrum (she is particularly fond of aquamarine, a shade that she says "radiates the peaceful, calming qualities of a still sea"), she still has room for punches of hot shades such as red and magenta.

The secret of making these bold colours work as part of a calming colour scheme, argues Guild, is white, "the classic colour of simplicity", which not only functions as a cool colour in its own right but also, she says, "gives other colours room to breathe, to stop competing, to be themselves".

And that's exactly what those of us who daydream over those magazine images of peaceful havens are looking for - a living environment that allows us the space to be ourselves. We may or may not believe that painting the room in shades of aqua and white will achieve this, but we have to decorate our homes in some way, and surely common sense tells us that a subtle, cool palette will be more conducive to relaxation than a riot of clashing, bright colours. We may or may not believe that painting a wall lilac will improve our self-esteem, but it's hard to argue with the idea that it's easier to think straight in a harmoniously decorated home free from clutter.

No doubt there will be some readers who remain unconvinced, who say they can relax perfectly well amid the piles of books, media equipment and collectibles that fill their brilliant-red sitting rooms - but a change of colour has got to be worth a try for those of us who need help unwinding at the end of the day. At any rate, I find painting quite therapeutic.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Slowly does it
fields.trailText: Slowly does it
fields.body:
The subject
Kitchen go-slow.

The basics
Cooking doesn't have to be fast, functional and frenzied. If you do the Knowledge's chill-out decathlon, you'll be a happier person.

The details
1 Get into slow roasting - maximum temperature 150C/300F/gas mark 2. Generous margin of error, less chance of overcooking.

2 Do the same with braising, the user-friendliest cooking method. Temps as above, for veg as well as meat.

3 Make stock, damnit! It's as easy as falling off a log, and 1,000 times more rewarding. Collect butcher's scraps and freeze until you reach stock-critical mass. Cooking at its gentlest and simplest.

4 Bake bread. Turning flour, yeast and water into a silken ball, watching the ball swell, shaping and baking cookery's greatest miracle. Immensely soothing. Absurdly satisfying. And 95% of the time, you're waiting, not working.

5 An extension of four: make pizza from your own dough. A tenth the price, easy-peasy.

6 Grow herbs. All you need is a sunny spot, a few seeds and some dirt. Saves money and makes you feel gooooood.

7 Beat Covent Garden at their own game and make soup! Veggies, stock, flavourings. Simmer till soft. Peace. Slaver.

8 Make ragout, the noble creation that launched 100 million servings of unspeakable spag bol. The real thing takes ages of simmering and freezes dreamily. Marcella Hazan's The Essentials Of Classic Italian Cooking has a killer recipe.

9 Beans, beans, the musical fruit. Simmered at great length with bacon, herbs, and tons of garlic - no better way to feed yourself for a week.

10 Make Thai curry pastes in a mortar and pestle - 30-60 minutes' pounding creates a texture that's far better than a food processor - and you'll have done all yourself.

Where to buy
You can't buy happiness.

The easy way out
Hire a cook.
fields.bodyText: The subject Kitchen go-slow. The basics Cooking doesn't have to be fast, functional and frenzied. If you do the Knowledge's chill-out decathlon, you'll be a happier person. The details 1 Get into slow roasting - maximum temperature 150C/300F/gas mark 2. Generous margin of error, less chance of overcooking. 2 Do the same with braising, the user-friendliest cooking method. Temps as above, for veg as well as meat. 3 Make stock, damnit! It's as easy as falling off a log, and 1,000 times more rewarding. Collect butcher's scraps and freeze until you reach stock-critical mass. Cooking at its gentlest and simplest. 4 Bake bread. Turning flour, yeast and water into a silken ball, watching the ball swell, shaping and baking cookery's greatest miracle. Immensely soothing. Absurdly satisfying. And 95% of the time, you're waiting, not working. 5 An extension of four: make pizza from your own dough. A tenth the price, easy-peasy. 6 Grow herbs. All you need is a sunny spot, a few seeds and some dirt. Saves money and makes you feel gooooood. 7 Beat Covent Garden at their own game and make soup! Veggies, stock, flavourings. Simmer till soft. Peace. Slaver. 8 Make ragout, the noble creation that launched 100 million servings of unspeakable spag bol. The real thing takes ages of simmering and freezes dreamily. Marcella Hazan's The Essentials Of Classic Italian Cooking has a killer recipe. 9 Beans, beans, the musical fruit. Simmered at great length with bacon, herbs, and tons of garlic - no better way to feed yourself for a week. 10 Make Thai curry pastes in a mortar and pestle - 30-60 minutes' pounding creates a texture that's far better than a food processor - and you'll have done all yourself. Where to buy You can't buy happiness. The easy way out Hire a cook.

fields.headline: Easy as pie
fields.standfirst: You don't need to spend hours over a hot stove to create a blissfully relaxing meal. You needn't spend a fortune, either, says Jeremy Lee
fields.trailText: You don't need to spend hours over a hot stove to create a blissfully relaxing meal. You needn't spend a fortune, either, says Jeremy Lee.
fields.body:
Get cooking!" Fern Britten's war cry sends the contestants on the popular TV show Ready Steady Cook into a flurry of activity, rush and bother. Quick cooking. Fast food. Dishes in 30 minutes, 15 minutes, five minutes. I want it now. NOW!

Well, really. It's enough to make you reach for the nearest chilled dinner from the freezer chest. This obsession with speed, with instant food, small wonder that fewer people can be bothered to get into the kitchen with any regularity these days. "Oh, I don't have time," they wail. Nonsense. You always have time for things you want to do. Instead of looking on cooking and shopping as a chore, you should treat them as therapy.

Cooking is a refuge from the stress, press and mess of the world out there. You have no idea how soothing chopping an onion can be until you try it. Okay, there's some thought involved, and a bit of time, but so there is in learning to dance the tango, mowing the lawn or voting to expel someone from Big Brother. So it's time we learned to slow down, chill out and hang loose in the kitchen.

There's no need to treat shopping as an ordeal, either. I don't mind admitting that I'm not too happy in supermarkets. In fact, I hardly ever go in them, but The Guv'nor said that it was time I did, and that I couldn't spend more than £30 on a dinner for six people - £5 a head! "Make it cheap and make it easy," he said. "I don't want to see anything that's going to give someone a nervous breakdown or keep them in the kitchen for a fortnight."

So forth I went. God knows, supermarkets are unfun places to find the inspiration you need from good ingredients, but if you look on shopping in them as a kind of treasure hunt, it takes on a different hue. The Guv'nor had mentioned ceviche, so it seemed a suitable idea to whizz past the bags of salad and attend the fish counter. The mackerel looked really good, all electric blue, delicious, nutritious, cheap and perfect for ceviche. Ceviche is the totally stress-free method of preparing fish. You dunk fish chunks in lemon or lime juice, which, like, cooks it. It's a doddle, and it makes a great little starter.

Next, the meat counter. Hmm. Respectable looking meat, and not under wraps, either. But I was on a budget. Then I saw a packet of organic mince. Not too fatty, and a nice red colour. Great for polpettone, that monument to slow cooking, a sublime meatloaf stuffed with cheese and delicately seasoned. But not everyone eats meat, so I needed some tomatoes for a lasagne. I turned back to the fruit-and-veg area, where I spied tomatoes of a so-so red, not that bad, but not that good. So, no tomatoes. Tinned would have to do.

There were some nice-looking little waxy potatoes, however. Boiled, dressed in a little olive oil, a soft boiled egg, perhaps, some spring onions and chives to go with the polpettone? Some things are sacred, such as good eggs, so I sought out the organic ones.

That left pudding, and I solved that with some nice seasonal plums, which would cook beautifully into an almondy paste in a tart. Then I spied some avocados to partner the ceviche. Some even had the odd black spot. Great! I gathered a few more bits, went to the flowers, then up to the wine before calling it quits.

Needless to say, the bill flew over the £30, but the food for the meal came in at not too far over, and, really, there's nothing to this supermarket shopping lark. Not much to the cooking of it, either. Lots can be done well ahead, so there's no last-minute bother. And when your guests ring that doorbell, there's not a bead of sweat on the brow, no nervous flutter in the tum, and no hint of rush or bother to be seen. Just you at peace with your kitchen, your food and yourself. That's proper cooking.

All recipes serve six.

Ceviche

With the fishing of salmon in an unholy state and the state of cod swiftly following suit, the prominence of mackerel will soon surface in a similar fashion to monkfish, which was once deemed fit only for pets. Quite right, too. The ceviche can be made several hours in advance.

6 small spanking fresh mackerel, or three larger ones, filleted
1 red chilli
Juice of 3 lemons
Juice of 3 limes
2 small red onions
1 small handful coriander, picked
3 very ripe avocados, if available

A kindly fishmonger will fillet and remove the bones from the fish for you. Ceviche is normally sliced thinly, but I prefer to cut the fillets into three pieces only, especially if they are only small.

Lay the prepared fish in a pretty earthenware dish, and pour over the lime juice. Peel and very finely chop the red onion and scatter this over the fish . Split the chilli lengthways, remove half its seeds (unless you like it devilishly hot, in which case leave them all in), and chop into a small dice, taking care not to touch your eyes (or any other sensitive body areas) with your 'chillied' hands. Add the chilli to the fish dish. Chop the coriander finely, and add to the dish. Liberally season the whole lot with sea salt, and mix together thoroughly. Cover the dish and refrigerate for a couple of hours.

When ready to serve, halve and peel the avocados, cut the flesh into thick wedges and place on a plate. Pile the ceviche on top. Garnish with a few slices of chilli and/or red onion, as well as a few leaves of coriander.

Polpettone

Ma used to make this from Elizabeth David's splendid Italian Food. The only change I've made to her recipe is to omit hard-boiled egg in the stuffing - instead, I'd serve the meatloaf with one soft-boiled egg per person on top of a warm potato salad with mayonnaise, chives and spring onions.

900g good minced beef
4 very fresh free-range eggs
3 cloves garlic
1 medium-sized onion
1 small handful flat-leaf parsley, picked
Sea salt
Freshly-milled black pepper
90g good ham, in two thick slices
90g Provolone
Sea salt
Freshly-milled black pepper

Peel and finely chop the onion and garlic. Wash, dry and finely chop the parsley. Put the minced beef in a large bowl, tip in the garlic, onion, parsley, salt and pepper, then the eggs. Mix well and put half the mixture into a suitable crock or loaf tin. Cut the ham and cheese into small pieces, and mix with salt and pepper. Lay in the middle of the layer of beef, and cover with the remaining beef mix. Push the mixture down with the heel of your hand, though with not too much force, and seal the crock with tin foil and a lid. Place the crock in a roasting tray, half-fill the tray with cold water, put it into a preheated, slow oven (150C/300F/gas mark 2) and cook for one-and-a-half hours. This is delicious hot, warm or cold, so the polpettone can be cooked at any time during the day, whenever suits you best.

Apart from the potato-and-egg salad already mentioned, a green salad and a dish of thinly-sliced tomatoes dressed with olive oil, sea salt and pepper make happy eating with polpettone.

Tomato and spinach lasagne

Buy only the very best lasagne verde for this dish (or, of course, make your own).

24 fully-ripe, top-quality tomatoes, or a 250g tin
4 cloves garlic, peeled and sliced thinly
Olive oil
1.5kg washed and picked leaf spinach
4 onions
Unsalted butter
Nutmeg
300g lasagne verde (preferably fresh, but dry if necessary)
Fresh Parmesan

For the béchamel

700ml milk
90g unsalted butter
75g plain flour
1 small sprig thyme
12 black peppercorns
1 bayleaf

Preheat the oven to 160C/325F/gas mark 3. Remove the eye from the tomatoes, and cut them in half. Place the halves, cut-side up, on a roasting tray and put a thin slice of garlic on each. Liberally season with sea salt and milled black pepper. Anoint with some olive oil and transfer to the oven to cook for one-and-a-half to two hours. Remove the tomatoes from the oven, and turn up the temperature to 200C/400F/gas mark 6. Set the tomatoes to one side.

Put a big pan of water on to boil and salt it generously. Once the water is thrashing, tip in the spinach, pushing it well into the water so that all of it wilts under the force of the hot liquid. Cook for 30 seconds, then lift out with a slotted spoon and transfer to a bowl of iced water. Once the spinach is cool enough to handle, squeeze it dry. Peel and finely chop the onions, and cook them gently in the butter until soft. Roughly chop the spinach, and mix into the sweated onion mix, along with a very generous grating of nutmeg, some sea salt and freshly milled pepper. Set the spinach mixture to one side.

Heat the milk in a saucepan. Melt the butter in a separate pot over a gentle heat, then stir in the flour. Let the roux cook for five minutes, stirring regularly, until it is pale gold in colour. Whisking all the while, start adding the milk bit by bit until all of it has been incorporated into the roux, and the bechamel is smooth - it should be the consistency of cream. Add the thyme, peppercorns and bayleaf, and set aside to infuse.

Refill the pan of water, and bring it to the boil. Drop in the pasta: if fresh, it will need but a few minutes; dried will require considerably longer. Once cooked, drain the pasta in a colander and run cold water over it to halt the cooking process, else it will go soggy.

Butter a handsome earthenware dish and lay out in it enough sheets of pasta just to cover the base. Spread some of the spinach mixture over the pasta, then some tomatoes, then ladle over some of the white sauce. Repeat these layers until everything has been used up, making sure that the top layer consists of béchamel. Liberally grate Parmesan over the top, then place the lasagne in the oven for 15 minutes until just beginning to colour. When serving, offer more fresh Parmesan.

Plum clafoutis

This pudding is also very good when made with mirabelles or greengages.

340g ripe plums

For the batter

20g toasted flaked almonds
70ml Armagnac (or Cognac)
55g caster sugar
Around 250ml milk - the exact amount will depend on how much alcohol the plums absorb
3 fine free-range eggs
1 tsp vanilla extract
1 pinch salt
70g plain flour

Preheat the oven to 175C/350F/gas mark 4. Bring a pan of water to the boil, and drop in the plums for 10 seconds. Remove the fruit and, when cool enough to handle, peel it. Steep the whole peeled plums in the Armagnac and sugar for at least an hour. Drain the plums and put to one side. Pour the steeping juices into the liquidiser, then top up with enough milk to make up 280ml of liquid. Add the remaining batter ingredients, and blend for a minute.

Put a two-litre earthenware dish in the oven to warm. Pour a thin layer of batter into the dish and let it set slightly. Sit the plums in the batter, and pour over the rest of the batter. Scatter the almonds on top, and cook until the clafoutis is slightly puffed and golden brown - around an hour. Lightly dust with icing sugar to finish

 Jeremy Lee is the chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

fields.headline: A slow pint
fields.standfirst: Freedom Pilsener
fields.trailText: Freedom Pilsener
fields.body:
'Good lager' and 'British' are rarely synonymous, but the small Freedom Brewery in Parsons Green, south-west London, proves there's more to cold-fermented beers than Carling and McEwan's. Freedom's Pilsener has been pleasing tastebuds in and around the capital for several years, and it has now been joined by Freedom Organic Pilsener (5%). It's available on draught in Freedom's two brew-pubs in Earlham Street, WC2, and Ganton Street, W1, and also in 330ml bottles in such specialist outlets as the Beer Shop in Hoxton, Swigg in Hampstead and Kelly's in Clapham (£1.30 to £1.50). It carries the Soil Association's seal of approval, which includes a German yeast strain that is guaranteed GM-free.

The other ingredients include German pale Pilsener malt and three German hop varieties, Hallertauer, Hersbrucker and Spalter. It's a delight to drink, with a rich cornflour nose backed by aromatic hops, juicy malt and tart citric fruit in the mouth, and a long, lingering dry and bitter finish dominated by the hops. With so much uncompromising hop bitterness, the beer is closer in style to a north German Pils than to the original Czech version from Pilsen. Further information: 020-7731 7372.

fields.headline: Trickle down effect
fields.standfirst: No matter how modest your outside space, it can always be made to work as a restful sanctuary, says Celia Woolfrey. And for that ulitmate blissed-out effect, simply add water.
fields.trailText: No matter how modest your outside space, it can always be made to work as a restful sanctuary, says Celia Woolfrey. And for that ulitmate blissed-out effect, simply add water.
fields.body:
The paradox of having a garden is that they are the best places for slowing down, but keeping them looking good involves more or less constant activity. This is not to say that some gardens aren't better than others at helping you unwind.

Ancient tradition thought of the garden as an oasis in the desert with walls to keep out the world and lush plants irrigated by sacred springs within. Broadly speaking, this is the basic plan of the Paradise garden, which persisted for centuries, and the idea of the walled garden as a place for relaxation - and, traditionally, erotic trysts - is one carved deep into the gardening psyche.

Niwa, the Japanese word for garden, means "an enclosure purified for the worship of the gods", conjuring up the idea of a quiet, protected place for peaceful contemplation; in this case, the atmosphere of calm is usually achieved by austere simplicity. But if you don't fancy this pure and Zen-like route to balance, you could still go for the design trick of a sense of enclosure, which is common to many traditions - a sanctuary that will be your own private domain.

In this respect, urban gardens are an ideal base to work from. They are often already surrounded by walls; and if not, then the small size of the average back yard for once is an advantage because it makes it easier and more affordable to screen it off with fences, trellis or climbing plants. Once you've got the sense of enclosure, then gateways, for example, become loaded with mental resonances, as well as being practical. Beds, borders and edgings then complement the picture.

Two designers from different backgrounds have both published books on the subject of the garden as a kind of inner sanctum. In The Inward Garden (Little, Brown, £27.50), the American Julie Moir Messervy, who was inspired by the traditional gardens of Japan, talks about seven primary elements of the garden - the grove, hut, enclosure, threshold, meadow, mount and spring - and how they can be represented in a small domestic space. A "hut" can be a garden bench backed by a tree, for example, or a "bridge" can be a simple granite slab over a rill, and still have resonance in a scaled-down landscape.

In his book, Portfolio Of Contemporary Gardens (Quadrille, £25), the British designer Stephen Woodhams shows how using symbolic elements - bleached stones and semi-succulents to represent a desert garden, for instance - can evoke a wider landscape, and how setting a garden apart both in time and space, and personalising it, gives it restorative powers beyond the pleasures of simply being outside doing nothing.

Both designers recommend water as the most powerful element influencing the atmosphere of a garden. The sound of a fountain trickling into a stone basin cools and relaxes, and the energy of water always seeking its lowest level is deeply satisfying, especially as a strong, constant flow.

Huge water extravaganzas, such as the Villa d'Este at Tivoli, the André Citroën gardens in Paris, or the amazing water chutes of the gardens of Nishat Bagh, in Kashmir, give the impression that you need a generous space and budget if you're going to use such features in a garden. But a rill a few centimetres wide, flowing down a set of six brick steps and into a small pool in a quiet corner of the Alhambra Palace gardens, in Granada, Spain, shows how the narrowest stream of water can add animation and life.

Still water works well, too. Pools, especially if they are sunlit, produce calming reflections that can be intensified if the lining is painted in a dark colour such as black or green. Always aim for a sense of abundance when using water, as in those swimming pools that gently overflow their edges.

Another designer, Christopher Bradley Hole, uses a rigid steel lining in pools, so that the water level is flush with the surrounding paving. But for abundance without building work, a beautiful, wide-necked pot filled to the brim and regularly topped up gives the equivalent effect.

One garden, in Catford, south London, shows how enclosure, water and simple shapes can work together to make a calm place without being a burden to maintain. The owners, Francis and Kirstin O'Connor, work irregular hours as a theatre designer and a doctor, and since their time off rarely coincides, they wanted to make sure they spent it relaxing rather than doing the gardening. With this brief, Andrew Mitchell, of the Vivid Space design group, built them a decking "stage" on which to eat out and entertain friends.

In answer to the question whether decking is suitable for the British climate, Mitchell points out that this one is made from English oak, which does not get slippery when wet. He has planed it for a smooth finish and nailed it to joists as you would a floor, using rust-free, stainless-steel nails, so it's solid like a boat deck.

The deck has now weathered to a silvery-grey colour, and is surrounded by raised beds of spiky phormiums, bamboo and, in summer, a hot border of purple basil and crocosmia; there's also a pond in one corner. The couple asked a horticulturalist friend, Simon Auton, for a planting scheme that would leave a few pockets of space that they could fill in with their own favourites. Auton tried to steer them towards having more space for plants and, in retrospect, Francis says it's the one thing they would do differently if they went through the process again.

This is a good compromise between being a slave to your garden and going for the minimalist "low maintenance" style that's high on concrete and Perspex, but low on live plants. And in any case, it's debatable whether this really does cut down on work. As garden designer Chris Maton says, "Though contemporary-style gardens are low maintenance in the traditional sense - low weeding and low watering - they involve more maintenance in the upkeep of materials. You end up treating metals, for instance, or cleaning glass. I always tell my clients that truly low maintenance is difficult to achieve."

There is a conflict in this talk of serenity-inducing gardens, because they inevitably involve getting the builders in. It's not ideal, but remember: after the work is done, you really don't have to do a thing, because if you really hate gardening, you can always get a gardener.

Tranquil tips

1 Choose plants that like the conditions you've got - soil, aspect, etc - so you don't have to nurse them.

2 Check out websites such as www.spidergarden.com or www.dig-it.com for off-the-peg planting schemes.

3 Go for repeat planting rather than scores of different varieties - it's much easier on the eye.

4 Eliminate bare patches in borders and the lawn so that weeds don't have a chance to get established.

5 Get rid of the lawn - it's a lot of work to keep it looking good, and there are more interesting surfaces about.

6 Let the worms do the work and use mulches to feed plants and improve soil structure.

7 Hoe up weeds before they set seed in spring - it will cut down on weeding for the rest of the year.

8 Buy 'young plants' (annual flowers and veg) in modules by mail order, rather than mess about sowing seeds.

9 Avoid lots of small container plantings - especially if you haven't much time to water them.

10 Have fences rather than hedges: no need to explain which one is more work.

Ancient tradition thought of the garden as an oasis in the desert with walls to keep out the world and lush plants irrigated by sacred springs within. Broadly speaking, this is the basic plan of the Paradise garden, which persisted for centuries, and the idea of the walled garden as a place for relaxation - and, traditionally, erotic trysts - is one carved deep into the gardening psyche. Niwa, the Japanese word for garden, means "an enclosure purified for the worship of the gods", conjuring up the idea of a quiet, protected place for peaceful contemplation; in this case, the atmosphere of calm is usually achieved by austere simplicity. fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.standfirst: Easy does it when it comes to buying wine, says Malcolm Gluck, as he sips his way through the mail-order list of one of Britain's most notable wine merchants
fields.trailText: Easy does it when it comes to buying wine, says Malcolm Gluck, as he sips his way through the mail-order list of one of Britain's most notable wine merchants.
fields.body:
There is no great English wine, but there is one great English wine merchant. He is a useful chap for readers who find supermarkets stressful, wine shops a strain, and conventional wine merchants unbearable stuffy. He is a truly independent character who ships all his own wines, is on first-name terms with all his vignerons, writes his own wine list, and sleeps above the shop (okay, his bed is expectorating distance across the office yard).

You may ask what such an individual is doing in this column. In fact, he has appeared once before, six years ago. I thus acknowledge my disgraceful neglect of Robin Yapp, of Yapp Brothers of Mere in Wiltshire, specialist in the Loire and the Rhône.

His wines? They fitted my definition of superplonks when I first tasted them in March 1970, and not much has changed, except Robin has since got himself an excellent 15.5 point (out of 20) house champagne (£15.95, from J Dumangin Fils), expanded into Provence, the Savoie, Alsace and Roussillon and - a truly startling innovation this - signed up the maker of Australia's most alcoholically intimidating shiraz (Ron Laughton, of Jasper Hill). Since Robin once told me that he found Australian wines industrially produced and "not the passionate products of original minds", Mr Laughton finds himself in choice company. But then his unbelievably demanding and heady Georgia's Paddock Shiraz 1998 rates 17 points and asks £28.75 for the privilege of getting pissed on it. A little goes a long way with Georgia and, in comparison, she makes Grange Hermitage, the overrated Penfolds brand, appear a jejune joke.

Robin's vignerons produce wines that have no appeal to the wine snob because they lack legendary status. Such wines are for the wine lover who values what the Spanish call duende - something with soul. The prices reflect the labour, love, skill, and personal committment put in to each wine, which is very different from sticking an impressive price tag on a bottle to excite the pulse and stimulate the purse of the shallow-minded status-symbol-seeker.

Take the wines of Denis Ferrer and Bruno Ribiere, which can claim only humble Vins de Pays Catalan status. The Ferrer family has been vignerons for 600 years, and the vines that make the Carignan-graped Domaine Ferrer Ribiere Centenaire 1999 are 122 years old. Yet the result is a gorgeously fresh and vigorous red wine of panache and pertinacity. It rates 17 points and costs £6.95.

I have been lucky enough to taste some sublime Yapp reds. Paul & Frederik Filliatreau's Saumur Champigny La Grande Vignolle (17 points, £8.35) is a deliciously quaffable, superbly textured wine of lingering minerality. Michel Gigon's Thouarsais Breton 1998 (16.5 points, £6.35) has tannins that dance on the tongue. Andre Vatan's Vin de Pays du Cher La Ronciere 1998 (16 points, £6.60) is an unusual pinot noir with floral-scents and chewy tannins. Jean-Louis and Sylvie Grippat's Saint Joseph 1998 (17 points, £13.95) has stunning richness, softness and ripeness. Jean-Marie Lombard's Brezeme Eugene de Monicault 1996 (17 points, £11.25), a 100% syrah, is mature and softening on the taste buds and has an ineffable sense of completeness and rich complexity. Denis Cheron has turned out an exemplary Vacqueyras Cuvée Spéciale 1995 (17 points, £8.50) and it is a benchmark Ctes-du-Rhne with bitter cherry fruit, a controlled earthy undertone and a lovely texture. It makes for perfectly mature, serious drinking. Georges Vernay's Collines Rhodaniennes Syrah 1998 (16.5 points, £7.60) is a delightfully piquant, savourily rich wine. Auguste and Pierre Clape's Ctes-du-Rhne Syrah 1999 (17 points, £12.25) is fresher, being much younger and fiestier. The fruit has a hedgerow sweetness which stretches the palate as the dry tannins begin to bite.

More unusual is Jacques Dalmasco's red Domaine de la Source Bellet 1998 (17.5 points, £15) the white of which appellation, Bellet, is the house wine of Nice. The red, made from folle noir and grenache, is a delicious revelation of luxuriously textured plum/cherry/blackcurrant richness with a rousing, happy lilt on its finish.

But even the gentle eccentricity and rarity of this wine must give way to Christine Campadieu's and Vincent Cantie's gloriously sexy Domaine La Tour Vieille Collioure 1998 (18 points, £8.75) which has an absolutely captivating richness, wonderful tannins, huge fruit with spice and wild herb touches, and the whole fabulous construct has a gently baked quality to it, a possibly bequest of the generous French Catalan sun.

On Yapp's white side, I enjoyed Jean-Baptiste Pinon's Jasnieres Les Truffieres 1989 (18.5 points, £14.75) which is off-dry, curiously honied and subtly vegetal, and with a burnt-buttery and walnutty richness with the texture of ruffled satin. Gerard & Jean-Louis Chave's Hermitage 1997 (16 points, £40) is remarkably textured, aromatic and nutty and has a compelling, almost malt-whisky tang to it. Monsieur Lombard has a white Brezeme, a great rarity, and his 1998 (17 points, £13.50) has a graceful oily texture and a peach and dry honey undertone. This is one of those uncommon white wines which works like a red, which to say that it has layers of subtle flavours which permit close examination over several hours, as the bottle empties and the mind fills.

Robin's list contains several interesting sweet white wines with a depth and a personality that does not consign them to playing second fiddle to dessert. The one I admire most is Michel and Laurent Berger's Montlouis Grains Nobles 1990 (17 points, £17.95) which, though lively now, has 25 years of development in it. By 2025, the layers of butterscotch richness will have become so concentrated you could consume the wine with a spoon.

Now be aware that I have only quoted single bottle prices and you can only sensibly buy a single bottle if you visit Mere. Yapp Brothers deals in cases sales - two cases and above being delivered free (large quantities attract a discount, as do cases collected by the purchaser from Mere personally, which I recommend visiting as it has a charming church, St Michael's, with some medieval stained-glass vaut le detour).

You can telephone Yapp Brothers on 01747 860423, email them on sales@yapp.co.uk, fax them on 01747 860929, and access the website on www.yapp.co.uk. The wine list alone is worth leafing through. The writer's prose style gives the flavour of the man as much as it conveys the sense of the wines.

fields.headline: Music for an eternity
fields.trailText: The 'performance' of Longplayer started at the new year. The final notes will be played, disasters and forgetfulness allowing, on January 1, 3000.
fields.body:
There are some very long pieces of music knocking around. Alexander Scriabin, at the time of his death in 1915, was outlining a work, The Mysterium, that would last a week and involve architecture, dance and landscape gardening as part of the performance. Erik Satie's Vexations - a fragment of music repeated more than 800 times - lasts 24 hours. In the early 60s, American minimalist LaMonte Young conceived of 'dream music' intended for continuous performance in 'dream houses'. But a piece of music that lasts 1,000 years? That's something else...

The 'performance' of Longplayer started at the new year. The final notes will be played, disasters and forgetfulness allowing, on January 1, 3000. It will not repeat itself once during these 1,000 years. Commissioned by Artangel, it has been developed by Jem Finer, a founder member of The Pogues with a handy computer science degree. Handy, because the piece is computer generated.

The core of Longplayer is a 20-minute recording of Tibetan music, that has been manipulated to create a 1,000-year-long loop. He has described the process as like 'six copies of the same gramophone record on different turntables all spinning at different speeds with different bits playing at the same time'.

Longplayer is thus more like a soundscape, or a piece of installation art, than a conventional piece of music. You can never experience it all. It will outlive you. If you listen to a fragment of it, you can but imagine the rest: the unknowable, ineluctable expanse of time stretching before you.

There is a listening post for Longplayer at Trinity Buoy Lighthouse, London E14. Details: 020-7336 6803. Or visit www.longplayer.org

fields.headline: 101 ways to slow down
fields.trailText: 1 Don't wear a watch.
fields.body:
1 Don't wear a watch.

2 Don't eat breakfast standing up.

3 Go shopping very early, or very late, or even on a Sunday.

4 When cooking a nice meal, cook double and have another meal ready for the next day; or quadruple, freeze it and have lots of nice meals.

5 Get an allotment.

6 Relax in the bath, don't rave in the shower.

7 Don't chase that bus - let it go.

8 Remember the Portuguese saying: 'Think of many things - do one.'

9 If someone asks 'How are you?', tell them.

10 Take responsbility only for the things you can control.

11 Chew.

12 Try a beard (men) or the hairy look (women). If God had intended us to have a smooth face, armpits or bikini line, he wouldn't have given us hair.

13 Smell the roses.

14 Read long novels, not short stories or magazines (other than Weekend, of course).

15 Do DIY and gardening only if you really love to do it.

16 Develop good friendships by seeing people individually, and not always in a big group.

17 Stay at home on bank holiday weekends.

18 Cross the road only when you see the green man.

19 Do something spontaneous - don't plan all your leisure time.

20 Give up the gym.

21 Do all your household shopping once a month, topping up with fresh goods as you need them.

22 Don't get a laptop.

23 Fall in love.

24 Take the scenic route.

25 Don't multi-task.

26 Don't go to Ikea at the weekend. Or at all, unless you have a thing about flatpacks.

27 Delegate up and down, at home and at work.

28 Buy presents and cards when you see them, not in a panic the day before.

29 Take your name off the junk mail lists - contact the Mailing Preference Service on 0845 703 4599 and your name will be removed from 95% of direct mailing lists.

30 The law of housework: disorder matters more than dust.

31 Work late if you really must, but don't ever take work home with you.

32 Coordinate your wardrobe, it will make picking and choosing much easier.

33 Don't eat in the street.

34 Retire from work as soon as you can afford to (see page 85, How To Retire).

35 Shop locally, rather than in huge, busy, out-of-town hypermarkets.

36 Watch TV only if there's something you desperately want to see.

37 Have fewer meetings.

38 Forget about ego and status - buy a slow car and enjoy the journey.

39 Unless you really have become 'friends', don't keep in touch with ex boyfriends or girlfriends - the experience will only bring you down.

40 If you have a mobile phone, keep it switched off most of the time. If people think you're always available, they'll call you even more.

41 Have a small, pocket-sized diary, rather than a hefty tome - it will encourage you to keep appointments to a minimum.

42 Clear your home of clutter every couple of months.

43 Before you visit a shop, call ahead to check they have what you're looking for.

44 Make a list of things to do - then cut it in half.

45 Let the phone ring a few times before you answer it.

46 Spend time listening to music - just listening to it, not doing the dusting at the same time.

47 Pay bills by direct debit.

48 Don't drink and drive, you'll enjoy neither.

49 Try to avoid rush hour.

50 Don't go to the video shop; try the library instead.

51 Make double quantities of items that freeze well, such as stock and pastry.

52 Leave your answer-phone off when you go away on holiday. Or better still, don't have an answer-phone at all.

53 Dab lavender oil on your pillow - it helps you sleep.

54 Buy a comfortable sofa.

55 Don't buy clothes that say 'dry clean only' on the label.

56 When you're calling an automated answering service, and you're told, 'If you have a touch-tone phone, press 2', don't press it. Instead, pretend you have an old-style analogue phone. You'll go straight through to an operator.

57 Take siestas.

58 Always put your keys in the same place when you get home.

59 Better 30 minutes too late in this world than 30 years too early in the next.

60 Throw away any clothes you haven't worn for the past two years. Or take them to the charity shop.

61 Train children at an early age to do their share of the Hoovering, washing up, sheet changing and other chores.

62 Get a proper set of screwdrivers rather than struggling with a knife to change a plug.

63 Open your emails only three times a day.

64 Remember that wasting time refreshes the soul.

65 Get the ringback facility added to your phone (call the Customer Services number for your network provider), then you need never again waste time waiting for others to come off the line.

66 Do one thing at a time.

67 Avoid hangovers, unless you have the time to indulge them.

68 Hang up your clothes when you take them off.

69 Write real letters and postcards, don't just send email.

70 Plan ahead - but leave time to be spontaneous.

71 Keep laundered duvet covers inside-out, so that they're easier to put on when changing the bed linen.

72 Either get unpleasant tasks out of the way at a once - or procrastinate shamelessly. You choose.

73 Work out if you could afford to work part-time, and consider it.

74 Walk.

75 If you want to spend more time doing something you're good at, and less doing chores for which you lack the skills or inclination, join a LETS (Local Exchange Trading Scheme) in your area - where people exchange goods or services (for example, you weed my garden, I'll paint your roof) without the need for money. webTitle: Seconds  out as the time lords  meet

fields.headline: Seconds  out as the time lords  meet
fields.trailText: 'I make the time,' declares Dr Demetrios Matsakis, 'so I can do what I want with it.' He's only slightly joking - if anyone runs the world's time, it's Dr Matsakis.
fields.body:
'I make the time,' declares Dr Demetrios Matsakis, 'so I can do what I want with it.' He's only slightly joking - if anyone runs the world's time, it's Dr Matsakis. He is Director of Time Standards at the US Navy's Directorate of Time - the hours, minutes and nanoseconds on the 60 atomic clocks at his laboratory in Washington DC provide the official source of time for the Department of Defense (and therefore the network of Global Positioning Satellites) and the standard of time for the US. He is the world's top time lord. And, today he's in the time centre of Britain - and no, it's not Greenwich.

It's been many years since Greenwich really made the time. If you want to find the clock capital of Britain now, you have go to Teddington, Middlesex, to the National Physical Laboratory (NPL), where Dr John Laverty and his team of eight scientists check the three caesium clocks that send out the national radio time signal from Rugby. NPL's signal is used by government and companies such as Railtrack (all station clocks in Britain are timed with NPL, 'although we can't make the trains run on time,' says Dr Laverty).

Under international agreement, world time actually comes together at Sèvres, just south-west of Paris, at the Bureau International des Poids et Mesures (BIPM). There, an average is taken from 200 atomic clocks in labs around the world. Each month, a report is sent back to the time labs such as NPL or Washington to let them know how close their clocks are to the average. 'If I'm 10 nanoseconds out, we have a problem,' says Dr Matsakis. However, as his lab provides 60 atomic clocks - approximately 40% of the world total compared with the UK's 3 or 4% - he can, of course, set the average. Why does it matter? GPS [Global Positioning Systems] satellites, for instance, are time-coordinated - and if one is even a nanosecond out, you could miss by feet.

It's certainly a weird career area. 'I was a real child of the space age,' says 50-year-old Dr Matsakis, who grew up with one eye peering through a telescope at the stars and has just been voted vice-chair of the prestigious International Astronomical Union's commission on time.

They get together every few months at time conventions to write equations on the back of napkins and discuss projects, such as 'redefining the second'. This is important because the world is not as exact as the atomic clock, and often moves faster or slower - at present, every so often 'leap seconds' are inserted into the year.

'The thing about time,' says Dr Laverty, at 36, a relative newcomer, 'is that everyone is so young - even when they're close to retirement'. They each have their own pet projects. For Dr Matsakis, it's 'finding the best way to average all clocks. It's the holy grail of time.'

NPL is now a 'GOCO' centre in the jargon of Whitehall, ie, Government Owned, Contractor Operated. The time has officially been privatised. But ask Dr Matsakis if the US Navy would sell off the time and he is adamant. 'No way,' he says. 'They need the time. Things have to work. If there's a war on they don't need some peacenik not giving them the time... ' Are they ever late? 'My personal timekeeping is pretty awful, actually,' Dr Laverty admits.

webTitle: Why we rats  feel we  have to race

fields.headline: Why we rats  feel we  have to race
fields.trailText: Imagine what it would be like to give up work on Wednesdays. We would slave away on Monday and Tuesday, put up our feet mid-week, and have the weekend firmly in sight when starting the second half of our week on Thursday.
fields.body:
Imagine what it would be like to give up work on Wednesdays. We would slave away on Monday and Tuesday, put up our feet mid-week, and have the weekend firmly in sight when starting the second half of our week on Thursday. Impossible? Utopian? The economics of the madhouse?

Not really. Think of the world as it was 60 or 70 years ago, before new technologies brought fridges, cars, foreign holidays and telephones within the grasp of the bulk of the population. We are so much wealthier now - in material terms, at least - we could still have a higher standard of living than our grandparents even if we cut our working week by 20%.

An international survey conducted by two economists - Andrew Oswald of Warwick University and David Blanchflower of Dartmouth College in the US - found that 69% of people in 27 countries wanted to spend more time with their families, 29% thought the life-work balance was just right, and 2% wanted to spend more time at the office. The richest, the United States, was the unhappiest of all, with 46% keen to spend much more time with their families and a further 39% wanting to work less.

Given that we are all supposed to aspire to the US model of turbo-charged capitalism, these are somewhat disturbing findings. The flexible labour market may be good for business, but bad for individuals. As the sociologist Richard Sennett argued in his book The Corrosion Of Character, the threat to the modern industrial system comes not from a dramatic, Marxist- style revolution but from a gradual disintegration.

The really interesting question is why we put up with this state of affairs. One answer could be that we simply don't know when we are well off. During the mid 19th century, six 12-hour days were the norm for mill workers, and since then hours worked have steadily declined. Worrying about the life-work balance is a luxury; during recessions we have other things on our mind - avoiding the sack, keeping up the mortgage payments.

Another explanation is that, for all the breast-beating, we spend more time at work because we want to. The professional middle classes may have fallen prey to jacket-on-the-back-of-seat syndrome but, if asked, most would say that they like their jobs.

Yet Oswald and Blanchflower found that the desire to spend more time with the family was particularly pronounced among middle-aged, highly qualified men.

In short, everyone may be behaving rationally as individuals but working inefficiently hard as a collective group. 'Keeping up with the Joneses is what rules. If you work hard, I feel I have to in order to keep up - in chances of promotion at work, in buying the latest cars and sweaters. If we could all agree to slow down together, we could all be happier.'

But there's the rub. Taking our foot off the pedal collectively may turn us into happier people, better parents, more considerate lovers, more productive workers, but we don't act collectively, we act as individuals. And as individuals we are too insecure to do what we think would be good for us.

fields.headline: What me?  Worry?
fields.trailText: In order to persuade the punters that precious quality time won't be wasted reading manuals, the self-help gurus have identified our increasing lack of it as one of their favourite targets.
fields.body:
Should you ever win the rollover and find yourself in possession of vast oceans of untenanted time, you could easily spend a decade reading self-help manuals, and then another putting their precepts into practice. Not everybody, of course, has that luxury, and in order to persuade the punters that precious quality time won't be wasted reading manuals, the self-help gurus have identified our increasing lack of it as one of their favourite targets.

Richard Carlson's Don't Sweat the Small Stuff : And It's All Small Stuff is a fine example of this anomaly. A blend of life-enhancing advice handily presented in bitesize chunks - or 'meditations' - it has sold more than eight million copies throughout the world and given birth to an unruly family of books, with add-ons designed especially for mothers, fathers, teenagers, newlyweds, workers and lovers. In other words, just about everyone, including those searching for the perfect present: who could resist the three-in-one boxed set? Or the Don't Sweat Treasury: A Special Collection For Friends?

Devoted readers speak of the books as 'Bibles' that 'changed their lives'. The more cynical might be more inclined to describe these 'helping rituals' as common sense larded with a hefty dose of schmaltz.

The basic premise is that we must rise serenely above minor irritations, thereby attaining a greater state of inner calm and happiness. Carlson advises, for example, that when a driver cuts you up, you refrain from a bout of road rage and 'try to have compassion for the person and remember how painful it is to be in such an enormous hurry'.

Meanwhile, if you're feeling alienated from the modern world, then simply 'Smile at strangers, look into their eyes and say, Hello'. Turn to meditation number 38, and the book will tell you to inform three people how much you love them; if that foxes you, shoot off to number 42, where you will learn to spend a moment every day thinking of someone to love - even, Carlson suggests, someone you've passed on the street.

It may all sound impossibly glib - not to say somewhat optimistic - but Carlson's miniature wisdoms have hit home with legions of the hurried and harried. With tenets such as 'When you die, your in-box won't be empty', 'Allow yourself to be bored' and 'Make peace with imperfection', this champion coper has become a bestselling author - it comes as no surprise to find that another of his books bears the title Don't Worry, Make Money.

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Tanya takes a break from a particularly stressful holiday.
fields.body:
There I was, on a yacht buffeted by a savage storm, crying to God (www.gospelcom.net) for help.

Miraculously, the storm abated as quickly as it had started. I ordered the crew to search for Migraine Alan. I was waiting by the stern, ashen-faced, when one of the sailors approached. 'Madam, could this be the gentleman?' He pointed at a pair of shoes protruding from a ventilation funnel, and I recognised the penny loafers (www.hackett.co.uk Migraine Alan was wearing. 'Yes! Get him out!' I cried.

'I'm afraid we'll have to reach harbour first. The gentleman needs medical assistance.' As soon as we repaired in Corsica, firemen released poor Migraine Alan from his tubular trap (a wave had swept him off his feet and plunged him head-first into the funnel), and the doctors found that he had multiple fractures. He's in the Centre Hospitalier d'Ajaccio (www.sante.gouv.fr), in chin-to-ankle plastercast and unable to speak, so I had to continue the holiday alone.

La Tomatina (www.latomatina.com) was fun, but being pelted with overripe tomatoes couldn't take my mind of the trauma I had been through. Migraine Alan was in hospital, but what about my nerves?

I retired to my bedroom and keyed in 'relax' on my laptop. www.RippleCreek.com promised me that melatonin, kava root and valerian root would do the trick, but that would mean waiting for these herbal remedies to come from the US.

I thought my next hit, Relax (Frequently Asked Questions), would have all the answers, but it was a nerve-jangling hell explaining a computer language. 'Slowdown' threatened to be equally disappointing, with economics sites predicting a financial downturn (I don't buy that sort of thing when I'm in the City). But then, bingo! Or should I say Brazil! The Bossa Nova experience (www.slowdown-music) was samba to my ears. For a nano-second, I thought of Migraine Alan in his lonely bed. Then I fell asleep.
