fields.headline: Sex in the  slow  lane
fields.trailText: It is difficult to approach the subject of tantric sex with a straight face and an open mind when you have browsed the reading list of the SkyDancing Institute.
fields.body:
It is difficult to approach the subject of tantric sex with a straight face and an open mind when you have browsed the reading list of the SkyDancing Institute.

SkyDancing, 'an ancient metaphor for the ability to achieve ecstatic states', is an organisation founded by Margot Anand, teacher of tantra and distributor of the rather platitudinous advice, 'instead of having sex, try making love'.

It was established to - and here you may struggle against the first impulse to snigger - promote the Art Of Everyday Ecstasy, the knack of slowing down sex and also the title of a book by Anand, which has about it the delirious quality of a 50s guide on how to achieve orgasm and vacuum the skirting boards at the same time. Along with basic reading material for Love and Ecstasy Training (LET), the SkyDancing Institute outlines how to master the advanced technique of Riding The Wave Of Bliss.

The tantric sex industry is divided into sassy, hi-tech outfits such as SkyDancing, which sell self-help videos while blurring the line between western psychotherapy and eastern philosophy, and organisations such as the Abhidhyan Yoga Institute, the 'authentic' voice of tantra yoga, usually based in India and run by middle-aged gurus.

Shri Acharya Abhidhyanananda Avadhuta, head of the Abhidhyan Institute, specialises in 'attaining inner peace' and fighting the forces of 'phony new-age tantra' which, he believes, emphasise all that sexy stuff at the expense of the ancient Hindu and Buddhist priorities of appeasing the deities.

The popular definition of tantric sex is sex undertaken in a state of meditative calm attained by both parties focusing on their spiritual sexuality. Definitions of spiritual sexuality vary between 'the joining together of the male/female principles' (Kay Parker, author of the Pictorial Guide To Tantric Sex Positions, with 85 full-colour photos), and the grander 'freedom of the eternal human soul from the bondages of the world' (Shri Acharya).

Both boil down to a ridding oneself of the culturally imposed inhibitions that foul up sex, the net result of which is supposed to be a prolonged orgasm of anything up to 10 minutes. To this end, teachers of tantra suggest a variety of exercises through which to counter the conditioning that men and women must follow proscribed roles during sex. The SkyDancing Institute suggests imagining that your partner's body is part of your own by assuming the yoga position of 'interlocking your legs' and holding it for an arduous 15 minutes.

The Abhidhyan Yoga Institute goes back a stage and suggests that you can't start interlocking with somebody else until you are sure that you love yourself. It advises beginners to sit quietly on a chair somewhere and contemplate their body: 'How does it look? How do you perceive the inside? Where are the organs? What is their colour? What is their condition? Healthy, sick, tired, full of life? Slowly, with an imaginary broom, sweep out the tension and fatigue and then gradually let a feeling of pleasant relaxation enter the body, as if a vast seascape has opened up before you.'

If you can stop tittering for long enough, it may improve your sex life. On the other hand, it may reveal ailments even more passion-killing than the traditional headache.

webTitle: At the 247th beat,  it will be...

fields.headline: At the 247th beat,  it will be...
fields.trailText: Internet time: it's confusing, complicated and heading our way. The theory goes like this: if the internet is a global community, how can you coordinate what's going on?
fields.body:
Internet time: it's confusing, complicated and heading our way. The theory goes like this: if the internet is a global community, how can you coordinate what's going on? Financial transactions, gambling or live webcasts would be a lot simpler if everyone around the world knew what hour it was without having to work out time zones. For the most part this is a question of convenience; in the business world, millions of pounds could be won or lost in a mix-up over an electronic time-stamp.

'Speed is the form of ecstasy the technical revolution has bestowed on man,' said Czech novelist Milan Kundera, and the phrase 'internet time' used to mean simply doing things really fast, without business plans and on the hoof - five-year forecasts telescoped to six months. But, just like John Harrison's struggles over longitude, there is no standard, yet.

The Brits have tried. Tony Blair launched a high-profile scheme in January to make Greenwich the focus of internet time. Greenwich Electronic Time (GET) consists of three atomic clocks in a warehouse opposite the Dome.

PC manufacturers are offered free software to tell time accurately to within a fraction of a second, but there are reports the package doesn't work properly with Microsoft's Internet Explorer, used by 80% of the world's net users - one test found times differing by nine seconds. But it may succeed yet, and you can find out more at www.get-time.org.

The Swiss watch makers, Swatch, have invented another solution - adopted already by US-based websites such as Apple and CNN. Swatch Internet Time divides the day into 1,000 beats - with one beat equivalent to one minute 26.4 seconds. Noon is 500 beats, and a day in Internet Time starts at midnight in Biel, Switzerland, where Swatch is based.

You can do a conversion at www.swatch.com/internettime and see how elegant it would be to meet your beloved at 857 beats. It is totally impossible to understand, of course.

But if you want to feel at ease with the earth, try the hippy-ish New Earth Time where the day is divided into 360 degrees (just like the turning of the earth, see?). In net-land, there are 360 earthbeats every day, 15 earthbeats in an hour and one earthbeat every four minutes.

It's complex, unreliable and understood by only a few. In other words, perfectly suited for the internet-age.

webTitle: City with  no time  for troubles

fields.headline: City with  no time  for troubles
fields.trailText: The Italian countryside is a regular holiday haunt for thousands of Britons - it's the slow tempo of life that draws visitors to the small sleepy towns.
fields.body:
The Italian countryside is a regular holiday haunt for thousands of Britons - it's the slow tempo of life that draws visitors to the small sleepy towns. But for local people, things are moving just a bit too fast with the pace of modern living simply not leaving enough time for life's essentials. Now a nationwide campaign is underway to keep the 21st century at bay.

Orvieto is a city in no hurry. From its table-top position above the Umbrian countryside, it sits protected from the stresses of life - there has never been an earthquake, it's never been bombed and the city has never suffered a major fire. One of Italy's oldest cities, it attracts thousands of tourists every year, won over by its beauty and tranquillity.

But even here it seems, life is a beat too fast and Orvieto is fighting back. It's joining forces with more than 30 towns and cities across Umbria and Tuscany - in the Citta Slow or Slow City movement.

'A slowing up would improve the quality of our life here,' says Louisa Borgna, one of the leaders of the Citta Slow campaign. 'It's not that we don't want progress, but we want to try to control the speed at which things are moving.'

Campaigners say that the movement isn't fuelled by nostalgia. They don't want to be seen as anti-technology or scared of the future. They say it is about having the all- important time and space to enjoy life's pleasures. The Citta Slow movement is a code of conduct, a form of self regulation for Umbria and Tuscany. 'To be a Citta Slow, people must place an emphasis on respecting and preserving cultural traditions,' says Louisa Borgna. 'Using modern inventions like electric buses can help prevent pollution, and we'll use our cars less often, too. We should also make an effort to keep the town beautiful and clean.'

Residents are also being asked to grow sweet-smelling plants and flowers in their gardens to ensure the aroma and look of rural Italy is as idyllic as possible. The campaign has won the backing of local people keen to ensure Orvieto retains the charm so enjoyed by tourists.

The Foresi family owns a wine cellar in the main square, which was dug by hand underneath the city 700 years ago. Its owner, Gianluca Foresi, says, 'Citta Slow is about not concentrating on time. It's about enjoying every minute, every bite of each day.'

Born and brought up in Orvieto, Signor Foresi says Citta Slow is the best thing that could have happened to his home town. 'You can just sit in the sun and not worry about your work, your business, your problems and your troubles. You might say we're living in a fairy-tale.'

 Daniela Relph was in Orvieto for BBC News 24.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText:
Jeanette Winterson asserts that men are less self-conscious and therefore more free. She has obviously not witnessed the average British male on a dancefloor, or seen a teenager agonising about which trainers he can be seen wearing at school, or the rare sighting of a househusband looking uncomfortable at a coffee morning. As a househusband myself, I have found that, just to be comfortable getting through a day, one has to be 'single-minded' and unselfconscious to a degree that is beyond most males.
Paul Humber
Cambridge
fields.body:
Jeanette Winterson asserts that men are less self-conscious and therefore more free. She has obviously not witnessed the average British male on a dancefloor, or seen a teenager agonising about which trainers he can be seen wearing at school, or the rare sighting of a househusband looking uncomfortable at a coffee morning. As a househusband myself, I have found that, just to be comfortable getting through a day, one has to be 'single-minded' and unselfconscious to a degree that is beyond most males.
Paul Humber
Cambridge

Libby Brooks's description of Jeanette Winterson's birthplace as 'near Manchester' without naming the well-known town (Accrington) is yet another example of the London-based media's ignorance (possibly deliberate) of the geography of northern England.

Accrington is a town with a population of more than 30,000, so it is hardly a small hamlet unknown outside the immediate area. It is more than 20 miles from Manchester and is, in fact, closer to several large towns such as Burnley and Blackburn (whose football team I seem to remember winning the premiership title recently), than it is to what seems the only place in the north-west (Manchester) of which people living south of Watford have heard.

Presumably, we northerners can henceforth describe such places as St Albans and Luton as 'near London', rather than affording them the dignity of being called by their proper name.
Peter Atkinson
Richmond, North Yorkshire

In common with many commentators on the topic, Julie Burchill misses the fundamental point. Handing responsibility for contraception over to the fertilising half of the adult population offers men, at last, a chance to control their reproductive urges. Not a case of devolving responsibility, but empowerment of the oft-misled victims of women's irresponsibility or wilful deceit. I will be bringing up my son to understand that, when and if he becomes a father, he will be at least 50% responsible.
Sarah Worsfold
Cobham, Surrey

In sympathy with Kate Groves' affront, I shall not buy the Guardian again, either. Skegness contains the salt of the earth. Please arrange for Adrian Mole to diss Taunton instead, and to diss it bigtime (it's awful).
Sarah Sheppard
Taunton

Adrian Mole's reference about Mel in Big Brother was quite funny. I shall buy the Guardian again.
Torsten Jäger
Cardiff

Adrian Mole's comments about Romanies were most unnecessary and unkind. I will not be buying a caravan again.
Ciaran Norris
London SE21

Your remarks about everything (most Saturdays) have been quite unnecessary and unkind. I shall not be reading anything again - ever.
Gerald Boyle
London NW7

The continued printing of these pointless letters is quite unnecessary and unkind. I shall buy the Guardian again.
Lesley Warner
East Barnet, Herts

 Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com. Fax: 020-7239 9935. A postal address must be supplied. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.

fields.headline: Crossing continents
fields.standfirst: This composer has travelled from China's rice fields to the world's most prestigious concert halls. He has been accused of talking up his humble beginnings, but it is by his challenging music - soon to be heard at the Barbican - that he will be judged, writes  John O'Mahony
fields.trailText: This composer has travelled from China's rice fields to the world's most prestigious concert halls. He has been accused of talking up his humble beginnings, but it is by his challenging music - soon to be heard at the Barbican - that he will be judged, writes John O'Mahony
fields.body:
It's early Sunday morning in SoHo, and downtown New York is beginning to wake up. On the wooden benches in front of Jean Claude's, a restaurant so rough-hewn and thoroughly French that it might have been airlifted from Aix-en-Provence, bleary-eyed punters are sifting lazily through the mammoth New York Times.

Turning down Prince Street, Tan Dun, China's best-known contemporary composer, looks every inch the archetypal SoHo inhabitant. Despite just stepping off a long flight from Beijing, he looks rested and relaxed, ambling along in sandals with abrown paper bag tucked under his arm: "Not many Asian artists really love or even experience this kind of environment," he says, pointing out various "hot" galleries hidden behind the postindustrial facades of the buildings. "Of all of my generation who moved to the States, I am the only person really working and living in New York as a normal New Yorker. I don't have any distance with the local people here. The culture is my culture. This is my home..."

Yet Tan Dun's origins couldn't lie further away from this modish corner of Manhattan. Over breakfast in his minimalist white-on-white apartment, he slips a cassette into the VCR, a documentary account for Chinese TV of his recent research trip to Hunan, the rural district of China where he was born and spent his early life.

In the opening shot, framed against a lake and a traditional Chinese wooden pavilion, he announces: "The most important thing in our lives is always to keep thinking about where we came from. Only then will we know where we are going." He goes on to detail a childhood immersed in the "shamanism and magic" of a rural village, an adolescence toiling in the rice fields during Mao's Cultural Revolution and a musical background so suffused with Chinese folk values that until the age of 20 he had "never heard uttered the names of Beethoven, Mozart or Bach". The camera pans across jagged, mist-enshrouded mountains. It cuts to a lavishly costumed Taoist ceremony performed by octogenarian monks. The monks play "sheng" mouth organs, elaborate bamboo instruments that issue a dank, sweet whine, and "po" hand cymbals, which work up a delightful clatter. The finale is the "feast of 100 dishes", in which every family in the village brings along a course, and on the screen Tan, now tipsy on home-made wine, sings comically with the local schoolgirl choir.

Tan Dun's journey between these two contrasting worlds - Hunan Province and NY State, as far east and west as it is possible to travel culturally and spiritually - is perhaps one of the most extraordinary success stories in modern classical music. From what he says was a starting point of blissful ignorance of the international canon, Tan has now established himself as one of the most sought-after composers in the world. From entertaining peasants in the auditorium of the rice field, he has graduated to some of music's most prestigious venues: Lincoln Centre, Carnegie Hall, the Barbican.

The same global cultural contrasts are evident in Tan Dun's remarkably diverse body of music, which Japanese composer Toru Takemitsu has described as "violent as a burst of human blood, yet full of grace". From Hunan comes the palette of sounds and timbres, the traditional Chinese instruments and the incantatory, contorted vocal techniques, employed to powerful effect in works such as the ritual opera Nine Songs. From urban New York we get the hip-hop rhythms, industrial guitars and samplers that propelled his hi-tech, thrash-aesthetic reinterpretation of Peony Pavilion, the classic 16th-century kunju opera. Hunan again provides the philosophical underpinnings, particularly the Taoist view of art as "reverberations with the vital forces in nature". Meanwhile, from the urban wellspring of New York comes the pure spirit of downtown experimentalism so evident in Soundshape and The Pink. "What is very little heard in European or western music is the presence of sound as the voice of nature," commented John Cage, who was a huge influence on Tan's early US work. "It is clear in the music of Tan Dun that sounds are central to the nature in which we live but to which we have too long not listened. In Tan Dun's music, the east and the west come together as our one home."

Finally, from its sheer diversity, and the necessity of communicating to listeners perched on the very extremities of human civilization, comes Tan Dun's mass appeal. His Heaven Earth Mankind (Symphony 1997), commissioned for the Hong Kong handover, was made into a video for MTV. And his soundtrack for Ang Lee's Chinese-language film Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon - premiered at the 2000 Cannes Film Festival - has already shifted 200,000 copies in the east.

His place on the global music stage is confirmed by the Tan Dun Festival which opens at the Barbican on September 28. Entitled Fire Crossing Water, it will feature UK premieres of his new work Water Passion as well as the score to Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.

However, the reaction to his work has been far from universally positive. Some Chinese composers have dismissed him as "not serious". The New York Times has printed scathing reviews, many of them by the music critic Bernard Holland, who has written: "He is like the proverbial boy locked in a pastry shop, gorging indiscriminately on everything around him." Tan Dun responds: "He says that I am always trying to mix wine and beer. I think he is crazy. Eventually we will all realise one day that there never were any boundaries, except those of man. All music is created by God."

But Tan's moments of solemnity are usually immediately undermined by a mischievous streak: "He's always been a spontaneously funny guy," says director Ang Lee, who has known him since the late 1980s. "Whereas most of the other Asians in New York were generally quite shy and reserved, he could keep you entertained for hours singing some hilarious Hunan village song about how the farmer was feeling up the pigs and stroking their tits." He is also an excellent raconteur: "Often you will find yourself going for lunch with Tan Dun," says Avril MacRory of the BBC, which co-commissioned his 2000 Today: A World Symphony for the Millennium, "and returning at nine or 10 in the evening."

However, Tan Dun's playful, imaginative ability to turn any situation into an entertaining anecdote has also earned him criticism. While his stories of shamanistic culture are voraciously devoured by those who have known him only in the west, many of his more cross-cultural acquaintances mutter about "exaggeration" and "embellishment". "Tan Dun is a completely urban person," says Zhou Long, a fellow composer who has known him since his early days at the Beijing conservatory. "He's not really from the village. He is from Changsha, the capital city of Hunan province. Sometimes, when you do promotion, you make stories. There is nothing wrong with that. If you are writing some biographical notes you can do that."

There would seem to be a certain amount of evidence to support this view. One example might be the Chinese TV documentary, which was shot not in his home locality but deep in the countryside, a plane journey away. The actual village where Tan Dun spent some of his childhood has long since been swallowed up by the Changsha suburbs. Tan Dun's reaction to these assertions is both conciliatory and indignant: "Perhaps they are right. Perhaps I am an urban person. I did spend some of of my time in the city. But anyone who says that I didn't also experience the culture of the countryside, then that is an insult to me and my background. They didn't come with me to live in a small village. They didn't come with me to be re-educated in the rice fields. How can they know how I lived my life?"

Tan Dun was born in 1957 in the central Chinese district of Hunan, the only son of Tan Xiang Qiu, a military officer in the People's Liberation Army, and Fang Qun Ying, then a doctor working in a Hunanese hospital. In the traditional manner, his first name, Dun, meaning "shield", comes last, though in the west he likes to be casually referred to as Tan. While his official publisher's biography - reproduced in most articles and interviews - cites the precise birthplace as the village of Si Mao, according to his father, Tan Dun was actually born in a military hospital on the outskirts of Changsha, now a rather grimy industrial regional capital of more than a million people. As was common Chinese practice for a busy working couple, his father and mother sent young Tan Dun off to live with his grandmother in the satellite village of Si Mao Chung, about 20 miles outside the city centre.

Tan Dun recalls the environment in the village as "very barbaric, very shamanistic, very mystic, very sacred, filled with traditional art forms, poetry and music... Like all the people of Hunan, the villagers were very secretive, very strange and completely devoted to their secret beliefs." It was this mystical environment, he says, that provided him with his first musical experiences, primarily through esoteric local rituals.

"From the local people, I started learning how to play Chinese folk instruments, bamboo flutes and the 'erhu' two-string fiddle. It was very natural. Music was simply part of life, in local kunju theatre or shamanistic ritual, mostly at weddings and funerals."

When he returned to the city, at what he says was the age of nine, his musical education continued when a teacher presented him with an decrepit old violin: "It only had three strings and as I had no money to replace it, I treated it like a three-stringed fiddle." By now, however, Mao's cultural revolution was getting into full swing and soon Tan Dun's parents were sent off to be re-educated in the countryside, his father by cleaning out the animal sheds on a farm, his mother to become what was known as a "barefoot doctor" among the peasants. At the age of 17, Tan Dun followed them to be re-educated in the rice fields of the Huangjin commune, about 50 miles outside Changsha.

Ironically, Mao's policy - which, Deng Xiaoping later said, caused "grave misfortunes" for China - turned out to be a real re-education for Tan Dun, who had now fully formed in his mind the ambition of one day becoming a composer: "In the daytime I would be planting rice in the fields for 10 hours, 12 hours," he recalls. "But in the evening I would direct all farmers in a kind of rural orchestra using their cooking pots and whatever else they can use. We had no money so most of our instruments were pots, branches of trees, bits of bamboo. I began also to collect many, many folk songs."

And against every professor in the selection committee, he argued that I should be taken on the course."

They accepted me because I was a little shaman."

But in Tan Xiang Qui's account, his son returned to the city at the age of six, not nine as Tan claims, and he also paints a picture of influences rather less traditional and shamanistic.

According to Tan Xiang Qiu, far from being primitive or ignorant, his son's traditional formal musical education was quite advanced for provincial China at that time: by the age of 14 he had mastered Chinese notation and a little later travelled to Beijing to meet the com poser Hua Lu Bin, expressly for the purpose of studying western music. It is difficult to believe that this quest for western musical knowledge might not have included at least some mention of Mozart or Bach.

As for the infamous audition at the Beijing conservatory, the examining professor, Li Xian, who would go on to become Tan Dun's mentor, recalls none of the events or details mentioned in the anecdote; not the questions about Beethoven or Bach, nor the three-stringed violin, nor the one- to three-hour session of traditional improvisation: "Two hours? No, that would have been impossible," he says stiffly. "Each student was allocated a specific amount of time for the tests. The maximum would have been about 20 minutes."

While Tan Dun actually gave a rather lacklustre performance at a very straightforward audition, it was his sparkling piano trio, the evocatively entitled I Dreamt of Chairman Mao, based on traditional Hunanese folk music, that earned him his place at the conservatory.

So, in September 1978, he packed his belongings - "a bamboo pole over my shoulder," he says, "one side wrapped up with my clothes, on the other side my scores" - and left Changsha to join the composers' class. After a visit in 1979 to China by a Japanese troupe who used traditional Japanese instruments to make contemporary music, Tan Dun began applying the same principle to Chinese instruments and music. One of the fruits of this approach was his first symphony Li Sao, inspired by a fourth century BC melancholic poem. The piece, whose title translates as On Encountering Sorrow, featured traditional instruments and caused some controversy. His next major work, the string quartet Feng Ya Song, came second in Dresden's Weber Prize, making Tan Dun the first Chinese com poser to win an international prize since 1949. The Dresden victory had an immediate effect on Tan's career, propelling him to the forefront of the "new wave" of Chinese composers, but his music was denounced by the state in its renewed campaign against "spiritual pollution".

Once the political storm had passed, Tan Dun made a request to continue his studies at Columbia, and permission was granted. So, in 1986, he took a flight from Beijing to New York and touched down in what would become his adopted homeland. "I took the subway from the airport to Manhattan," he recalls, "and I immediately understood that it wasn't at all the place I had imagined. I saw many people in the subway car, and they were all different colours. I asked myself, 'What country is this?' "

However, Tan soon tired of Columbia University. "I immediately wanted to get away from the kind of depressing, bitter, atonal, selfish and superintellectual post-post-whatever music I was being forced to write there." Columbia soon reciprocally tired of him, and the professors there display a simmering animosity towards him that continues to this day: "He was actually a very nice guy. He was a very good raconteur and I remember he was telling me stories from China that were perfectly human and very entertaining," says Columbia lecturer Mario Davidovsky. "But he was at that point enormously involved in promoting himself and his career. And he was much more interested in that than anything that might have been going on at the university."

As Columbia was only paying his fees, he had to earn money to live. "I worked in restaurants and played my fiddle on the streets of Greenwich Village. That was my biggest classroom and in some way it was very close to my village in China, with its ritual music and its religion."

At the first opportunity, he moved from the university dormitories into the basement of a brownstone in Chinatown, began to attend cutting-edge performance works and gradually became part of an artistic Greenwich Village set that included Steve Reich, Philip Glass and Meredith Monk. It was also about this time that Tan Dun first met John Cage and his music became, as he puts it, "Cagealised": "Though I had been using incidental noises and found instruments since I was living in the village, of course I never thought of it as avant garde. But he was doing what I had done in the countryside 20 years previously."

When Tan Dun decided that he wanted to launch himself into this world, he turned to his landlady, Mary Scherbatskoy, who had previously been a producer of dance. "He just asked me casually one day if I'd like to produce an opera. And he showed me the score, and it was quite astonishing. But of course, being Chinese he wanted a cast of thousands. The piece, Nine Songs, also based on Chinese poetry, used traditional ceramic Chinese instruments and opened with an extended sample of Tan Dun's shamanistic wailing. It was a sensation when performed at the Pace Downtown Theatre in May 1989.

Tan Dun went on to produce a number of experimental performance-based and dance pieces: Soundshape in 1990 at the Guggenheim Museum, which included an entire village orchestra cast in ceramic, and The Pink in 1993, which included a cast of naked dancers playing instruments constructed entirely out of paper or cardboard. It was at the last of these, in which Tan Dun also performed as the naked conductor, that he first met his future wife, Jane Huang, then editor of a New York-based Chinese fashion magazine: "After the show we all went to a bar . . . Immediately, he began paying me a lot of attention - I had a stomach upset and he went to the trouble of trying to get the waitress to get me some milk. Then suddenly, he said to me, 'Would you like to come to Tibet with me?' I didn't know what to say, I was absolutely shocked. I had completely misheard the question and thought he said to me, 'Would you like to come to bed with me?' But in fact we did end up going to Tibet very soon afterwards. We wanted to get married in the mountains. It was a very quick romance." Because of laws barring overseas Chinese from marrying in China, they had to settle for a tower-block register office in Hong Kong. They now have an two-year-old son, Ian.

By this time, Tan Dun's reputation was beginning to cross over into the mainstream. An association with the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra was the catalyst for the Orchestral Theatre series, four instalments of experimental gimmickry (part II saw the audience join in with trance-like chanting) multimedia (part III was set against a newsreel ranging from the Beatles to Mao's revolution) and a full orchestral score. The Edinburgh Festival commissioned Tan Dun's phenomenal Marco Polo, which featured a "postmodern" libretto by New York Times music critic Paul Griffith in which Marco and Polo appear as two characters/singers representing the yin/yang, east/west boundaries of modern culture.

"I don't really have any great interest in the east and the west as a dialogue," Tan Dun says. "What I am interested in is trying to find a single language and distinctive style that is made up of many, many cultures and that can reach from many different diverse cultures." It is ironic that, in pursuit of this goal, he feels he needs to play up the primitive aspects of his background to such a degree, though in fact, the emphasis of his biographical details probably says more about the need for modern composers to distinguish themselves as much in their press packs as in their work.

However, Tan Dun will ultimately be judged not on his life story but on his music, and in this area he still has a great deal to offer: "One of the things I like about pop music is its accessibility and power. There, music just becomes the art of dancing together, performing together. And I think that if you can find that same international communicable quality, and somehow combine it with a very distinct personality and a very local and a very, very inward point of view, then you can smash the world."

Life at a glance

Born: August 8 1957, Changsha, Hunan, China.

Education: Beijing conservatory, 1978-85; Columbia University, 1986-89.

Married: Jane Huang, 1994 (one son, Ian, aged two years).

Operas: Nine Songs, 1989; Marco Polo, 1993-4; Peony Pavilion, 1998; Tea Opera, to be premiered in 2001.

Orchestral works: Li Sao, 1979; Feng Ya Song, 1983; On Taoism, 1985; Orchestral Theatre I-IV, 1990-1999; Death and Fire: Dialogue with Paul Klee,1992; Ghost Opera (with Kronos quartet), 1995; Heaven Earth Mankind (Symphony 1997), 1997; 2000 Today: A World Symphony for the New Millennium, 1999; Water Passion after St Matthew, 2000.

Experimental performance work: Soundshape, 1990; Silent Earth, 1991; Jo-Ha-Kyu, 1992; The Pink, 1993.

Awards: Weber Prize, second place, 1983; Suntory Prize, 1992; Grawemeyer Award, 1998.

On the wooden benches in front of Jean Claude's, a restaurant so rough-hewn and thoroughly French that it might have been airlifted from Aix-en-Provence, bleary-eyed punters are sifting lazily through the mammoth New York Times. Turning down Prince Street, Tan Dun, China's best-known contemporary composer, looks every inch the archetypal SoHo inhabitant. Despite just stepping off a long flight from Beijing, he looks rested and relaxed, ambling along in sandals with abrown paper bag tucked under his arm: "Not many Asian artists really love or even experience this kind of environment," he says, pointing out various "hot" galleries hidden behind the postindustrial facades of the buildings. "Of all of my generation who moved to the States, I am the only person really working and living in New York as a normal New Yorker. I don't have any distance with the local people here. The culture is my culture. This is my home..." Yet Tan Dun's origins couldn't lie further away from this modish corner of Manhattan. Over breakfast in his minimalist white-on-white apartment, he slips a cassette into the VCR, a documentary account for Chinese TV of his recent research trip to Hunan, the rural district of China where he was born and spent his early life. In the opening shot, framed against a lake and a traditional Chinese wooden pavilion, he announces: "The most important thing in our lives is always to keep thinking about where we came from. Only then will we know where we are going." He goes on to detail a childhood immersed in the "shamanism and magic" of a rural village, an adolescence toiling in the rice fields during Mao's Cultural Revolution and a musical background so suffused with Chinese folk values that until the age of 20 he had "never heard uttered the names of Beethoven, Mozart or Bach". The camera pans across jagged, mist-enshrouded mountains. It cuts to a lavishly costumed Taoist ceremony performed by octogenarian monks. The monks play "sheng" mouth organs, elaborate bamboo instruments that issue a dank, sweet whine, and "po" hand cymbals, which work up a delightful clatter. The finale is the "feast of 100 dishes", in which every family in the village brings along a course, and on the screen Tan, now tipsy on home-made wine, sings comically with the local schoolgirl choir. Tan Dun's journey between these two contrasting worlds - Hunan Province and NY State, as far east and west as it is possible to travel culturally and spiritually - is perhaps one of the most extraordinary success stories in modern classical music. From what he says was a starting point of blissful ignorance of the international canon, Tan has now established himself as one of the most sought-after composers in the world. From entertaining peasants in the auditorium of the rice field, he has graduated to some of music's most prestigious venues: Lincoln Centre, Carnegie Hall, the Barbican. The same global cultural contrasts are evident in Tan Dun's remarkably diverse body of music, which Japanese composer Toru Takemitsu has described as "violent as a burst of human blood, yet full of grace". From Hunan comes the palette of sounds and timbres, the traditional Chinese instruments and the incantatory, contorted vocal techniques, employed to powerful effect in works such as the ritual opera Nine Songs. From urban New York we get the hip-hop rhythms, industrial guitars and samplers that propelled his hi-tech, thrash-aesthetic reinterpretation of Peony Pavilion, the classic 16th-century kunju opera. Hunan again provides the philosophical underpinnings, particularly the Taoist view of art as "reverberations with the vital forces in nature". Meanwhile, from the urban wellspring of New York comes the pure spirit of downtown experimentalism so evident in Soundshape and The Pink. "What is very little heard in European or western music is the presence of sound as the voice of nature," commented John Cage, who was a huge influence on Tan's early US work. "It is clear in the music of Tan Dun that sounds are central to the nature in which we live but to which we have too long not listened. In Tan Dun's music, the east and the west come together as our one home." Finally, from its sheer diversity, and the necessity of communicating to listeners perched on the very extremities of human civilization, comes Tan Dun's mass appeal. His Heaven Earth Mankind (Symphony 1997), commissioned for the Hong Kong handover, was made into a video for MTV. And his soundtrack for Ang Lee's Chinese-language film Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon - premiered at the 2000 Cannes Film Festival - has already shifted 200,000 copies in the east. His place on the global music stage is confirmed by the Tan Dun Festival which opens at the Barbican on September 28. Entitled Fire Crossing Water, it will feature UK premieres of his new work Water Passion as well as the score to Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. However, the reaction to his work has been far from universally positive. Some Chinese composers have dismissed him as "not serious". All music is created by God." But Tan's moments of solemnity are usually immediately undermined by a mischievous streak: "He's always been a spontaneously funny guy," says director Ang Lee, who has known him since the late 1980s. "Whereas most of the other Asians in New York were generally quite shy and reserved, he could keep you entertained for hours singing some hilarious Hunan village song about how the farmer was feeling up the pigs and stroking their tits." webTitle: The case for the defence, football's lost art

fields.headline: The case for the defence, football's lost art
fields.standfirst: There is more to winning a game than simply scoring goals. Stopping them helps, too
fields.trailText: There is more to winning a game than simply scoring goals. Stopping them helps, too.
fields.body:
These days nobody wisely leaves a football match before the final whistle. That would be rather like walking out on Psycho without discovering what was in the fruit cellar.

Increasingly, it would seem, the game is saving its most dramatic moments until last. Already this season the Premiership has seen eight instances of 2-0 or 3-0 leads being lost, and in half of these matches the survivors have not found the net until the last 20 minutes or so.

The latest examples occurred on Wednesday night, when Derby County found themselves 3-0 down at home to Middlesbrough with 22 minutes remaining but still forced a draw, while Arsenal scored twice in the last 14 minutes at Stamford Bridge to deny Chelsea the victory which a 2-0 lead had suggested would be theirs.

The previous evening Tottenham, losing 2-0 to Everton just before half-time, had won 3-2. A fortnight ago Southampton held Liverpool to 3-3 at the Dell after Gérard Houllier's team had led 3-0 with just over a quarter-of-an-hour remaining and on the same afternoon, at Upton Park, West Ham wiped out Manchester United's 2-0 advantage with goals in the 86th and 89th minutes.

When even the Premiership champions cannot hold a two-goal lead for the last few minutes it is clear that what was once an occasional oddity has become a trend. All right, Chelsea had suffered much the same against Arsenal last October, when a hat-trick from Nwankwo Kanu overturned their 2-0 lead in the last 15 minutes, but until recently teams with any sort of nous usually held what they had.

Now it appears that the knack of winning matches, which was never just about scoring more goals, is becoming a forgotten art. It is as if the game itself is still in a state of shock following Manchester United's remarkable comeback in the 1999 European Cup final in Barcelona when Bayern Munich's 1-0 lead was overturned during three minutes of stoppage time.

Whatever happened to the ability of winning sides to keep possession, slow the game down and employ all manner of artifice to consume time? The leading teams of the 70s and 80s - Leeds United, Liverpool and Everton, for example - were masters of the practice of chloroforming matches once they had established a firm grip on them.

Part of the reason why this happens less often is that the laws of the game have either been changed or re-interpreted to make it harder for teams to waste a few seconds here and there. Liverpool regularly used Ray Clemence to instigate attacks but the pass back to the goalkeeper was also a useful delaying tactic.

Now a goalkeeper no longer has this luxury unless a team-mate heads or chests the ball to him. The tempo of matches has speeded up considerably since this law was introduced and, while the consequences have been mixed, the loss of the back-pass as a wholly reliable outlet for a team under pressure is part of the reason for the increase in exciting finishes.

So is the more liberal application of the offside law. Everton in their championship-winning seasons were even sharper than Liverpool in being able to step up at the right second to get an opponent flagged down. Tedious though this might have been to the spectacle, it was an organisational skill demanding good timing and concentration on the part of the defenders.

Now, with the question of whether or not an attacker is interfering with play reduced to a lottery, no defence can afford to assume that a man in an offside position will in fact be given offside. As a result defenders find themselves covering more ground and making tired errors towards the end of a game.

Looking back, the football of 30 years ago was defenders' utopia. It is hard to believe now that there was a period when it was assumed that an attacker through on goal could be brought down from behind, a yard outside the penalty area, with the offender receiving no more punishment than a free-kick because "there was nothing else he could have done".

Even the minor time-wasting habits, such as kicking the ball out of play or arguing at free-kicks, are becoming less available. No sooner has a ball been whacked into the crowd than another is immediately to hand. And, slowly but surely, referees are applying the new rule which advances a free-kick 10 yards if there is dissent.

Anything which produces a greater likelihood of goals being scored and makes it harder for teams to kill matches off is to be applauded. But too many easy goals cheapen the game and what is needed now is a new breed of defenders capable of taking all the recent changes to their trade on board and still making it difficult for opposing forwards to find a way through.

George Graham, while welcoming his Tottenham team's recovery to beat Everton this week, was right to point out that overall the present defending in the Premiership is poor. Outstanding sides are invariably based on outstanding defences - witness the present French team - but, when Chelsea cannot hold a lead even with Marcel Desailly and Frank Leboeuf in their back four there is clearly some way to go.

In the meantime stout females with strong vocal chords have never had it so good.

webTitle: Just the ticket as Reds try glasnost

fields.headline: Just the ticket as Reds try glasnost
fields.standfirst: Not all of the muck flung Manchester United's way is sticking these days, it seems
fields.trailText: Not all of the muck flung Manchester United's way is sticking these days, it seems. This time the cheque really was in the post.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson's feud with the BBC (he is, at present, not on speaking terms with either Match of the Day or Five Live) appeared to have taken a turn for the worse when the Old Trafford season ticket ordered by a senior man at the corporation's Manchester operation failed to materialise.

Was it merely paranoia or was the Beeb's representative to conclude that Ferguson's legendary powers of control extended to the ticket office and that a statement was being made?

Sadly for fans of conspiracy everywhere, it was the cock-up theory that held sway. The Beeb's man was escorted to his seat after flashing his passport at the turnstile and his ticket finally arrived a month into the season after what turned out to be an administrative oversight.

And on the subject of relationships between fans and the world's richest club, the supporters' group, Shareholders United, has been in touch in response to a piece here a fortnight ago about the growing glasnost at Old Trafford.

Two years ago SU was formed as a group to fight the Manchester United board's decision to sell the club to BSkyB. Now the new chief executive Peter Kenyon has not only turned up at one of the group's meetings but has agreed to pay for a postal ballot for the SU representative on his new fans' forum.

Whatever next: elected members of the board?

webTitle: Blazers ought to keep their shirts on

fields.headline: Blazers ought to keep their shirts on
fields.standfirst: You know all that stuff about refereeing and common sense...
fields.trailText: You know all that stuff about refereeing and common sense...
fields.body:
It is encouraging to see the Football Association so fearlessly living up to its new mission statement: "To use the power of football to build a better future."

This week the referee Steve Lodge was reprimanded by the fine blazers of Lancaster Gate for failing to punish the Arsenal players Patrick Vieira and Silvinho with yellow cards during their club's game with Charlton this season.

And what was the players' crime? Had Vieira again been trying out the face wash he first offered to Neil Ruddock last year? Was Silvinho learning a bit too much about the dark arts of marking at corners from his grizzled defensive colleagues?

No. The pair had removed their shirts in celebration of a goal. Which is now deemed such an appalling solipsism that the statutory punishment is the brandishing of the yellow. It is lucky Vieira did not take off his singlet as well as his shirt. Otherwise, presumably, he would have been liable to a red one.

As silly regulations go, this one is right up there in the golf class (remember Padraig Harrington being disqualified after winning a tournament at the Belfry because he did not sign his card?)

Quite why footballers feel the urge to strip off in celebration is another issue but the habit hardly seems one which requires urgent attention. When Ryan Giggs famously peeled off his top in an FA Cup semi-final it seemed to do little harm apart from revealing such a luxurious growth of chest hair it suggests he has a sponsorship deal with Monsanto.

But the FA feels otherwise. The cynic might infer that in a month when the European Commission has stated its keenness to change the transfer system and the 14 most influential clubs in Europe have established their own lobbying organisation complete with a chief executive sitting in an office in Brussels, the FA has been moved to act to prove that not all of its powers in the game have ebbed away.

In which case, unlike the administrators, at least the players still have shirts to remove.

webTitle: Confident Salisbury edges Surrey towards the championship title

fields.headline: Confident Salisbury edges Surrey towards the championship title
fields.standfirst:
Surrey 453-4 dec
Durham 241 & 10-0
fields.trailText:
Surrey 453-4 dec
Durham 241 & 10-0
fields.body:
The Oval was shrouded in gloom all day, the ground more soulless than ever, and the Palace of Westminster tried in vain to hold its own with the surrounding philistine office blocks. John Major's pleas for aesthetic improvements took on an impassioned urgency.

But on this unlit stage Surrey, with the occasional eye on progress at Old Trafford, seemed to edge tantalisingly nearer the championship title.

They would like it settled before next week's meeting with Lancashire, a match that could be either theatrically tense or grimly anti-climactic.

Much will depend today on the weather and the sustained tricks of Ian Salisbury and Saqlain Mushtaq. In yesterday's limited play they bowled unchanged, with varying dexterity, some frustration and the occasional loose ball, which Durham waited to dispatch with misplaced optimism.

Salisbury, back in favour, ended with seven wickets and all the signs that he could win the game - and clarify any mathematical doubts about the championship - by today.

He was on song, reminding one of former leg spinners, when times were a little more leisurely and pedestrians walked less in fear - especially at short leg and silly point. He has so clearly rediscovered confidence and found added variety.

Play did not start until mid-afternoon and, with five lights on, Surrey immediately relied on their spinners. Six Durham wickets had already gone; those who remained defended stubbornly, as if determined to delay any Surrey celebrations.

The left-hander Andrew Pratt went first, sharply stumped. He had hung around diligently and so had Nicky Phillips until taken at short leg off Mushtaq. Durham were all out for 241, a deficit of 212 and a daunting prospect for a team without a regular captain and already relegated.

Following on, they faced a nominal five overs before rain ended play. Saqlain suffered the indignity of a late belted boundary to mid-wicket from Steve Harmison but loose deliveries were rare. His close fielders had, as ever, negligible need for evasive action.

fields.headline: England players could be charged
fields.standfirst: English cricket's bubble may be burst as the match-fixing investigations continue apace in India
fields.trailText: English cricket's bubble may be burst as the match-fixing investigations continue apace in India.
fields.body:
English cricket's fear that it is about to become embroiled in the match-fixing scandal intensified yesterday after indications from Indian police that they will disclose corruption charges against two England players by the end of the month.

India's Central Bureau of Investigation will expose the involvement of two England players when they submit their interim report into match-fixing, according to a highly-placed official in the federal agency.

"The report is to be submitted by September end and it will contain an exhaustive picture of corruption in the game," said the official, who hinted that several Pakistan and Indian players would also be implicated.

With the joyful reaction to England's Test series victory against the West Indies barely subsided, and the winter tours to Pakistan and Sri Lanka being viewed with confidence, the authorities now privately fear that impending allegations of English misconduct could have devastating consequences on team morale.

The Indian CBI probe has taken place alongside the investigation launched by Delhi police, whose corruption charges against the disgraced South African captain Hansie Cronje five months ago finally forced cricket to address the bookmaking and bribery scams that were threatening to bring the game to its knees.

Indian investigators held discussions in London recently with Scotland Yard officers investigating the information provided by the former England all-rounder, Chris Lewis.

Lewis claimed he had been approached by Ashim Kheterpal, an Indian sports promoter, last summer, and pressed to act as a middle-man in fixing England's Test series against New Zealand. Lewis told the England and Wales Cricket Board, and the police, that Kheterpal had given him the names of three England players involved in match-fixing.

The new revelations came a day after CBI detectives summoned India's national coach, Kapil Dev, for questioning at its New Delhi headquarters and sent a two-member squad to Bombay for an "informal chat" with star Indian batsman Sachin Tendulkar.

Kapil Dev was questioned after his former team-mate, Manoj Prabhakar, accused him of offering a £40,000 bribe to underperform against Pakistan in 1994.

The Indian cricket board have dropped Mohammad Azharuddin, their former captain, Ajay Jadeja and Nikhil Chopra from a preliminary squad of 23 for the ICC Trophy in Kenya in October. Their homes and banks were raided by detectives two months ago. Cronje has also accused Azharuddin of introducing him to a bookie during one of his trips to South Africa.

The omission of the trio was expected after sports minister Sukhdev Dhindsa urged that players under investigation should be dropped till they are proved innocent.

webTitle: Northants delayed in tying up the title

fields.headline: Northants delayed in tying up the title
fields.trailText: It may be assumed with some confidence that Northamptonshire will be crowned the inaugural Second Division champions. Nevertheless, just as Imelda Marcos may one day take up walking in bare feet, Matthew Hayden's men could yet lose to Essex today.
fields.body:
It may be assumed with some confidence that Northamptonshire will be crowned the inaugural Second Division champions. Nevertheless, just as Imelda Marcos may one day take up walking in bare feet, Matthew Hayden's men could yet lose to Essex today.

Northants, who added 66 in the 70 minutes' play possible at Wantage Road yesterday to lead by 164 with one first-innings wicket intact, learned that a draw would be sufficient to secure the title when Glamorgan went down by seven wickets. Essex remain the only side that can overhaul them.

Paul Franks took six wickets in Glamorgan's second innings to help Nottinghamshire to a nervy first win at Trent Bridge for 15 months. Chasing 63 for victory after Glamorgan's batting folded once again, Steve Watkin reduced the hosts to 28 for three before they wrapped it up to move up to third.

Ian Harvey claimed match figures of 10 for 32 as Gloucestershire strengthened their late effort to add promotion to the three trophies already won by demolishing Sussex by an innings and 18 runs with two days to spare at Hove.

Sussex, 89 runs behind on first innings, were routed for 71 in 25 overs. Harvey took four for 13 with his brisk medium pace after hitting a fluent 60 as Gloucestershire, resuming on 74 for two, were bowled out for 227.

In the First Division Hampshire's spinners Shane Warne and Shaun Udal destroyed Derbyshire's batting at Southampton with six wickets between them.

In reply to Hampshire's 522, Derbyshire were 346 for four and well placed to avoid the follow-on. But, once Rob Bailey (90) had gone, Derbyshire lost their last six wickets for six runs in 18 balls. Second time round they closed on 32 for two, still 138 behind.

A third-wicket stand of 117 between Rahul Dravid and Ed Smith kept Kent in contention against Yorkshire at Canterbury but at 194 for four they are still 207 adrift. Dravid looked on course for his second championship hundred of the season until, on 72, he was lbw to England's Matthew Hoggard.

webTitle: Denness has Lancashire in a sweat

fields.headline: Denness has Lancashire in a sweat
fields.standfirst:
Somerset 132
Lancashire 142-3
fields.trailText:
Somerset 132
Lancashire 142-3
fields.body:
If Lancashire retained any serious designs upon stealing a title long assumed to be in Surrey's grasp, then the sight of Mike Denness stalking the corridors here yesterday was enough to make them consider immediate surrender.

When the ECB's pitch liaison officers are in town, with the remit to dock points for unacceptable surfaces, pity the county that finds Denness rapping on the door. Behind that mild-mannered exterior, and velvety Scottish lilt, lurks a veritable rottweiler.

Derbyshire, Middlesex and Yorkshire have been penalised this season, although Middlesex subsequently and properly won their appeal, and in each case Denness has been the inspector involved. And this is the man the Australians once claimed to be a soft touch.

Lancashire will discover today whether a responsive surface, on which they needed less than 50 overs to bundle out Somerset, will meet with official disapproval. Denness was embarking last night on interviews with the groundsman Peter Marron, plus both umpires and captains.

The pitch, although far from dangerous, bounced unevenly for the seamers before lunch, and it will be no surprise, especially with the season at such a crucial stage, if Denness summons a second member of the pitches advisory committee for further deliberations.

Lancashire and Surrey meet in the final round of matches here next month, and Surrey, confident of their second successive championship, began the penultimate fixtures with a 19-point advantage.

Statistically this means Lancashire must at least match Surrey's points tally to keep the title race alive; realistically, they need to beat Somerset over the next two days while rain again frustrates Surrey at the Oval. An eight-point deduction would hand Surrey the title if Surrey win; a 20-point fine for an unfit pitch would give them the title whether they win or not.

Somerset's top order was demolished by Mike Smethurst. Peter Bowler became his 50th first-class wicket of the season, but the most important was that of Somerset's captain, Jamie Cox, whose 53 included nine boundaries before being caught at short leg. Greg Chapple made light work of the tail.

For Lancashire to achieve 400 on this pitch for maximum batting points would require another epic from Michael Atherton. He was 54 not out at the close, but Lan cashire had lost three batsmen to the left-arm spin of Ian Blackwell, and John Crawley has appendicitis.

Dermot Reeve, Somerset's outgoing coach, caused a surprise last month by advocating Blackwell for England. Yesterday he bowled Mark Chilton with his first ball, caused Saurav Ganguly to mishit to midwicket and deceived Neil Fairbrother in the flight.

Last year, at Derbyshire, Blackwell ran in off two paces in the manner of Shane Warne. Now he has a longer run, but has dyed his hair Warne-blond and bowls in sunnies. Let us hope he skips the phase involving mobile phone messages.

Lancashire will discover today whether a responsive surface, on which they needed less than 50 overs to bundle out Somerset, will meet with official disapproval. Denness was embarking last night on interviews with the groundsman Peter Marron, plus both umpires and captains. The pitch, although far from dangerous, bounced unevenly for the seamers before lunch, and it will be no surprise, especially with the season at such a crucial stage, if Denness summons a second member of the pitches advisory committee for further deliberations. Lancashire and Surrey meet in the final round of matches here next month, and Surrey, confident of their second successive championship, began the penultimate fixtures with a 19-point advantage. Statistically this means Lancashire must at least match Surrey's points tally to keep the title race alive; realistically, they need to beat Somerset over the next two days while rain again frustrates Surrey at the Oval. An eight-point deduction would hand Surrey the title if Surrey win; a 20-point fine for an unfit pitch would give them the title whether they win or not. Somerset's top order was demolished by Mike Smethurst. Peter Bowler became his 50th first-class wicket of the season, but the most important was that of Somerset's captain, Jamie Cox, whose 53 included nine boundaries before being caught at short leg. Greg Chapple made light work of the tail. For Lancashire to achieve 400 on this pitch for maximum batting points would require another epic from Michael Atherton. He was 54 not out at the close, but Lan cashire had lost three batsmen to the left-arm spin of Ian Blackwell, and John Crawley has appendicitis. Dermot Reeve, Somerset's outgoing coach, caused a surprise last month by advocating Blackwell for England. Yesterday he bowled Mark Chilton with his first ball, caused Saurav Ganguly to mishit to midwicket and deceived Neil Fairbrother in the flight. Last year, at Derbyshire, Blackwell ran in off two paces in the manner of Shane Warne. Now he has a longer run, but has dyed his hair Warne-blond and bowls in sunnies. Let us hope he skips the phase involving mobile phone messages.

webTitle: England turn for the worse in Pakistan

fields.headline: England turn for the worse in Pakistan
fields.standfirst: Mike Selvey talks to John Edrich, ex- of Surrey and England, and considers England's spin dillemma
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey talks to John Edrich, ex- of Surrey and England, and considers England's spin dillemma
fields.body:
John Edrich turned up in the back of the Oval press box last week. He is 63 now but looks 20 years younger, so that you could imagine him still strapping on the pads and pottering out to take on the best. He has leukaemia, too,though you would not suspect that either, so brimful of health did he look. He says he feels fine.

So we chattered away for a while, about England and Surrey and the year he suddenly decided to hit sixes (49, he thinks) because there was a cash prize on offer. Then, inevitably for us, we got round to West Indies, Old Trafford and 1976. For me this represented the start of a brief Test career; for him it was the end of a long and distinguished one that began, with nice symmetry, 13 years previously on the same ground against the same opponents.

For 80 minutes on the evening of the third day of his final game he and Brian Close, protected by neither helmets nor umpires, were subjected to as cynical a barrage of brutal short-pitched bowling from Andy Roberts, Michael Holding and Wayne Daniel as can have been delivered in the history of the game, and survived battered, bruised but in good spirits.

Anyway, for all the trauma, no chances were offered until, with the close in sight and immediately after a particularly nasty over from Holding had left Close with broken ribs and the bowler a belated warning for intimidation, Clive Lloyd brought on Albert Padmore to bowl to Edrich.

Albert who? Padmore was an off-spinner from Barbados and his first ball was turned to the onside by Edrich, who was sitting back contemplating the next delivery when he realised that Close, who had faced Holding for five successive overs at the other end, had sneaked up on him, noise masked by his Green Flash plimsolls. After all the flak Edrich was all but run out because Close wanted to get at the off-spinner.

But what, Edrich and I pondered the other day, was Padmore doing playing. Only three fast bowlers? Well, they had yet to learn the value of four. It did not take long, however: for the last two Tests that summer the three were augmented by Vanburn Holder, and the die was cast. Only 12 spinners have played for West Indies since, although Carl Hooper, the most successful, was a batsman, and Roger Harper, an allrounder and the next best, mostly supported four seamers.

And on the occasion when a spinner actually replaced one of the fast-bowling giants it has rankled. "Why play a spinner for the sake of it if a paceman can do the job better?" says Holding, who conceded that the appearance of Mahendra Nagamootoo at the Oval was precisely because for the first time in 25 years the back-up pacemen were not up to it.

It serves to highlight a dilemma that will confront England in the coming winter when they tour Pakistan and Sri Lanka. Already the war of words is starting with Wasim Akram saying England have no chance because they do not know the conditions and cannot play spin. Saqlain Mushtaq will destroy them, he says, and the Pakistan board should prepare pitches to accommodate him.

England, aware that this might be a possibility, have searched desperately for a couple of spinners to add to their touring party and have come up with Ashley Giles and Ian Salisbury, although the prospect of facing either is not about to send Saeed Anwar and Inzamam-ul-Haq into a cold sweat.

Whenever England have played a spinner, be it Phil Tufnell, Robert Croft (no more letters, please, the waste bin is overflowing), Giles, Salisbury or Chris Schofield, the overwhelming feeling after the match has been that a good seamer could have done the job as well if not better.

So the question will need to be addressed, even if the pitches produced in Pakistan are made for the benefit of Saqlain - and it is by no means certain they would go over the top in any case, given Saqlain's skill on good pitches plus the presence of Wasim, Waqar Younis, Shoaib Akhtar and Abdur Razzaq - is it in England's interest to break up either the bowling attack or the balance of the side that has proved so successful this season?

So, which bowler would you omit to make way for Giles or Salisbury? Darren Gough? Andy Caddick? Dominic Cork then? Well, not Craig White, whose reverse swing could make him a major factor.

To my mind, even now, the conditions in Lahore, Faisalabad and Karachi would have to be alien in the extreme even to contemplate fragmenting the current unit.

So get Michael Vaughan's off spin up to speed, and that of Graeme Hick as well, and let's have no more nonsense about the rest until our own Shane Warne, Muttiah Muralitharan or Saqlain emerges.

webTitle: Sorry Oxford find ground for optimism

fields.headline: Sorry Oxford find ground for optimism
fields.standfirst: Wycombe Wanderers 3 - 1 Oxford United
fields.trailText: Wycombe Wanderers 3 - 1 Oxford United
fields.body:
The victory that Oxford United were granted earlier in the day inside a council chamber will have a long-term benefit that will survive long after the memory of last night's three points, vigorously contested by these Second Division neighbours, has faded.

By agreeing to the impoverished club's request for planning permission to build a leisure complex, Oxford city council effectively unlocked the chains that have bound their new 15,000 capacity stadium since December, 1996.

That site, at Minchery Farm on the outskirts of the city, has stood as a monument to the crippling poverty of football's lower orders for near on four years. When the builders were laid off they had been told to take an extended Christmas break.

Now with the go-ahead to construct a cinema complex, night club and bingo hall on land adjacent to the farm, the Oxford chairman Firoz Kassam can give new life to the steel skeleton and provide the means for investment in a team that remains near the foot of the division after last night's fifth defeat in six games.

Any other decision by the grey suits and Kassam had vowed to walk away. Now, after years of obstruction and delay, he could celebrate. "I can't work miracles so we will not be able to begin work on Monday but we should restart in a matter of days," he said.

"I am trying to do my bit off the pitch and now the players need to concentrate on their job on it. It will be nice to see some improved results."

If Oxford harboured genuine hopes of adding to that success with victory here they survived only the opening three minutes. After that Wycombe scored and from then until half-time proceeded to demonstrate that the gulf between these sides is indeed as wide as the league table suggests.

Steve Brown's corner was met by a powerful header from Jamie Bates and Andy Baird poked the ball home from close in. The set-piece had followed a smart incision from Maurice Harkin and throughout a torrid first half Oxford struggled to keep the sprightly midfielder at arm's length.

Michael Simpson was also full of imagination, Chris Vinnicombe needed no prompting to join the attacking flow from left-back and the visitors were required to resist a stream of crosses and any number of accurate passing combinations.

Richard Knight was out bravely at the feet of Germaine McSporran and from Simpson's free-kick Mark Rogers won a header amid a clutch of defenders but seemed to lose his bearings and his effort sailed over the top.

McSporran scored a second late on and after Peter Fear had reduced the arrears Brown scored with a twice-taken penalty. It puts Wycombe into second place, their highest ever standing in the Football League.

webTitle: Ipswich out to trade on the Titus tackle

fields.headline: Ipswich out to trade on the Titus tackle
fields.standfirst: Ipswich's teenage central defender has been quick to make his Premiership mark, writes Roy Collins
fields.trailText: Ipswich's teenage central defender has been quick to make his Premiership mark, writes Roy Collins.
fields.body:
Such is the immediacy of sporting fame these days that Ipswich fans could have been excused for queuing to see the movie Titus in the belief that they would be watching the life story of their teenage centre-half Titus Bramble, who has been a Premiership player for all of three weeks.

The racing tipster Henry Rix, a besotted Ipswich fan, has already named a horse after him, although the four-legged Bramble, a selling plater, is less of a thoroughbred performer than the real thing.

Bramble, astonishingly, had been a Premiership player for less than 80 hours when Howard Wilkinson called him into the England Under-21 squad, playing him for the opening 45 minutes of the 6-1 win over Georgia.

If he continues to improve at that rate, the England captain Tony Adams may soon - assuming such a physical manoeuvre is possible given his dodgy back - be looking over his shoulder at Bramble, who says: "It's always been my dream to play for England but I'm still a baby. I couldn't believe it when a journalist called me on my mobile to tell me about the Under-21s. I just kept saying: 'You're lying to me, you're lying to me.' I still have to pinch myself to believe things have happened so quickly."

One can understand the 19-year-old's disbelief, seeing that he was injured for most of last season and was taking a few gently recuperative steps in the reserves as Ipswich's season came to its dramatic climax in the First Division play-offs. Prior to that he had played two full games for the club in the 1998-99 season.

There is a moral for every young player, however, in the story of Bramble's summer. While some of the cream of young England talent were earning unsavoury headlines over assorted sex antics abroad, Bramble returned from Ayia Napa to begin training two weeks early, determined to shed his excess holiday pounds and achieve maximum fitness.

In truth he had believed it would be October or November before his manager George Burley would feel ready to trust him with a first-team shirt. But Bramble was so impressive in pre-season games that he found himself standing nervously in the tunnel at Tottenham on the opening day, with his hero Sol Campbell across the corridor from him.

"I always get nervous in the tunnel," he says, "and I was a bit star-struck at White Hart Lane, though my second full game for Ipswich was at Sunderland in front of 40,000 people, so it was nothing new. And once I got a kick, I was fine."

Four days later Bramble made his full home debut against Manchester United, announcing himself with a thunderous tackle which floored, not to mention flabbergasted, Roy Keane. Among those sucking in their breath in the stand was the former England defender Kevin Beattie, who had made a similarly magnificent debut for Ipswich against United 28 years earlier. "That was one of mine," he said of the tackle, and he could have offered no higher praise.

Jaap Stam paid tribute to Bramble afterwards and Keane, by way of congratulations, offered a manly handshake. Matt Holland, the Ipswich skipper, says the players try to steer clear of Bramble's tackles in training, while John Scales, who played alongside him at Leicester on Wednesday, says: "He has got all the attributes to make a really top player. He is not just about strength and power. The boy also has self-belief, composure and great mental strength."

Against Sunderland a fortnight ago he proved those qualities with a remarkable goal, running from the halfway line, taking a return pass from Marcus Stewart and tucking the ball away like a natural-born striker. He began up front as a kid until a coach moved him to right-back and then, given his weight and height - he is now 6ft 1in and 13st 10lb - to a more natural centre-half position.

For all that, Bramble, an Ipswich lad who has been with the club since he was eight, understands that he is learning his trade in the Premiership. And after admitting to being at fault for Tottenham's third, late goal by Les Ferdinand in the opening game, he has learned that a tired mind leads to blundering limbs at the frenetic pace of the top league.

He says: "The pace is much quicker than in Division One and in the last 15 or 20 minutes your mind gets tired. I was struggling towards the end at Tottenham and I got caught ball-watching for the third goal. The boss was very good about it - he said I'll learn in time."

After four appearances for Ipswich two seasons ago, two of them as substitute, Bramble broke his right ankle, an injury that kept him out until January of this year. When he was finally declared fit, Town sent him on loan to Colchester, and in his second game he damaged his knee, which was diagnosed as tendinitis.

Some fear that his fierce tackling could lead to more injuries and that, like Beattie, another brilliantly forceful player, they could curtail his career. Bramble thinks he has just been unlucky, saying: "I still tackle as hard as ever but I've cut out the rash ones." Keane might have something to say about that.

webTitle: Deadline set for Foxes' Belgrade switch

fields.headline: Deadline set for Foxes' Belgrade switch
fields.standfirst: Now Leicester must wait for Red Star's safety assurances before booking their tickets to Belgrade
fields.trailText: Now Leicester must wait for Red Star's safety assurances before booking their tickets to Belgrade.
fields.body:
Leicester City have been guaranteed that their Uefa Cup first-round second-leg tie against Red Star Belgrade will be switched to a neutral venue if the Yugoslav authorities fail to deliver written assurances about the safety of the travelling party.

Uefa yesterday brought the match forward by a week to September 21 so that it will not coincide with the potentially tumultuous results of the presidential elections in which Slobodan Milosevic may be removed from office.

Under stringent conditions demanded by the Leicester chairman John Elsom, the Serbian Football Federation must obtain written undertakings from the government and police that the travelling players, management and staff will be at no risk whatsoever. If they cannot provide those assurances before 3pm on Tuesday, Uefa has told Leicester the match will be played in Sofia.

"We have insisted on certain conditions because we need it to be a certainty that the security of our party is ensured throughout our stay," said Elsom. "As such, the Yugoslav authorities have a deadline to meet, otherwise the game will be moved."

In all likelihood, however, Leicester will reluctantly become the first British team to play in Belgrade since the Nato bombings, after Partizan Belgrade were required to move their Uefa Cup match against Leeds United last season to Heerenveen in the Netherlands.

The first leg will take place at Filbert Street next Thursday and, on the advice of Uefa and the Foreign Office, Leicester will not sell any tickets for the return fixture.

"We haven't got everything we would have wished for but this scenario is better than at first because it means we will not be playing in the aftermath of the elections," said Elsom.

"I feel sorry for our fans because they will be unable to play any part in one of the most important games in the club's history. For their sake I would dearly love to get through to the next round so we could hopefully get a better draw, somewhere like Norway."

The Football Association executive director David Davies said yesterday's developments showed that Uefa recognised the problem facing Leicester but the situation had not been fully resolved.

"Clearly this matter is not at an end," he said. "We are well aware they are monitoring the situation, like us, very closely."

Rotherham's manager Ronnie Moore will report Cardiff's Bobby Gould to the League Managers' Association over the transfer of Leo Fortune-West. The striker joined the Welsh club for £300,000 yesterday but Moore is unhappy about the way the former Wales manager Gould finalised the deal.

"As far as we were concerned the deal was dead on Monday," Moore said. "They never came back to ask permission to speak to him again. They spoke to him direct and they should have spoken to me first.

"What Bobby Gould has done is unacceptable. I'm going to report him to the LMA to let him know my feelings on the situation."
