fields.headline: Robson's revolution, one year on
fields.standfirst: A year ago, Newcastle took on Chelsea sitting at the foot of the Premiership. Today they do so again standing proud at the top. And it's all down to one man . . .
fields.trailText: A year ago, Newcastle took on Chelsea sitting at the foot of the Premiership. Today they do so again standing proud at the top. And it's all down to one man . . .
fields.body:
On top of the league he may be, but Bobby Robson appeared bewildered, even embarrassed by all the fuss yesterday. With the Premiership manager of the month award sitting proudly at his arm, the Newcastle manager stumbled in response to the first question thrown at him.

"What does this award mean?" he echoed. "Well, it's a reflection on everything around the club, not just me. We're a pretty formidable team now. I'll accept it on behalf of everybody. We're all in this together, after all."

Typical Robson. The former England manager celebrates a year in charge at St James' Park this afternoon, entering his 50th game as Newcastle manager in search of his 25th win. It is hard to believe he inherited a side at the foot of the Premiership, reeling from a derby defeat by Sunderland that marked the lowest point of Ruud Gullit's disastrous year in charge.

Now, having motored into mid-table and to an FA Cup semi-final last season, the Magpies lead the Premiership for the first time since November 23 1996. Indeed, there is a perfect symmetry about this afternoon's visit of Chelsea. Robson's first match in charge after replacing Gullit as manager was at Stamford Bridge; the Londoners won 1-0, Newcastle stayed joint bottom with a solitary point, but the first seeds of success had been sown.

A week later Sheffield Wednesday were beaten 8-0; a year on, the Toon is buzzing again. "We've made great strides," said Robson. "In footballing terms it's been meteoric. The response from the players since I've been here has been wonderful, quite magnificent. It's all down to them."

The club's supporters disagree. "The man's a saint," said Gary Mowlem, a lifelong Newcastle fan and season ticket holder. "If I'd been out of the country for four years and come back to hear that we'd had Kenny Dalglish and Ruud Gullit in charge, I'd be asking 'How many trophies have we won?' But they were disastrous.

"In hindsight, the board should have taken the plunge and appointed Bobby four years ago. Just imagine what he would have achieved with the £60m spent by Dalglish and Gullit; we'd be champions by now. Instead we wasted those years and Bobby's had to work with no resources whatsoever."

"When Robson was first mentioned as a possible manager I didn't really want him here," admitted Mark Jensen, the editor of the Newcastle fanzine The Mag, to incredulous gasps at the publication's office. "There were two things to consider: You could say he was too old, but then again he had so much experience.

"I suppose in some ways it was similar to when Keegan came in. At that time he was the only man who could do the job, and that's probably what happened with Bobby as well. As a seasoned Newcastle fan I was just looking on the dark side. But I'm happy to hold my hands up now and say I was wrong."

Such sentiments are shared by the players Robson has transformed from whipping boys to table-toppers. "The gaffer saved my Newcastle career," says the midfielder Rob Lee, a veteran of the Kevin Keegan era at St James' Park who had fallen so far in Gullit's estimation as to be denied even a squad number. "If Gullit had been at the club for another month or so he would have wrecked a few Newcastle careers, not just mine. I would have left and I don't think Alan Shearer would have been too far behind.

"It's strange, but if we hadn't lost the derby against Sunderland we would never have had Bobby Robson. It was sad that it had to be that way, but I can't complain now. I'd reached the stage where it had all become too much for me. It was the most awful time of my life. I have never been treated like that by anybody. I didn't deserve it and it was all coming to a head. Now, with Bobby, everything has changed."

With relatively little money to spend, Robson's principal success has been to galvanise a squad who had lost all self-belief under Gullit. Of the side that took the Magpies to the summit on Wednesday by beating Coventry 2-0, only two were bought by Robson, but the infectious enthusiasm of the manager transposed itself into the team's performance.

"He may be 67 but you watch him out on the training pitch, running around with the players, and it goes to show that if you're good enough you're young enough," added Jensen.

"Bobby's done it all. He'd managed one of the biggest clubs in the world at Barcelona and had taken England to a World Cup semi-final. He was also a Geordie, which helped, although that was no guarantee of success; Jack Charlton had black and white blood running through his veins and couldn't do it up here."

But Robson could. "We've worked hard to improve every segment of the team," he said. "Our work ethic has been 100%, our defence looks stronger now than it has done in months and we have strengthened the squad despite letting a number of players go in the summer.

"We're not going to win the championship - to leap from 11th in the table to winning the Premiership is too big a jump to make in one year - but we can improve on last season. We will be chasing the dreaded four of Manchester United, Arsenal, Chelsea and Liverpool."

His immediate task is to try to avoid the fate of most recipients of the monthly managers' award - defeat even before the champagne has gone flat - against one of that quartet. Chelsea beat Newcastle three times last season - "I don't think any team's done that to me in my life before" - and Robson has spent the week keeping his players' feet firmly on the ground.

"Everyone's all excited about being top of the league, but it's September, not May. The Chelsea game will show us how close or how far we are away from challenging," he added. "They bugged us last season, but we're not afraid of anybody. This'll be the test we need."

fields.headline: Ellis loses re-election vote
fields.trailText: Aston Villa's shareholders delivered a damning verdict on their controversial chairman Doug Ellis yesterday by refusing to re-elect him to the board at the club's annual meeting.
fields.body:
Aston Villa's shareholders delivered a damning verdict on their controversial chairman Doug Ellis yesterday by refusing to re-elect him to the board at the club's annual meeting.

Ellis, chairman since 1982, was defeated 60-40 on a show of hands at the stormy meeting. He was visibly shaken by the verdict, which followed his second inquisition by shareholders in less than 24 hours; he had also been given a rough ride by 500 or more at a pre-agm fans' forum on Thursday evening.

"Judging by the reaction it appears I do not have the support of the shareholders present," he said after the fans' forum. "But I know I have the support of the majority of shareholders and the people of Birmingham because of all the letters I receive."

The 77-year-old is taking a Canute-like approach to the tide of criticism, but it was the second vote of no confidence he has suffered in the six times he has stood for re-election and if he were not the major shareholder his hold on office would be precarious.

"We want him off the board for the good of the club," said Jonathan Collett, a spokesman for the newly formed Aston Villa Independent Supporters Association.

Ellis was also given the thumbs-down in 1986 when he was defeated by Buck Chinn, the chairman of the Aston Villa Shareholders Association. Then, as is expected again this time, Ellis retained his seat because of his substantial shareholding. He holds 46% of the stock and, with proxy votes still to be counted, he will be re-elected when the second ballot is held on Monday.

The Aston Villa Independent Supporters Association had much to do with the vote against Ellis and wanted the proposed 9p dividend to shareholders to be channelled into team building instead.

Last year's reported loss of £4.8m followed a profit of £20m for the previous 12 months, and shares worth £3.42 apiece after being valued at £11 at flotation only three years ago are symptoms of the malaise. Average attendances for Premiership games also fell by 5,000 last season.

The dissent mirrors the feelings aired by the captain Gareth Southgate, Ugo Ehiogu and Julian Joachim. All three are keen to leave, with Southgate and Ehiogu citing the club's lack of ambition as the main reason. Villa have yet to win this season.

To add to the gloom at Villa Park, it was revealed last night that the manager John Gregory had made an unsuccessful attempt to sign Real Madrid's midfielder Steve McManaman, who is included in the Spanish club's squad to face Valenica today.

Henning Berg, 31, has re-joined Blackburn on a three-month loan after struggling to get a game with Manchester United. "I am delighted to be back and I certainly know my way around this place," he said. "I had no hesitation in agreeing. If all goes well I'd like it to be a permanent move."

The Norway defender cost £400,000 when he arrived at Ewood Park seven years ago but was sold to United for £5m in 1997.

Coventry's manager Gordon Strachan has signed two Honduras internationals for undis closed sums. Jairo Martinez, a 21-year-old striker, and Ivan Guerrero, 23 and a midfielder, will arrive after representing their country at the Olympics.

In the latest twist to the saga of the European Commission threat to the transfer system, the EC has confirmed that dialogue with football authorities will continue until the end of the year. "We are particularly pleased with the confirmation given of a new timetable, with our ideas submitted by October 31 and a dialogue taken forward to December 31," said Per Omdal, Fifa vice-president and chairman of the task force set up to find a solution to the EU's legal challenge to the transfer regulations.

fields.headline: McLeish challenges the Celtic order
fields.standfirst: Hibernian's manager finds out just how far he's really come when he takes his league leaders to Parkhead today
fields.trailText: Hibernian's manager finds out just how far he's really come when he takes his league leaders to Parkhead today. Thomas Kerr reports.
fields.body:
Few figures in Scottish football are more recognisable than Alex McLeish. With his flaming orange hair, and a nose that has been bashed to various contours after 20 years and 77 international caps in his days as the sentinel of Aberdeen's defence, he will need no introduction when he leads his Hibernian team to Glasgow to face Celtic this afternoon.

The equivalent of the earth having fallen from its axis currently prevails in Scottish football. Hibs top the Premier League, with Celtic and Rangers relegated to second and third respectively.

If McLeish's team can survive at Parkhead today it will confirm the most momentous start in 25 years for the club.

The story of McLeish's rise and fall and rise again in management is one of the wonders of the new season. He began well as a coach with Motherwell before that club slid towards relegation. Motherwell's bitter followers still lament his time at the club.

McLeish, though, is maturing impressively with Hibs. He seems to have grasped that he learned more than he realised in his playing career.

Andy Roxburgh, the former Scotland manager and now Uefa technical director, said of him: "You could walk into any hotel of any footballing gathering in Europe with Alex and he would know players from every country from having played against them. I was amazed at how encyclopaedic a knowledge he had of the game and its cast."

Today, McLeish is using these contacts to benefit Hibs. His signing of Franck Sauzee, the former Marseille and French international, has done wonders to arouse the club.

The pair had crossed swords on a few fields of battle and the 33-year-old did not hesitate to answer the call when McLeish came knocking.

Hibs, as a result, are playing some of their best football since the legendary 70s, but whether they can preserve their league lead at Parkhead today is intriguing.

In many respects the old order in Scotland still seems in transigent. Didier Agathe had been excelling for Hibs before he walked out on the club to join Celtic last week.

McLeish goes into this game suffering few illusions. "This is our stiffest test yet," he said yesterday. "I believe we can win, and I want my players to believe it, but the majority will still be expecting us to lose.

"There is a hunger about Celtic now that they are into their stride under Martin O'Neill. To be honest, I think to take anything away from Parkhead would be a magnificent achievement for us."

Rangers face an equally alluring match at Dens Park against Dundee, whose bright start has been scarred by seven sending-offs in seven matches.

As if a fraught game in a tight stadium is not enough for Dick Advocaat, the Rangers manager already has one eye on the Champions League match against Sturm Graz at Ibrox on Tuesday.

webTitle: Buffon in trouble for choosing the wrong number at Parma

fields.headline: Buffon in trouble for choosing the wrong number at Parma
fields.standfirst: The Parma 'keeper's number is up. Probably just misunderstood
fields.trailText: The Parma 'keeper's number is up. Probably just misunderstood.
fields.body:
Squad numbers have a habit of causing problems. West Ham's Paulo Futre once stormed out of Highbury into a taxi after refusing to wear No16 and later paid £100,000 to get his favourite No10. But even that looks tame compared with the fuss Gianluigi Buffon has caused with his choice of shirt at Parma.

The goalkeeper's decision to wear 88 caused consternation among Italy's Jewish community, which pointed out that the figure is a neo-Nazi symbol. "H" is the eighth letter of the alphabet, so 88 equates to HH, or Heil Hitler.

Buffon has previously worn a shirt bearing the slogan "Boia chi molla" - "Death to cowards" - which was used by fascists in Benito Mussolini's day. But he called a press conference yesterday to explain that people had the wrong impression. After his mother had said her son's accusers "should be ashamed of thinking such things", that is.

"I have chosen 88 because it reminds me of four balls and in Italy we all know what it means to have balls: strength and determination," he said. "And this season I will have to have balls to get back my place in the Italy team."

The plot, though, thickens. "At first I didn't choose 88," he explained. "I wanted 00 but the league told me that was impossible. I also considered 01 but that was not considered a proper number. I liked 01 because it was the number on the General Lee car in the TV series the Dukes of Hazzard."

Buffon, who said the Holocaust disgusted him and the "Nazi slur" had hurt him, added that he was willing to heed a call from the Jewish community, which asked him to switch shirts "out of respect for Jews, tziganes [gyspies] and homosexuals".

"I am ready to change numbers if that will help," he explained. "I didn't know the hidden meaning of 88."

Apparently that "Boia chi molla" episode was all an innocent error as well. "When I wore that shirt I was stupid because I did not know it was a phrase used by the fascist regime," said Buffon. The 22-year-old, who missed Euro 2000 after breaking his hand in a friendly and has since lost his place to Francesco Toldo, found others willing to put his case.

"We are honest people," said his mother. The African foundation for medicine and research added: "He gave us money to build two wells in Kenya." Meanwhile Parma's director of football, Michele Uva, remarked: "The Jewish community should deal with more serious matters."

Lazio's Claudio Lopez scored twice against Internazionale in Italy's Super Cup final last night when the Serie A winners completed a 4-3 win despite going behind after three minutes when Robbie Keane scored with a neat lob.

webTitle: Swinging both ways with the non-fighting Irish

fields.headline: Swinging both ways with the non-fighting Irish
fields.standfirst: Ron's in the dugout
fields.trailText: This week Ron the Manager followed the Irish squad to Amsterdam to find out if it was all it's craiced up to be.
fields.body:
Ho ho, it's the way oi tell 'em ... isn't it? ... it's the crack! ... er ... the craic! with the road-blocks and strikes at the French ports ... I decided to head for Holland!

Rather than spend last weekend in the company of a bunch of surly pig-farmers ... I tagged along with the Republic of Ireland squad ... marvellous! ... "Vive la différence!" And what supporters! ... ho ho! ... great bunch of lads ... refreshing! ... constantly! ... no hooligans ... no shenanigans ... yet they're as "Oirish" as the team these days, Jack!

Friday night in Amsterdam ... the Irish Quarter! ... a small guest-house next to the Irish team hotel ... early to bed and not a peep from next door! ... after high-jinks in Dublin lost him two key members of the squad ... Mick McCarthy's put his foot down firmly! ... takes a big man to do that!

Amsterdam ... hmm? ... Euro 2000? ... wasn't it? ... troublemakers taking advantage of the relaxed drug laws ... Smoking pot! ... Don't worry ... not the Irish lads! ... They're just here for the craic!

Ambassadors! ... not like the English in Paris! ... disgraceful! ... ho ho! ... only joking! ... ashamed to be English? ... come on ... imagine being French! ... the dirty ... what? ... Oh sorry ... but imagine being German! I ... what? ... oh, alright.

Saturday afternoon! ... Crowded into Shenanigans bar ... Roaring on the Scots on the big screen TV! ... bit of a "criic" in my neck! ... sinking a few jars of the "black stuff"! ... one-nil to Scotland ... and off to the stadium.

I tried Craig Brown on the mobile to congratulate him on a towering victory over mighty Latvia! ... but not a sausage! ... But the craic! ... ho! ... heard a marvellous story about Posh 'n' Becks! ... I'll tell you later!

... Wheep! ... Come on, Ireland! ... Well, they certainly looked at home for the first hour ... rain coming down like stair-rods! ... does anyone still use stair-rods?* ... a great performance! ... Came agonisingly close! ... The final whistle! ... a draw away to Holland and everyone's a bit subdued!

An early night beckoned when the heavens opened again ... a downpour of biblical proportions! ... Dived into a little place called "Sodom and Begorrah"! ... looked shut ... but a hand-written sign ... down the back passage and there's the rear entry! And in the corner! ... Blow me!... it couldn't be! ... Ken Bates!

Well, I sidled over ... dug him in the ribs ... ruffled his hair ... and tugged his beard! ... ho ho!

... and it wasn't him! ... It was Captain Birdseye! ... the old Captain Birdseye ... I've never been so embarrassed! ... Couldn't shake the bugger off all night!

Emerging blinking woozily into the light some hours later ... after a few drops of the "hard stuff"! ... a somewhat over-affectionate message from Craig ... not sure it was meant for me ... maybe he'd hit the redial button by accident ... but marvellous singing voice! ... light Scottish tenor! ... ho ho ... sound familiar? ... up to our knees in what? ...

Posh and Becks! ... ho ho! ... what? ... cut 200 words? Oh sorry, I'm going to have to leave it there this week.

webTitle: Money: Shares puzzle for Woolwich investors

fields.headline: Shares puzzle for Woolwich investors
fields.trailText: Battered Woolwich shareholders -they saw 1997 windfalls slump by a quarter before Barclays Bank brought relief with a bid last month - have another battle.
fields.body:
Battered Woolwich shareholders -they saw 1997 windfalls slump by a quarter before Barclays Bank brought relief with a bid last month - have another battle.

But this time the struggle will be mental, not financial. Woolwich's 1.15m shareholders must now work their way through the contents of the very large envelope from Barclays which has been thumping on to doormats this week.

And the takeover literature for the £5.6bn uncontested cash and shares offer could take over even more shelf space if investors ask for the optional 200 page plus A4 Barclays "listing particulars".

Despite the weight, Woolwich holders will find no advice on whether to swap their stock for Barclays shares or for cash. No one from either side will tell them if Barclays shares are a good bet or not.

And Woolwich's retreating army will have to work their way through to page 199 in one book and page 24 in another before they find any details of tax considerations. Despite the "This document is important and requires your immediate attention" line on each item, few are likely to get beyond the glossy 12-page A5 questions and answers booklet where they will not find anything at all about potential tax liabilities.

Because windfall shares were free, their entire value less a small inflation adjustment for the period up to March 1998 could be liable for capital gains tax (CGT) unless the shares were held in a personal equity plan.

This is unlikely to affect anyone with a typical holding. But it could hit those with larger stakes or investors who have clocked up capital gains elsewhere. The annual "exemption" is £7,200 - after that investors could pay up to 40p in the pound on their gains.

Those with a possible tax bill will need to opt for as many Barclays shares as possible rather than take cash. Rolling over one share into another as part of a takeover does not incur a tax bill. Those holding Woolwich in a Pep are also likely to go for the shares unless they have another stock in mind - Pep rules ban long-term cash holdings.

The "Q & A" booklet was included on the insistence of the Woolwich team in the teeth of opposition from Barclays lawyers who did not believe in special help for small shareholders. But while it is mute on tax problems, or on whether to take the cash or the shares, it does explain the choice mechanism.

Shareholders are being offered £1.64 plus 0.1175 Barclays share for each Woolwich share. No one can be sent part of a share -cheques will compensate for fractions.

If holders do nothing they will receive Barclays' set formula when the deal is finalised - and there is no chance it will not go through. Big investors are backing this deal so even a major small shareholder vote for continuing Woolwich independence will be futile.

Investors can opt for all shares either for tax reasons or because they think Barclays is a good bet (see above). Alternatively they can go for cash and no shares - this choice could be popular with investors who are fed up with the stock market.

But there are no guarantees that investor choice will be honoured. Barclays has structured the deal so that it knows exactly what Woolwich will cost - it intends to issue 179m new shares and pay out around £2.7m in cash no matter how shareholders use the mix'n'match option.

If too many go for cash, it will scale down their requests and increase the shares they receive - or vice versa. All shareholders will be treated equally in this exercise, however. And as it is unlikely that investors will select in the exact proportions of the Barclays offer, many will be disappointed.

Investors have until October 20 to make their choice. Much will depend on the Barclays share price on that date - if it is higher than £16.44, big investors will go for shares or if it is lower, the institutions may opt for cash.

Cheques and share certificates will be sent by November 7.

Brokers banking on Barclays

Opting for Barclays shares at the fixed £16.44 offer price looks like a sure fire winner - the shares are currently trading over £17 - still shy of the 2000 high at £18.28, though substantially above this year's £13.44 low point.

But beyond the hopes of making a quick turn, the shares are rated a longer term purchase in the City. Out of 17 brokers giving an opinion on Hemscott.net, 12 are backing Barclays as a buy with the others suggesting that investors should hold. There are no negatives.

Big institutional broker Merrill Lynch is a Barclays fan. Its analysts believe Woolwich "is the best placed strategically of the mortgage banks". It likes Woolwich's Open Plan bank product and the way Barclays can move its mortgage business to the lower cost Woolwich.

Brokers are cheered by Woolwich boss John Stewart's sticking at his post. He is willing to swap his - admittedly virtually worthless - options for those in Barclays.

They see Barclays with an "each way bet on financial services" - it wins if mortgage margins crumble and wins if internet style banks take off thanks to Open Plan.

webTitle: Axa threatened with court for £1.7bn distribution

fields.headline: Axa face a tough tackle on payout
fields.standfirst: Insurer threatened with court for £1.7bn distribution which the Consumers' Association says will favour shareholders too much. Patrick Collinson reports
fields.trailText: Insurer threatened with court for £1.7bn distribution which the Consumers' Association says will favour shareholders too much. Patrick Collinson reports
fields.body:
Axa's plans to pay out its £1.7bn "orphan estate" received a stunning blow yesterday when the Consumers' Association said it is to take court action to block what it describes as a "shoddy deal" for policyholders.

The CA has taken independent actuarial advice which it says shows that Axa's shareholders are grabbing far too large a share of the surplus cash. It now wants policyholders to contact the CA so it can mount a case against Axa at the November 20 High Court hearing at which Axa needs to gain approval for the plan to go ahead.

Ashley Holmes, the CA's head of legal affairs, says: "Three things are emerging. Firstly, it is becoming clear that shareholders are benefiting far more from this distribution than policyholders. Secondly, the position has been spun by Axa to make it appear that shareholders are not getting such a large share, and thirdly, the documents sent to policyholders are almost completely incomprehensible."

The CA asked several actuaries, including KPMG, to go through the Axa proposals with a fine toothcomb. "Recommendations from the Treasury have previously stated that policyholders are generally entitled to at least 90% of these funds and shareholders should receive no more than 10%. But our evidence shows that the deal will deliver just 31% to policyholders," it says.

On that basis, policyholders are only receiving £527m, or £1bn less than they should be earning on a 90/10 distribution. In cash terms, it suggests that the £400 average windfall for policyholders quoted by Axa should instead be just over £1,000.

The CA's research and planned court action will come as a shock to the 660,000 policyholders who received mailings from Axa last week. The packs contained an immensely complex 110-page policyholder circular, accompanied by a voting form, which Axa wants returned by October 16. Axa's plan needs the approval of 35% of policyholders, with payouts expected to be made in February 2001.

But the CA action may halt the plan, even if it gains the 35% approval needed from policyholders. This is because the High Court has the power to block the plan if it believes it is against the interests of with-profits policyholders.

Policyholders are now left in a difficult position. Should they vote for the cash or wait and see what happens in the High Court? They may vote yes, but find the plan blocked. Or they may vote no (or not return the voting form) in which case two scenarios could arise. The High Court may reject the plan after the CA's representations, in which case Axa will have to go back to the drawing board and produce a better alternative. But if the High Court accepts the plan, the "no" policyholders will have lost their right to a windfall payout. They will not lose their rights over the orphan estate, but will not receive the cash bonus; instead they will have to wait for a special bonus at an unspecified time in the future.

"It is a very tough decision for people to make," admits the CA's Mr Holmes. "Axa has dressed this process up as 'choice' - but, in reality, they are not giving people choice. We can't take decisions for individual policyholders. What we are saying is that we have new evidence that the deal is a poor one, and that if people agree with us and are unhappy about the deal, they should contact us. We want as many people as possible to do so."

Mr Holmes says policyholders should write to CA at Dept LM at PO Box 44, Hertford X, SG14 1SH, or by email to orphan@which.net. The CA has also prepared a briefing on the Axa deal, summarising advice from its actuaries, obtainable by ringing 020 7770 7264/7061.

One Axa policyholder who shares the CA's concerns is Jobs & Money reader Rowland Clayton of Great Malvern in Worcestershire. He wrote to us this week with his objections to the deal. He is also writing to the High Court detailing why it should reject the proposals which he says give policyholders a "Hobson's choice."

He says: "The policyholders own 90% of the inherited estate. It is stated, but not con firmed by [Axa's] independent actuary that the share- holders' benefit will be £100-£200m, compared with the benefit to policyholders of £300m.

"If these figures are correct, much less than 90% is going to policyholders. The implication is that the proposals are designed to benefit the shareholders rather than the policyholders. This does not seem equitable. I suggest the High Court should refuse to sanction these proposals."

Axa is standing by its proposals. Spokesman Stuart Prosser says: "We spent a lot of time working on these proposals and believe it is a fair offer for policyholders. But it's not only us who believe this.

"We have the approval of an independent actuary and the Financial Services Authority feels the same way. Both the FSA and the independent actuary are acting on behalf of policyholders, not shareholders."

The CA's principal concerns about the deal centre around the £836m that Axa wants to put aside for tax and lock-in liabilities. "The reality is that careful tax planning could result in a considerable amount of this money going to shareholders. Furthermore, the lock-in deduction appears to be based on unduly stringent critieria."

It also disputes that the FSA has in reality approved the Axa proposals. "If you read the FSA document closely, it is not approval; what it says is that that it has no reason why it should stop Axa from going forward for a vote," says the CA's Mr Holmes.

One thorny issue remains for the CA, though. Who will pay for the court action? CA is hoping that, in the style of the recent Equitable Life court case, Axa will fund the court challenge so it can establish that its deal is fair. Or not.

webTitle: Widowers fight for just tax deal

fields.headline: Widowers fight for just tax deal
fields.standfirst: A campaign is underway to get the same bereavement rights for both men and women. David Brodie explains why
fields.trailText: A campaign is underway to get the same bereavement rights for both men and women. David Brodie explains why
fields.body:
Men are rarely viewed as the victims of sex discrimination, but in the past six years almost 200,000 widowed men have been denied a tax relief - typically worth around £500 - which has been available to widows.

The government's position is so weak that it has settled one claim by a widower in order to avoid a hearing before the European Court of Human Rights, but the Revenue still flatly refuses to make payments to other men. This week the charity TaxAid launched a campaign for justice for all widowers.

The Widow's Bereavement Allowance (WBA) was introduced in 1980 to ease financial burdens facing women who lost their husbands, giving them a special tax relief in the year of widowhood and the following tax year.

While this was fair at a time when the tax system discriminated against wives, a relief given solely to women became indefensible following the introduction of independent taxation of married couples in 1990, and the rising importance of the European Convention on Human Rights, which outlaws sex discrimination.

In 1995 Christopher Crossland's wife died and he gave up his £50,000 a year job to care for his children. He claimed the WBA, but the taxman said it was not available to men. While many would have given up, Mr Crossland decided to fight his case right up to the European Court of Human Rights.

At that point, fearing another embarrassing defeat before the European Court, the government backed down and settled the case by paying him the £575 claimed plus his legal costs. It also abolished the WBA for women widowed after April 5 2000.

That Crossland settlement was reached in November 1999 and since then hundreds of claims have been made by men widowed in recent years seeking similar treatment. But every time the Revenue has refused to make any payment.

The Revenue says it has no legal authority to grant relief to men, as the law refers only to widows. When we suggested that, having settled with Mr Crossland, it was unfair to deny a payment to other widowers in the identical position, a spokesman claimed he was prohibited by the rules of confidentiality from discussing Mr Crossland's affairs.

Whatever the precise legal position, it is grossly unfair to settle with one person, just because he has the tenacity to fight his case, but then deny payment to others in an identical position. This is a clear breach of the promise, in the Revenue's Service Commitment, to treat all taxpayers fairly.

TaxAid believes the Revenue's case is weak and is encouraging all men widowed between April 6 1994 and April 5 2000 to write a short letter (see end) to their tax office to claim a payment.

TaxAid is also asking all accountants and tax advisers to claim on behalf of male clients who were widowed in that period.

The campaign is being supported by barrister Philip Baker of Gray's Inn Tax Chambers, who is taking a pro bono case to the European Court on behalf of another widower. There are also plans to fight a case in the UK courts after the Human Rights Act comes into force on October 2, and to have the matter raised in Parliament.

Widowers and accountants who make claims are asked to write to TaxAid to report that they have done so. The charity will keep a register of the number of claims made, to help to demonstrate the strength of public feeling on this issue.

TaxAid may be contacted through its website, www.taxaid.org.uk or by writing to TaxAid, Linburn House, 342 Kilburn High Road, London NW6 2QJ. David Brodie is director of TaxAid.

What you need to say

Dear Sir,

Following the settlement by the Revenue in the "Crossland case", I am writing to claim a widower's bereavement payment in respect of the death of my wife [give her name] on [give the date of her death].

Yours faithfully
fields.bodyText: Men are rarely viewed as the victims of sex discrimination, but in the past six years almost 200,000 widowed men have been denied a tax relief - typically worth around £500 - which has been available to widows. The government's position is so weak that it has settled one claim by a widower in order to avoid a hearing before the European Court of Human Rights, but the Revenue still flatly refuses to make payments to other men. This week the charity TaxAid launched a campaign for justice for all widowers. The Widow's Bereavement Allowance (WBA) was introduced in 1980 to ease financial burdens facing women who lost their husbands, giving them a special tax relief in the year of widowhood and the following tax year. While this was fair at a time when the tax system discriminated against wives, a relief given solely to women became indefensible following the introduction of independent taxation of married couples in 1990, and the rising importance of the European Convention on Human Rights, which outlaws sex discrimination. In 1995 Christopher Crossland's wife died and he gave up his £50,000 a year job to care for his children. He claimed the WBA, but the taxman said it was not available to men. While many would have given up, Mr Crossland decided to fight his case right up to the European Court of Human Rights. At that point, fearing another embarrassing defeat before the European Court, the government backed down and settled the case by paying him the £575 claimed plus his legal costs. It also abolished the WBA for women widowed after April 5 2000. That Crossland settlement was reached in November 1999 and since then hundreds of claims have been made by men widowed in recent years seeking similar treatment. But every time the Revenue has refused to make any payment. The Revenue says it has no legal authority to grant relief to men, as the law refers only to widows. When we suggested that, having settled with Mr Crossland, it was unfair to deny a payment to other widowers in the identical position, a spokesman claimed he was prohibited by the rules of confidentiality from discussing Mr Crossland's affairs. Whatever the precise legal position, it is grossly unfair to settle with one person, just because he has the tenacity to fight his case, but then deny payment to others in an identical position. This is a clear breach of the promise, in the Revenue's Service Commitment, to treat all taxpayers fairly. TaxAid believes the Revenue's case is weak and is encouraging all men widowed between April 6 1994 and April 5 2000 to write a short letter (see end) to their tax office to claim a payment. TaxAid is also asking all accountants and tax advisers to claim on behalf of male clients who were widowed in that period. The campaign is being supported by barrister Philip Baker of Gray's Inn Tax Chambers, who is taking a pro bono case to the European Court on behalf of another widower. There are also plans to fight a case in the UK courts after the Human Rights Act comes into force on October 2, and to have the matter raised in Parliament. fields.headline: Well-red students
fields.trailText: I think I'm addicted to reading. On a long flight I'm such a word junkie that I end up reading all that small print on the back of the ticket about not carrying bombs on planes if you can avoid it (it's the Warsaw Convention, check it out next time.)
fields.body:
I think I'm addicted to reading. On a long flight I'm such a word junkie that I end up reading all that small print on the back of the ticket about not carrying bombs on planes if you can avoid it (it's the Warsaw Convention, check it out next time.)

And if I'm in the bath too long, it's only a matter of time before I start reading the labels on the back of the shampoo and bubble bath. And apart from learning the Finnish for "hair care" (it seems to be a country where they've mistaken a stutter for a language), you'll soon discover that almost everything that's in a plastic container in a bathroom is made of the same ingredients.

They might claim to be unique, they might be revolutionary, they might be for entirely different markets and purposes, but you can bet your backside that, apart from the packaging, they're all more or less the same stuff. Take a look at your shampoo, shaving foam, bath lotion, bubble bath, even your minty-blue cool-gel toothpaste and among the main ingredients will be aqua (water), laureth sodium sulfate (stuff that foams up) and a whole list of other near-identical contents.

This same sense of more or less the same products dressed up in different boxes may have occurred to the hundreds of thousands of students who, in the next couple of weeks, will be choosing their first bank account and might be struggling to find the differences.

For the banks, this is a once-a-year chance to recruit customers who could stay with them for life. And by promising a few introductory offers now, the banks hope to acquire account holders who, in a few years, will be high-earning graduates.

This is big business, as the current total for students in higher education has reached more than 1.75 million. So what are students being offered to lure them into a lifetime relationship?

If you cut away the slightly embarrassing attempts to be hip in the packaging, the high street banks are almost all promising the same three things: a basic current account, an interest-free overdraft and a freebie (along the lines of a CD voucher). And considering the long-term benefit to the banks, I'm always surprised how modest these efforts are. Given that it's difficult to get young people excited about a bank account, you'd think that the free gifts could have been slightly more adventurous.

For instance, Barclays offers £40 worth of vouchers, NatWest promises a CD player or £35 cash and HSBC will slip you £50 or a young person's railcard, the level of birthday present teenagers might expect from a generous granny rather than a global financial organisation.

It might not be particularly ethical, but if the banks got serious about bribing and offered free tickets to New York they could sign up a whole generation of students for the price of a few charter flights. So if the freebies aren't going to turn many heads, the interest-free overdraft limits could be the biggest attraction.

These range between £500 and £2,000, often with the higher limits only available to students after a couple of years. For first-years, Abbey National is offering £1,000 in interest-free overdrafts, Bank of Scotland £1,200, Barclays £1,250, Lloyds TSB, £1,500 and NatWest will negotiate individually. And in terms of what students need most - money - there are not going to be many better ways of borrowing.

Using an interest-free overdraft is certainly preferable to another product on offer, the student credit card. In my own time at university, the campus bank manager handed me a £50 cheque guarantee card as gingerly as if it were a loaded revolver with the safety catch off, so the idea of giving me a credit card would have killed him on the spot.

But there are now customised cards, such as the Student Barclaycard, which takes no prisoners with interest at 19.4 APR. By the time students graduate it's estimated that almost a third will have credit card debts.

There are other benefits on offer to students. Discounted insurance is available from banks including HSBC and the Royal Bank of Scotland, covering contents and travel - and since students often end up in the type of insecure accommodation favoured by burglars, it's well worth considering.

And the advice available from banks shouldn't be overlooked. Student life is now synonymous with debt, and debt can be a very stressful and isolating experience, so specialist advice from a bank with a branch in or near university could be a very valuable service. And remember, as you're heading towards thousands of pounds of debt, don't spend those £40 CD vouchers all at once.

Email: coughlan_sean@hotmail.com

webTitle: Money: What if your pension fund is over-valued?

fields.headline: Know your rights when you're overpaid
fields.trailText: A High Court ruling after Scottish Equitable over-valued a pension fund by £172,500 will help determine rights of other investors when they receive overpayments, writes Richard Colbey.
fields.body:
A High Court ruling after Scottish Equitable over-valued a pension fund by £172,500 will help determine rights of other investors when they receive overpayments, writes Richard Colbey.

Gordon Derby had bought a pension with ScotEq in 1988. Two years later he took early retirement, cashed in much of the fund and bought an annuity. In 1995 he asked ScotEq how much he would be entitled to on his 65th birthday. He reminded ScotEq that he had already taken money from the fund. But he was told the fund was worth £201,000. Surprised it was so high he sought confirmation and was assured the figure was correct.

ScotEq did not realise its mistake for another 16 months: it then sought back the £172,500 extra Mr Derby had been paid. But Mr Derby had disposed of the money. He used £150,000 to buy another pension from the Norwich Union; £42,000 to pay off his mortgage, and the remaining £9,000 he had simply spent.

The judge ruled the issue was whether Mr Derby had changed his position in reliance on the overpayment. He was guided by a 1991 House of Lords' decision arising from Mr Cass, a partner in solicitors Lipkin Gorman, gambling around £223,000 from the client account at the Playboy casino. When the theft was discovered the partners tried to recover the money from the club. It was held they were entitled to £154,000.

The club had received stolen money and were not entitled to it. However, it had also paid out money when Mr Cass won. Legally it had not been obliged to pay this, as gambling contracts are unenforceable, and the partners argued it should not be entitled to deduct this from the sums it had to pay back to them.

The Lords considered that the casino had altered its position by making these payments to Mr Cass, which were only made in the belief that he was entitled to gamble. The judge thought Mr Derby had not acted to his detriment in reliance on the over-payment. He claimed that he would have worked harder and earned more in the 16-month period had he not had the £201,000 but the judge did not believe his age and health would have let him do so.

The only "detriment" Mr Derby had suffered was spending the £9,000, which he would not have done had he not been misled about his financial position. As far as the mortgage was concerned he may only have repaid because of ScotEq's overpayment, but he was no worse off because of that or he would still have been liable for it.

And his new pension could be "unwound" to pay back ScotEq. Spending that £9,000 was analogous to the club paying Mr Cass. He had altered his position in the belief he was entitled to it, but that was the only sum he could keep. So anyone who receives overpayments from financial institutions will have more chance of keeping the extra if they fritter it away rather than invest it. Mr Derby's entitlement to keep the sum was based on his belief that he was entitled to it. Had he spent it knowing he had been overpaid, he would have had to repay it.

Richard Colbey is a barrister

webTitle: Money: Many policyholders at Scottish Provident will miss out on large windfalls from the Abbey National deal

fields.headline: It may not be that bonanza
fields.standfirst: Many policyholders at Scottish Provident will miss out on large windfalls from the Abbey National deal, warns Tony Levene
fields.trailText: Many policyholders at Scottish Provident will miss out on large windfalls from the Abbey National deal, warns Tony Levene
fields.body:
Demutualisation bonanzas could prove illusory for hundreds of thousands of Scottish Provident policyholders. They should look carefully at their documentation before planning how to spend the windfalls promised following Abbey National's swallowing up of the Edinburgh life insurer.

They will also need to check just when their policy was issued - the rules for some older policies are more generous than for those issued over the past four and a half years.

After being "in play" for some months, Scottish Provident finally threw in the mutuality towel this week when it said it was falling under the Abbey National umbrella where Glasgow-based life company Scottish Mutual has resided since 1992.

Continuing as a mutual made little sense, it believes, especially as it now specialises in protection plans, such as life or critical illness cover, rather than traditional with-profits business. And while it will not publicly admit it, the other touted option - a stock market float - would not have succeeded due to the firm's relatively small size.

Demutualising means policyholders lose out because they no longer own the entire with-profits fund. It has to be shared with outside investors - in this case Abbey National which will be paying £1.8bn for the life company.

In return for giving up their vote and part of their share in the proceeds, the 325,000 with profits shareholders will end up with windfalls averaging around £4,500 - near enough the eventual level paid out last month by Scottish Widows and substantially ahead of the typical amount on offer from pensions specialist NPI. They will also receive a further £1,500 on average in "enhanced policy benefits" - although just how holders will be made aware of this in these notoriously opaque funds is not clear.

With-profits policyholders include those with pension plans - where sales to new investors stopped in 1997 - and endowment policies. Scottish Provident endowments were sold to back mortgages by independent financial advisers.

The life insurance company is currently sending out review letters to homebuyers. It says "an average number have a shortfall". Scottish Provident stopped selling endowments late last year. According to Money Management, returns on 25-year policies maturing this year were below average.

The typical £4,500 payout may be improved - the Scottish Widows windfall went up as actuaries refined their sums. And that average amount will vary from a minimum £500 to a possible £100,000 plus for the very biggest long-term pension plans.

A further 125,000 policyholders who have non-profits plans, such as unit linked investments into both pension and endowment plans, are members but will not lose financially when mutuality disappears.

Investors in these funds will receive a flat £500 irrespective of the size of their holding. This is identical to the payout offered by Scottish Widows to their unit linked and non-profit customers.

But around 350,000 Scottish Provident policyholders will get nothing. They have no membership rights, although it is doubtful if this was ever pointed out to them by the independent financial advisers (IFAs )who sell all Scottish Provident plans.

The great majority of these - some 300,000 - have bought protection policies such as life, income replacement, critical illness and medical cover.

These have all been sold under the "Self Assurance" label. Scottish Provident has been very successful in replacing pensions and endowment sales with IFA based sales of protection - it is by far the biggest supplier of these plans in the independent area.

But oddly anyone who bought and still holds a protection policy sold before January 1996 counts as a member and will qualify for the flat £500 payment.

Around a further 40,000 policyholders are also excluded from the £2bn payment bonanza. They are holders of plans bought from the offshore arm - Scottish Provident International. This is legally a subsidiary of the with-profits fund so they do not have membership rights whatever policies they hold.

Abbey National customers receive nothing, although shareholders could profit if the deal lives up to the promise. Abbey's 15m account holders could see cheaper life cover if Scottish Provident products are sold in branches at the same price as sales through IFAs, and if sales of Aberdeen unit trusts are routed through branches.

Aberdeen, which is 39% owned by Scottish Provident, is being sacked in August 2002 as Scottish Provident's main fund manager in favour of the Abbey National in-house team.

The timetable now points to a vote on demutualisation early next year - probably at the end of January. Barring cataclysms, the result is a foregone conclusion. This will be followed by a virtual rubber stamping at the Court of Sessions in the summer.

With-profits policyholders will then be told exactly how much they stand to make. And all windfalls will be paid out in autumn 2001.

fields.headline: Savers on a slippery slope
fields.trailText: Banks and building societies have taken the hint from yet another announcement of unchanged Bank of England interest rates - they are using the standstill stance to edge the rates they pay to savers on to a downward slope.
fields.body:
Banks and building societies have taken the hint from yet another announcement of unchanged Bank of England interest rates - they are using the standstill stance to edge the rates they pay to savers on to a downward slope.

This leaves an offer of "up to 10% tax-efficient income from a top performing trust" as both a magnetic attraction for income seekers but also one which investors will treat with caution - headline promises of high income tend to come with small print traps.

Problems can include excessive charges or one-way bets, where any growth above the promised level belongs to the fund management company, whereas shortfalls are down to the investor who can see their capital eroded by up to half. Over and above all that, investors are locked in for typically five to six year periods with substantial penalties for those looking for an early exit.

But a new offer from Edinburgh-based investment trust group Ivory & Sime - now part of the Friends Provident group - tries to square the circle by offering up to 10% income to investors in its relaunched ISIS investment trust without hidden traps and the chance of capital growth. And for all but the richest investors, the income will effectively be tax free.

Ivory & Sime first launched an ISIS trust in 1993 with a seven-year life. That is now reaching its end - it will expire in October - but the existing holders voted to continue the trust and enlarge it. It is currently worth around £50m. After the new deal offer, it could grow to £90m but no further.

The fund invests in a portfolio of UK blue chip and smaller growth companies - with some success over five years where it emerged as the top trust in its class turning £1,000 into £2, 389 - although recently it has slipped with growth of 25.8% over the past year, just below the sector average.

But the main interest lies in its structure which manages to avoid normal investment trust rules which demand that 85% of the income from shares is distributed to shareholders who are then taxed.

Ivory & Sime has created a trust where the public buys "ordinary" shares which have no income. The yield from the shares goes to the holders of "fixed-rate annuity shares". They are a fiendishly complicated piece of financial engineering, but as they are all held by parent company Friends Provident and not traded, investors do not need to understand them. These shares are used to boost the capital to make up for the lack of income. The end result is that by encashing ordinary shares on a regular basis, investors can have an income stream which the Inland Revenue will count as a capital gain.

Provided the annual gain is below the capital gains tax exemption level - currently £7,200 per person - the income is effectively tax free.

Investors can select how much they want encashed between 0% and 10% a year - paid annually, quarterly or monthly - so the trust can generate long term growth.

"This decision can be changed at any time without charge or penalty," says Ivory & Sime's Fiona Mackenzie. "So you can decide to keep your capital intact if share prices fall or your need for income drops. Alternatively, you can sell in the market."

Charges are a very low 0.55% a year with no entry or exit costs. Launch investors do not pay stamp duty.

The one thing that can go wrong is that the underlying investments fail to grow. Those who continue to take their full income will find their investment shrinks.

It will face competition from the new LeggMason Investors American Assets fund which promises "outstanding growth potential and 8.25% income" although neither is guaranteed.

This investment trust will concentrate on US stocks with around half in blue chips listed in New York, around 15% in a portfolio of dollar denominated bonds with the balance in a portfolio of UK split level investment trusts. If the decline of the pound against the US currency continues, investors will make extra gains.

On top of all this, the fund will be almost doubled through a bank loan deal. For each £1 invested - the minimum is £1,000 - the fund will invest a further 94p through this borrowing.

There are a number of risks besides a reversal of the pound's current fortunes. A big interest rate increase could hit the bank loan; investing in split level investment trusts where many funds already invest in each other can be dangerous as a fall in one or two could have a house of cards effect; and the US stock market could go into reverse.

Investors with no interest in income but who fear stock market volatility might take advice on the Manor Park UK Accelerated Growth Fund.

This is a five year lockaway with a minimum £5,000 investment which guarantees it will repay the original capital at the end of the period no matter what happens to share prices. In addition, it will pay out 120% of any gain in the FTSE 100 index of top UK companies. There is no limit on the growth - guaranteed by top rated financial institutions.

Besides having to sign up for five years, the downside is that the fund ignores dividends which makes up a substantial part of long term growth.

fields.bodyText: Banks and building societies have taken the hint from yet another announcement of unchanged Bank of England interest rates - they are using the standstill stance to edge the rates they pay to savers on to a downward slope. This leaves an offer of "up to 10% tax-efficient income from a top performing trust" as both a magnetic attraction for income seekers but also one which investors will treat with caution - headline promises of high income tend to come with small print traps. Problems can include excessive charges or one-way bets, where any growth above the promised level belongs to the fund management company, whereas shortfalls are down to the investor who can see their capital eroded by up to half. Over and above all that, investors are locked in for typically five to six year periods with substantial penalties for those looking for an early exit. But a new offer from Edinburgh-based investment trust group Ivory & Sime - now part of the Friends Provident group - tries to square the circle by offering up to 10% income to investors in its relaunched ISIS investment trust without hidden traps and the chance of capital growth. And for all but the richest investors, the income will effectively be tax free. Ivory & Sime first launched an ISIS trust in 1993 with a seven-year life. That is now reaching its end - it will expire in October - but the existing holders voted to continue the trust and enlarge it. It is currently worth around £50m. After the new deal offer, it could grow to £90m but no further. The fund invests in a portfolio of UK blue chip and smaller growth companies - with some success over five years where it emerged as the top trust in its class turning £1,000 into £2, 389 - although recently it has slipped with growth of 25.8% over the past year, just below the sector average. Ivory & Sime has created a trust where the public buys "ordinary" shares which have no income. The yield from the shares goes to the holders of "fixed-rate annuity shares". They are a fiendishly complicated piece of financial engineering, but as they are all held by parent company Friends Provident and not traded, investors do not need to understand them. These shares are used to boost the capital to make up for the lack of income. Provided the annual gain is below the capital gains tax exemption level - currently £7,200 per person - the income is effectively tax free. webTitle: Markets still seem to go for high-tech

fields.headline: Markets still seem to go for high-tech
fields.standfirst: With indicators for the UK economy looking gloomy, Robin Stoddart assesess the prospects for small investors
fields.trailText: With indicators for the UK economy looking gloomy, Robin Stoddart assesess the prospects for small investors
fields.body:
As the revival in technology stocks, including BT, seems to have run its course, the influence of old economy issues is liable to increase, particularly during the post-holiday flood of results. For the most part these do not present a pretty picture as the overvalued pound and high raw materials prices hold down profits.

Chemical manufacturers are reporting tough conditions at home and little help from trends in Germany, which tends to set prices and provide the stiffest competition. Corus, the former British Steel, now merged with Hoogovens of Holland and its German partner, is wallowing in the red.

Growth companies such as the pharmaceutical leaders are raising earnings rapidly again, thanks to their overseas spread. But although there was a surprising rebound in optimism over manufacturing output and exports during the summer, stock market enthusiasm remains restricted to bright prospects in advanced technology and medium-sized and smaller firms with special attributes.

The outlook for the UK economy is less bright than for most other industrialised countries and more worrying than the City and pre-election Whitehall might have us believe. Strong tax revenues are no more a guarantee of wise spending than the lottery.

About the most pessimistic assessment of the economy, including the likely trend of inflation and interest rates, comes from Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, the US investment bank branch of Citigroup that acquired the largest UK investment house remaining outside foreign ownership in the Spring. Under the heading "Tarnished New Economy" the banking house contrasts poor productivity and investment here with the stellar performance across the Atlantic. The review warns of the impact of constantly rising domestic demand, fed by imports of well over a quarter of consumption, on the trade deficit, inflation and interest rates over the next year.

A rise in rates of a full percentage point is anticipated. Naturally, most of it will be after the next Budget and following the general election. Pay and labour costs are expected to accelerate and the emphasis on educational spending in the recent sharp loosening of the Chancellor's old restraints, will not quickly correct "shortfalls in education and skill standards" in the UK. Support for sterling is not assured.

It is noticeable that the rise in share prices to new peaks, particularly in Europe, included the lesser indices outside the top 100 shares in London, but left Vodafone and other leaders, particularly in manufacturing and retailing, cold. The smaller company funds that have performed best in London are once again those with a strong technology bias.

Among unit trusts, Close Beacon has benefited from early stage investing in new companies, achieving better than 200 per cent appreciation over a year and twice as much over five years. In just a year Artemis UK Small Cos and Murray Smaller have gained 150%, though over three and five years the smaller-sized and nimble Duncan Lawrie comes second, matched over the longer period by Gartmore UK and Irish with a 300 per cent leap. Edinburgh Fund Managers' unit fund in the sector has doubled over a year, but the average, including most smaller company insurance funds, grew by just over a third.

Among investment trusts AIM has recovered to stay at the top of the list of annual appreciation with a gain of 250 per cent, helped by the rise in top holding Transense Technology and the rebound in JSB Software. The share price has moved closer to asset values since vast profits in BATM were taken. Murray Enterprise managed 200 per cent, well ahead of next-placed Dresdner RCM Smaller and Eaglet.

Recently, Ivory & Sime UK Smaller seems to have caught some of stablemate AIM's verve, with Autonomy, Anite and London Bridge Software starring. Over recent months 3i Smaller Quoted Companies has led the way with a gain of a third, helped by the parent group's experience with Bookham and other new issues.

Although it slipped back Fleming European Fledgling would command number three position over three years. Along with TR European Growth, Beacon, Herald and Duncan Lawrie, it is over a longer period at the top of the whole London-managed smaller companies field. Wide international coverage lends strength and the Swiss pay TV encoder Kudelski was one of many stars last year.

Apart from the stake in the Fleming Frontier European Discovery Fund, which invests in newly-quoted companies, the largest stake was in Germany's Intershop Communications, the e-commerce software supplier. It appreciated 700%. The "new economy" strength of Holland and Sweden was recognised through holdings, including Versatel Telecom and internet consultants Framtidsfabriken.

webTitle: Older people are surfing the net

fields.headline: Silver surfers ride
fields.standfirst:
Growing numbers of older people in our society are expanding their power and influence through the net. Jill Papworth reports

Net news
fields.trailText: Growing numbers of older people in our society are expanding their power and influence through the net. Jill Papworth reports
fields.body:
An increasing number of websites are being aimed at "silver surfers", the fast-growing band of older people who are discovering the power of the internet.

"It's very easy to write older people off when it comes to new technology," says a spokesperson for Age Concern, the UK's largest charitable operation, which celebrates its 60th birthday this week. "But the reality is that one in four people aged 50 plus uses a computer in their spare time, some 2.2m older people already use the internet and even more email their friends and family."

Recognising the internet as a valuable information and communication tool for older people, particularly the isolated, Age Concern, in partnership with Microsoft, is piloting Mobile IT Training Sessions (MITS) around the UK to introduce the new technology to older people.

This week has also seen the launch Help the aged's website, which aims to provide 10.8m older people, their relatives and carers with information on all aspects relating to the older population. It allows visitors with poor vision to enlarge text on screen or change colours.

Help the Aged director general Michael Lake says: "The sheer power of the internet to inform and empower older people has the potential to change the way everyone lives their lives. For too long retired people have been excluded from the routes to political and social influence. This will now change as the silver surfers access services, consumer goods and government from the comfort of their own homes."

So where do novice silver surfers start? If you can't afford your own computer, many public libraries and local colleges offer cheap access to PCs and hundreds of day centres are also connecting up to give thousands of low-income pensioners ready access to internet sites.

There is a growing wealth of websites aimed at those in their middle to older years. Here is a taster of some worth visiting.

http://www.helptheaged.org.uk

This user-friendly site lets you access the charity's range of advice leaflets on subjects including pensions, residential care and welfare support as well as background briefings on the older population and government policy. You can also get information on events and campaigns, make donations online and register to receive emailed monthly policy update bulletins.

http://www.ageconcern.org.uk

This site comes with a useful guided tour with short cuts to its main sections including news, Age Concern publications, links to other useful websites and a huge range of factsheets on a range of topics for older people which you can read on screen or print.

http://www.bbb.org.uk

Baby Boomer Bistro is "an internet chat cafe designed for the over-50s" set up by Age Concern's sister organisation Age Resource. After registering by choosing a chat name and a password, you to join in online discussions about day-to-day events and topics by visiting different "rooms", some with specific themes and some designed for private chats. The rooms are regularly monitored to ensure they are not being abused.

http://www.arp.org.uk

The website for the Association of Retired and Persons over 50, Britain's largest campaigning organisation for people over 50 with 100,000-plus members. Lots of interesting and useful information on a wide range of topics including health, study, retirement, employment, property, caring, travel and finance, though the association is an introducer for financial products only from CGU Financial Services. Allows you to email your views on various topics.

http://www.vavo.com

Launched a year ago and now with over 40,000 registered members, this is described as the market leading "portal" or "online community" for people aged 45 and over where the site contents are largely dictated by what members want.

It offers access to a several channels including news, on-line shopping, health, travel, finance and dating, where you can read features and ask questions of experts.

You can also access more than 100 topic areas set up and run by members, complete with chat rooms, on anything from hobbies and leisure pursuits to campaigning issues such as lobbying for better pensions and getting older people back to work.

So popular is the site that more than 200 members are meeting face-to-face for a weekend in a hotel later this month to celebrate vavo.com's first birthday.

http://www.seniority.co.uk

Described as an, "informative, fun and interactive online community created by and for people aged 50(ish!)", this is a similar, but smaller, idea to vavo.com, though perhaps a bit more tricky to use.

http://www.idf50.co.uk

"I don't feel 50" is a lively site set up in 1998 as "the first UK site for over 50s" by Graham Andrews, who felt that existing over-50s organisations tended to be a bit, "po-faced and institutional". The aim of the site is to give' "practical, unbiased help to people aged 50-plus" and it gives lots of information on a range of serious subjects from financing your retirement to prostate cancer as well as lighter topics such as all-time favourite music albums. Also allows exchange of views via email.

http://www.hellsgeriatrics.com

An intriguing site which introduces itself by saying: "For too long the world wide web has been the domain of callow youth. Now it is time for the over-50s to fight back and claim their rightful status in cyberspace." It offers chat rooms and a small mix of both serious and fun topics including a section on alien life and a good humour section. Its irreverent tone is set by the caveat: "HG is a non-profit making organisation but not intentionally so!"

http://www.saga.co.uk

As the website for Saga magazine, the UK's largest monthly magazine for people aged 50 and over, this has the current issue online plus a large amount of archived material from past issues.

http://www.lifebegins.net

This is an online magazine for, "discerning 50-somethings" which offers great service for novice silver surfers because it explains the basics of website mechanics so clearly.

Its forum section, for example, is,"an electronic bulletin board on which you can submit your comments and views which stay on the board for three months and to which any number of people can respond" while its chat section offers, "instantaneous, simultaneous discussions without a written record of what has been said".

fields.headline: Volunteering steps forward
fields.standfirst: Firms that give their staff time to work in the community are finding it increasingly rewarding
fields.trailText: Firms that give their staff time to work in the community are finding it increasingly rewarding.
fields.body:
If figures from the National Centre for Volunteering are to be believed, half the population of the UK - 22 million people of working age - volunteer. They contribute 88 million hours a week to education, homelessness, the environment and many other causes.

'One of the strongest and most exciting current trends,' according to the NCV, 'is the number of companies backing their employees to volunteer.' This change, so that companies which used to give money now actively encourage staff to become involved, is partly explained, says the NCV, by the fact that the Government is encouraging business to become more involved in social problems and that companies are recognising the links between profitability and the wellbeing of their community.

But the main reason is that 'there are clear benefits for the company and staff - especially in skills development, team-building, enhanced public image and self-confidence', says the NCV.

Giving Time: Volunteering in the 21st Century, from the thinktank Demos and Community Service Volunteers (CSV), predicts that this trend will become part of corporate citizenship under the influenceof two pressures: attracting consumers and retaining staff.

The report's author, Gavin Mensah-Coker, says: 'People will look not only at prices, quality of services and merchandise but at the company's social policies and practices. Consumers will have more information and will assert their power through spending habits.' The report goes on to say that employee volunteering will be carefully managed and controlled by companies in order to maximise the return on their investment. 'Analytical models will establish the links between community involvement schemes and the profit margin of the company involved.'

On the benefits of volunteering for employee retention, Mensah-Coker says: 'With the "pick and mix" approach to career development replacing the "job-for-life" attitude, employers will have to work much harder to build employee loyalty. Part of that will be giving employees the opportunity to volunteer in company time without penalty, supporting the community in the ways that they choose.'

This is already happening through organisations such as CSV. Among the 100,000 people who volunteer through CSV each year are around 4,000 employee volunteers working for 300 different companies. These volunteers generate 36,000 hours of community support. According to CSV's Liz Hover: 'CSV encourages and supports employers who wish to involve their staff as volunteers in the community. This can be either through the management of a project or by providing advice, support and training to companies wishing to run the project themselves.'

One of CSV's highest-profile collaborations with business is its partnership with TXU Europe, formerly Eastern Group, the national energy provider. The 'Energy for Action' scheme offers TXU employees regular volunteer placements within their local community.

Erol Burns, a finance manager with Eastern Energy, is a volunteer: 'The company lets employees give half a day a month to help a local organisation with CSV and the volunteer must match that with personal time. I joined the scheme just over a year ago and have been working with the Ipswich and East Suffolk branch of Headway, which looks after people with serious head injuries.'

By organising and assisting in outdoor activities for patients at Ipswich hospital, Burns saves them the cost of a driver for day trips. 'The outings go extremely well. CSV provides a good support system and the training required. My advice to anyone thinking of volunteering is really just to have the right attitude: keep an open mind and don't be frightened to take on anything. At Headway there are full-time staff, which helps.'

He says: 'It is very satisfying to put something into the community, a win-win situation for everyone. It is good for my personal development, seeing how some people have to struggle in their daily lives, as well as the struggle the charity has to make ends meet; and it's good for the company, giving them the opportunity to show their commitment to a wider audience.

'I've made a lot of new friends. I go in every second Friday afternoon. I really look forward to it and I know they look forward to my visits - and that's a really lovely feeling.'

But volunteering is not always plain sailing. 'There can be pitfalls,' says Burns. 'Employees can find it hard to keep the commitment going. Both the volunteer and the charity have to be flexible. Balancing the pressures between work and the charity isn't always easy, and it can sometimes be hard finding half a day.

Yet despite the seeming rise in the number of schemes to encourage volun teering, either through workplace schemes or trying to reach individuals, many voluntary organisations still find it hard to attract volunteers.

Mark Walker is development officer at the northern region office of the Alzheimer's Disease Society and a passionate advocate of volunteering. 'We are not sexy at all. We find it hard to attract volunteers because people tend to think that we only deal with dribbling old people smelling of wee. Apart from the fact that that simply isn't the case, you can volunteer without having to have any contact with people with dementia. We pride ourselves on the support we give and the opportunities we provide for personal development. And we offer a range of options, from being a listening ear for carers, providing office support, even decorating an office badly in need of a coat of paint.'

For some volunteers, charities can offer the chance of changing careers and finding more fulfilling work. Says Walker: 'One of our volunteers who began on our helpline wanted a more compassionate job than she had at the Benefits Agency. She went on to work for us full time for two years and has now moved to another extremely good job in the voluntary sector.'

 CSV: 020 7278 6601; NCV: 020 7520 8900

How to become involved

The following involve giving time or skills to the community, in or out of company time, on a regular or occasional basis:

Team challenges
These involve events where a group of employees tackle a community problem or task, while building teamworking skills. Increasingly this has become the popular choice of companies who want to strengthen teams but not to engage in overly physical team activities.

Development assignments
These have two very clear objectives: to complete a real project in a charity, and to develop the employee's individual skills, typically over 100 hours.

Secondments for transitions
At times of major career change or in preparation for retirement, for periods of three-to-24 months, the secondee joins the community organisation while remaining an employee of his or her firm.

Mentoring
A one-to-one basis for involvement, particularly popular in education, but also growing fast in the voluntary sector, often at senior management level.

Business on board
Volunteers serve as trustees on management committees of community organisations and not-for-profit bodies.

Other
Other ways to get involved include match-giving, where the employer matches employees' charitable contribution and participation in fundraising events.
