fields.bodyText: If figures from the National Centre for Volunteering are to be believed, half the population of the UK - 22 million people of working age - volunteer. They contribute 88 million hours a week to education, homelessness, the environment and many other causes. 'One of the strongest and most exciting current trends,' according to the NCV, 'is the number of companies backing their employees to volunteer.' This change, so that companies which used to give money now actively encourage staff to become involved, is partly explained, says the NCV, by the fact that the Government is encouraging business to become more involved in social problems and that companies are recognising the links between profitability and the wellbeing of their community. But the main reason is that 'there are clear benefits for the company and staff - especially in skills development, team-building, enhanced public image and self-confidence', says the NCV. Giving Time: Volunteering in the 21st Century, from the thinktank Demos and Community Service Volunteers (CSV), predicts that this trend will become part of corporate citizenship under the influenceof two pressures: attracting consumers and retaining staff. The report's author, Gavin Mensah-Coker, says: 'People will look not only at prices, quality of services and merchandise but at the company's social policies and practices. Consumers will have more information and will assert their power through spending habits.' The report goes on to say that employee volunteering will be carefully managed and controlled by companies in order to maximise the return on their investment. 'Analytical models will establish the links between community involvement schemes and the profit margin of the company involved.' On the benefits of volunteering for employee retention, Mensah-Coker says: 'With the "pick and mix" approach to career development replacing the "job-for-life" attitude, employers will have to work much harder to build employee loyalty. Part of that will be giving employees the opportunity to volunteer in company time without penalty, supporting the community in the ways that they choose.' This is already happening through organisations such as CSV. Among the 100,000 people who volunteer through CSV each year are around 4,000 employee volunteers working for 300 different companies. These volunteers generate 36,000 hours of community support. According to CSV's Liz Hover: 'CSV encourages and supports employers who wish to involve their staff as volunteers in the community. This can be either through the management of a project or by providing advice, support and training to companies wishing to run the project themselves.' One of CSV's highest-profile collaborations with business is its partnership with TXU Europe, formerly Eastern Group, the national energy provider. The 'Energy for Action' scheme offers TXU employees regular volunteer placements within their local community. Erol Burns, a finance manager with Eastern Energy, is a volunteer: 'The company lets employees give half a day a month to help a local organisation with CSV and the volunteer must match that with personal time. I joined the scheme just over a year ago and have been working with the Ipswich and East Suffolk branch of Headway, which looks after people with serious head injuries.' By organising and assisting in outdoor activities for patients at Ipswich hospital, Burns saves them the cost of a driver for day trips. 'The outings go extremely well. CSV provides a good support system and the training required. My advice to anyone thinking of volunteering is really just to have the right attitude: keep an open mind and don't be frightened to take on anything. At Headway there are full-time staff, which helps.' He says: 'It is very satisfying to put something into the community, a win-win situation for everyone. It is good for my personal development, seeing how some people have to struggle in their daily lives, as well as the struggle the charity has to make ends meet; and it's good for the company, giving them the opportunity to show their commitment to a wider audience. 'I've made a lot of new friends. I go in every second Friday afternoon. I really look forward to it and I know they look forward to my visits - and that's a really lovely feeling.' But volunteering is not always plain sailing. 'There can be pitfalls,' says Burns. 'Employees can find it hard to keep the commitment going. Both the volunteer and the charity have to be flexible. Balancing the pressures between work and the charity isn't always easy, and it can sometimes be hard finding half a day. Yet despite the seeming rise in the number of schemes to encourage volun teering, either through workplace schemes or trying to reach individuals, many voluntary organisations still find it hard to attract volunteers. Mark Walker is development officer at the northern region office of the Alzheimer's Disease Society and a passionate advocate of volunteering. 'We are not sexy at all. We find it hard to attract volunteers because people tend to think that we only deal with dribbling old people smelling of wee. Apart from the fact that that simply isn't the case, you can volunteer without having to have any contact with people with dementia. We pride ourselves on the support we give and the opportunities we provide for personal development. And we offer a range of options, from being a listening ear for carers, providing office support, even decorating an office badly in need of a coat of paint.' For some volunteers, charities can offer the chance of changing careers and finding more fulfilling work. Says Walker: 'One of our volunteers who began on our helpline wanted a more compassionate job than she had at the Benefits Agency. She went on to work for us full time for two years and has now moved to another extremely good job in the voluntary sector.'  CSV: 020 7278 6601; NCV: 020 7520 8900 How to become involved The following involve giving time or skills to the community, in or out of company time, on a regular or occasional basis: Team challenges These involve events where a group of employees tackle a community problem or task, while building teamworking skills. Increasingly this has become the popular choice of companies who want to strengthen teams but not to engage in overly physical team activities. Development assignments These have two very clear objectives: to complete a real project in a charity, and to develop the employee's individual skills, typically over 100 hours. Secondments for transitions At times of major career change or in preparation for retirement, for periods of three-to-24 months, the secondee joins the community organisation while remaining an employee of his or her firm. Mentoring A one-to-one basis for involvement, particularly popular in education, but also growing fast in the voluntary sector, often at senior management level. Business on board Volunteers serve as trustees on management committees of community organisations and not-for-profit bodies. Other Other ways to get involved include match-giving, where the employer matches employees' charitable contribution and participation in fundraising events.  Source: National Centre for Volunteering

fields.headline: High-tech investors on the button
fields.trailText: The speculative frenzy in small-tech stocks that gripped the market in January and February returned last week, but the revival turned out to be short-lived.
fields.body:
The speculative frenzy in small-tech stocks that gripped the market in January and February returned last week, but the revival turned out to be short-lived.

On September 1 the FTSE 100 index soared by 123.5 points to touch a year high of 6,795. Some of the small high-tech shares favoured by dot.com investors leapt in value, with Durlacher up by 29% on the day. Barclays Stockbrokers says that the number of trades it handles, which has been running at around 6,000 per day, suddenly jumped to 10,000.

Unfortunately another feature of earlier this year also returned; the computer systems handling trades at both Charles Schwab and Barclays Stockbrokers temporarily went out of action.

But by Tuesday this week the revival had petered out and later in the week the FTSE was trading back below 6,700 points. So was it just a flash in the pan or a sign that there are a lot of buyers waiting on the sidelines?

According to Justin Urquhart Stewart of Barclays Stockbrokers, there was evidence that some small investors used the spike in the market to offload a lot of the bombed-out shares they have been holding at a loss.

"We saw a big wave of buying on Thursday, Friday and Monday, and then saw almost exactly the same people selling again in the following days. It may be that some people are taking profits and there are signs that people are jumping out as much as jumping in. When there is the slightest show of enthusiasm on Nasdaq for technology stocks, small investors come into the market to sell out again."

However, Mr Urquhart Stewart also believes there is another wave of people waiting to begin investing in technology shares who are waiting for the right time.

webTitle: Ruthless Surrey leave nothing to chance

fields.headline: Ruthless Surrey leave nothing to chance
fields.standfirst:
Surrey 453-4dec
Durham 165-6
fields.trailText:
Surrey 453-4dec

Durham 165-6
fields.body:
There were times when Mark Butcher and Ian Ward looked as if they would never be parted. The two left-handers moved on remorselessly from the night before, not much extended by Durham's range of bowlers. The disparity in stature between these counties was almost tangible.

The stand was worth 359, only 20 short of what would have been a Surrey record for the first wicket in the County Championship, achieved by Abel and Brockwell in 1897. And there was even a suggestion that either Butcher or Ward might have slightly unrealistic visions of approaching Bobby Abel's historic 357 on this ground in another match, just over 100 years ago.

This was run-making the easy way, despite Durham's best-intentioned efforts from all too meagre resources. It even seemed as though the partnership might have to be broken by the batsmen themselves. For some odd reason, considering the affinity the two had revealed, they once ran into each other as they crossed. It was almost as if they felt they needed to introduce an element of danger to spice the alliance.

Then suddenly Ward was leg-before to Simon Brown, who in his best spell so far had just got past the bat more than once. Ward's 144, full of clean, measured driving, contained 13 boundaries.

Butcher, now in unfamiliar company, lost a little of his composure, as is so often the case. He might have been caught in the covers, again off Brown, and finally lost his off stump to Steve Harmison. It was an overdue psychological fillip for a bowler whose progress this season has been so indeterminate.

Butcher's innings of 191 was his second highest and his 16th hundred. In just over seven hours he had punched and pulled 23 boundaries, as well as treating himself to a third-man six through Harmison's generosity. It was Butcher at his best.

From this point Surrey were thinking of the declaration and going for their shots. Nadeem Shahid was in most attractive mode until caught at mid-on; Adam Hollioake was out to an extravagant hook before bringing his team in. Saqlain Mushtaq's fingers were tingling by now, and Ian Salisbury was thinking, reasonably enough, of another fruitful pairing in prospect.

And so it proved. The spinners were soon on, though not before Martin Bicknell had conjured up a beauty of genuine pace which seamed back to bowl Jon Lewis, temporarily in charge of his demoted team.

Surrey can be ruthless executioners. They don't spare feelings - nor chances. Not only are they the best balanced bowling side in the country, they field as if impatiently scenting an innings defeat for Durham and the looming opening of the drinks cabinet.

It is clearly contagious. Alex Tudor, hardly renowned as the most agile member of the side, stretched that elongated frame, balletic by his standards, to catch Paul Collingwood at mid-on. Ward then sprawled sideways to hold on to Jimmy Daley's cover drive.

Simon Katich alone had stayed resolutely before being last out on the day, stumped off a bold pull against Salisbury. It was patently unwise as the ball was turning with ominous regularity and four of the wickets so far have gone to the leg-spinner. Durham, having conceded the biggest stand against them so far in a first-class fixture - exceeding that in the match when Brian Lara scored 501 - are 288 behind.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Darren Lehmann, Yorkshire's Australian left- hander, continued to mine his rich vein of form with a century in only 89 balls on the opening day of the First Division game against Kent in Canterbury.
fields.body:
Darren Lehmann, Yorkshire's Australian left- hander, continued to mine his rich vein of form with a century in only 89 balls on the opening day of the First Division game against Kent in Canterbury.

It was a fourth first-class century of the season for the championship's leading run-scorer. Anthony McGrath, with 133, and Michael Vaughan, 69, played their part and the Tykes were 365 for seven at stumps.

Derbyshire's batsmen made a defiant response to Hampshire's huge first- innings total in Southampton. Luke Sutton and Michael Di Venuto each hit a half- century as Derbyshire closed the second day at 188 for two on a placid pitch. Shane Warne, 34, and Dimitri Mascarenhas, 62, had pushed Hampshire up from 368 for four overnight to 522.

Andrew Harris, five for 69, claimed his fourth five-wicket haul of the season as Nottinghamshire ripped through Glamorgan to enforce the follow-on at Trent Bridge. The Welsh club tumbled to 187 all out and then lost three quick wickets to end up 22 for three at stumps, still 161 behind.

The Australian Ian Harvey claimed championship-best figures of six for 19 as the one-day kings Gloucestershire kept their promotion drive alive in the four-day game in Hove. Sussex were skittled out for 138 but the visitors showed that the pitch was not to blame by reaching 74 for two.

Mark Ramprakash, 88no, and Justin Langer smashed Middlesex back into contention against Warwickshire at Lord's. Langer reached 50 off only 27 deliveries and helped the hosts end their first innings on 350, 66 behind. Poor bowling then handed the initiative back to the visitors, who moved on to 109 for one, a lead of 175.

webTitle: The best form of defence is defence

fields.headline: The best form of defence is defence
fields.trailText: This week has certainly shown one thing: that the quality of Premiership defending has dropped. While Chelsea were throwing away a two-goal lead over Arsenal, Middlesbrough were letting Derby back from three down. And that after Spurs had recovered to beat Everton the night before. Let's be honest, it would not have happened in Serie A.
fields.body:
This week has certainly shown one thing: that the quality of Premiership defending has dropped. While Chelsea were throwing away a two-goal lead over Arsenal, Middlesbrough were letting Derby back from three down. And that after Spurs had recovered to beat Everton the night before. Let's be honest, it would not have happened in Serie A.

Seven times this season top-flight clubs have let points slip after being two or three goals up; even Manchester United got in on the act at West Ham. And George Graham is spot on when he says there are not as many good defenders around.

To my mind not enough want to do the ugly work the job's all about: throwing themselves in the way of shots and crosses, and not just nicking or jockeying but making full-blooded tackles. Too many seem to be looking for the ball when it breaks and thinking how they can start an attack.

Whenever you talk to people in the game about centre-backs these days the first thing they ask is "Can he bring the ball out?" But that should not be the issue.

Italy were the best team defensively in Euro 2000 and they were hardly pretty to watch. Alessandro Nesta and Fabio Cannavaro occasionally played a decent pass but more than anything they were blocking, tackling, scrambling things away and sprinting to close down. To a good defender a yard is a mile, and some here need reminding what it's about.

Italy proved that despite the tightening up by referees there is still room for strong tackles and bravery. The change in the Premiership may be related to the number of foreign defenders, some of whom rely on interceptions and jockeying rather than the blood-and-guts stuff.

But I also wonder whether it might be down to the environment the British lads are brought up in. There may be a slight comfort zone. Not everyone is like Stuart Pearce or Terry Butcher, who could have been paid £20m a week in their mid-20s and would still have put their career at risk if there was a ball to be won.

I must emphasise that I love flowing, attacking football and would hate the emphasis to be switched to defence. Nor do I think centre-halves should be cloggers. But I used to remind my defenders that they were paid to defend. I would tell them: "Get hit in the face, get hit in the groin, wherever. But I don't want to see you get hit on the backside."

That's why I regard Paul McGrath as the finest centre-half I worked with. People said Paul was a class act but his biggest strength for me at United and Aston Villa was that he was brave and he won the ball. I think he could have used the ball better but he made a centre-forward's job hard.

There are not many around in his mould now. For my money Ugo Ehiogu and Martin Keown are the best defending centre-backs in the country, and Jaap Stam also reminds me of an old-fashioned English centre-half, adequate with the ball but a great destroyer.

P eople such as they thrive on defending but I don't think it means a lot to many others. Even Sol Campbell never gives me the impression he really wants to put his body in front of shots. And in that respect the cupboard looks pretty bare for England in the future. Rio Ferdinand and Gareth Barry are not that type.

It must be said that a defender's lot is harder now. The tempo is quicker, the accent is more on attack and the quality of forward is far better. Mental tiredness may be a problem.

Of course defenders have not been helped by changes to the offside and back-pass laws either. Teams such as Arsenal used to squeeze up the park and anything over the top was turned back for the keeper to pick up. It is not so easy now.

The 3-5-2 formation can also cause problems because several wing-backs are good coming forward and weak at the back. But the bottom line is that the quality of defending is deteriorating.

I have felt for a while that England would struggle to hold teams out. And much as I love watching Nwankwo Kanu or Gianfranco Zola, it would be nice to see one or two homegrown players emerge determined to protect the goal with their life.

fields.headline: Kewell ruled out until Christmas
fields.trailText: Leeds United will have to contest the Champions League first-round group stage without Harry Kewell, after their player of the year last season was yesterday ruled out of the game for three months.
fields.body:
Leeds United will have to contest the Champions League first-round group stage without Harry Kewell, after their player of the year last season was yesterday ruled out of the game for three months.

The forward will have an operation today to clean up the area around the damaged achilles tendon which forced his withdrawal from Australia's Olympic squad.

After visiting a specialist in Monaco over the summer Kewell had been advised to sit out pre-season training in the hope that the problem would right itself. But the Leeds medical staff now believe there is no alternative to surgery.

"You have to give people the chance to recover without surgery but I always thought this could happen," said David O'Leary, Leeds's manager. "It is a big blow but it will be great to see him fit and strong in December."

Dean Sturridge has reacted to allegations from Middlesbrough's manager Bryan Robson that Derby had "cheated" their way back from 3-0 down to earn a point in Wednesday's match at Pride Park.

Robson was incensed that after Paul Ince kicked the ball into touch so that Phil Stamp could receive treatment, Sturridge failed to return it from the throw-in. Instead the Derby forward threw it to Deon Burton, who won a corner from which Branko Strupar scored.

"Middlesbrough were cheating," Sturridge retorted. "Phil Stamp went down but the referee told him to get up and he did straight away. There didn't seem to be much wrong with him.

"Paul Ince just kicked the ball out to waste time because they were dying on their feet and we had them under the cosh." Sturridge added that he had been following his manager Jim Smith's instructions. "He was screaming at me to throw the ball to Deon, so I did."

A referee, Steve Lodge, has been charged by the Football Association with a "technical irregularity" after failing to book Patrick Vieira and Silvinho for removing their shirts while celebrating goals in Arsenal's 5-3 win over Charlton last month. Although Lodge will have to explain why he failed to apply the mandate, which was introduced before the season, he is unlikely to be suspended.

Nigeria, the Olympic champions, have accepted that Arsenal's Nwankwo Kanu will not be linking up with the squad for the Sydney games. "We regret Kanu's absence but then there are other players we believe could equally represent Nigeria," said a spokesman for its FA.

Dwight Yorke's return to Manchester United 24 hours later than expected, after playing in a World Cup qualifier, has been played down by the Trinidad & Tobago FA. It is understood that Yorke and several of his British-based team-mates stayed to celebrate the 4-0 victory over Canada which booked their country a place in the final Concacaf qualifying round.

"We were aware of this after the fact," a spokesman said. "There may have been an incident but we don't really know."

The win means that Trinidad and Tobago will play 10 more games during 2001, in addition to two more group matches this year. However, its FA believes they will coincide with dates in Europe. "Concacaf is not the only region playing qualifying games; England are going to have qualifying matches as well over the next year," the spokesman added.

North Korea will not stage matches in the 2002 World Cup despite the easing of tensions with South Korea, joint hosts with Japan. A total of 20 venues will be used, with France beginning their defence of the trophy on May 31 in Seoul. The final takes place in Yokohama, Japan, on June 30.

 Celtic's Martin O'Neill has won Scotland's manager of the month award for August.

webTitle: Spin fails to queer Northants pitch

fields.headline: Spin fails to queer Northants pitch
fields.standfirst:
Essex 233
Northamptonshire 337-7
fields.trailText: Spin by the truckload, strokes to swoon over, a bareheaded batsman, at least one adherent of the Fred Astaire school of footwork , and another giant step for Northamptonshire-kind. What more, bar the odd ray of sun, could the neutral possibly ask for? Certainly not a 24-hour wait to discover whether the pitch was suitable.
fields.body:
Spin by the truckload, strokes to swoon over, a bareheaded batsman, at least one adherent of the Fred Astaire school of footwork , and another giant step for Northamptonshire-kind. What more, bar the odd ray of sun, could the neutral possibly ask for? Certainly not a 24-hour wait to discover whether the pitch was suitable.

Perturbed by the degree of turn on the first day, Phil Sharpe, the pitch liaison officer, had summoned AC Smith "for a second opinion". This was a mite worrying. During the latter's tenure as chief executive of the Test and County Cricket Board, after all, so reluctant was he to commit himself that, if his wife had asked him what time she could expect him for supper, she would probably have received a clipped "No comment".

At length, happily, decisiveness prevailed, not to mention common sense and justice. The not-guilty verdict came shortly after tea, drawing rapturous applause, though by then nerves were all but shot.

"It had been quite stressful up till then," admitted Bob Carter, Northants' director of cricket, relief palpable. "It definitely spoilt the celebrations after we'd supposedly clinched promotion on Wednesday, but tonight I think we'll make up for it." The sound of corks a-popping confirmed as much.

"We're trying to produce cricketers to do well at a higher level," Carter added, tact and exasperation mingling uneasily. "We've got two spin bowlers who can turn the ball and that can only be good for English cricket."

The case for the defence was impressive. Jason Brown claimed that most of his victims fell to the arm ball. Peter Such, the circuit's most experienced twirler, did not strike until his 18th over. The most eloquent rebuttal, though, came from Matthew Hayden, whose superlative season's- best 164, his fourth century, spanned the best part of six hours, during the course of which he revived that terribly old-fashioned stricture about moving one's feet. That he happens to be Australian is assuredly no coincidence.

So dominant was the home captain that he made almost 60% of the 294 runs scored off the bat during his imperious reign. David Sales matched him during a third-wicket stand of 122 but more via force than felicity. Upon reaching 50, Hayden made a polite but pointed gesture to the pitch panel. He would have been eminently justified in taking a leaf out of Harvey Smith's book.

fields.headline: Scary Movie
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It doesn't quite work, but the Wayans writing-directing team is clearly a potent talent for the coming decade
fields.body:
The first 20 minutes or so of the Wayans brothers' Scary Movie are sublimely enjoyable, not just for the inspired teen-horror spoof but for the happy reminder of the 1977 grossout classic Kentucky Fried Movie, with its uproarious Catholic High School Girls In Trouble. In fact, the whole of Scary Movie's pre-credit sequence could function very well as a sketch for KFM.

Some critics have wondered aloud what the point is of parodying movies like Scream and I Know What You Did Last Summer, which already have archly ironic self-awareness. The aspiration of the Wayans brothers is simpler than that of Kevin Williamson, who wants to have his cake and eat it with movies which are genuinely scary but also demonstrate the director's connoisseurship of the genre. The Wayans brothers just want to make us laugh, arguably a more attractive vocation.

And for the first 20 minutes, they do. After that the gag-rate plummets, and it's a long haul to the credits. Scary Movie doesn't quite work, but the Wayans writing-directing team is clearly a potent talent for the coming decade.

fields.headline: A poem of darkness
fields.standfirst: Peter Bradshaw hails a haunting, disturbing, daring - and misunderstood - masterpiece from Bruno Dumont
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Every time I watch it, I am possessed with an Ancient Mariner-like desire to grab the sleeves of passers-by and tell them to see it. Its scenes, its images, its strange atmospherics reverberate ineradicably in the mind
fields.body:
When L'Humanité was shown in Cannes last year, it was jeered to the echo. Many critics mocked the movie, denouncing it for its glacial, pseudo-Bressonian slowness and failure to function plausibly either as a policier or a psychological study. Most damningly of all, it was held to have been a disastrous follow-up to Dumont's much-admired first film, La Vie de Jésus.

But I can't agree. Far from being a disappointment or an artistic wrong turning, Dumont's film is a cogent development from La Vie de Jésus and nothing less than a masterpiece: haunting, disturbing and daring. It resists the generic boundaries of thriller, or police drama, or realist conventions of any sort, seeming instead to attain the status of some horrifying, extended bad dream which has somehow been tricked out with the superficial appurtenances of real life. Only its inconsistencies and unrealities hint at the fact that the viewer has actually been immersed in a strange nightmare universe: a hyper-real poem of darkness.

Just as in La Vie de Jésus, the action takes place in the grim, undistinguished countryside of northern France. Admirers of that film will remember that its hero Freddy, having been taken into police custody on a serious criminal charge, is for some reason allowed to wander out and lie down in a cornfield for the final shot. Then, Dumont hinted at the discovery of a subversive, even a darkly playful way of subtly modifying the realities of day-to-day life, these realities being the more coercive, and their contravention the more disquieting, for being police realities.

In this film, an 11-year-old girl has been brutally raped and murdered. Dumont does not scruple to show the naked corpse, left on the edge of a ploughed field. The camera, in one of its many slow, silent takes, shows tiny ants scurrying over the pitifully pale, bruised skin. But just before this, we have seen Pharaon (Emmanuel Schotté) running over this field, and collapsing in the mud, his bulging eyes staring straight ahead. Pharaon turns out to be a police superintendent investigating the case and, moreover, a painfully inadequate individual whose strange, torpid manner is due to his girlfriend and baby having recently died. So we are invited to assume that Pharaon is in fact the murderer.

Or are we? As the film continues, nothing in Pharaon's behaviour is obviously consistent with the classic template of a deranged murderer gradually disclosing his true self to the camera; in fact his weird running across the field might be some sort of intuitive, premonitory empathy with the victim.

Pharaon is to all intents and purposes a simpleton, a virtual village idiot. And yet he is also a police officer, despite the fact that, as one of the locals snarls at him: "You're too stupid to be a cop!" Indeed, the entire police department conduct their investigations in what looks like a very lugubrious and casual manner; there seems no systematic interrogation of witnesses, no DNA analysis, and an approach to a local psychiatric hospital is casually suggested by one of the sergeants on the basis that his brother-in-law works there. The top brass from "Paris and Lille" are supposed to be helping but nowhere is their big-city sophistication to be seen in the film.

But this does not diminish its haunting power, because the police-procedural qualities carry a subtly parodic air; they are a puzzle; they are defiantly at odds with a rational existence. And in any case, they are subservient to the scalp-prickling anxiety and creeping sense of horror that Dumont slowly but surely accumulates, largely through Pharaon's fascination with unpleasant phenomena, such as the beefy sweatiness of his inspector's neck, similar to the revolting pink flesh of a sow and her litter in the farmyard of the victim's family, the queasy panoply of "humanity".

It is one of the most bizarre, yet somehow inspired touches of this film that Pharaon turns out to be the grandson of a distinguished artist, also called Pharaon De Winter, whose brooding self-portrait Pharaon loans to a local gallery. Is his obsessiveness, his stupefied, faintly malign obsession with pain the remnant of an artistic nature? Like so much else in this captivating film, it is a mystery.

L'Humanité demands a considerable investment of attention, and a willingness to enter Dumont's islanded world of violence and dysfunction and accept it partly as an elaborate, visionary metaphor. Once that investment is made, the rewards are very great. Every time I watch it, I am possessed with an Ancient Mariner-like desire to grab the sleeves of passers-by and tell them to see it. Its scenes, its images, its strange atmospherics reverberate ineradicably in the mind.

webTitle: Fishing for the truth about Murdoch the Piscean

fields.headline: Fishing for the truth about Murdoch the Piscean
fields.standfirst: Shark or dolphin? The Media Medium wonders if there is something fishy about Rupert Murdoch.
fields.trailText: Shark or dolphin? The Media Medium wonders if there is something fishy about Rupert Murdoch.
fields.body:
Pisceans often get a good press for being dreamy, artistic and compassionate. You can be forgiven then for failing to recognise media mogul Rupert Murdoch as a paid-up Piscean (11.59pm GST, March 11 1931, Melbourne).

What the books often forget is the inner contradiction in Pisces. The symbol is two fish swimming in opposite directions. One is a helpful dolphin, the other an all-devouring shark.

Murdoch's watery nature is compounded by three planets in Cancer the crab. Water signs run deep and shy away from the sunlight, like fish beneath the surface or crabs scuttling under rocks.

This can be an asset in a business context because water knows which way the tides are turning. Murdoch couples this with a libertarian, entrepreneurial moon in horsy Sagittarius, which loves the thrill of the chase. Only now - in the dot.com era - is his confidence beginning to wane with projects like FiredUp.

Murdoch's silver-spoon background and good fortune come from Jupiter in Cancer - the family sign - and its connections with the moon. But what really drives him on?

His daughter Elisabeth seems to speak truthfully when she says her father is not driven by greed. Murdoch's published time of birth gives us a fuller psychological profile than one based only on his day of birth. His ambitious Capricorn Ascendant is tied in with an opposition of controlling Saturn and autocratic Pluto, right across his money and death zones.

Murdoch's media career began in 1952 when his father died suddenly and he returned to Australia to take over the family publishing business.

Saturn-Pluto transmutes mortality into cash - a burden of responsibility which forever pursues him like the ghost of the father. The question of legacy for him now is the same question that has always been there, binding his offspring through a business empire.

The current focus in his horoscope is on Neptune crossing Venus until the end of November 2001. This god of the sea has been his empire builder, but now it suggests sacrifice and dissolution.

Neptune's same influence triggers News International's UK horoscope (July 28 1904), perhaps putting it at sea in the coming months. Murdoch is slipping towards a dissolving agenda, rather than a definitive stand-down.

He may take a major step along these lines in February, but how will the family shape up? Elisabeth, Lachlan, James... watch this space for further astro-analysis, coming soon.

fields.headline: Brussels backs off on transfers
fields.standfirst: Upbeat mood as attention shifts to new system of compensation
fields.trailText: Football breathed a huge sigh of relief yesterday when the European Commission stepped back from the brink of insisting that transfer fees be abolished.
fields.body:
Football breathed a huge sigh of relief yesterday when the European Commission stepped back from the brink of insisting that transfer fees be abolished.

After a meeting with various representatives of the European game, the commissioner for education and culture, Viviane Reding, is understood to have agreed that a form of compensation should replace the current system when players move between clubs during their contracts.

This compromise will go some way to easing the worries of clubs throughout Europe who feared the consequences of losing transfer income, especially smaller clubs who would have faced bankruptcy.

The newly formed Transfer Task Force will now set about framing specific models of compensation to put to the commission by the end of next month. The task force's first meeting is on Tuesday. The ultimate aim is to reach agreement with the commission on a replacement for transfer fees by the end of the year.

"I'm confident that with goodwill from all sides a satisfactory solution is within reach," said Reding. "Between now and October the ball is in the footballers' half of the pitch."

Uefa, the European game's governing body, which has taken the lead in negotiations with the commission after widespread disillusionment with the world body Fifa's attempts to broker a deal, was equally optimistic."We had a very positive and very constructive meeting," said Uefa's director of communications Mike Lee. "It is the first time European football has put its concerns to the commission and they were received very well by Viviane Reding."

The prime minister Tony Blair had promised to apply governmental pressure to safeguard some form of transfer fee and yesterday won the backing of the German chancellor Gerhard Schröder for a French-led campaign to keep the system. "We thought Mr Blair's statement very helpful," said Lee.

The commission's principal objection to the current system of transfer fees is that the clubs effectively operate as a cartel, preventing the freedom of movement of labour as laid down in the Treaty of Rome.

Though Uefa and the European leagues present yesterday acknowledge that some change is necessary to get round this problem, they - and various European governments - argue that football should be treated as a special case because the current system has the benefits of redistributing funds among clubs, financing investment in youth training, maintaining some contractual obligation between player and club, and ensuring a level of compensation for a player's loss.

Pedro Tomas of the Spanish league said: "The world of professional football does not wish in any way to operate outside the scope of the Treaty of Rome, but the specific nature of football as a sport is recognised across Europe."

This has been accepted by the commission to a degree, though it has still to agree to a precise plan. Last week Fifa alarmed Uefa and the European leagues by agreeing to abandon any transfer fees for players over 24. This is now an unlikely outcome.

One of the alternative models being considered by the task force, which comprises representatives of Uefa, Fifa, the Spanish and German leagues, and Fipro, the international players' organisation, is based on the Spanish transfer system in which a future fee is agreed between a player and a club when he signs.

Should he subsequently change clubs, that is the transfer fee payable.

This solution would circumvent accusations of restricting players' freedom of movement because they would have freely entered into the agreement in the first place.

Luis Figo, who recently moved from Barcelona to Real Madrid, had a buy-out clause in his Nou Camp contract stating that any potential purchaser would have to pay £37m. Real did so.

Should this system be chosen, a ceiling might have to be set to avoid further inflationary sums. In addition Reding suggested that a uniform transfer window be introduced, and that some form of compensation for younger players was also acceptable.

fields.headline: The Sydney Olympics
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Sydney Olympics
Sign up for our special email service, The Olympian
fields.trailText: 1. Don't tell anyone, but there's going to be a few little sporting events in Sydney over the next couple of weeks. Not that serious, really. Low-key, you know. Might be worth popping along.
fields.body:
1. Don't tell anyone, but there's going to be a few little sporting events in Sydney over the next couple of weeks. Not that serious, really. Low-key, you know. Might be worth popping along.

2. The Olympic events are spread around the city, but the main focus of attention will be the Olympic Park.

3. That's where the main stadium will host Saturday's opening ceremony, most athletic events and both football finals. It's nine miles out of town.

4. Then there are numerous other stadiums dotted around for the dozens of sports on show. It's a sport-freak's playground, but you might be in need of performance-enhancing drugs yourself in order to keep up with the frenetic carnival of events.

5. Triathlon, biathlon, weightlifting, swimming, archery - these Spartan spectacles are a bit austere after a while. For something more in keeping with the Sydney vibe, hit Bondi for the beach volleyball. Infamously easy on the eye, in idyllic surroundings, you may just never get to the Olympic Park. Surfing's not an Olympic sport yet though.

6. Sydney's also becoming renowned as a Pacific-situated crucible for western and oriental cultures. Appropriately, eastern martial arts have crept into Olympic schedules in recent games - you can watch judo at Darling Harbour and lithe-limbed taekwondo at the state sports centre at the Park. The Chinese table tennis stars will also be showcasing their mantis-like dexterity at the latter.

7. If you're really digging this cultural melange, then it's probably time you hit out into the city. Sydney has some fantastic fusion cooking, blending European and Asian styles: Rockpool, on George Street, is one celebrated example. The kaleidoscopic variety of different options is dazzling: best bring a decent restaurant guide.

8. And just in case, by some miracle, the inevitably cack-handed symbolism of the opening ceremony is lost on the punters, there are a number of Olympic-related exhibitions taking place.

9. Bone up on Olympic history at the Powerhouse Museum, benefit from a, like, conceptual exploration of sport at the Museum of Contemporary Art and then there's a gargantuan Olympic Arts Festival to keep you topped up on culture. Strewth!

10. Oh, and there's a bridge and that weird opera house to visit too.

And just in case, by some miracle, the inevitably cack-handed symbolism of the opening ceremony is lost on the punters, there are a number of Olympic-related exhibitions taking place. 9. Bone up on Olympic history at the Powerhouse Museum, benefit from a, like, conceptual exploration of sport at the Museum of Contemporary Art and then there's a gargantuan Olympic Arts Festival to keep you topped up on culture. Strewth! 10. Oh, and there's a bridge and that weird opera house to visit too.

fields.headline: Clinton wins oil pledge
fields.standfirst: Saudis to raise production as revolt on prices brings France to a halt
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton last night won a pledge from the world's biggest oil producer, Saudi Arabia, to halt the relentless rise in the price of crude which yesterday brought France to a halt and prompted fears of a global recession.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott, Charlotte Denny  and  Jon Henley in Paris
fields.body:
Bill Clinton last night won a pledge from the world's biggest oil producer, Saudi Arabia, to halt the relentless rise in the price of crude which yesterday brought France to a halt and prompted fears of a global recession.

As UK petrol firms responded to the 10-year-high in oil prices by putting up fuel prices by 2p a litre, crown prince Abdullah said Saudi Arabia would raise production by 700,000 barrels a day in an effort to ease pressure on the west.

However, oil experts said the 3% increase in output would not be enough to bring crude oil prices to below $30 a barrel and motoring organisations warned that British drivers could soon expect to pay £4 for a gallon of petrol.

Speaking at the UN millennium summit in New York, President Clinton said he had put pressure on Saudi Arabia to take action ahead of Sunday's meeting of Opec - the 11-member oil producers' cartel.

"I told him I was very concerned that the price of oil is too high, not just for America but for the world," said Mr Clinton after his meeting with the crown prince. "If it was to cause a recession in any part of the world that would hurt the oil producing countries."

Large parts of France ran out of fuel yesterday as hauliers and farmers, more determined than ever to win big fuel tax cuts from the government, continued their four-day blockade of oil refineries and depots.

Angry farmers, already active on most of the 120 blockades up and down the country, successfully blocked the entrance to the Channel tunnel with their tractors, triggering scuffles with British tourists.

Around 50 British holidaymakers mounted a counter-blockade by blocking a lane being used by the authorities to allow French cars to trickle past the barricades, and threatened to cut off the main A16 motorway if they were not allowed to get through the blockade and go home. Under police escort, a convoy of British cars and coaches was eventually allowed through in the late afternoon.

A British police sergeant, who was part of the convoy but asked not to be named, said: "It seems we managed to outmanoeuvre them with a bit of British courage and some cunning. We played them at their own game and it worked. In the end it was quite a fun victory for all."

Another convoy member, Frank Davidson, 49, said: "This was as sweet a victory as Wellington over Napoleon at Waterloo. They didn't like it when we put up a fight."

While talks resumed late in the afternoon between the French transport minister, Jean-Claude Gayssot, and the two main hauliers' federations, the government reiterated that it would go no further than the 15% tax cut, worth £100m, it offered on Wednesday. Meanwhile, the European commission threatened legal action if the free movement of goods within the EU was disrupted.

As the protest spread, the hauliers, farmers, ambulance drivers and coach firms were joined by thousands of taxi drivers in massed "go-slow" processions that brought traffic to a halt in a dozen cities and caused motorway tailbacks.

At least three regional airports reported they would be out of aviation fuel by this morning. Wholesalers at the main Rungis market outside Paris said supplies of fresh fruit and vegetable were beginning to be affected and 80% of the country's petrol stations were either dry, subject to rationing of £15 per vehicle, or had been requisitioned for emergency service use only.

In the financial markets yesterday, the price of a barrel of crude oil eased back from a peak of $34.50 to $33.91. However, dealers said that most of the Saudi production increase had been anticipated by the markets and that prices were not likely to fall markedly.

They said Saudi Arabia was the key player in the crisis because it was the only Opec nation with the spare capacity to pump the extra oil needed to bring prices under control. But it can expect opposition from other Opec members who are enjoying extra revenues from the price surge from under $10 a barrel at the start of last year.

Lawrence Eagles, oil analyst at the City firm GNI Securities, said a harsh winter could boost demand by an extra 500,000 barrels a day, pushing prices still higher."You can't rule out $40 a barrel if Opec aren't prepared to act," he said.

fields.headline: Most wanted: Most everywhere
fields.trailText: Booker Barbie | Druggy perfumes
fields.body:
Most wanted: Booker Barbie

As far as role models go, only Madonna and Nigella Lawson have ever done it for me. But according to a survey by the Guide Association, Barbie still has an inordinate sway over impressionable young female minds: the most popular career aspirations of teacher, vet, nurse and childcare worker correspond closely with the Barbie career dolls. Concerned that not one of the girls questioned mentioned "writer" as a possible career choice, Mslexia, the magazine for women writers, has commissioned award-winning fashion designer Rebecca Nixon to design outfits for a proposed new doll to be added to the range: Booker Barbie. Booker Barbie would come complete with two contrasting looks - a Writing at Home outfit comprising dressing gown, tracky bottoms and odd socks, and Booker Prize outfit of snappy trousersuit. Suggested accessories include a word processor, pencils and coffee mug. Mattel UK, who manufacture Barbie, have told Mslexia that their "interesting" proposal has been forwarded to American HQ. Fingers crossed.

Most everywhere: druggy perfumes

A round of applause to the designers on this one. Addictive, euphoria-inducing, exciting, youthful - if you were launching a perfume, how would you convey such an image on your scent? Drugs, my friends, drugs, but not as we once knew them.

Celebrities stumbling out from the Met Bar, noses covered by anorak or pashmina, is all very 90s. Gone are the days when we even raised an eyebrow at this shameful spectacle.

But, let's be honest here, we all need a bit of an energy boost from time to time, and there are times when a double shot of latte just won't suffice. Gucci Rush has been keeping fragrant fashionistas on the go since it was launched last spring, and, as of last week, boys have been allowed to join in the fun.

Now shoe designer to Sloane Street savvies, Patrick Cox, has provided us with yet more choice about where we can get an olefactory high. From High, in fact, his first perfume available from next week.

The dizzying, stripey design on the front promises much fun to be had with this liquid potion, but I find that the perfumes themselves provide sufficient pleasure: they are fantastically glitzy (pink for girls, blue for boys),yet contained in gratifyingly weighty, Philip Starck-esque bottles. How now can you get?

And with the drug references, there is little danger that your granny wears any of these scents either.

Lasts longer, less expensive and no horrible comedown. But be warned - with scents as yummy as these, they are dangerously habit-forming.

 High for Men, £25 for 50 ml, High for Women, £27 for 50ml, from Harvey Nichols from September 15. Gucci Rush for Men, £28 for 50ml, Rush for Women, £35 for 50ml, from department stores nationwide.

webTitle: The quest for literacy in Pakistan

fields.headline: The quest for literacy in Pakistan
fields.standfirst:
Women find independence with learning
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Past the narrow, dirty bazaar, barely wide enough for farmers leading their oxen, and down a maze of shaded streets the lives of the women of Ghaziabad are quietly changing.
fields.body:
Past the narrow, dirty bazaar, barely wide enough for farmers leading their oxen, and down a maze of shaded streets the lives of the women of Ghaziabad are quietly changing.

Three years ago Moafia Nazir's parents would not let her walk alone through the market in this poor, conservative corner of Pakistan. The neighbours' gossip would have shamed the family.

Moafia, who was 17 at the time, could not read or write. She dropped out of school as a young child and never went back. Eventually she convinced her parents to let her cross the bazaar in this village on the outskirts of Lahore because on the other side was the Khoj school. This was a chance to try again.

Three years on she has just passed the first of her matriculation exams, equivalent to GCSE, and is teaching at the school herself.

"I always wonder why it is in Pakistan that girls should not get an education and why they should not be allowed out of their houses," Moafia said. "Why do the men think there is a problem?"

Education is failing Pakistanis. Just 45% of the adult population are literate, while for women in backward, rural Baluchistan that figure slumps to just 8.8%.

Khoj, which translates as "quest", has taken a radically different approach to tackling the problem.

Urdu is taught phonetically to adult women and literacy classes are entwined with discussions about community development and the rights of women in an often unforgiving and deeply conservative Islamic society.

"If you teach only literacy it will flop," said Nasira Habib, a philosophy graduate who developed the unconventional phonetic teaching system and started Khoj in 1994.

"Literacy is just a tool. If there is no training of the mind, then literacy only creates dumb people who don't ask questions and become complacent."

Most women at the school learn to read and write within three months, although the basic course lasts a year. Lessons are based on a list of key words, used to provoke discussions. The first word the adults learn is aurat or "woman".

Still studying for her next matriculation exam Moafia, dressed in a polka dot shalwar kameez trouser suit, crouches on a classroom floor teaching what she has learned to a crowd of children and earning her economic independence.

"Learning about the word "aurat" taught me I could do something and that I should not think I am a woman and I cannot do anything," she said. "It has made me think: 'I am a woman. I have rights. How can I get my rights?'"

As the muezzin in the mosque next door calls for lunchtime prayers Moafia joins the adult classes for their daily two-hour lesson on the rooftop of a nearby building, another of the 10 Khoj centres in Ghaziabad.

On the wall is a poster of a pen, held up like a sword in a shaft of light. "Education is a strength," it reads. Another poster shows a woman in an academic gown holding a scroll: "Better education will provide better employment."

The women all have stories of how their literacy has helped them check the expiry date on packets of medicine, understand medical reports or simply read bus numbers and escape the ridicule of their male neighbours.

But for most the biggest lesson has been dealing with the opposition from their families and centuries of conservative tradition.

Razia comes from a Sindi family of four sons and four daughters. Only the boys were allowed to go to school.

"I used to wear a burqa and never went to the bazaar," she said, describing the all-enveloping cloak women in only the most traditional Pakistani communities are still forced to wear. "Now I come here and I am not afraid of men as I was before. Men are no longer a threat to us."

One of the first questions the women ask is whether arranged marriages, which are the norm in the narrow streets of Ghaziabad, are justified.

"We ask people to respect traditions but rights are rights, there is no compromise on that," said Sumera Jabeen, one of the senior teachers at Khoj.

"We told them it is their right to choose their life partner for themselves. It is a revolution but we think that bad customs should be broken."

Pakistan

Male

Adult literacy rate 52%

Number of illiterates (millions) 20

Net primary school enrolment rate 49%

Female

Adult literacy rate 26%

Number of illiterates (millions) 28

Net primary school enrolment rate 38%

 Education spending as % of GNP Pakistan 2.7% Nigeria 0.7%

 Military spending as % of GNP Pakistan 5.7% Nigeria 1.4%

Source: World Bank

webTitle: Gestures not enough to teach the world

fields.headline: Gestures not enough to teach the world
fields.standfirst:
The right to education
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: We have been here before. The high-level conferences, the firm commitments, the hand-wringing, the international agreements that promise the earth and deliver next to nothing - all have been part of the backdrop to the campaign for debt relief. Now there is a threat that the campaign for universal primary education could go the same way.
fields.body:
We have been here before. The high-level conferences, the firm commitments, the hand-wringing, the international agreements that promise the earth and deliver next to nothing - all have been part of the backdrop to the campaign for debt relief. Now there is a threat that the campaign for universal primary education could go the same way.

Today is international literacy day and there is plenty for the world community to do. Out of a global population of 6bn, 880m adults are illiterate, two thirds of them women, most of them in south Asia. The next generation of people that will be unable to read and write has already been born unless action is taken speedily to turn fine words into action.

It is four months since the UN conference in Dakar that promised that every child would be inside a classroom by 2015 and the signs are not promising. In theory, the conference was a step forward, committing every country in the developing world to produce an action plan for education and pledging governments in the developed world to ensure that the plans would not go unimplemented for lack of cash - around $8bn (£5.6bn) a year.

The World Bank is now trying to put together a global initiative, but as is the way with global initiatives, this is taking time. And time for a child out of school in sub-Saharan Africa is a commodity that quickly loses its value.

One of the reasons it is taking time is because of the attitude of some western governments, including Britain. The aid agency Oxfam called for a dedicated global action fund to ensure that the Dakar declaration did not go the way of the Jontien declaration of 1990, which called for universal education by 2000 but failed to marshal the necessary resources to turn the vision into reality.

Britain's Clare Short is a strong opponent of earmarking special funds for education, arguing that the problem for developing countries is not a lack of finance but a lack of the proper policies. She believes calls for a fund are simply "gesture politics".

Tony Blair, who has pledged that the government's "education, education, education" manifesto should apply to the whole world, failed to move the subject up the agenda of the Group of 7 at its meeting in Okinawa in July. Instead the G7 focussed on closing the digital divide between North and South: the gap in access to new technology between rich and poor countries.

This is a worthwhile objective. One third of the world's population live in countries which have fewer telephone lines in total than Italy. Around 90% of telecommunications traffic takes place between rich countries, while 50% of the world's population have never made a phone call. As the knowledge economy takes root in the coming years, this lack of access will take a heavy toll and widen the divide still further.

Bringing telephone lines and computers to poor countries sounds like an excellent idea - particularly to those hi-tech companies lobbying for wider access for their products - but it is putting the cart before the horse. A computer is not much use to a child who cannot read.

Without determined international action these children, their families and their countries will be marginalised in poverty, probably irrevocably, and Fortress Europe will increasingly find it impossible to keep the most desperate individuals out.

And all these figures underestimate the full extent of the literacy problem, perhaps by as much as half. They are based on school attendance figures, and ignore the problem of the numbers of children who leave school functionally illiterate. In Africa, where increasing numbers of children will be out of school unless there is emergency action by western institutions, a new generation of adult illiterates is set to create a dangerously marginalised section of society and fire the wars of deprivation like Sierra Leone's.

Even in the industrialised world illiteracy is a problem, with almost a quarter of young adults in the US having difficulty reading all but the simplest of texts. In the developed as in the undeveloped world low literacy invariably means poverty and the spiralling problems of drugs, violence and insecurity which go with it.

fields.headline: Nigerians denied power of words
fields.standfirst:
Barely one in six people in Kano can read
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Nana Dahiru steers clear of almost every kind of officialdom unless she has her nine-year-old son Malam in tow.
fields.body:
Nana Dahiru steers clear of almost every kind of officialdom unless she has her nine-year-old son Malam in tow.

The post office is not too bad. Usually the boy has to do no more than write an address on his mother's behalf. But Mrs Dahiru is not keen on the state government offices where she has to renew her trader's licence, and she views the police station as a special kind of hell. Her son, Malam, does not always understand the paperwork and mistakes are seized on by some officials to extort his mother's hard-earned naira as penance.

Mrs Dahiru, a 32-year-old seller of secondhand clothes, cannot read or write a word of any language beyond her name, numbers and the names of a few products in the shops. Her husband, Mustapha, a driver at the state electricity company, is hardly more fortunate. He can scribble a little Arabic from his days studying the Koran under his Islamic teachers but it is hardly functional literacy.

So it is left to Malam to guide his parents through the world of letters and official paperwork. He even fills in his own application to attend school.

"I never went to school, not for one day, so I never learned to read or write," said Mrs Dahiru. "When I was young it did not seem to matter because my elder brother read the Koran to me. My father couldn't read either. My brother was the only one in our family.

"Sometimes it can be difficult. Officials point to some writing and tell you you are doing things wrong and you don't know if it is true or not. The police are very bad because they are not from here and they look down on us."

Illiteracy is the norm among adults in the northern Nigerian state of Kano. Barely one in six of its indigenous population can read and write. There is no sign the situation will improve. The average child's education amounts to a total of just nine months in school, and that is still better than in many other northern Nigerian states.

Tellingly, almost all of Kano city's bookshops are confined to the quarter reserved for Christians who are mostly Igbo traders from south-eastern Nigeria where education is more valued.

The result is an adult population deprived of opportunity and confined to a world where illiteracy is a way of life for almost everyone.

Sometimes illiteracy can demand an unimaginable price. A Christian woman who was unable to read accidentally used a pamphlet printed with extracts from the Koran to wipe her baby's bottom. After a neighbour saw what happened, an outraged mob of Muslims descended on the woman's home and dragged her husband off to jail. But they became impatient for a trial and the man was hauled out of his cell and beheaded.

Mrs Dahiru lives in a poor part of Kano where the struggle for daily survival is overwhelming. Her family barely has enough money to feed the four children. The cost of Malam's schoolbooks amounts to more than a month's income. As the eldest son, he is the only one getting an education.

Mrs Dahiru says she would like to learn to read but there are too many obstacles. "It would make a difference. I sometimes feel ashamed that I have to rely on my son to write for me but it is good he can read. But I have no one to teach me. My husband cannot do it and Malam is too young," she said.

"The government should help us with schools for adults. I would go but it is true that there are a lot of men who would not let their wives go. They ask why a woman needs to read, but I think they are secretly ashamed if they have a wife who can read and they cannot."

There was once an adult education system in Nigeria, but like much else it has been consumed by the swamp of decay. The government stopped paying the teachers, so many stopped teaching. Even when they were not discouraged by the lack of salaries, the schools fell into disrepair and many simply have no electricity, so there are no evening classes.

Some villages ask the government for classes but there are no funds. Islamic organisations have stepped into the breach left by the government in many areas of life, and that includes teaching people to read. But their focus is on the Koran, usually in Arabic.

During Bill Clinton's visit to Nigeria last month, the chief of the only village he visited included funds for adult education classes on a list of needs he optimistically hoped the US president would meet. He is still waiting.

Male

Adult literacy rate 67%

Number of illiterates (millions) 11

Net primary school enrolment rate 60%

Female

Adult literacy rate 47%

Number of illiterates (millions) 17

Net primary school enrolment rate 58%

 Education spending as % of GNP Pakistan 2.7% Nigeria 0.7%

 Military spending as % of GNP Pakistan 5.7% Nigeria 1.4%

Source: World Bank

fields.headline: Leading industry figures pay tribute to Bruce Gyngell
fields.trailText: Leading figures in the TV industry have been paying tribute to Bruce Gyngell.
fields.body:
Leading figures in the TV industry have been paying tribute to larger-than-life character, Bruce Gyngell, who died last night.

Pinewood Studios chairman Michael Grade described Gyngell, who died in a London hospital last night after battling cancer for more than a year, as "one of those all-to-rare broadcasting executives who relied entirely on his instincts and his flair.

"He was a man who always led from the front. I don't believe he ever got the credit he deserved for the positive influence he had on British broadcasting. He was also a man of the utmost integrity."

Clive Jones, chief executive of Carlton Television, said Gyngell "was a kind and generous man... eccentric and quirky, but also charismatic and engaging. He played a key role in establishing a popular mix of entertainment, information and authoritative news as the regular fare of breakfast television in the UK.

"He also had a role in helping to sweep away some of the old-fashioned Spanish practices that bedevilled the production process in the 1980s."

Yorkshire Television's managing director, Richard Gregory, who worked with Gyngell at Yorkshire, said: "Bruce was an extremely energetic and colourful chief executive with a highly individual style. He was well liked by many of the staff here for his generous nature and personal approach."

Sir David Frost, who worked alongside Gyngell at TV-am, described him as an outstanding leader: "Working for him, people achieved more than they ever thought themselves capable of. He was a great Australian who loved Engla," he said.

Former TV-am presenter Mike Morris, who fronted Yorkshire TV's Calender news programmes, said: "He brought a dynamism and excitement to things. There is no question but that his imprint can still be seen in certain areas of British TV, but occasionally he tripped up over his own hubris. He was unforgettable."

fields.headline: Location, Protestation and Explanation
fields.trailText: VAZ - WHAT IS HE GOOD FOR?
fields.body:
VAZ - WHAT IS HE GOOD FOR?

The other day the Fiver was at the airport, waving sarcastically as Leicester chairman John Elsom, Leicestershire East MP Keith Vaz and the FA's wonderful David Davies departed for Geneva, armed with only their immeasurable charm and a stack of "collated information" from the Foreign Office. Their mission was to persuade Uefa that Belgrade was bandit country, the sort of place that even hardened cowboys like Robbie Savage should avoid - especially on September 28th when Leicester were due to play Red Star Belgrade. And as we saw the airplane finally lift off the ground - which, with Mr Vaz on board, it did with some difficulty - the Fiver confidently predicted they didn't have a hope in hell.

And - what do you know? - we were actually right. Well, sort of. Because today Uefa decided that the tie would still go ahead in Belgrade (home of bad man Slobodan Milosevic and a place the Foreign Office advises all Britons to avoid) but announced it will now be played a week earlier, thus avoiding all the civil unrest that's bound to kick off when President Milosevic wangles his way to an unpopular election win. Which is obviously a good thing.

Or is it? Because Elsom didn't exactly perform triple salchows with pike at the news. "We would have found Sofia an acceptable venue for this game as it is only four hours away from Belgrade, and Red Star played Montpellier there last year," he whined. "Throughout my negotiations, the Foreign Office have been advising against non-essential travel to Yugoslavia, which implies there is some risk." But just as Balkan War II looked like being set into motion, Elsom relented: "We certainly would not want to disobey a Uefa directive as that would mean being thrown out of the competition." Which means, we assume, that Savage will be let loose on Belgrade. Heaven help them.

PRICK UP YOUR EARS

The Fiver has only just recovered from the tinnitus caused by He Is Emmanuel Petit's year-long whine regarding his desire to leave Arsenal. So what's the first thing we are presented with the very second our poor battered ears have been nursed back to full health? That's right, an unbearable screeching sound sailing out of the very same man's mouth - and this time he's telling everyone that he never actually asked for a move at all. Gah! Why, we oughta ...

"I never expressed the wish to leave Arsenal," the pony-tailed Barcelona midfielder loudly honked in the general direction of France-Football magazine today. "I was never asked my opinion - that's why I've fallen out with Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein. Instead, I was presented with a fait accompli. In the interest of everyone, that of Arsenal and of myself, I accepted a move - but it wasn't easy. In leaving I am losing friends." How selfless is that? What a great guy! And there was us thinking he couldn't get on the plane to Spain fast enough.

Oh, hold on, we were right in the first place. "I'm relieved above all to have finished with so-called English fair play. It's a utopia. They confuse fighting spirit with violence. The fault does not lie with the supporters, but certain younger players who take themselves for cowboys." The man with the reading collection of David Icke and the hair of Peter Stringfellow probably had a lot more to say for himself, but by this time we'd taped our ears up. Not for any pre-emptive safety purposes, you understand. We just couldn't be bothered to listen to him any more.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I love the man" - Peter Taylor on Glenn Hoddle, that beautiful guy bringing his Southampton side to Filbert Street tomorrow.

BUFFON ACCUSED OF NAZI SYMPATHIES

Parma goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon, who was last year accused of harbouring Nazi sympathies after appearing on television in a shirt bearing a legend used by fascists in Mussolini's Italy, is preparing to explain himself after it was announced he has requested to wear the number 88 shirt for the upcoming season. The number 88 is used by neo-Nazis to say "Heil Hitler", H being the eighth letter of the alphabet.

"We want him to tell us why he chose this number and to change it out of respect for Jews, tziganes [gypsies] and homosexuals," Jewish sports official Vittorio Pavoncello told onefootball.com today. Buffon had initially declined to comment, but has agreed to hold a press conference later today to explain his actions.

Meanwhile, Parma are sticking up for their player, who has earned an otherwise liberal reputation on the back of much charity work: "The Jewish community should deal with more serious matters," said their director of football Michele Uva. The player's mother has also entered the fray, telling reporters that "they should be ashamed of thinking such things". She enigmatically went on to say that Buffon chose the number 88 "for his own reasons".

THE RUMOUR MILL

Aston Villa manager John Gregory has failed in an attempt to sign Steve McManaman from Real Madrid. "We have spoken to him," admitted Gregory. "But he is going to stick it out at Real and he has not been deterred in any way by the comments their coach has made."

Patrick Vieira is an £11.5m target for Roma, according to reports.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Bobby Robson has been named Carling manager of the month for August. Meanwhile, Leeds striker Alan Smith has won the Carling player of the month award.

John Gregory will not face a FA disciplinary hearing for his outburst against Chelsea, despite criticising the club for being "fake pretenders with false illusions" and accusing them of "tapping up" Gareth Southgate.

Henning Berg has returned to Blackburn on a three-month loan from Manchester United. The Norwegian central defender said: "Blackburn has the ability to be a top club again, and has a fiercely ambitious manager. I had no hesitation in agreeing to the deal. If all goes well I'd like it to be a permanent move."

Cameroon defender Lucien Mettomo has rejected a move to Blackburn. His agent said Mettomo, who plays for Saint Etienne, did not wish to step down a division.

Derby striker Branko Strupar has travelled to Germany, where he is expected to have surgery on a hernia problem.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 3: Wycombe Wanderers v Oxford United - Live (7.30pm)

"Despite Chris Kamara's numerous outside broadcasts, his brilliantly Brylcreemed hair, which resembles Lionel Richie circa 1982, never once appears ruffled," writes a clearly impressed Nick Oldfield. "This man has class and it's high time the Fiver recognised it. Easy like Sunday morning? Only when Kamara's presenting his Nationwide round-up."

Hold The Back Page (10pm)

Ah, if only the same thing could be said about Woolnough on a Sunday morning.

Sky Sports 1: Premiership Preview (11.30pm)

His bouncing bouffant doesn't stand so tall then, we can tell you.

webTitle: Warehouse's  flattering collection of womens' trousers

fields.headline: Shake a leg
fields.standfirst: They are either too long or too short, or they make your bum look big. Why do women find it so hard to find a flattering pair of trousers? High-street chain Warehouse thinks it has found the answer.  Susannah Conway puts its new collection through its paces
fields.trailText: They are either too long or too short, or they make your bum look big. Why do women find it so hard to find a flattering pair of trousers? High-street chain Warehouse thinks it has found the answer.
fields.body:
Pantaloons, knickerbockers, cigarette pants, drainpipes and combat kecks: there are numerous ways to construct four pieces of rectangular material into a pair of trousers, but am I the only woman in Britain who has difficulty finding a pair of strides to suit her? Didn't think so. I doubt my heart will be the only one to beat a little faster at the news that high-street favourite, Warehouse, has come up with a solution that promises to banish British women's trouser woes: The Collection, launched this month, comprises eight key trouser shapes from tailored lurex to sleek black, with a choice of details including kick flares and back zips, with prices ranging from £30 to £50. This is the first stand-alone trouser collection from a high-street store and is a shrewd homage to the success of the slightly pricier Joseph's Essentials range of trousers, which many lean-limbed shoppers already rely on. So has Warehouse come up trumps?

Women have been wearing trousers since the beginning of the last century. Coco Chanel boosted their appeal in the 20s when she introduced "yachting pants" to be worn for leisurely pursuits. From working in regulation trousers in factories during the second world war to donning unisex bell bottoms in the 60s, women in trousers became acceptable. Yet it remains difficult to find a pair that flatters, with too few manufacturers understanding the trouser secret: that the length/ waist/bottom ratio has to be right. Trousers don't necessarily have to make you look "slim", rather, women are more concerned with making their bottom look "fit", that is rounded, pert and not too big.

A quick poll among my female friends revealed that each had precise criteria when selecting trousers. For Jane, who is 5ft 3in, the perfect trousers would be "flattering on my bum, a good length: not too loose or tight, plain not patterned, in a dark colour and with side pockets and front zip". The ideal pair for Lucy, 5ft 11in, would need to have "a good butt with the waist fitting perfectly and not gapey. They must not bag at knee and should be sharp and snappy." Louise, 5ft 2in, summed up her requirements with, "my perfect pair of trousers manages to make my legs look longer and my bum smaller".

The majority of women shoppers have a fair idea of what suits them, but there are ways to cheat. The following styles seem to be universally flattering: wide leg, boot leg, flat-fronted, or slightly flared. There are also styles which look universally bad - elasticated waists, for example. Much better to have the waist of your trousers shaped with darts and seams than clenched around your middle with unforgiving elastic. Equally, tapered legs give a larger woman's figure a frog-like look so better to stick to the straight leg, or slightly flared. Trousers cut for a more mature figure, particularly those sold in stores such as M&S, allow extra fabric on the hips, which is forgiving to a pear- shape, although it can lend a "saddle-bag" effect to women with narrower hips.

If you are short waisted, one word: hipsters. These will create the illusion of a longer upper body - wear a snakey belt on your hips, and suddenly your waist has dropped two inches. Trouser legs should err on the long side - why make your legs look shorter, after all? - with the hem sitting on your shoe. However, a hem that brushes against the floor is best left to the young and trendy in Hoxton.

Then there's the underwear issue. Do you want the world to see what sort of knickers you are wearing? Trousers and VPL (visible panty line) have an irritating tendency to go hand in hand and a fleshy rear cut in half by knicker elastic is plain unsexy. The solution is to get friendly with a full-length mirror and a G-string, as trousers that look fabulous from the front could be disastrous from behind. A G-string can be comfortable if you choose cotton versions that are less a "string" and more a "strip" of fabric. Tight shorts-style briefs also work - hipster versions avoid showing your pants everytime you sit down - and M&S does a range of trouser knickers that lend elasticated support and uplift to your derrière.

We gathered four women - two over 5ft 10in, the other two only a whisper over 5ft - and shut them in a studio with a rack of trousers from Warehouse, and a few competitors. The problems started when two women, with a height difference of nearly 8in between them, tested the same pair of size 12 trousers. Inevitably, neither found a perfect fit. They were either too long or too short and while trews can be taken up, they can not be taken down. More time was spent trying on than shooting the photographs, with much sticking up of hems and yanking down waist bands in an effort to make hems reach ankles. Warehouse fared well, with thumbs up for the Prince of Wales check (£45) and chalk stripe (£45), but as they don't come in different lengths the taller testers were left disappointed.

The designer versus high-street debate is a decision for your pocket rather than your figure. Predictably, the cheaper the trouser, the weaker the cut, as our testers confirmed, but that doesn't mean Miss Selfridge or Oasis won't be trouser heaven for you. Petite ranges are also a good bet for trousers with smaller proportions - try Marks & Spencer, Next and Dorothy Perkins.

The rule is, if you find a pair that flatters, buy them in every colour - better still, get them made for you. Then you will know that someone somewhere has the template for your perfect trousers ready to be run off in whichever fabric takes your fancy. Trouser nirvana indeed.
