The ideal pair for Lucy, 5ft 11in, would need to have "a good butt with the waist fitting perfectly and not gapey. They must not bag at knee and should be sharp and snappy." Louise, 5ft 2in, summed up her requirements with, "my perfect pair of trousers manages to make my legs look longer and my bum smaller". The majority of women shoppers have a fair idea of what suits them, but there are ways to cheat. The following styles seem to be universally flattering: wide leg, boot leg, flat-fronted, or slightly flared. There are also styles which look universally bad - elasticated waists, for example. Much better to have the waist of your trousers shaped with darts and seams than clenched around your middle with unforgiving elastic. Equally, tapered legs give a larger woman's figure a frog-like look so better to stick to the straight leg, or slightly flared. Trousers cut for a more mature figure, particularly those sold in stores such as M&S, allow extra fabric on the hips, which is forgiving to a pear- shape, although it can lend a "saddle-bag" effect to women with narrower hips. If you are short waisted, one word: hipsters. These will create the illusion of a longer upper body - wear a snakey belt on your hips, and suddenly your waist has dropped two inches. Trouser legs should err on the long side - why make your legs look shorter, after all? - with the hem sitting on your shoe. However, a hem that brushes against the floor is best left to the young and trendy in Hoxton. Then there's the underwear issue. Do you want the world to see what sort of knickers you are wearing? Trousers and VPL (visible panty line) have an irritating tendency to go hand in hand and a fleshy rear cut in half by knicker elastic is plain unsexy. The solution is to get friendly with a full-length mirror and a G-string, as trousers that look fabulous from the front could be disastrous from behind. A G-string can be comfortable if you choose cotton versions that are less a "string" and more a "strip" of fabric. Tight shorts-style briefs also work - hipster versions avoid showing your pants everytime you sit down - and M&S does a range of trouser knickers that lend elasticated support and uplift to your derrière. We gathered four women - two over 5ft 10in, the other two only a whisper over 5ft - and shut them in a studio with a rack of trousers from Warehouse, and a few competitors. The problems started when two women, with a height difference of nearly 8in between them, tested the same pair of size 12 trousers. Inevitably, neither found a perfect fit. They were either too long or too short and while trews can be taken up, they can not be taken down. More time was spent trying on than shooting the photographs, with much sticking up of hems and yanking down waist bands in an effort to make hems reach ankles. Warehouse fared well, with thumbs up for the Prince of Wales check (£45) and chalk stripe (£45), but as they don't come in different lengths the taller testers were left disappointed. The designer versus high-street debate is a decision for your pocket rather than your figure. Predictably, the cheaper the trouser, the weaker the cut, as our testers confirmed, but that doesn't mean Miss Selfridge or Oasis won't be trouser heaven for you. Petite ranges are also a good bet for trousers with smaller proportions - try Marks & Spencer, Next and Dorothy Perkins. The rule is, if you find a pair that flatters, buy them in every colour - better still, get them made for you. Then you will know that someone somewhere has the template for your perfect trousers ready to be run off in whichever fabric takes your fancy. Trouser nirvana indeed.

webTitle: Displaying the technology trend: The Westbourne Hotel

fields.headline: The Westbourne Hotel
fields.trailText: These days, computers are almost more fashionable than clothes. When Apple launched the new PowerMac G4 cube recently they did so not in a boardroom but in London's fashionable Charlotte Street Hotel. Style obsessives turned up, salivating over the shiny goods, proving geek chic has gained a whole new meaning: computers are rapidly becoming the new style statement.
fields.body:
These days, computers are almost more fashionable than clothes. When Apple launched the new PowerMac G4 cube recently they did so not in a boardroom but in London's fashionable Charlotte Street Hotel. Style obsessives turned up, salivating over the shiny goods, proving geek chic has gained a whole new meaning: computers are rapidly becoming the new style statement.

One new venture that has fused futuristic technology into its luxurious surroundings is the Westbourne Hotel in Notting Hill, due to open its doors on September 18. "My friends are junkies for information," says the hotel's project co-ordinator Giles Baker who created this modern B&B for the millennium guest. The four bedrooms that lead out to the Japanese-inspired bamboo garden will each contain a console desk with "bowl" detail floating off the wall housing a flat plasma screen. This will provide access to the internet, a CD-Rom and DVD system, with online shopping also available.

Baker, previously responsible for the Kabaret Club and Piers Adam's barber shop (gentlemen's grooming with internet consoles), is described as a "lifestyle conceptual designer" who has found his niche carving out new style concepts for the jet set. "The plasma screen is a signifier of modernism," he says. "Two years ago I wouldn't have been able to afford to have digital wiring but within a few years houses in Knightsbridge will get sold on the back of their multimedia wiring facilities."

This technological trend is becoming increasingly apparent inside London's newest hotels, with digital information carousing through the bricks and mortar not only of the Westbourne, but of the Sanderson (plasma screens in the entrance and lifts filled with holograms), and One Aldwych (mini TVs on bendy stalks in the bathroom and an ISDN line for every guest). Add exclusivity in to the mix and you have desire and aspiration being piped directly into a design-led hotel environment.

 Prices start from £150 per room. Reservations: 020-7229 7791

webTitle: Government to fill gaps in sex education

fields.headline: Government to fill gaps in sex education
fields.standfirst:
Education Unlimited
Some sex education sites on the net:
The BBC's So
Channel 4's Generation Sex
The government's Mind Body Soul
More sites
fields.trailText: The government is to give teenagers the facts about sex that they fail to get from either their parents or school in a major campaign aimed at cutting the number of pregnancies among teenage girls.
fields.body:
The government is to give teenagers the facts about sex that they fail to get from either their parents or school in a major campaign aimed at cutting the number of pregnancies among teenage girls.

Ministers are determined that the campaign will not be judgmental. Research commissioned by the Department of Health and the Central Office of Information, which will be published later this month, states categorically that teenagers "strongly reject communication they perceive as patronising, authoritarian or not addressed to them as equals. This includes sources which they perceive to be treating them as children, that try to be like them (captured in the phrase 'trendy vicar') or that tell them what to do or to believe."

Messages that are factual and non-judgmental have some effect, say the researchers, "whereas messages based on fear and on abstinence ('just say no') have clearly proved ineffective."

The campaign is still in the planning stage and ministers are reluctant to be drawn on the detail because of the inevitable controversy. The churches, many parents and rightwing morality groups will be outraged that young people will not be given a clear message that under-age sex is wrong and that sex within marriage is the ideal.

Yvette Cooper, the minister for public health, said many things were yet to be decided, but certain principles were clear. "Getting teenage pregnancies down means working with teenagers and parents to see what works. The research shows that teenagers take no notice of patronising messages and we're very clear that the campaign must be as much about boys as about girls."

The government has earmarked £15m for its publicity campaign - half of which it intends to come from the private sector. Radical measures are thought necessary because the UK has the highest teenage pregnancy rate in Europe , with about 90,000 conceptions a year.

The advertising agency Delaney, Lund, Knox, Warren has been given a contract to begin exploring with teenagers the style and content of messages they will accept. Another arm of the campaign will focus on encouraging parents to talk to their children.

The government's research, compiled by independent researcher Christine Eborall from studies in the UK and abroad, has clearly shown that teenagers most want to hear it from mum and dad.

Where parents talk to their children about sex, the children are more likely to delay and use contraception but, says the government's research, "nowadays most parents feel ill-equipped to fulfil this role. They find the subject embarrassing and are uncertain about what to say or when and how to say it. They feel they ought to give a formal sex talk, but the worry that their children probably already know more than they do inhibits them from initiating any communication.

"Fathers are particularly poor in this respect, with the result that boys often miss out completely on sex education in the home. And the fact that sex education is taught in school gives parents an excuse to avoid the issue."

But school sex lessons, where they exist, are embarrassing and teenagers are left "ignorant and desperate for more information". It is not surprising many girls turn to teen magazines. "However, they [the magazines] are also perceived by parents and older young people to encourage sex and to foster dissatisfaction and frustration among young readers by setting unachievable standards of beauty and sexual attractiveness."

Young people quickly learn that sex is taboo and inherit their elders' stereotypical views - boys want to be macho studs while girls unrealisticly associate sex with romance. This social climate, together with much greater exposure to the adult world through families and the media than before, ignorance about contraception and diseases and the use of alcohol, are all factors in early and unprotected sex, the research says.

Ministers are being urged to build the campaign around a single central idea based on love and sexual attraction, which would interest teenagers and become familiar through a slogan or jingle. Also being considered are the use of humour, animation, cartoons and the internet.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week four

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week four
fields.standfirst: Each week throughout the season, Football Unlimited's finest take on the bookies, and you the reader, in an attempt to find the betting champion. It's a marathon not a sprint, brought to you in association with Blue Square
fields.trailText:
Current totals:
Paul MacInnes = £98.82
Sean Ingle £97.57
Football Unlimited punters' collective = £80
Scott Murray = £74.37
fields.body:
Current totals:
Paul MacInnes = £98.82
Sean Ingle £97.57
Football Unlimited punters' collective = £80
Scott Murray = £74.37

Paul MacInnes

Bradford v Arsenal four goals or more 7/4 and Newcastle to beat Chelsea 7/4: £7.50

Alright then. Safely ensconced in Mr Murray's good books after following that elusive "value", I have taken two bets that I consider to have a reasonable amount of value in them and added them together to make what I believe is known the trade as a "double".

My wagers both come about as a result of watching the Chelsea v Arsenal game midweek. Seeing the Gunners come back from two goals down I now believe that they can score any time, any place, and that fortress Valley Parade will be violated on more than one occasion on Saturday afternoon. Chuck in the odd spectacular strike from Dean Windass/Benito Carbone/Ashley Ward (who must surely come into the first-team frame soon) and you've got a likely goalfest. Combine this with the fact that the Premiership has been averaging over three goals a game this season and "four goals or more" looks a good bet.

Betting on the home team in the Premiership does seem to be by and large a mug's game. All the odds are in the negative (or whatever you call things like 2/5). Which makes 7/4 for a Newcastle win over Chelsea look all the more enticing. The Toon have had a great start to the season; Chelsea have not. Bobby Robson is a great tactician; Gianluca Vialli is not. St James' Park will be packed to the rafters with 50,000 nutty Geordies on Saturday afternoon; Chelsea will be lucky to take up a couple of executives who have an office in Durham. 7-4 a Newcastle win is value, of that I am sure. But whether that means the bet comes off is distinctly another matter.

Sean Ingle

Arsenal to beat Bradford at 4/6: £15

This week I've lost my bottle, gone soft - and started dancing with Mr single odds-on bet. And, if truth be told, I feel soiled. Disgusted even. Of course it's not what I wanted to do - I originally combined this bet with Leeds to win away at Coventry (surely good value at 11/10) - but as my hand hovered over my left mouse button, I suddenly saw Blue Square's Patrick Murray, covered in red body paint and with a small stake in his hand, perched on my shoulder. And he was telling me over and over again: don't do it, don't it, Sean. Play safe. Become an accountant.

And so I did. I guess my only justification is that if this bet comes off I will be a tenner to the good, which would be nice. And whatever way you look at it Arsenal do look decent value to win at Valley Parade tomorrow. They have Henry, Kanu and Bergkamp while Bradford have Dean Windass and Benny Carbone. They are on a high after Wednesday night's comeback at Chelsea, while Bradford have to pick themselves up after their 6-0 mauling in midweek. But didn't Arsenal lose 2-1 to Bradford early this year at Valley Parade, I hear you cry! Yes they did - but this time it will be different. Trust me.

Scott Murray

Liverpool v Manchester City: four or more goals at 13/8: £10

Liverpool may have started this season sluggishly after finishing the last pathetically, but Premiership defences look out. Things clicked into place for Michael Owen the other week against Southampton and he hasn't looked back since (which is just as well, because he would have seen Marian Pahars making fools of his defenders at the other end). If his hot run continues, expect the home scoreboard to tick over at regular intervals.

Not that I'm writing City off. They won at Leeds, after all, and Paulo Wanchope will be licking his lips at the prospect of facing the shaky Djimi Traore. But if the home team are in the mood - and they will be, assuming Phil "world's angriest man" Thompson still hasn't calmed down about their Dell capitulation - I can see havoc being wreaked at the other end.

This week's guest bet comes from Jason Langford, a project manager, who works mostly in Brussels.

Liverpool to beat the -1.25 Asian handicap against Manchester City at evens: £10

I have it! After hours spent deliberating and calculating whether Sheffield Wednesday and Wimbledon were capable of scoring more than a goal between them, I've reverted to a very simple formula. Manchester City aren't really very good. Besides which, they won their last game, which means they lose this one, right?

So, despite being tempted by the 28/1 for Sunderland/Man U H-T/F-T and the 14/1 about Charlton/draw H-T/F-T on Sunday (who says lightning doesn't strike four times), I'm going for a tenner on Liverpool to beat the -1.25 on the Asian handicap at evens. The beauty of this bet, as I understand it, is that even if they win only by a goal, I get my money back! And when you picture Michael Owen running at Gerard Wiekens and Steve Howey, it's hard to see any other outcome than a comfortable Liverpool victory.

Would you like to bet your life away? Send a mail to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk with a subject heading that goes something like "I have no moral qualms about betting with somebody else's money", and next week it could be you!

And don't forget to find out just how badly our betters have fared on Monday when Blue Square's analyst Patrick Murray will help to steer them back on to the right path.

webTitle: Henchman branded a liar on eve of Hong Kong poll

fields.headline: Henchman branded a liar on eve of Hong Kong poll
fields.trailText: Hong Kong has been shaken, on the eve of an important election, by a political scandal involving the chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, and his closest adviser, Andrew Lo.
fields.body:
Hong Kong has been shaken, on the eve of an important election, by a political scandal involving the chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, and his closest adviser, Andrew Lo.

Yet Mr Tung will lose no seats in Sunday's poll for a new legislative council, because in Hong Kong's defective democracy there is no way of voting for or against the government.

Yesterday's newspapers gave their entire front pages to the sensational resignation of two Hong Kong University officials after an independent inquiry concluded that Mr Lo - whom it described as an "untruthful witness" - had urged one of them to quash public opinion surveys being run by a university researcher.

Mr Tung, the chief executive, was said to be unhappy because the surveys by the researcher, Robert Chung, revealed his declining popularity. To try to get them stopped, Mr Lo privately lobbied the university's vice-chancellor, Cheng Yiu-chung. In the wake of the inquiry's findings he has resigned, and so has a deputy vice-chancellor, Wong Siu-lun.

Mr Tung refused to give evidence to the inquiry and has so far resisted calls to dismiss Mr Lo. The government is staging float parades, carnivals, and roller-blade displays to persuade people to vote on Sunday, with election souvenirs which include cords for mobile phones and a new issue of postage stamps.

But in Hong Kong's "executive-led" system, inherited from British colonial rule, there are no ministers or formal ruling party. The legislative council is allowed only to "raise questions" about the government's work.

"Without political accountability," said Martin Lee, who leads the Democratic party, "the people are only electing the opposition. We must hope for a high voter turnout which can be interpreted as dissatisfaction".

The official slogan is "Your vote can make the difference," but government leaders have not explained how. The council's work is "related to [Hong Kong's] well-being", one senior official said vaguely. The only real democratic contest takes place for the 24 seats - out of a total of 60 - that are directly elected from five geographical constituencies. The main challenger to the Democratic party is the Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong (DAB), often described as "pro-Beijing".

The DAB prefers to present itself as a loyal opposition which "loves China" but reserves the right to disagree. "We have good connnections with the Chinese government," said the DAB's secretary general, Ma Lik. "They will listen to us and not to the Democratic party - because they [the Democrats] always say that China is wrong."

Asked for an example of DAB opposition to Beijing, Mr Ma could cite only an instance in 1994 when it protested at a Bejing proposal to impose a tourist tax at what was then the border between Hong Kong and China.

But even the DAB appears genuinely critical of Mr Tung, and many of its supporters dislike the tycoons who have backed him. The DAB is expected to do better in this election than the Democrats, who have suffered from internal dissension and lost political momentum.

But the DAB has been shaken by its own scandal: its vice-chairman, Gary Cheng, was publicly denounced by his party after he admitted giving a confidential government document to a contact from one of his business interests.

Paradoxically, the "single-list" method introduced to weaken the Democrats after Britain's 1997 handover of the colony to China - by abolishing the first-past-the-post system - may now work against the DAB. People lower down the party's list for Hong Kong Island could lose out if Gary Cheng's conduct costs the DAB votes, yet because he heads the list Mr Cheng could get a seat.

Only in "functional constituencies", professional groups that elect 30 council members, have the Democrats got a chance, in constituencies such as education and social welfare which are not dominated by business interests.

Asked for an example of DAB opposition to Beijing, Mr Ma could cite only an instance in 1994 when it protested at a Bejing proposal to impose a tourist tax at what was then the border between Hong Kong and China. But even the DAB appears genuinely critical of Mr Tung, and many of its supporters dislike the tycoons who have backed him. The DAB is expected to do better in this election than the Democrats, who have suffered from internal dissension and lost political momentum. But the DAB has been shaken by its own scandal: its vice-chairman, Gary Cheng, was publicly denounced by his party after he admitted giving a confidential government document to a contact from one of his business interests. Paradoxically, the "single-list" method introduced to weaken the Democrats after Britain's 1997 handover of the colony to China - by abolishing the first-past-the-post system - may now work against the DAB. People lower down the party's list for Hong Kong Island could lose out if Gary Cheng's conduct costs the DAB votes, yet because he heads the list Mr Cheng could get a seat. Only in "functional constituencies", professional groups that elect 30 council members, have the Democrats got a chance, in constituencies such as education and social welfare which are not dominated by business interests.

fields.headline: Tribute to Bruce Gyngell
fields.standfirst: Maggie Brown pays tribute to Bruce Gyngell, former head of TV-am, who died last night
fields.trailText: Maggie Brown pays tribute to Bruce Gyngell, former head of TV-am, who died last night.
fields.body:
Bruce Gyngell, the Australian inventor of British breakfast television, who has died aged 71, was one of the most colourful, idiosyncratic and domineering of media pioneers. He was far removed from the grey-haired executives who have tended to control ITV television behind the scenes. Gyngell stood out even in an industry where media tycoons from Lord (Lew) Grade to Rupert Murdoch called the shots. His staff nicknamed him the "Pink Panther" because of his love for the colour he saw as life enhancing (he wore pastel pink shirts, and had his office painted pink, with yellow sofas).

His 50-year career was packed with dramatic twists, spanning the start of TV in Australia - his was the first face to appear on screens - and the introduction of sofa-style TV to Britain. Gyngell is best known here for his high profile completion of the rescue of TV-am in 1983, after a disastrous launch.

The first commercial breakfast franchise had teetered on the verge of collapse, losing £500,000 a month, when he was persuaded by Australian colleague and businessman Kerry Packer (who had taken a rescue stake) to sort it out. By 1986 it was ready for flotation on the stock exchange, and briefly flowered into the most profitable of TV networks. This was achieved by ruthlessly targeting programme costs - and dumping the 1984 Olympics coverage. He made the station a place "of eternal summer so that the lost, lonely people could turn on and feel warm and bright" - naff, but effective.

He single-handedly invented friendly, sofa-style TV and chatty presentation, although in fact it was far from easy. The TV-am sofas were actually benches, to encourage guests to sit up, but were upholstered to disguise this. Viewers felt they had joined a surrogate family, with Anne Diamond playing the fresh-faced but smart girl from next door. The company, run from its Camden, North London, headquarters (with distinctive egg cups on the roof) by staff working unsociable hours, was moulded around him and his often faddish likes and dislikes.

Some thought him barmy, predatory, or worse. You had to fit in. But he encouraged newcomers into TV. His former secretary, Ulrika Jonsson, was made the weather girl, to inject some cheer into forecasts. Gyngell broke the rules and liked to pose as being outside of the wasteful British TV establishment, while always remembering to court the powerful. One of his early fallings out was with a youngish, talented executive on the rise, Greg Dyke, who had already set TV-am on the road to recovery before Gyngell arrived with Roland Rat.

Gyngell, an outspoken believer in market forces, but with charm bordering on charisma, became prime minister Margaret Thatcher's favourite broadcasting executive. When she complained about ITV being the "last bastion of restrictive practices", he endured a bruising technicians strike between 1987 and 1988 - more than 200 people were sacked - but suffered a heart attack due to stress.

He wanted ITV to change, to cut out waste and to redraw the regional network, and a Channel 5 to provide more competition. But by 1988 he was speaking out against a blind auction of franchises, recognising the destruction it would wreak. By a cruel twist, the highest bidder auction Thatcher introduced in the flawed 1990 Broadcasting Act ensured TV-am's £14.3m bid was completely overshadowed by a rival consortium offer of £34.6m, when the awards were announced in October 1991. TV-am, the company he had shaped and nurtured, was effectively destroyed. But Gyngell had a final surprise up his sleeve. A day after the news broke, Gyngell was hosting the first (and last) TV-am journalism awards. He dramatically, almost as an afterthought, produced a handwritten letter from Thatcher and read it out to an astonished audience.

"When I see how some of the licences have been awarded, I am mystified that you did not receive yours and heartbroken. You of all people have done so much for the whole of television... I am only too painfully aware that I was responsible for the legislation," she wrote. It was a sensation. The audience gasped, then applauded. Thatcher was saying sorry.

In true Gyngell style, he refused to be broken. He proceeded to hold the company together until December 31, 1992, through the sheer force of his personality. The final morning's broadcast ended, at 9.30am, with the station belting out "You're Simply the Best" as a photo of everyone who had ever worked for the station was flashed onto the screen - from Ulrika Jonsson (weather girl) to doorman and Mrs Thatcher's daughter, Carol. It was a moment of high emotion, and great sadness. Gyngell then hosted a champagne-fuelled farewell party with the sole founder-survivor, Sir David Frost, by his side. Yet, true to promise, the severance terms were very generous and many of his multi-skilled, hard working staff were snapped up by successor GMTV and the rest of ITV. Five years later, he had the bitter satisfaction of being proved right as the licence payments were slashed.

Bruce Gyngell, broadcasting executive, born July 8 1929, died September 7 2000.

This is an extract from the full obituary, which appears in tomorrow's Guardian

webTitle: UK farmers and truckers threaten more blockades

fields.headline: UK farmers and truckers threaten more blockades
fields.trailText: British farmers and truckers have vowed to continue their French-style disruption over high fuel costs after hundreds turned out to blockade an oil refinery.
fields.body:
British farmers and truckers have vowed to continue their French-style disruption over high fuel costs after hundreds turned out to blockade an oil refinery.

A continuing blockade by protesting farmers and hauliers prevented dozens of tankers from leaving Shell's Stanlow oil refinery near Ellesmere Port in Cheshire.

Lorry drivers were planning a protest later today on the A1 near Gateshead, Tyne & Wear. And farmers warned that demonstrations would continue over the weekend and spread across the country.

On the continent, French attempts to blockade the Channel tunnel in a similar protest against fuel prices were thwarted by police.

However, with petrol growing extremely scarce in France because of widespread blockades, the UK's Freight Transport Association reported that two British lorry drivers had their vehicles hijacked and diesel fuel syphoned off by protesters in the Cherbourg area.

UK Transport Minister Lord Macdonald said British protesters did not have the right to interrupt vital supplies.

But David Handley, chairman of Farmers for Action UK warned: "This is going to be an ongoing situation. I would suggest to you this is going to be the winter of unrest."

A Shell spokesman at Stanlow said the protest would begin to have an effect on petrol stations throughout the north of England later today.

Last night, more than 250 farmers and lorry drivers used vehicles to block the Shell oil refinery.

Farmers' spokesman Brynle Williams said demonstrators had travelled from North Wales, Cheshire, Lancashire, Staffordshire and Shropshire to protest at escalating pump prices.

Seven fuel tankers were held up outside the plant during the six-hour protest, as police withheld from using their powers to break up the blockade. Organisers warned there will be more action at the weekend.

"The farmers and the road hauliers have now combined and have come to demonstrate their displeasure with the cost of fuel and with the possibility of a three or four pence increase," said Mr Williams.

Plaid Cymru MP Elfyn Llwyd, who has met some of the drivers - many of whom were from north Wales - said he could not condone their action, but he sympathised with their predicament.

The member for Meirionnydd Nant Conwy said he feared someone could get hurt if the protests continued and he urged the demonstrators not to break the law.

"They have a case to put to government and I would hope very shortly that government will sit down and reconsider the matter because we are paying well over the odds for fuel in the UK," he said. "One individual told me that his monthly fuel bill has gone up by £1,000 in three months and he has virtually been broken completely now economically... I'm concerned that somebody may get injured."

Mr Llwyd said Chancellor Gordon Brown had sufficient excesses in his coffers to alleviate the fuel costs. He told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that cars, vans or Land Rovers were not a luxury in rural areas, such as his constituency, but a necessity for people to get around because of a lack of reliable public transport. It was "absolutely ridiculous" that fuel cost almost £4 a gallon.

After the all-night blackade, protesters were given 10 minutes to clear the road and as the deadline passed up to 30 officers filed down the highway.

There was uproar in Britain as oil companies announced another rise of 2p on the cost of a litre of fuel. It is now feared that fuel could rise to nearly 87p a litre within weeks, taking the cost of a gallon to £4.

The latest increase is due to a rise in the price of crude oil; oil producers' body Opec will meet in Vienna on Sunday to discuss the issue.

fields.headline: Guardian launches northern edition
fields.trailText: The Guardian is launching a new edition, The Guardian North, to make the newspaper more relevant to readers in the north.
fields.body:
The Guardian is launching a new edition, The Guardian North, to make the newspaper more relevant to readers in the north.

The Guardian North will launch on September 18 and will have two separate editions covering the north-west and Yorkshire. News will be covered in more depth where there is local interest and the newspaper will offer more locally relevant sport, listings and arts reviews. Readers of the Guardian North will, for example, find Leeds or Manchester United on the back page rather than Arsenal.

The Guardian's editor, Alan Rusbridger, said, " The Guardian North will still be a national newspaper. What we are doing is offering readers in the north national news with more localised information where it is useful or relevant - in sport, reviews and listings."

A giant poster publicising the launch will go up in Deansgate in the centre of Manchester on September 18.

The Guardian has strong roots in the north, having started out as the Manchester Guardian in 1821. It already has an established northern office and team of journalists. This is team is being expanded and will be backed by additional resources in London.

fields.headline: New army recruitment campaign targets children
fields.trailText: The Army is launching a controversial campaign that targets children as potential recruits. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Army is launching a controversial campaign designed to sign up children as young as 12 as potential recruits.

An ambitious new members' scheme will target 12- to 16-year-olds with an advertising campaign that guides people to a new website, Camouflage, where they can sign up to receive information about the Army. Members will receive a magazine, entitled Army, which will provide insights into the life of a soldier. Anyone interested will also be able to send off for a free Army career video.

The campaign, entitled "Millennial kids", has been put together in consultation with the Henley Centre for Forecasting and is designed to appeal to today's career-seeking global citizens. According to research commissioned by the Army, millennial kids are career-seeking global citizens with a growing sense of civic responsibility who want to use their skills in a succession of different jobs.

The Army aims to communicate directly with 100,000 under-16s in its first year, and to attract 15,000 potential recruits.

Separately, the Army will today launch an ad campaign to attract recruits for non-combat jobs. The three ads, which feature young people showing the potential for military trade skills in civilian situations, will be premiered tonight between 9.30pm and 10.00pm during South Park on Channel 4.

fields.headline: Sex education
fields.standfirst: With dads still passing on stories about flying storks and in-school lessons still proving plain cringe-making, the government's preparing to roll up its sleeves and get stuck into sex education again. Steve Morris explains the issue (without fudging the embarrassing bits)
fields.trailText: With dads still passing on stories about flying storks and in-school lessons still proving plain cringe-making, the government's preparing to roll up its sleeves and get stuck into sex education again. We explain the issue (without fudging the embarrassing bits).
fields.body:
What is the government proposing?
Ministers believe that there is a gap in the sex education available to young people from parents and teachers. Research has revealed that most parents, especially fathers, feel ill-equipped to teach their children the facts of life. School sex lessons are considered embarrassing and often leave children in desperate need of more information. The government is keen to produce a new "non-judgmental" campaign simply setting out the facts about sex and sexual love.

Why is the problem so acute?
The UK has the highest teenage pregnancy rate in Europe with some 90,000 conceptions a year - nearly four times as many as most countries and seven times as many as the Netherlands. Studies suggest that on average 25% of teenagers have had sex before they are 16. Young people who are sexually active before they are 16 are less likely to use contraceptives and more likely to regret their first sexual relationships. A survey published today by the Family Education Trust claims that children under the age of 16 from broken homes are twice as likely to be sexually active than those living with two parents.

What do children and young people think of the way they are taught sex education?
Most believe that they should receive sex education at school. Surveys by the Sex Education Forum, an umbrella organisation for groups with interests in issues such as health, education and religion, have found that more than two-thirds of nine-year-olds think they should be taught sex education in the classroom. 60% of young teenagers, meanwhile, believe that serious sex education should start in junior school between the ages of nine and 11. They say they want open and honest discussion, not only about the physical act but about feelings and relationships, including homosexuality, and real-life dilemmas.

What obligations do schools have to provide sex education?
The basic biology of reproduction is set out in National Curriculum science, compulsory for all pupils aged between five and 16. Secondary schools must also give lessons on HIV and Aids and sexually transmitted diseases. After that, it is up to individual governing bodies in both primary and secondary schools - in consultation with parents - to formulate policies setting out what additional sex education they will be giving. Parents are allowed to examine this policy and withdraw children from any sex education outside the National Curriculum if they desire. Many schools are also beginning to teach education as part of the new "personal, social and health and education and citizenship framework" published last year. Among the aims of the framework is "developing good relationships and respecting the differences between people". Campaigners believe sex education in schools remains "patchy" - excellent in some places, almost non-existent in others. There is also criticism that what is taught can be "over-biological".

Are schools allowed to teach about issues such as homosexuality?
Yes. Though Section 28 - which outlaws the "promotion" of homosexuality in schools by local authorities - remains on the statute books, it does not in reality impact on schools. No prosecution has ever been initiated under its terms and local authorities no longer run schools anyway. However it does cause anxiety for some teachers and legitimise the wishes of those who, for personal reasons, do not want to teach about homosexuality. The various acts covering what may be taught in schools do not specifically prohibit the discussion of certain sexual issues. However, a teacher may wish to seek advice if, for example, a pupil asks a question about an illegal act. If a child admits to under-age sex, a teacher should encourage him or her to seek professional and parental advice.

What role should parents play in sex education?
Experts agree that parents must get involved. The Sex Education Forum encourages parents to "start early" - children need to be told about body changes and feelings before they experience them. More than one in ten girls start their periods before being told anything about them. Children will get sex education anyway from peers, from older children and from the media. The messages might well be confusing. Most experts believe that parents should begin teaching their children sex education when they start asking questions - this will probably be before primary school age. More than 95% of parents want schools to teach sex education and most wish they had had more sex education when they were at school.

What other sources are available for a young person seeking sex education?
Access to the internet has opened up almost endless sources of information for young people. There are any number of websites giving children and young people access to information about sex. And earlier this year the Brook Advisory Centre came in for criticism for producing what was described as a "good grope guide" aimed at 14-year-olds. It described how teenagers could have fun without having full sex, but caused some headteachers and family campaigners to claim that it could encourage underage sex.

How will the new campaign differ?
As the campaign is still in the planning stage, few details about it have emerged. Ministers are determined that it will not be judgmental but will provide young people with the facts they need. It might well be based around a single central idea based on love and sexual attraction, encapsulated in a jingle or slogan. It will also encourage parents to talk to their children. The campaign, however, is likely to be controversial with some church figures, right-wing morality groups and some parents if it does not give a clear message that underage sex is wrong and sex within marriage the ideal.

It might well be based around a single central idea based on love and sexual attraction, encapsulated in a jingle or slogan. It will also encourage parents to talk to their children. The campaign, however, is likely to be controversial with some church figures, right-wing morality groups and some parents if it does not give a clear message that underage sex is wrong and sex within marriage the ideal. fields.headline: PCC to issue new privacy guidelines
fields.trailText: The Press Complaints Commission is to publish new guidelines for the media to protect the privacy of the prime minister's son, says Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The Press Complaints Commission is to publish new guidelines for the media to protect the privacy of the prime minister's son, Leo Blair.

Chairman Lord Wakeham said it was in everyone's interest to set stronger guidelines on stories affecting the children of high-profile public figures.

The advice follows a request by Tony Blair, who was upset when unofficial photographs of his son's Christening appeared in the press.

Speaking this morning on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, Lord Wakeham said: "Unless the press go absolutely mad, we should be reasonably all right about free expression in the newspapers. We will watch it very carefully."

Lord Wakeham said existing guidelines were temporary in nature because they worked for a while but then quickly became out of date whenever a new situation arose.

He added that he expected that the PCC would need to address a few problems arising from human rights legislation.

"The prime minister has asked me to produce some guidelines as to how the code ought to apply to children, to Leo in particular. We are just trying to put that together and we should be hopefully able to publish it fairly soon. It is not a new problem, but it needs to be redefined every now and again. We are not looking for perfection," said Lord Wakeham.

"What we are looking for are practical, working ways forward, so that it is reasonable on both sides. The public gets to know what it should know, newspapers get their stories, but at the same time privacy is not intruded on."

fields.headline: Monster.com announces £13.7m pan-European campaign
fields.trailText: Monster.com, the US jobs and recruitment site, today unveiled a £13.7m pan-European ad campaign.
fields.body:
Monster.com, the US jobs and recruitment site, today unveiled a $20m (£13.7m) pan-European advertising campaign that gently mocks people's misguided attempts to claw their way up the career ladder.

The campaign, created by Saatchi & Saatchi, breaks later this month in 15 European countries including the UK. It will run on television, press, radio, posters and the internet. The television commercials were shot by Fredrik Bond, the award-winning Swedish director whose credits include campaigns for Adidas, Guinness and Skoda.

The television campaign features a series of characters trying unsuccessfully to impress their bosses. In one ad, a young man playing in goal at the office football match performs an aggressive tackle on his boss, with disastrous effects. In another, an ambitious young woman's plans to impress her boss with her golfing technique backfire when she becomes overly competitive.

The strapline is: "For career advice worth listening to and thousands of jobs visit monster.co.uk, the world's leading career network."

Separately, Monster.com yesterday awarded its $75m (£51m) US advertising account to Arnold Communications.

fields.headline: One in four shun internet
fields.trailText: September 8: A new Which? report claims 15m people in the UK do not intend to go online, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Despite the growing number of TV internet products aimed at non-internet users, they do not seem to have any inclination to go online.

A report by consumer association Which? said one in four people in the UK remain insistent they will never go online.

The report raises questions about the viability of electronic voting and banking if 15m people intend never to go online, and says the government and internet businesses cannot afford to ignore them.

These people said their reasons are simple: mistrust of the internet, the cost of net access and the concept that the web is a haven for fraud and pornography.

Balancing this out, 13m people in the UK have regular access to the internet.

fields.trailText: With the media already settling into the Sydney saloons for saturation coverage of that glorified school sports day, turn to www.silly2000.com, a worthy and wry homegrown Australian attempt at putting the Olympics into perspective. Updated daily, in both "American and non-American", the site offers surfers a steroids race sweepstake ("bet on those most likely to take drugs"), gossip (do you know the rowing lanes apparently use oversize toilet stopcocks instead of buoys) and spoof news, including an "exclusive" on the record-breaking 100ml urine sample dash. If that doesn't make you chortle, then turn to the Manchester 2000 section which is (yep, you guessed) incomplete.

Plastic bags around your feet sealed at the top with Vaseline to create "an airtight, precious greenhouse effect" and walking barefoot around a local swimming pool changing room.

The temperature in Morden is approximately 15 degrees celsius, and Morden is in the same time zone as Mill Hill East, so there's no need to adjust your watches."

fields.headline: CMGI to offload businesses in push for profit
fields.trailText: September 8: CMGI, the internet holding firm behind AltaVista and DoubleClick, plans to sell off a number of its businesses, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
CMGI, the internet holding firm behind AltaVista and DoubleClick, plans to sell off a number of its businesses in order to position itself to move into profit.

The company said it could reduce the number of companies it owns, or has stakes in, to little as five, down from 17, either by divesting them or consolidating. A number of job losses are expected.

CMGI is expected to merge its interactive marketing companies, AdForce, Engage and Yes Mail, as well as its business-to-business companies, Navipath and 1st Up.

The wide-ranging restructuring aims to create six business divisions focusing on search and portals, internet infrastructure, internet professional services, interactive marketing, e-business and fulfilment, and venture capital investments.

CMGI has also ditched plans for a $1.5bn (£1bn) international venture capital fund with Hicks, Muse, and Tate & Furst, which was first mooted six months ago, because of an assumed conflict of interest.

The strategy is aimed at making the company easier for investors to understand and set its share price, which has fallen by more than 70% from its peak, on the road back to recovery.

webTitle: Shuttle Atlantis blasts off to space station

fields.headline: Shuttle Atlantis blasts off to space station
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Space shuttle Atlantis, carrying five Americans and two Russians, is on its way to furnish the growing international space station.
fields.body:
Space shuttle Atlantis, carrying five Americans and two Russians, is on its way to furnish the growing international space station.

Nasa had worried for days that rain might delay the launch. But the approaching storm slowed down and stayed far enough offshore, allowing the shuttle to rise from its seaside pad into a cloudy sky at 12.45 GMT, right on time.

Atlantis' 11-day voyage is the first shuttle flight in almost four months and the start of what Nasa hopes will be a rapid-fire series of missions to the space station.

It was an auspicious start - this was the first punctual launch for the space shuttle program since John Glenn's return to orbit in October 1998.

"Have a nice trip. Make the station into a home," launch controller George Gross told the astronauts just before liftoff.

"We intend to do just that," replied shuttle commander Terrence Wilcutt.

The space station was soaring over Hungary, 6,600 miles away, when Atlantis took off. The shuttle should catch up early Sunday.

The five US astronauts and two Russian cosmonauts will be the first to float into the space station's new Russian-made control module, Zvezda, which means Star. Its arrival 1 1/2 months ago nearly doubled the size of the station to a crowded three rooms.

Wilcutt and his crew will unload thousands of pounds of supplies from Atlantis and a Russian supply ship that already is docked to the space station. They also will install the toilet, set up the treadmill and lay cable. Until Zvezda's launch in July, more than two years late, space station construction was on hold. Despite the extra time, Zvezda failed to meet Nasa safety standards for noise and micrometeoroid protection. Mufflers and shields eventually will be added; in the meantime, everyone inside, Atlantis' crew included, will have earplugs.

Space shuttle Discovery must follow with the first piece of space station truss, or framework, before the first permanent residents can move in at the beginning of November.

Altogether, Nasa plans eight shuttle flights to the space station over the next year, beginning with Atlantis' mission.

"We made use of the delays to get our hardware ready, and now it's time to show that we can deliver on what we said we were going to do," said Robert Cabana, manager of space station international operations.

The high point will be the launch of the US lab Destiny in January. At that point, the international space station will be larger than Russia's Mir. That is also when controllers in Houston will take over day-to-day space station operations from their counterparts in Moscow.

Russia is supposed to supply more cargo ships and more space station components. But because of the country's financial crisis, everything beyond this year is in question.

Atlantis is due back on September 19, although Nasa hopes to conserve enough power to extend the mission by one day.

fields.headline: Kitano launches rival Tokyo festival
fields.trailText: Japanese actor-director (Beat) Takeshi Kitano has announced that his production, distribution and promotion team, Office Kitano, is to launch a festival of Asian and independent film
fields.body:
Japanese actor-director (Beat) Takeshi Kitano has announced that he will be diversifying even further from his film and TV career, and at the same time getting a piece of the hottest action in world cinema today. His production, distribution and promotion team, Office Kitano, is to launch a festival of Asian and independent film, Screen Daily reports.

Kitano's festival, Filmex 2000, is something of an antidote to the growing commercialism of the long-established Tokyo International Film Festival, which this year opens with End Of Days and closes with Charlie's Angels. Asia is today widely acknowledged to be a source of some of the world's most exciting and innovative films, and this year, both the Cannes and Venice festival were dominated by selections from Iranian, Chinese and Japanese directors, to name but a few.

Indeed, some dubbed this year's Cannes festival the 'Year of Iran': two Iranians shared the Camera d'Or (the award to first time film-makers): Zamani baraye masti ashba from Bahman Ghobadi and Djomeh from Hassan Yektapanah; while the jury prize went to Samira Makhmalbaf for her film Blackboards.

"We are interested in presenting independent Asian films and those which cannot be shown in Japan," said Shozo Ichiyama, Filmex director and head of T-Mark, Office Kitano's specialist film division.

Filmex 2000 will be held in Tokyo between the 16 and 24 December, and will include a competitive section for Asian films by emerging directors as well as a series of special screenings showcasing independent film-making from around the world.

Confirmed so far are three Iranian titles: Jafar Panahi's Venice competition film The Circle and Samira Makhmalbaf's Blackboards, and another Venice competitor Jia Zhangke's Platform.

Kitano's own documentary series Travelogues is expected to be screened in an out-of-competition slot. The full line-up will be announced in mid-October.

webTitle: Lorry driver may hold key to Sarah's murder

fields.headline: Lorry driver may hold key to Sarah's murder
fields.trailText: Police are today appealing to a lorry driver who may have seen the killer of murdered schoolgirl Sarah Payne to step forward.
fields.body:
Police are today appealing to a lorry driver who may have seen the killer of murdered schoolgirl Sarah Payne to step forward.

A car driver has told police a white van pulled out of the lane beside the field where Sarah's body was found, at around 11pm on July 1, the night she vanished.

The Transit-style van then pulled out in front out in front of a white lorry, forcing it to brake suddenly, before the car, lorry and van all drove north up the A29.

Police are now desperate to find the driver of the 35ft-long lorry, who they believe could have seen the eight-year-old's killer just after he dumped her naked body in a field beside the A29, just north of Pulborough, West Sussex.

Detective Superintendent Peter Kennet, who is leading the inquiry, said: "You could perhaps be one of the key witnesses to the entire inquiry as to what you actually saw on the night of Saturday July 1."

He continued: ""Sarah probably was buried at about that time, so therefore you have seen the vehicle that carried Sarah's murderer."

Sarah's brother Lee, 13, has told police he saw a white Transit-style van in the lane where she vanished, just minutes after she started to walk home alone towards her grandparents' home in Kingston, West Sussex, at about 7.45pm.

The car driver, from London, contacted police on July 29 to tell them what he had seen. He had been following the lorry for about 10 miles before they reached Pulborough. He said it was white, 30ft long, 12ft high and had curtains along its side panels. It had a distinctive black and white logo painted across its rear doors, showing a black tyre with a spanner sticking through its middle, and had a British number plate.

The car driver has also given police details about the white van, which detectives say fit the description of the van spotted by Lee Payne, but he did not see the van's driver.

Mr Kennet said the van pulled out sharply from the track beside the field where Sarah's body was found and said the lorry had been forced to brake sharply to avoid a crash.

He said the van only had its sidelights on and was described as a "ghost vehicle" by the car driver.

The van turned off the A29 and headed towards Barns Green, about four miles north of the spot where Sarah's body was found on July 17.

The murder hunt has now cost more than £1m, with 50 officers working on the case. Police have spoken to more than 5,000 people and taken more than 1,000 statements.

Mr Kennet said: "Morale is high and we remain confident of a successful outcome."

Police still have not found Sarah's underwear, blue Fred Perry-style sports dress and one remaining black shoe.

A possible sighting of the blue dress in the hamlet of Brooks Green, near Coolham, West Sussex where her one shoe was found, has now been ruled out.

Anyone with information about the murder should contact Sussex police on 0845 6070999.

webTitle: Labour finds £5bn hole in Hague plan

fields.headline: Labour finds £5bn hole in Hague plan
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague suffered a blow to his election campaign last night when it emerged that a central plank of his manifesto would cost £5bn, a sum that would add 2p to the basic rate of income tax.
fields.body:
William Hague suffered a blow to his election campaign last night when it emerged that a central plank of his manifesto would cost £5bn, a sum that would add 2p to the basic rate of income tax.

After the Conservative leader unveiled his pre-election manifesto this week with a pledge to reform the basic state pension, Labour released figures indicating that his plans would cost billions of pounds and jeopardise the income of pensioners.

Mr Hague tried to woo young voters when he pledged to offer them the chance to save for retirement through a state-funded alternative to the basic state pension. Anyone who opted for the scheme would pay less in national insurance to allow them to build up a private or occupational pension scheme.

The Tories refused to be drawn on how much their pension would cost, saying that the plan was still on drawing board. This left the way clear for Labour, which last night released an analysis to the Guardian. The costing, drawn up by the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, said the loss of national insurance revenue proposed would lead to a £5bn "black hole" within five years "if only half of those under the age of 45 opted out of paying national insurance. "

"However, if everyone opted out - as seems likely, given this is a one-way bet - this would double the costs: £10bn of lost national insurance contributions in five years time."

Mr Darling claimed that the huge cost of the scheme highlighted the "irresponsible" approach to spending adopted by the Tories, who committed themselves in their manifesto to cut spending by £16bn.

However, the scheme also poses a threat to the pensioners of today because their weekly pensions are funded from current national insurance contributions.

Mr Darling said last night that the scheme showed that the Tory party was "out to lunch" on tax and spending.

He told the Guardian: "This plan is economically illiterate. It can be funded only by increasing taxes, increasing borrowing or lowering pensions. This is ill thought out."

He demonstrated Labour's determination to concentrate on the Tories' approach to tax and spending by mocking Mr Hague for his boast he would shave billions off the government's spending plans while the Tory leader was simultaneously dreaming up uncosted policies. "For 18 years the Tories pilloried us over tax and spending," he said. "Now their tax and spending plans are falling apart at the seams."

Mr Darling's assault on the pension scheme will add weight to critics of Mr Hague who believe that he made a mistake by unveiling such an important policy without apparently thinking it through.

Some Tories believe that the leadership had not realised that the plan would attract attention, and had expected the shadow social security secretary, David Willetts, to be given a free run when he presented it later this month.

However, Labour wasted no time, attacking it as a backdoor privatisation of the state pension - an attack echoing the devastating onslaught on the Tories' pension plans in 1997 that killed off John Major's election campaign.

The Tories will say Mr Darling's figures are grossly exaggerated. However, Labour believes they are in a muddle over their spending plans. The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, said at the launch of the mini manifesto that it was "fiscally neutral", with any spending increases balanced by savings. At the same time he refused to be drawn on his tax and spending plans, saying they would be unveiled later.

Anyone who opted for the scheme would pay less in national insurance to allow them to build up a private or occupational pension scheme. The Tories refused to be drawn on how much their pension would cost, saying that the plan was still on drawing board. This left the way clear for Labour, which last night released an analysis to the Guardian. The costing, drawn up by the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, said the loss of national insurance revenue proposed would lead to a £5bn "black hole" within five years "if only half of those under the age of 45 opted out of paying national insurance. " "However, if everyone opted out - as seems likely, given this is a one-way bet - this would double the costs: £10bn of lost national insurance contributions in five years time." Mr Darling claimed that the huge cost of the scheme highlighted the "irresponsible" approach to spending adopted by the Tories, who committed themselves in their manifesto to cut spending by £16bn. However, the scheme also poses a threat to the pensioners of today because their weekly pensions are funded from current national insurance contributions. Mr Darling said last night that the scheme showed that the Tory party was "out to lunch" on tax and spending. He told the Guardian: "This plan is economically illiterate. It can be funded only by increasing taxes, increasing borrowing or lowering pensions. This is ill thought out." He demonstrated Labour's determination to concentrate on the Tories' approach to tax and spending by mocking Mr Hague for his boast he would shave billions off the government's spending plans while the Tory leader was simultaneously dreaming up uncosted policies. "For 18 years the Tories pilloried us over tax and spending," he said. "Now their tax and spending plans are falling apart at the seams." Mr Darling's assault on the pension scheme will add weight to critics of Mr Hague who believe that he made a mistake by unveiling such an important policy without apparently thinking it through. Some Tories believe that the leadership had not realised that the plan would attract attention, and had expected the shadow social security secretary, David Willetts, to be given a free run when he presented it later this month. However, Labour wasted no time, attacking it as a backdoor privatisation of the state pension - an attack echoing the devastating onslaught on the Tories' pension plans in 1997 that killed off John Major's election campaign. The Tories will say Mr Darling's figures are grossly exaggerated. However, Labour believes they are in a muddle over their spending plans. The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, said at the launch of the mini manifesto that it was "fiscally neutral", with any spending increases balanced by savings. At the same time he refused to be drawn on his tax and spending plans, saying they would be unveiled later.

fields.headline: Straw brother guilty of assault
fields.trailText: The brother of Home Secretary Jack Straw was today convicted of indecently assaulting a 16-year-old girl.
fields.body:
The brother of Home Secretary Jack Straw was today convicted of indecently assaulting a 16-year-old girl.

William Straw, 47, had pleaded not guilty at Nottingham magistrates court to assaulting the girl at her home in the Bramcote area of Nottingham in April of this year.

District judge Peter Nuttall found Straw guilty and fined the Open University administrator £750 plus £275 court costs.

The court heard how he had bumped into the girl, a friend of the family, while she was out shopping on April 19 this year. He asked her to come to his home to see his new dog. The girl declined saying she had GCSE revision, but a short time later Straw rang her home and repeated the offer. The girl, who cannot be named for legal reasons, told the court Straw then rode his bike around to her house.

Father-of-two Straw, who will be placed on the sex offenders' register for five years, then invited himself in, the girl told the court.

She said: "He came in to the kitchen and asked if I was okay.

"I had not asked him to come in, I felt worried and nervous but I offered him a cup of tea because he is a friend of the family."

She said Straw, who is married but separated, started chatting and at one point touched part of her stomach exposed below the crop top she was wearing.

She said the pair continued to talk and Straw then asked where her bedroom was and if he could have a look. "I started to get more worried but he was a family friend so I said yes," she told the court. She and Straw went to the bedroom where he sat on the bed stroking it and saying how soft it was.

As they left the room to go back downstairs, the teenager said Straw turned and put his hands on her hips. She told the court: "He started rubbing my hips and staring at my breasts. I told him he was scaring me and he seemed to snap out of a trance."

Straw then apologised and went back downstairs leaving a short time later and apologising again for his actions.

webTitle: 41 hurt as US tourist bus crashes

fields.headline: 41 hurt as US tourist bus crashes
fields.standfirst: Emergency contact number: 020 8313 3016
fields.trailText: A bus full of British tourists has crashed in the US, injuring all 41 on board, including two who lost limbs when the vehicle skidded 200 feet across a two-lane road.
fields.body:
A bus full of British tourists has crashed in the US, injuring all 41 on board, including two who lost limbs when the vehicle skidded 200 feet across a two-lane road.

A further six people suffered critical injuries in the Nevada crash.

Rick Palmer, of the University of Nevada Medical Centre, told the Las Vegas Review-Journal newspaper that a 72-year-old man had both his arms severed near the elbows.

The crash scene is five hours by road from both Las Vegas and Reno and casualties have been transferred to hospitals in both cities by helicopter and aeroplane.

"The driver for an unknown reason went off the road, crossing both lanes and went off the left hand shoulder of the highway," Nevada Highway Patrol spokesman Trooper Richard James said.

The coach was carrying 39 passengers, a tour director and driver, said a spokesman for British tour operator Archers Direct, who chartered the coach from a Californian firm.

Mr James later confirmed 27 casualties were being taken to Washoe Medical Centre and the bus involved was a triple-axle Prevost registered in 1999.

"We're not sure if speed was a factor and weather conditions were clear and there was no wind," he said.

A spokesman for Bromley-based Archers Direct said: "Senior personnel are currently en route from the UK and staff in the USA are co-operating fully with the local authorities to determine the cause of the crash. Our immediate and primary concern is for the welfare of the customers and their relatives."

Mr James said: "Two people were airlifted to the University of Nevada Trauma Centre in Las Vegas where they received some sort of amputations, but we do not have full details. Their injuries were received as the vehicle was sliding along the highway."

Other injured have been transported to Washoe Medical Center in Reno, where spokeswoman Kate Griswold said the injured included a middle-aged man from Oxford, a 55-year-old woman from Yorkshire and another middle-aged woman.

The tourists were on the 10th day of a 15-day holiday of a lifetime around the western United States.

Priced at £1,100 a head, the party left the UK on August 29 and had taken in San Francisco, Los Angeles, Palm Springs and the Grand Canyon.

webTitle: Did a Russian missile hit the Kursk?

fields.headline: Did a Russian missile hit the Kursk?
fields.standfirst:
Berliner Zeitung
Secret of the Russian sub still awash in the Barents
fields.trailText: A guided missile from a Russian warship sank the Russian submarine Kursk, a German newspaper has reported.
fields.body:
A guided missile from a Russian warship sank the Russian submarine Kursk, a German newspaper has reported.

The report in the Berliner Zeitung daily said that FSB domestic intelligence service chief Nikolai Patruschev had handed a report to President Vladimir Putin which said the "Granit" missile had been fired by the Russian warship Peter the Great as part of an exercise that had been going on since early August - killing all 118 people on board.

However, Interfax news agency quoted Deputy Prime Minister Ilya Klebanov as saying there was no shooting under way at the time of the disaster, and that no live warheads would have been used during the training exercises. Navy spokesman Igor Dygalo also said no live ammunition would have been used, and said the two ships would not have been operating within striking range. "In the process of exercises such an accident is strictly excluded because surface ships and submarines operate within strictly defined training zones," Interfax quoted him as saying.

But the German newspaper said both the head of the Northern Fleet, Admiral Vyacheslav Popov, and its chief of staff, Vice-Admiral Mikhail Mozak, had been on board the warship on August 12, the day of the accident.

The report did not say why the missile had hit the Kursk, but speculated that it may have been an error in a new weapon system or that the Kursk was not recognised as a friendly craft.

The two explosions caused by the missile were visible from the bridge of the Peter the Great, the paper said. Russian officials have suggested a foreign submarine may have collided with the Kursk, causing it to sink with all 118 people on board. There was no immediate comment from the FSB in Moscow.

webTitle: Secret of the Russian sub still awash in the Barents

fields.headline: Secret of the Russian sub still awash in the Barents
fields.standfirst:
Russian reticence has laden the Kursk disaster with a shroud of enigma. Richard Norton-Taylor looks at the on-going efforts to ascertain what happened to the scuttled submarine

Did a Russian missile hit the Kursk?
fields.trailText: Russian reticence has laden the Kursk disaster with a shroud of enigma. Richard Norton-Taylor looks at the on-going efforts to ascertain what happened to the scuttled submarine.
fields.body:
A flagship Russian nuclear-powered submarine crashes to the bottom of the Barents sea with no explanation. There's scarcely a better scenario to launch a flood of conspiracy theories, let alone send Hollywood screenwriters scurrying for their laptops. Experts - some genuine, some self-styled - offer conspiracies, explanations. Speculation is fuelled by the silence of the Russian government, not to mention the crew.

Among the theories, of course, was that the Kursk had been hit by a US, or even a British, submarine keeping watch on the Russian navy's northern fleet exercise. There was a report that a damaged US submarine had berthed at the Trident nuclear missile base at Faslane. Nonsense, said the Ministry of Defence, the submarine was merely docking to allow its crew some rest and recreation.

Yesterday, President Clinton's aides handed Vladimir Putin a US intelligence report confirming that there had indeed been two American submarines in the area at the time. The report is said to contradict claims by Russian officials that the Kursk had collided with another vessel or struck a mine.

According to the US report, top-secret acoustic sonar readings identified two separate explosions, two minutes and 15 seconds apart. US naval intelligence, who insisted there was no collision, speculated that the first explosion was the result of an experimental torpedo - apparently liquid-fuelled - and the second the result of a warhead exploding. The 118 sailors on board must have died almost immediately, the US officials said.

"The information which we received yesterday comes from the technical monitoring of the area where the Kursk sank," Putin said at a news conference on Thursday. "It refers to explosions registered in the area, and will help us analyse the situation and make conclusions on what caused the catastrophe," he said. The mystery continues

webTitle: Bruce Gyngell, former boss of TV-am, dies

fields.headline: Bruce Gyngell, former TV-am boss, dies
fields.trailText: Bruce Gyngell, one of the most colourful figures in UK commercial broadcasting in the last three decades, died last night.
fields.body:
BBC director general Greg Dyke today led TV industry tributes to Bruce Gyngell, who died last night.

Dyke, who worked with Gyngell during his days at breakfast broadcaster TV-am, said: "Bruce was one of the more colourful characters in our business. He was widely liked. The industry will be a duller place without him."

Gyngell, 71, who was managing director of TV-am in the 1980s, died after a battle with cancer last night in the private Lister Hospital, in Chelsea.

The first face to appear on Australian TV in 1957, Gyngell was brought in to revive TV-am in 1984.

The Australian-born TV executive was also managing director of ATV in the 1970s and Yorkshire-Tyne Tees Television in the 1990s.

The news was announced this morning by David Keighley, a family friend and formerly director of corporate affairs at TV-am.

fields.headline: Red Star return moved forward
fields.trailText: Leicester City's Uefa Cup first-round second-leg match with Red Star Belgrade has been switched from September 28th to September 21st to avoid the presidential election in Yugoslavia.
fields.body:
Leicester City's Uefa Cup first-round second-leg match with Red Star Belgrade has been switched from September 28th to September 21st to avoid the presidential election in Yugoslavia.

Earlier this week Uefa had insisted that they would not change the date or the venue of the game - despite Foreign Office fears that it would take place amid political turmoil in Belgrade.

But after meeting Leicester City chairman John Elsom yesterday, Uefa has agreed to move the date to September 21st - three days before the election.

However the new date "still remains conditional on Uefa receiving written assurances relating to the security and safety of the travelling City party" from Yugoslav state authorities and security forces by Tuesday, it said.

And Uefa has also advised Leicester not to take any supporters to Belgrade.

webTitle: Latest national newspaper ABCs show broadsheets are up

fields.headline: Tabloids suffer at hands of broadsheets in latest ABCs
fields.trailText: Broadsheets are up, tabloids are down, according to the latest batch of ABCs on national newspapers. Amy Vickers reports.
fields.body:
Broadsheets are up, tabloids are down, according to the latest batch of ABC six-month data on national newspapers.

In the six months from March to August, the daily tabloids sold 7.1m copies, a gain of 2.9% month-on-month, but an overall year-on-year decline of 2.92%. The mid-markets (Daily Express and The Daily Mail) were also in decline with total sales dropping 1.59% month-on-month to 3.4m.

The daily broadsheets were the only titles to collectively gain sales year-on-year. The national dailies gained 2.3% to 2.9m while the national Sundays rose 0.26% to 2.99m.

Sunday Business was the shining star of the Sundays, racking up a year-on-year rise of 14.72% to 63,486, despite recording a decline of 6.20% month-on-month over the past six months.

Other notable gains and losses included London's Evening Standard, which dropped 8.33% over the past six months to 438,776, and the Financial Times and the Scotsman, which recorded annual growth of 18.33% and 17.14% respectively.

Overall, total morning newspaper sales declined year-on-year by 1.14% and the Sundays' net circulation dropped 1.46%.

fields.headline: What an offer, Hezza
fields.trailText:
What an offer, Hezza
The response to Michael Heseltine's generous offer to sell his book to staff at the knock-down price of £10 has apparently met with a terrific response. So much so that Hezza has promised to sign every one personally. "His generosity exceeds our wildest expectations," said a Haymarket source.
