fields.headline: Media Monkey business
fields.trailText:
What an offer, Hezza
Michael Heseltine's generous offer to sell his book to staff at the knock-down price of £10 has apparently met with a terrific response. So much so that Hezza has promised to sign every one personally. "His generosity exceeds our wildest expectations," said a Haymarket source.
fields.body:
What an offer, Hezza
Michael Heseltine's generous offer to sell his book to staff at the knock-down price of £10 has apparently met with a terrific response. So much so that Hezza has promised to sign every one personally. "His generosity exceeds our wildest expectations," said a Haymarket source.

Jungle fever?
A memo went round Haymarket Publishing's offices today with the following unmissable offer for all Michael Heseltine's minions: "Haymarket has a quantity of Michael Heseltine's book, "Life in the Jungle", published today, at the special price of £10." The lines to Hezza's office must be jammed.

Wise words
Andrew Neil, speaking at the recent People and Profits in the New Economy conference: "If you have trouble with recruitment and retention, then your company sucks." Could that be the same Andrew Neil who has recently had quite a lot of trouble with staff retention at the Scotsman? Your words, Andrew, not ours.

Mo better box
Word that retiring Labour MP St Mo of Mowlam is considering a TV career has got the Media Monkey flicking through its contacts book in search of old broadcasting muckers who may be able to help out. The first call will undoubtedly be to the ITV Network Centre, where they are still a chief executive short of a full ITV Council. St Mo would be the ideal candidate - after all, she has plenty of experience of a job where people are always knifing you in the back. But Media Monkey would welcome other suggestions...

"Nasty" Nick snapped
Media Monkey is certain the Sun, as the official Big Brother newspaper, will be gagging to get its hands on some photos reportedly doing the rounds, which show "Nasty" Nick Bateman in his first public clinch with a member of the opposite sex since being evicted from the house of two-way mirrors. The offending snaps, taken outside the Met Bar after the TV Quick awards on Tuesday night (September 4), are said to feature Nick in a warm embrace with, er... go-getting Sun TV reporter Emily Smith. All in the line of duty, no doubt.

Sky's the limit
Does the low cunning of the BSkyB marketing department know no bounds? Imagine little Johnnie and Jemima's delight when, after a spot of bulletin reading courtesy of Sky News during their visit to the Millennium Dome, they are given a videotape of the performance to take home and treasure. Imagine their disappointment when, on getting home and watching the video, they have to sit through several minutes of trailers for Sky TV services before glimpsing their brief moment of fame. Fiendishly clever.

A few Choice words
The dirtiest catfight in telly, Terry Wogan v Stuart Murphy, splutters on in the letters column of BBC in-house organ Ariel. You may recall that in a letter to Ariel last week, BBC Choice head honcho Murphy launched a stout defence of the BBC following La Wogan's recent attack on the corporation, telling him he was "living in a bizarre fantasy world of an Auntie's Bloomers script". This week in Ariel, BBC broadcasting and presentation staffers Mark Thomas and Christina Dunley leapt to Wogan's defence, accusing Murphy of "wanting us to work for a Stalinist BBC where employees dare not utter any criticism of their masters". The pair conclude: "Let's face it Stuart, Choice has never delivered on the promise of its name... the sooner BBC3 rises from its ashes the better." Miaow!

Don't talk at Talk
The queen of New York publishing, Tina Brown, is giving Brits abroad a bad name. Staff members at Talk magazine have been told not to approach Ms Brown directly with ideas or questions, as their input is "driving her crazy". New York magazine reports gleefully that the new rule is that editorial director [Bob Wallace] or his direct underling [Perry van der Meer] must filter Tina's traffic. Wallace disputes the account, saying that while Van der Meer -- who worked under Brown at The New Yorker -- was brought in recently to streamline the editorial process, "anyone can still come to Tina and me or e-mail us at any time about any issue. And believe me, they do." The New York Times' source notes sorrowfully: "No one wants to hear that they're driving their boss crazy." Ms Brown is in England on holiday.

Croaky name?
It's official: advertising agency names are getting sillier. First there was Mother - the trendy, Clerkenwell-based agency that looks after Harvey Nichols and Hoegaarden Beer. Then the disgraced political lobbyist Derek Draper launched an ad agency and mysteriously decided to call it Farm. Now Swiss banking giant Credit Suisse - a company that's surely old enough to know better - has appointed an agency called Strawberry Frog to handle its ads. It makes you long for the good old days, when adland was full of egotists who called their agencies after themselves, and had done with it.

A little unfortunate
Marks & Spencer has been trying to do its bit for normal women by using unusually curvaceous models (to put it politely) in its new ad campaign. So it was unfortunate that only the day before the distinctly uncurvy Tara Palmer-Tomkinson appeared on the front page of the Daily Mail as the new face of Splendour.com - a lingerie-selling website in which M&S has a stake. A small case of double standards, perhaps?

No small beer
Far be it from us to suggest that anyone in advertising takes the whole business of making ads too seriously. But the reaction of Heineken international marketing manager Frazer Thompson to the French ban on alcohol ads may have been a little extreme. "In France the world has gone dark," said a grief-stricken Thompson.

Toilet watch
News that Channel 4 is planning to bring out a Big Brother jigsaw in time for Christmas has inspired the Media Monkey to ponder what other sensational TV tie-ins broadcasters may have up their sleeves. We'll start the ball rolling with the mouth-watering prospect of Channel 4 linking up with Armitage Shanks and Triton to bring out Big Brother-branded toilets and showers with built-in CCTV cameras. Other suggestions welcome.

Obvious passion
It seems that some people who are involved with the media juggernaut that is Big Brother are not satisfied with being stuck in the wings and are itching to get into the limelight. Step forward Jason George (from Big Brother website designer Victoria Real ), James Herring (whose company, Avalon, is handling Big Brother's PR) and Charlie Gardner (PR for Big Brother producer Endemol UK), who late one night during the Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival were overheard auditioning for the role of the show's voiceover man in the George Bar. Queue much repetition, in cod Geordie accents, of illuminating lines such as: "Craig realises he is being filmed..."

Duddy phone
Terry Duddy, chief executive of Argos, was ominously silent after parent company Great Universal Stores bought Jungle.com for a bargain £37m. Was he furious that the Argos internet operation had to link up with a company that has debts of £10m? No, Duddy's mobile phone kept cutting out, leaving many members of the press quote-free. Congratulations are due to Rafik al-Hariri, ex-prime minister of Lebanon, after his storming victory in the country's general election. A memo went round Haymarket Publishing's offices today with the following unmissable offer for all Michael Heseltine's minions: "Haymarket has a quantity of Michael Heseltine's book, "Life in the Jungle", published today, at the special price of £10." The lines to Hezza's office must be jammed. Could that be the same Andrew Neil who has recently had quite a lot of trouble with staff retention at the Scotsman? Your words, Andrew, not ours. Mo better box Word that retiring Labour MP St Mo of Mowlam is considering a TV career has got the Media Monkey flicking through its contacts book in search of old broadcasting muckers who may be able to help out. fields.headline: Ashes target for leg-before detector
fields.trailText: Dodgy lbw decisions may be a thing of the past by the time the Ashes series is contested in England next summer, if new technology is given the go-ahead in time by the International Cricket Council.
fields.body:
Dodgy lbw decisions may be a thing of the past by the time the Ashes series is contested in England next summer, if new technology is given the go-ahead in time by the International Cricket Council.

Two scientific developments are being considered by the game's governing body. The first is a version of the "red zone" used by Channel 4 in its Test coverage, which shows whether the ball pitches in line with the stumps; the second, known as Hawk-Eye, is an invention by a Siemens company and tracks the projected route of the ball after it hits the pad.

Sunset & Vine, which produces Channel 4's cricket and introduced the red zone, has sponsored the latest research, and the United Cricket Board of South Africa will experiment with both systems to assist with lbw decisions in domestic cricket this season before reporting back to the ICC.

The managing director of the UCB, Ali Bacher, said of the "lbw mat", or red zone: "The mat will be useful in determining whether the ball has pitched outside leg stump or, when the batsman has played a shot and the ball has pitched inside leg, whether the point of impact was between wicket and wicket."

Bacher highlighted the dismissal of Brian Lara in the second innings of the fifth Test between England and West Indies at the Oval, when Lara was given out lbw despite the mat showing the ball had pitched marginally wide of his leg stump, which if he was trying to play the ball meant he should have been given not out.

Referring to Hawk-Eye, Bacher said: "We will also have a system where, via the television cameras, radar and computers, we will be able to determine whether a ball which has struck the batsman would have hit or missed the stumps. If the cost is not prohibitive and if the technology is foolproof we will introduce it."

Hawk-Eye, invented by Paul Hawkins at Siemens' research lab in Hampshire, adapts a military missile-tracking system to predict the path of a ball. In the case of an lbw decision, it can calculate to within 5mm whether the ball would have hit the stumps. The process takes two to three seconds.

"There's still a lot of work to be done on it but it will be ready to use by March next year, in time for the Ashes series," said Hawkins, who has himself played minor counties cricket for Buckinghamshire.

Bacher said the new measures would be used only to assist the officials on the field. The umpires would communicate with the television umpires but "it will still be up to the standing umpires to make the decision" once their questions had been answered.

The ICC will review all the evidence next May. "Any system considered for lbw decisions will have to be proven and the technology will need to be available in all Test-playing countries," it said.

webTitle: Restaurants: Simply Heathcotes and Wong Chu Chinese Restaurant, Manchester

fields.headline: Simply Heathcotes and Wong Chu Chinese Restaurant, Manchester
fields.trailText: Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15
fields.body:
Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

Telephone: 0161-835 3536

Address: Simply Heathcotes, Jacksons Row, Deansgate, Manchester M2 5WZ

Paul Heathcote now has eateries in Preston and this bright space in Manchester. Top-notch Euronosh, thoughtfully cooked, reasonably priced, and, with the Menu Rapide - £12.50 for two courses, £14.50 for three, served 11.45am-2.30pm and 5.30-7pm - swiftly prepared from well-chosen ingredients that nab the palate and leave you with an unheavy satiety. The menu changes daily, but typically offers tangy slow-roasted pork with poached pear, earthy chargrilled lamb chops with bubble and squeak polenta, hake with saffron and mussel risotto, and a tantalising trio of plum tarte tatin, prunes and Armagnac ice cream. Proper food, that.

Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Telephone: 0161-236 2346.

Address: Wong Chu Chinese Restaurant, 63 Faulkner Street, Manchester M1 4FF.

Bustling Hong-Kongesque emporium in Manchester's Chinatown. All the usual favourites in the menu, but the real treats are at the back. Complete rice dishes, chow mein, ho fun and noodle soup (£3.80-£6.00) prepared before your eyes. Amidst much chopping and steam emerge piles of roast duck, char siu, crispy pork, beef, chicken, prawn, squid, bean curd and vegetables in whatever combination you fancy atop perfectly cooked rice, unctuous crispy noodles, reassuringly fat rice sticks or delicate mixed-meat broth with soft vermicelli. Fast, furious and fun. Wong Chu turns up the heat on better-known rivals. And the Chinese tea is free.

On the menu: colcannon

Country of origin? Ireland.
Ingredients? Mashed potatoes and cabbage or kale.
Hang on a sec. I thought we did that last week.
That was champ, mash with spring onions, another thing entirely. Oh. How so? With colcannon you can add onions, shallots or leeks, and cream and butter to the mash and cabbage, and not be accused of heresy. And you serve it in bowls with a large blob of butter on top.
Sounds like bubble and squeak. Bubble and squeak is fried. Frying colcannon is forbidden by law.

Just out

Uncle Ben's Rispinos Rice Snacks
Form: Small biscuits of compacted rice.
Flavour: Caramel, chocolate, and apple and cinnamon-flavoured Rispinos all carry the ghost of the flavouring agent, which isn't enough to counter the puffed wheat flavour of the rice.
Verdict: "Less than1% fat" trumpets the packet. It's less than 1% of anything, including calories. It's like eating crisp polystyrene. The texture is everything - flavour is almost non-existent. But they are pleasant and one is never enough.
Price: 27p per 27g pack of 10 Rispinos or 59p per 60g bag.

Food on the net

www.valvonacrolla.com
Needs no introduction - the online arm of the fabled Italian delicatessen launched earlier this year to serve its loyal following. Pros: Around 300 to 400 of the most popular and more obscure lines including malt whiskies, amarena cherries, panforte and their own fonteluna sausage.
Cons: A hand-holding approach towards the scary business of e-commerce.
Delivery: Varies by region. Orders must be placed by 10am. Premium/ standard for delivery next day on UK mainland and economy for delivery within eight working days.
Charges: Free on orders over £100. £5 for economy service on mainland.

webTitle: Eastern designers attempt to woo the west

fields.headline: Indian summer
fields.standfirst: London, Paris, New York, Milan - and New Delhi?  Hadley Freeman reports from India Fashion Week on eastern designers' attempts to woo the west
fields.trailText: London, Paris, New York, Milan - and New Delhi? Hadley Freeman reports from India Fashion Week on eastern designers' attempts to woo the west
fields.body:
Swirling paisley prints, mirror work, bejewelled flip flops: there is no doubt that Indian-influenced fashion has been enjoying an extraordinary popularity for the past few seasons in the west. Leaving aside the pashmina palaver of two years ago, which was more of a fad than an interest in Indian fashion, it can be seen across the high streets and on celebrities. Gold detailing and fringed shawls have been repeated to the point of cliche. Madonna sported a bindi in her video for Frozen and even Boyzone have been spotted with decorative henna work adorning their bodies. Yet something is strikingly missing here. There is a complete dearth of prominent Indian fashion designers in the west.

Part of the problem lies, ironically, with our established appreciation of Indian fashion: it has already arrived, albeit in derivative forms. Designers such as Stella McCartney, John Galliano, Matthew Williamson, Jade Jagger and Gaultier have long been experimenting with Indian-inspired fashion - to the point that Indian designers themselves might not have sufficient novelty to swerve the cameras of the international media away from the familiar faces of Galliano et al.

So it is a shame that last month's first India Fashion Week provoked such a lukewarm response in its own country and has received relatively little attention overseas.

Lamke India Fashion Week, held in New Delhi over six days, showed the collections of 33 Indian designers. It marked the first attempt by the recently formed Fashion Design Council of India (FDCI) to bring Indian designers to global prominence. Although fashion shows have been held in India for the past 15 years, they were genteel, quaintly old-fashioned affairs: a designer would show on his own and it was a glam evening, replete with cocktails. The fashion week was a long-overdue attempt to showcase the talents of as many Indian designers as possible and attract the attention of international buyers and media.

The FDCI's attempts to sell the Indian fashion industry to the west were apparent throughout: designers were instructed to use western approaches in their designs, such as concentrating on ready to wear rather than couture; many showed a mix of eastern and western clothes; and some used western models, such as Jodie Kidd.

Teething problems, though, were apparent. The Hindu, India's national newspaper, dubbed the affair "a farce", complaining that some shows did not begin on time. "Many of the shows were running late and some of the designers had very short notice," concedes Gitanjali Kashyap, fashion designer and member of the FDCI. Jodie Kidd disagrees: "I had a really great time in India. Now I'm just looking forward to going back again."

The designers believe that the poor fashion industry infrastructure in India is the main obstacle to their attempts to break into western markets. "India doesn't really have a retail system, so designers don't have any real back-up," says designer Rina Dhaka.

Nina Patel, a designer for the eastern clothing company Red Blue Purple, based in London and Bombay, is pragmatic about the situation: "There are just so many manufacturing problems in India. Buyers need to be able to fax through requests and know that samples will turn up on time. So no, at the moment India can't compete with London, Paris, New York and Milan, but it can with places like Hong Kong."

Fellow designer Manoviraj Khosla points out the central irony of the Indian fashion industry: "Lots of American and British stores source from India and have factories here, such as Nicole Farhi, French Connection and The Gap. Indian designers need to make their own labels, not just work in production for western companies."

Many eastern designers are more than willing to accommodate their designs to western tastes and needs. Two months ago shopmahal.com, a British based website, was launched, targeting the non-Asian press. It allows visitors to learn about and buy all elements of Indian fashion, from food to clothes to health treatments. The website's PR officer, Vaishali Shah, explains: "Six months ago we saw how all things Indian were really gaining momentum in Britain, and we wanted to take advantage of this. It's funny, two years ago I would not have worn a mirror choker or a bindi in this country because I would have thought they were 'too Indian'. Now it's trendy to wear them, especially with western clothing."

Britain's links with India mean that this country might be the most fertile and accommodating ground for raising the profile of Indian designers. The current vogue for individuality and authenticity suggests a growing market for real Indian designs. Rina Dhaka's clothes, for example, have been worn by Naomi Campbell and Tara Palmer-Tomkinson, and the TV presenter Jayne Middlemiss is one of Nina Patel's most loyal clients. Part of the attraction of Lamke India Fashion Week for Jodie Kidd was to see the origins of the styles she has worn for western fashion designers. "So many designers I've worked for have been influenced by designs from the east. So I have always really wanted to go there."

Whether India can break into the stronghold of the four main fashion cities is another matter. Wealthier, more established fashion weeks - Brazil, Toronto, Hong Kong - have failed to do so. But for the moment, most of the Indian designers would just be happy with some western acknowledgement. "I'm not angry at the west, it's just frustrating that they don't know anything about Indian fashion," says Gitanjali Kashyap.

The former president of the fashion house Chloe, Mounir Moufarriage, the man who recruited Stella McCartney, announced this week that he has formed a partnership with Indian designer Ritu Beri, who also showed in the fashion week. He hopes to launch her first ready-to-wear collection in the US in early October. "The quality is outstanding, far beyond what you would expect," he has said. "I think we could see a lot more from India in the next three to five years."

Rina Dhaka's clothes, for example, have been worn by Naomi Campbell and Tara Palmer-Tomkinson, and the TV presenter Jayne Middlemiss is one of Nina Patel's most loyal clients. Part of the attraction of Lamke India Fashion Week for Jodie Kidd was to see the origins of the styles she has worn for western fashion designers. "So many designers I've worked for have been influenced by designs from the east. So I have always really wanted to go there." Whether India can break into the stronghold of the four main fashion cities is another matter. Wealthier, more established fashion weeks - Brazil, Toronto, Hong Kong - have failed to do so. But for the moment, most of the Indian designers would just be happy with some western acknowledgement. "I'm not angry at the west, it's just frustrating that they don't know anything about Indian fashion," says Gitanjali Kashyap. The former president of the fashion house Chloe, Mounir Moufarriage, the man who recruited Stella McCartney, announced this week that he has formed a partnership with Indian designer Ritu Beri, who also showed in the fashion week. He hopes to launch her first ready-to-wear collection in the US in early October. "The quality is outstanding, far beyond what you would expect," he has said. "I think we could see a lot more from India in the next three to five years."

fields.headline: Associated Newspapers signs cross-media Megawheels deal
fields.trailText: Associated Newspapers has signed a cross-media agreement with online car dealer magazine Megawheels.
fields.body:
Associated Newspapers has signed a cross-media deal with online car dealer magazine Megawheels.

The deal includes Associated New Media's This Is London (www.thisislondon.com) and a new classified supplement in Friday's Evening Standard. The online classified advertising title will be incorporated into This Is London as an additional motoring channel, enabling ANM users to tap into thousands of car sale ads.

Associated Newspapers refused say how much the deal is worth.

"The car market represents a major revenue stream for our papers. We will be able to deliver to our readers a quality motoring website and print publication, as well as provide our classified ad clients with an unparalleled access to their customer base," said Murdoch MacLennan, managing director of Associated Newspapers.

fields.headline: Media stories from today's papers
fields.trailText: Top stories
fields.body:
Top stories

All the papers cover Italian internet service provider Tivali's $5.9bn (£4.1bn) acquisition of World Online.

The other main media story of the day is Granada Media's tie-up with Arsenal Football Club. The broadcaster is investing £47m in the north London club.

The Guardian

The Guardian reports that Channel 4 is considering the future of the Big Breakfast after failing to persuade popular host Johnny Vaughn to reconsider his decision to quit. Falling ratings, an uninspiring presenter line-up and increasing competition have prompted a "wide-ranging review", according to a Channel 4 executive.

The Financial Times

The FT carries a story about the latest project by Indian entrepreneur and Hotmail co-founder Sabeer Bhatia. Bhatia's 23rd start-up, Arzoo.com, will capitalise on the globally mobile workforce by using a pool of freelance software professionals to resolve IT problems over the web.

The Daily Telegraph

The Telegraph reports that BSkyB plans to start including personal video recorders in its set-top boxes early next year. The devices will allow BSkyB's satellite TV subscribers to skip the ads, and record programmes more easily.

The paper's Peterborough column carries a story that Paul Burrell, former butler of Diana Princess of Wales, is dusting off his uniform to butler for the Royle Family. However, he will not be making an appearance on our screens just yet - he is donating his services to a charity event for the Francis House Hospital, where cast members will be the celebrity guests.

The Times

Media pages: Damian Whitworth writes a full-page piece on the man George W Bush called a "major league asshole". The article chronicles a series of less-than-flattering articles written by Adam Clymer, veteran political correspondent of the New York Times, on Bush.

Raymond Snoddy echoes the views of many in an opinion piece headlined: "Time for ITV to pull its finger out." He describes ITV's many embarrassments this week, and points out that the ITV companies have had nearly a year to replace Richard Eyre.

Another piece describes how Freemasonry Today, the official magazine of the UK's 350,000 masons, is relaunching in an effort to attract younger readers, more advertising and newsstand distribution.

The Sun

The Sun's Big Brother obsession continues with the news that Tom and Claire were caught kissing and cuddling in London's China White nightclub. Claire's boyfriend, Troy Harrington, was reportedly nowhere to be seen.

And hoax e-mailers are promising holidays and jokes to anyone who dials 0901 1989 103 - the number to vote Mel out, providing us with the perfect excuse to give you that number again (today's your last chance).

The Army has launched a raunchy ad campaign in which a squaddie tries to bed his girlfriend in her parents' home without waking them up. The Saatchi & Saatchi ad will be broadcast tonight during South Park.

Gratuitous Tabloid story of the day

Liz Hurley has posed naked for next month's GQ magazine, prompting yet more pictures of Hurley in various states of undress. The Mirror at least has the decency to apologise to readers who may be offended by the paper's pathetic lack of self control, and promises never to fall for Hurley's publicity stunts again. Yeah, right.

fields.headline: Ape TV lures Open's Richard Chong
fields.trailText: Independent TV agency Ape TV has poached Open head of design Richard Chong to be its creative director, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Ape TV, the independent TV agency set up at the start of this year, has poached Open head of design Richard Chong to be its creative director.

Chong joins a growing team Ð there are currently 12 staff Ð headed by Peter Barrett, former sales director at Carlton Screen Advertising. He will work on a number of recently won accounts and design the interfaces for interactive TV projects.

Ape TV is a partnership between media agency the Allmond Partnership (TAP) and Amicus Digital, the digital marketing agency chaired by former England rugby union player Brian Moore. The agency handles interactive TV business for, among others, BT and Miller Freeman's U-travel.

Amicus Digital, which runs WapWorld in partnership with Sir Bob Geldof's media company 11 Alps, has also appointed Monica Khiroya, a founding member of the team, as managing director.

fields.headline: Obituary: Tim Aspinall
fields.standfirst: Writer and producer of original drama and landmark series for television
fields.trailText: Tim Aspinall, who has died aged 65, was a television writer, director, producer and a true original. In the 1960s he wrote and produced Coronation Street. He scripted series ranging from Love Story for ATV, to Villains and Bullman for Granada and a BBC Horizon drama documentary on Brunel.
fields.body:
Tim Aspinall, who has died aged 65, was a television writer, director, producer and a true original. In the 1960s he wrote and produced Coronation Street. He scripted series ranging from Love Story for ATV, to Villains and Bullman for Granada and a BBC Horizon drama documentary on Brunel.

In 1972 he produced a landmark Thirty Minute Theatre production of Samuel Beckett's Krapp's Last Tape for BBC television. It featured Patrick Magee, the writer's finest interpreter, in the name role. Later in that decade at Thames Television, working with his close friend Verity Lambert, Tim produced Hazell, Born And Bred, Jemima Shore Investigates - for which he also wrote - and other popular, well-crafted series. He directed drama and documentaries - including Channel 4's Wine Programme and What It's Worth - and, at TVS, in the late 1980s, helped me to develop and encourage many young writers, directors and producers.

I first met him towards the end of 1968 when he arrived at BBC Television Centre to script-edit and, soon afterwards, produce BBC2's Thirty Minute Theatre. Tim regaled us with tales of Fleet Street and Granadaland, and charmed us with his witty, sometimes racy, west London anecdotes. And, with a laidback and assured style, he delivered an extraordinary run of original television drama, week after week.

Tim wrote many fine, often quirky scripts himself - with dialogue often close to poetry - and produced startlingly electric drama; no more so than with Rhys Adrian. At the BBC, in the early 1970s, Rhys and Tim - and I, and others - delivered television plays that included The Gardeners Of My Youth, Buffet and the brilliant Thrills Galore.

Tim was born in Hampstead, London. His father, an army officer, was killed in Burma during the second world war, while his mother was a Spanish aristocrat of Basque origin. He was educated at Beaumont school and in his late teens joined the Eastbourne Gazette. A holiday relief stint at the Daily Mail turned into a job and he later worked at the Mirror and Express. In 1964 he went to Granada in Manchester as a script-editor, and took a director's course with the company.

In the 1970s, post-BBC, he remained a freelance, but joined me at TVS in 1987 and never left my side during the five years I was controller of drama. He produced the first series of Perfect Scoundrels, several single plays, a strand of student films and videos, Take One, where his talent as a teacher augmented his producing brilliance.

Tim loved life, and celebrating activities that he could share with others - cricket, jazz, soccer, classical music, the arts, wine, and eating and cooking good food - his bread-making talents were legendary and he never arrived anywhere without a warm loaf from his oven.

Tim married first Judy, with whom he spent his 20s and very early 30s, together with James, Penny and Matty. Early in his BBC life he married his perfect foil, Mary, and they adopted Ruby and Charlie.

Richard Harris writes: I first met Tim Aspinall when we were young writers on an anthology of television plays produced by the inspiring Stella Richman. He wrote like a dream; his stuff didn't always work and sometimes it was so far off the wall it was out of the building, but it was always full of ideas, full of imagination. Tim had style in the way he was with people - and a kind of subversion about him.

The second time we worked together it was with him as director, the third time as producer. Working with him was always a pleasure. It wasn't the be-all and end-all for him, but if the work could somehow lead to the real stuff of life, so much the better. But the work always got done and always to his high standards - and with that little bit extra on the budget.

We fell out about five years ago, but I really missed working with him. And then, about a couple of years ago, I was taken seriously ill. One afternoon there was Tim, parking his bike in the front garden. He had brought me some home-made soup and we were off and running again. I am not saying he saved my life, but he was one of those who made bloody sure I hung on to it.

But as I was getting stronger and stronger, he, unaccountably, seemed to be less himself. What they found was tumours in his stomach and his liver and suddenly, like some terrible sort of twist, it was him asking the questions and me trying to give the answers. Two days after his first operation I went to see him and he was dancing with a nurse, trailing his tubes behind him.

He was sent home to build up strength for his second operation: he still gave me cooking lessons, and we still went to the pictures in the afternoon. But this time it was him walking slowly and me catching his arm as we crossed the road. At last they said it was time for him to go in and have the tumour cut away from his liver. Complications set in. He died 10 days later. He was a very special man, a one-off.

webTitle: Rank Group considers move into online gaming

fields.headline: Rank Group looks at online gaming market
fields.trailText: The Rank Group, which owns the chain of Mecca Bingo shops, is considering moving into online gaming. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Rank Group, which owns the chain of Mecca Bingo shops, is considering moving into online gaming according to chief executive Mike Smith.

Rank, which also owns the Hard Rock Cafe chain and the Deluxe video operation, has reported a 9% increase in proforma pre-tax profits for the six months to June 30. However, on a non-proforma basis the group showed a fall of about 48% for its half-year profits, down £42.1m from £80.5m a year ago. The group attributed the fall to charges for the sale of its Universal Studios film business and for interest capitalised in 1999.

Commenting on the results, Smith said: "The group continues to make progress both in terms of improving operating performance and reducing its span of activities... We are down to four large, credible business groupings but there will be more reshaping of the group in the coming months as we continue to pursue improved shareholder value."

Earlier this week Rank sold its Tom Cobleigh pub chain for £90m. The group is also in talks over the sale of its holiday arm, which includes the Butlins holiday chain.

fields.headline: Rivals brace themselves for Big Brother finale
fields.trailText: ITV and the BBC are bracing themselves for a ratings hammering next weekend as their minority rival, Channel 4, milks the last out of its reality phenomenon, Big Brother.
fields.body:
ITV and the BBC are bracing themselves for a ratings hammering next weekend as their minority rival, Channel 4, milks the last out of its reality phenomenon, Big Brother.

Channel 4 will devote its key weekend schedules to Big Brother next week, when the show of the summer reaches its climax. Though analysts had predicted a fall-off in the show's ratings, it has hit the main networks hard this week, just as they rolled out their autumn schedule big guns.

ITV has achieved its lowest ever weekly share (25.7%). And last Friday, BBC1 recorded its worst Friday peaktime share - 19% - since March 1995.

A senior programme source revealed last night that C4 will blitz next weekend's schedules for the series' finale. Next Friday - the announcement of the winnning contestant - the standard two half-hour shows will each be extended to 60-minutes between 8.30pm and 9.30pm and from 11pm to 12pm.

On Saturday night, the broadcaster will air a Big Brother theme night, with a 60-minute special documentary made by Adam and Joe Show producers World of Wonder and a half-hour programme from Big Brother creator Endemol about the programme's impact in different countries.

The weekly Big Brother omnibus will be extended to 90 minutes and brought forward from its normal late-night slot.

Word of next week's Big Brother bonanza comes as sources close to the production revealed that this week's eviction is expected to top 2m calls by the time the phone lines close at 8.50pm tonight. The previous record votes cast were 1.5m last week, for Claire v Craig, and 1.4m last month for Caroline v Craig.

Channel 4 executives are said to be delighted with the continued response to the show, despite complaints that the action is becoming boring as the number of contestants falls, which the volume of phone calls this week dispels.

The high level of interest may have been sparked by Mel's first nomination for eviction. The Scary Spice lookalike has divided viewer opinion, with some regarding her as scheming and manipulative, but others feeling that she has been the victim of selective editing by the Big Brother production team.

The level of phone voting (at 10p a call) has prompted programme executives to hope for a turnout of around 3m next week when the final poll will allow the public to decide which of the three remaining Big Brother contestants deserves the £70,000 prize money.

The show's producers, Endemol Entertainment UK, and Channel 4 are understood to be planning to open the phone lines all week instead of four days to maximise the volume of calls. Channel 4 will be hoping for a repeat of last week, when, with the help of Big Brother, live cricket and the terrestrial premier of Elizabeth, the broadcaster notched up a best ever weekly audience share of 13.3%, according to unofficial overnights.

webTitle: BSkyB's next generation set-top boxes to incorporate X-TV software

fields.headline: BSkyB to incorporate X-TV software into new set-top boxes
fields.trailText: BSkyB has confirmed that it will incorporate X-TV personal TV recorder software in its next generation set-top boxes. The new box, set to launch in the early part of next year, will be the first integrated personal television recorder and pay-TV service in Europe.
fields.body:
BSkyB has confirmed that it will incorporate X-TV personal TV recorder software in its next generation set-top boxes. The new box, set to launch in the early part of next year, will be the first integrated personal television recorder and pay-TV service in Europe.

The deal boosts BSkyB's standing in the personal video recorder community as it is the only broadcaster to be working with the type of technology in the UK. Its joint venture with TiVo, to sell TiVo branded boxes at a price of around £300, will hit the shops next month.

The new set-top boxes will allow for the digital recording (TiVo is analogue) of up to 40 hours of programming and will essentially feature the same type of services as the TiVo box.

webTitle: Axe hovers over Channel 4's Big Breakfast

fields.headline: Axe hovers over Channel 4's Big Breakfast
fields.standfirst: Ratings slump forces review of wake-up show
fields.trailText: It broke the mould of breakfast television, making stars of Chris Evans, Gaby Roslin and Denise Van Outen. But falling ratings, tired ideas and an uninspiring presenter line-up have led Channel 4 to wonder whether there is a future for the Big Breakfast's diet of early morning mania.
fields.body:
It broke the mould of breakfast television, making stars of Chris Evans, Gaby Roslin and Denise Van Outen. But falling ratings, tired ideas and an uninspiring presenter line-up have led Channel 4 to wonder whether there is a future for the Big Breakfast's diet of early morning mania.

Executives are discussing whether to axe the show, after failing to persuade the current host, Johnny Vaughan, to reconsider his decision to quit. Competition is intensifying: GMTV and BBC1 are relaunching their breakfast programmes, while cable and satellite channels are capturing more young viewers in the early morning. The show has lost more than half its audience in five years.

At the very least, the Big Breakfast will undergo a radical revamp when Vaughan leaves at the end of the year. In a final attempt to shore up the programme, Outen is being brought back to parry Vaughan's tired jokes.

A Channel 4 executive said that in a wide-ranging review the only certainty was that the principle of "fun at breakfast" would be maintained; there would be no question of launching a news service to rival GMTV or BBC1.

The show may survive in its present form if a suitably charismatic pair of presenters can be found. Dermot O'Leary, host of Channel 4's hugely successful Sunday morning strand, T4, has been standing in for Vaughan during the summer and may be offered a permanent position.

However, critics point out that even when Vaughan fronted the Big Breakfast with Outen, praise from the press was not matched by a boost in ratings. Only its high media profile has stopped the axe from falling earlier. Its audience now languishes at 400,000, almost as low as the terrible ratings that prompted the replacement of its predecessor, the Channel 4 Daily.

The Big Breakfast was the brainchild of Charlie Parsons, who was behind Network 7 and The Word. With his partner, Waheed Alli, and their friend Sebastian Scott, he launched Evans and Roslin to the screens in 1992. Soon the show was gaining more than 1m viewers.

Many of its regular features achieved cult status, and its success in attracting youth audiences came from its canny sense of kitsch. Paula Yates would interview celebrities in a bed, Keith Chegwin hosted off-beat location reports, and Lily Savage made regular appearances. The mix was held together by a strong line-up of presenters, led by Evans.

But since his departure, the show has lacked buzz. There was a disastrous relaunch fronted by Sharron Davies, but the arrival of Vaughan and Outen heralded a revival in critical acclaim, if not in ratings.

Scott said Channel 4 should aim its breakfast show away from the overcrowded youth and children's market: "They should be servicing viewers who don't want to watch GMTV. There's an entire generation of people who have nothing to watch in the morning."

The BBC is pinning its hopes for a breakfast revival on a new show starting October 2, with the foreign correspondent Jeremy Bowen and the newsreader Moira Stuart. GMTV is offering a new set, some new presenters and a harder journalistic edge.

Highlights: sex sparks

 The Big Breakfast was launched in a blaze of publicity in 1992. Paula Yates set the tone when she turned up to meet the press in a dress made of artificial turf and covered in daisies and veg. Gaby Roslin's debut almost never happened: she was the replacement for Emma Forbes, who pulled out shortly before the launch.

 The tempestuous relationship between Yates and Michael Hutchence is due in no small part to the Big Breakfast. In her regular slot, Yates - then married to Bob Geldof, co-owner of the show's producer, Planet 24 - interviewed the rock star in bed, where she displayed a level of intimacy that was steamy even by her flirtatious standards. The rest is showbiz history.

 After the departure of Gaby Roslin, ratings continued to fall, and the show underwent a radical relaunch. However, the sparks of sexual chemistry failed to fly between the children's TV presenter Rick Adams and the former champion swimmer Sharron Davies. The only good thing to come out of the debacle was the employment of Denise Van Outen as the flying weather girl, whose ability to bellow over the roar of the helicopter resulted in her promotion to Johnny Vaughan's side.

 The Big Breakfast has been the launchpad for a number of successful showbiz careers - but not for others. Kelly Brook, plucked from an obscure career as a lingerie model, ended her brief stint when producers became fed up with her difficulty in reading long words on her script. They had to be spelled phonetically.

 Johnny Vaughan's hyperactive style, which has been the cornerstone of the show's critical success, has occasionally landed him in hot water. He regularly rants against the French, the Germans and the Millennium Dome. A particularly ill-advised tirade against travelling people brought a flood of complaints to Channel 4 - and Gypsy curses.

webTitle: French chaos as fuel tax blockades spread

fields.headline: French chaos as fuel tax blockades spread
fields.trailText: France's fuel tax standoff escalated further yesterday as serious fissures began to appear in the ruling coalition and the European commission threatened legal action to maintain the free movement of goods.
fields.body:
France's fuel tax standoff escalated further yesterday as serious fissures began to appear in the ruling coalition and the European commission threatened legal action to maintain the free movement of goods.

With some 80 % of the country's petrol stations either empty, under tight rationing or reserved for the emergency services, taxi drivers became the latest group to join the campaign for fuel tax cuts, causing traffic chaos in more than a dozen cities with massed "go-slow" protests.

Farmers declared there was no prospect of them withdrawing from the barricades they are helping road hauliers to man outside 125 oil refineries and fuel depots around France.

Dodging riot police, several hundred farmers succeeded in blocking the entrance to the Channel tunnel at Calais late yesterday afternoon, leading to angry confrontations with motorists. The blockade was later temporarily lifted to allow furious British holidaymakers on to the shuttle.

Other farmers drove tractors and trailers on to train tracks outside Strasbourg and Bordeaux, bringing high-speed TGVs in the east and west to a standstill for most of the day.

Nantes, Nice and Rennes airports reported they had all but run out of aviation fuel, school meals went undelivered in the Vosges, emergency-only petrol stations went dry in Brittany, and police were called in to guard requisitioned pumps in Lyons.

For the first time in the four-day blockade, the French capital began to feel the pinch. While surrounding fuel depots were largely kept open by armed riot police, Paris petrol stations began to run out of fuel, particularly diesel, in increasing numbers.

Furious at the fuel tax cuts already offered to the road hauliers, the Green party, a minority member of the Socialist-led coalition, warned the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, that it would react "forcefully" if any more concessions were made to road users.

"I back the cabinet that I am a member of, but I want to remind everyone that I joined it on the understanding that we would work for clean air and for moving away from road to rail transport," said the environment minister, Dominique Voynet.

She had demanded an urgent meeting with Mr Jospin and said the Greens "were not in this government in order to do the exact opposite of what we were elected to do".

Mr Jospin said on Wednesday night there would be no further negotiations with the hauliers and the government's offer was final.

In Brussels, the European commission sent a formal request to Paris "concerning a possible obstacle to the free movement of goods", spokesman Jonathan Todd said. France would be violating EU law if it did not ensure its frontiers and main routes were kept open to goods traffic, he said.

webTitle: How Opec came back to haunt the west

fields.headline: How Opec came back to haunt the west
fields.standfirst: Record demand and tighter supply have sent oil prices soaring but, unlike in the 70s, the producers may back down
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton's message to crown prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia was brief and to the point when they met yesterday. Unless the world's biggest oil producer shook some sense into the militant members of the Opec cartel, there was a risk of plunging the world economy into recession.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton's message to crown prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia was brief and to the point when they met yesterday. Unless the world's biggest oil producer shook some sense into the militant members of the Opec cartel, there was a risk of plunging the world economy into recession.

This week's Millennium Summit in New York has been the ideal time for some diplomatic arm-twisting, and the outgoing US president has taken full opportunity of the presence of 189 world leaders to spell out to the Saudis the consequences of turning up the heat on the big industrialised economies.

With rising energy costs casting a shadow over Al Gore's election hopes, halting the relentless rise in the oil price to its highest level in 10 years has become a key policy objective in Washington. Nor did Mr Clinton need to look very far for a world leader to support him. Jacques Chirac was also at the United Nations summit to give a first-hand account of how France is grinding to a halt as a result of the protests at rising petrol prices.

After years in the doldrums, Opec has now grabbed centre-stage once more. It is 27 years since the 11-nation cartel first came to public notice when its response to Israeli victories in the Yom Kippur war was to increase oil prices fivefold, triggering a period of stagflation - rising prices and lengthening dole queues - in the west.

Over the past 18 months it has again been flexing its muscles, agreeing to curb production as world demand for oil rises. As motorists have found to their cost, the result has been a sharp increase in petrol prices at the pump.

Prince Abdullah probably did not take much persuading at his meeting with Mr Clinton. The Saudis are well aware that a downturn in the west could cause a collapse in the oil price. Even so, they are likely to get some flak from other Opec members at the cartel's meeting in Vienna on Sunday, who say that the oil producers are being unfairly criticised for a problem caused by higher fuel taxes and refinery bottlenecks in the west.

A chart on its website headed "The rip-off race" cheekily compares the prices of a barrel of oil, a barrel of Coca Cola and a barrel of Perrier water. Needless to say, it shows that oil is a bargain, though perhaps less thirst-quenching.

Today, Opec has more muscle than ever before - at least in theory. Its share of worldwide production has increased from 36% to 41% over the last 10 years, and its share of proven reserves has increased from 67% to 78%. This trend, in the view of some analysts, is likely to continue.

But Opec's ability to use this muscle is limited because its members - Algeria, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, and Venezuela - have divergent interests and its decisions have to be based on consensus.

Oil-producing countries range from those which can barely produce enough for their own needs to those which are almost totally dependent on oil for their foreign exchange earnings.

Dependent

The most dependent countries benefit from high prices but also need price stability. Drastic changes, up or down, hamper longer-term development and can mean re-drafting the national budget at short notice. Besides the Opec countries, Russia, Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan, Yemen, Oman and Mexico fall into this category.

Julian Lee, analyst at the London-based Centre for Global Energy Studies, said yesterday that Sunday's discussions will not be about whether a production increase is needed, but by how much.

"It is all but certain that the situation will trigger an increase of 500,000 barrels a day, which will be fairly generally accepted," he said. "But Saudi Arabia will push for a bigger increase - because it sees this as being in its own long-term interests and those of Opec generally."

The Saudis are well-placed to do this because they hold about two-thirds of Opec's spare capacity which is estimated at 3m barrels a day. The Saudis would to some extent be shielded from a fall in oil prices by revenue from their extra production.

But other Opec countries - Algeria, Iran, Libya, Nigeria and Venezuela - would lose money as a result of lower prices because they have little spare capacity.

Venezuela, which currently holds the presidency of Opec, is at the forefront of the reluctant faction. At 3.1m barrels a day it is Latin America's largest producer - but almost totally dependent on oil. Each $1 drop in oil prices costs it about $1bn (£665m) a year.

Its charismatic president, Hugo Chavez, has called an Opec summit in Caracas for later this month, and argues that the real issue is not high prices, but fair prices.

"We understand that they [consumers] start to feel uneasy when crude oil prices reach $30 a barrel, but they can imagine how it must have been for us when it fell to $8," he said recently.

Coming at a critical moment in the Middle East peace process and in the midst of an American presidential election campaign, the argument over oil prices has acquired a political dimension.

The Americans have been shouting more loudly than usual, and the perception that this was motivated, at least in part, by the electoral needs of the Democrats caused some resentment.

Since then, the issue has been further complicated by American efforts to drum up support for its proposals on the Israeli-Palestinian issue. On the thorny question of Jerusalem, the Arab governments generally view the US as oversympathetic towards Israel. This is not a particularly good moment for Arab governments to be seen kow-towing to the Americans.

Any decision to increase production will also have a built-in assumption that existing supplies will continue unabated. But with low stockpiles around the world, consumers have no real cushion against disruption of supplies from less dependable sources such as Iraq, Nigeria, Colombia and Angola.

webTitle: Will that old black magic ruin Brown's best laid plans?

fields.headline: Will that old black magic ruin Brown's best laid plans?
fields.trailText: Events, as Harold Macmillan once remarked, have an irritating habit of messing up the government's best laid plans.
fields.body:
Events, as Harold Macmillan once remarked, have an irritating habit of messing up the government's best laid plans.

At the very moment that Gordon Brown is being hailed as one of Britain's finest chancellors, his successful handling of the economy virtually guaranteeing Labour victory at the next election, the prospect of economic crisis has loomed over the horizon.

Doomsters warned yesterday that the tripling of the price of crude oil means Britain will hit recession, ensuring a return to the dreaded cycle of boom and bust. On the three recent occasions when oil prices rose as dramatically - in 1974, 1979 and 1990 - the British economy hit the rocks within 18 months, the pessimists said.

Motoring organisations warned yesterday that the inevitable surge in the price of petrol - it is expected to rise by 7p to 87p a litre - would have devastating results. Michael Johnson of the AA said: "If the increase takes place, drivers will be bewildered at best and very angry at worst. It always hits the person at the pump."

Both the RAC and the Freight Transport Association called on the government to cut the 75% Treasury levy on fuel - the highest rate in Europe.

The Treasury refused to be drawn on whether it would cut the tax on fuel. However, a spokeswoman pointed out that the chancellor responded to the concerns of motorists in his last budget in March when he scrapped the fuel duty escalator introduced by the Conservatives.

"In the last year we have had the lowest increase in fuel in 11 years," she said.

The abolition of the fuel duty escalator took the wind out of the sails of the Tory leader William Hague. He had hoped to champion the interests of motorists but in the past few days he and his party have been remarkably quiet about the oil crisis.

The Tories' relative silence shows higher fuel prices are unlikely to damage Labour at the next election. Governments of every hue levy exorbitant fuel duties and voters have rarely rebelled over the price of fuel, as the dismal response to the summer's Dump the Pump campaign showed.

The stoicism of British voters means there will be no repeat of the kind of protests that are paralysing France. David Russell, of the Freight Transport Association, said his members would never take to the streets because direct action would alienate voters, destroying his group's leverage over the government.

"We do not behave like the French, although there are some elements who are interested in pursuing that line out of sheer frustration," Mr Russell said.

The failure of British truckers - or most disaffected workers - to take to the streets highlights striking cultural differences between Britain and France, according to the Labour MP and foreign office aide, Denis Macshane.

"France has always been prone to sudden sharp mobilisations because there is not the tradition of debate that we have," he said. "In Britain people also seem to have become inured to rises in petrol prices."

While ministers may calculate that they will escape punishment over petrol price rises, there will be private alarm at the threat to the economy. The Treasury played down the dangers yesterday, declaring: "We do not have alarm bells ringing."

However, the doomsters warned that Britain will now move towards a recession. Andrew Oswald, professor of economics at Warwick University, said: "We have never before ridden out a trebling of oil prices without a slowing down of the world economy. Oil is the world's black magic."

The Treasury played down the dangers yesterday, declaring: "We do not have alarm bells ringing." However, the doomsters warned that Britain will now move towards a recession. Andrew Oswald, professor of economics at Warwick University, said: "We have never before ridden out a trebling of oil prices without a slowing down of the world economy. Oil is the world's black magic."

fields.headline: Irish to the core
fields.standfirst: You know 'im and love 'im, apparently - Irish singing supremo Brian Kennedy's got the Big Apple in the palm of his hand, finds a bemused Michael Ellison
fields.trailText: You know 'im and love 'im, apparently - Irish singing supremo Brian Kennedy's got the Big Apple in the palm of his hand, finds a bemused Michael Ellison.
fields.body:
Kennedy: the name helps, of course, especially in America. Take the case of a well-heeled 39-year-old with rolls of fat on the back of his neck who appears regularly in the media because of a murder he may or may not have committed 25 years ago.

This, in itself, is not exactly a rarity. Were it not a requirement of the commentator's code of conduct to place the phrase "nephew of the late Robert Kennedy" right after the name of Michael Skakel, readers and viewers would not be troubled much with accounts of his activities, and certainly not by the several books written about him.

Brian Kennedy has nothing to do with the clan, unless you count the fact that he is living downtown on the west side of Manhattan, as did the late JFK Jr. And he did sing near the ship John F Kennedy in the post-Independence Day celebrations this year.

Not exactly a blood line, but this simple misfortune of birth does not prevent Brian from being a household name. Honestly. It says so right here in the New York Times: "His three solo albums have made him a household voice in Ireland and England."

With all due respect to Mr Kennedy, this is at the very least a moot point. He might be a household voice in the homes of Van Morrison, for whom he served as a vocal foil for some years, but he is surely less well-known in, say, the backstreets of Derby. Try to buy one of the aforementioned household-invading albums on the internet and you will find that CDNow and Amazon.com list only one between them.

But the New York Times will not be thwarted on this one. The old grey lady, as the paper is known, has it that he is practically mobbed on the streets of Dublin. So it's nice to be in Manhattan, where Kennedy is appearing in Riverdance on Broadway, and the neighbours in his apartment building don't even know who he is. Monica Lewinsky, for instance, passes by completely unaware of his fame. Kennedy, japester that he is, tells this class of person that he is a guitar repair man.

"The anonymity that can be conferred by the big city is breathtaking, given Mr Kennedy's European celebrity." There may be those who continue to subsist without sharp intakes of breath when in his presence, but Irish tourists are not among them. Screams and embraces by entire families are reported.

But there is a dark side to this happy portrait of a European sensation snuggled up in a blanket of obscurity, pulled back a little only by stray emissaries from his own kind: as a child he lived on the Falls Road in Belfast.

Here, the Times notes: "The salary of his father, a Roman Catholic working for the British postal system, was so appallingly low that the Kennedys lived for a time as squatters in a cottage so infested with cockroaches 'that we had to burn them out.'"

Now never mind the implication of servitude; the idea that perhaps the British postal service might have paid the elder Kennedy more had he been a Protestant; that the family would surely have been living high on the hog had he been working for the postal service of any nation other than that imposed on Northern Ireland by "the British" - say, the Irish Republic's; and it does depend on what you understand by "a cottage" a type of accommodation with which the Falls Road has never been blessed; but cockroaches?

He would be more likely to come across such individuals in his well-appointed, personality-infested quarters in The Atrium, in the West Village. Or, indeed, in Arlene Grocery, a club in the Lower East Side where he has been playing on nights off from Broadway.

It cannot be denied that he has held up well against the ravages of irrational adulation, welcome obscurity and those cockroaches. Arlene's is so over-subscribed, the room for the gig so far above its legal occupancy limit, that it is possible to image that this is how "the British" would have liked to corral the Kennedy family, had they been granted the free hand Pinochet extended to his military in Chile.

Kennedy is affable, expansive and self-effacing. Crucially though, he is also performing a number of songs. True, he has an extraordinary voice, shifting, it would seem effortlessly, through his astonishing range as though he were employing the most efficient of gearboxes. And he goes down extremely well with the largely Irish audience.

But, unfortunately, he is one of those singers who makes the lyrics audible and some of these are excruciatingly trite. One is called Christopher Street, after the site of the Stonewall riots nearly 30 years ago and still a centre of gay activity.

Here, the singer notes, it can be very busy. Later on it seems rather quiet. He guesses that even New York has to sleep sometimes.

The great fear is that Kennedy might believe this to be an original notion.

Six songs were enough. By this point, at least, he had made no attempt to essay the Ebb and Kander classic Theme from New York, New York. "If you can make it here, You can make it any where, It's up to you, New York, New York."

webTitle: Morris urges TUC caution on euro entry

fields.headline: Morris urges TUC caution on euro entry
fields.standfirst:
Attack on union leaders 'running down the pound'

Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's closest trade union ally has accused his fellow TUC leaders of playing a "very dangerous game" by backing Britain's early entry into the euro, and thereby risking losing a promised referendum that could be won by the government by holding it when the time was right.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's closest trade union ally has accused his fellow TUC leaders of playing a "very dangerous game" by backing Britain's early entry into the euro, and thereby risking losing a promised referendum that could be won by the government by holding it when the time was right.

In a move reflecting the chancellor's determination to control policy on the single currency, Bill Morris, leader of the transport union, said the euro enthusiasts, who include TUC general secretary John Monks, were "running down the pound" and "preaching doom and gloom".

In an interview with the New Statesman magazine ahead of the TUC conference in Glasgow, Mr Morris insisted it should be the government that ought to "lead the debate on the euro", and he ridiculed claims that millions of British jobs could be lost by staying out of the single currency.

The chancellor has appointed Mr Morris to the court of the Bank of England, and, as if to emphasise the closeness of his view to those of the chancellor's, Mr Morris also published a Mori opinion poll showing a 10% net increase in the proportion of those prepared to back entry by Britain if the five convergence tests stipulated by Mr Brown were met.

Mr Morris's curtain raiser for the TUC euro debate next week - the chancellor will address the congress on Tuesday - was made as it emerged that Tony Blair has agreed to a formal structure of regular Downing Street meetings with the TUC for the first time since Labour returned to office.

In a sign of warming relations after what Mr Monks described as a "productive but patchy" first three years, there will be an official quarterly meeting between the two sides, backed with exchanges of position papers and a joint secretariat.

The arrangements, which supersede present ad hoc contacts, will also bring in other ministers when necessary, and follow moves for a more systematic relationship between the TUC and the trade and industry department under Stephen Byers.

But Mr Blair is still resistant to pressure from the unions to establish any broader tripartite "social partnership", bringing together government, unions and employers, as is common throughout the rest of the EU.

Although there are what Mr Monks calls "oases of tripartism" in Britain (such as the low pay commission and the health and safety executive) the government is reluctant to raise the spectre of 1970s-style corporatism as practiced by previous governments, though the TUC argues that use of such bodies can avoid the damage caused by "parallel lobbying" by unions and employers.

Mr Monks yesterday pointed to a "surge" of recognition agreements with employers as evidence that "unions now find themselves in the most favourable political and economic context for more than 30 years", although membership growth has been hit by job losses in manufacturing.

He also said that the TUC would press the Labour party to adopt three policies in particular for the next parliament.

It wants a legal obligation on employers to provide training for workers, the provision of company information and consultation rights for British workers, and complete protection of the terms and conditions of public sector employees whose work is transferred to the private sector.

fields.headline: Embarrassed by the truth
fields.standfirst:
Martin Kettle reports from Washington on the real reason that George W Bush insulted a New York Times journalist

Audio: Hear George W Bush's remark
fields.trailText: Martin Kettle reports from Washington on the real reason that George W Bush insulted a New York Times journalist.
fields.body:
When Adam Clymer's biography of Senator Edward Kennedy was published in the United States last year, it won respectful rather than dazzling reviews.

The last of the Kennedy brothers is a substantial subject in every way, and Clymer had obliged with a substantial volume, stretching to more than 650 pages.

Reviewers praised the book as "thoughtful and thorough," "painstaking" and "at times pedestrian," which are not necessarily the sort of words that send publishers into raptures.

This week, Clymer's name was in the news again. In a Labour Day gathering in a Chicago suburb, George W Bush turned to his running mate Dick Cheney and, thinking that the microphone was switched off, said to him: "There's Adam Clymer from the New York Times - a major league asshole."

Cheney replied: "Oh, yeah, he is, big time."

Bush's Labour Day blooper has been the talking point of the week and has been variously interpreted - to say nothing of variously reported (the Times buried the story in a news round-up and failed to quote Bush's words).

One school of thought says that the overheard remarks show the real Bush, supposedly a much nastier fellow than the chirpy grin merchant with whom we are now so familiar.

Another says, maybe so, but the remarks will do Bush nothing but good, since they provide proof that there is lead in his pencil.

What the reporting has missed, though, is why Bush should have been moved to make his comments.

As the reviews of his book about Ted Kennedy suggest, Clymer is not some fly-by-night chancer, trying to make a name for himself by baiting a top politician.

On the contrary, Clymer is a veteran. He's been around nearly as long as Ted Kennedy himself.

He appears to be an American journalist of the old school. He is a natural practitioner of the art of thoroughness - in the articles he writes in the Times just as much as in his book writing.

Clymer hasn't spent much time this year on the campaign trail with Bush or anyone else. He has never been the Times's regular man on the campaign bus.

Most of what he has written has been researched and from a distance; recently he has written a lot about the candidates' political advertising, and about the campaign finance issue.

What he has also done, however, is to have penned one of the most damning articles about Bush to have appeared during the year. It was published in April, and it dealt with Bush's record on health policy in Texas. It began with this powerful indictment:

"Texas has had one of the nation's worst public health records for decades. More than a quarter of its residents has no health insurance. Its Mexican border is a hotbed of contagion.

"The state ranks near the top in the nation in rates of Aids, diabetes, tuberculosis and teenage pregnancy, and near the bottom in immunisations, mammograms and access to physicians."

The article went on to point out that Texas's health record is a deeper problem than be laid at the door of any one politician, but it also explained that Bush has not tried to tackle it.

Health has never been one of Bush's priority issues as governor. Though Bush makes much of his positive approach to Texas's Latino population, the health situation is worst in the state's most heavily Latino counties along the Mexican border - with disease rates "at third world levels," Clymer wrote.

It was hardly surprising that Clymer's article angered the Bush campaign, because it had a story to tell and because it highlighted an area of public policy of which Bush has a weak grasp.

While Bush is confident when he deals with subjects like education and defence, he is noticeably less chipper on health issues.

For much of the past 10 days, the Republican camp has been on the defensive about health policy, ever since Bush launched a campaign ad that claimed he would support extending a prescription drug benefit to retired Americans who are covered by the federal government's Medicare programme.

How will it work and how much will it cost, Al Gore responded? Bush had to confess that he didn't know and that he was working on the details.

In Pennsylvania on Tuesday, Bush finally filled in the gaps, announcing a $158bn programme (Gore would spend $253bn).

But it had been a damaging week, knocking Bush off his own agenda. No wonder that the Democrats have despatched Joe Lieberman into enemy territory this morning to make a speech in Houston on Bush's health care record.

Seen in this context, Bush's outburst against Clymer can be viewed as more than just another politician randomly abusing another journalist.

It becomes a more specific and more significant story, of a journalist who has angered a politician by exposing his weakness on an issue that could make or break his presidential bid.

In those circumstances, Bush's language was surprisingly restrained.

webTitle: Making sure the young can marry

fields.headline: Making sure the young can marry
fields.standfirst:
Middle East editor Brian Whitaker looks at the growth of charities that help Arab couples meet and marry


Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Middle East editor Brian Whitaker looks at the growth of charities that help Arab couples meet and marry.
fields.body:
Arab weddings are splendid occasions, often spread over several days. They are also horrendously expensive.

In a culture where appearances are important and generosity is a much-prized virtue, lavish feasts, extravagant parties and high-priced wedding dresses have become the norm.

Some families even take out the equivalent of a mortgage to pay for it.

The groom is also expected to provide a dowry for his bride, which in some countries can be almost prohibitive, though in others it may just be a token amount.

The cost of a typical wedding ranges from $10,000 or so in Jordan to $50,000 or more in the Gulf - four or five years' wages for someone on an average salary.

For many young Arabs the solution is to delay their marriage: men seek work abroad to earn more money, though it can still take 10 years or so to save enough for the big day.

The result is that Arabs are marrying later and later. In Jordan, 60 per cent of men aged 25-30 are unmarried. Women who reach the age of 30 without marrying risk being regarded as unusa - permanently unmarriable spinsters.

This conflicts with the precepts of Islam, which regards marriage as a religious duty and encourages people to marry early to minimise the temptations of pre-marital sex.

Arab society expects brides to be virgins and loss of virginity is a serious matter which, in some of the more traditional communities, can result in a young woman being killed by her father or brothers to protect their family's "honour."

These difficulties have led to a new phenomenon in the Middle East: the growth of Islamic charities which organise and pay for collective weddings, and even provide a suitable marriage partner if necessary.

Last Monday, Syria had its first experience of a collective wedding when 10 couples married at Qatana, near Damascus.

A second wedding - scheduled for Valentine's Day next year - will knot together 50 couples. Other collective weddings have been held in Jordan, Egypt and Yemen.

Besides providing a party for 350 guests, the charity gave each couple almost £800 in cash and presents donated by individuals and businesses in the area.

For the donors, these gifts count as zakat - the 2.5 per cent of disposable income that Muslims are required to donate to charity each year.

The work of a Jordanian marriage-promotion charity called al-Afaf (Arabic for "chastity") is described in the latest issue of Third World Quarterly.

By last year it had organised six collective weddings, some of them very large. At one, Pepsi donated 2,000 cans of drinks and a local bakery provided 3,000 slices of cake.

The parties are organised according to "authentic Islamic customs and morals" - which means that men and women are kept apart, and Koranic verses are recited continuously.

One wedding last year had six different bands, though the music was suitably religious.

Part of al-Afaf's aim is to demonstrate to other couples that weddings need not be ostentatious, socially-competitive and financially ruinous events.

The charity also acts as guarantor on interest-free bank loans, mainly for hard-up young men who would otherwise be unable to marry. To qualify, a borrower must prove that he intends to marry and that the money will be used for wedding expenses.

Over four years, the scheme has provided 791 loans totalling more than $571,000 and very few borrowers have defaulted on the repayments.

In one case, a young man from a wealthy family was given a loan when his family threatened to cut him off because they disapproved of the woman he was planning to marry.

The charity felt that, without financial help, he might end up unhappily married or not married at all.

Al-Afaf also runs a free matchmaking service. Applicants of both sexes fill in a detailed questionnaire that is examined by a committee consisting entirely of women.

This satisfies a social and religious requirement that no man will see a woman's application. The committee then informs male applicants of any suitable woman.

At that stage, the Arab tradition for arranged marriages takes over. The man sends a female relative to the woman's house to announce his interest.

If the proposal is accepted, the male heads of the each household meet to discuss terms, such as the amount of the dowry. Representatives of the charity can be called in to help if negotiations run into trouble.

Although al-Afaf's motives are basically religious, it recognises that young people are more likely to be driven to use its services by financial hardship or the difficulty of finding a marriage partner in a society where the sexes are kept apart as much as possible.

The loans and marriage-broking facilities have proved more popular than the collective weddings which some couples suspect will be used to draw them into Islamic religious organisations.

But al-Afaf does not seem to mind and points out that its services are available to Christians too. It argues that promoting marriage benefits society generally and discourages "western" alternative lifestyles.
