To qualify, a borrower must prove that he intends to marry and that the money will be used for wedding expenses. Over four years, the scheme has provided 791 loans totalling more than $571,000 and very few borrowers have defaulted on the repayments. In one case, a young man from a wealthy family was given a loan when his family threatened to cut him off because they disapproved of the woman he was planning to marry. The charity felt that, without financial help, he might end up unhappily married or not married at all. Al-Afaf also runs a free matchmaking service. Applicants of both sexes fill in a detailed questionnaire that is examined by a committee consisting entirely of women. This satisfies a social and religious requirement that no man will see a woman's application. The committee then informs male applicants of any suitable woman. At that stage, the Arab tradition for arranged marriages takes over. The man sends a female relative to the woman's house to announce his interest. If the proposal is accepted, the male heads of the each household meet to discuss terms, such as the amount of the dowry. Representatives of the charity can be called in to help if negotiations run into trouble. Although al-Afaf's motives are basically religious, it recognises that young people are more likely to be driven to use its services by financial hardship or the difficulty of finding a marriage partner in a society where the sexes are kept apart as much as possible. The loans and marriage-broking facilities have proved more popular than the collective weddings which some couples suspect will be used to draw them into Islamic religious organisations. But al-Afaf does not seem to mind and points out that its services are available to Christians too. It argues that promoting marriage benefits society generally and discourages "western" alternative lifestyles. brian.whitaker@theguardian.com

webTitle: Martin Woollacott: The dome is probably the last-ever grand exhibition

fields.headline: The dome is probably the last-ever grand exhibition
fields.standfirst:
Patriotic celebrations of industrial might no longer wash
Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: It would be poetic, if not particularly just, if the failure of the Millennium Dome were to mark the end of the era of grand exhibitions which Britain inaugurated so brilliantly in 1851. The Great Exhibition, and its slightly later French rival, the Exposition Universelle of 1855, established a model copied, embellished and extended around the world.
fields.body:
It would be poetic, if not particularly just, if the failure of the Millennium Dome were to mark the end of the era of grand exhibitions which Britain inaugurated so brilliantly in 1851. The Great Exhibition, and its slightly later French rival, the Exposition Universelle of 1855, established a model copied, embellished and extended around the world.

That model combined studied national boastfulness, commercial ambition and political propaganda with pretensions to world peace, an almost religious commitment to science and technology and a mission to inform and entertain the masses.

The great wave of exhibitions that followed after 1851 was part of a dramatic process of cultural globalisation in the 19th century. But the different kind of cultural globalisation to which we are now subject has undermined the grand exhibition, even in its much reduced form of recent years, as the dome's fate has shown.

The dome's difficulties will be studied with care by any government contemplating a similar exercise, as will those of Germany's Expo 2000 in Hanover, which has already lost the German taxpayer £750m. Hanover suggests that the dome's problems may be as much to do with conditions that affect such enterprises everywhere as they are with Britain and its present government.

The early exhibitions were extraordinary packages of high and low culture, of romanticised nationalism, internationalism and imperialism interwined, as Paul Greenhalgh, head of research at the Victoria and Albert Museum, has shown in his enlightening book. You could listen to the best and worst of music, peer at native villages complete with actual natives, study the latest industrial products or simply contemplate a life-size replica of an elephant made entirely of walnuts.

When exhibitions came off well, they could give such a fillip to a nation's prospects that countries fell over themselves to stage them - in the thirties a convention was devised to ration out the number allowed each country.

When they went badly, they could deliver a blow to the finances and the political fortunes of a regime. The 1873 Vienna Exhibition almost bankrupted the city. The French Exhibition of 1878, which was intended to prove that France had fully recovered from military defeat and internal trouble, failed in both its financial and its political objectives. Having a bad pavilion at a successful exhibition in another country, as the United States did in Britain in 1851, was another kind of disaster. "We were the laughing stock of the nations," one American wrote mournfully.

Most exhibitions were either modestly successful in financial terms, or lost relatively small sums. Such costs were acceptable because the gains in trade, prestige and social cohesiveness - the exhibitions were from the beginning conceived as exercises in national harmony - were seen to be high.

The almost continual run of exhibitions in the years up to 1939 also created a kind of international consensus on the value of industry and science, the importance of art, especially decorative art, and the relations between the advanced world and its colonies.

Clearly those who organised the dome made particular mistakes, but it may be that the fundamental error was not to understand that the times have changed. Those who attended the exhibitions of the past saw scenes that stayed in their memories for a lifetime, so different were they from what ordinarily came their way as spectacle and entertainment. They also absorbed a drama justifying the national projects of those days and drawing together the various strands of political, intellectual and artistic life into a grand scheme of things.

Those who attend them today inevitably do so in a spirit of sometimes carping comparison with what is available on television or film, in the modern museum and gallery, on package holiday or at the theme park. Nor are they particularly open any longer, for good or ill, to an old-fashioned political message.

The great exhibitions anticipated the role of modern media, which sprang out of the technical advances which the exhibitions celebrated. This progeny, which does what the exhibitions used to do - but does it in more specialised and permanent ways - has made it more and more difficult to repeat the tours de force of the past. Here is Alistair Cooke, writing ecstatically in 1963 of the US science pavilion, designed by Minoru Yamasaki, at the Seattle World's Fair:

"Twenty panels showing the rising and the setting of the sun, a tornado, the northern lights, a comet, the visual splendour of the New England fall; an electrical storm... then... we grope our way into genetics by walking through a corridor of panels that stylise the rainforest."

A not-too-different account of some of the exhibits at Greenwich can be imagined. But in the nearly 40 years between the two have come both the special-effects revolution that allows us to hurtle through inter-galactic space in the comfort of the cinema and the rise of the television nature documentary that has made us as intimate with the habits of trout or badgers as poachers.

Turn-of-the-century exhibitions imported whole villages from Africa and south-east Asia, the "inhabitants" cooking, washing and weaving while the visitors watched - a faint precursor, perhaps, of the human zoo programmes now popular on television. But the exotic is now available, insofar as it still exists, not only on the screen but on the beach in Thailand itself.

The theme-park industry, which can be said to have sprung directly out of the exhibition tradition, has meanwhile outdone the exhibition as entertainment. Europeans are visiting theme parks in record numbers - up two-thirds in the past decade to 101m admissions last year - and may soon be as assiduous attenders as Americans. Next year's attractions at Port Aventura in Spain will include a temple of fire, in which visitors walk through flames. Hard to match such sensations at an exhibition that must spread its resources to cover a range of objectives.

But the greatest change of all, it can be argued, is that people have lost interest in the plot line that held exhibitions together in the past. In their international aspect they were above all about western success and primacy, about the great good of modernisation, about the never-ending nature of progress. In their purely patriotic dimension, they celebrated national successes in industry, science and the arts to which few countries can now point so confidently. Much of what Britain, for example, had to celebrate in industry and science in 1951 no longer exists.

Exhibitions of one kind and another will continue. But what Greenhalgh calls "the strange combination of carnival and ceremony, of circus and museum, of popularism and elitism" that was the grand exhibition, of which the dome is a very late example, has had its day.

 Ephemeral Vistas by Paul Greenhalgh is published by Manchester University Press

webTitle: Palace trip is better, says prince

fields.headline: Palace trip is better, says prince
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The Prince of Wales added his voice to the growing chorus of dome critics yesterday when he took a swipe at the beleaguered structure by insisting a visit to Buckingham Palace was a better day out.
fields.body:
The Prince of Wales added his voice to the growing chorus of dome critics yesterday when he took a swipe at the beleaguered structure by insisting a visit to Buckingham Palace was a better day out.

Members of the public looked on in amazement as the prince, who had joined them during an official visit to Buckingham Palace, said: "It's better than going to the dome."

Some of the 5,600 people who take the tour each day during the summer opening did double takes as they saw the prince, accompanied by his private protection officers, wandering through the state rooms.

The prince, who was on an official visit to the palace as chairman of the Trustees of the Royal Collection Trust, appeared to be significantly more impressed by his own family's visitor attraction than the one in Greenwich despite having never visited the dome.

He raised his eyebrows after being informed by staff at the palace that a tour there was a much cheaper option - £22.50 for a family ticket compared with £57.

Well known for his outspoken views attacking modern architecture, the prince has been reported as saying he does not approve of the Greenwich attraction.

He was in Edinburgh on the millennium eve when the Queen, the Duke of Edinburgh, and Tony and Cherie Blair attended the official opening.

A St James's Palace spokeswoman said the prince had never made any public statement on the dome.

webTitle: MPs join demands for Falconer's head

fields.headline: MPs join demands for Falconer's head
fields.standfirst:
Finance director faces sack in latest turmoil over the dome
Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The dome's financial director is expected to be sacked today. Labour MPs meanwhile joined the chorus calling for the head of Lord Falconer, the minister with ultimate responsibility for the fiasco.
fields.body:
The dome's financial director is expected to be sacked today. Labour MPs meanwhile joined the chorus calling for the head of Lord Falconer, the minister with ultimate responsibility for the fiasco.

Neil Spence, the accountant who has presided over the "black hole" in the dome's books, was waiting to hear of his fate from David James, the City troubleshooter brought in to keep the attraction open.

Lord Falconer, a commercial lawyer and close friend of the prime minister, was called an "endearing amateur" by Martin O'Neill, the influential chairman of the trade and industry select committee. There is also a growing belief among Labour MPs that even if he rides the present storm, he could be sunk by a national audit office report into the dome next month.

A spokesman for Mr James, who was highly critical of the lack of proper records of the dome's assets and contracts, said he "could not guarantee" that Mr Spence would survive his shake-up.

Mr Spence has already been in effect replaced by John Darlington, chief executive of the Robinson Group, whom Mr James drafted in to oversee the proposed sale to Nomura. The last part of Mr Spence's job, dealing with cash flow, has been handed over to an accountant from PricewaterhouseCoopers.

Mr O'Neill's carefully couched criticism of Lord Falconer comes as a major blow to his chances of clinging on. Even though Mr O'Neill stopped short of demanding his dismissal, he said a government minister from the Commons should now be put in charge of the dome to improve accountability.

"The lack of proper scrutiny and control over the spending suggests a naivety on behalf of the political masters of the project," said Mr O'Neill.

"They were not asking the right questions and addressing the issues as we expect. There is about members of the House of Lords in charge of important projects a sense of the endearing amateur, a sort of Lord Peter Wimsey."

Jeremy Corbyn, Labour MP for Islington North, went further. "I think the Prime Minister is protecting him because he's very close to him, because he's a friend of his, and I would think at the very least Lord Falconer should consider his position, and perhaps resign."

Even if Lord Falconer gets over these hurdles, he will have to weather the Commons public accounts committee, which will question officials from the dome, millennium commission and culture department on November 24.

Downing Street, however, rallied behind the beleaguered minister and said Mr Blair believed he was doing "a good job in difficult circumstances". A spokesman added that Mr Blair - whose family have yet to visit the dome - had no plans to visit the complex.

The Liberal Democrats, who have held back from calling for his resignation until now, piled on the pressure.

Spokesman Norman Baker said: "I am afraid that Lord Falconer must answer the calls for his resignation and go. He has overseen this project for two years and should have done far more to prevent what has now become a national embarrassment.

"The Tories must also take some of the blame. The idea of the dome was theirs. They created its shaky financial arrangements and insisted on the shroud of secrecy which has surrounded the dome ever since."

With the news that the dome's closing extravaganza was finally cancelled yesterday, even its most vocal supporter, the former Tory deputy prime minister Michael Heseltine, admitted serious errors had been made.

Mr Heseltine, who sits on the millennium commission which gave the dome an extra £47m on Monday, said it should have had the power to hire "a great entrepreneur with creative flair from the very beginning".

He accused his party leader William Hague of scoring "easy political points" for calling for the dome to shut now.

Mr Hague hit back: "It has become worse than a national embarrassment and it ought now to be closed."

The thorny issue of bonuses to the dome's directors took another twist last night, when a New Millennium Experience Company source revealed that he "did not expect anyone to get their full money".

Directors are entitled to bonuses of up to 30% of their total earnings at the dome and Jennie Page, who was sacked as chief executive in January, is thought to have walked away with her £150,000 bonus intact.

The bonuses will be decided at the end of the year by the board.

Yesterday it also emerged that the dome's sponsors, who played a key role in the sacking of Ms Page, would have sued to get their money back if it had closed early. "We all want the dome to stay open to the end of the year as it was supposed to," said a spokesman for Boots, which sponsors the Body zone.

fields.headline: Rail users condemn service failures
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Britain's railways were yesterday savagely criticised by passengers, who accused them of performing worse than before privatisation and called for lower fares.
fields.body:
Britain's railways were yesterday savagely criticised by passengers, who accused them of performing worse than before privatisation and called for lower fares.

The criticism from the rail passengers' council, a statutory body representing the views of passengers, comes as the industry is still reeling from the Paddington rail crash and waiting anxiously for the verdict of the official inquiry.

Launching the report, Stewart Francis, the council's chairman, said: "It is depressing to see performance remaining almost static overall.

"Four years after the start of privatisation, and after all the time, effort, money and promises, we still have a system performing no better than when the whole process started - indeed in many cases it is performing worse."

He said that it was becoming ever clearer that, on top of private money, substantial amounts of public money had to be spent to bring about real improvements. "Quality public transport cannot be bought cheaply."

In a veiled attack on the shadow strategic rail authority, which controls the performance of the train companies, Mr Francis called for a regulatory system which encouraged rail companies to deliver what passengers wanted. He said current rules did not work well enough.

He said one of the council's main concerns was the level and complexity of fares. "While welcoming the bargain deals which have slashed the cost of travel for many passengers, we are horrified at the erosion of traditional 'turn up and go' fares and the imposition of restrictions, effectively raising many other passengers' fares."

More than a third of passengers thought rail gave poor value for money, and in too many instances performance bore little relation to the fare charged.

Mr Francis said the regulatory process designed to prevent swingeing price increases had been undermined. "We must continue to argue that fare levels must, when capacity allows, start to come down."

The council expressed disappointment at the replacement of the £2 family railcard child flat fare with a percentage-reduced fare. On some long distance Anglo-Scottish routes, some child fares have risen by more than 500%.

For too many passengers, rail was still an exercise in frustration, delays and old rolling stock. Overcrowding was still blighting too much of the network. One surprise was the fall in the number of complaints, down from last year's 18,771 to 15,120.

Mr Francis said the franchise replacement process now underway held out the best hope for years that the mistakes of the past could be put behind the industry.

The Association of Train Operating Companies accepted much still needed to be done and that the report was a fair reflection of the issues in the industry. It was dealing with an extra million passenger journeys a week on a congested network.

Off the rails

 35% of passengers felt they were not getting value for money

 Delays and cancellations rose 3% to 737,000

 Four out of 11 commuter companies ran overcrowded trains

 Fines for trains run with too few carriages rose 32%to £3.5m

 14m minutes were lost through delays

 Railtrack was responsible for 43% of last year's delays, track faults 17%, and train breakdowns 23%

fields.headline: Health plan 'needs 10,000 more GPs'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Doctors yesterday warned the health secretary, Alan Milburn, that he would be unable to deliver the government's plan for NHS reform without a bigger increase in the number of GPs.
fields.body:
Doctors yesterday warned the health secretary, Alan Milburn, that he would be unable to deliver the government's plan for NHS reform without a bigger increase in the number of GPs.

Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said there would have to be an additional 8,000-10,000 family doctors, instead of the 2,000 promised by ministers.

After the BMA council's first full discussion of the plan, he said that the council agreed with 97% of the government's objectives, but questioned the adequacy of the resources available to implement them. "GPs want to spend more time with patients. In my own case, it is a bonus if I can give them more than five minutes."

It was hard to see how the promise of access to a GP within 48 hours could be achieved, he said. The government promised 2,000 extra GPs by 2004 but, of those, 1,100 were in the pipeline before expectations were raised. webTitle: Tories suffer massive attack on choice of music

fields.headline: Tories suffer massive attack on choice of music
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: When William Hague approached the podium in Birmingham on Tuesday to launch his party's latest policy document, Believing in Britain, he did so to an unfamiliar tune. Gone was the traditional Conservative party fanfare Land and Hope of Glory and in its place the strains of Man Next   Door by Massive Attack boomed from the speakers.
fields.body:
When William Hague approached the podium in Birmingham on Tuesday to launch his party's latest policy document, Believing in Britain, he did so to an unfamiliar tune. Gone was the traditional Conservative party fanfare Land and Hope of Glory and in its place the strains of Man Next Door by Massive Attack boomed from the speakers.

To the party's image consultants it must have seemed the perfect combination for the modern Conservatives: the sound of urban Britain combined with a homely theme. There was just one problem - the band abhors everything the party stands for and yesterday announced that they would be consulting their lawyers.

"Massive Attack have not and will never support the Conservative party or their policies," the Bristol-based dance band said.

"If our music has been used by the Tories it is without our knowledge or our permission. The misappropriation of our music by any organisation or broadcaster will be dealt with in the strongest way we can."

A spokesman for the band's management company said: "The Tories couldn't have picked a worse band politically. Massive's political leanings are far more to the left than Hague, although I'm not sure they would give permission to any political party to use their music.

Last night Conservative central office was keen to play down the incident. "It's a massive attack over nothing," said a spokesman. "The music was for background and was not intended for broadcast."

The spokesman was unable to comment on whether Mr Hague is a fan of the band but said it was popular among staff at Smith Square.

fields.headline: Tiscali buys out World Online
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: World Online's brief and turbulent ride on the stock market was bought to an end last night after the Dutch internet service provider was taken over by Italian rival tiscali.com in a £3.4bn deal. The enlarged group will be Europe's second biggest ISP after Germany's T-Online.com with a market value of around €12.5bn(£7.6bn) and 3.5m active subscribers.
fields.body:
World Online's brief and turbulent ride on the stock market was bought to an end last night after the Dutch internet service provider was taken over by Italian rival tiscali.com in a £3.4bn deal. The enlarged group will be Europe's second biggest ISP after Germany's T-Online.com with a market value of around €12.5bn(£7.6bn) and 3.5m active subscribers.

Tiscali offered a premium of 26.5% to the worldonline.com share price to clinch the €20 per share all-share deal and draw to a close one of the most remarkable and brief histories of a major European internet company.

World Online has been dogged by controversy ever since it emerged that founder and chairwoman Nina Brink had sold a large part of her shareholding prior to the company's flotation. The sale was made at a fraction of the float price of €43, caused panic among other investors when it was made public and shattered World Online's share price.

Angry investors then threatened to sue the firm and the blue-chip investment banks who had advised on the float. Yesterday's sale price was less than half the flotation price. Tiscali will now have around 6.1m customers or 15% of the continent's 40m internet subscribers. Analysts said the Italian firm's cash pile would be significantly boosted by the £1bn World Online raised when it came to market.

"Tiscali needs cash and World Online has cash," Lehman Brothers analyst Rufus Grantham said. "Tiscali can't go into the market in its current state."

However, others warned that the deal was essentially a merger of two of the weaker European ISPs and that others like T-Online and Wanadoo of France were more likely to emerge as the sector's driving forces. "This draws together two companies with no obvious operational synergies," said Miles Saltiel at West LB Panmure. "The only synergy is the use of World Online's cash to defray losses but it does nothing to diminish the rate of those losses. The character of this deal confirms what investors fear: these are two weak companies that require support and this merger does nothing to provide the fundamentals that they require."

Tiscali chief executive officer Renato Soru offered a more bullish analysis, claiming that the group would now be in a position to drive the widely anticipated consolidation among ISPs and make cost savings of €550m. "The bigger you are the better," he said. "You either have to lead or be consolidated."

James Kinsella, the former Microsoft executive brought in to replace Ms Brink as World Online chairman, will become chief executive, while Mr Soru is chairman designate. A former supermarket boss who set up Tiscali in Sardinia three years ago, Mr Soru will also be the largest shareholder with around 35% of the equity.

Dealers believe that the huge volume of new shares that will be issued to fund the deal could depress the value of both companies in the short term. Online auctioneers QXL.com and Ricardo.de, plus Terra Networks and Lycos, found this was the case when announcing their mergers.

Freeserve, the leading UK ISP, is likely to remain a key target for consolidation. Analysts believe T-Online, which has had one offer turned down, is its most likely suitor. Tiscali shares closed up at €45.95, almost a third above the year low of €34.10 in January.

webTitle: UN tries to curb peace disasters

fields.headline: UN tries to curb peace disasters
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone hostage-taking spurs rapid reform of conflict strategy
Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The United Nations security council last night agreed to overhaul its much-maligned peacekeeping operations, with special focus on conflicts in Africa.
fields.body:
The United Nations security council last night agreed to overhaul its much-maligned peacekeeping operations, with special focus on conflicts in Africa.

The council rushed through a six-step programme after suffering the embarrassment of seeing 500 of its peacekeeping force taken hostage by ramshackle rebel forces in Sierra Leone this year.

The speed of the UN response is a sign of the extent to which the organisation's image has been battered by a decade of disastrous operations.

At a 90-minute meeting, the 15-member security council backed the plan. Attending were representatives of the five permanent members: the US president, Bill Clinton, the British prime minister, Tony Blair, the Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, and the French president, Jacques Chirac.

In a lengthy declaration published at the end of the meeting, the council pledged "to enhance the effectiveness of the United Nations in addressing conflict at all stages, from prevention to settlement to post-conflict peace-building".

In an early test of its new resolve, it also issued a separate statement condemning the African countries involved in the fighting in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

The UN has begun organising a peacekeeping force for Congo but last night the security council reiterated that the troops will not be committed until the countries involved in the conflict abide by the ceasefire agreed in Lusaka last year.

The reform of the peacekeeping operations was recommended in a report by a UN panel of experts a fortnight ago after investigations into why the UN had performed so badly in Rwanda and the Balkans. The security council has since acted with unprecedented haste.

The declaration will be the one concrete success to emerge from the biggest-ever gathering of world leaders in New York. For the first time, Africa was singled out. The declaration said the security council will give equal priority to maintaining peace throughout the world but "in view of the particular needs of Africa, to give special attention to the promotion of durable peace and sustainable development in Africa, and to the specific characteristics of African conflicts".

As a first step in reform, the security council will adopt "clearly defined, credible, achievable and appropriate mandates". In the past, mandates have been so vague they have often added to problems. The weakness of the UN mandate in the Balkans was repeatedly exploited by the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.

With one eye on the hostage-taking in Sierra Leone, the security council said the new mandates will include "effective measures for the security and safety to United Nations personnel and, wherever possible, for the protection of the civilian population".

Other steps include helping the UN to obtain trained and properly equipped personnel for peacekeeping operations. Many of the UN troops sent to Sierra Leone from developing countries were short of basic equipment, in particular proper communications. The security council promised greater consultation with contributing countries.

One of the biggest and most expensive changes will be the creation of a permanent UN high command responsible for the planning, deployment and conduct of peacekeeping operations in an effort to reduce the chaos that often surrounds its interventions.

The final step agreed was for "a more up-to-date and sounder foundation for financing peacekeeping operations".

The British delegation also managed to squeeze in a reference condemning trade in diamonds from conflict zones.

fields.headline: The rat race
fields.standfirst:
What's happening in Big Brother
Special report: Big Brother
fields.trailText: What's happening in Big Brother
fields.body:
If the rumour-mongers and Nasty Nick's Sun diary are to be believed, Mel, the one-time long-standing hot tip to make it all the way to the end of the show, will be out on her ear tonight. Spurious statistics about the percentage of calls against her are zipping about the ether in text-message and email form, and a frantic whispering campaign is being waged around the nation's water-coolers, photocopiers, greasy toast shops or wherever it is that such conversations take place.

The rise and fall of Melanie is a curious business. Personally, I feel that she's less grating now than she was in that early, man-whispering state that earned her house-queen and likely-winner status. Having given up on the thong-flashing antics and the boy-backing voting system, she's reinvented herself as a more palatable human, give or take the occasional dubious assertion that she's doing all this for her mum.

But maybe we're about to witness payback for all the scheming she indulged in during those early days. Big Brother karma in motion. Maybe we're just overcome at the novelty value of being in the position to vote against her. Or maybe there's some darker political agenda here. Could she be about to suffer the wrath of multitudes of men who consider themselves to have been teased to distraction by manipulative hussies like her in the past?

Of course, maybe it's all nonsense and Mel will survive the evening's expulsion, which brings us on to the manner in which the anti-Mel line and other Big Brother-related gossip is disseminated. Crucial to the programme's success, e-gossip is a powerful force - fast-moving (one click on the Forward icon, and you're away) and endowed with a credibility that spoken gossip never quite achieves. Never before have we witnessed its might at such close hand. Malicious speculation will never be the same again.

webTitle: Police free immigrants held by Chinese gang

fields.headline: Police free immigrants held by Chinese gang
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Armed police used stun grenades to free eight illegal immigrants believed to have been held hostage by a Chinese "Snakehead" gang in the largest anti-kidnap operation ever mounted in the UK.
fields.body:
Armed police used stun grenades to free eight illegal immigrants believed to have been held hostage by a Chinese "Snakehead" gang in the largest anti-kidnap operation ever mounted in the UK.

Seven women and one man were freed during the raid on a house in Poplar, east London, on Wednesday afternoon. Two women were discovered crammed into a tiny cupboard space measuring 2ft by 1ft behind a false wall in the two-bedroom maisonette.

The women, who, along with the rest of the victims had been held captive for at least 10 days, were distressed and received medical attention.

The other hostages were said to be shaken but in relatively good health given the length of their ordeal and the strain of being held against their will. All eight have been taken to a secret address under police protection and will be questioned by immigration officials tomorrow.

Thirteen people found in the flat were arrested on suspicion of kidnapping and false imprisonment and were being questioned last night at three central London police stations. Another person arrested at the scene, a juvenile, was released from custody yesterday.

A police source said the abductions appeared to be an "archetypal snakehead kidnap". The gangs specialise in trafficking illegal immigrants into the UK using extensive smuggling networks.

Police were alerted when one of the hostages, a man in his early 20s, escaped from the house on Byng Street in the Isle of Dogs on Monday morning. He was found in a distressed state by a taxi driver who took him to a local police station.

Officers from Scotland Yard's kidnap and specialist investigations unit mounted a 24-hour surveillance operation to locate the remaining captives. More than 100 officers were involved in the operation over three days.

Shortly before 1pm on Wednesday, officers from the specialist firearms unit fired stun grenades through the front window of the maisonette. A small explosive charge was then fired to remove the lock on the front door and officers stormed the flat.

There was no resistance from the suspects although a replica firearm was found in the flat.

An eyewitness, Sharon Hurley, 39, who runs a mobile snack business near the flat, described seeing armed officers dressed in black and wearing gas masks storm the flat. "We heard a series of loud bangs right on 1pm and all wondered 'what the hell was that'," she said.

"Then we saw all hell breaking loose outside the flat. There were at least four or five armed police dressed all in black, over half a dozen police vans and two ambulances in the street. The officers were carrying rifles or machine guns. They told us later that the bangs we heard were stun grenades."

All 22 people in the flat, some of whom were dressed only in underwear, were marched on to the street, searched, photographed and then clothed in white boiler suits before being driven away for questioning.

Human traffickers charge up to £20,000 to organise passage from China and the majority of the money is paid when the illegal immigrants reach the UK. The majority of Chinese illegal immigrants come from Fujian province, a largely agricultural area.

Last month four men were arrested and charged with kidnapping and false imprisonment after a police raid at an address on the Thamesmead estate in Greenwich on the opposite bank of the Thames.

Figures released by the national criminal intelligence service (NCIS) show an increase in incidents of kidnapping and extortion involving Chinese-organised gangs in the last year. The number of kidnaps in the UK rose from 41 in 1998 to 72 last year.

An NCIS source said there were typically three scenarios in kidnap cases: "Groups of illegal immigrants smuggled into the country by one gang may be kidnapped by a rival gang and money demanded; they may be taken hostage by the people they payed to smuggle them into the country; or they may be kidnapped after falling behind on payments."

Jabez Lam, a Chinese community activist, said economic hardship and political repression were behind the increasing numbers of immigrants.

"Unemployment is rising fast in China and it forces people into increasingly desperate choices. These people sometimes leave children and family behind in order to try and make money abroad to support them."

webTitle: Vaccine in GM fruit could wipe out hepatitis B

fields.headline: Vaccine in GM fruit could wipe out hepatitis B
fields.standfirst:
Vaccine could wipe out virus
Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Tomatoes and bananas genetically modified to contain hepatitis B vaccine could rid the world of the virus, a leading American scientist said in London yesterday.
fields.body:
Tomatoes and bananas genetically modified to contain hepatitis B vaccine could rid the world of the virus, a leading American scientist said in London yesterday.

The virus, which causes high fever and attacks the liver, is a precursor of liver cancer, the biggest single cause of cancer deaths. This new development will save hundreds of thousands of lives a year, said Charles Arntzen, the scientist who developed the technology.

The breakthrough in producing a cheap, stable vaccine by genetically modifying plants became biology's holy grail in the 1990s, and is seen by the US bio-tech industry as its vindication and public relations saviour. Plant vaccines will be a billion-dollar business, said Professor Arntzen, who leads a team of the world's top plant scientists at Cornell University in New York state.

Successful experiments show that the vaccine worked, he added, and will cost less than one penny a dose to make. A single gene transferred into a tomato or banana plant is reproduced as a protein thousands of times inside the fruit. When eaten it passes into the intestine and then into the blood stream producing antibodies against hepatitis B - working the same way as a traditionally injected but much more expensive vaccine.

A single dried banana chip or tomato paste sandwiched in a wafer contains enough protein to act as a vaccine dose. Traditional vaccines have to be refrigerated and cost £10 for a successful course, making them too expensive for developing countries where hepatitis B kills many people directly and causes the death of many more through subsequent cancer.

Prof Arntzen, who is director of the Boyce Thompson institute for plant research at Cornell, has been visiting his opposite numbers at Britain's top plant research laboratory, the John Innis institute attached to Norwich University.

Talking to scientists at the US embassy in London, he said it was the most exciting area of biological science and that 40 new vaccines being worked on worldwide opened the possibility of eradicating some diseases altogether.

His institute was founded by a high-ranking Salvation Army officer in the 1920s to expand human understanding of plants and to enhance their benefits to humankind. It was for this altruistic reason that its scientists had tried to produce cheap vaccines from plants that would benefit millions of people in the developing world who could not afford western medicine.

"We have rid the world of smallpox through vaccination, we are close with polio. Now I believe we can do it with hepatitis B too," Prof Arntzen said.

His experimenting began in the 1990s with e-coli antibodies being genetically introduced into potatoes and fed to mice. A small quantity of uncooked potato was enough to produce antibodies in mice. Three clinical trials on human volunteers produced the same results but it did not work in cooked potatoes because the antibodies producing proteins were too unstable.

However, when the technology was used for hepatitis B using tomatoes, the proteins remained stable, allowing the vaccine to work even in processed or dried tomatoes. Thirty original plants, producing 15lb of tomatoes a week, were enough to produce thousands of doses of effective vaccine at one cent per four doses.

The vaccine has been held back because the US department of agriculture and the food and drug administration had no licensing mechanism for plant vaccines. "They are working on it and hope to have something up and running in two years," said Prof Arntzen.

The virus, which causes high fever and attacks the liver, is a precursor of liver cancer, the biggest single cause of cancer deaths. This new development will save hundreds of thousands of lives a year, said Charles Arntzen, the scientist who developed the technology. The breakthrough in producing a cheap, stable vaccine by genetically modifying plants became biology's holy grail in the 1990s, and is seen by the US bio-tech industry as its vindication and public relations saviour. Plant vaccines will be a billion-dollar business, said Professor Arntzen, who leads a team of the world's top plant scientists at Cornell University in New York state. Successful experiments show that the vaccine worked, he added, and will cost less than one penny a dose to make. A single gene transferred into a tomato or banana plant is reproduced as a protein thousands of times inside the fruit. When eaten it passes into the intestine and then into the blood stream producing antibodies against hepatitis B - working the same way as a traditionally injected but much more expensive vaccine. A single dried banana chip or tomato paste sandwiched in a wafer contains enough protein to act as a vaccine dose. Traditional vaccines have to be refrigerated and cost £10 for a successful course, making them too expensive for developing countries where hepatitis B kills many people directly and causes the death of many more through subsequent cancer. Prof Arntzen, who is director of the Boyce Thompson institute for plant research at Cornell, has been visiting his opposite numbers at Britain's top plant research laboratory, the John Innis institute attached to Norwich University. webTitle: Drug sub Colombians discover cocaine barons' latest weapon

fields.headline: Drug sub Colombians discover cocaine barons' latest weapon
fields.trailText: Colombian police officers have found a 30m-long submarine, designed to smuggle cocaine, being built in a secret workshop 400 miles from the country's Caribbean coast.
fields.body:
Colombian police officers have found a 30m-long submarine, designed to smuggle cocaine, being built in a secret workshop 400 miles from the country's Caribbean coast.

Agents found the vessel in mountains near the Colombian capital Bogota on Wednesday. No arrests were made but documents found at the site show that the smugglers planned to transport the submarine to the Caribbean. Instructions on how to build a submarine, written in Russian and translated into Spanish, were found nearby.

"It sounds like a fairy story, but it is true. The drug barons are developing more and more sophisticated methods to ship cocaine," said the national police chief, General Luis Ernesto Gilibert. "The technology used was advanced."

Law enforcement officials say Colombian drug barons - who produce up to 520 tonnes of cocaine each year - are collaborating with the Russian mafia to exploit new markets in eastern Europe. However, a spokesman for the Russian embassy said there is little sign that Russian criminals are actively involved in smuggling from Colombia.

"It seems very unlikely. We have a much bigger problem with smuggling through Asia," he said. Police technicians estimate the submarine cost $5 m (£3.3m) to build. It is not the first "narco-sub" to be found in Colombia but it is certainly the largest, with accommodation for three people and a cargo bay big enough to carry up to 15 tonnes of cocaine.

In 1993, officers found a crude submarine in the Caribbean port of Santa Marta. It was used to smuggle shipments of 1.5 tonnes to Panama.

fields.headline: Australian wine edges out French
fields.trailText: Much to the chagrin of France, Australia is maturing into the finest wine producing nation, according to judges at the world's largest sampling contest.
fields.body:
Much to the chagrin of France, Australia is maturing into the finest wine producing nation, according to judges at the world's largest sampling contest.

At the International Wine Challenge awards in London on Wednesday night, three-quarters of the Australian wines entered won an award, compared with half of those entered by French producers, who traditionally dominate the event. The outcome, in the contest's 16th year, enabled Australians to claim they produced some of the best bottles available in the £7 to £20 range.

"The Australians have done fantastically well this year," said Chris Losh, editor of Wine magazine, the competition organiser. "The French now know their crown has slipped." Perhaps the biggest shock was the award for Bordeaux-style category, where the French were clear favourites: the winner was CJ Pask Reserve Merlot 1998 from Hawkes Bay in New Zealand, selling for £15.49. It beat off competition from French wines three times the price.

Yesterday some French producers greeted the result with disdain, claiming it was beneath their more established vineyards to take part in such a competition.

Jackes Salle, wine producer and editor of the Larousse Encyclopaedia of Wine, said he was pleased to see new world wines improving, but insisted the best French vineyards had nothing to prove. "If you are the owner of a wine classified in 1855, what is the point in entering a competition?" he told the BBC's Today programme. "You have been first over 100 years, and you cannot get higher.

"Most of the great wines, in France and elsewhere, which have a certain reputation, do not want to pit themselves against other wines which are ready to drink earlier. It takes time for many of these wines to develop and mature."

John Duval, chief wine maker at the Australian wine firm Penfolds, winners of the red wine maker of the year section, replied that New World wines might have been considered crude some years ago, but today they were more subtle and had a greater range.

"We have decided to show the rest of the world our best wines," he said. "Before we drank them and sent only average wines abroad, but now we are making the best available everywhere." Australia is Britain's biggest supplier of wines costing £4 to £5, and its market share of off-licensed trade is 14%, creeping up on France's 25%. The Australian Wine Bureau said that shipments to Britain last November totalled 19m litres, and five of the top 10 selling brands were Australian.

Mr Losh said: "There are still some great French wines on the market, but if you are unsure what you are looking for and pick up a bottle of Australian, you usually can't go wrong."

At the awards were two British wines which won medals in the champagne and sparkling wine section. Cuvee Merret Belgravia NV from Sussex, costing £14, was highly commended, as was Valley Vineyards Ascot NV from the Thames Valley, also under £15.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Holidaymakers 'need help'
fields.body:
Holidaymakers 'need help'

Tour operators should protect holidaymakers from injury or illness caused by poor conditions, campaigners said yesterday. The volunteer groups Holiday TravelWatch and Consumer Safety International called on the Government to set up a watchdog, Ofhol; a 24-hour help line; and a levy on the industry to pay for it.

Woman head after 1,100 years

The independent Wells Cathedral school, Somerset, has appointed a headmistress for the first time since it was founded in 909. Elizabeth Cairncross, former deputy head of Christ's Hospital school in Sussex, described her new job as "interesting".

Memory loss link to chemicals

People regularly exposed to pesticides are more prone to mild cognitive dysfunction - like memory loss - in later life, according to a Maastricht ageing study reported in the Lancet.

Puppies ride free

A Dundee bus company has become the first in the country to issue free passes for puppies. The firm is to provide travel cards for the Guide Dogs for the Blind Association to allow the city's 20 volunteer puppy walkers to use any Travel Dundee service free.

Madonna's surprise

Pop star Madonna wants to surprise clubbers by making unannounced appearances in London and New York during this autumn. Her last tour was in 1993. "I like the idea of doing that, and playing to 2,000 to 5,000 people," she told Rolling Stone magazine.

webTitle: Heart patient in pioneer pump op

fields.headline: Heart patient in pioneer pump op
fields.trailText: A retired hospital psychotherapist from Birmingham has become the world's first coronary disease victim to have an electric pump implanted permanently in his heart.
fields.body:
A retired hospital psychotherapist from Birmingham has become the world's first coronary disease victim to have an electric pump implanted permanently in his heart.

Peter Houghton, 61, had been told by doctors he had less than six weeks to live when he volunteered to have the thumb-sized device inserted into his left ventricular wall. After six weeks the symptoms of his heart failure had disappeared, with his heart muscle - only pumping at a tenth of its potential after a heart attack three years ago - dramatically repairing itself, his kidneys working more efficiently, and with him losing 15 kgs of weight.

His ability to exercise had also drastically improved. Before the operation, on June 20, walking 10 yards made him breathless. Now he strides out for two miles each day.

"We're very excited by the outcome," said Stephen Westaby, the cardiac surgeon who operated on him at Oxford's John Radcliffe hospital, and who believes that, within 10 years, the pumps could be as common as pacemakers. "Before the operation, he probably only had a 50/50 chance it would be successful. Now all his organs are working normally, and he's a fit man living at home."

The three-hour operation was part of a clinical trial which will see four more heart disease sufferers operated on by the end of the year.

The pump was inserted in Mr Houghton's heart, with a fine electric wire threaded through the chest to the neck, where a titanium button was screwed into the skull. The pump is run by batteries and a controller, both the size of a portable phone, which are carried on a belt. A wire connects these to the titanium button, protruding from behind the ear.

The operation is revolutionary because, while three Jarvik 2000 pumps have been inserted as an aid for patients awaiting heart transplants in Houston, Texas, this is the first time one has been intended to be used permanently.

webTitle: New fathers likely to get two weeks of paid leave

fields.headline: New fathers likely to get two weeks of paid leave
fields.trailText: Fathers will be allowed to take two weeks of paid paternity leave under radical plans to give parents more time to care for their children.
fields.body:
Fathers will be allowed to take two weeks of paid paternity leave under radical plans to give parents more time to care for their children.

The idea is favoured by a group of ministers examining ways of improving parental leave without antagonising business leaders.

Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, yesterday called on employers to recognise the importance of child caring. Many parents were trying to juggle "the responsibility of being a good parent with holding down a job", he said as he launched a consultation on changes to parental leave.

The government is to publish a green paper this year outlining changes to entitlements; giving fathers two weeks' paid leave after the birth of their child is expected to among the main proposals. At present they are entitled to 13 weeks' unpaid leave if they have children, up to age five.

Under the new proposal, the leave would have to be taken immediately after the birth to allow companies to plan for an employee's absence.

One ministerial source said the aim was to balance the demands of campaigners, who want fathers to be allowed to choose when to take their leave, with the needs of employers, who are wary of improving parental leave.

"A lot of people work shifts, and their absence has to be covered by someone else," the source said. "The people who are calling for a more flexible system come from the world of researchers and academics, who are a minority."

Ministers are likely to struggle to win the support of business for the proposal. This week the Confederation of British Industry called on the government to resist demands for paid parental leave.

Digby Jones, CBI director general, said his members feared ministers were planning new legislation on workers' rights in an appeal to Labour's core supporters before the election. "Enough is enough," he said. "We have had 16 pieces of employment legislation in two years. I hope Tony Blair and Gordon Brown will behave like statesmen and put the country first."

Mr Byers said the aim was to ensure that new measures were not harmful to business. "Particular attention will need to be given to the effect on small business."

webTitle: MPs call for computer security review after leaks

fields.headline: MPs call for computer security review after leaks
fields.trailText: MPs are to consider an urgent review of the security of their computer systems after complaints from Labour and the Liberal Democrats that key documents may have become vulnerable to hacking.
fields.body:
MPs are to consider an urgent review of the security of their computer systems after complaints from Labour and the Liberal Democrats that key documents may have become vulnerable to hacking.

The call for a review of security follows the leak of three draft Liberal Democrat policy documents in the past few months. The latest leak to the Guardian this week centred on a document analysing the costings of its manifesto. It was sent by email to only four senior Liberal Democrats.

The few paper copies of the costings documents were gathered up following a presentation to the Liberal Democrat shadow cabinet in July.

The Guardian has no knowledge of how its source gained access to the document.

The review may form part of a wider inquiry by the Commons information select committee into plans for a centralised computer system for all MPs, which could even open the way for online debates.

At present, each MP on the parliamentary intranet buys their own computer machinery, in contrast to the unified system used by the devolved assemblies in Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales.

The latest Liberal Democrat leak follows disclosures to newspapers this summer of the party's draft pre-budget statement and a draft of its general policy document released this week.

Matthew Taylor, a Liberal Democrat MP, believes MPs' and ministers' computer files are vulnerable to hacking from inside and outside the Commons.

fields.headline: Still more jobs required
fields.standfirst:
Employment growth is slowing as the labour market reaches capacity. Job-creation policy should now be targeted on excluded groups

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: A new Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) analysis of official employment figures shows that slightly more new jobs were created in the three years up to the last general election - John Major's last years - than in three years since. Unemployment fell less sharply during Tony Blair's first three years than under the last three Tory years. To add insult to injury our figures stir up the north-south jobs debate by showing that manufacturing jobs have fallen by 180,000 in the last three years after growing by 150,000 in 1994 -97.
fields.body:
A new Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) analysis of official employment figures shows that slightly more new jobs were created in the three years up to the last general election - John Major's last years - than in three years since. Unemployment fell less sharply during Tony Blair's first three years than under the last three Tory years. To add insult to injury our figures stir up the north-south jobs debate by showing that manufacturing jobs have fallen by 180,000 in the last three years after growing by 150,000 in 1994 -97.

It sounds like grist to the mill for government opponents. This is evidence, they will say, that New Labour does not deserve its new-found reputation for economic management. The figures do indeed deserve close scrutiny. But the fact is that the lower unemployment is, the harder it is to reduce it further. When unemployment reaches the catastrophic levels it did in the (Tory) recessions of the early 80s and 90s, totals fall easily when the business cycle eventually turns upwards. In such circumstances there are many people with recent work experience who can take up job opportunities and employers have plenty of opportunity to find the right people to match their needs among the unemployed.

But as an economy edges closer to full employment - as it has done in the past two years - each extra percentage point fall gets harder to achieve.What's more, governments tend to want a slower fall in the later stages of the cycle to prevent the emergence of inflationary pressures. And the new jobs do not always go to unemployed people. A booming labour market can encourage people who were not working or looking for work to take up the new job opportunities.

In this light Labour's record looks impressive. A better question is what happens the next few years. What should the parties (all of whom are now committed to full employment) be putting in their manifestos? Economist Richard Freeman describes the American experience of full employment. Unemployment there has been about 4% the last couple of years, compared to 5.6% here. In the United States this has brought real social as well as economic benefits. Wages for the lowest paid have risen after nearly two decades of decline, crime has fallen, disadvantaged groups such as young black men and lone parents have seen rising employment and incomes, even the teenage pregnancy rate has been reduced.

But though achieving full employment on the back of the long boom has brought enormous benefits, there are still problems that do not seem to be solved by the availability of jobs. Inequality in the US is still huge and there seems to be a core of people who stay in poverty and deprivation even at a time of full employment. There are still homeless people on the streets, many disabled people cannot work, some lone parents still have not responded to the welfare reforms. Freeman estimates this core as around 10% of the adult population - many millions of people.

The UK government's slogan has been "work for those who can, security for those who cannot". The challenge facing Labour over the next few years will be to be more ambitious on both counts. The official target is to get "a higher percentage of people in employment that ever before". But all that involves is adding 1% to the current figure of 74.6% (of working age population in work). At the moment, only half of lone parents, 46% of disabled people, two-thirds of men over 50 and two-thirds of people from ethnic minorities are in work. What if they became targets for "full employment"? The table offers some targets. 1 is getting parents with children aged 5+ into jobs; 2 is halving the current difference between employment for disabled and non-disabled people; 3 is getting men aged 50+ into at the same rate as in the late 70s; 4 is raising employment among ethnic minority people of working age to the same level as whites. Overall, we need to get something like 80% of the work force into jobs. This has been achieved in some European countries and in parts of the UK. It will mean letting the economy grow and extending the New Deal.

Not much of a problem for the government, you might think. More controversially, it may also require direct intervention by the state to create jobs in the areas with the highest unemployment rate.

Secondly, we need to recognise the limits of a work-based social policy agenda. It will not benefit significant groups of people. Boom in the US has given policy-makers various options on what to do with their budget surplus: significant action and spending to help the most disadvantaged is now a possibility. In the UK government will need to come up with ways to cater for the very varied needs of this excluded group, without creating perverse incentives for people just a little better off. There needs to be more help for the homeless and drug addicts, for the most severely disabled, for some lone parents and people with poor basic skills. The public policy dilemma is that this needs to be done without providing disincentives to people with fewer problems from working where they can.

All the major political parties are committed to full employment. But a left-of-centre party will be judged by whether it is committed to tackling unemployment in the most disadvantaged groups and areas, and whether it will alleviate the poverty of those for whom work really is not an option.

Matthew Taylor is director of the Institute for Public Policy Research

At the moment, only half of lone parents, 46% of disabled people, two-thirds of men over 50 and two-thirds of people from ethnic minorities are in work. What if they became targets for "full employment"? The table offers some targets. 1 is getting parents with children aged 5+ into jobs; 2 is halving the current difference between employment for disabled and non-disabled people; 3 is getting men aged 50+ into at the same rate as in the late 70s; 4 is raising employment among ethnic minority people of working age to the same level as whites. Overall, we need to get something like 80% of the work force into jobs. This has been achieved in some European countries and in parts of the UK. It will mean letting the economy grow and extending the New Deal. Not much of a problem for the government, you might think. More controversially, it may also require direct intervention by the state to create jobs in the areas with the highest unemployment rate. Secondly, we need to recognise the limits of a work-based social policy agenda. It will not benefit significant groups of people. Boom in the US has given policy-makers various options on what to do with their budget surplus: significant action and spending to help the most disadvantaged is now a possibility. In the UK government will need to come up with ways to cater for the very varied needs of this excluded group, without creating perverse incentives for people just a little better off. There needs to be more help for the homeless and drug addicts, for the most severely disabled, for some lone parents and people with poor basic skills. The public policy dilemma is that this needs to be done without providing disincentives to people with fewer problems from working where they can. All the major political parties are committed to full employment. But a left-of-centre party will be judged by whether it is committed to tackling unemployment in the most disadvantaged groups and areas, and whether it will alleviate the poverty of those for whom work really is not an option. webTitle: Patrick Diamond: Labour should not play safe for victory

fields.headline: Safety first has had its day
fields.standfirst:
New Labour needs to move from being a competent manager to becoming a creative entrepreneur
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The common perception after the summer break is that Labour has the next election in the bag.
fields.body:
The common perception after the summer break is that Labour has the next election in the bag.

Yet complacency of this kind could fuel the danger of a low turnout by demotivating Labour supporters. Playing safe for victory would risk a serious loss of New Labour's momentum for the second term. The temptation is inevitably strong. But it would be a disastrous strategy for New Labour.

The latest polls show that the government is hugely popular by any historical comparison. It can boast a strong economy with rising employment and living standards. After the recent comprehensive spending review announcement, the indications are that voters are beginning to trust New Labour's plans for a sustained improvement in public services through reform and investment.

In these circumstances, playing safe for victory may seem the low-risk option. It means maintaining the caution that defined New Labour's approach in the run-up to the 1997 election, and relying on a tightly controlled, centrally run system of media management to cope with a hostile press and a Tory campaign desperate to exploit any weakness.

Yet to pursue the safety-first approach could be fraught with risk. A centre-left party that is serious about change has to do more than win an electoral mandate. It has to carry its political coalition with it to shape a radical social democratic agenda for the second term and beyond.

The challenge facing New Labour is not just about maintaining its discipline, though that is essential. It is about reinvigorating intelligent debate. Raising the level and quality of political discussion among those committed to the government's success will be central to New Labour's ambitions for a sustained period of office.

In the next few months New Labour needs to define with greater clarity the central components of the second-term programme, and maintain the momentum for radical change. For when the choppy seas of government get rougher, as inevitably they must, New Labour will need a committed coalition of supporters from the trade unions, business and the public sector to argue its corner. If New Labour is to be a broad-based movement, it is essential that the coalition shares in its goals, understands its ideas and drives forward its political priorities.

New Labour needs to as sert a realistic sense of progressive ambition. One way of describing the progressive goal would be Britain as a modern, successful European country; enjoying the high-quality public services that Scandinavia and Holland take for granted; being part of a European society that uniquely combines economic dynamism, personal freedom and social justice. And working with our EU partners to be a force for good in the world.

Yet for this to be achieved New Labour needs a more assertive style. To move from being a competent manager of the machinery of state to become a creative entrepreneur taking Britain forward. Now is the time to push forward the parameters of the policy debate for the next parliament.

There could not be a more opportune moment. Britain faces questions of fundamental importance. How do we close the knowledge and performance deficit with our economic competitors to expand the productive capacity of the UK economy? How do we create an active welfare and employment policy that abolishes unemployment? Can Britain deliver a radical step change in the quality of public services that transforms people's expectations of what the state can deliver?

As these questions demonstrate there are hugely important debates in today's Labour party - about what constitutes a good economy for the centre-left; about how we can raise the quality of work available so that people are fulfilled and engaged in the workplace; about how we can address the "work-life balance" in the modern economy. These are all issues that call for further debate within the centre-left community.

Progress exists to bring together Labour party members with ministers, advisers, MPs, policy experts, trade unionists, and business to encourage discussion of this kind. This weekend a conference will take place involving all these stakeholders to drive this process forward.

These debates are not fruitless intellectual abstraction, nor are they divisive. Too often the cynics conspire to associate political debate with division and factionalism. The Labour party has suffered from the most bitter sectarianism imaginable. It cannot return to the dark days of the early 1980s, and it must ensure that New Labour's political coalition is fully engaged in the debate.

The task ahead is to construct a policy-rich agenda for governance that will sustain New Labour through successive terms of office. In the 1990s the centre-left in Britain and Europe demonstrated the capacity to defeat parties of the right. But the left has yet to fully articulate and win the consent for the clear set of governing principles that can help New Labour and its sister parties to retain political power. It is to that task that we now turn.

 Patrick Diamond is director of Progress

fields.headline: Two into one
fields.standfirst:
The Catholic view that the Siamese twins should not be separated is right, though for the wrong reasons

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Siamese twins are fascinatingly horrible freaks of nature (or of God, for those who imagine He in His bounty creates such things). This melding of bodies into one raises mythic spectres of merged identities full of the mystery of personhood.
fields.body:
Siamese twins are fascinatingly horrible freaks of nature (or of God, for those who imagine He in His bounty creates such things). This melding of bodies into one raises mythic spectres of merged identities full of the mystery of personhood.

So this has been an obsessively interesting news story, followed in gripping detail as the parents strive to stop the doctors officiously keeping alive this monstrous abnormality that might or might not be two people. The doctors want to save one child at the expense of the other, the parents don't. How everyone has relished the moral, ethical and legal dilemmas. How intellectually enthralling the arguments in courts have been. What a field day for the lawyers, with "Mary" represented by the official solicitor, while "Jodie" and the parents each have barristers of their own.

We no longer parade our freaks in fairgrounds, we put them in the courtroom for general public dissection instead. This has become a textbook angels-on-pins question to enliven every pub and wine bar in the land. Only the extraordinary personal anguish expressed by the judges themselves reminds us of the human horror at the centre of it all.

The big beasts of medical ethics have been locking horns, the rationalists against the religious as usual. The parents are represented as simple deeply religious Catholics from a faraway rural community who want to leave things to "God's will". They ask: "Why should we kill one of our daughters to enable the other to survive?" Supported by the Pro-Life Alliance, they have been offered a safe haven in Italy by a Roman Catholic cardinal to escape the murderous knives of British medicine.

The (somewhat Jesuitical) Catholic doctrine of double effect says that the intention is what counts: if doctors thought there was a shred of a chance of saving Mary's life then her subsequent unfortunate death would be acceptable, but she cannot be deliberately murdered to save her sister. It is never right to do a bad thing for a greater good. (No, put aside all thoughts on the history of the Vatican.) Catholic theologians say death is unimportant, a transition to the next life, so saving every life in every situation is not a priority. Given the great lengths they will go to to save an unborn life against a mother's will, it seems odd. But that's their position. Jodie's death is preferable to Mary's murder.

In the other corner, upholding the first judge, are the rationalists. Dame Mary Warnock has pronounced. It's a simple matter. Either one or both dies, which is best? Easy. Professional philosophers take us through a lively set of hypotheticals displaying the criteria needed to reach that position through a sifting of the options.

Professor Bernard Williams, the celebrated ethicist offers these: 1) The spelunker case: a fat man is jammed in the only exit to a pothole. Do the other cavers kill him to escape? Answer: yes, because it's an unavoidable emergency, a situation of no one's contriving. 2) The trolley case: a rail trolley is speeding towards a man strapped to the line, do you intervene to change the points and save him? Yes, of course. Ah, but what if there were five men strapped to the other line, would you let him die to save more lives? If you let him die, can he sue regardless of saving the other five? No, the decision is imposed on the man at the points, so in extremis numbers of lives saved must count.

But that raises the cannibalisation case: if a healthy man walks into a hospital where three others are about to die for lack of his organs, do you kill him to save the others? No, you can't go arbitrarily redistributing lives but sometimes in emergencies you have to make the best of bad choices, in which case numbers of lives saved do count. So on that analysis, one live child is better than two dead. However, as Professor Williams himself says, in the real world things don't always look quite like his philosophy.

Nothing in this case is clear-cut. The finicky arguments continue as to whether Mary exists as a legal entity - has she drawn breath or is she a growth? But it's emerging in court that the medical outcome for Jodie is far from clear. The twins are joined almost right down the front to the anus like a seamless cylinder with mingled bowels. If separated, Jodie might well be doubly incontinent and she might never walk. Her brain function might not be 100% either.

The reason her parents should be allowed to make this decision themselves is that either way, they are the ones who will have to live forever with the outcome. They may have to care for a severely disabled child with very little help. Since they cannot live with the idea that one child has been murdered to save the other, they are likely to pass those feelings on to the child. So they must be free to decide, relieving the squeamish judges of their sleepless nights.

Ah, say the rationalists, but wouldn't you intervene to save a Christian Science child dying of appendicitis or a Jehovah's Witness child in need of a blood transfusion? Parents are not always right and children do need to be protected from cranks. The extraordinary thing about these life and death medical ethics cases is that they knit a tangled web of contradictory principles. The right to life is a very flexible principle. Pro-lifers were passionately opposed to letting the vegetative patient Tony Bland die through having his feeding tube removed and yet they want to see these twins die. As for the rationalists, is it really so rational to strive to keep alive a frail baby in need of many painful operations against its parents' will on some semi-religious notion of the sanctity of life?

Far too much effort goes into officiously keeping alive damaged specks of humanity as ground-breaking paediatricians save ever-younger foetuses. Last month the British Medical Journal reported that nearly half of very premature babies grow up with some kind of neurological disability: a quarter of babies born at 22-25 weeks are severely disabled - blind and unable to walk. The report highlighted the importance of telling parents the risk and letting them, not doctors or courts, make decisions about life-saving treatment.

A study from the national perinatal epidemiology unit last month studied the high number of premature babies with cerebral palsy and the phenomenal cost not just to the NHS, but in their 50% greater chance of needing special schools and having life-long health problems and loss of family income, with increased family breakdown. Newspapers like stories of the smallest baby ever saved by the doctors, but there are no follow-ups after the home-from-hospital picture.

The right to life is not an absolute. It is inextricably and untidily linked in almost every case with social and psychological considerations, as well as the money that might have bought more health and happiness elsewhere. For the courts to demand that parents must keep alive severely deformed children against their will is perverse and unkind. The Catholic arguments confuse the issue, but this time, for all the wrong reasons, the Pope is infallible.

webTitle: Burger King needs a boss before a float

fields.headline: Burger King needs a boss before a float
fields.trailText: The £2.5bn flotation of Burger King could be delayed due to difficulties in recruiting a new boss for the global fast-food chain, Diageo said yesterday.
fields.body:
The £2.5bn flotation of Burger King could be delayed due to difficulties in recruiting a new boss for the global fast-food chain, Diageo said yesterday.

The news emerged as the world's biggest drinks company announced an 11% rise in underlying profits for the year to £1.98bn, as surging sales of Johnnie Walker and Smirnoff offset a slowdown at food business Pillsbury.

Diageo had planned to float a 20% stake in Burger King on the New York stock exchange early next year but group chief executive Paul Walsh said: "It is more important to put processes in place to maximise value than slavishly to try and hit a specific timetable."

Diageo is trying to find a replacement for Dennis Malamatinas, who resigned as Burger King's chief executive in June. The company is also keen to get trading back on track - Burger King's operating profits grew just 4%.

Diageo's biggest spirits brands fared better, achieving a 12% increase in sales with Baileys, Malibe and Cuervo among the top performers.

However, the group's performance was held back by a slowdown at Guinness - which suffered its first fall in sales in Ireland - and at Pillsbury, which is about to be merged with General Mills. Pillsbury's profits were flat.
