webTitle: When doing nothing is the best option

fields.headline: When doing nothing is the best option
fields.standfirst: Inflation signals remain confused
fields.trailText: The decision to keep rates on hold for the seventh month in a row may have been boring, but you can bet your life that the chat at yesterday's meeting of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee was anything but.
fields.body:
The decision to keep rates on hold for the seventh month in a row may have been boring, but you can bet your life that the chat at yesterday's meeting of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee was anything but.

After last month's cliffhanging five-four decision in favour of "no change," the committee was probably just as divided over the rate decision yesterday. There will still have been those worried that private sector spending is not slowing rapidly enough to allow room for Gordon Brown's generous public sector spending plans to kick in, while the doves on the committee will have been cheered by a decline in earnings growth and a further easing of the property boom.

The joker in the pack has been the exchange rate. While sterling is testing seven-year lows against the dollar, the euro's tumble on the foreign exchanges has once again ratcheted up the pressure on manufacturers struggling to export to Europe. Because firms buy most of their raw materials and fuel in dollars, the current situation is the worst of all possible worlds, but from the Bank's standpoint the overall impact of the exchange rate is little changed since it last met.

The Bank declined to act last month despite its own forecasts showing inflation above its 2.5% target in two years' time. It would have been inconsistent for it to have raised rates yesterday after a month of conflicting signals from the economy. Doing nothing yesterday might have been boring, but it was the right thing.

Invensys sinks

Those who believe mergers destroy as much value as they create will be adding Invensys - the tie-up between Siebe and BTR - to their textbook studies unless a turnaround is effected pretty sharpish. The company yesterday reported trading difficulties in many of its core areas and, ominously, in software, where it has just forked out £470m to take majority control of the troubled Dutch group Baan.

Invensys' Canadian-born chief executive, Allen Yurko, blames an array of market difficulties - such as a slowdown in US residential building and a reduction in demand from the oil and gas sector as well as reductions in semi-conductor prices. Unsurprisingly, the City was sceptical of these claims pointing out that the US economy is booming, oil prices are rocketing and software sales are up everywhere.

Analysts accept that Invensys is sitting at the top engineering table where competition between Honeywell, Emerson and Schreiber is intense. But what value the merger of Siebe and BTR with the thousands of job losses and sales of businesses if it were not to make Invensys leaner, fitter and able to weather a storm?

So the markets gave Mr Yurko a serious clout on the head yesterday. A 37% share price fall in a Footsie company in a single day is almost unheard of.

One thing in particular which has stuck in the City's collective craw is the admission that software margins are being squeezed.

Having sold off businesses such as automotive products, environmental technology and aerospace operations, Invernsys faces a real question over whether it really needed to move into software. If it was an attempt to bring a bit of e-glamour to a business rooted in the old economy, it has all gone horribly wrong.

Stout surfeit

Are the Irish finally falling out of love with the creamy black stuff? It appears so, according to Diageo, which yesterday revealed that sales of Guinness had fallen in the Emerald Isle for the first time.

The 4% decline is hardly cause to sell shares in the world's biggest drinks company. But it does point to a longer-term trend - Diageo blamed Ireland's booming economic growth , which means "people are doing other things, rather than just going to the pub".

The problem, for Diageo is that Guinness has traditionally been the drink of the working man in Ireland. It hardly ranks alongside vodka and Red Bull as a trendy tipple for young, urban Dubliners or for the legions of employees of the country's burgeoning hi-tech industry.

In countries where Guinness has been introduced much more recently the drink is doing fine - because it is associated with Rutger Hauer's stylish marketing patter and with glossy advertisements showing horses bursting through waves.

Such a renaissance could take a while in the drink's home territory, where Guinness will always be the devil's buttermilk first produced by Arthur Guinness in 1759. Perhaps europhobes who want an example of the euro throwing an economy out of kilter and in the process doing serious damage to a country's cultural heritage should take up the issue.

The company yesterday reported trading difficulties in many of its core areas and, ominously, in software, where it has just forked out £470m to take majority control of the troubled Dutch group Baan. Invensys' Canadian-born chief executive, Allen Yurko, blames an array of market difficulties - such as a slowdown in US residential building and a reduction in demand from the oil and gas sector as well as reductions in semi-conductor prices. Unsurprisingly, the City was sceptical of these claims pointing out that the US economy is booming, oil prices are rocketing and software sales are up everywhere. Analysts accept that Invensys is sitting at the top engineering table where competition between Honeywell, Emerson and Schreiber is intense. But what value the merger of Siebe and BTR with the thousands of job losses and sales of businesses if it were not to make Invensys leaner, fitter and able to weather a storm? So the markets gave Mr Yurko a serious clout on the head yesterday. A 37% share price fall in a Footsie company in a single day is almost unheard of. One thing in particular which has stuck in the City's collective craw is the admission that software margins are being squeezed. Having sold off businesses such as automotive products, environmental technology and aerospace operations, Invernsys faces a real question over whether it really needed to move into software. If it was an attempt to bring a bit of e-glamour to a business rooted in the old economy, it has all gone horribly wrong. Stout surfeit Are the Irish finally falling out of love with the creamy black stuff? It appears so, according to Diageo, which yesterday revealed that sales of Guinness had fallen in the Emerald Isle for the first time. The 4% decline is hardly cause to sell shares in the world's biggest drinks company. But it does point to a longer-term trend - Diageo blamed Ireland's booming economic growth , which means "people are doing other things, rather than just going to the pub". The problem, for Diageo is that Guinness has traditionally been the drink of the working man in Ireland. It hardly ranks alongside vodka and Red Bull as a trendy tipple for young, urban Dubliners or for the legions of employees of the country's burgeoning hi-tech industry. In countries where Guinness has been introduced much more recently the drink is doing fine - because it is associated with Rutger Hauer's stylish marketing patter and with glossy advertisements showing horses bursting through waves. Such a renaissance could take a while in the drink's home territory, where Guinness will always be the devil's buttermilk first produced by Arthur Guinness in 1759. Perhaps europhobes who want an example of the euro throwing an economy out of kilter and in the process doing serious damage to a country's cultural heritage should take up the issue.

fields.headline: £3bn wiped off Invensys price
fields.trailText: More than £3bn - one-third of the company's value - was wiped off the price of shares in Invensys yesterday after the engineering group issued a profit warning and announced an immediate restructuring with 3,000 jobs to be axed.
fields.body:
More than £3bn - one-third of the company's value - was wiped off the price of shares in Invensys yesterday after the engineering group issued a profit warning and announced an immediate restructuring with 3,000 jobs to be axed.

The automation and controls specialist said trading activity had been "below expectations" with a downturn in a range of main markets such as US residential, oil and gas, and software systems.

Reference to the computer sector particularly upset the City because Invensys has just completed an unpopular deal to take over troubled Dutch software group Baan where 1,000 jobs have already gone.

Allen Yurko, chief executive of Invensys - the product of a merger between Siebe and BTR 18 months ago - plans to cut up to 3% of the group's total staff and shut several plants in the US and Mexico.

He blamed some of the staff reductions on the dollar's strength against the euro and said only 300 jobs at most would go in Britain.

But he admitted there were wider problems: "The expected recovery in our capital goods markets has not materialised, with oil and gas expenditure down a further 3% year on year. Equally significant has been the effect of an 11% year-on-year reduction in US housing starts on our residential controls markets."

On the positive side there had been significant improvements in the telecoms, information technology and electronic equipment divisions and targets were being met on merger cost reductions. But some gains had been offset by the lower performance of software systems and automation system divisions.

Although there had been growth in high-end software, Invensys complained there was continued weakness in its core markets which were being made worse by pricing pressures, higher product development costs and escalating semiconductor prices.

Analysts said they would be slashing their end-of-year forecasts, with ABN Amro predicting a pre-tax profit of £600m, which includes rationalisation costs, instead of £740m. Guy Hewett, engineering analyst with the Dutch bank, said: "It is disappointing, given the scale of rationalisation, that margins have suffered and they have not been able to compete effectively in the market place."

Another industry specialist said: "It is a pretty severe warning. Buying Baan and then reporting margins under pressure in software is just what no one wanted to hear."

But Invensys defended the Baan acquisition and said its integration and restructuring were proceeding well. "A new management team has been put in place with incentive plans which will reward [with] a rapid return of the business to growth and profitability."

It insisted problems in the group had nothing to do with Baan, whose acquisition had already driven Invensys' share price close to a 12- month low. Shares in Invensys ended the day down 93p - 36% - to 167p.

The job losses at Baan represent 25% of the workforce; many of the Dutch company's sales offices are being merged with those of its new parent. Invensys will have to write off an extra £30m in the first-half results, to be reported at the end of November, and £35m in the second half. Some Baan shareholders, disappointed at the deal, have refused to sell their stakes to Invensys.

webTitle: Coup for NTL as Carter snubs ITV

fields.headline: Coup for NTL as Carter snubs ITV
fields.standfirst: Cable company hopes to boost image as it claims ad executive headhunted by network
fields.trailText: Stephen Carter, the advertising executive who had been tipped to land the job of ITV Network chief executive, has instead accepted a job at cable company NTL.
fields.body:
Stephen Carter, the advertising executive who had been tipped to land the job of ITV Network chief executive, has instead accepted a job at cable company NTL.

Mr Carter will join NTL as chief operating officer from advertising agency J Walter Thompson. The agency acts for NTL and came up with the cable firm's slogan "technology tamed".

The appointment was viewed as a clear admission that the cable industry is in dire need of a bit of marketing nous. Cable & Wireless Communications, which NTL recently bought, is commonly among the most fiercely criticised companies in Britain for its poor levels of service.

Mr Carter's decision to accept the job at NTL is a further embarrassment for ITV which has struggled to fill its chief executive slot for nine months. He is reported to have turned ITV down two weeks ago.

The ITV job was vacated when Richard Eyre left to join Pearson TV in January and a succession of candidates have decided against joining the network at the 11th hour.

Others understood to have snubbed ITV include Richard Hytner, chief executive of advertising agency Publicis, Dominic Proctor, chief executive of Mindshare and Peter Littlewood of confectionary group Mars. The job carries a package of about £500,000.

Mr Carter, who was chief executive of J Walter Thompson, will replace Leigh Wood who the company said was standing down at the end of next March to spend more time with her husband and four children.

Barclay Knapp, NTL chief executive, said Mr Carter's background made him a good replacement. "His track record in building successful consumer brands comes at a perfect time in NTL's stage of development," he said.

Mr Carter had been at J Walter Thompson since joining its graduate trainee scheme after completing a law degree at Aberdeen university.

He became managing director of the London office in 1994 and took over as chief executive of the group, owned by WPP, three years later.

NTL's chief rival, Telewest yesterday said it would resume marketing its digital cable TV service on October 1 after overcoming a shortage of set-top boxes which had flattened the group's share price over the summer. Chief executive Adam Singer said the group has "all the boxes we need until the end of the year".

The introduction of digital has caused BSkyB to surge ahead of its cable rivals which have suffered a series of delays to their own launches. The announcement failed to halt the slide in Telewest's share price which was off 4p at 179.5p.

fields.headline: Powderject gains vaccine booster
fields.trailText: Some of Britain's most widely used vaccines could be produced in powder form, following the purchase of Celltech's preventive medicines division for £55m by needle-free technology company Powderject Pharmaceuticals.
fields.body:
Some of Britain's most widely used vaccines could be produced in powder form, following the purchase of Celltech's preventive medicines division for £55m by needle-free technology company Powderject Pharmaceuticals.

The division, which employs 800 people in Speke, Merseyside, is one of the biggest suppliers of vaccines to the national health service. It manufactures flu vaccines, which are distributed to the elderly each winter, yellow fever antidotes for travellers and BCG inoculations against tuberculosis.

Powderject wants to introduce its technology, in which powdered medicines are blasted through the skin at supersonic speeds

Powderject's chief executive, Paul Drayson, said: "Powderject's technology is particularly good at delivering vaccines because of its accuracy. We can deliver medicine into the right layer of skin and the particles are so small that they rest inside the body's immune cells."

Powderject is already developing a powder version of the flu vaccine Fluvirin, which is three to four years away from marketing. Mr Drayson said the BCG vaccine, distributed to most of the country's teenagers, was another promising candidate.

"The main cost of a vaccine programme is the person needed to administer it. Our vaccines can be self-administered, or an unskilled person can do it."

The deal sharply increases the scale of Oxford-based Powderject, which employs just 250 people. It will be funded by a placing of shares at 600p to raise £35m.

Mr Drayson said he was initially put off buying the division because it received a warning last year on cleanliness and quality grounds from the US food and drug administration. Half of the flu vaccines produced in the plant in 1999 had to be thrown away, although the problems have since been rectified.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: • Concessions Music group EMI has offered concessions to address European commission concerns that its planned joint venture with the Time Warner music arm could damage competition. "We have presented undertakings to the commission and await a response from officials," an EMI spokesman said.
fields.body:
 Concessions Music group EMI has offered concessions to address European commission concerns that its planned joint venture with the Time Warner music arm could damage competition. "We have presented undertakings to the commission and await a response from officials," an EMI spokesman said.

 Active Viewing Viacom's CBS Television has entered a pact with Microsoft's WebTV Networks to deliver interactive television programming. The companies said that interactive TV programming will begin with the 2000-2001 season and include CBS dramas, comedies, specials, variety shows, movies and sport. They said the pact was the first to include such programming for comedies and dramas.

 Moving Britain's first "totally online" property conveyancing service is being started today and claims it will shake up traditional high street solicitors by cutting the time it takes to buy or sell a home by a third or more. Legalmove.com is developed by conveyancing firm Hammond Direct.

 No comparison Song-swap company Napster, being sued for copyright infringement distanced itself from a case against MP3.com in which district judge Jed Rakoff ruled on Wednesday that the online music provider had wilfully violated copyrights. He awarded Universal Music from $118m to $250m in damages.

"We believe it is clear from a reading of Judge Rakoff's decision that the MP3.com case is both factually and legally distinct from the Napster case," said Jonathan Schiller, a lawyer for Napster.

Clearance The proposed $34bn acquisition by Deutsche Telekom of VoiceStream Wireless cleared its first US regulatory hurdle, the companies said. The justice department let the waiting period expire under the Hart-Scott-Rodino antitrust law. Other regulators have still to approve the deal. VoiceStream shares rose $3 to $117 in the afternoon.

fields.headline: Trafficmaster on fast growth road
fields.trailText: Trafficmaster, the traffic information provider, yesterday predicted a tripling of revenue next year and said it was on course to becoming established in continental Europe.
fields.body:
Trafficmaster, the traffic information provider, yesterday predicted a tripling of revenue next year and said it was on course to becoming established in continental Europe.

The British company yesterday reported that first-half profits fell by a third because of the cost of rapid European expansion in Germany, Italy and France. Sales were down because of a move away from hardware sales.

The company said pre-tax profit was £1.5m for the half-year to June 30, down from £2.1m for the corresponding period last year. Operating costs, related to investment, increased by around £1.6m. Turnover fell from £7.3m to £5.6m. The City took fright and shares fell 18p to close at 717.5p.

David Martell, Trafficmaster's chief executive, said this year has been about setting up "building blocks" for growth.

Mr Martell founded the company in 1990 with £200,000 of his own cash after he became exasperated with the lack of information about traffic jams. The company produces dashboard devices which use roadside scanners to inform drivers of congestion.

The idea has been taken up across the continent. The company expects that Germany will generate revenue at the end of this year and France and Italy in the first quarter of next year.

"We are confident that we will treble our turnover next year, it shows the kind of growth that we are expecting," Mr Martell said.

Trafficmaster has raised £66m by finance expansion and said £20m would be left when the European investment programme is largely complete by the end of the year.

The company has a pilot scheme in Detroit but the focus for the next couple of years remains Europe, with Germany being particularly important, he said.

Analysts said Trafficmaster was likely to break even at the end of the year and the results were positive.

webTitle: Letters: More ifs and buts about the dome

fields.headline: More ifs and buts about the dome
fields.trailText: If anyone had said they could regenerate a whole area of hopeless, workless derelict land (Dome - a devastating verdict, September 7), removing and cleaning up a foot deep of polluted and poisoned topsoil; providing work and decent houses through the whole of north Greenwich and Charlton; building environmentally friendly supermarkets and decent roads, not to mention persuading someone to build a whole new tube line to give it identity and pride; to cap it all, building one of the most staggeringly beautiful and original buildings, the equivalent of the Eiffel Tower or the Sydney Harbour Bridge, and filling it with some of the best, most interesting engineering and invention Britain has to offer, which is the second most successful attraction in Europe after Disneyland, I would not have believed them.
fields.body:
If anyone had said they could regenerate a whole area of hopeless, workless derelict land (Dome - a devastating verdict, September 7), removing and cleaning up a foot deep of polluted and poisoned topsoil; providing work and decent houses through the whole of north Greenwich and Charlton; building environmentally friendly supermarkets and decent roads, not to mention persuading someone to build a whole new tube line to give it identity and pride; to cap it all, building one of the most staggeringly beautiful and original buildings, the equivalent of the Eiffel Tower or the Sydney Harbour Bridge, and filling it with some of the best, most interesting engineering and invention Britain has to offer, which is the second most successful attraction in Europe after Disneyland, I would not have believed them.

And if they said they could use this to lever another billion pounds of private money to build the millennium village and local industry... and that they could do all this for less than £500m of lottery money. Well, I would have told them they were talking sheer nonsense.
Dorian Kelly
Colchester, Essex illuminati@theatre.org

 Lest any developer thinks it can redevelop the site (Buyer poised for property killing, September 7) , let them be aware that it will need a further expensive clean up. When I researched the regeneration of the Greenwich peninsula two years ago, I was informed by Greenwich council that the decontamination process was only sufficient to meet planning requirements for the New Millennium Experience exhibition. The Department of Environment told parliament in April that the standard of clean-up of the contaminated land "would not necessarily be sufficient to allow houses with gardens to be built on the site".
Dr David Lowry
Stoneleigh, Surrey dlowryrmb@compuserve.com

 Long before David James arrived, the traffic snarl-up potential of the dome was well understood and Greenwich council granted planning permission only on condition than no more than 1% of visitors should come by car. A 1996 survey showed that no comparable event had less then 35% coming by car. The dome has attracted half a million visitors a month, of whom 98% arrive by public transport and 1% on foot or cycle. If car use could be kept to this proportion in London as a whole, think of the congestion costs that could be avoided.
Ian Yearsley
London

 Absence of car parks - that's why the dome never had a hope of attracting 12m visitors. People will go to a theme park because they can take the family en masse, carry the push chairs, stuff in raincoats and umbrellas and pack the picnic too.The blind, mindless incompetence of it all started with the very first plan.
Frank Page
Longtown, Herefordshire

 Catherine Bennett (G2, September 7) asks who should be blamed. I would start with the designers. The Crystal Palace is an icon in the history of architectural engineering design. The Sydney Opera House is the most recognisable image of Australia. The stunning Bilbao Guggenheim is attracting visitors from all over the world to northern Spain. These buildings engage our attention because they were products of innovative creative imagination. When I first saw images of the dome, I was reminded of a cow pat with grass stalks poking through it. It never had a chance of being important.
Derek Sellars
Sheffield
ddsellars@beeb.net

 As a midlander in southern exile, I can't resist a small gloat. An open competition was run to decide where the British millennium exhibition should be held. The best proposal was adjacent to a mainline railway station, an airport and an existing exhibition centre, with acres of parking places. But Birmingham International station and airport and the NEC are not in London. This was too much for a metropolitan elite which believes civilised life ends at Harrow and Wealdstone, and so a fiddle was produced to ensure the project was moved to London.
Alan Harrison
Brunel University
cbstath@brunel.ac.uk

 The dome is a magnificent building, in a magnificent setting: the problem is the trivia that went into it. To sell it off for a mere £100m is criminal. It is a national asset that could be used as an indoor, weatherproof cricket stadium and sports centre for athletics etc. Let us have a campaign to save it.
Tony Cheney
Ipswich

 Why can't ministers ever admit their cock-ups? They are largely responsible for the cynicism of the public. And what about the doctrine of ministerial responsibility? Was Lord Carrington the last honourable minister?
Grenville Wall
Vantaa, Finland
gren.wall@kolumbus.fi

 If, finally, the dome proves to be a financial and intellectual failure, is there any other Tory grand projet which will come to a similar end? The pseudo-commercialisation of education and medicine, for example, seems to have resulted in academic inflation in the one, and relegation to the bottom of the European league in the other.
Michael Hammet
Winchester

This was too much for a metropolitan elite which believes civilised life ends at Harrow and Wealdstone, and so a fiddle was produced to ensure the project was moved to London. Alan Harrison Brunel University cbstath@brunel.ac.uk  The dome is a magnificent building, in a magnificent setting: the problem is the trivia that went into it. To sell it off for a mere £100m is criminal. It is a national asset that could be used as an indoor, weatherproof cricket stadium and sports centre for athletics etc. Let us have a campaign to save it. Tony Cheney Ipswich  Why can't ministers ever admit their cock-ups? They are largely responsible for the cynicism of the public. And what about the doctrine of ministerial responsibility? Was Lord Carrington the last honourable minister? Grenville Wall Vantaa, Finland gren.wall@kolumbus.fi  If, finally, the dome proves to be a financial and intellectual failure, is there any other Tory grand projet which will come to a similar end? The pseudo-commercialisation of education and medicine, for example, seems to have resulted in academic inflation in the one, and relegation to the bottom of the European league in the other. Michael Hammet Winchester

fields.headline: The cruellest choice
fields.standfirst: A decision for parents, not for the state
fields.trailText: The case of the Siamese twins, Jodie and Mary, is a parent's worst nightmare. Jodie, according to evidence in the court hearings, is a "bright and alert baby, sparkling and sucking on her dummy"; her sister Mary's state is "pitiable" - she cannot even cry, because she has no lungs of her own. Mary depends on Jodie for her blood and oxygen. She is incapable of independent life but is slowly draining her conjoined sister, and unless they are separated, both will die within six months. The doctors in charge of the case want to save Jodie, which would mean killing Mary. The parents insist that God's will be done and that nature should be left to take its course. The only way to resolve the deadlock in this agonising dilemma has been to resort to the courts. Not surprisingly, the appeal court judges and the barristers admit to sleepless nights as they wrestle with the ethical and emotional implications.

Jodie, according to evidence in the court hearings, is a "bright and alert baby, sparkling and sucking on her dummy"; her sister Mary's state is "pitiable" - she cannot even cry, because she has no lungs of her own. Mary depends on Jodie for her blood and oxygen. She is incapable of independent life but is slowly draining her conjoined sister, and unless they are separated, both will die within six months. The doctors in charge of the case want to save Jodie, which would mean killing Mary. The parents insist that God's will be done and that nature should be left to take its course. The only way to resolve the deadlock in this agonising dilemma has been to resort to the courts. Not surprisingly, the appeal court judges and the barristers admit to sleepless nights as they wrestle with the ethical and emotional implications.

Part of that perhaps arises from the sense that the law is not the right arbiter in this extremely unusual and delicate situation. The parents and the official solicitor acting on Mary's behalf have appealed against the high court decision for the operation to go ahead and the lawyers are debating fine legal points along the murky boundary between what is an unlawful killing and what constitutes "withdrawal of treatment". But the crux of this case is not to be found in such legal issues, but in a broader consideration of what is in the best interests of all - both parents and children.

It seems common sense that the right thing to do is to save one life, rather than lose both. But it is also common sense that the parents' wishes lie at the heart of the case. The Manchester hospital where the children are being treated has been inundated by members of the public protesting at the parents being overruled in the high-court judgment. Of course, in some cases we understand that parents' rights can be superseded by the state's responsibility to protect children's rights; for example, the state can overrule a Jehovah's Witness parent's refusal to allow a healthy child to have a blood transfusion.

But this is not such a case. In addition to the anguish the parents feel at one of their daughters dying and their own moral objections to this as devout Catholics, the benefits for Jodie are not even clear. There are serious questions about the quality of Jodie's life after the operation; the parents are certain that the health service in their home country and their financial situation would prevent them from caring properly for her if she was seriously disabled. They would perhaps have to leave her behind for fostering in England. In such circumstances how can the court enforce the operation even if it is ethically the right thing to do? After all, it will be the parents who will be left to carry the can. No, given the age and vulnerability of both the twins, this case has to be regarded as a question of private morality, leaving the state no right to intervene.

webTitle: Dreaming spires ... ... may nowadays be dreaming of profits

fields.headline: Dreaming spires ... ... may nowadays be dreaming of profits
fields.trailText: One-2-One, the phone company, is paying to regild the 4.5 metre-high angel that has stood on top of Guildford cathedral for the past 40 years or so. This is not an act of piety. The angel will become a transmitter. From Woking to Basingstoke, "I'm on the train, Mum" and "Darling, I'll be 15 minutes late" will have a heavenly intermediary.
fields.body:
One-2-One, the phone company, is paying to regild the 4.5 metre-high angel that has stood on top of Guildford cathedral for the past 40 years or so. This is not an act of piety. The angel will become a transmitter. From Woking to Basingstoke, "I'm on the train, Mum" and "Darling, I'll be 15 minutes late" will have a heavenly intermediary.

God, we can rest assured, will not much mind, given all that He has gone through in past millennia - not to mention the years since His demise was announced (this year sees the centenary of the death of Friedrich Nietzsche). The Anglican church, too, having this week suffered indignity at the hands of Rome, has more to worry about than commercialisation. And seeing the money-grubbing that goes on in other, older cathedrals, visitors to Surrey's 20th-century brick barracks might well conclude this is a more tasteful way of accommodating Mammon. One-2-One's use of the Guildford angel will not be visible; theologians might even work up some trinitarian enthusiasm for the idea of streaming rays and golden reflections. You can bet, come Saturday lunch in the vicarage, it will inspire a few analogy-hungry sermons.

And to judge by the latest guidelines on siting transmission masts for mobile telephony, atop a church tower is probably as safe as it is going to get - never that many people around, given the way congregations are shrinking.

fields.headline: Hostages to fortune
fields.trailText: So the message from Freetown seems to be "education, education, education" (West Side Boys demand college places to end hostage crisis, September 7).
fields.body:
 So the message from Freetown seems to be "education, education, education" (West Side Boys demand college places to end hostage crisis, September 7).
Paul Harrington
London

 Is this how boys cope with girls outperforming them?
Paul Brazier
London

 Has the EU commissioner who is urging members of Opec to provide "a substantial increase in oil production" (Europe urges Opec to bring oil prices down, September 7) stopped to consider whether or not this will assist any country to meet its commitments under the Kyoto climate change abatement treaty? I thought not.
Andrew Warren
Association for the Conservation of Energy

 If an umpire can draw his little square to seek the help of technology in judging a call for "run out" (Phoenix rises in time for ashes, September 6), why can't he request such for when the batsman has decided to "pad up" without offering a stroke, to answer the question of whether the ball would have hit the wicket?
Peter Porteous
Chichester, W Sussex

 As one who likes champagne, it irks me to see the English cricket team emulating racing drivers - and showing the IQ of a cricketer's box - by squirting the lovely stuff over each other.
John Walker
Llwynhendy, Dyfed

 I have heard the most pathetic mobile phone conversation ("I'm on the train" etc) yet while queuing for the gents at the oval: "Hello, I'm having a piss at the moment..."
Neil Shepherd
Hemel Hempstead, Herts

 Eight words and a picture. Steve Bell (September 7) says it all. Such brilliance.
Cllr Gwyneth Cooper
Chester

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: • In a report headed Hague in trouble, page 5, July 24, we claimed that Daniel Hannan, Conservative MEP for South-East England, was using an office at Conservative Central Office (CCO) to raise money for the Danish "No" campaign. We further stated that he had sent an email appealing for money for the "No" campaign. We have been informed and accept that, while Mr Hannan has appealed for funds, he did not send this particular email, and that he does not use his office at CCO to raise money for the campaign but uses a PO box registered to his home address. We apologise for any misunderstanding.

webTitle: A way out for the west

fields.headline: A way out for the west
fields.standfirst: We need not be the prisoners of Opec
fields.trailText: A Labour government chucks money at a lame duck. Fawlty Towers is named as the greatest British television programme of all time. The world holds its breath as petrol prices soar ahead of a meeting of Opec ministers in Vienna. There has been more than a whiff of the 70s in the air this week. It would only take Jacques Chirac to murmur "Is there a crisis?" on his return to France from the Millennium summit in New York and we would have the full set.
fields.body:
A Labour government chucks money at a lame duck. Fawlty Towers is named as the greatest British television programme of all time. The world holds its breath as petrol prices soar ahead of a meeting of Opec ministers in Vienna. There has been more than a whiff of the 70s in the air this week. It would only take Jacques Chirac to murmur "Is there a crisis?" on his return to France from the Millennium summit in New York and we would have the full set.

The blockades of refineries and fuel depots in France show that oil has lost none of its ability to cause economic and political waves since Opec's heyday a quarter of a century ago. Saudi Arabia's announcement yesterday that it would increase oil production by 3% came after quite blatant arm-twisting by Washington, but is almost certainly too little too late. Oil prices dipped slightly after the news, but in the short term, the increase will do little to correct the imbalance between demand and supply. Analysts believe that the price of a barrel of crude could hit $40 over the next few months, particularly if the rich countries of the north experience a hard winter. The £4 gallon looms.

According to devotees of the new weightless economy, none of this is much to worry about because the technological revolution of the past decade has made the global economy much less vulnerable to oil shocks than they were in the past. But governments in the west are right to be worried. Rising oil prices have meant big trouble three times in the past 30 years - in 1973, 1979 and 1990 - and they could very well spell trouble this time too. Since the start of 1999, global oil prices have increased almost fourfold, and are now starting to have an impact on economic activity. In the US, the higher cost of fuel is reining in the boom; in Europe it has pushed inflation above 2% and prompted the European Central Bank to raise interest rates. Japan, only just emerging from a 10-year recession, is especially vulnerable to higher energy costs. It would indeed be ironic if it was the symbol of the old economy that finally put paid to the overblown claims of the disciples of the new paradigm.

Governments are also right to expect a backlash from both producers and consumers as business costs rise and living standards are squeezed. One reason the Clinton administration has been calling in favours with Saudi Arabia is the fear that dearer energy will cost Al Gore votes in November's election. In France, the Jospin administration has already felt the effects of the direct action by road hauliers which - in complete contrast to Britain's feeble "dump the pump" campaign - has paralysed large parts of the country and forced Paris to offer them concessions.

In the end, however, this is not a rerun of the 70s and eventually prices will come down. As Sheikh Yamani - another blast from the past - warned Opec earlier this week, the recent surge in prices is probably the oil cartel's last hurrah. Why? Because higher prices will lead not only to the discovery and exploitation of new fields, but also the search for alternative energy sources. "The stone age came to an end not for a lack of stones and the oil age will end, but not for a lack of oil," he said.

Western governments could and should be doing more to hasten this process. To the extent that they have been levying ever-higher taxes on oil but refusing to recycle the proceeds into real investment in wave and solar power, they really have only themselves to blame if the voters turn nasty.

webTitle: Mo, Mo, we miss you so

fields.headline: Mo, Mo, we miss you so
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: My god, I thought it would be so different. All so very different. Who will ever forget the sheer, joyous, fan-bloody-tastic feeling of mind-blowing exhilaration we all felt on that bright, confident dawn of May 2 1997, after New Labour had swept to power?
fields.body:
My god, I thought it would be so different. All so very different. Who will ever forget the sheer, joyous, fan-bloody-tastic feeling of mind-blowing exhilaration we all felt on that bright, confident dawn of May 2 1997, after New Labour had swept to power?

This is what I wrote at the time, as part of a text that is still studied in media courses around the land: "After 18 long, hard years, the forces of good have triumphed, sleaze has been vanquished and this poor benighted country has been instantly transformed.

"Under Tony Blair, no child need ever look plaintively up at a tree, unable to reach for that rosy apple.

"Under Tony Blair, no senior citizen at a supermarket till need ever fumble for loose change in an old coat.

"Under Tony Blair, no discontented youth need ever again perform an armed robbery on a sub-post office in order to be able to afford a brand new motor-scooter.

"Under Tony Blair, there will be no greenhouse effect, no BSE, no negative equity, no traffic snarl-ups on the M25, no deaths from drunk-driving, no feuds in Northern Ireland, no toxic waste, no increased bank charges and no inner-city kiddies under- performing in their GCSEs.

"Under Tony Blair, Britain will be transformed into a land of hope and plenty, a land from which we will all be filled with a new glow of confidence to march into a golden future. Hail Tony! Hail New Labour! And welcome, my friends: welcome to tomorrow!"

Reading this text today, over three years on, I have every reason to feel disenchanted. I had slogged my guts out for a New Labour victory, often talking until the early hours in other people's houses of the great benefits Tony Blair would bring not just the ordinary, decent people of this country, but those of us involved in the London media, too.

An end to parking restrictions on the north side of Upper Street. A revitalised ICA, with free access to early Tarkovsky movies to all people, regardless of race or creed, on the presentation of a birth certificate. An open invitation to dinner with Chris Smith for ongoing dialogue to encourage increased state funding for the arts. And - just as importantly - an end to disease, prejudice and poverty not only in the capital but in every city in Britain.

And now what? Or - to put it another way, a way that conveys just a small part of my anger - and NOW BLOODY WHAT?

For too long, I suffered in silence. When the Millennium Dome was built, I applauded it as a "soaraway success story - a fitting emblem for a new kind of Britain: efficient, forward-looking, popular and, above all, supercool". Why, I even found signs for optimism when hospital waiting lists grew longer. "It all goes to show," I wrote, "that never before has the NHS been so popular, so vibrant, and, perhaps above all, so supercool."

But I can hold my tongue no longer. No longer can I hold my tongue. It is my tongue that can no longer be held by me.

Mo Mowlam has announced her departure. She no longer feels like working with Blair, Put simply - and I write this with tears in my eyes - Mo is to go.

I have known and loved Mo for more than a quarter of a century now, ever since we both sat around on beanbags setting the world to rights, smoking what we probably shouldn't have been smoking and all to the radical, thought-provoking, but above all caring, sound of Justin Hayward and the Moody Blues. I suppose it was when I first witnessed her performing a miracle - she fed a gathering of up to 5,000 on no more than a handful of loaves and fishes - that I first realised Mo was someone rather special.

OK, the joint was pretty strong, and when I came down from it I realised there were in fact just five individuals in the room, each with his or her own portion of smoked kipper pté on ready-sliced granary loaf, but the point still holds: Mo is a lovely, lovely centre-left/left-of-centre person and fascist Tony and the rest of his spiteful, hardhearted control-freak cronies can ill afford to lose her from this administration or any other.

It could have all been so different, so very, very different. If Mo had been given the free rein she deserved, there would have been an end to all rows in government. Instead, the cabinet would have gathered not around a starchy table, but on the floor, with their shoes cast off any-old-how. The cabinet secretary would have placed some Marvin Gaye on the sound-system and they'd have come up with some really, really exciting ideas about the world and how to stop bad things happening and start good things happening, and it would have all had a really happy ending.

But now Mo's gone and it's never to be. And, believe me, I'm hurting.

And - just as importantly - an end to disease, prejudice and poverty not only in the capital but in every city in Britain. And now what? Or - to put it another way, a way that conveys just a small part of my anger - and NOW BLOODY WHAT? For too long, I suffered in silence. When the Millennium Dome was built, I applauded it as a "soaraway success story - a fitting emblem for a new kind of Britain: efficient, forward-looking, popular and, above all, supercool". Why, I even found signs for optimism when hospital waiting lists grew longer. "It all goes to show," I wrote, "that never before has the NHS been so popular, so vibrant, and, perhaps above all, so supercool." But I can hold my tongue no longer. No longer can I hold my tongue. It is my tongue that can no longer be held by me. Mo Mowlam has announced her departure. She no longer feels like working with Blair, Put simply - and I write this with tears in my eyes - Mo is to go. I have known and loved Mo for more than a quarter of a century now, ever since we both sat around on beanbags setting the world to rights, smoking what we probably shouldn't have been smoking and all to the radical, thought-provoking, but above all caring, sound of Justin Hayward and the Moody Blues. I suppose it was when I first witnessed her performing a miracle - she fed a gathering of up to 5,000 on no more than a handful of loaves and fishes - that I first realised Mo was someone rather special. OK, the joint was pretty strong, and when I came down from it I realised there were in fact just five individuals in the room, each with his or her own portion of smoked kipper pté on ready-sliced granary loaf, but the point still holds: Mo is a lovely, lovely centre-left/left-of-centre person and fascist Tony and the rest of his spiteful, hardhearted control-freak cronies can ill afford to lose her from this administration or any other. It could have all been so different, so very, very different. If Mo had been given the free rein she deserved, there would have been an end to all rows in government. Instead, the cabinet would have gathered not around a starchy table, but on the floor, with their shoes cast off any-old-how. The cabinet secretary would have placed some Marvin Gaye on the sound-system and they'd have come up with some really, really exciting ideas about the world and how to stop bad things happening and start good things happening, and it would have all had a really happy ending. But now Mo's gone and it's never to be. And, believe me, I'm hurting.

fields.headline: Family rendezvous
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Borrowdale
fields.body:
Borrowdale

The charm of the Lakes brings us back for a family rendezvous in the last week of August most years. And this year we were in Upper Borrowdale, firstly at Rosthwaite and latterly at Seatoller. The early part of the week, still blessed with sunshine, saw happy tribes of grandchildren from Oxford and Glasgow splashing in the beck, building dams, and renewing friendships with their cousins. There were serious walks too.

Haystacks was conquered on Sunday morning by a company including young Toby who could be pleased, at 8, to match the climbing requirement. Meanwhile, I had escorted two of the pre-teen cousins on the semi-serious walk from Seatoller to Grange which starts with a climb over the first shoulder of land. Chattering non-stop, they covered the ground with ease.

Borrowdale was delightful in late season sunshine - a twittering voluble company of house martins and some swallows filled the air around the eaves of the old stone farmhouse up the lane as they did around several other farm properties we passed. I had not seen house martins in such numbers since a Cornish seaside break in their nesting season at Portscatho.

The other species Borrowdale has in great numbers is the Herdwick sheep and, since Herdwicks were the last breed we had in our fun farming decade, albeit on the lusher pastures of Gloucestershire. It is always interesting to look at the local flocks of the dale - enjoying late summer grass and benign conditions. Single lambs are the norm here, but on southern pastures and generously fed through the winter with hay and rations, our Herdwicks usually produced twins from their first year.

The weather broke on Thursday, fortunately after the departure of most of the young family, and continuous rain foiled a planned golf rendezvous at Windermere where a fellow member of my home club and I had planned a match. The rain transformed the Haas Ghyll which tumbles down the hill at the other end of the terrace - a crashing, foaming, torrent was the scene by evening, as water flowed off the hill and down the road from the Honister Pass.

webTitle: Letters: Promoting business in the global economy

fields.headline: Promoting business in the global economy
fields.trailText: Either George Monbiot wrote his article on Conservative policy towards Nafta (Vote Tory for a federal superstate, September 7) before bothering to find out what our policy was, or he believes some very strange consequences indeed flow from free trade.
fields.body:
Either George Monbiot wrote his article on Conservative policy towards Nafta (Vote Tory for a federal superstate, September 7) before bothering to find out what our policy was, or he believes some very strange consequences indeed flow from free trade. Our policy is to support a free trade agreement between the EU and Nafta, to extend the free-trade zone across the Atlantic, as a prelude to global free trade by 2020. This was set out in our European election manifesto last year and it is the policy contained in our document Believing in Britain, published this week.

Such an arrangement would benefit not just Britain but the EU as a whole - and, indeed, it would also benefit the members of Nafta. Trade is the greatest engine of prosperity and progress there has ever been. A modern, outward-looking European Union would be embracing such policies with open arms.

Conservatives believe that Britain does not have to choose between Europe and America. Britain is part of several overlapping and interlocking networks. Our membership of the EU and our transatlantic relationship are both vital to our interests and influence in the world.
Francis Maude MP
Shadow foreign secretary

 In contesting my article about the United Nation's relationship with big business, John Ruggie (Letters, September 4) insists that "never has any president of the general assembly _ announced that businesses would be given a formal role in UN decision-making. The idea is preposterous."

Well, it's certainly preposterous. But David Korten, a highly respected academic, was an observer at a meeting hosted by ambassador Razali Ismail, president of the general assembly, on June 24 1997. The president, he reported, announced "that a framework for the involvement of the corporate sector in UN decision-making would be worked out under the auspices of the commission on sustainable development".

Soon afterwards, a leaked memo from Unctad (UN Conference on Trade and Development) revealed that such preposterous ideas were already being implemented: "There is close cooperation with the ICC [International Chamber of Commerce] in helping countries to formulate competition and consumer protection law and policy."

Mr Ruggie claims that the UN secretary-general "did not launch the business humanitarian forum". But Mr Annan wrote the speech with which the forum's first meeting began. Mr Ruggie insists that the forum is not co-chaired by the UN high commissioner for refugees. Indeed it isn't but, as I suggested, it was last year. He also insists "no logo was developed" for the UN Development Programme's pact with business. But a leaked document revealed the agency was envisaging "a specially designed logo" . Like the rest of scheme, it was dropped as a result of an outcry from activists all over the world.
George Monbiot
Oxford

webTitle: Letters: No vote for homes' transfer

fields.headline: No vote for homes' transfer
fields.trailText: Wendy Alexander MSP has not "thrown ideology to the wind", but converted to the "state is bad" ideology that both she and Tommy Sheridan used to fight so hard against (Out of stock, Society, September 6).
fields.body:
Wendy Alexander MSP has not "thrown ideology to the wind", but converted to the "state is bad" ideology that both she and Tommy Sheridan used to fight so hard against (Out of stock, Society, September 6). What we council tenants want is repairs to our homes, affordable rents and security of tenure. Council tenants are being blackmailed: vote to stay with the council and shiver in your crumbling flats, or vote for a new landlord and have essential repairs done.

Housing associations can borrow on the security of their houses, like any homeowner. Councils cannot. In every other EU country, a council can borrow against its assets for capital expenditure. Ironically, if Gordon Brown joins the euro he will have to fall in line on this. The Scottish executive has promised to take on Glasgow's debt of £1.2bn only if tenants vote for a new landlord. Where I live in Edinburgh, yards from parliament, they have promised £4.3m if we do likewise. Why has Labour decided to abolish council housing? Those politicians who rely on council tenants' votes had better watch out come the next election.
Neil Wilkinson
Holyrood and Lochview Residents Association neilwilkinson@hotmail.com

 The policy of transferring social housing out of local authority control has never been debated by the Labour party. How can council tenants be expected to believe that democratic control will be retained following such transfers?
Michael Ball
London

webTitle: Relatives weep over the horror of Omagh

fields.headline: Relatives weep over the horror of Omagh
fields.standfirst:
Videos of bomb carnage shown to victims' families at inquest
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Relatives of the 29 people killed in the Omagh atrocity broke down and wept yesterday as they watched for the first time horrifying amateur videos shot immediately after the Real IRA car bomb blast. The footage included sickening images of the dead and dying.
fields.body:
Relatives of the 29 people killed in the Omagh atrocity broke down and wept yesterday as they watched for the first time horrifying amateur videos shot immediately after the Real IRA car bomb blast. The footage included sickening images of the dead and dying.

Several families left the inquest to watch the three videos, lasting about 10 minutes, in a side room. Their wailing could be heard outside, and they said afterwards that the sounds of screaming on the footage were as upsetting as the gruesome pictures.

Greater Belfast coroner John Leckey is presiding over the inquest into the deaths of 29 people, killed when a 500lb car bomb went off in the Co Tyrone town on August 15, 1998. It is expected to last four weeks, and yesterday was the second day of the hearing.

Only a short clip of the first video to be shown yesterday has been screened on television news. None of the rest of the footage has been shown.

Michael Gallagher, whose son Aidan, 21, died in the explosion, said: "I thought at first how could someone stand there and video a scene like that. Now I am glad they did. The opportunity should be given so everyone can see it, so that they can see the true horror of Omagh."

Mario Radford, whose son Alan, 16, was also killed, said: "When I saw the videos. I could not believe one human being could contemplate such destruction on another. It makes me angry these people are walking the streets. I have never felt anger or bitterness, but I do want justice.

"It was my solicitor who pointed Alan's body out to me. I was very near him. I don't know how I couldn't find him. I would probably have ended up in a mental hospital if I had."

The first film to be shown depicted an injured girl, aged about 13, wandering in a daze close to the bomb scene. She was crying: "Where's mummy? Where's mummy?"

The background sound of screaming was constant, and a badly injured woman, her face bloody, staggered about in shock. Her hands were raised and she constantly cried: "Oh my God. Oh my God."

As several people crouched over one victim, a man desperately instructed them on first aid. He said: "Keep the pressure on it. Hold pressure on it. Hard. Keep pressure on it."

One of the dead or injured was shown being carried away in a tattered red tarpaulin. A little girl was being helped to an ambulance.

The second video had a commentary from the man filming it. He had an Australian accent. He said: "You just would not believe this. You just would not believe what has fucking happened. The centre of the town had been wrecked by a fucking bomb two minutes again, less than that. You would not fucking believe it. So much for the fucking peace process."

His video was filled with the sound of crunching glass underfoot. At one point a woman shouted: "Somebody help me. Somebody help me."

Mr Leckey said the video was important because it showed that a water mains had been ruptured. That hampered the rescue, because victims and body parts moved under the force of the water.

In the third video there was a glimpse of the remains of a body, looking like a slab of raw meat. There was also a severed leg, partly covered in a bin-liner. In both cases, the operator quickly averted his camera.

One woman was lying on the ground alongside another, comforting her. The victim was motionless.

The camera swept along a bus used to ferry the injured to hospital. They had a catalogue of bloody injuries, and were in shock. One girl, her back terribly ripped, was supported by two friends. She lolled as if unconscious.

One man said: "Look for bodies. Keep your eyes going." Another muttered: "They were only doing their shopping." A third said: "Terrible. Terrible."

Patsy McElhatton, 59, a member of the Fintona cycling club, shot one of the videos, believed to be the third. He had his camera with him because of a club event.

Mr McElhatton said outside the inquest: "I was down at the scene less than four minutes after it went off. I knew a lot of people there, and, as I was filming, I was wondering why am I doing this? But I thought at least this will be shown around the world, and people will know what a bomb can do."

He had handed the video to police, after considering getting rid of it.

Mr McElhatton said: "The full horror of it all only hit me seven weeks ago. I won't walk down that street anymore. I wish I was never there, to tell you the truth."

The Police Federation in Northern Ireland announced it was appointing counsel to represent all of its members appearing at the inquiry. The move follows tough questioning of police witnesses over their reactions to the three confused bomb warnings, and has divided the families.

Michael Mansfield QC, appearing for Lawrence Rush, widower of Libby, 57, and Barry Fox, an Omagh solicitor representing the families of victims Esther Gibson, 36, and Avril Monaghan, 30, and her daughter Maura, 18 months, have led the probing. They are focusing on police procedures.

Ken Duncan, a solicitor for the family of Deborah Anne Cartwright, 20, who also died, objected. He wanted the questioning halted until the officers' legal teams arrived, and, after debate, the video evidence was taken.

Mr Leckey will rule this morning on whether he will subpoena Francie Mackey, the Omagh-based chairman of the 32-County Sovereignty Movement. It is believed to be linked to the Real IRA.

fields.headline: It wasn't me
fields.trailText: You repeat the allegation that I was the "Downing Street poisoner" responsible for a "whispering campaign" against Dr Mo Mowlam (Mowlam quits, September 5).
fields.body:
You repeat the allegation that I was the "Downing Street poisoner" responsible for a "whispering campaign" against Dr Mo Mowlam (Mowlam quits, September 5).

I believe that this allegation derives from a newspaper article by Ms Julia Langdon and is, I understand, also contained in her forthcoming book. You should be aware that this allegation is entirely untrue. I have been advised that it is also defamatory. Further, Dr Mowlam herself has publicly stated that she does not believe that I am responsible for a "whispering campaign". My lawyers are in contact with Ms Langdon and her publishers, Little Brown & Co UK, to ensure that all untrue and defamatory allegations are removed.
Jonathan Powell
Prime minister's chief of staff

webTitle: Foreign aid staff flee West Timor

fields.headline: Foreign aid staff flee West Timor
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: The United Nations yesterday evacuated virtually all foreign employees of international organisations and many local staff from Indonesian West Timor, a day after three UN workers were murdered by pro-Jakarta militiamen.
fields.body:
The United Nations yesterday evacuated virtually all foreign employees of international organisations and many local staff from Indonesian West Timor, a day after three UN workers were murdered by pro-Jakarta militiamen.

The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, who is in New York for the millennium summit, blamed his political opponents for orchestrating the crisis to embarrass him. The Indonesian military, which did little to intervene during Wednesday's attack in the town of Atambua, tried to play down the incident, saying it was "a local brawl that got out of hand".

Four battalions of Indonesian army reinforcements prepared to head to West Timor in a bid to restore order yesterday, as the UN flew its workers and staff of international non-governmental organisations to safety in Bali.

"We left Kupang [the regional capital] for the airport in a convoy of 101 people at 5.30am," said Andrew Harper, programme coordinator for the UN high commissioner for refugees in West Timor. "We had a military and police escort and there were police at all the major intersections."

These precautions were deemed necessary following widespread rumours that the militia were heading for Kupang from Atambua. Residents of the town were visibly worried yesterday. A woman said many people were packing up and preparing to head to the hills, or out of Timor, if the situation deteriorated.

Another 69 people, mostly local staff of international organisations, crossed from Atambua into East Timor with the bodies of the three murdered UNHCR staff, said Mr Harper. "There will be another flight tomorrow from Kupang for the remaining 50 national and two international staff still there," he added.

In Jakarta, the Indonesian security minister, Susilio Bambang Yudhoyono, said 15 people had been arrested in connection with the attack on the UNHCR office and the ensuing riot. Another person had been arrested for the murder of a militia leader the previous evening that allegedly sparked Wednesday's rampage.

The Indonesian military, elements of which are widely accused of actively supporting the militias in West Timor, seemed less concerned by their failure to protect the UN staff. "What happened was just a local brawl that got out of hand," a senior spokesman, Air Marshal Graito Usodo, told a press conference.

President Wahid did not share these sentiments. Speaking on the sidelines of the millennium summit in New York, he said the Atambua incident was the latest episode in a protracted campaign to topple him. "This happened when I am here in New York, at the UN, to embarrass me."

Mr Harper disagreed. He blamed the government for not disarming the militia and separating them from the approximately 130,000 refugees from East Timor who are still camping in squalid conditions, one year after the militia forced them out of their home land after East Timor's overwhelming independence vote.

"The authorities do not have control in many areas," he said. "What happened [on Wednesday] demonstrates clearly that they cannot guarantee our security, even though they promised to last October." Then the Indonesian government signed a memorandum of understanding with the UN, promising to provide sufficient security for humanitarian workers and to ensure that the refugees had safe access to them.

In the last year the militia, a mixture of pro-Jakarta East Timorese paramilitaries, West Timorese thugs and members of the Indonesian military, have attacked and intimidated almost half the refugees into staying in West Timor. In the last few weeks they have focused mainly on intimidating the UNHCR staff, who are responsible for organising the repatriation to East Timor.

The Indonesian military, elements of which are widely accused of actively supporting the militias in West Timor, seemed less concerned by their failure to protect the UN staff. "What happened was just a local brawl that got out of hand," a senior spokesman, Air Marshal Graito Usodo, told a press conference. President Wahid did not share these sentiments. Speaking on the sidelines of the millennium summit in New York, he said the Atambua incident was the latest episode in a protracted campaign to topple him. "This happened when I am here in New York, at the UN, to embarrass me." Mr Harper disagreed. He blamed the government for not disarming the militia and separating them from the approximately 130,000 refugees from East Timor who are still camping in squalid conditions, one year after the militia forced them out of their home land after East Timor's overwhelming independence vote. "The authorities do not have control in many areas," he said. "What happened [on Wednesday] demonstrates clearly that they cannot guarantee our security, even though they promised to last October." Then the Indonesian government signed a memorandum of understanding with the UN, promising to provide sufficient security for humanitarian workers and to ensure that the refugees had safe access to them. In the last year the militia, a mixture of pro-Jakarta East Timorese paramilitaries, West Timorese thugs and members of the Indonesian military, have attacked and intimidated almost half the refugees into staying in West Timor. In the last few weeks they have focused mainly on intimidating the UNHCR staff, who are responsible for organising the repatriation to East Timor.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 This is one for the conspiracy theory of genius. Yesterday one of Sierra Leone's New Shaft newspaper's four pages (civil war has shrunk the cutely named tabloid) was taken by an advert. Diana's Death Revisited read the headline, "Diana's death was wrapped in controversy ever since." It goes on: "The royal family didn't want any more embarrassment. Is that why she died in a Paris subway, along with her boyfriend? The Faiad's [sic] of England want to know! She was their daughter-in-law." Underneath this is a reprint of the Daily Mail front page of September 4 1992, revealing Diana's affair with James Gilbey. Alexander Hitchen, Mr Al Fayed's spokesman, denies any involvement, and since the Egyptian must be able to spell his name you have to believe him. A call to the New Shaft unearths the fact that the advert was paid for, but we are advised to contact editor Franklyn Bunting Davies. Clark Kent of the Daily Planet, Woodward and Bernstein of the Washing Post, Franklyn Bunting Davies of the New Shaft... yes, it has that legendary ring. We cannot get through, however, so the questions remain: who would want to place such an ad, and why?

 You won't believe this - I know I don't - but a speed camera has recorded another Diary offence in a borrowed car... and just as with BMW before them, Rolls-Royce are grassing us up to the Bill. In east Leeds two weeks ago, the Corniche RR1 was filmed at 54mph in a 40mph zone. Another three points and £40, then... but for who? No one's talking - no one can be compelled to incriminate themselves under the soon to be in force Human Rights Act - but a feeling in my water says it may have been Gerald Kaufman.

 At the Sun, David Yelland is confused again. The alopecian editor, who dispensed with his wig after it became trapped in the doors of a New York subway train, is baffled by the dome. Originally he was violently against, but when BSkyB lobbed £12m into the sponsorship pot a religious revelation persuaded him it would be the next wonder of the world. Now, however, in a long editorial rant headlined This Wretched Mess, he thunders: "It will stand in the public's memory as a monument to the vanity of big-headed and pig-headed politicians." Yes, and to the wretched crawling to their proprietor's other media interest of bald-headed editors. Now do buck up, man, and for God's sake get a grip.

 Another editor comes to our attention. At the Royal Albert Hall on Wednesday, the Independent on Sunday's Janet Street-Porter met someone from the Observer and related how she once clocked an offending hack with her handbag. She then realised what brought this to mind: the Observer man, she decided, looked a bit like me. I am tempted to chant "Come and have a go if you think you're hard enough"; but on reflection the old girl is plenty hard enough, so I think we'll let it lie.

 "Someone's got to ask," writes Express columnist Kathryn Knight. "Were the Beatles that great?" Yes, Kathryn, they were. That's why, 30 years after the split, your paper gave two pages yesterday to a new book. "Their music's not bad," (you're very kind), "but weren't they just a bunch of lads with mop tops strumming guitars." No, they weren't. Nervous columnists traditionally crave that comforting blanket of journalism, the bulging postbag, but there are idiocies about sex, drugs, race etc, to get readers going without resorting to rot about the Beatles.

 In Ankara, police are hunting a mugger who may be auditioning for a Turkish remake of Batman. In recent months, the Tickler has cornered 300 victims in alleyways and tickled them until they coughed up. "It's no laughing matter," an Ankara police spokesman told us yesterday. Or might have done if we'd had the energy to call.

webTitle: Clinton fails to find Jerusalem compromise

fields.headline: Clinton fails to find Jerusalem compromise
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The chances of the US president, Bill Clinton, securing a Middle East peace settlement receded yesterday after the White House admitted he had failed to make any progress in talks at the UN millennium summit.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill  in New York and  Suzanne Goldenberg  in Jerusalem
fields.body:
The chances of the US president, Bill Clinton, securing a Middle East peace settlement receded yesterday after the White House admitted he had failed to make any progress in talks at the UN millennium summit.

Mr Clinton held separate discussions with the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian president, Yasser Arafat, on the fringes of the summit. The White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said he could report no progress on the contentious issue of control of Jerusalem and that no further meetings were planned.

Time is running out for Mr Clinton, with the US presidential election only two months away and Mr Barak's coalition government facing collapse next month.

More pressing, Mr Arafat and his colleagues will meet this weekend to decide whether unilaterally to declare Palestinian independence on September 13, as they had threatened unless a deal was in place. The Palestinian delegation said the declaration could be delayed.

Mr Clinton had been desperate to secure a Middle East settlement as the main legacy of his presidency.

He met Mr Barak and Mr Arafat on the upper floor of the Waldorf-Astoria hotel in an attempt to see if there was a compromise that would complete the deal almost secured in July at Camp David. But White House officials said the positions had slipped back since then.

Mr Arafat, in his speech to the millennium summit, took an uncompromising stance, declaring that Palestine should have sovereignty over Arab east Jerusalem, ditching the possibility of a compromise that might have seen the city share sovereignty or come under international control.

Mr Arafat told the summit that the Palestinians had already made painful sacrifices for peace.

An Israeli official said nothing could happen in the peace negotiations until Mr Arafat demonstrated he was ready to discuss ideas offered at or since Camp David.

The public mood in Israel swung from anticipation to gloom yesterday after President Clinton failed to break the deadlock.

The acting foreign minister, Shlomo Ben Ami, warned against over-optimism at the prospects of reaching a peace agreement while Mr Clinton remains in power.

The mood darkened perceptibly as Israeli negotiators said there was no further room for manoeuvre with the Palestinians." We cannot be more flexible in our stances regarding Jerusalem," Gilead Sher, a negotiator, told Israel's army radio.

Although the focus of negotiations since the collapse of the Camp David summit in July has been the status of Jerusalem, Mr Ben Ami emphasised that there were wide gaps between the two sides on refugees, as well as on less contentious issues like borders and settlements. "We should not make the mistake of thinking that some symbolic compromise that Arafat agrees to on the Temple Mount solves the rest of the problems," he said.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Bringing Up Baby | The Outlaw Josey Wales | Gattaca | Simon Of The Desert
fields.body:
Bringing Up Baby
(Howard Hawks, 1938)
7pm, Carlton Cinema

Classic screwball comedy, the first such venture for stars Katharine Hepburn and Cary Grant. He's an absentminded professor whose plans for a life of quiet study and sensible marriage are wrecked by her barmy heiress. And Baby, of course, is a leopard. Still breathlessly funny after all these years.

The Outlaw Josey Wales
(Clint Eastwood, 1976)
10pm, Sky Cinema

Eastwood directs and stars as Josey Wales, who, scarred by the brutal killing of wife and child in the civil war, goes looking for revenge. Along the way he attracts a surrogate family of stragglers, notably Chief Dan George as a not-so-wise old Cheyenne, gradually and comically undercutting the icy Man With No Name persona. Josey wreaks his vengeance and learns forgiveness, while director Eastwood is equally adept at violent action and stunning landscape.

Gattaca
(Andrew Niccol, 1997)
11.45pm, Sky Premier

An unusually intelligent sci-fi thriller set in a genetically correct futureworld where people are rated at birth as Valid or In-Valid. Ethan Hawke is one of the latter, bucking the system with the aid of Jude Law's crippled, bitter Valid, who sells him his blood, hair and urine in order to enter the Gattaca corporation, which will open his way to the stars. Uma Thurman is another citizen with a secret. Beautifully produced, but curiously muted emotionally, dramatically and in its autumnal hues.

Simon Of The Desert
(Luis Buñuel, 1965)
4.45am, FilmFour

Bible-bashing Buñuel has Simon Stylites (Claudio Brook) perched on a pillar in the desert, exposed to all manner of temptations by the devilish Silvia Piñal. Meanwhile the villagers, at first so proud of their saint, grow irritated... An iconoclastic masterclass in a mere 50 minutes.
