fields.headline: Harvey Hinds
fields.standfirst: Eminence grise of the Greater London Council, influencing the capital's politics to benefit young people in particular
fields.trailText: Harvey Hinds, who has died aged 80, was a clergyman, youth worker, educationist and leading Labour local government politician. His superb organisational and people skills - frequently exercised behind the scenes - came to the fore during the years 1967-83 when he was chief whip of the often volatile Labour group on the Greater London Council.
fields.body:
Harvey Hinds, who has died aged 80, was a clergyman, youth worker, educationist and leading Labour local government politician. His superb organisational and people skills - frequently exercised behind the scenes - came to the fore during the years 1967-83 when he was chief whip of the often volatile Labour group on the Greater London Council.

When the long-time Labour leader Sir Reg Goodwin resigned in 1980, Hinds recognised that the next administration would need to respond to the massive social shift which had taken place in London during the 1970s upheaval: he desperately wanted a change from the old-style Labour leaders who paid more attention to officers than to their elected colleagues.

Following the 1981 election, with a majority of just nine, the Labour Group was split - left 22, right 18 and centre 10. Wanting a leader who would give a clear lead and implement change, he saw the best hope in Ken Livingstone and a new generation of talented young politicians, rather than a continuation of the old guard.

With Illtyd Harrington, as deputy leader, Hinds used his influence to lead the vital centre block of votes into the Livingstone camp to create an administration which was to change the face of politics in London.

But with numbers so tight, there was always the risk of the right voting with the Tories on occasions. Gradually, the tensions within the Labour group began to subside and, as Ken Livingstone was the first to recognise, this was largely due to Hinds' work as chief whip in managing to defuse the complaints of the often outraged right about the latest left-wing proposal.

Politics came into his life relatively late. Born into a Worcester fruit-growing family, he blossomed as a scholarship boy at King's School, Worcester, where his wide-ranging interests included singing in the cathedral, and he became head of his house. An exhibitioner at St Edmund Hall, Oxford, he read French and German before changing to philosophy, politics and economics.

The priesthood was always anticipated, and graduation was followed by two years at Westcott House theological college, Cambridge. But thoughts of a comfortable rural parish were cast aside following a chance invitation to visit the Charterhouse Public School Mission in the backstreets of Bermondsey, South London. The conditions in the area and the lack of opportunities for its youngsters opened his eyes.

From 1944-58 he was assistant missioner at Charterhouse, and then warden of the Wellington College Mission in East Lane, Walworth. These were pastoral roles with an emphasis on running youth clubs and taking children out to the greener suburbs to practise sport, and to camp in the grounds of Charterhouse and Wellington schools, and to the Isle of Wight - often their first glimpse of real countryside and the sea.

In 1958, Hinds moved round the corner as rector of St Peter's, Walworth. There he immersed himself in the local community, opening up the crypt as a social centre for local families. His insistence that local children should have local facilities led to the creation of the massive Burgess Park in Walworth, which he was asked to open in 1982.

Hinds' expertise in youth and educational issues led to membership of the team responsible for the Newsom Report - Half our Future - of 1963, on educational provision for 13 to 16-year-olds. Finding a natural home in the Labour party, Hinds's political life began with election to Southwark Council in 1960 and to the Greater London Council in 1967. It ended with the abolition of the GLC in 1986. He was chairman of Southwark's children's committee and of the London youth committee.

He was vice-chairman (1967-70) and then chairman (1970-77) of the schools committee of the Inner London Education Authority, a key player in the controversial reorganisation of secondary schools along comprehensive lines and in the devolution of some local budgetary control to schools, years ahead of the Thatcher government's proposals.

Though Hinds became an honorary canon of Southwark Cathedral in 1969, his political activities and achievements had confirmed his frustration with the church's inability and lack of desire to change social conditions, so he left it in 1972 to become chief executive of the London Union of Youth Clubs, which supported leaders in over 700 clubs.

The wide-ranging umbrella of the GLC also allowed Hinds to pursue other interests. It brought membership of the South Bank Theatre board (overseeing the birth of the National Theatre), the board of London Festival Ballet and the Port of London Authority. Hinds' year as ceremonial chairman of the GLC, 1983-84, saw the staid reception rooms and the wonderful riverside terrace of County Hall opened up to all Londoners, rather than just the "great and the good".

Abolition of the GLC in 1986 allowed a total life change and retirement to the Hertfordshire village of Tewin, where Hinds was a familiar figure with William, his beloved Airedale dog. There, he created a magnificent cottage garden.

Married twice, he is survived by his second wife Lin, and by Anna and Jeremy from his first marriage.

fields.headline: Prince's tribute to Lawrence parents
fields.standfirst: Special report: Stephen Lawrence
fields.trailText: Stephen Lawrence's mother yesterday warned that it could take more than one generation to implement the changes stemming from the inquiry into her son's racist murder.
fields.body:
Stephen Lawrence's mother yesterday warned that it could take more than one generation to implement the changes stemming from the inquiry into her son's racist murder.

Doreen Lawrence spoke at the inaugural Stephen Lawrence memorial lecture, delivered by the Prince of Wales. Her son, who was 18 in 1993 when stabbed to death at a bus stop, had dreamed of becoming an architect, and the prince used his speech to announce a scholarship named after him aimed at increasing ethnic minority architects.

Speaking before the prince's address, Mrs Lawrence said many lessons arising from the murder and the bungled police investigation had yet to be learned: "How it should be changed is going to take some time, not even in Stephen's generation will it happen, but the generation to come."

She and Neville Lawrence, father of Stephen, have set up a trust to raise funds to support ethnic minority architects, with the aim of a "Stephen Lawrence" student in each of the country's 30 architecture schools.

Most of the Prince of Wales's speech, made at his architecture foundation, was an attack on modern architecture, but he expressed his deepest sympathy for Mr and Mrs Lawrence, saying: "I wish them well in their quest to build something positive from the shocking and sudden loss of their son."

webTitle: How well do you know your world leaders? (And what did they have to do to get in the front row?)

fields.headline: How well do you know your world leaders? (And what did they have to do to get in the front row?)
fields.trailText: The United Nations proudly subscribes to the principle that all nations and all people are equal. But that maxim took a knock yesterday when it published the official picture of the world leaders attending the millennium summit in New York.
fields.body:
The United Nations proudly subscribes to the principle that all nations and all people are equal. But that maxim took a knock yesterday when it published the official picture of the world leaders attending the millennium summit in New York.

The UN recognises 189 countries and here were most of them. Only 14 of the world leaders attending the summit were missing. It was an opportunity to demonstrate a new look for the 21st century, a happy mix of nations, an informal huddle, free of status.

Instead, the old order was reaffirmed. The developing nations were pushed to the back as the western leaders took pride of place. The US president, Bill Clinton, was near the centre, with Tony Blair, close by.

The Cuban leader, Fidel Castro managed to squeeze into the second row. Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi foreign minister, was pushed all the way to the back row.

A spokeswoman for the UN protocol department insisted there was a logic behind the positioning. She said the secretary-general, Kofi Annan, had been placed in the centre, with the two co-chairmen of the summit flanking him, and then the permanent members of the security council.

After that the order was decided alphabetically by country, beginning with heads of state, then heads of government, and then deputies. The protocol was disrupted by some who were too infirm to climb to the back and by the inclusion of interlopers.

The picture was meant to have only one representative from each country but Jordan and Norway had two on show. So too did San Marino, but in its case it was justified as it has joint leadership, two captain regents of equal standing.

But that maxim took a knock yesterday when it published the official picture of the world leaders attending the millennium summit in New York. The UN recognises 189 countries and here were most of them. Only 14 of the world leaders attending the summit were missing. It was an opportunity to demonstrate a new look for the 21st century, a happy mix of nations, an informal huddle, free of status. Instead, the old order was reaffirmed. The developing nations were pushed to the back as the western leaders took pride of place. The US president, Bill Clinton, was near the centre, with Tony Blair, close by. The Cuban leader, Fidel Castro managed to squeeze into the second row. Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi foreign minister, was pushed all the way to the back row. A spokeswoman for the UN protocol department insisted there was a logic behind the positioning. She said the secretary-general, Kofi Annan, had been placed in the centre, with the two co-chairmen of the summit flanking him, and then the permanent members of the security council. After that the order was decided alphabetically by country, beginning with heads of state, then heads of government, and then deputies. The protocol was disrupted by some who were too infirm to climb to the back and by the inclusion of interlopers. The picture was meant to have only one representative from each country but Jordan and Norway had two on show. So too did San Marino, but in its case it was justified as it has joint leadership, two captain regents of equal standing.

fields.headline: Appreciation
fields.trailText: Anne Karpf writes: Desmond Wilcox (Obituary, September 7) was my first boss. He (unwittingly) taught me that you could find a person terribly hard to respect yet absurdly easy to like.
fields.body:
Anne Karpf writes: Desmond Wilcox (Obituary, September 7) was my first boss. He (unwittingly) taught me that you could find a person terribly hard to respect yet absurdly easy to like.

Among his employees, Desmond's vanity and economy with the truth were taken for granted. He reinvented his past exploits regularly, though not always consistently, and inflated his own achievements. Prurience was his metier. He co-originated the pioneering Man Alive, whose early series humanised social problems in a fresh way, but by the mid-1970s this had deteriorated into a style of documentary that fished for tears and quarried for personal revelations. Under his aegis, we were forever being dispatched to find homeless, unemployed, heartwringing single parents - with an articulacy that matched our own.

Although he liked strong, bright women and promoted them, he could be lumberingly inappropriate. As a young researcher I had a letter published in the Guardian without first obtaining his permission (as BBC policy demanded) on the debate about rape, following the celebrated case in which a judge suggested that a woman's "no" might sometimes mean "yes". Desmond's note, mildly rebuking me, ended by suggesting that I "lie back and enjoy it".

Both his wives and his long-time collaborator, Bill Morton, were Jewish, and eventually he himself converted to Judaism.

Desmond inspired tremendous loyalty. His liberalism was cast-iron, his sense of humour unflagging. When, in a research report, I mentioned the attractiveness of a potential male participant, he guffawingly accused me of "groinspeak". Resolutely heterosexual, he flirted with both women and men and charmed us all. It was almost impossible not to feel affection for him. Desmond Wilcox was a thoroughly human executive just before the arrival of the suits.

webTitle: Union calls for fat cat salaries for troubleshooting heads

fields.headline: Union calls for fat cat salaries for troubleshooting heads
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Headteachers brought in to turn around failing schools should be given almost complete autonomy and awarded pay packages worth about £750,000 over five years, a report said yesterday.
fields.body:
Headteachers brought in to turn around failing schools should be given almost complete autonomy and awarded pay packages worth about £750,000 over five years, a report said yesterday.

The National Association of Head Teachers, which commissioned the study by Hay management consultants, said "thinking the unthinkable" with corporate-style pay packages was the only way to attract the most experienced heads away from successful schools and into the most challenging.

Under the NAHT proposals headteachers of up to 100 schools, including the 25 "fresh start" schools and new city academies, would be released from national regulations on pay, management structure, the curriculum and exclusions.

They would take home up to £120,000 for five years, plus a bonus of up to £75,000 for delivering success, and health insurance for themselves and their family, help with childcare, pension enhancements and possibly a car.

"I know people will say these are 'fat cat' salaries but this is a modern renumeration package for a modern head," said David Hart, the association's general secretary.

Mr Hart said the success of formerly "failing" schools should be measured in ways other than the percentage of pupils winning five or more A*-Cs at GCSE.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, and Michael Barber, the head of the standards and effectiveness unit, accept that headteachers need time to turn schools around. But they also argue it is inevitable that, to keep the confidence of parents and the local community, heads have to deliver some short-term improvement in GCSE results.

Estelle Morris, the minister for school standards, said last night: "This government has raised the maximum salary a headteacher can earn from £57,399 in 1997 to £75,972 from this September. This higher salary is designed to attract high calibre candidates to demanding headships."

She added: "In the future, fresh start schools will be required to set a plan of action with clear targets to raise standards. Heads will be able to set out ambitious plans for improvement and if we think those plans have a real chance of succeeding, then extra funds will be unlocked."

The authors of the Hay report, Helen Murlis and Beccy Wallace, said headteachers of fresh start schools were at a level comparable to a chief executive. But the report adds that there would often be a need to change headteachers after five years, when a "more mainstream" head might be the right appointment.

webTitle: School shut after jam jar bomb found

fields.headline: School shut after jam jar bomb found
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A school in Essex was evacuated yesterday after a crude home-made bomb was found with a note warning that further devices had been planted there.
fields.body:
A school in Essex was evacuated yesterday after a crude home-made bomb was found with a note warning that further devices had been planted there.

Army bomb disposal experts carried out a controlled explosion after the jam jar - stuffed with wire and containing a small amount of explosive - was discovered on a shelf in the boys' toilet block at Notley high school in Braintree.

More than 1,000 pupils and staff were evacuated from the school after the bomb was found by a pupil yesterday morning. He immediately reported the find to a teacher, who raised the alarm. Most of the pupils were sent home

A spokesman for Essex police said: "The bomb disposal experts described it as serious. It was clear it was something that was not made by a five-year-old. But it was basically a very crude device.

"There was some element of explosive but the Royal Logistic Corps, who carried out the controlled explosion, said it was not primed and there was no detonator or timer so it could not self-explode."

The school's headteacher, John Hartley, said he hoped to reopen the school today.

Later Inspector Joe Wrigley, of Essex police, said a 15-year-old boy had been arrested and was in custody at Braintree police station.

fields.headline: Acquittal fuels rape trials debate
fields.standfirst: Call for accused men to have anonymity unless convicted as student cleared of sex assault says case has blighted his future
fields.trailText: Nicholas Buoy remained impassive as he was acquitted of rape and indecent assault of a 28-year-old woman he had met at a party last September.
fields.body:
Nicholas Buoy remained impassive as he was acquitted of rape and indecent assault of a 28-year-old woman he had met at a party last September.

As he left Cambridge crown court on Wednesday he expressed relief, but made it clear he did not view the verdict as a win. "My future," he said "has been blighted by this case."

Mr Buoy, 24, who told the court that he drunk so much during a graduates' party at Homerton College last September that he had no recollection of the alleged attack, said that the trauma of the case would stay with him for years and asked for time "to rebuild my life".

Laboratory tests showed traces of Mr Buoy's DNA in the woman's hair, but there was no evidence that sexual intercourse had taken place.

His comments about his future fuel the debate over whether defendants in rape cases should be given the same anonymity that is granted to their alleged victims.

Ashley Pittman believes they should. Now 22, he was acquitted of raping a fellow University of Wales undergraduate after a disco in 1996. The allegations were not made until two years later and there was no forensic evidence.

"Rape is a very serious offence and there's no denying it does happen and in that situation a woman's anonymity is right and fair. But it is not fair that the girl who accused me continued with her life while my face and name is all over the papers," he said.

"There's no need to print a man's name until he has been proven guilty."

Mr Pittman was contacted by friends and distant relatives who he had decided not to tell about the charges after they had read reports of the case.

He worries about the effect on his future career of having being identified. He said: "I think the public quickly forget these cases. I do worry however about applying for jobs and being asked why I took a year out of university."

He was forced under bail conditions to leave his university course in Aberystwyth and live with his parents in Wiltshire where opportunities to work with computers are scarce.

"I lost a year of my life and with it about £30,000 in earnings. I was torn away from my friends and the place I wanted to be. Now my university friends are jet-setting around Europe or earning money. I had to take a year out I didn't choose," he said.

During the seven months he waited for the case to come to court his drinking was "really, really bad" and he visited a psychiatric nurse for depression.

Next month Mr Pittman will return to university to complete the final year of a computer science degree.

"I've become cynical. It took so little evidence to actually make the allegations that I believe virtually anyone could have made them.

"The thought of going back to university makes me nostalgic. I'm going back to life before the whole ordeal. It's like going back to my childhood because the case made me grow up fast."

Mr Pittman's mother, Sylvia, said that although the trial had finished the tension had not gone away. "There's no support for the men accused or his family supporting him," she said.

"Because of the bail conditions I had to become my son's jail keeper. He has suffered a miscarriage of justice and, I believe, should be given financial compensation.

"What did she suffer? No monetary loss and she didn't suffer under our son's hands."

After a large increase in the number of prosecutions, according to a recent Home Office report, 25% of reported rape cases in 1985 resulted in conviction compared with only one in 10 in 1996.

It states that this may be due to the crown prosecution service's increased willingness to prosecute rapes where the defendant and the accuser knew each other, as well as when the man is unknown to the woman.

fields.headline: Alan Caddy
fields.standfirst: Guitarist who found fame with the Tornados
fields.trailText: Alan Caddy, who has died aged 60, was a founder member of the Tornados, the only serious challengers to the Shadows as most popular British instrumental unit of the 1960s. The quintet are best remembered for 1962's million-selling Telstar.
fields.body:
Alan Caddy, who has died aged 60, was a founder member of the Tornados, the only serious challengers to the Shadows as most popular British instrumental unit of the 1960s. The quintet are best remembered for 1962's million-selling Telstar.

If unable to build on a number one in the US - where no UK outfit had ever made much headway - the Tornados scored three more entries - Globetrotter, Robot and the Ice Cream Man - in 1963's domestic Top 10 before the advent of Merseybeat, with its emphasis on vocals. Suddenly rendered passé, they soldiered on with a still impressive workload while largely repeating earlier ideas on disc.

Unlike the others, Caddy, who was born in Chelsea, London, was classically trained, having served as a boy soprano in Westminster Abbey, and studied violin as leader of the orchestra at school in Battersea, before the onset of puberty found him looking for an opening in pop as a guitarist. It came when he joined a skiffle group, the Five Nutters, who were omnipresent at their own KKK Club in Willesden.

After a transitional period as Bats Heath and the Vampires, they went professional as Johnny Kidd and the Pirates in 1958. Among few homegrown rock 'n' rollers regarded with awe, they made a television debut on ITV's Disc Break, with 1959's Please Don't Touch. Much of its charm emanated from Caddy's galvanising riffing.

However, because Caddy was riven with self-doubt about his ability, another guitarist picked the staccato lead on Kidd's climactic Shakin' All Over - which, while it knocked Cliff Richard from the top in August 1960, netted Caddy only a standard session fee of 15 guineas.

Within a year, Johnny Kidd was becalmed outside the Top 50, and Caddy and his fellow Pirates had abandoned the apparently sinking ship, retaining their stage costumes to be the Cabin Boys behind Tommy Steele's brother, Colin Hicks, a huge attraction in Italy.

Hicks proved a difficult employer, and Caddy flew home to land on his feet as mainstay of the Tornados, assembled in the first instance to back Ken Charles, Pamela Blue, John Leyton and Mike Berry and similar protégés of the console boffin Joe Meek, in his RPM studio in Holloway Road, London.

Following a miss with Popeye Twist, written by Caddy and drummer Clem Cattini, the ethereal Telstar was taped as a routine backing track - albeit with a poignant "second subject" plucked by Caddy - hours before a show with Billy Fury in Great Yarmouth. Overnight, Meek transformed it into the quintessential 1960s instrumental. Though dismissing the RPM sound as "unadulterated lift music", Caddy remained a Tornado throughout their period of greatest celebrity as both respected sidemen, hit parade contenders and patron saints of myriad combos created in the same image - notably the Volcanos, with Polaris.

The first perceptible sign of danger occurred with Dragonfly, a comparative flop, coinciding with the exit shortly before of bass player Heinz Burt - and, with him, most of the group's teen appeal - in autumn 1963. As injurious a departure in its way was that of Caddy, after the release of 1964's Away From It All, an album containing four of his compositions. By then, Caddy was well-placed to make a living as a session musician, and even become a star in his own right, but, said Clem Cattini: "He never achieved his potential because he didn't believe in himself."

Caddy took a job as house arranger and producer for Avenue Records, a budget label specialising in covers of current hits. Next, he moved to a similar post in Canada. Back in England by 1975, Caddy was involved in a remake of Telstar by a reconstituted Tornados, but chose not to return to the public stage - although he was persuaded to pitch in occasionally when attending RPM Appreciation Society evenings - as he was a few months ago when he gave his last performance, which included a game, if ragged, crack at the timeless Telstar.

Alan Caddy is survived by his wife and daughter.

webTitle: Serb maverick who has Milosevic on the run

fields.headline: Serb maverick who has Milosevic on the run
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: If the opinion polls are correct and the elections fair, Slobodan Milosevic has less than a month left as Yugoslavia's president - and the candidate tipped to beat him is a rare animal among the Serbian elite, a man who never joined the Communist party or accepted favours from the present regime.
fields.byline: Gillian Sandford  in Belgrade and  Jonathan Steele
fields.body:
If the opinion polls are correct and the elections fair, Slobodan Milosevic has less than a month left as Yugoslavia's president - and the candidate tipped to beat him is a rare animal among the Serbian elite, a man who never joined the Communist party or accepted favours from the present regime.

This unusual record in a centralised country where careers rarely advance without loyalty to the ruling party belongs to Vojislav Kostunica, leader of the Democratic party of Serbia. The latest figures from the Centre for the Research of Alternatives put him at 52%, against Mr Milosevic's 26%. Two other recent polls gave him a lead of more than 20%.

Mr Kostunica's success is all the more extraordinary, given that he is a low-key professor of constitutional law who admits that he has none of the fashionable requirements of modern electioneering. "I am not a presumptuous man and I do not think that I am charismatic at all. I am not a populist either", he told a press conference in Belgrade this week, according to the text his party put out on its website (www.dss.org.yu).

His attraction may be that he is the exact opposite of Mr Milosevic in character. He prides himself on being approachable and trustworthy. His campaign posters say: "Who can look you straight in the eye? Kostunica".

He is also helped by rare unity among Serbia's many opposition parties which back him. Only the Serbian Renewal Movement led by the maverick Vuk Draskovic has put up its own candidate.

The elections were called by Mr Milosevic a year early, after he rushed through constitutional amendments calling for the president to be elected by direct popular vote instead of by the parliament. This would allow him to run for two new four-year terms. He hoped to wrongfoot the the opposition, but the polls suggest he may have miscalculated.

The opposition and most independent analysts assume that there will be poll fraud, unless Mr Kostunica is ahead by a huge margin.

The opposition candidate traces his ancestry to a hamlet called Kostunici in central Serbia. This region, known as Sumadiya, where two uprisings against the Ottoman empire began, is the heart of historic Serbian nationalism.

On the stump he appeals to nationalist pride, evoking local heroes who fought against Serbia's occupiers. In Zajecar, on the eastern border with Bulgaria, he told a crowd: "Everyone in Serbia has some heroic blood. We will show how worthy we are of our ancestors on September 24."

Aged 56, he is a lifelong anti-communist, a moderate Serb nationalist and an economic liberal. He was among Belgrade University staff who were sacked in 1974 for opposing constitutional changes which gave Yugoslavia's republics and Kosovo substantial autonomy.

After Tito's death he co-authored the first book which was allowed to be published advocating a multi-party system. Six years later he refused to take his job back at the university when Serbia's new leader, Mr Milosevic, offered it.

Instead, Mr Kostunica took up the political fight against Mr Milosevic and joined other friends in forming the Democratic party. They were elected to the federal parliament. Three years later the party split over whether to co-operate with Mr Milosevic, and Mr Kostunica took the radicals with him to form the Democratic party of Serbia.

Although a strong supporter of the rights of Serb minorities during Yugoslavia's dissolution, he was never involved in paramilitary activities.

"In parliament he was one of the best speakers. He's honest and keeps his word. He does not seem obsessed by power, as most Serb politicians are," a senior journalist said.

One of his main promises is to change the Serbian constitution towards a parliamentary system. He then says he will resign after 18 months and hold new elections.

In foreign policy he is trying to steer a line between strong criticism of Nato and opening Serbia towards integration with Europe. He denounces western sanctions and welcomes French hints that they may be lifted after the poll.

He wants closer ties with the Serb-run entity in Bosnia. His attitude to Serbia's sister republic, Montenegro, is ambiguous. While he says he would accept an independent Montenegro, he has irritated its government by accusing it of being afraid of democracy in boycotting the elections.

In Kosovo he has close links with the Serb leaders in northern Mitrovice, who want to turn their part of the city into an enclave. He sneers at the US administration for relying on Mr Milosevic as a guarantor of peace in Bosnia and then denouncing him as a war criminal. He jeers at Mr Milosevic for pretending he won in Kosovo when his policy ended in "capitulation".

Denied access to the state television and radio, Mr Kostunica has campaigned in small towns. "Most people can hardly make ends meet. They are humiliated and tormented," he said. "Now they have raised their heads."

His big problem is whether Mr Milosevic will let him win. Mr Kostunica puts the issue in apocalyptic terms: "These are not normal elections. It is a matter of life and death."

What their papers say

"We have to win against Nato. We need people of granite to be our president, as President Milosevic is - hero of the country's defence and the man who launched renewal and rebuilding"

Borba [Struggle] - federal government newspaper

"Our proven enemies, Nato and the opposition, are working together. Their goal is further destabilisation of the country, economic torture and fragmentation," said Veselin Stanojevic, JUL board member, in the village of Vojnik

Vecerni Novosti [Our Newspaper] - federal government controlled

"While every honourable citizen was happy for every bridge, road and house that has been rebuilt, the opposition Nato parties compete in convincing our citizens that rebuilding and progress are just illusion and tricks," said Mirko Marijanovic, vice-president of Serbia

Politika [Politics] - main state organ

Massive support for beloved leaders is more important for [the Milosevic regime] than the individual thoughts of citizens hidden by the curtain at the poll booth

Danas [Today] - Non-government newspaper
fields.bodyText: If the opinion polls are correct and the elections fair, Slobodan Milosevic has less than a month left as Yugoslavia's president - and the candidate tipped to beat him is a rare animal among the Serbian elite, a man who never joined the Communist party or accepted favours from the present regime. This unusual record in a centralised country where careers rarely advance without loyalty to the ruling party belongs to Vojislav Kostunica, leader of the Democratic party of Serbia. The latest figures from the Centre for the Research of Alternatives put him at 52%, against Mr Milosevic's 26%. Two other recent polls gave him a lead of more than 20%. Mr Kostunica's success is all the more extraordinary, given that he is a low-key professor of constitutional law who admits that he has none of the fashionable requirements of modern electioneering. "I am not a presumptuous man and I do not think that I am charismatic at all. I am not a populist either", he told a press conference in Belgrade this week, according to the text his party put out on its website (www.dss.org.yu). His attraction may be that he is the exact opposite of Mr Milosevic in character. He prides himself on being approachable and trustworthy. His campaign posters say: "Who can look you straight in the eye? Kostunica". He is also helped by rare unity among Serbia's many opposition parties which back him. Only the Serbian Renewal Movement led by the maverick Vuk Draskovic has put up its own candidate. The elections were called by Mr Milosevic a year early, after he rushed through constitutional amendments calling for the president to be elected by direct popular vote instead of by the parliament. This would allow him to run for two new four-year terms. He hoped to wrongfoot the the opposition, but the polls suggest he may have miscalculated. The opposition and most independent analysts assume that there will be poll fraud, unless Mr Kostunica is ahead by a huge margin. The opposition candidate traces his ancestry to a hamlet called Kostunici in central Serbia. This region, known as Sumadiya, where two uprisings against the Ottoman empire began, is the heart of historic Serbian nationalism. On the stump he appeals to nationalist pride, evoking local heroes who fought against Serbia's occupiers. In Zajecar, on the eastern border with Bulgaria, he told a crowd: "Everyone in Serbia has some heroic blood. We will show how worthy we are of our ancestors on September 24." Aged 56, he is a lifelong anti-communist, a moderate Serb nationalist and an economic liberal. He was among Belgrade University staff who were sacked in 1974 for opposing constitutional changes which gave Yugoslavia's republics and Kosovo substantial autonomy. After Tito's death he co-authored the first book which was allowed to be published advocating a multi-party system. Six years later he refused to take his job back at the university when Serbia's new leader, Mr Milosevic, offered it. Instead, Mr Kostunica took up the political fight against Mr Milosevic and joined other friends in forming the Democratic party. They were elected to the federal parliament. Three years later the party split over whether to co-operate with Mr Milosevic, and Mr Kostunica took the radicals with him to form the Democratic party of Serbia. Although a strong supporter of the rights of Serb minorities during Yugoslavia's dissolution, he was never involved in paramilitary activities. "In parliament he was one of the best speakers. webTitle: Cleared head kept out of school

fields.headline: Cleared head kept out of school
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Governors of a south Wales primary school voted last night to maintain the year-old suspension of Marjorie Evans, the headteacher cleared last week of slapping an unruly 10-year-old pupil across the face.
fields.body:
Governors of a south Wales primary school voted last night to maintain the year-old suspension of Marjorie Evans, the headteacher cleared last week of slapping an unruly 10-year-old pupil across the face.

The decision followed an hour-and-a-half meeting at the school which is at the centre of a separate police investigation into allegations of inappropriate emotional and physical handling of pupils.

The National Union of Teachers, which has supported Mrs Evans throughout her suspension, said it was extremely disappointed at the governors' conclusion and complained that the appropriate procedures had not been followed before the suspension was renewed at the beginning of this month.

Graham Powell, the chairman of governors who has been a strong supporter of Mrs Evans's reinstatement, said the decision had been taken following the advice of Monmouthshire county council's legal and education department. He said a further meeting would be held on September 28.

In a statement after the meeting, he said "The governors wish to emphasise that the suspension is not a disciplinary step and is without prejudice."

Mrs Evans, 56, has been suspended since September last year when the 10-year-old special needs pupil accused her of slapping him when he became difficult after being told he could not go swimming with his classmates because of previous bad behaviour.

Neither the boy nor the school can be identified for legal reasons.

Governors decided last week to maintain the suspension in the light of the continuing inquiry by Gwent police despite Mrs Evans' successful appeal against a conviction for common assault following a trial at Abergavenny magistrates court in July. A judge at Cardiff crown court told her she left the court with her good character entirely intact.

Mrs Evans's supporters have complained that she has become the victim of a witch-hunt by a small group of parents and staff seeking to remove her from the school.

Gwent police, whose handling of the new investigation has come under fierce criticism, have refused to comment on the nature of the alleged mistreatment of children at the 210-pupil school.

One mother has expressed concern that her children had become "pawns" in the affair even though she had made no complaints against Mrs Evans or another teacher, Janet Bowen, who has been suspended in connection with the inquiry.

Mr Powell confirmed last night that the police had not informed him of the allegations or by whom they had been made.

NUT spokesman Gethin Lewis called for a meeting to hear the nature of the allegations.

In a statement Mrs Evans said she was disappointed that the governing body had not decided to lift her suspension.

"At no time have the police interviewed me regarding the further allegations, nor have these allegations been put to me. Following my acquittal I thought that this nightmare would be over. However, these new allegations have only served to add to the stress and pressure that I have been forced to endure."

webTitle: Time warp trap of microchip allergy

fields.headline: Time warp trap of microchip allergy
fields.trailText: From the outside, Joan Stock's neat, white bungalow in the village of Saltford on the outskirts of Bristol looks like the ideal retirement home.
fields.body:
From the outside, Joan Stock's neat, white bungalow in the village of Saltford on the outskirts of Bristol looks like the ideal retirement home.

Step inside, however, and you enter something of a technological time warp. Instead of a colour television and video, a 12-inch black and white portable sits incongruously on a stand designed for something much bigger. The telephones belong to an earlier era. Even the washing machine and tumble drier have long been overtaken by advances in white goods technology.

The lack of modern conveniences does not reflect an unusual form of asceticism. Nor is it due to parsimony, but to a rare hypersensitivity to microchips that has made Mrs Stock's life a misery for more than 25 years.

Mrs Stock says that if she goes near a computer or sits in a modern motor car she quickly begins to suffer with a pain that she likens to a pencil boring through the back of her head.

"I have earache and toothache and my vision goes distorted. It is just as though you are drunk and you don't know what you are doing," she said yesterday. "I find it very scary, especially when the eyes go. They can be like that for hours and I worry that they may not become all right again. The pains in my head can last for days."

Mrs Stock, a sprightly 79, says that she first noticed the problem in the mid-1970s when an electronic typewriter was introduced to the office where she worked as a secretary for the old Wessex water authority.

But life has become increasingly problematic as the years have progressed because of the widespread use of microchips in everyday items.

Supermarket checkouts have become a no-go area; modern telephones with their number storage facilities are out of the question; and even a trip to a favourite local pub is no longer a possibility since they installed electronic bar equipment.

Mrs Stock's problem has been attributed to a rare sensitivity to electromagnetic fields of a particular frequency given out by some modern electronic goods.

According to David Dowson, a specialist in complementary and environmental medicine to whom she turned for help several years ago, her condition is extremely rare.

He said he had only come across eight similar cases in 15 years, but although people often dismissed the problem as psychological, it was not. "Avoidance is the best answer," he said yesterday. "I have one patient who has moved to the middle of Dartmoor."

Mrs Stock, a great-grand mother who spends much of her time reading and listening to the radio, says her own GP has been very understanding.

"He doesn't know what to do for me, but he has been very kind and when I do have to go and see him about something he gives me the last appointment so he can switch the computer off in the surgery."

The biggest disappointment Mrs Stock and her husband Roy face lies in the restriction that her sensitivity to 21st century life has placed on their activities.

They are unable to travel by public transport, making foreign holidays an impossibility, and have even had to stop going to the theatre because of computerised tills and lighting systems.

Mr Stock, a retired solicitor who served with the RAF during the second world war, drives an Escort which he bought secondhand almost 15 years ago.

He would like to buy a newer car but knows it could be packed full of electronic gadgetry. At the same time he is worried about breakdowns in case his wife has to travel home in a modern vehicle. It is a concern she shares.

Mrs Stock added: "When I am out in the open air there is no problem - it is in confined spaces, such as houses, shops and cars.

"My biggest regret is not being able to go and visit people. I'm a sociable person and there are lots of things I would like to do.

"But my friends and family know I'm not potty and have been very supportive. It's just a good job I'm nearly 80 and not eight because I would not get an education."

fields.headline: Blue chips lose their way
fields.trailText: A shock profit warning, a decent showing from the oil sector and weakness in a couple of heavyweight telecom stocks all conspired to bring the FTSE 100 to a near standstill yesterday.
fields.body:
A shock profit warning, a decent showing from the oil sector and weakness in a couple of heavyweight telecom stocks all conspired to bring the FTSE 100 to a near standstill yesterday.

At the close, the blue chip index was 5.5 points lower at 6.689.2, with all the other major indices putting in similar performances. The Techmark 100 edged up 4.37 to 4,025.20 while the FTSE 250 eased 15.9 to 7,000.

After seeing TMT (technology, media and telecom) stocks march to the top of the hill only to come back down, market professionals are not sure where the market is heading next. The decision by the Bank of England's monetary policy committee to peg interest rates did nothing to help.

No one seemed to have a particularly new story to play with; there were just a few casual mentions of some educated buying of Marks & Spencer (down 3p to 214.5p) calls in the option market and the usual speculative interest in Hays, up 16.5p to 426.5p. The gossips continue to insist some form of corporate activity is on the cards.

Not that there was a lack of activity - market turnover of shares topped 1.5bn - but, Invensys aside, this was more a case of trading than buying. "We have seen some bottom fishing and some more profit-taking, but that's about it," one dealer said.

Controls and automation group Invensys saw its market capitalisation shrink by around a third following a profit warning that stunned the City. The downgrades rolled in: Deutsche Bank cut its earnings forecast for the current financial year by 20%, Merrill Lynch slashed its estimate by 12%. The only crumb of comfort for shareholders was that, following the sharp fall, some dealers were saying that Invensys could be vulnerable to a bid. The shares closed down 93p at 167p after 282.9m units had changed hands.

Meanwhile, the strong crude price continued to lend support to the oil majors BP and Shell. Both hit record levels before falling back to finish 4.5p better at 661.5p and 10p stronger at 616p respectively. FTSE 250 stocks Lasmo joined in the fun, advancing 7p to 155.5p.

Shares in British Airways, however, slid 10p to 321p on fears that the escalating cost of fuel will hit profits further.

The telecoms picture was mixed. British Telecoms, which is expected to tap the bond market soon with huge issue, was under pressure again, falling 17p to 833p, while the profit-takers moved in to clip the wings of Cable & Wireless, down 64p to £12.25p.

However, Vodafone, whose shares have been volatile of late, closed 9p higher at 291 as it revealed it has signed up its 10 millionth British mobile user.

Diageo gained 16p to 584.5p after posting full-year figures which appeared to justify its decision to focus on alcoholic drinks and offload Burger King and its Pillsbury food unit. Dealers were impressed by a solid performance from its UDV wine and spirits division and Guinness.

Speciality chemicals group ICI, down 11p at 454p, was unsettled by a profit warning from US peer Dupont, while Sema, up 40p to £11.90, continued to fight back.

In the FTSE 250, fund management group Aberdeen Asset Management fell 51p to 578p after Abbey National, off 5.5p at 843.5p, made clear it had no intention of acquiring the 38.8% stake owned by Scottish Provident. Abbey National yesterday acquired Scottish Provident for £1.8bn.

But telecoms kit firm Spirent, which will join the FTSE 100 later this month, surged after reporting a 33% rise in interim profits. Its shares closed 84p better at 639p - a closing high.

In the small cap world, Dataflex rose 30p to 302.5p on the back of a £10m contract win and Cairn Energy climbed 14.5p to 236.5p after reporting a 167% jump in first-half profits.

webTitle: New debt pledge made to defuse Prague protests

fields.headline: New debt pledge made to defuse Prague protests
fields.standfirst: Special report: debt relief
fields.trailText: The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund last night sought to defuse growing protests at the sluggish pace of international debt relief efforts, with a pledge to give help to 20 of the world's poorest countries by the end of the year.
fields.body:
The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund last night sought to defuse growing protests at the sluggish pace of international debt relief efforts, with a pledge to give help to 20 of the world's poorest countries by the end of the year.

With the IMF's new managing director, Horst Kohler, set for a confrontation with debt campaigners and charities at a lunch hosted by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, today, the Fund and the Bank issued a joint statement promising to end the delays and bottlenecks.

Western leaders committed themselves a year ago to giving 24 countries debt relief under the heavily indebted poor countries (HIPC) initiative by the end of 2000, but with less than four months to go only 10 have received any assistance.

Debt campaigners have blamed the two international financial institutions for dragging their feet on debt relief, accusing them of ring-fencing debt relief with new time-consuming conditions which poor countries must fulfil.

Although the fund and the bank deny that they have been erecting fresh road blocks to debt relief, they have been coming under pressure from politicians including Mr Brown and the development secretary, Clare Short, to accelerate the process.

"We are doing everything possible to achieve speedy implementation of the HIPC initiative," said Mr Kohler and the World Bank president, James Wolfensohn, in a joint statement.

The IMF and World Bank have agreed to show greater flexibility when assessing the economic track records of poor countries applying for debt relief - a move which they say will increase the number of countries eligible for debt relief this year from 20 to 24.

The move comes as the World Bank and IMF are bracing themselves for mass protests at their annual meetings in Prague later this month, at which the slow progress on debt relief will be one of the contentious issues. Debt campaigners believe that the current deal is not just too slow but is also not generous enough to provide a new start for indebted countries.

Adrian Lovett, deputy director of Jubilee 2000, said: "The international effort to relieve debt has become hopelessly bogged down in red tape. The scheme is totally discredited."

fields.headline: Safety in Safeway
fields.trailText: Wal-Mart might not agree but the departure of Allan Leighton, the head of its European operations, is likely to be good news for the rest of the British food-retailing sector. Without his flair and drive, Wal-Mart's Asda is likely to be a less formidable opponent.
fields.body:
Wal-Mart might not agree but the departure of Allan Leighton, the head of its European operations, is likely to be good news for the rest of the British food-retailing sector. Without his flair and drive, Wal-Mart's Asda is likely to be a less formidable opponent.

US investment bank Merrill Lynch reckons Mr Leighton's departure is good news, at least in the short term, for Safeway. Merrill says that if Asda loses momentum Safeway should be able to keep going the deep-discount promotional strategy that has delivered a revival in sales growth.

All of which means Safeway's shares, which yesterday rose 1.25p to 273.5p, are likely to remain reasonably well supported until interim figures in November. Longer-term Merrill remains cautious. From October, Safeway's like-for-like sales comparatives start to get tough which means there will be a risk that its January trading statement will disappoint.

webTitle: Now it's £35k for starters in the City

fields.headline: Now it's £35k for starters in the City
fields.standfirst: Dot.com glamour drives up the price of top graduates
fields.trailText: Fifteen graduates, who started their working lives at the investment bank UBS Warburg this week are among the most pampered and privileged new entrants to the British workforce.
fields.body:
Fifteen graduates, who started their working lives at the investment bank UBS Warburg this week are among the most pampered and privileged new entrants to the British workforce.

Along with 200 other new graduates taken on by the investment bank this year, they have received signing-on bonuses of £3,000 each. They will get starting salaries of £35,000. In March these 21-year-olds will receive their first, modest performance-related bonuses. But once they qualify for a full bonus year - after 18 months - they could receive a bonus of £25,000. In less than two years, the graduates will take home more than £80,000.

They are not unique. At Merrill Lynch, one of the top tier American banks, new graduates are given signing-on bonuses of £6,500 and a yearly basic salary of £37,500. This year Merrill's top analysts received bonuses of around £30,000. If this level of compensation is sustained next year, a 22-year-old who has worked for the company for a year could earn a total of £74,000, nearly four times the average annual wage.

Attractive wages and bonuses reflect the unmet demand for top graduates. Fierce competition now comes from top dot.com companies, which can offer the excitement of a new venture as well as the lure of share options.

Heidi Plant, head of campus recruitment at UBS Warburg, said: "There are plenty of good graduates on the market but competition is getting fiercer every year. Graduates have more choices and it is a candidate-led market rather than an employer-led one."

One senior investment banker said that good graduates were scarce because they seemed more interested in dot.com companies.

Traditional companies have had to enlarge the financial package to attract talent. Andersen Consulting recently announced a £10,000 "golden hello" for new recruits and increased its starting salary from £25,500 to £28,000.

Even smaller consultancies, such as Spectrum, a specialist in communications, are having to adapt. Susan Hahn, the company's human resources manager, said: "Salaries have increased in the last couple of years because we need to be competitive with other companies. But we think that the quality of experience in the digital industry and the environment we offer are just as important."

Spectrum gives its new employees a starting package of around £32,000. This includes a signing-on bonus, offered for the first time this year. Employees receive performance-related bonuses in July and January. After a year in the company, the bonuses can be worth up to 20% of the graduate's salary.

A couple of months ago the Guardian reported that 150 members of staff at ARM Holdings, the fast-growing British microchip designer, had become millionaires.

"Graduates who have been with the firm for just three years can be worth £400,000 or £500,000," Bill Parsons, ARM's human resources director, said at the time, adding that every employee had stock options.

Companies such as UBS Warburg which have offered jobs to students during their last year of study might have to offer higher signing-on bonuses to stop them being enticed away before they join. Even that might not be enough to hold on to staff for long.

Selvan Masilamany, a Cambridge graduate with a first class degree, left his job at Merrill Lynch just before he completed his first year. He went to work for globalresident.com, a London property rental dot.com.

"The environment is more relaxed. The job is more challenging and full of variety. You get to see the whole of the business rather than just a small section of it."

Mr Masilamany took a salary cut, but at the new company he has share options. "The salary in banking is very appealing but you do work hard for it. You have the option of making money in dot.com companies and it is more exciting."

Lastminute.com, which employs 260 people in Britain, has no problem attracting good graduates, despite the collapse of its share price.

The company's head of recruitment, Nicola Alcorn, says the firm has more "approaches [from undergraduates] than we can handle". The starting salary at lastminute.com is considerably lower than that offered by firms in the City, ranging from £15,000 to £20,000. Working hours can also be longer depending on business pressures, often including weekend work.

Ms Alcorn says that the company is looking for top graduates and offers training. Morenike Williams, a 22-year-old Oxford graduate employed in lastminute.com's marketing department, chose this as her first job because of the environment.

"I did an internship with the company when there were only five people. It was really exciting. The learning curve is incredibly steep, and it is a dynamic vibrant place to work in."

A spokesman for one of the big six accountancy firms in the City acknowledges that companies are having to pay graduates much more than they are worth when they leave university. According to him the aim is to "lock in" top graduates with potential, so that they can develop a career within the company.

Andrew Williams, chief executive of Oxbridgejobs.com, a company set up to find jobs for Oxford and Cambridge graduates, explains why there is such high demand for his "products".

"We believe intellectual capital is replacing physical capital as an organisation's most valuable capital, and the best place to source intellectual capital is from the elite universities."

If he is right then investment banks, leading consultancies and dot.com companies, which are still solvent next year will have to bid even higher for the next crop of top graduates. And they will have to find even more imaginative ways to hold on to them.

fields.headline: Born again
fields.standfirst: Gas board's new image
fields.trailText: First there was British Gas. Then, after the demerger in 1997, there was BG (and Centrica). Next month, after a second demerger and a £125,000 rebrand, there will be . . . Lattice.
fields.body:
First there was British Gas. Then, after the demerger in 1997, there was BG (and Centrica). Next month, after a second demerger and a £125,000 rebrand, there will be . . . Lattice.

David Varney, outgoing BG chief executive, hopes the new name symbolising a network of infrastructure technologies will finally put paid to the pejorative "gas board" on doorsteps throughout the land.

The rebranding exercise, carried out with agency Fourth Room, will end up costing a few million more as the fleet of vans carrying out repairs will have to lose the BG tag and carry just the name of Transco, the gas pipelines business at the core of the new Lattice group. But the full demerger, including the confusing name change of BG International, the exploration and production business, into BG Group, will cost shareholders around £80m. This will include £24m in compensation to employees for winding up their Save As You Earn Scheme.

Listing particulars for the two new companies will be issued on September 18, with an emergency general meeting to approve the demerger on October 16 and scheduled completion on October 23.

The last set of results from BG yesterday saw the group take £250m in special charges in the second quarter before the demerger.

The move depressed operating profits from £301m to £101m despite the surge in oil prices.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Byers halts Interbrew deal
fields.body:
Byers halts Interbrew deal

Trade secretary Stephen Byers yesterday called in the competition commission to investigate the £2.5bn purchase of Bass's brewing division by Interbrew, the Belgian producer of Stella Artois.

The widely expected move means Interbrew cannot integrate its acquisition until the commission publishes its verdict, which is due by December 6. The commission is likely to order the disposal of at least one lager brand.

Budge says he will not budge

Richard Budge, chief executive of RJB Mining, intends to remain at the head of Britain's biggest coal miner following any takeover.

Yesterday, as the company reported an interim pre-tax loss of £10m, RJB declined to discuss takeover talks with Renco, the US industrial group dubbed one of America's worst polluters. However, in a statement accompanying its results announcement RJB confirmed continuing "discussions with a prospective bidder".

Mr Budge denied any involvement in the takeover talks but said: "I am intending to stay on."

Lufthansa may buy A3XX

German carrier Lufthansa confirmed yesterday it would decide early next year whether to buy the Airbus A3XX super jumbo or Boeing's stretch 747.

John Leahy, senior commercial director of Airbus, announced yesterday that three airlines had signed 22 memorandums of understanding for the A3XX, and he was well on the way to obtaining firm orders for up to 50 aircraft by the end of the year. Mr Leahy said Australian carrier Qantas was among a half a dozen airlines in talks.

GUS backs Burberry

Burberry said yesterday it had the backing of its parent, Great Universal Stores, in striving to change image from traditional clothing to high-fashion garb with the opening of a flagship store in Bond street, London.

webTitle: Britt Allcroft quits as Thomas flops

fields.headline: Britt Allcroft quits as Thomas flops
fields.trailText: Britt Allcroft, the woman widely credited with turning Thomas the Tank Engine into a global phenomena, has quit as deputy chairman of the children's television group that bears her name.
fields.body:
Britt Allcroft, the woman widely credited with turning Thomas the Tank Engine into a global phenomena, has quit as deputy chairman of the children's television group that bears her name.

Ms Allcroft's resignation follows poor reviews and disappointing cinema takings for the recently released Thomas and the Magic Railroad feature film which she wrote, produced and directed. The Southampton-based company's name is to be changed to Gullane Entertainment.

However, the company insisted that Ms Allcroft would remain its "creative cornerstone" after signing a two-year contract to develop the Thomas brand from her adopted base in Los Angeles.

Ms Allcroft may seek to sell some of her 8% stake to satisfy demand from US investors. Managing director William Harris will step up to chief executive and commercial direc tor Charles Falzon becomes president. Results for the year to June 30 met analysts' expectations as pre-tax profits climbed 39% to £6.78m and turnover climbed 20% to £18.08m. The dividend climbed 11% to 3p per share.

Art Attack, a property acquired in March, and Sooty, the veteran glove puppet, made strong contributions but revenues were once again dominated by Thomas.

The full effect that the feature film has on revenues will not be seen until the end of this financial year, but Thomas continues to perform strongly in all markets, and a new television series has been produced, the company said.

Earlier this year Britt Allcroft plc rejected the chance to merge with rival HIT Entertainment, the company behind Bob the Builder. HIT was offering around £10 per share, largely in new shares, but Britt decided to remain independent. Its shares closed down 2p at 605p.

fields.headline: At this price?  Spirent
fields.trailText: Spirent, the high speed telecommunications testing equipment specialist, is on the up. The company, which changed its name from Bowthorpe, won Footsie status this week - positive news that was reinforced by some nifty interim figures yesterday. And so the shares are soaring again, up 90p, or 16%, to close at 639p.
fields.body:
Spirent, the high speed telecommunications testing equipment specialist, is on the up. The company, which changed its name from Bowthorpe, won Footsie status this week - positive news that was reinforced by some nifty interim figures yesterday. And so the shares are soaring again, up 90p, or 16%, to close at 639p.

This is a business whose customers reside at the cutting edge of the new economy - names such as Cisco Systems and Lucent Technologies. It sells them equipment to test and monitor high speed switches, routers and other networking equipment.

According to analysts, the high growth in the company's communication division surprised even the most optimistic of watchers.

The communication part of the business, which draws together most of the company's monitoring equipment, has grown 80% organically, which is twice the rate of the expectations and accounts for 66% of the company's profit in the first half.

The company said it expects testing equipment to provide an increasing share of its earnings, as telecommunications networks expand to cope with the growth of the internet. Spirent boosted its testing business last year by acquiring America's Netcom Systems for $479m (£320m) in cash and assumed debt, and the betting is that another acquisition is on the way.

This is a market leader in a highly fragmented market which is both growing and consolidating at breakneck pace. It trades on a multiple that reflects as much: 75 times historical earnings and 50 times this year's prospective income.

It still has some sorting out of the group's old non-core assets to be done - businesses such as sensing solutions (components that gauge temperature and pressure) and its aerospace and power industries software division. But for investors who can live with some volatility the shares are still worth buying.

Julia Snoddy

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: Can I let my husband return to a hobby that leads him into temptation?
fields.trailText: Can I let my husband return to a hobby that leads him into temptation?
fields.body:
Six years ago, I learned that my husband was having an affair with a woman 30 years his junior - one of a series of long-standing relationships with leading ladies in his amateur theatre group. After counselling, I decided to stay with him and asked him to leave the theatre, which he did. Redundancy led to his retirement at 55. I continued to teach full time.

Since then, he has done nothing more than attend a 20-week recreational course in philosophy, deal with the supermarket shopping and cut the grass. I've suggested voluntary work, study, part-time work and travel, but he spends his time in bed and reading. He is bored, and thoroughly bad-tempered, partly because of a sleep deficit resulting from the early stages of prostate cancer diagnosed three years ago, and partly because my work prevents my being lively company to divert him. He claims leaving the theatre has "fettered his mind" and left him incapable of wanting to do anything but return and play King Lear. Is this really the only future? How can I accept calmly his return to temptation?

Time to stop nagging

Don't you think it's time you took the blinkers off? As a former teacher myself, I know how narrow and small-minded teachers can be. The theatre offers all the fun, colour and excitement that you do not. You have laid the law down and made him leave it, offering in exchange educational courses and voluntary work. Ageing and ill as he is, and probably afraid that he might not have much longer, he probably doesn't see much point in those activities. There's no wonder he's depressed.

He has made an effort to accede to your wishes. He obviously regrets it and is not behaving very well, but he is waiting for you to do your part. The first thing you should do is stop nagging and start asking. Why does he need all these affairs? And why only the leading ladies? Is he even telling the truth? Having counselling for just yourself is hardly going to help you as a couple.

As to future temptation (and at 61, with all the physical effects of prostate cancer, it is increasingly unlikely) why not encourage him to return to the theatre, and go with him? Amateur companies always need behind-the-scenes workers - prompters, stage managers, props, wardrobe, scenery painters, committee members etc - which call for the organisational skills that all teachers possess. You might even discover that you enjoy it, too, which will create a new bond, and keep all those voracious leading ladies at bay.
Clare Girvan
Exeter

Go your separate ways

What a miserable existence your husband must be leading! And really, what a mean-minded, self-centred person you come over as! I found your letter one of the worst advertisements for conventional marriage I've encountered in a long time.

Significantly, you never once indicate that you actually love your husband. Why, therefore, do you want this charade of a relationship to continue? For that matter, why does he? Perhaps he has become more dependent because of his illness; perhaps he always was a dependent sort of man.

My recommendation to you both would be: free yourselves up. Get out from under one another's feet. Any meaningful relationship between you is probably over because love has gone out of it. Sticking together the way you are now isn't going to help either of you. At the very least you could bear in mind some of the things that were said in last week's Private Lives about the possibilities of a "platonic marriage", or another form of relationship.
R M Love
Glasgow

Get yourself a toy boy

How old did you say he was? Thirteen and a half? Have you contacted the Guinness Book of Records about this marathon sulk? Buy the silly old goat a bottle of Grecian 2000, send him back to his play-acting and carry on with your life. You'll hardly notice any difference.

For your recreation, may I recommend the acquisition of a toy boy? They are widely available, decorative and amusing, not to mention useful around the house, disposable and easily replaceable. Look for the label "Sauce For The Goose... "
Carla Randle
Crewe

You can't lock him up

The man forced offstage will not be in bed reading for much longer if he is wise. How absurd to make a loved one stop what they love to do. If she really thinks he does not still "play" on the side, then she is a fool. You cannot lock someone up and expect them to be happy. If love and trust were ever present at all in the relationship, there would be no need to ask another to be miserable.
MysterysVixyn@aol.com

Next week

I'm a 13 year-old girl who attends a single-sex grammar school. For almost a year now I have known that I am a lesbian. I have told no one about it.

It makes me very uncomfortable when people laugh at homosexuals. My friends, I think, suspect. This secrecy is a constant source of anxiety to me. Added to the normal pressures of being a teenager, it makes life almost unbearable, and living with me must also be almost unbearable as it makes me very emotional.

I would like to be open about this, but I am worried about how people will react. Should I acknowledge my homosexuality openly or confide only in my closest friends for the moment? Or should I tell no one?

I live in quite a small town and I doubt it can be kept a secret from everyone for long. What do you think I should do?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 020-7239 9935, email private.lives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

Why, therefore, do you want this charade of a relationship to continue? For that matter, why does he? Perhaps he has become more dependent because of his illness; perhaps he always was a dependent sort of man. My recommendation to you both would be: free yourselves up. Get out from under one another's feet. Any meaningful relationship between you is probably over because love has gone out of it. Sticking together the way you are now isn't going to help either of you. At the very least you could bear in mind some of the things that were said in last week's Private Lives about the possibilities of a "platonic marriage", or another form of relationship. webTitle: What the Fiat Punto ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Fiat Punto ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Fiat Punto ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad: We open on a car, shot from overhead and either side, moving in slow motion towards a brick wall. The film cuts artfully from angle to angle and replays sequences to capture the full effect of the impact, as in a proper crash test film. We then cut to the inside of the car where two test dummies are rocking from the impact. Suddenly they begin to speak. "Can't you look where you're going?" asks the female dummy in the passenger seat. "It just came out of nowhere," replies the driver, as the female crossly mimics his classic excuse, saying "Ooooh, it just came out of nowhere." The endline comes up: "Spirito di Punto".

The jargon: This entertaining 20-seconder for the Fiat Punto is a tactical spot to promote the fact that the car has won the What Car? Safety Award 2000. It presents a "unique twist on actual crash test footage", says agency D'Arcy, also nicely developing the theme that's run through all Punto work to date - namely, the relationship between couples in cars.

Personality: The typical Fiat Punto driver is 25-35 years old, fun-loving, urban, loves Italy and all things Italian, is style-conscious, extrovert, vivacious, etc, etc, and despite what you might think from the ads, could just as well be male as female.

Financial status: You're a core Daily Mail reader, though some of you might dip into The Guardian occasionally. Either way, the Fiat Punto costs from £8,000-£11,000 - the sort of motor driven by your regular ABC1s.

Telling lifestyle detail: If you lived in London, it would be Camden or Southfields rather than Islington (too edgy) or Fulham (too posh). You probably wouldn't be seen dead in Majorca for your holidays.

Other relevant data: The ad uses real crash test footage of a Fiat Punto, shot at 1,000 frames per second, with animated dummy footage bolted on. The last two lines were improvised during filming.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Afternoon Play, The Salt March | BBC Proms 2000
fields.body:
A key episode in India's independence struggle is recalled in the Afternoon Play, The Salt March (2.15pm, Radio 4). Mahatma Gandhi's campaign against Britain's salt monopoly involved a 240-mile walk from Ahmedabad to the sea. Gandhi started with 78 companions but thousands came to hear him speak at each stopping point. After he had taken a symbolic handful of salt from the sea, he and 60,000 others were jailed. But that wasn't the answer: within a year political talks had opened.

In 1995, Georg Solti was asked to conduct a concert to celebrate the United Nations' 50th anniversary. He agreed on condition that he could assemble an orchestra from the world's finest players. The World Orchestra for Peace, comprising 85 players from 25 countries, re-assembles at the Royal Albert Hall this evening for BBC Proms 2000 (7.0pm, Radio 3). Conducted by Valery Gergiev, its main offering is Shostakovich's searing Seventh Symphony, commemorating the siege of Leningrad.

fields.headline: Dying of the light
fields.trailText: Ethel's death was a very fine EastEnders (BBC 1), and Gretchen Franklin as Eth and June Brown as Dot were downright disconcerting. Who'd have thought the old girls had so much blood in them?
fields.body:
Cheerio, my dearie-o. "There's a dance in the old dame yet..." The Song of Mehitabel.

Dylan Thomas said that, when he was a young dog in Swansea, girls came in pairs. Always one pretty and pert and always one in glasses. It is easy to see that in the East End of the 30s, Ethel would be the Clara Bow of Bow and Dot would not. This is the sort of unlikely friendship which sets in the cement of time.

Seventy years later, Ethel came home to die in Albert Square. Though, as Pauline - who found herself giving house room to a flibbertigibbet with terminal cancer - protested, "She has no family and this hasn't been her home for years." "Well, that ain't what she feels," snapped Dot.

Ethel's death was a very fine EastEnders (BBC 1), and Gretchen Franklin as Eth and June Brown as Dot were downright disconcerting. Who'd have thought the old girls had so much blood in them?

Like the remains of a fish supper, Eth was reduced to skin and bone and sauce... Plenty of sauce. "I've always been a bit of a looker, you know. Not like Plain Jane here." Plain Jane being the devoted Dot. "I had my pick of men. It was like standing in a strawberry patch of Gregory Pecks."

She was only lightly connected to the world, like the balloon tied to her wheelchair, and Dot was determined to give her the time of her life in the face of the gritted teeth of medical opinion, which favoured a nice, bright, positive hospice. "She's dying, Dot." "Well, she ain't dead yet!"

So Eth was carried triumphantly into the Vic on the shoulders of six strong men like, she said, the Queen of Sheba. Though, of course, coffins are carried that way too. Her birthday party was a roaring success, partly due to Eth's recipe for punch, which turned out to be two-thirds rum. Any resemblance to the Queen Mother's birthday is wholly coincidental.

After the ball was over, Dot tucked her up in bed and promised her a cup of cocoa with brandy in it. The years rolled back for Eth like a red carpet. "My mother used to tuck me in and then she'd bring me this 'ot chocolate. Until the war, of course, and then I'd to make do." Dot trotted round her bed, tucking and trotting, until at last they clung together like girls whispering after lights out.

The template for Dot and Eth was Ena Sharples and Minnie Caldwell in Coronation Street. Once, through some misfortune, they were thrown together with only one bed between them... "Let's 'unch up together," said Ena with unaccustomed tenderness.

EastEnders has occasional specials where two people, nearly always women, talk about birth or copulation or death. Without putting it quite like that.

This time it was death.

Dot had made Eth a birthday cake with 15 candles, which happened to be her age when they met. She couldn't blow them out. She had lung cancer. "How long have I known you, Dot?" "Seventy odd years and we've been friends all that time." "Well, that ain't true. You wouldn't even talk to me. You thought I was a fool." "But we had some times though, you and me. I've never said it but I'm very fond of you." "Yeah, I am of you." In such close up, you noticed that Dot had remarkable eyes.

She is the only religious person in Albert Square, so when Eth begged for morphine to end her life, she recoiled. "Ethel, I've spent my whole life living a certain way. I can't change now." But Eth, as pretty women do, had winning ways. "I know, Dot, but this isn't your life. This is my life. In a few days, a week, I won't be able to move. I won't be able to speak. Help me, Dot, before it's too late."

Dot took the morphine from the drawer and poured a glass of water. She said "I only want you to be 'appy." Eth was suddenly rippling with dimples, and you saw the girl in the strawberry patch. "I am. Don't cry. Oh, how silly. Never mind. I know who you are. You're the best friend I ever had." She laughed and Dot wept. If you were old enough, you recognised the song that was playing as "If it's a crime, then I'm guilty. Guilty of loving you."

Gretchen Franklin, who is 89, once said "I can play the comedy scenes or the tear-jerkers." Wicked old thing. She can too.
