fields.headline: Moscow wars
fields.standfirst:
Prostitutes hurt

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Fifteen Russian women, believed to be prostitutes, were injured yesterday when a man lobbed a grenade at them in what appeared to be the latest bout of heavily armed gang warfare erupting on the streets.
fields.body:
Fifteen Russian women, believed to be prostitutes, were injured yesterday when a man lobbed a grenade at them in what appeared to be the latest bout of heavily armed gang warfare erupting on the streets.

The women all suffered leg injuries and received hospital treatment. A man was also injured in the attack which happened at 4 o'clock in the morning.

Although Moscow is on edge exactly a year after a series of bomb blasts left almost 300 people dead, police said there was no suggestion of terrorism and blamed the incident on criminal feuding between gangs running Moscow's thriving sex industry.

Another bomb last month in the city centre killed 12 people in a pedestrian underpass. The authorities linked that blast, like last year's explosions, to Chechen "terrorists".

In separate incidents, police also reported that they had arrested two men, one from Azerbaijan and one Muscovite, in possession of plastic explosives, bomb-making equipment, TNT, ammunition, and firearms.

Earlier this week a man threw a home made bomb into a shop on a St Petersburg street. No one was injured.

The same day an explosion at a market in Ryazan south of Moscow killed three people. Both incidents were attributed to underworld feuding.

fields.headline: The story of my rape
fields.standfirst: As a student backpacking in Italy,  Mary Beard  was raped by a stranger on a night train. For more than 20 years she has been retelling the incident - to herself, as much as to other people - in an attempt to make sense of it
fields.trailText: As a student backpacking in Italy,  Mary Beard  was raped by a stranger on a night train. For more than 20 years she has been retelling the incident - to herself, as much as to other people - in an attempt to make sense of it.
fields.body:
In September 1978, on a night train from Milan, I was forced to have sex with an architect on his way to the site of a biscuit factory he was designing somewhere outside Naples (or so he claimed).

It's a simple enough story. I was a graduate student, changing trains at Milan, and laden with luggage for a term's research in Rome. There were a couple of hours to wait for the most convenient train south, so I went to the station bar on the lookout, I suppose, for an opportunity to wheel out my still very faltering Italian. The architect was there, on the lookout too, presumably. Discovering that I had no couchette for the journey, he insisted on trying to book one for me; he took my ticket (which I meekly gave him), returned triumphant and then helped me with my cases and backpack to the train. Predictably enough, as it now seems (though I'm sure I didn't foresee it at the time), what he had actually booked was a two-berth first-class wagon-lit. He bundled me in, took off my clothes and had sex, before departing to the upper bunk. I woke a few hours later just outside Rome to find him on top of me again, humping away - taking his last chance before handing me over to the sleeping-car steward to be deposited on the platform, while he no doubt slept on to Naples.

The only face I have chosen to remember (or perhaps recreate) from the whole incident belongs to this steward, the sly and uncomfortably knowing face of a man who had recognised exactly what was going on and had seen it all before, many times. As he pressed a small plastic cup of coffee into my hand in a routine way, I could tell that it would have been useless appealing to him for help, even if I'd had the chance.

To all intents and purposes this was rape. I did not want to have sex with the man and had certainly not given consent. If I appeared to be compliant, it was because I had no option: I was in a foreign city, with enough of the local language to ask directions to the cathedral maybe, but not to search out a reliable protector and explain convincingly what was happening.

If no violence was used, it was because the man's weapon was my own tiredness (a mind set on sleep, rather than watching for the telltale signs of danger) and the luggage. With two heavy cases and a backpack, I couldn't make a dash for it. Nor could I just abandon a couple of pieces: never mind the clothes; I had spread my precious thesis and all the notes carefully through the different cases (a misplaced faith in the eggs-in-one-basket caveat, as it turned out).

That said, I can't claim to have been particularly traumatised by what happened. I suffered no subsequent aversion to late-night trains, foreign railway stations or even Neapolitan biscuits; and I would give my eyeteeth to be able to zoom around Europe in a first-class wagon-lit - something I haven't been able to afford since.

Instead, I nursed some strange and oddly misplaced grudges. One was against the funding council that was sponsoring my research; for had they not insisted, I reasoned, on my using the cheapest method of transport (at that time, a train), and allowed me to go by plane instead, none of this would have happened. Another was against the friend who had been going to travel with me - even though it was I who had changed my plans and had come on later. Another was against the biscuit-factory man himself, not so much for what he did, but for doing it twice. Even now, more than 20 years later, I can still rage at the memory of waking up to find him doing it again.

If all this suggests that I'm letting my rapist off comparatively lightly, that is partly because in the intervening years the retelling of this story (to myself as much as to other people) has generated quite other interpretations of what went on, which coexist - and compete - with the account I've just given.

The first of these is the predictable slide from "rape" to "seduction": I wasn't overpowered or coerced; whatever happened in the station bar, it amounted to "persuasion" or to an exercise of choice on my part. In fact, something like that was the first euphemistic version I chose to tell my friends on arriving in Rome: I had, I complained, been "picked up" in Milan and ended up in bed with the guy on the train; I never mentioned the word "rape".

But I have also caught myself making sense of the whole incident as a much more emphatically willed part of my sexual history: the perfect degree-zero sexual encounter between complete strangers, happening in no single place but on the move, in the more or less exotic (or at least cinematically resonant) location of a wagon-lit.

In this version, any seduction was done - however inadvertently - by me; the triumph was my own. In pointing to this ambivalence in my responses, I'm not intending to condone the rapist, nor to weaken the case for seeing rape in general as a crime of male violence and male power over women. I'm also well aware that I got off extremely lightly, and that there are many victims of rape for whom an "ambivalent response" would be an undreamed-of luxury. (I can see, conversely, that my alternative versions of this encounter could so easily be interpreted as classic exercises of denial, or refusal to face the rape as rape.)

What I am trying to highlight is the crucial importance, both culturally and personally, of rape narratives. For rape is always a (contested) story, as well as an event; and it is through the telling of rape-as-story, in its different versions, its shifting nuances, that cultures have always debated most intensely some of the unfathomable conflicts of sexual relations and sexual identity.

The tale of the rape of Lucretia, for example, is hardly tellable - as many Roman writers themselves discovered - without raising the question of where seduction ends and rape begins; the rape of the Sabines puts a similar question mark over the distinction between rape and marriage. In fact, almost every narrative of sexual coercion (including my own) forces its teller to confront the question of sex as something women do, or something they have done to them; and of how a slightly different spin on the rape story can lead to an entirely different answer.

Narratives also take much longer in the telling than the event itself. It is now a truism of feminist sociology that the courtroom testimony of the rape victim amounts to a replay of the rape; a re-rape. But it doesn't stop there. The fact that I have taken care to recall my own relatively harmless encounter with sexual coercion more than 20 years ago is not so much to do with its unforgettable trauma, but with the psychic and ideological function that remembering the event still fulfils.

I may well be a bad judge of what that function is; but my sense is that the narrative was not only a useful way of understanding my own post-adolescent sexual experience at the time (what exactly was I doing?), but has been an important focus for rethinking that experience from the perspective now of motherhood and middle age. The same must be true for hundreds of thousands of women with equally tawdry, everyday stories of sexual coercion to tell. Remembering rape is about making sense of sex.

 Dr Mary Beard is a reader in classics at Newnham college, Cambridge. This is an edited version of an article that first appeared in the London Review of Books.To subscribe to the LRB call 020-7209 1141

But I have also caught myself making sense of the whole incident as a much more emphatically willed part of my sexual history: the perfect degree-zero sexual encounter between complete strangers, happening in no single place but on the move, in the more or less exotic (or at least cinematically resonant) location of a wagon-lit. In this version, any seduction was done - however inadvertently - by me; the triumph was my own. In pointing to this ambivalence in my responses, I'm not intending to condone the rapist, nor to weaken the case for seeing rape in general as a crime of male violence and male power over women. I'm also well aware that I got off extremely lightly, and that there are many victims of rape for whom an "ambivalent response" would be an undreamed-of luxury. (I can see, conversely, that my alternative versions of this encounter could so easily be interpreted as classic exercises of denial, or refusal to face the rape as rape.) What I am trying to highlight is the crucial importance, both culturally and personally, of rape narratives. For rape is always a (contested) story, as well as an event; and it is through the telling of rape-as-story, in its different versions, its shifting nuances, that cultures have always debated most intensely some of the unfathomable conflicts of sexual relations and sexual identity. The tale of the rape of Lucretia, for example, is hardly tellable - as many Roman writers themselves discovered - without raising the question of where seduction ends and rape begins; the rape of the Sabines puts a similar question mark over the distinction between rape and marriage. In fact, almost every narrative of sexual coercion (including my own) forces its teller to confront the question of sex as something women do, or something they have done to them; and of how a slightly different spin on the rape story can lead to an entirely different answer. Narratives also take much longer in the telling than the event itself. It is now a truism of feminist sociology that the courtroom testimony of the rape victim amounts to a replay of the rape; a re-rape. But it doesn't stop there. The fact that I have taken care to recall my own relatively harmless encounter with sexual coercion more than 20 years ago is not so much to do with its unforgettable trauma, but with the psychic and ideological function that remembering the event still fulfils. I may well be a bad judge of what that function is; but my sense is that the narrative was not only a useful way of understanding my own post-adolescent sexual experience at the time (what exactly was I doing?), but has been an important focus for rethinking that experience from the perspective now of motherhood and middle age. The same must be true for hundreds of thousands of women with equally tawdry, everyday stories of sexual coercion to tell. Remembering rape is about making sense of sex.  Dr Mary Beard is a reader in classics at Newnham college, Cambridge. fields.headline: No: 1716
fields.standfirst: Jeremy Kane
fields.trailText: Jeremy Kane
fields.body:
Stop the presses! Clinton having affair with a White House intern! Oh, please. Monica Lewinsky is, like, so last decade. Give poor Bill a break.

No, no, new century, new Clinton romantic exploits. Ah, you must be referring to the heart-warming news that young Chelsea has found love.

Indeed. So tell me about this dashing young swain. He has the fine and upstanding name of Jeremy Kane, is 21 years old and met Chelsea at university. He is currently an intern in the White House's speech-writing department and he and Chelsea have been an item for a year, bless 'em.

Still, that dark hair, those flashing eyes, that fixed smile, clutching the arm of a Clinton - there is something worryingly familiar here. Yes, it does seem that the quickest way to a Clinton's heart is through a White House internship.

Presumably Hillary welcomed this besotted intern into the family with more enthusiasm than the last one her family had dealings with? Apparently so. Young Jeremy spent last New Year's Eve and Easter with the Clinton family and was their guest at this year's Democratic Convention in Los Angeles.

How cosy. But isn't Chelsea coming to Britain soon? Sadly for Jeremy, she has her sights set on studying at Oxford, as her father did before her.

And is this Chelsea's first love affair? Not quite. In fact, they met when she was going out with Jeremy's friend, Matthew Pierce. Matthew, however, quit the scene as he found the constant presence of the secret service put a bit of a crimp in his social life.

Oxford-bound, tempestuous lovelife, romancing an intern... Truly, Chelsea does seem to be her father's daughter. Yes, with the obvious exception that so far she has apparently done nothing to merit being pulled up in front of the senate and we have yet to hear ugly details of her bedroom habits.

Do say: "Aww, isn't young love beautiful?"

Don't say: "Fancy a cigar, Chelsea?"

webTitle: Turkish police block gay tour from Roman ruins

fields.headline: Turkish police block gay tour from Roman ruins
fields.trailText: Turkey's tourism minister apologised yesterday after hundreds of gay tourists were prevented by local police from entering the coastal town of Kusadasi and the nearby Roman ruins at Ephesus.
fields.body:
Turkey's tourism minister apologised yesterday after hundreds of gay tourists were prevented by local police from entering the coastal town of Kusadasi and the nearby Roman ruins at Ephesus.

"I hope they will complete their trip without any problems," the minister, Erkan Mumcu, said. "We cannot discriminate according to people's sexual preference."

The group of 833 gay men, including a number of Britons, arrived in Turkey on Wednesday on the cruise liner Olympic Voyager on its way from Israel.

Several bus loads of men on their way to the spectacular ruins at Ephesus were turned back by the police. Others were prevented from entering the town of Kusadasi to go shopping.

"When we got back, a guy from the ship just said: 'Get on the ship as fast as you can,' " Ken Damon from Tucson, Arizona said. "We were going to spend two weeks in Kusadasi, but we don't want to be in a country that doesn't respect us."

Local people, including the mayor, were also quick to apologise. "This is against human rights," Haci Kahveci, a local tradesman said. "If it happens again we'll take action. It shouldn't be tolerated."

Most of the gay tourists were from the United States. The US embassy contacted Turkish authorities to demand that the Americans be allowed to travel freely. By then, however, the damage had been done.

One of the organisers of the tour, Jonathan Evrin, said they had visited Turkey last year without encountering any problems, and he was at a loss to explain the sudden change in attitude.

Homosexuality is not technically illegal in Turkey, but officials said yesterday that there was a clause in the passport law which could allow the authorities to prevent gays entering the country. The local gay community complains of constant discrimination, even though many gay singers are very popular.

Yesterday the tourists moved on to Istanbul, where they were shadowed by a heavy police presence. Riot police and motorcycle outriders accompanied the tourist buses as they visited some of the city's best known sites.

The interior minister had issued a personal guarantee that the tourists would be safe, but there are red faces in the bureaucracy over an incident which has not done much for Turkey's image as a hospitable tourist destination.

fields.headline: Police to challenge jury verdict
fields.standfirst: Special report: deaths in custody
fields.trailText: Five policemen who stood chatting as a black, former paratrooper choked to death on a police station floor, are to challenge an inquest verdict that he was unlawfully killed. The officers will question why unlawful killing was given as an option to the jury at Hull coroner's court where the inquest into the death of Christopher Alder took place in July and August.
fields.body:
Five policemen who stood chatting as a black, former paratrooper choked to death on a police station floor, are to challenge an inquest verdict that he was unlawfully killed. The officers will question why unlawful killing was given as an option to the jury at Hull coroner's court where the inquest into the death of Christopher Alder took place in July and August.

Mr Alder, who was 37, was arrested after arguments over treatment at Hull royal infirmary, where he was taken after a fight outside a nightclub in the city on April 1 1998. His death was recorded by security cameras at Hull police station, where the officers said they thought he was play acting or asleep.

The crown prosecution service is reviewing its decision to charge the men - Sgt John Dunn and PCs Matthew Barr, Neil Blakey, Nigel Dawson and Mark Ellerington - with misconduct in public office.

The solicitor of Mr Alder's family, Ruth Bundy, called at the inquest for the CPS to consider a manslaughter prosecution.

Andy Jarratt, chairman of Humberside police federation, which is supporting the officers, said: "They [the officers] are simply following the advice of our legal team to take this action."

Mr Alder's sister Janet, who has campaigned for a full explanation of her brother's death for more than two years, said: "It's absolutely disgusting. It shows once again the disrespect for Christopher's right to life."

webTitle: Cleft palates linked to pregnancy stress

fields.headline: Cleft palates linked to pregnancy stress
fields.trailText: Severe emotional stress during pregnancy may cause malformations such as a cleft palate in the baby, according to research published in this week's Lancet medical journal.
fields.body:
Severe emotional stress during pregnancy may cause malformations such as a cleft palate in the baby, according to research published in this week's Lancet medical journal.

Psychosocial stress affects the nervous system, hormone production, and the cardiovascular, metabolic and immune systems, say researchers.

"If stress is severe or prolonged, it could in theory induce congenital malformations through cortisone, one of the major stress hormones," write Dorthe Hansen and colleagues from the John F Kennedy Institute in Glostrup, Denmark.

Cortisone given to pregnant mice, they say, increases the risk of the young being born with a cleft palate, shortening of the head, shortening of the mandible and spina bifida. Some human studies have suggested that women with unwanted pregnancies are more likely to have a congenitally malformed baby, and stressful life events in pregnancy such as job loss, separation or bereavement have been associated with defects such as cleft lip and palate in babies.

To try to establish the real risk of severe stress in pregnancy, the Danish researchers identified women who suffered the death or life threatening illness of an older child or their partner while they were pregnant or up to 16 months previously, between 1980 and 1992.

They identified 3,560 such pregnancies, and randomly selected 20,299 others for comparison. Then they looked for malformations of what is known as the cranial-neural-crest (cleft lip and palate and heart malformations) which are thought to be vulnerable to environmental factors.

They found that women who suffered severe stress while pregnant were more likely to have a baby with congenital malformation such as a cleft palate, especially if the stressful event was the death of a child and if it occurred within the first three months of the pregnancy.

No significant effect was seen after the death or serious illness, cancer or heart attack, of a partner. "Severe life events in children may on average cause more stress in the woman than severe life events in partners," they write.

webTitle: Tube lesson helps save Pisa's tower

fields.headline: Tube lesson helps save Pisa's tower
fields.trailText: After 10 years of drama, the tower of Pisa is leaning a little less. Yesterday its tip had moved 23cm back towards the vertical.
fields.body:
After 10 years of drama, the tower of Pisa is leaning a little less. Yesterday its tip had moved 23cm back towards the vertical.

John Burland, a soil engineer and professor at Imperial College, London, is instrumental in the £15m plan to save Italy's most famous construction error.

He told the British Association the tower was moving back at 1.5mm a day, as 15 cubic metres of soft silt and clay were gently sucked from underneath the foundations at one side.

The aim was to move its highest point 45cm, restoring the tilt to what it had been before a lurch in 1838.

Professor Burland was the soil engineer who estimated the possible tilt of the tower of the Houses of Parliament with the construction of an underground car park in 1970. "We didn't do too badly, but the clock tower moved in the opposite direction from the one we predicted," he confessed.

In 1990 he joined a commission set up by the Italian prime minister to stabilise Pisa's tower, the ultimate civil engineering challenge.

Previously he had helped in the 40-metre deep excavation of the Jubilee tube line under Big Ben, and here he used the experience of the 1970s in order to protect the tower by gently injecting 132 cubic metres of grout (sand and cement) under it.

The solution adopted to rescue Pisa was a mirror image of that for Big Ben. "Instead of pumping grout on the low side of the tower - which would have had it over, it was so close to collapse - we did the reverse. We have been extracting soil from below the high side, which is a very novel technology."

Work began at the start of the year. Prof Burland has controlled the project from his office at Imperial College. "It is a bit like riding a bicycle by fax," he said, "and we are about halfway there."

The tower leans at 5.5 degrees from the vertical, and the aim is to bring it back half a degree. Work stopped for the August holiday and resumed on Monday, aiming for an official reopening on the feast of San Renieri, patron saint of Pisa, on June 16 2001.

The building was begun in 1173 as the bell tower of Pisa's cathedral, and, as construction proceeded with interruptions over 200 years, the tilt began and was partly corrected for in the design of the upper tiers.

fields.headline: Angel heralds heaven-sent mobile solution
fields.trailText: One might argue that angels and mobile phones have much in common, delivering messages from another world that are frequently disturbing, incomprehensible or abruptly terminated.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
One might argue that angels and mobile phones have much in common, delivering messages from another world that are frequently disturbing, incomprehensible or abruptly terminated.

One of England's most prominent angels, the 15ft golden weather vane that soars over Guildford cathedral high on its hill above the Surrey town, will soon serve both God and mammon, rising towards heaven on a One-to-One radio mast.

When the angel is replaced on Monday, having been regilded with real gold leaf at a cost of £20,000 paid for by the phone company, the pillar on which the vane rotates will appear unchanged, but will be a new steel structure concealing a base station and masts.

Phone companies have long seen churches as a heaven-sent solution to their problems, and have often been welcomed with open arms by parishes at their wits' end to meet maintenance bills.

The companies have fought bruising battles with residents over siting base stations and masts, exacerbated by the unresolved scientific debate over possible long term health implications of the radio waves. There are believed to be more than 20,000 masts in Britain, and an estimated 100,000 more will be needed over the decade.

Against this background, thousands of churches, typically sited on the highest point of the surrounding land scape, isolated and with tall towers, appear a godsend.

Although the practice has made conservation groups and some worshippers uneasy, it is blessed by John Prescott's environment department, and the Anglican and Catholic church authorities have each said that any decision rests with individual churches.

Hundreds carry some mobile phone equipment, often disguised as flagpoles or lightning conductors. In return the churches get a rent, £3,000 to £30,000 a year, depending on the equipment, and often get help with restoration work when it is installed.

The 12th century St Mary Redcliffe in Bristol has Vodaphone masts and cables concealed in the 292ft spire that Elizabeth I called "the fairest in England". St Mary's vicar, Rev Tony Whatmough, said cheerfully: "The church has always been involved in the business of communication."

However, the Churches Conservation Trust said it believed any approaches should be very carefully considered, both for aesthetic and potential long term safety reasons.

The Grade II* listed Guildford cathedral was designed by Sir Edward Maulf in 1936 but not completed until the 1960s, when the angel, designed by a local metalworker, William Pickford, was added.

Cathedral administrator Bill Evershed called the deal "a win win" situation for the cathedral and for One-to-One, which needed to update equipment sited on the roof since 1993. There had been no objections, he said.

fields.headline: Anarchy of hands behaving badly
fields.trailText: Anarchic hand syndrome is so grotesque it verges on the comic, and is one of neurology's most puzzling phenomena, according to Sergio Della Salla, a consultant at the University of Aberdeen.
fields.body:
Anarchic hand syndrome is so grotesque it verges on the comic, and is one of neurology's most puzzling phenomena, according to Sergio Della Salla, a consultant at the University of Aberdeen.

He told the British Association that some cases of brain damage resulted in a hand doing the opposite of what its owner intended.

"One of our patients once, at dinner, much to her dismay saw her left hand taking fish bones from leftovers and putting them into her mouth," he said. "Another complained her hand did what it wanted, and she tried to control its drifting by hitting it or talking to it in anger and frustration."

The syndrome was demonstrated by Peter Sellers in the film Dr Strangelove, when he grabbed his arm to prevent a Nazi salute.

Another researcher reported that an anarchic hand patient had problems in choosing TV channels because, as soon as the right hand selected one station, the left hand would press another button. Patients with the condition behaved as if they two streams of consciousness. Prof Della Salla said such symptoms "should make us think about our concepts of agency, and free will".

webTitle: Stem cell 'repair kit' for stroke victims

fields.headline: Stem cell 'repair kit' for stroke victims
fields.standfirst: British Association Foetus tissue may aid paralysed patients
fields.trailText: Patients crippled by stroke could next year have stem cells injected into their brains to restore movement in paralysed limbs.
fields.body:
Patients crippled by stroke could next year have stem cells injected into their brains to restore movement in paralysed limbs.

The cells are part of an "immortal" stockpile of cells taken from an aborted foetus, treated with a gene taken from a monkey cancer virus, and grown in laboratory dishes by a British biotech company called ReNeuron.

Tissue from one foetus could be used to treat 1,000 patients, the British Association for the Advancement of Science's annual festival, Creating Sparks, at Imperial College, London, was told yesterday.

There are 140,000 stroke victims a year in Britain. Blood clots interrupt the supply of oxygen to the brain and cells die.

Two years ago, scientists learned how to manipulate stem cells - the natural machinery that allows a fertilised egg to turn into a human composed of 100 trillion cells of more than 200 different kinds.

But stem cells are a challenge to science. They make new blood, liver, or nerve tissue, but there is nothing to distinguish them from the cells around them.

"We define them on the basis of their behaviour and what we know now is that they exist throughout our lives," said Dr John Sinden, chief scientist of ReNeuron. "Stem cells are normal cells. They keep dividing but they can only divide a limited number of times, so that we gradually lose them through life."

Stem cells also exist in the brain. Most of the body rejects transplanted tissue, but other experiments have shown that the brain will accept foreign cells.

The ReNeuron researchers injected mouse brain stem cells into rats damaged by stroke, and watched the rodents recover. The hope is that under the right conditions, foetal brain stem cells implanted into the brains of adult stroke victims will move around and begin repairing damaged parts of the brain.

The scientists used a mutant gene from a simian virus to "immortalise" the donated foetal stem cells, and kept them multiplying at 33C. The gene is switched off at 36C. The normal human temperature is 38C. So once the stem cells were implanted in a human brain, they would stop multiplying indiscriminately - that is, they could not start a tumour. But they could, in theory at least, begin to form new cells for injured brains.

"The brain is a highly specialised organ and it seems to have lost the capacity to use stem cells through evolution, probably because it is a specialisation: it needs to retain a kind of fixedness about its make-up," said Dr Sinden.

"But nevertheless it retains a capacity to respond to stem cells. So if we can actually apply stem cells, then the brain will use those stem cells, particularly the damaged brain."

"Our approach is to take stem cells from different regions of the developing brain, so that we can take a cell from the region that is most affected by stroke," he said. "That is going to be our stroke cell line.

"We can take cells from the region affected by Alzheimer's disease and that is going to be our Alzheimer's cell line. And cells from the region affected by Parkinson's are going to be our Parkinson's cell line.

webTitle: Pacemaker cut from body with penknife

fields.headline: Pacemaker cut from body with penknife
fields.trailText: Police are investigating the case of a GP who borrowed a penknife to cut a pacemaker from the chest of an 81-year-old patient who had just died in her own home.
fields.body:
Police are investigating the case of a GP who borrowed a penknife to cut a pacemaker from the chest of an 81-year-old patient who had just died in her own home.

It is alleged that he used the penknife after asking the woman's daughter for a carving knife and then rejecting it.

The south Manchester coroner, John Pollard, ordered the inquiry after being notified by an undertaker who was shocked to discover an unstitched two-and-a-half inch wound when he arrived to collect the body of Edna Everson, who had died at her bungalow in Bramhall, Greater Manchester, after a long illness.

Dr Arepalli Krishnamurthy had been called to the house to certify Mrs Everson's death.

Last night Stockport health authority described the actions of Dr Krishnamurthy, 56, as "unexpected and inappropriate".

"There is no dispute about the facts of the matter," said Peter Milnes, the authority's chief executive. "Dr Krishnamurthy was interviewed as a matter of urgency and the incident is now being reviewed by the health authority's GP panel and a report is expected next week."

Dr Krishnamurthy, known as Dr Murthy, is not treating patients at present and a locum is working at his surgery in Stockport.

Mrs Everson's daughter Jennifer, 55, who cared for her mother until her death last month, said the doctor had behaved insensitively.

"He marched in and asked for a knife to take the pacemaker out," she told the Manchester Evening News. "I presumed that was normal procedure. He didn't explain why he was doing it."

Dr Krishnamurthy borrowed the penknife from Mrs Everson's neighbour, Geoffrey Conley.

"[The doctor] simply made an incision and took it out," he said. "It took between 10 and 30 seconds. He turned round and put the pacemaker in my hand. I put it on the chest of drawers."

Pacemakers are routinely removed from bodies to avoid the risk of explosion during cremation. But the procedure is usually carried out by undertakers.

"This is not a situation which any of our companies has come across before," said a spokesman for the group to which the funeral firm belongs. "Once the documentation is completed, pacemakers are removed as part of the embalming process."

A spokeswoman for the British Medical Association said it would be very unusual for a pacemaker to be removed soon after death in a patient's home."There needs to be respect for patients and their families," she added.

Det Chief Inspector Kenny Caldwell of Stockport CID said: "We have been directed by the coroner to make inquiries into the incident on his behalf. We are doing so. The full details will be reported back to the coroner and the health authority."

Dr Krishnamurthy was not available for comment yesterday. At his surgery he was said to be on leave.

webTitle: Court backs ban on Gypsy fair

fields.headline: Court backs ban on Gypsy fair
fields.trailText: The high court yesterday refused to overturn an order banning a horse fair which was set to attract thousands of Gypsies to a Kent village this weekend.
fields.body:
The high court yesterday refused to overturn an order banning a horse fair which was set to attract thousands of Gypsies to a Kent village this weekend.

The Gypsy Council and Eli Frankham, who - like his forefathers - has been going to the fair at Horsmonden all his life, had claimed that the decision to stop the event, which takes place on the village green every second Sunday of September, was an "unnecessary overreaction".

Their counsel, Jan Luba QC, told deputy judge David Pannick in London that to the Romany community the fair was "an essential part of their remaining limited calendar of social and cultural events and its existence is integral to their traditional way of life".

But the judge, who had to give his ruling before 6pm when the order banning the fair under the 1986 Public Order Act was due to start, said Tunbridge Wells borough council and the home secretary had acted lawfully. The order lasts until Monday morning.

He said it was surprising that the Romany community had not made its challenge in April when the local parish council decided to cancel the fair - the first step in the process.

The parish council said the fair had outgrown the village, giving rise to disorder and disruption to the community.

The judge said the impact of the cancellation was mitigated by the existence, 20 miles away at Dartford, of an alternative private site for the fair.

He made no order for costs and refused permission to appeal.

fields.headline: Flexible work hours in demand
fields.trailText: Margaret Hodge, the junior equal opportunities minister, last night sought to "kill the myth" that employees without childcare responsibilities resented workmates on flexible contracts who rushed home to look after families.
fields.body:
Margaret Hodge, the junior equal opportunities minister, last night sought to "kill the myth" that employees without childcare responsibilities resented workmates on flexible contracts who rushed home to look after families.

She published early results from a national survey of 7,500 employees showing that demand for flexible working was equally strong among those with caring responsibilities and those without. In both groups 19% want to be able to work part-time.

Demand for flexitime was similar among both groups, with 37% of the carers and 34% of non-carers wanting that option. Just over a quarter of both groups wanted to be able to work from home.

"A better balance between work and life is an issue for everyone," Ms Hodge said.

The survey in 2,500 workplaces and 250 company headquarters showed 24% of all employees currently work flexitime, but 36% would like the opportunity to do so.

webTitle: Womb risk found in cancer drug

fields.headline: Womb risk found in cancer drug
fields.trailText: Tamoxifen, lauded as the nearest thing possible to a miracle drug for breast cancer, holds a serious risk of womb cancer for women who use it long-term, says a study in this week's Lancet medical journal.
fields.body:
Tamoxifen, lauded as the nearest thing possible to a miracle drug for breast cancer, holds a serious risk of womb cancer for women who use it long-term, says a study in this week's Lancet medical journal.

Dutch researchers who studied more than 300 women on tamoxifen say that the benefits of the drug for those who have suffered breast cancer still far outweigh the risks. But they suggest the drug may not be suitable for preventing disease in healthy women with a high risk of developing breast cancer.

Tamoxifen has been used for two decades to treat breast cancer.

It has been so effective that scientists have regularly investigated and then established new ways of using it against the different stages of the disease.

But the Dutch paper is sobering, an editorial in the Lancet reflects.

While the increased risk of cancer of the endometrium (lining of the womb) has been well known, it has been assumed that those cancers that developed as a side-effect of the drug were not severe. Instead, Liesbeth Bergman and colleagues from the Netherlands Cancer Institute, Amsterdam, report that the endometrial cancers they found were advanced and less likely to have a favourable outcome than those in women who had not taken tamoxifen.

The risk of endometrial cancer increased with the length of time the woman had taken the drug. Survival rates were 77% among long-term tamoxifen users compared with 94% among non-users.

Leading investigator Flora van Leeuwen said: "We do not think that this unexpected result has consequences for the treatment of breast cancer patients, because the survival benefits of tamoxifen for breast cancer far outweigh the adverse effects."

fields.headline: Dramatic entrance
fields.standfirst: 'Oiky' Burke praises young playwrights
fields.trailText: The actor Kathy Burke confessed yesterday she was so frustrated that no one would cast "an oiky bird" like her that she started writing plays for herself.
fields.body:
The actor Kathy Burke confessed yesterday she was so frustrated that no one would cast "an oiky bird" like her that she started writing plays for herself.

Burke, 36, a north Londoner who won best actress at Cannes for her part in Nil by Mouth and appeared in the Oscar-winning Elizabeth, said many writers assumed working class actors like her were stupid.

As she launched the Royal Court's Young Writers Festival, she said often the only way to get a decent part was to write it. She won a Time Out award for her play Mr Thomas.

"Young writers are much more open and write about the world as it is, so they have more real characters. You hear a lot of older actors complaining that there are no parts for them out there. But it is young writers who write the best parts for older people. I can't wait to be an old bag so I can get a few of them."

Four one-hour plays by writers as young as 15 will be performed at the Sloane Square theatre next month, as well as rehearsed readings of four others drawn from more than 400 scripts submitted.

webTitle: Islanders sue in US over impact of Rio Tinto mine

fields.headline: Islanders sue in US over impact of Rio Tinto mine
fields.trailText: Using an 18th-century American law designed to combat piracy on the high seas, the people of Bougainville island in Papua New Guinea have filed a damages claim in California against Rio Tinto, the Anglo-Australian mining giant based in London.
fields.body:
Using an 18th-century American law designed to combat piracy on the high seas, the people of Bougainville island in Papua New Guinea have filed a damages claim in California against Rio Tinto, the Anglo-Australian mining giant based in London.

The suit, alleging that years of copper mining by the company harmed the environmental and human rights on the island, was filed on Wednesday at a San Francisco federal court under the Alien Tort Claims Act 1789. It allows foreign nationals to sue American companies for alleged human rights violations committed abroad.

Rio Tinto said: "We categorically reject the claims. They have no merit whatsoever." A hearing has yet to be fixed to see if the US court will accept jurisdiction. The claimants' lawyers are hoping the court will agree on the basis that Rio Tinto has extensive mining interests in the US, including California.

The company, the third largest mining conglomerate in the world, owns, through a subsidiary, 53% of the huge Panguna copper mine - a hole in the forest 3.7 miles long, 2.5 miles wide and a third of a mile deep.

It was opened in 1972 but shut in 1989 when complaints about environmental damage grew into armed conflict over the island's mineral wealth between the government of Papua New Guinea and the Bougainville Revolutionary Army. An eight-year guerrilla war ensued.

The legal claim, filed by a Seattle lawyer, Steve Berman, alleges that the company brought financial influence to bear on Papua New Guinea's government, which is accused by the plaintiffs of killing 15,000 islanders through aerial bombing, village-burning and other acts of destruction.

It says that the company razed forests, polluted rivers, retarded crop growth and caused birth defects. The island has a population of about 170,000.

Mr Berman said: "We intend to prove that Rio Tinto treated Bourgainvilleans with no respect and thought of them as inferior in every way: socially, economically, racially and politically."

The Alien Tort Claims Act was passed in 1789 to allow victims of theft by pirates at sea to sue onshore. Since 1980 there have been cases where federal courts have ruled that individuals and companies can stand trial in the US for crimes abroad, even if the plaintiffs are foreigners.

The first case against a company was two years ago when a Los Angeles judge ruled that the US oil company Unocal could stand trial for human rights abuses committed by the authorities in Burma on behalf of Unocal. In April another California judge ruled that another oil company, Chevron, could be tried in the US for abuses committed by Nigerian police against people living in the delta area where the oil is pumped.

Three years ago the Panguna mine achieved international notoriety when Papua New Guinea brought in a private British military company, Sandline, to quell the rebellion using mercenaries from South Africa.

The resulting scandal and a backlash by elements of Papua New Guinea's military led to Sandline being told to leave the country and the government falling.

The successor government agreed yesterday - after two years of peace talks with Bougainville representatives - to consider a proposal for a referendum on Bougainville's status which could include questions on autonomy or independence.

webTitle: New York arrests signal resurgence of Mafia

fields.headline: New York arrests signal resurgence of Mafia
fields.trailText: Thirty-eight people and 11 companies stood accused yesterday of bleeding millions of dollars from the construction industry in a racket run by the Mafia, believed until recently to be in terminal decline.
fields.body:
Thirty-eight people and 11 companies stood accused yesterday of bleeding millions of dollars from the construction industry in a racket run by the Mafia, believed until recently to be in terminal decline.

Union officials, contractors and reputed members of the Lucchese crime family were among those charged with a racket in which a 5% "mob tax" was levied on work in New York, worth $40m (about £27m) over the past three years.

Steven Crea, said to be the Lucchese family's 53-year-old acting boss, and 10 other members or associates of organised crime were alleged to have bought off corrupt union leaders and extorted money from contractors by promising protection from other mobsters.

The projects included building three schools, road and bridge repairs and work on the Park Central hotel in midtown Manhattan, formerly known as the Park Sheraton, where the fabled hitman Albert Anastasia was shot dead in a barber's chair 43 years ago.

The Mafia's grip on the construction industry was thought to have been broken after dozens of gangsters, building firms and union officials were convicted in the late 1980s and early 90s.

"The price of liberty is eternal vigilance," said Robert Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. "You can't declare victory and walk away. The fight against organised crime is far from over."

The power and influence of New York's so-called Five Families were reduced drastically by internecine warfare and aggressive legal action, with a large measure of the credit taken by Rudy Giuliani, then a prosecutor and now the city's mayor.

When John Gotti, the Teflon Don who headed the Gambino family, was jailed for life for murder and racketeering in 1992, that was taken to be the mob's nadir.

Popular culture has taken to representing the Mafia as warped buffoons rather than figures from a corpse-strewn opera, the most recent examples being the television series The Sopranos, Analyze This, the movie starring Robert De Niro, and Jim Jarmusch's film Ghost Dog.

But there have been signs of regrouping and claims that the Bonanno family, thought 10 years ago to be on the brink of expiring, has forged its way back to a position second only to the dominant Genovese.

This is said to be the work of one Joe Massino, an unflashy character who has imposed order and discipline on an organisation that supposedly specialises in the relatively low-risk areas of illegal book-making and loan-sharking.

"I don't believe there is such a thing as the Mafia," said Mr Massino. "A bunch of Italians go out to eat and they say it's the Mafia."

fields.headline: Chicken won
fields.standfirst: McDonald's takes a cue from the hit film and demands better conditions for hens used to supply eggs for its McMuffins
fields.trailText: It could be called the Chicken Run effect. McDonald's, bogey-figure to environmentalists and vegetarians throughout the world, finds itself under fire from the American egg industry for being too soft-hearted towards hens with its new requirements for egg farmers.
fields.body:
It could be called the Chicken Run effect. McDonald's, bogey-figure to environmentalists and vegetarians throughout the world, finds itself under fire from the American egg industry for being too soft-hearted towards hens with its new requirements for egg farmers.

McDonald's, anxious perhaps to repair its somewhat tattered reputation with those concerned with animal welfare, has introduced new conditions that egg producers must meet if they wish to supply the corporation with eggs for its McMuffins.

Egg producers must cease immediately the practice of withdrawing food and water to stimulate egg production, end beak trimming and, by the end of 2001, increase the space allotted to a hen by 50% to 72 square inches - eight inches by nine inches or 20cm by 23cm.

The requirements fall short of what animal welfare supporters would seek for hens and cannot be described as free range, but they have been welcomed by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta). A spokeswoman for Peta said: "What McDonald's has done will spare 5m hens a great deal of suffering."

McDonald's is enjoying its moment on the high ground and said that it would carry out spot checks to ensure that egg producers meet the requirements.

Egg producers have been told that if they do not meet the new conditions they will be struck off the list of agreed suppliers.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Floods spread rat disease
fields.body:
Floods spread rat disease

A disease spread from rat urine is killing more people in Thailand this year than at any time in almost 60 years, the health ministry said yesterday.

At least 182 people have died from leptospirosis because heavy flooding has made conditions good for bacteria.

AP, Bangkok

Mines deployed in 20 conflicts

Landmines are in use by 11 governments and at least 30 rebel groups in 20 conflicts, the British-based group Landmine Action said yesterday.

The heaviest use since March 1999, it said, was in Chechnya, mainly by Russian forces, and in Kosovo, primarily by Yugoslav forces but also by the Kosovo Liberation Army.

Other areas include Georgia, Burma, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Afghanistan, on the Eritrea-Ethiopia border, Colombia, south Lebanon, Turkey and northern Iraq. Anti-personnel mines are, in theory, banned by treaty.

Richard Norton-Taylor

fields.headline: Alex Cox
fields.trailText: Home Entertainment: Will Hodgkinson finds that director Alex Cox's tastes are as catholic as his creations
fields.body:
Alex Cox is an anarchic director. He made his first movie, the punk classic Repo Man, on Hollywood money, then did his best to get as far away from Tinseltown as possible.

"The film director's career is designed to take you to Hollywood - Alan Parker is a good example. He started on commercials, then he made films that glorify the FBI," says Cox, referring to his fellow compatriot's film Mississippi Burning. "Now he's head of the Film Council."

Cox's career has taken a different path. Between occasional acting jobs and presenting the BBC's Moviedrome, he has made the junkie saga Sid and Nancy, the spaghetti western homage Straight to Hell, the Nicaraguan odyssey Walker, and the Spanish-language police-corruption drama, Highway Patrolman. "After Sid and Nancy, I kept getting junkie scripts, which was the last thing I wanted to do."

Cox's tastes are as catholic as his creations. At his Liverpool base, he keeps the videos that continue to inspire him. At the top of the heap are 20 by the great surrealist Luis Bunuel. "He's the man. I don't think he ever made a bad film, and most directors do. I like his Mexican films best, in particular The Exterminating Angel, which is his first satire of the bourgeoisie. But Bunuel was really a bourgeois himself, for all that he was an anarchist; he was unfaithful to his wife, he was a wine connoisseur and a gourmand. He was just like Fernando Rey, who always plays the character in his films that is satirised the most."

Cox has recently made a documentary on another of his heroes, Kurosawa. "He was cantankerous, exigent, a difficult person. I'm very impressed by his last film, Madadayo, which is critical of Japanese society and of his own status within it - as an old man revered by a bunch of fools - very like King Lear, and therefore Ran [Kurosawa's film of Lear]. It's about the fallibility of old age, and of the false nature of the great man, and Kurosawa was that great man."

How direct an influence do these cherished films have? "You just steal from them. We stole the structure of Kiss Me Deadly for Repo Man. Before that it was just an anecdotal tale of LA punks and a car repossession firm." Straight to Hell was a tribute to another film in his collection, Django Kill. "After the success of Django, there were all kinds of spin-offs, and this is a particularly obscure, violent and perverse one which you would only know about if you were a spaghetti western fanatic. I have two versions of it."

Cox also has the original Django, another obscurity called Tepepa, which features Orson Welles as a Mexican general, and three versions of Big Silence, a slice of Italian nastiness by Sergio Corbucci, director of the original Django. "It's the only film I know where the bad guys win. Films like this killed the American westerns - Peckinpah politicised the genre, and spaghetti westerns turned it inside out. They were dances of death."

Moviedrome detritus also fills the shelf space: Tarkovsky's Solaris, Godard's Alphaville, Mike Hodges' Get Carter, along with the work of German pioneers Fassbinder and Herzog - although Cox's admiration really lies with Herzog's old leading man Klaus Kinski, demonised by his former friend in a documentary. "As a director, you're complicit in what happens to your cast, yet he makes out that it was Kinski who was impossible and not him. What he doesn't appreciate is how loyal Kinski was to him. Many actors betray their talent for money, and Kinski never did that."

If the films in Cox's collection have anything in common, it is that they all possess a certain defiance, and you get the impression that he is unforgiving on those who fall short of this. One of his favourite films is Lindsay Anderson's O Lucky Man. "Anderson came from a patrician background, yet he was a standard-bearer for breaking down its conventions. But I lost respect for him after he made a TV film called The Old Crowd. The critics hated it, and up until then he had been their golden boy. He lost his confidence, went on to make absolute rubbish and just became a wimp. These rich kids can't take a licking." Has Cox ever had a licking? "Oh, now and then."

Cox also keeps a selection of little-known Russian and Mexican favourites close at hand, and King Kong and Citizen Kane, but few modern Hollywood movies. He can recognise a fellow dissident spirit, however. "I admire Paul Verhoeven. He's making these giant special effects films, but he's managed to maintain his own sense of perversity. Starship Troopers has teenage heroes who are Nazis - didn't the studio heads realise?

"But even he had a price to pay. He was on our Kurosawa documentary and a Dutch guy saw it and said, 'That's not Verhoeven. Those aren't his teeth.' He has to deal with studio execs and actors the whole time, and you've got to have perfect teeth to do that. The question is, is it worth it?" Cox's teeth, by the way, are all over the place.

fields.headline: Intruder tried Mbeki's bed
fields.trailText: South Africa's security services were red-faced yesterday after an intruder broke into the home of President Thabo Mbeki and spent a long weekend guzzling his good food and liquor and enjoying his beds.
fields.body:
South Africa's security services were red-faced yesterday after an intruder broke into the home of President Thabo Mbeki and spent a long weekend guzzling his good food and liquor and enjoying his beds.

The intruder - described by the local press as a tramp, but believed to be a mentally unbalanced man - reportedly broke into the Cape Town mansion on Friday but was only discovered on Tuesday by accident.

Evidence of a break-in was discovered on Monday and the unit responsible for ministerial safety was called in. They declared the house intruder-free after searching it with the help of sniffer dogs and failing to detect the man, who had hidden in an attic.

He was finally arrested on Tuesday after bumping into the presidential cook who sounded the alarm. It was discovered that he had tried out several of the beds in the mansion and, judging from the empty bottles, had a taste for KWV brandy.

Mr Mbeki was at the United Nations millennium summit in New York, and ministers who live on the presidential estate with their families were away in Pretoria or their constituencies during the parliamentary recess.

Police tried to cover up the incident, but it was leaked to the media.

The presidential home had seemed well-protected, with security fencing and entrances intensively guarded by police, but there have been a series of petty crimes, including the theft of chairs. They were stolen by a gardener who had been given security clearance despite facing murder charges.

webTitle: How Nike ads became a breeding ground for film directors

fields.headline: Sharp shooting
fields.standfirst: Sam Delaney  on how Nike ads became a breeding ground for hot new film directors
fields.trailText: Sam Delaney on how Nike ads became a breeding ground for hot new film directors
fields.body:
There is currently a clutch of Hollywood directors who share a similar reputation for big-budget, star-studded and visually extravagant movies. They also share something slightly more improbable: a background in 30-second adverts for sports shoes.

Next week sees the release of The Cell, the first feature film to be directed by prince among ad directors, Tarsem Singh. He is the latest to have joined the prestigious alumni of Nike commercials directors who have successfully transferred their skills to a feature length format.

For company, he has the likes of David Fincher, Spike Jonze and Dominic Sena and he will soon be joined by Anthony Hoffman, director of the forthcoming Val Kilmer movie, Red Planet. Can it be mere coincidence that the Nike campaign has for over a decade been breeding Hollywood directors at such an impressive rate? Perhaps. After all, a company with such a glamorous brand and big budget is likely to recruit the world's hottest ad directors - and these ad directors invariably end up dabbling in features anyway. (Alan Parker, Adrian Lyne and the brothers Scott proved this point long ago).

The advertising agency who create the ads and hire the directors would beg to differ. "We've always gone for the directors who will take our ideas and run with them, regardless of whether they're big names or not," says Wieden and Kennedy producer Henry Lu, who works on the Nike campaign. It appears that when inexperienced directors walk into Wieden and Kennedy for meetings with Nike executives, they come out again ready to shoot multi-million dollar movies for Hollywood's biggest studios. So what's their secret?

Certainly, it's an ad agency with a reputation for an absurdly creative atmosphere - complete with an in-house basketball court and games of hockey in the corridors. Tarsem is keenly aware of the advantages of working for such a company: "Nike always come to you with a more open brief," he says. "They don't give you a storyboard and tell you to make an ad in the way their executives have already decided. Instead, they seek out directors that they think will bring their own ideas along. They're not interested in giving you a present that you just have to put on film. I wouldn't say they train you to be a feature film director, it's just that they happen to look for the same sort of people that Hollywood look for.

"They want their directors to be able to work with constantly-shifting goal posts and ideas that evolve continually throughout the shoot. And because their ads very often involve superstars, they want directors who are going to be able to deal with them. These are things that aren't necessary with all ads but are necessary when you're making a feature film."

Tarsem had also spent years displaying an abundance of craft via his work for Nike. In 1994's Good Versus Evil ad, he created a visual spectacular while simultaneously conveying a compelling storyline whereby the Devil was destroyed by Eric Cantona. He is keen to play down the significance of his narrative skills, how ever. "The advertising trend, particularly with Nike, is for aggressive, explosive visuals," he says. "That's also a very popular look in Hollywood and so they will ask me to do that sort of a film. No one in Hollywood is going to look at my Nike ads and think: 'This guy would be perfect for a film that's dialogue-driven.' They're going to think I'd be good for a very visually dramatic film. In fact, if they hired me on the basis of my ads then asked me to do something where the narrative was driven by dialogue I'd be shocked."

There is more to winning the attentions of Hollywood producers than a few spectacular shots. Nike's advertising agency are particularly proud of their endeavours to tell universal tales. "For better or for worse, we've always tried to concentrate on the entertainment rather than the advertising," says Henry Lu. "And Nike are more lenient with us in that sense. If we'd taken the idea for Good vs Evil to other clients, they would have said: 'Yeah right! When do we get to see the shoes?' But Nike just loved it and let us get on with it."

Nike's size helps. You could show a Hollywood producer the greatest 30-second ad ever created but if it turned out to be promoting the virtues of, say, Winalot, they wouldn't be convinced. Hollywood studios doubtlessly feel more comfortable handing a multi-million dollar project over to someone who has already been trusted with the brand image of a company like Nike. As one London advertising executive puts it: "Having that swoosh appear on the closing frame of your commercial lends it certain credence."

Anthony Hoffman directed Nike ads over the course of seven years before making Red Planet for Warner Bros this year. He is certain of the brand's cachet. "No matter what other ads I had on my reel, the Hollywood executives always responded to Nike," he says."The guys in Hollywood are already aware that there are a lot of ad directors who can shoot the hell out of something," he says. "But they also want to know if you can tell a story. Nike ads are fairly unique in that they will allow you to do both."

In any case, films like The Cell and Dominic Sena's Gone in 60 Seconds have proved that Nike graduates are able to balance their penchant for the aesthetically lavish with a nod in the direction of storytelling. Similarly, Spike Jonze's Being John Malkovich and David Fincher's Seven were enough to affirm the ability of directors from the Nike stable to make features with an intricate, overriding plot. Tarsem says that working on a movie makes you long to make an ad - just as being back in ads makes you long for another movie. He, along with Hoffman and Fincher, will get the chance to prove their worth when their brand new Nike ads are broadcast throughout the forthcoming Olympics. "Directors love to shoot," he says. "Hollywood is all about lunches and meetings. You've got to be shooting something in between and, as it happens, once you've made a movie you come back as a better ad director."

 The Cell is released on September 15.

fields.headline: Orson Welles, James Stewart... Edward Norton?
fields.standfirst: He's won plaudits playing venomous altar boys, eager lawyers, neo-Nazis and Brad Pitt's sparring partner in Fight Club. Now he's decided to try his hand at directing. Could this be a step too far?
fields.trailText: Edward Norton's won plaudits playing venomous altar boys, eager lawyers, neo-Nazis and Brad Pitt's sparring partner in Fight Club. Now he's decided to try his hand at directing. Could this be a step too far?
fields.body:
Say hello to the brilliant young man, the great hope of modern Hollywood. And the first thing you notice is the absence; what he doesn't walk in with. Because however you define star quality - the glint of an eye, the ease of a smile - Edward Norton doesn't have it. If you're searching for a movie idol, you're in the wrong place. With his black jeans and Gap T-shirt, he looks just like what he is: an intelligent, educated American of a certain age and background.

Handshake, small talk about his jet lag. Nothing special. But take a look at that CV: it's immaculate. A breakthrough from nowhere in the 1996 thriller Primal Fear, followed by triumph after triumph after triumph. No wrong moves, just critical sweet talk every time he steps onscreen, supported by the patronage of directors as diverse as Woody Allen and Milos Forman, John Dahl and David Fincher. A list to which, two weeks after his 31st birthday, his own name can now be added with the romantic comedy Keeping the Faith, wherein he appears both behind and in front of the camera.

We should have seen it coming. Ascension always came naturally for Norton, the eldest son of a teacher and an attorney, brought up in Columbia, Maryland, a planned community designed by his architect grandfather, James Rouse. He attended Yale, majoring in history between theatre productions and Japanese classes. Even now, there's something unshakably Ivy League about him: a hesitant laugh, a pensive articulacy.

But don't think you can pin him down that quickly, the rich boy with the good life. After working in Osaka for his grandfather's Enterprise Foundation ("designed to create decent housing for low-income families"), he spent five years in New York, in dead-end jobs, appearing off-Broadway, losing out in auditions. He wasn't brilliant. Not yet. He only turned brilliant with Primal Fear. When Leonardo DiCaprio - remember him? - exited the project, he screen-tested for the pivotal role of an altar boy with a venomously split personality. Norton gently stuttered through a peach of an Appalachian accent. The gig was his; he stole the film.

Afterwards, with scripts his for the taking, he cherry-picked: an east coast fop in Allen's Everyone Says I Love You, an eager lawyer in Forman's The People Vs Larry Flynt, a Bacchanalian gambler in Dahl's Rounders, a brutal neo-Nazi in the flawed but fascinating American History X. Then came Fincher's Fight Club, in which he flaunted his bruises with corporate fascism and Swedish furniture. It was quite some performance, in quite some film. He was the new Dustin Hoffman and Robert De Niro rolled into one: the leading man du jour, a face fit for magazine covers.

And, besides it being fun, there was a substantive foundation. I mean, if you strip away the fact it's about a rabbi and a priest, what you have is three people wrestling with turning 30, which I was at the time, where certain assumptions you had about yourself just don't seem to work any more.'

It's the need for something to believe in, for something real. And if Faith and Fight Club have anything in common, it's that same hostility to the hip, the knowing, and the ironic: the desire for authenticity, whether via God or an Ikea-baiting revolution. So, is this what's pulling Edward Norton's strings?

"Yeah. And actually, in Larry Flynt as well. Hmmm. I mean, I personally have never really connected with that vision of our generation as this aimless, angst-ridden mass, that's one of the reasons I liked Fight Club - because it was about something I believe, that our generation's disease is not aimless angst, but a real despair. It's like what Radiohead are getting at on OK Computer, that feeling of being truly oppressed by modernity, and having a desperate need to reconnect with an authentic self. And, yeah, one of the things I like about Keeping the Faith is that these characters are searching for that same authenticity."

All of which, with Hollywood busy grooming him as a hybrid of Jimmy Stewart's everyman and Orson Welles's precocious genius, raises a question: namely, once you've got the world's attention, what do you do with it? What does the man who could be anything do with his time? Do a De Niro and keep hacking out the character roles? Use that actorly gravitas and follow the lead of Warren Beatty, who once called him out of the blue to offer him career advice, and flirt with political power beyond the confines of Beverly Hills? Or maybe just try to make better, more honest films?

"Well," he says, "I get a little tired of irony being the only way of looking at the world, and of deflecting our vulnerability with glib denials. I don't think that's anything like what our generation is really about. And yeah, in both Keeping the Faith and Fight Club, you've got these characters who are opening their arms and getting ready to be whacked, whether that's through loving another person, or being seduced by nihilism. And if people come to equate me with that kind of openness, then I take that as a compliment."

And what if - or when - the lustre comes off in his hands, if, after the promotional dust settles, people aren't shocked at the bold departure of Keeping the Faith as much as disappointed by it. What happens to a brilliant young man when he falls on his face? "Oh, I'm prepared for that. Sure. I mean, in the industry town where I have to work, a lot of people regard Fight Club as a failure, simply because it lost money, which to me is ridiculous. But, yeah, at some point something I'm working on won't come as close to what I wanted as the films I've done so far. It's too potentially disastrous a process for that. I mean, there are great Beatles songs, and there are lesser Beatles songs..."

He spins around, makes sure to catch my eye. "Not that I'm comparing myself to the Beatles. But yes, I'd rather take the chance and work on something which is on some level a discussion of how we're living, and where we should be going. And if that doesn't come off, which one day it won't, then fine. You know? At least I took the chance."

webTitle: The resurrection of The Silent Movie Theatre

fields.headline: The Silent Movie theatre closed after its owner was shot during a show...
fields.standfirst: ...now it's the place to be seen in LA. Austin Mutti-Mewse  on the resurrection of a shrine to a bygone era
fields.trailText: ...now it's the place to be seen in LA. Austin Mutti-Mewse on the resurrection of a shrine to a bygone era
fields.body:
Charlie Lustman recalls the first time he saw the Silent Movie Theatre lying derelict on Hollywood's Fairfax Avenue: "I walked past the place one day and I swear it was saying, 'Save me.'" That was in April 1999; six months and $1m later, the Silent Movie Theatre had reopened for business. "I knew nothing about restoring buildings and had never seen a silent film," Lustman continues. "I think that's important, because I was not saying to the kids, 'Hey, you must see this silent film, it's always been in my life.' But I'm saying, 'Give it a try, you might learn something.'"

On its first week, the audience were so advanced in years that some had even worked in the movies they were about to watch. One attendee observed: "It looked as if the youngest person in the house was about 88." But things were to change, as professionals, college students and kids started to buy tickets. A month on and the whisper was that silent movies had actually become fashionable. Johnny Depp and Angelina Jolie were seen sitting in the back row. Meg Ryan and Dennis Quaid were said to sit mesmerised by the flickering images before them. Suzanne Ault, of the entertainment bible Variety, said: "Hollywood people are always looking for something new. Right now this is it."

Lustman believes that the Silent Movie Theatre, as a permanent fixture, will entice the filmgoer long after the initial honeymoon period has worn off. "There is a yearning for purity that is self-evident in silent film. It unites people of all nations - because these films are silent, there is no dialogue. And their appeal is universal."

The Silent Movie Theatre has stood in its present position for the last 58 years. Like so many other buildings of historical interest in Los Angeles, it had been earmarked for demolition. But two years ago, a restaurateur stepped in to save the building, planning to turn it into a Mexican gourmet food store. Then Lustman appeared: "It didn't seem like a solid investment at first."

The theatre's previous owner was Lawrence Austin, a film enthusiast who had acquired the building from Dorothy Hampton. She and her husband John didn't believe people would ever want to see a silent film again when they bought it in the early 40s, but intended to keep it as shrine to a bygone era, and would screen films for their own enjoyment and that of close friends. Mark McLaughlin, a colleague of Charlie Lustman, says: "It is largely thanks to the Hamptons that a number of classic masterpieces survived. They would tour the studios to buy silent films and, because nobody wanted them, they amassed a sizeable collection."

When the theatre was boarded up in the 70s it was believed, wrongly, that the couple had gone from whence they came. "John and Dorothy hadn't gone away," remembered actress Mae Madison, a former Busby Berkeley Girl. "They hid like church mice behind the broken-down facade, hanging onto their films. I don't know how they survived."

John Hampton died in 1990 from lung cancer, apparently contracted from exposure to the chemicals he used in his pioneering attempts to restore the old negatives. To meet medical bills, the Hamptons sold their print collection for some $400,000. Lawrence Austin, a son of one of the couple's friends who sometimes paid visits to see films, approached Dorothy about opening the theatre again. The shutters came off in 1991 and, although rather haphazard, public screenings recommenced.

Then, in January 1997, the cinema's history took a dark turn: Austin was murdered in the auditorium as a Larry Semon comedy short was flickering before a small audience. A gunman walked up and shot him twice in the chest. The gunman, a 19-year-old called Christian Rodriguez, was hired by James Van Sickle, Austin's gay lover, who worked as a projectionist. Van Sickle, heavily in debt, was to inherit the business after Austin's death and felt he couldn't afford to wait for his boyfriend to die of natural causes. With Austin now dead, and Van Sickle and his accomplice charged with murder, the doors were padlocked shut. Further down Fairfax Avenue, Dorothy sat in a nursing home suffering from Alzheimer's disease, totally unaware of what had happened to her beloved theatre.

It was two years later that Charlie Lustman noticed the "For Sale" signs as he munched a falafel sandwich at a nearby stall. The $1m Lustman needed to restore the cinema was raised through a consortium of investors and rich friends. "I persuaded enough people so I could take the place back to its former glory."

Finding the film stock to screen was another task. Most of the major studios had either lost or destroyed cans of silent films to make way for sound, thinking that it was history and so obsolete. Former silent film stars were tracked down through the Screen Actors Guild in the hope that they might have an original print of their own. Charles Rosher was once the most famous and highly paid cameraman in the world, having worked at Universal Studios before becoming a cinematographer to the biggest silent screen actress of them all, Mary Pickford; his daughter, Joan Marsh, herself an actress working in silents throughout the 1930s and early 40s, remembered when a call came through requesting any film material. "I knew this young guy was trying to locate old movies," said Marsh, who sadly died last month. "I had some of father's in the barn outside. I should've investigated earlier, as when I opened the cans there was nothing but dust!"

Despite the odds, Lustman began to find footage and to his amazement complete and beautifully restored films, mostly belonging to private collectors. A few let him show them for nothing.

Irving Thalberg said that silent film was never truly silent because it always had someone in the orchestra pit hammering away at an organ. The organist would watch the movie and play, adjusting the score to the mood of the film.

Bob Mitchell's career waned when the talkies arrived. He, more than anyone else, is excited by Lustman's venture as, after nearly six decades as an out of work organist, he has a job again. Bob, now 94, plays with a new passion. His eyes light up as the house fills with an audience. "It's great to see young people settle down and watch the screen. Those kids with shaved heads, baggy pants and skateboards are fascinated by the films they've paid to come and see."

Bob stands in the lobby holding onto his walking stick. The walls behind him bear the portraits of the silent screen actors who were superstars when he was young: Douglas Fairbanks, Mary Pickford, Harold Lloyd, Billie Dove, Gloria Swanson, Harry Langdon and the Talmadge sisters. "I think I actually helped their careers by accompanying their movies with music. Yeah, I honestly believe that. My job was very sought after in 1922."

"The circumstance surrounding the theatre could make for a great movie", grins Lustman. "It could be silent, but no one is serious about financing a silent movie anymore. That is why it is important to keep this place alive. I love it when I look into the dark and see 50 faces six nights a week waiting in anticipation to watch a movie with Rudolph Valentino, Garbo, Chaplin, Gloria Swanson or Clara Bow."

And people still flock to the final resting-places of Hollywood's golden icons. Tom DeMille (no relation to Cecil) is the managing director of the Hollywood Cemetery. He is a tall thin man with pure white teeth and an orange suntan and looks like some thing between magician David Copperfield and Barry Manilow. He has been employed there for the past eight years, although has been a daily visitor for the last 15. "Old stars are big," he told me. "Every week we have someone come into the mausoleum where Rudolph Valentino is buried to clean the lipstick-prints off his tomb... No sooner is your back turned than they are back again. The Hollywood Cemetery is one of the city's biggest tourist attractions; lots of people come out here to find the final resting-place of their heroes. Sure Lustman's movie house will be a big success. Old movie stars are big business."

The actress Anita Page, who was there the night the theatre officially re-opened, is about the last of the silent stars still living and it is she who has the last word: "If I'd known my films were going to be watched again by a whole new audience, I'd have acted a whole lot better!"

 For more information: www.silentmovietheatre.com
