I love it when I look into the dark and see 50 faces six nights a week waiting in anticipation to watch a movie with Rudolph Valentino, Garbo, Chaplin, Gloria Swanson or Clara Bow." And people still flock to the final resting-places of Hollywood's golden icons. Tom DeMille (no relation to Cecil) is the managing director of the Hollywood Cemetery. He is a tall thin man with pure white teeth and an orange suntan and looks like some thing between magician David Copperfield and Barry Manilow. He has been employed there for the past eight years, although has been a daily visitor for the last 15. "Old stars are big," he told me. "Every week we have someone come into the mausoleum where Rudolph Valentino is buried to clean the lipstick-prints off his tomb... No sooner is your back turned than they are back again. The Hollywood Cemetery is one of the city's biggest tourist attractions; lots of people come out here to find the final resting-place of their heroes. Sure Lustman's movie house will be a big success. Old movie stars are big business." The actress Anita Page, who was there the night the theatre officially re-opened, is about the last of the silent stars still living and it is she who has the last word: "If I'd known my films were going to be watched again by a whole new audience, I'd have acted a whole lot better!"  For more information: www.silentmovietheatre.com

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.trailText: Video releases
fields.body:
Tarzan

Retail (£17.99) and DVD (£22.99/£24.99) Buena Vista Cert U

****

Disney's cartoon ape-man saga is full-blooded, very colourful and wonderfully vertigo-inducing. There's not much sense of the 19th century about it, but its updating includes a neat role-reversal - here Tarzan has to teach Jane gorilla-speak. The fights and chases are dynamic and while there's none of the wit of A Bug's Life, there are a few nice jokes ("It's way past your nest-time") and spirited vocalising from the Brits in particular: Minnie Driver (a spirited Jane), Nigel Hawthorne and Brian Blessed. Disney's background depth is impressive as ever and there are only a few soggy moments. The DVD includes an hour of extras.

Double Jeopardy
Rental Paramount Cert 15 **

I got a bit tetchy about the plot holes early on, when Ashley Judd wakes up on a yacht covered in blood with her husband missing. By the time Tommy Lee Jones turns up half an hour in, they had turned into Grand Canyon-sized chasms of disbelief and when his boss tells Jones: "Stop playing mission impossible," you half-expect him to say: "No Cruise was Mission Impossible, I was The Fugitive," as he does another stone-faced chase role after parole-skipping Judd. Once you accept that this bears the same relation to real life as rivets do to avocado pears, it's quite fun. If a team of warthogs with small moustaches had flown over my patio in perfect formation during the last half-hour, I'd barely have raised an eyebrow.

webTitle: How to Read and Why by Harold Bloom

fields.headline: How to Read and Why by Harold Bloom
fields.standfirst: Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: The book that raced up the US bestseller lists while infuriating every academic who read it.
fields.body:
Let me fuse Bacon, Johnson and Emerson: find what comes near to you that can be put to the use of weighing and considering and that addresses you as though you share the one nature. Reading is a solitary pleasure that allows one to know oneself better; literature is a far truer, more constant friend than any corporeal presence. I'm talking generally here. Pity me not as "Harold No Mates".

Free your mind of the pernicious academic cant of multiculturalism, gender and sexuality that stalk the corridors of American universities; ideology, partic ularly in its shallower versions, destroys one's capacity to apprehend and appreciate irony. So I exhort you to recover the ironic, by which I mean saying one thing and meaning another. But do not recover it too quickly; I am not being ironic now. I'm merely being pompous.

Recapture the enthusiasm of reading with an Hazlittian gusto but do not read to improve others; self-improvement is challenge enough for any individual spirit. But see ye not reading as purely a selfish praxis. Just as I am a candle to illuminate your amoebic sensibilities so shall ye also be a lantern for your fellow protozoans.

Some said short stories can be read at one sitting, of course, because short stories are many and varied. Most can be divided into the Chekovian-Hemingwayesque and the Kafkan- Borgesian, though neither style necessarily tells a story.

Poetry is the crown of imaginative literature, a prophecy of visionary despair, though not a despair with which you might be familiar. All verse, be it the lyrically symbolic or the dramatic monologue, is best memorised; anyone who is not prepared to learn by heart Milton's Paradise Lost is wasting time.

Shakespeare. Ah, the bard, the bard. The apotheosis of all that is truly great in the literary canon. He is the universal that others can only imitate. Most playwrights are not worthy to be mentioned in the same sentence, though Ibsen and Wilde have their merits.

I fear for the novel. I do. There are Murdoch and Pynchon, but where are the modern writers to emulate Cervantes, Dickens and Proust? I fear the novel is dying. Read and re-read the greats again. Get thee away from thy computer. There is no time to be lost.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested...

Determinedly elitist US academic reaffirms his love for Shakespeare, Dante and Dickens while putting the boot into his peers

webTitle: Media kick-off Granada grabs stake in the Gunners

fields.headline: Media kick-off Granada grabs stake in the Gunners
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Granada Media yesterday agreed to take a 5% stake in Arsenal football club in a deal valuing the north London side at around £400m.
fields.body:
Granada Media yesterday agreed to take a 5% stake in Arsenal football club in a deal valuing the north London side at around £400m.

The agreement follows Granada's acquisition of a stake in Liverpool FC last year and means that virtually all of the top-flight clubs have now aligned themselves with media partners.

The deal will see Granada invest £47m in Arsenal, of which some £20m is in return for equity and the re mainder for a half share in a new joint venture to exploit the internet and for media rights. Granada will become media agent to Arsenal, handling advertising, sponsorship, merchandising, publishing and licensing agreements.

The media group has a £30m option over a further 4.99% of Arsenal conditional on the club gaining planning permission for a new 60,000 seat stadium.

Steve Morrison, chief executive of Granada, said the opportunities for the joint venture called AFC Broadband include merchandising, advertising and the delayed broadcast of Arsenal matches over the web. He said the march toward internet via the television would prevent the need for a dedicated Arsenal pay-TV channel.

Mr Edelman said the cash would be used to help fund the development of the new stadium at Ashburton Grove in north London. The club has long been constrained by the limited capacity of Highbury, above, and expects to put a planning application in towards the end of the year.

webTitle: Brat-Packer Andrew McCarthy makes his return

fields.headline: Ghosts of the past
fields.standfirst: The 90s weren't a good time for ex Brat-Packer Andrew McCarthy. But now he's back. Will his new supernatural drama The Sight be enough to resurrect his career?
fields.trailText: The 90s weren't a good time for ex Brat-Packer Andrew McCarthy. But now he's back. Will his new supernatural drama The Sight be enough to resurrect his career?
fields.body:
Whatever happened to Andrew McCarthy? In fact, whatever happened to most of the other members of the Brat Pack? Like Molly Ringwald, Ally Sheedy, Rob Lowe, Anthony Michael Hall and Judd Nelson, baby-faced McCarthy was one of the fastest rising stars of the 80s, and also one of the fastest to disappear.

Apart from Tom Cruise and Demi Moore, these beautiful young twentysomethings were erased from Hollywood A-lists. The million-dollar kids were no more, and McCarthy was no exception. But the former teen star is now making a conscious effort to relaunch his career, playing the lead role in The Sight, a multi-million-pound joint production between Sky and Fox Studios. The pilot, which also stars Amanda Redman and 60s icon Honor Blackman, was filmed entirely on location in London earlier this year and will air exclusively on Sky One on Sunday.

A mystery drama with a supernatural element, the story centres on Michael Lewis (McCarthy), a brilliant young American architect with a difference. A man who seems to have it all, but who's troubled by strange dreams and alarming visions. Not only can he see into the soul of an old building, he also has the ability to see and communicate with a number of ghosts lurking in the limbo between life and death.

In the light of the huge success of the film The Sixth Sense, it seems a good idea to create a TV programme that features a character with the ability to see and commune with the dead. However, writer/director Paul Anderson (Shopping; Event Horizon) is keen to point out that he came up with the idea way back in 1994, before The Sixth Sense had been dreamt up. Perhaps influenced by The X-Files, he's created a piece of TV with a similarly striking visual impact: "I really wanted to get away from the rather hackneyed idea of just another detective story, so I decided to create a central character who solves the mystery but isn't a professional policeman. I decided to make him an architect, partly because it's different, but also because the murders of the children take place in specific places which are an integral part of the mystery."

Anderson came up with the idea of Andrew McCarthy early on in the project: "I'm very instinctual when it comes to casting, and as soon as he walked through the door to meet me in Los Angeles, I knew he was the right person. He was literally the first person I saw for the role, and I knew there and then that he'd be perfect. What's great about Andrew is that as he's moved away from the Brat Pack image, he's got this slightly haunted look about him, so you can believe he can see these ghosts. He has that great combination of the depth required to play the scary stuff, mixed with a light comic touch. It was important to me to find somebody who had that range."

Executive Producer Jeremy Bolt was also thrilled when they managed to sign up the former pin-up: "To us he's a kind of icon. The boy that we all loved watching in those movies has now become a man and he carries a lot of history in his eyes. It was important to us to cast someone who could be convincing as an architect and someone who the audience would accept as intellectual - there's an intelligence about Andrew. We were after someone who was handsome and strong without being macho; someone who could look tormented; who you'd believe had these demons, but who also had a sense of humour and lightness. We basically wanted an actor who could play light and dark and who also had name value."

McCarthy himself is too modest to wallow in this sort of praise, but he does admit to ditching the "pejorative" Brat Pack label. It's something he's always tried to ignore. "Only in hindsight was I aware that it was a big deal," he explains. "I don't think I've seen any of those people since we finished St Elmo's Fire. And I've never met Anthony Michael Hall."

McCarthy was the Mr Nice of the 80s, the sensible member of the Brat Pack. The characters he played seemed a touch deeper than those played by Lowe, Estevez and Nelson. Films like 1983's Class and John Hughes' Pretty In Pink (with McCarthy as a rich boy courting Molly Ringwald) rewarded him with a million-dollar lifestyle. He had follow-up roles in Less Than Zero and Weekend At Bernie's, but by this time the Brat Pack craze was dying down as grown-ups returned to the cinema.

The 38-year-old recently returned to the stage with a role in an off-Broadway play. Now he's waiting for reactions to the pilot for The Sight, as is Anderson, who has pledged to stay involved if a series is commissioned. Anderson has already tried to emulate Hollywood blockbusters (his attempt to cash in on the Terminator series with his futuristic thriller Soldier failed to achieve similar success), but whether Architect Michael Lewis can become as popular as Agent Fox Mulder remains to be seen.

 The Sight, 9pm, Sunday, Sky One

webTitle: An idiot's guide to diamond geezers

fields.headline: An idiot's guide to diamond geezers
fields.trailText: Snatch, the second movie from Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels director Guy Ritchie, is straight in at number one in the pop culture charts and still no one seems concerned with whether it's any good.
fields.body:
Snatch, the second movie from Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels director Guy Ritchie, is straight in at number one in the pop culture charts and still no one seems concerned with whether it's any good. Instead we've been given a steady drip of the stuff that really matters. We know, for example, that on a photo shoot Ritchie and producer Matthew Vaughn got locked in a high-stakes poker game from which they couldn't be distracted. That Ritchie plucked some of the cast off the street (Andy the doorman from Bow, Addy the east end wheeler dealer); that Brad Pitt didn't use a stand-in for his bare-knuckle boxing scenes and that between takes the cast would play chess, gamble, and generally muck about at full "Oi! On me 'ead" volume, in their own brand of rhyming slang.

We know that Ritchie used many of the same actors and crew as he did on Lock, Stock and that, when the big Hollywood finger comes out of the sky, those boys are going with him. Somehow the issue with Snatch is not whether Ritchie has pulled off another artful dodgy movie but whether he's still the geezer, the captain of macho mateyness, the self-styled king of camaraderie. You don't even need to have seen the film to know that it has achieved what it set out to, namely to create a bloke bonding session that makes Arsenal supporters look like a bunch of noncommittal ponces.

What Ritchie and Vaughn have spotted is not (as their imitators imagined) a gap in the market for homegrown gangster movies, but a chance to exploit something at which the British male is still perceived to be a world leader - old fashioned camaraderie. Ritchie's milieu is a post-Krays fantasy, populated with Crombie-wearing diamond geezers who may be murderers, but they'd never let you down. It's about friends, male friends, the kind that Chris Evans and Gazza and Danny Baker longed to be.

This is why Brad Pitt, who seems to be more than usually afflicted with the "acting is a poof's job" complex, asked to be in on whatever Ritchie did after Lock Stock: because it was a guaranteed mate-fest about mates, for mates and just being there, having a laugh over the pints and pickled eggs, and would do more for his cred than $10m. Pitt has been quoted saying that the cast blew him away: "I was really taken with the camaraderie these guys have together." No mention of the genius of the director, the brilliance of the script, just bloody marvellous testosterone-tanked up mates.

Coincidentally, Brad has just married Jennifer Aniston, who was made by the 90s pals comedy, Friends. Ritchie, further down the line, detected that all that fluffy, girly, Häagen-Dazs-sharing stuff has run its course (especially if you are male) and his partner, Madonna, was naturally first to go with the change in mood. One minute she was Miss Tricky, with Rupert Everett at her beck and call, the next she was "the missus", up the duff, having her cheeks chucked by Vinnie Jones and being dragged around in a Ritchie armlock, claiming to like nothing more than a pint of Guinness down the Windsor Castle.

So it's a shame that Snatch turns out to be the visual equivalent of one of the entries in the Met officer's handbook to London's ethnic and religious minorities. Snatch is the intellectually challenged person's guide to a caricature of London gangland. Every line is delivered at duuuur speed, every bit of geezer dialogue laboured to allow you to memorise the jargon so when you nip round the corner for some pasta afterwards you can start calling the Irish waiter "piker", and each other "mincey faggoty balls".

A bit of illegal boxing, dog fighting, hare coursing, a lot of shooting and sawing up of bodies, endless nothing queer about us jokes, some luverly slang and there you have it: the potted excellent adventure out east for morons. Since Lock, Stock you can't move down the dogs for would-be Vinnies from Kensington. Who knows what'll happen now.

Well, for a start, guess who was in the cinema watching Snatch on Saturday night? Gwynie Paltrow and Ben Affleck (she was wearing cream cords and a jumper). Now you'd have thought that they could have arranged to see it without paying £7 and enduring the scrum. But then that would have been to miss the whole point of the exercise, which is to soak up some of the old Brit camaraderie, the old Saturday night fancy-a-Snatch-and-a-sausage scene, and to feel like a real guy and his missus.

webTitle: The best diary scene: Scary Movie

fields.headline: The best diary scene
fields.standfirst: Scary Movie
fields.trailText: Scary Movie
fields.body:
Cindy Campbell (Anna Faris) is alone in the house, with a killer in a ghost mask stalking the neighbourhood. She answers the phone - it appears to be the killer.

"I'm in the house," he whispers menacingly. "Do you know where I am?"

Cindy gasps, then sprints into the living room. The killer continues goading her, laughing maniacally.

"I could be anywhere... I'm like the wind, baby."

Cindy looks around the room in panic.

"Where am I?"

Cindy notices a pair of feet poking out from behind the sofa.

"Er, you're behind the couch."

The killer stops laughing.

"Huh? How did you know that?"

"I can see your feet."

The killer kneels up, then looks around.

Shrugging, he rises to his feet, then chases Cindy up the stairs. She throws a vase at him; he brushes it aside. Next she hurls a bicycle; he ducks out of the way. Finally, she pushes her grandmother (Babe Dolan) down the stairs, who falls in a crumpled heap on top of the killer. As both stagger to their feet, Cindy pushes a piano towards them. Missing the killer completely, it then flattens her grandmother.

"I'm in the house," he whispers menacingly. "Do you know where I am?" Cindy gasps, then sprints into the living room. The killer continues goading her, laughing maniacally. "I could be anywhere... I'm like the wind, baby." Cindy looks around the room in panic. "Where am I?" Cindy notices a pair of feet poking out from behind the sofa. "Er, you're behind the couch." The killer stops laughing.
